column2: He has, in an absolute manner, destroyed all blindness. He has drawn out the world from the mire of transmigration.
I render homage to Him, to this teacher of truth, before composing the treatise called the Abhidharmako'a.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śāstraṃ praṇetukāmaḥ svasya śāsturmāhātmyajñāpanārthaṃ guṇākhyānapūrvakaṃ tasmai namaskāramārabhate ya iti /
column2: Desiring to compose a treatise, with the intention of making known the greatness of his master, the author undertakes to render him homage and to first present his qualities.
“He” refers to the Buddha, the Blessed One.
“He has destroyed all blindness,” that is to say, by him or through him blindness with respect to all things is destroyed.
“Blindness” is ignorance, for ignorance hinders the seeing of things as they truly are.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tacca bhagavato buddhasya pratipakṣalābhenātyantaṃ sarvathā sarvatra jñeye punaranutpattidharmatvāddhatam / ato 'sau sarvathāsarvahatāndhakāraḥ /
column2: By this, the Buddha, the Blessed One is sufficiently designated, for he alone, through the possession of the antidote to ignorance, has definitely destroyed all ignorance with respect to all knowable things, so that it cannot rearise.

But the Pratyekabuddhas and the Śrāvakas have also destroyed all blindness, for they are freed from all ignorance defiled by the. But they do not know the qualities proper to the Buddha, objects very distant in space or time, nor the infinite complex of things;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kliṣṭasaṃmohātyantavigamāt / na tu sarvathā / tatha hyeṣāṃ buddhadharmeṣvativiprakṛṣṭadeśakāleṣu artheṣu cānantaprabhedeṣu bhavatyevākliṣṭamajñānam /
column2: therefore, they have not destroyed blindness in an absolute manner, for the ignorance freed from the defilements is active in them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ityātmahitapratipattisaṃpadā saṃstutya punastameva bhagavantaṃ parahitapratipattisaṃpadā saṃstauti saṃsārapaṅkājjagadujjahāreti /
column2: Having thus praised the Blessed One from the point of view of qualities useful to himself, the author praises him from the point of view of qualities useful to others: “He has drawn-out the world from the mire of transmigration.”
Transmigration is a mire, because the world is bound up in it, and because it is difficult to traverse.

The Blessed One, having pity on the world which finds itself drowned without recourse in this mire, has pulled it out, as much as possible, by extending to each one the hands of the teaching of the Good Law.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: iti ya evamātmaparahitapratipattisaṃpadā yuktastasmai namaskṛtyeti śirasā praṇipatya /
column2: “I render homage,” by prostrating myself even to my head “to this teacher of truth:” teacher of truth,” because he teaches in conformity with that which is, without error. By thus qualifying the Blessed One.
The author indicates the manner in which the Blessed Oxe is useful to others.
It is by the true teaching that the Blessed One, the teacher, has pulled the world our of the mire of transmigration, not by his supernatural powers, nor by the granting of favors.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmai namaskṛtya kiṃ kariṣyāmī tyāha śāstraṃ pravakṣyāmi /
column2: After having rendered homage to this teacher of truth, what will the author do? “I shall compose a treatise.”
A treatise is that which instructs disciples.
Which treatise? The Abhidharmakośa.
What is Abhidharma?
Abhidharma is pure prajñā with its following.
Prajñā which will be defined below is the discernment of the dharmas.
Pure prajñā is undefiled prajñā.
The “following” of prajñā is its escort, namely the five pure skandhas which coexists with prajña.
Such is the absolute meaning of Abhidharma.

It is also prajñā, and the Treatise which brings about the obtaining of pure prajñā. In common usage, the word Abhidharma also designates all prajñā which brings about the obtaining of Abhidharma in the absolute sense.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāpi ca śrutacintābhāvanāmayī sāsravā prajñā upapattipratilambhikā ca sānucarā /
column2: Whether the word "defiled prajñā" is innate or natural, or the result of effort, hearing, reflection, or absorption, it is called Abhidharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yacca śāstramasyāḥ prāptyarthamanāsravāyāḥ prajñāyāḥ tadapi tatsaṃbhārabhāvādabhidharma ityucyate /
column2: The Treatise is also called Abhidharma because it leads to the attainment of pure prajñā.
Dharma is that which has self-characteristics.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadayaṃ paramārthadharmaṃ vā nirvāṇaṃ dharmalakṣaṇaṃ vā pratyabhimukho dharma ityabhidharmaḥ / ukto 'bhidharmaḥ / idaṃ tu śāstraṃ kathamabhidharmakośam / tasyārthato 'smin samanupraveśāt sa cāśrayo syetyabhidharmakośam  // sa hi śāstrasaṃjñako 'bhidharma etasminnarthato yathāpradhānamantarbhūta ityetacchāstraṃ tasya kośasthānīyaṃ bhavati / athavā so 'bhidharma etasyāśrayabhūtaḥ śāstrasya / tato hyetannirākṛṣṭam /
column2: Abhidharma envisions the dharma that is the object of supreme knowledge, or Nirvāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ataḥ sa evāsyābhidharmaḥ kośa ityetacchāstramabhidharvarmakośam / kimarthaṃ punarabhidharmopadeśaḥ kena cāyaṃ prathamata upadiṣṭo yaṭa ācāryo 'bhidharmakośaṃ vaktumādriyata iti //
column2: The Abhidharmakośa is named so because it incorporates the Abhidharma's meaning and serves as its foundation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āha// dharmāṇāṃ pravicayamantareṇa nāsti kleśānāṃ yata upaśāntaye 'bhyupāyaḥ / kleśaiśca bhramati bhavārṇave 'tra lokastaddhetorata uditaḥ kilaiṣa śāstrā //
column2: Apart from the discernment of the dharmas, there is no means to extinguish the defilments, and it is by reason of the defilements that the world wanders in the ocean of existence. So it is with a view to this discernment that the Abhidharma has been, they say, spoken.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yato na vinā dharmapravicayenāsti kleśopaśamābhyupāyaḥ / kleśāśca lokaṃ bhramayanti saṃsāramahārṇeve 'sminan / atastaddhetostasya dharmapravicayasyārthe śāstrā kila buddhenābhidharma uktaḥ /
column2: Apart from the discernment of dharmas, there does not exist any means for the extinguishing of the defilements, and these are the defilements which cause the world to wander in the great ocean of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi vinā 'bhidharmopadeśena śiṣyaḥ śakto dharmān pravicetumiti /
column2: For, without the teaching of the Abhidharma, a disciple would be incapable of discerning the dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tu prakīrṇa ukto bhagavatā bhadantakātyāyanīputra-prabhṛtibhiḥ piṇḍīkṛtya sthapitobhadanta dharmatrāto dānavargīyakaraṇavadityāhurvaibhāṣikāḥ
column2: However, the Vaibhasikas explain, the Blessed One spoke the Abhidharma in fragments. And in the same way that the Sthavira Dharmatrāta made a collection of the Udāṇas scattered throughout the Scriptures, the Udānavarga, in this same way the Āryan Katyāyāniputra and the other Saints established the Ābhidharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katame punaste dharmā yeṣāṃ pravicayārthamabhidharmopadeśa ityāha
column2: What are the dharmas of which the Abhidharma teaches the discerning?
The dharmas are impure, “in a relationship with the defilements,” or pure, “with no relationship to the defilements.”
‘This is the complete teachings of all the dharmas.
What are the impure dharmas?
Conditioned dharmas, with the exception of the Path, are impure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mārgasatyaṃ varjayitvā 'nye saṃskṛtā dharmāḥ sāsravāḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: With the exception of the Path, all conditioned dharmas are.
They are impure because the defilements adhere to them. Without doubt certain defilements, for example false views, can have the Path or the unconditioned dharmas, for their object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmaṃ nirodhamārgasatyālambanā api āsravā upajāyante na tinuśerate tatreti na tayoḥ sāsravatvaprasañgaḥ /
column2: This does not make the Path or these dharmas impure, or in a relationship with the defilements, because the defilements do not adhere to them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā 'tra nānuśerate tat paścādanuśayanirdeśa eva jñāpayiṣyāmaḥ /
column2: This point will be explained later in the Fifth Chapter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktāḥ sāsravāḥ / anasravāḥ katame / anāsravā mārgasatyaṃ trividhaṃ cāpyasaṃskṛtam / katamattri vidham / ākāśaṃ dvau nirodhau ca
column2: The undefiled truth of the Path and the three unconditioned things are pure.
The two extinctions are pratisaṁkhyānirodha, extinction due to knowledge, and apratisaṁkhyānirodha, extinction not due to knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ityetadākāśādi trividhamasaṃskṛtaṃ mārgasatyaṃ cānāsravā dharmāḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam / nahi teṣvāsravā anuśerata iti / yadetat trividhamasaṃskṛtamuddiṣṭam
column2: The three unconditioned things and the truth of the Path are pure dharmas because the defilements do not adhere to them.
Space is “that which does not hinder. ” Space has for its nature not hindering matter which, in fact, takes.
place freely in space; and also of not being hindered by matter, for space is not displaced by matter.
Pratisaṁkhyānirodha is disjunction.
disjunction from the impure dharmas īs pratisaṃkhyānirodha. Pratisaṃhkhyāna or pratiaṃhhya signifies a certain pure prajñā, the comprehension of the Truths.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhādīnāmāryasatyānāṃ pratisaṃkhyānaṃ pratisaṃkhyā prajñāviśeṣastena prāpyo nirodhaḥ /
column2: The “extinction” of which one takes possession by this prajñā is called pratásaṁkhyānirodha;
we could say pratisaṃkhya-nirodha, “the extinction obtained through pratisaṃhkhyā, but the middle word is elided, as in the expression “0xcaṟt, and ṉot “cart hitched to oxen”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punareka eva sarveṣāṃ sāsravāṇāṃ dharmāṇāṃ pratisaṃkhyānirodhaḥ / netyāha /
column2: Is there but one single pratisaṁkhyānirodha from all of the impure dharmas?
Why is this?
Each separately. Each disjunction taken separately is pratisaṁkhyānirodha.
The objects of “disjunction” are as numerous as the objects of “junction”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hi duḥkhadarśanaheyakleśanirodhasākṣātk karaṇāt sarvakleśanirodhasākṣātkriyā prasajyeta /
column2: If it were otherwise, if pratitaṁkhyānirodha were single, then a person who has experienced the extinction of the defilement which is abandoned by seeing the Truth of Suffering, would have obtained at. It would be useless for him to cultivate the part of the Path which is opposed to these defilements.
This does not mean that all extinction is alike, that there is nor an extinction corresponding to another extinction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhyuktam “asabhāgonirodha” ityasya ko 'rthaḥ / nāsya kaścit sabhāgaheturasti nāsau kasyacidityayamasya vākyasyārtho na tu nāsya kaśicat sabhāgo 'stīti /
column2: This means that extinction does not have a "cause corresponding to its effect," and that it is not a "cause corresponding to its effect.
A different type of extinction, which consists of the absolute hindering of arising, is called epratisankhyānirodha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgatānāṃ dharmāṇāmutpādasyātyantaṃ vighnabhūto visaṃyogād yo 'nyo nirodhaḥ so 'pratisaṃkhyānirodhaḥ / na hyasau pratisaṃkhyayā labhyate / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: Apratisaṃkhyānirodha is an extinction which is different from "disjuṇction; " it consists of the absolute hindering of the arising of future dharmas.
It is so called because it is obtained, not by the comprehension of the Truths, but by the insufficiency of the causes of arising. odors, tastes and tangibles pass from the present into the past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathaikarūpavyāsaktacakṣurmanaso yāni rūpāṇi śabdagandharasaspraṣṭavyāni cātyayante tadālambanaiḥ pañcabhirvijñānakāyairna śakyaṃ punarutpattum na hi te satyā atītaṃ viṣayamālambayi tulmiti /
column2: It follows that the five sense consciousness, the visual consciousness, etc. , which have had for their object other visible matter, sounds, odors, tastes and tangibles, cannot arise, for the sense consciousnesses are not capable of grasping their object when the object is past.
There is thus an absolute hindering of the arising of the said consciousnesses, by reason of the insufficiency of the cause of arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catuṣkoṭikaṃ cātra bhavati / santi te dharmā yeṣāṃ pratisaṃkhyānirodha eva labhyate /
column2: Here we have a four-fold alternative: solely pratisaṁkhyānirodha of the impure dharmas, past, present, and destined to arise;
solely apratisaṁkhyānirodha of pure, conditioned dharmas, not destined to arise;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santi yeṣāmapratisaṃkhyānirodha eva / tadyathā 'nutpattidharmāṇāmanāsravasaṃskṛtānām / santi te yesāmubhayam / tadyathā sāsravāṇāmanutpasttidharmāṇām / santi yeṣāṃ nobhayam /
column2: pratisañkhyānirodha and apratisaṃkhyānirodha of impure dharmas, not destined to arise;
and neither pratisaṃkhyānirodha nor apratisaṁkhyanirodha of pure dharmas, past, present or destined to arise.
We have said that the impure dharmas are the conditioned dharmas, minus the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sāsravā” iti katame te saṃskṛtāḥ / te punaḥ saṃskṛtā dhārmā rūpādiskandhapañcakam /
column2: What are the conditioned dharmas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpaskandho vedanāskandhaḥ saṃskāraskandho vijñānaskandhaścetyete saṃskṛtā dharmāḥ /
column2: These are the aggregate of matter, the aggregate of the sensations, the aggregate of ideas, the aggregate of mental formations, and the aggregate of consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sametya saṃbhūya pratyayaiḥ kṛtāḥ iti saṃskṛtāḥ /
column2: Saṃbrṛta, conditioned, is explained etymologically as “that which has been created by causes in union and combination.”

There is ṅṉo dharma which is engendered by a single cause. Even though the expression sarskrṛ̥ta signifies “that which has been created,” it also applies to future dharmas and to present dharmas, as well as to past dharmas; in fact, a dharma does not change its nature by changing its time period.
In the same way, one calls milk iñ the udder dugdha, “that which has been drawn,” and kindling indhana, or “wood to be burned.” Conditioned things are the paths;

they are the foundations of discourse; they are “possessed of leaving; ” they are “possessed of causes.” Conditioned things are paths—that is to say, the time periods, the past, present and future—because they have for their nature. In the same way, one says that a path led somewhere, that it goes, or that it will go to the town.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta eva saṃskṛtā gatagacchadgamiṣyadbhāvādadhvānaḥ adyante 'nitayatyeti vā /
column2: Or rather conditioned things are called paths because they are devoted by impermanence.
Discourse, means words, or speech; discourse has names or words for its foundation.

Should one take literally the definition given by the stanza, and say that conditioned things are words? By “foundations of discourse” one should understand “the foundations of discourse, that is, words, together with that which the words signify.”
If we understand “foundations of discourse” to be only words, we would be at variance with the Prakaraṇapāda which says;
“The kathāvastus, the foundations of discourse, are embraced within the eighteen dhātur”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: niḥsaraṇaṃ niḥsāraḥ sarvasya saṃskṛtasya nirvāṇam / tadeṣāmastīti saniḥsārāḥ / sahetukatvāt savastukāḥ /
column2: Niḥsāra signifies “leaving” which is the Nirvāṇa of all conditioned things. As one should depart from conditioned things, one qualifies them as “endowed with leaving.”
Conditioned things are dependent on causes; they are thus.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ityete saṃskṛtadharmauaryāyāḥ / ta eva puyaḥ saṃskṛtā dharamāḥ /
column2: Such are the diverse synonyms of “conditioned things.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye sāsravā upādānaskandhāste ataḥ kiṃ diddhaṃ /
column2: When they are impure, they are upādānaskandhas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya upādānaskandhāḥ skandhā api te syuḥ eva nopādānaskandhāḥ /
column2: Impure conditioned things constitute the five wpādānaskandhas. Everything that is upādānaskandha is shandha;
pure conditioned things are included within the skandhas, but are not included within the upādānaskandhas.
The upādānas are defilements.
The upādānaskandhas are so called because they proceed from the defilements, as one says “grass fire” or “straw fire;
” or rather because they are governed by the defilements, as one says “the king’s man;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upādānāni vā tebhyaḥ saṃbhavantīti upādānaskandhāḥ puṣpaphalavṛkṣavat /
column2: ” or rather because they give rise to the defilements, as one says “flower-bearing tree” or “frnit-bearing tree.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta eva sāsravā dharmā ucyante / saraṇā api /
column2: They are called “of battle.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: raṇsā hi kleśāḥ / ātmapāravyāvādhanāt / stadanuśayitatvāt saraṇāḥ / sāsravavat /
column2: The defilements are of battle because they injure oneself and others. Impure conditioned things are qualified “of battle,” “in a relationship with battle,” because the defilements of battle adhere to.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaḥ duḥkhaṃ samudayo loko dṛṣṭisthānaṃ bhavaśca te  //
column2: They are also suffering, arising, the world, the locus of false opinions, existence.
Suffering, because they are odious to the Saints.
Arising, because suffering arises from them.
World, because they are in the process of decomposition.
Locus of opinions, because the five opinions abide in them and adhere to them.
Existence, because it exists.
We have seen that there are five skandhas. Let us first study rāpaskandha.
Rūpa, or matter, is the five sense organs, five objects, and avijñapti.
The five organs are the organs of sight, hearing, smell, taste and touch.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcārthāsteṣāmevacakṣurādīnāmindriyāṇāṃ yathāsvaṃ ye pañca viṣayāḥ rūpaśabdagandharasaspraṣṭavyākhyāḥ /
column2: The five objects of the five organs are visible matter, sounds, odors, tastes and tangibles.
And avġ̥ñapti;
such is rūpaskandha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra ya ete pañca rūpādayo 'rthā uktāḥ /
column2: The points of support of the consciousnesses of these things, namely the subtle material clements, aṟe the five.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadvijñānāśrayā rūpaprasādāścakṣurādayaḥ  // rūpaśabdagandharasaspraṣṭavyavijñānānāmāśrayabhūtā ye pañca rūpātmakāḥ prasādāste yathākramaṃ cakṣuḥśrotraghrāṇajihvākāyā veditavyāḥ /
column2: The five which are the point of support of the consciousnesses of visible matter, sounds, odor, taste and tangibles, and which consist of the suprasensible subtle material elements, are, in this order, the organs of sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathoktaṃ bhagavatā “cakṣurbhikṣo ādhyātmikamāyatanaṃ catvāri mahābhūtānyupādāya” rūpa prasāda iti vistaraḥ / yānyetāni cakṣurādīnyuktani tadvijñānāśrayā rūpaprasādāścakṣurādayaḥ /
column2: The Blessed One said in fact, “The eye, Oh Bhikṣus, an internal āyatana, a subtle matter derived from the primary elements.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣurvijñānādyāśrayā ityarthaḥ / evaṃ kṛtvā prakaraṇagraṇtho 'pyanuvṛtto bhavati / “cakṣuḥ katamat /
column2: Or rather, the points of support of the visual consciousness, or eye consciousness, etc. This interpretation is in conformity with the Prakaraṇa which says: “What is the organ of sight?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣurvijñānāśrayo rūpaprasāda” iti vistaraḥ / nirddiṣṭāni pañcendriyāṇi /
column2: It is the subtle matter which is the support of the consciousness of sight.”
Let us now examine the five objects beginning with visible matter, rūpāyatana.
Visible matter is twofold.
Visible matter is color and shape.
Color is fourfold: blue, red, yellow, white;
other colors proceed from out of these four colors.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samsthānamaṣṭavidhaṃ dīrghadi visātāntam / tadeva rūpāyatanaṃ punarucyate /
column2: Shapeis eightfold: long, short, square, round, high, low, even, uneven.
Or twentyfold.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā nīlaṃ pītaṃ lohitamavadātaṃ dīrghaṃ hrasvaṃ vṛttaṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ unnatamavanataṃ sātaṃ visātaṃ abhraṃ dhūmo rajo mahikā cchāyā ātapaḥ ālokaḥ andhakāramiti /
column2: Or there are some twenty types: the four primary colors, the eight shapes, and eight more colors: cloud, smoke, dust, mist, shade, hot light, light, darkness.
Some make a color of the firmament which appears like a wall of lapis-lazuli; this would give us the number twenty-one.
Even signifies of even shape; uneven is the opposite;
mist is the vapor which rises from the ground and from water;
hot light is the light of the sun;
light is the light of the moon, the stars, fire, grasses and gems;
shade-arisen from an obstacle to light-is where forms still remain visible;
darkness is the opposite.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣaṃ sugamatvānna vipañcitam / asti rūpāyatanaṃ varṇato vidyate na saṃsthānataḥ
column2: The other terms do not call for any explanation.
Visible matter can be color without being shape: blue, red, yellow, white, shade, hot light, light, darkness.
There can be shapes without there being color: that part of the long, of the short, etc. , which constitutes bodily action.
There can be color and shape at one and the same time: all the other categories of visible matter.
Some other Masters maintain that only hot light and light are exclusively color;

for blue, red, etc. , present themselves to the sight under the aspect of long, short, etc. But, say the Sautrāntikas, how could a sigk thing be twofold, For, in the system of the Vaibhāṣikas, color and shape are distinct things, Zravya, iv.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ punarekaṃ dravyamubhayathā vidyate / astyubhayasya tatra prajñānāt /
column2: Because color and shape are perceived in a single substance.
The root vÉd has here the sense of “to know,” and not the sense of “to exist.”
But, reply the Sautrāṇntikas, you should admit that bodily action is at onṉe and the same time color and shape.
Sound is eightfold.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upāttānupāttamahābhūtahetukaḥ sattvāsattvākhyaśceti caturvidhaḥ / punarmanojñāmanojñabhedādaṣṭavidho bhavati / tatropāttamahābhūtahetuko yathā hastavākchabdaḥ / anupāttamahābhutahetuko yathā vāyuvanaspatinadīśabdaḥ / sattvākhyo vāgvijñaptiṣabdaḥ / asattvākhyo 'nyaḥ upāttānupāttamahābhūtahetuko 'pyasti śabda ityapare / tadyathā hastamṛdaṅgasaṃyogaja iti / sa tu yathaikau varṇaparamāṇurna bhūtacatuṣkadvayamupādāyeṣyate tathā naivaiṣṭavya iti / uktaḥ śabdaḥ //
column2: It is fourfold: having for its cause present primary elements forming part of the organs, having for its cause other primary elements, belonging to living beings, and not belonging to living beings. Each of these four categories is agreeable or disagreeable.
Sweet, sour, salty, pungent, bitter, and astringent.
For good odors and bad odors are either excessive or non-excessive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sugandhadurgandhayoḥ samaviṣamagandhatvāt / trividhastu śāstre / “sugandho durgandhaḥ samagandha” iti /
column2: But, according to the Prakaraṇa, odor is threefold: good, bad, and equal or indifferent.
The tangible is of eleven types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: spraṣṭavyamekādaśadravyasvabhāvam / catvāri mahābhūtāni ślakṣṇatvaṃ karkaśatvaṃ gurutvaṃ laghutvaṃ śītaṃ jighatsā pipāsā ceti / tatra bhūtāni paścādvakṣyāmḥ /
column2: Eleven things are tangible things: the four primary elements, softness, hardness, weight, lightness, cold, hunger, and thirst.
“Softness” is smoothness; “hardness” is roughness;
“weight” is that by which bodies are susceptible of being weighed;
“lightness” is the opposite;
“cold” is what produces a desire for heat;
“hunger” is what produces a desire for food; “thirst” is what produces a desire for drinking.
In fact the tangible which produces hunger and thirst is designated by the word hunger: the cause is designated by the name of the effect.
In the same way that it is said “The appearance of the Buddha is (the cause of) happiness;
the teaching of the religion is happiness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukhā saṅghasya sāmagrī samagrāṇāṃ tapaḥ sukhaṃ” // iti /

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyapi tatra vastrāṇyekaśo na tulyante sañcitāni punastulyante /
column2: It is true that the clothes of the gods of Rūpadhātu, individually, have no weight; but, brought all together, they have weight.
It is true that bothersome cold is lacking in Rūpadhātu but beneficent or pleasing cold is found there: such is the opinion of the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anugrāhakaṃ kilāsti / yadetadbahuvidhaṃ rūpamuktaṃ tatra kadācidekena dravyeṇa cakṣurvijñānamutpadyate yadā tatprakāravyavacchedo bhavati /
column2: It is possible for one visual consciousness to arise from a single thing, from a single category of visible matter: when a characteristic of this thing is separately distinguished.
In other cases, one consciousness is produced by many things: when such a distinction is lacking;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā senāvyūhamanekavarṇasaṃsthānaṃ maṇisamūhaṃ ca dūrāt paśyataḥ /

column2: The same remark is applicable to the auditory consciousness, the olfactory consciousnesses, etc. But one touch consciousness arises from only five things at most, namely the four primary elements and one another of the other tangibles, soft, hard, etc. Such is the opinion of certain masters.
But, according to another opinion, one touch consciousness can arise from eleven tangibles at one and the same time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu caivaṃ samastālambanatvāt sāmānyaviṣayāḥ pañca vijñānakāyāḥ prāpnuvanti na svalakṣaṇaviṣayāḥ / āyatanasvalakṣaṇaṃ pratyete svalakṣaṇaviṣayā iṣyante na dravyasvalakṣaṇamityadoṣaḥ / idaṃ vicāryate /
column2: According to what you say, each of the five sense consciousnesses bears on a totality, for example the visual consciousness bears on blue, red, etc. ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyajihvendriyayoryugapad viṣayaprāptau satyāṃ katarad vijñānaṃ pūrvamutpadyate /
column2: consequently the sense consciousnesses. When the organs of touch and of taste attain their object at the same time, which consciousness is the first to arise?
The one whose object is the strongest.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samaprāpte tu viṣaye jihvāvijñānaṃ pūrvamutpadyate / bhoktukāmatāvarjitatvātsasntateḥ /
column2: But if the strength of the two objects is equal, the consciousness of taste arise first, because the desire for food dominates.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktāḥ pañācendriyārthāḥ yathā ca teṣāṃ grahaṇaṃ /
column2: We have explained the objects of the five organs of sense consciousness, and how these objects are perceived.
Let us now examine the aviñapti, which is the eleventh category of rāpaskandha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vikṣiptācittakasyāpi yo 'nubaṇdhaḥ śubhāśubhaḥ / mahābhūtānyupādāya sa hyavijñaptirucyate //
column2: There is a serial continuity also in a person whose mind is distracted, or who is without mind, pure or impure, in dependence on the primary elements: this is called the avijñapti.
from the mind that provoked the zvġñapti, for example, a bad mind when the avijñapti has been provoked by a good mind.

“Also in a person:” the word “also” indicates that @vájñapti also exists in a person with a non-distracted mind, and in a person whose mind is not in the two absorptions.
“A serial continuity” is a flux.
“Pure or impure” means good or bad.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalākuśale prāptivāho 'pyastīdṛśa iti tadviśeṣaṇārthamucyate mahābhūtānyupādāyeti / hetvartha upādāyārtha iti vaibhāṣikāḥ /

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpakriyāsvabhāvāpi satī vijñaptivat paraṃ na vijñāpayatītyavijñaptiḥ / [008/09-008/09
column2: This serial continuity, while being by its nature matter and action, like v#jñapti, bodily and vocal action, nevertheless does nothing by way of informing another as vjñaptiÉ does.

What are the primary elements?
The primary elements are the elementary substanṇce “earth,” and the elementary substances ”water,” “fire” and “wind.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ityete catvāraḥ svalakṣaṇopādāyarūpadhāraṇād dhātavaścatvāri mahābhūtāny ucyante /

column2: Or it is because they assemble on a large scale in the mass of the earth, the water, the fire and the wind, where their modes of activity are manifested together (Viébhāṣā, TD 27, p. 663all).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “vāyudhātuḥ katamo laghusamudīraṇatvam” iti prakāraṇeṣu nirdiṣṭaṃ sūtre ca /

” the Prakaraṇa also says: “Lightness is a derived rēpa.”

column2: Consequently, the dḥarma which has motion for its nature is the wind element: its nature is manifested by its act of motion.

By deteriorating, by being transformed.

its place being occupied by another rūpa.

further, in order that the comparison be exact, the gvjñapéi should perish when the vijñapti perishes, as is the case for the shadow and the tree. Second explanation.

column2: Now the same does not hold for gvjñapti whose point of supportThus, from the fact that avjñapti is called rūpa because its point of support is rpa, one cannot conclude that visual consciousness should be called rāpa. Therefore, the second explanation is the right one.
The organs and objects which have been defined as rāpaskandha.

Sensation is painful impression, etc. Vedanāskandha is the threefold mode of feeling or experiencing sensation which is painful, pleasant, neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

Ideas consist of the grasping of characteristics.
The grasping of the diverse natures—perceiving that this is blue, yellow, long, short, male, female, friend, enemy, agreeable, disagreeable, etc—is samjñāskandha.

Saṁkāraskandha are the samskaras different from the other four skandhas. The samskaras are everything that is conditioned; but the name is reserved for those conditioned things which are not included in either the skandhas of rupa, vedana, or samjña, explained above, or in the skandha of vijnana explained below.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhagavatā tu sūtre ṣaṭ cetanākāyā ityuktaṃ prādhānyāt / sā hi karmasvarūpatvādabhisaṃskaraṇe pradhānā /

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evoktaṃ bhagavatā “saṃskṛtamabhisaṃskaroti / tasmāt saṃskārā upādānaskandha ity ucyata” iti
column2: Also the Blessed One said, "The upadana skandha called sankhara is so called because it conditions conditioned things," that is to say, because it creates and determines the five skandhas of future existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ ca bhagavatā “nāhamekadharmamapi anabhijñāyāparijñāya duḥkhasyāntakriyāṃ vadāmīti / evamaprahāye” tyuktam /

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ bahudhātuke 'pi dvāṣaṣṭirdhātavo deśitāḥ / teṣāṃ yathāyogaṃ saṃgraho veditavyaḥ //
column2: In this same way the sixty-two dhatus enumerated in the Bahudhazuka should be arranged within the eighteen dhatus by taking their.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya ime tatra ṣaḍ dhātavaḥ uktāḥ pṛthivīdhāturabdhātustejodhāturvāyudhāturākāśadhāturvijñānadhāturityeṣāṃ dvayorlakṣaṇamanuktam /
column2: Among the six dhātus or elements mentioned in the Sūtra, — earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, space element, and consciousness element—the last two have not been defined.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat kimākāśamevākāśadhāturveditavyaḥ sarvaṃ aca vijñānaṃ vijñānadhātuḥ/ netyāha /
column2: Is the space element the same thing as all space, the first of the unconditioned things?
Is all consciousness the consciousness element?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: chidramākāśadhātvākhyam chidramityucyamānaṃ kiṃ veditavyam / ālokatamasī kila / nahi chidramālokatamobhyāmanyad gṛhyate /
column2: Cavities are called the space element, it is, one says, light and darkness. According to the School, the void of the space element is light or darkness—that is to say, a certain type of color, of matter, for that which one perceives in a cavity is light or darkness.
Being by its nature light or darkness, the void will be day or night.

The void is called aghasāmantaka rāpa. Agha, some say, is etymologically explained as atyarthamṁ ghātāt: “because it is extremely capable of striking or of being struck.” Oneshould thus understand ggha as solid, agglomerated matter.
The void is thus a type of matter close to agha. According to another opinion, agha signifies “free from striking”.
void is agha because other matter does not strike it; it is at the same time close to other matter;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya tatsāmantakamiti / aghaṃ ca tadanyasya rūpasya tatrāpratighātātsāmantakaṃ cānyasya rūpasyetyapare /
column2: it is thus both agġha and samāntaka.
The consciousness element is an impure consciousness. Impure consciousness, that is to say, the mind which does not form part of the Path.
Why is it not called pure?
Because these six dhātus are the support of arising.
The six dhā¢us are given in the Sūtra as support, as the raison d’ere of arising, that is to say, of the “mind at conception”, and of all existence until the “mind at death”.
The pure dharmas are opposed to arising, to existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadevaṃ satyeṣāṃ catvāro dhātavaḥ spraṣṭavyadhātāvantarbhūtāḥ pañcamo rūpadhātau ṣaṣṭhaḥ saptasu vijñānadhātuṣviti /
column2: Thus the five sense consciousnesses, which are always impure, and the mental consciousness when it is impure, give us the consciousness element. Of these six dhātus, the first four are included within the tangible. The fifth is included within visible matter, and the sixth within the seven dhātus enumerated above.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye punarime aṣṭādaśa dhātava uktāsteṣāṃ kati sanidarśanāḥ katyanidarśanāḥ /
column2: Among the eighteen dhātus, how many are visible, “capable of being pointed out?
” Only rāpadhātu is visible.
One can indicate its place, here, there.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ bhavati anidarśanāḥ śeṣā iti // kati sapratighāḥ katyapratighāḥ /
column2: The other dhātus are invisible.
The ten dhātar which are exclusively material are capable of being struck.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya ete rūpaskandhasaṃgṛhītā daśa dhātava uktāste sapratighāḥ /
column2: The ten dhātus which are included within the rāpaskandha are capable of being struck.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratigho nāma pratighātaḥ sa ca trividhaḥ /
column2: Striking, or collision, is of three types: āvaraṇapratighūta, viṣayapratighāta, and ālambanapratighāta.

Avaraṇapratighāta, being struck by reason of resistance: the quality that belongs to a body of making an obstacle to the aṟising of another body in the place where it itself is found; impenetrability.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā hasto haste pratihanyate upale vā / upalo 'pi tayoḥ /
column2: When a hand strikes a hand or a rock, when a rock strikes a rock or a hand, it is counterstruck or repelled.
Viṣayapratighāta, the striking of the organ with that which is its sphere of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathoktaṃ prajñaptā“vasti cakṣurjale pratihanyate na sthale /
column2: According to the Prajñapti: “There is an eye, an.
organ of sight, which is struck by water and not by dryness, namely the eye of a fish;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti sthale na jale / prāyeṇa manuṣyāṇām / astyubhayatra /
column2: there is an eye which is struck by dryness and not by water, namely, the eyes of humans in general, with the exception of fishermen;
there is an eye which is struck by water and by dryness, namely, the eye of a crocodile, a crab, a frog, or fishermen;
there is an eye which is neither struck by water nor by dryness, namely the eyes which are not of the preceding categories (for example, the eyes of beings who perish in the womb).
There is an eye struck by night, namely the eye of a bat, an owl, etc;
there is an eye which is struck by daylight, namely the eye of humans in general, with the exception of thieves, etc. ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rātrau divā ca / śvaśṛgālaturagadvīpimārjārādīnām / nobhayatra / etānākārān sthāpayitve“tyayaṃ viśayapratighātaḥ / ālambanapratighātaścittacaittānāṃ sveṣbālamvaneṣu / kaḥ punarviṣayālambanayorviśeṣaḥ /
column2: there is an eye which is struck by the night and by daylight, namely the eye of a dog, jackal, a horse, a leopard, a cat, etc. there is an eye which is not struck by either night or daylight, namely the eyes which are not of the preceding categories.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmin yasya kāritraṃ sa tasya viṣayaḥ /
column2: Viṣaya is the place where the organ exercises its activity, seeing, hearing, etc. , āambana is what is grasped by the mind and the mental states. Thus, whereas the mind and mental states have both viṣaya and ālambana, the eye, the ear, etc. , have only v²ṣaya.
Why terrm “striking” or “evolving” the activity of the organ or the mind with respects to its viṣaya or ālambana?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaḥ punaḥ svasminviṣaye pravarttamānamālamvane vā pratihanyata ityucyate / tasmāt pareṇāpravṛtteḥ /
column2: Because the organ does not proceed, is notactive, beyond the viṣaya: thus īt is struck by the visaya (for one says in common usage that one is struck by a wall beyond which one cannot “proceed”).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nipāto vā 'tra pratighāto yā svaviṣaye pravṛttiḥ
column2: Or rather, “to strike” signifies "to encounter:” this is the process or activity of the organ with respect to its own sphere.

When we say that ten dhātus are capable of being struck, or sapratigha, `characterized by pratighāta,’ we are speaking of āvaraṇapratighāa: these bodies are mutually impenetrable, capable of collisioṉ.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye dharmā viṣayapratighātena sapratighā āvaraṇapratighātenāpi ta iti catuṣkoṭikaḥ prathamā koṭiḥ sapta cittadhātavo dharmadhātupradeśaśca yaḥ saṃprayuktaḥ /
column2: Are the dharmas which are sapratigha through “striking theFour alternatives: the seven c#tadhātus and one part of the dharmadhātu, namely the sarṁprayuktas, are sapratigha solely through "striking the sphere of action";
the five spheres, visible matter, etc. are sapratigha solely through "impenetrability";
the five organs, eye, etc. are sapratigha from the above two points of view;
one part of the dharmadhātu, namely the viprayukias, are not saprabigha through "striking the sphere of action," but are sapratigha through "striking the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye dharmā viśayapratighātena sapratighā ālambana pratighātenāpi ta iti / paścātpādakaḥ / ye tāvadālambanapratighātenāpi viṣayapratighātenāpi te /
column2: Let us now answer the second term of the question: the dharmas which are sapratigha through striking the object" are also sapratigha through "striking the sphere of action";

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syurviṣayapratighatenaiva nālambanapratighātena / pañcendriyāṇi / “yatrotpitsormanasaḥ pratighataḥ śakyate paraiḥ karttum /
column2: but there are dharmas which are sapratigha through "striking the sphere of action" without being at the same time sapratigha through "striking the object," namely the five organs.
The Bhadanta Kumāralābha says: "Sapratigha is that in which and with regard to which the consciousness can be hindered from.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhadantakumāralātaḥ / uktāḥ sapratighā apratighāśca // eṣāmaṣṭādaśadhātūnāṃ kati kuśalāḥ katyakuśalāḥ katyavyākṛtā /
column2:
Among the eighteen dhāṣus, how many are good, how many are bad, and how many are morally neutral?
avyākṛtā aṣṭau	Eight dhātus are morally neutral.
katame aṣṭau /	What are the eight?
ya ete sapratighā daśoktāḥ /	These are the ten dhā$us which are characterized as sapratśigha.
ta evārūpaśabdakāḥ //	Minus visible matter and sound.
pañcendriyāṇi gandharasaspraṣṭavyā dhātavaśca / ete 'ṣṭau kuśalākuśalabhāvenāvyākaraṇādavyākṛtāḥ /	“Minus visible matter and sound,” that is to say, eight dhātas: the five material ogans, odor, taste and the tangible, are neutral, not being defined as good or bad;
vipākaṃ pratyavyākaraṇādityapare / evamanāsrave 'pi prasaṅgaḥ // tridhā 'nye	or rather, according to another opinion, not being defined from the point of view of retribution.
anye daśa dhātavaḥ kuśalākuśalāvyākṛtāḥ /	The other dhātus can be, according to the case, good, bad, or neutral.
tatra sapta dhātavo 'lobhādisaṃprayuktā kuśalāḥ /	The seven dhātus are good when they are associated with the three good roots, bad when they are associated with bad roots, and neutral in all other cases. The dharmadhātu includes the good roots, the dharmas associated with these roots, the dharmas that issue from these roots, and pratisaṁkhyānirodha or Nirvāṇa;
lobhādisaṃprayuktā akuśalāḥ / anye avyākṛtāḥ /	the bad roots.
dharmadhāturalobhādisvabhāvasaṃprayuktasamutthaḥ pratisaṃkhyānirodhaśca kuśalaḥ / lobhādisvabhāvasaṃprayuktasamuttho 'kuśalaḥ anyo 'vyākṛtaḥ /	The dharmas associated with these roots and the dharmas that issue from these roots, and neutral dharmas, for example, space.
rūpaśabdadhātū kuśalākuśalacittasamuṭthau kuśalākuśalau kāyavāgvijñaptisaṃgṛhītau /	Rūpadhātu and śabdadhātu, the visible matter and the audible, are good or bad when they constitute a bodily or vocal action that issued from a good or bad mind.
tadanyāvyākṛtau / uktaḥ kuśalādibhāvaḥ /	They are neutral in all other cases.
eṣāmaṣṭādaśadhātūnāṃ kati kāmadhātvāptāḥ kati rūpadhātvāptāḥ /	Among the eighteen dhātus, how many exist in each sphere of existence, Kāmadhātu, Rūpadhātu, and Ārāpyadhātu?
kāmadhātvāptāḥ sarve	All exist in Kāmadhātu.
āptā aviyuktāḥ kāmadhātupratisaṃyuktā ityarthaḥ / rupe caturdaśa /	All the dhātus are associated with or bound to Kāmadhātu, not disassociated from Kāmadhātu.
rūpadhātau caturdaśa dhātavaḥ /	Fourteen exist in Rūpadhātu. There are fourteen dhāeus in Rāpadhātu.
vinā gandharasaghrāṇajihvāvijñānadhātubhiḥ //	With the exception of odor, taste, the consciousness of odor, and the consciousness of taste.
tatra hi gandharasau na staḥ / tayoḥ kavaḍīkārāhāratvāttaddvītarāgāṇāṃ ca tatropapatteḥ /	Odor and taste are lacking there, for they are morsel-food" and no one is born into Rūpadhātu who is not detached from this food.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato ghrāṇajihvāvijñāne api na staḥ / ālambanābhāvāt /
column2: Since odor and taste are lacking, the consciousness of odor and taste are lacking also.
Objection: Tangible things should be lacking also, for it is also.
Tangible food by the “mouthful.”
No, for tangible things are not exclusively food. Tangibles which are not food do exist in Rūpadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gandharasayorapyeṣa prasaṅgaḥ / nāsti vinā 'bhyavahāreṇa gandharasayoḥ paribhogaḥ /
column2: Objection: One can reason in the same way with respect to odor and taste.
The tangible has a useful function apart from food: it serves as the point of support of the organs; it serves as a support in general; and it serves as clothing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādabhyavahāravītarāgāṇāṃ gandharasau tatra niṣprayojanau na tu spraṣṭavyam / anye punarāhuḥ /
column2: Odor and taste have no function outside of eating; they are of no use to beings detached from food.
Śrīābha gives a different explanation: When a person in Kāmadhātu enters into absorption or dhyāna, he sees visible matter; he hears sounds;
his body is comforted by a certain tangible which accompanies physical well-being produced by the āhyāna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eṣāmeva trayāṇāṃ dhyānopapattau saṃbhavo na gandharasayoriti /
column2: One can conclude from this fact that, in the celestial abodes of Rūpadhātu which bear the name of dhyāna, there are visible, audible and tangible things, but not taste and odor.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi ghrāṇajihvendriyayorabhāvaprasaṅgo niṣprayojanatvāt / asti prayojanam / tābhyāṃ hi vinā'; śrayaśobhaiva na syāditi vyavahārśca /
column2: We think that, if odor and taste are lacking in Rūpadhātu, the organs of smell and taste should also be lacking, for they do not serve.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyetat prayojanamadhiṣṭhānamevāstu śobhārthaṃ vacanārthaṃ ca mā bhūdindriyam /
column2: The organs of smell and taste are useful in Rūpadhātu, for, without them, beauty and elocation would be missing. The nose, support of the subtle matter that constitutes the organ of smell, suffices for beauty; the tongue, the place of the oṟgan of taste, suffices for elocation.
The members:—nose and tongue,—which support the organ, cannot be deprived of this organ.

There is no nose or tongue where the subtle matter that constitutes the organ of smell or the organ of taste is missing, in the same way that the sexual member is always endowed with a special organ of touch which is called the sexual organ.
One can well conceive that the sexual member is lacking when the sexual organ is lacking, for, stripped of this organ, it serves no function;
but the nose and the tongue are useful independent of the organs of smell and taste.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato 'sya vinā 'pīndriyeṇa yuktaḥ saṃbhavaḥ / niḥprayojanā 'pīndriyābhinirvṛttirbhavati / yathā garbhe niyatamṛtyūnām /
column2: Thus the nose and tongue exist in Rūpadhātu, although the organs which correspoad to them are lacking. Thus there are only twelve dhātus in Rūpadhātu. Agreed!
The arising of an organ can be without usefulness: but it is never without a cause.
What is the cause of the arising of an organ, if not a certain act commanded by a desire relative to this organ?
Now whoever is without attachment to the object, odor, is also without attachment to the organ, the organ of smell.
Thus there is no reason for the organs of smell and taste to appear among beings who are reborn in Rūpadhātu, since these beings are detached from odors and tastes.
Otherwise, why is the sexual organ lacking in Rūpadhātu?
The sexual organ is a cause of ugliness.
Is it not beautiful among beings who possess the marks of the Mahāpuruṣas?
Moreover, it is not by reason of its utility that the sexual organ arises, but rather by reason of its cause.
Given its cause, it will arise, even if it is ugly.

According to the Vaibhāṣikas, toMaintain that the organs of smell and taste are lacking in Rāpadhatū is to contradict the Sūtra. The Sūtra teaches that beings of Rūpadhātu possess, complete, all the organs: they are never one-eyed, or only one-eared.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāni tatrendriyāṇi tairavikalā ahīnendriyā iti ko 'tra virodhaḥ /
column2: This text teaches that beings of Rūpadhātu possess, complete, the organs that exist in Rūpadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itarathā hi puruśendriyasyāpi syāt prasaṅgaḥ / evaṃ tuvarṇayanti /
column2: If the Vaibhāṣikas do not understand it thus, they must then attribute the sexual organ to those beings. Although odor and taste are lacking there, the organs of smell and taste exist in Rūpadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sta eva tatra ghrāṇajivhendriye na tu gandharasau /
column2: In fact, a person who is detached from odors keeps his attachment with respect to the organ of smell which is part of his person.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmabhāvamukhena hi ṣaḍāyatane tṛṣṇāsamudācāro na viṣayamukhena /
column2: Thirst enters into action with regard to these six organs of consciousness, not by reason of the object of these six organs, but by reason of the person himself. Thus the arising of the organs of smell and taste has a cause, even if one were detached from odors and tastes.

But the same does not hold for the sexual organ. Attachment relative to this organ has for its principle attachment to the tactile consciousness of sexual union. Now beings who will be reborn in Rūpadhātu are. Detached from this consciousness; thus they have not accomplished actions commanded by a desire relative to the sexual organ;
thus this organ is lacking in Rūpadhātu.
In Ārāpyādhatu, there is a mental organ, an object of the mental consciousness, and the mental consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpavītarāgāṇāṃ tatropapattirato 'tra daśa rūpasvabhāvā dhātavastadāśrrayālambanāśca pañca vijñānadhātāvo na saṃabhavanti //
column2: Beings detached from matter arise in Ārūpyādhatu, thus the ten dhãātus which are material, namely the five organs and their objects, and the five consciousnesses which have for their point of support and for their objects a material dhāu, are lacking in Ārūpyādhatu. How many dhātus are ispure?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kati sāsravāḥ katyanāsravāḥ / ya ete manodharmamanovijñānadhātava uktāḥ
column2: How many are pure?
The three dhātur which have just been named can be pure or impure.
They are pure when they form part of the Truth of the Path or of unconditioned things; in the opposite case they are impure.
The others are impure.
The other dhātus, fifteen in number, are solely impure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kati savitarkāḥ savicārāḥ katyavitarkā vicāramātrāḥ katyavitarkā avicārāḥ / savitarkavicārā hi pañca vijñānadhātavaḥ /
column2: How many dhātus ate associated with vôtarka aṇd with vicāra, free from vitarka and associated with vicāra, or free from both vi¢arka andFive consciousnesses always include viarka and vicara.
They are always associated with vitarka and with vicāra, for they are gross, being turned towards externals.
The word hi, "always," indicates restriction; they are exclusively dharmas which include vitarka and vicāra.
The last three dhātus are of three types.
These dhātus are the mental organ, the object of mental consciousness, and the mental consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra manodhāturmanovijñānadhātuḥ saṃprayuktaśca dharamadhāturanyatra vitarkavicārābhyāṃ kāmadhātau prathame ca dhyāne savitarkāḥ savicārāḥ
column2: In Káāmadhātu and in the First Dhyāna, the mamodhātu, manoviñānadhāu, and that part of the dharmadhāytu which is associated with the mind, with the exception of viarka and vicāãra themselves, are associated with vitarka and vicāra.
In the intermediary dhyāna, these same are free from viarka, but associated with vicāra.
In the higher stages up to and including the last stage, these same are free from both viarka and vicāra.
The part of the dharmadhātv which is disassociated from the mind and the vicāra of the intermediary dhyāna are free from.
As for vitarka, it is always accompanied by vicāra; it is always free from vitarka, since two simultaneous viarkas are impossible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātau prathame dhyāne vicāra eṣu triprakāreṣu nāntarbhavati / sa kathaṃ vaktavyaḥ / avicāro vitarkamātaraḥ /
column2: But the vicāra of Kāmadhātu and the First Dhyāṇa are not placed within any of the three categories: in fact, it is always associated with v/śarka, and it is never accompanied by vicāra, two simultaneous vicāras being impossible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyavicārābhāvāt vitarkasaṃprayogācca / ata evocyate “syuḥ savitarkasavicārāyāṃ bhūmau dharmāścatuḥprakārāḥ /
column2: We therefore say that, in the stages which include v#arka and vicāra , there are four categories: 1.
The dharmas associated with the mind, with the exception of vi$arka and vicāra, are accompanied by vūarka and vicāra.
Vitarka is free from viṭarka, but . accompaṅied by vÉcāra.
The dharmas disassociated from the mind are free from vitarka aṇd vicāra.
Vicāra is free from vicāra, and is accompanied by vétarka.
The other dhātus are free from the one and the other.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśa rupiṇo dhātavaḥ śeṣā nityamavitarkā avicārā asaṃprayogitvāt //
column2: The other dhātus are the ten material dhātus.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi pañca vijñānakāyāḥ savitarkāḥ savicārāḥ kathamavikalpakā ityucyante /
column2: Not being associated with the mind, they are free from both vitarka and vicāra.
They are free from vikalpa to the extent that they are free from nirūpaṇāvialpa and from anusmaraṇavikalpa.
According to the Vaibhāṣikas, vikalpa is of three types: vikalpa in and of itself or by definition, vikalpa consisting of examination, and vikalpa consisting of remembering.
The five sense consciousnesses include the first type of vkalpa but not the other two.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: netarau / tasmādavikalpakā ityucyante / yathā ekapādako 'śvo 'pādaka iti /
column2: This is why one says that they are free from vikalpa, in the same way that when a horse has only one foot, one says that it does not have any feet.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra svabhāvavikalpo vitarkaḥ / sa caitteṣu paścānnirdekṣyate /
column2: “Vikalpa by definition” is viṭarka, which we shall study in the chapter on the mental states.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itarau punaḥ kiṃsvabhāvau / yathākramaṃ tau prajñā mānasī vyagrā smṛtiḥ sarvaiva mānasī //
column2: As for the other two vikalpas: They are dispersed mental prajñā, mental memory whatever it may be.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: manovijñānasaṃprayuktā prajñā mānasītyucyate / asamāhitā vyagretyucyate / sā hyabhinirūpaṇāvikalpaḥ /
column2: Mental prajñā, that is, the discernment of the dharmas associated with the mental consciousness, but dispersed, that is to say, not concentrated, not in the state of absorption, is either vikalpa of examination or by definition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mānasyeva sarvā smṛtiḥ samāhitā cāsamāhitā cānusmaraṇavikalpaḥ /
column2: All mental memory, concentrated or not.
How many dhātus “have an object,” that is to say, are the subject of consciousness?
The seven dhātus which are mind have an object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣuḥśrotraghrāṇajihvākāyamanovijñānadhātavo manodhātuśca ete sapta cittadhātavaḥ sālambanā viṣayagrahaṇāt /
column2: Only the dhātus of visual, auditory, olfactory, taste, touch, and mental consciousness have an object, because they always grasp their spheres.
And also one part of the dharmadhātu.
That part which consists of the dharmas associated with the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣā daśa rūpiṇo dhātavo dharmadhātupradeśaścāsaṃprayuktako 'nālambanā it isiddham /
column2: The other dhātus, namely the ten material ḍhātus and the part of the dharmadhātu which is not associated with the mind, do not have an object. How many dhātus are non-appropriated?
How many are appropriated?
Nine are non-appropriated.
What are these nine?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye sapta sālambanā uktāḥ aṣṭamaṣyārdhena sārdham /
column2: The seven that have been mentioned which have an object, together with one-half of the eighth.
The eight that have been mentioned, and sound.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ime te navānupāttāḥ / sapta cittadhātavo dharmadhātuḥ śabdadhātuśca /
column2: These nine are never appropriated: the seven dhātus of mind, the dharmadhātu, and sound are never appropriated.
The other nine are of two types.
They are sometimes appropriated, sometires non-appropriated.
The five organs of seṇse consciousness, of the present time, are appropriated.
They are not appropriated in the future and in the past.

Four objects,—visible matter, odor, taste, and tangible things,—are appropriated when they are present, when they are an integral part of the organs. Every other visible matter, every other odor, every other taste, and every other tangible is not appropriated: for example, the physical matter,—color and shape—, of hair, body hair, pails and teeth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye 'nupāttāstadyathā mūlavarjeṣu keśaromanakhadanteṣu viṇmūtrakheṭasiṃghāṇakaśeṇitādiṣu bhūmyudakādiṣu ca /
column2: —with the exception of their roots, which are bound to the body or to the organ of touch; color and shape of excrement, urine, saliva, mucus, blood, etc. ;
the color and shape of eaṟth, water, fire, etc. What is the meaning of the expression “appropriated?”

That which the mind and the mental states grasp and appropriate to themselves in the quality of a support is called “approprated.” Organic matter, that is to say matter which constitutes the five organs ofConsciousness, as well as matter not separable from organic matter, is "appropriated," is "made one's own," by the mind: this results from the fact that, in the case of well-being or illness, there is a reciprocal reaction between the mind and this matter.
Matter that the Abhidharma calls "appropriated," is called in common language, saceśanā or sensitive matter.
How many dhātur are primary matter, or the great, primary elements? How many are secondary matter, matter derived from the primary elements?
The tangible is of two types.
Tangibles are the four primary elements, solidity, fluidity, heat, and motion;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhautikaṃ ślakṣṇatvādi saptavidham / bhūteṣu bhavatvāt / śeṣā rūpiṇo nava bhautikāḥ /
column2: and sevenfold secondary matter, the soft, the hard, etc. The other nine material dhātus are solely secondary matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcendriyadhātavaśca catvāro viṣayāḥ / ete nava dhātavo bhautikā eva /
column2: The other material dhātus, the five organs and the objects of the first four organs, are solely secondary matter.
As is the part of the dharmadhātu which is material.
The same for avġñapti, which forms part of the dharmadhātu.
The dhātus of mind are neither primary matter nor.
According to the Bhadanta Buddhadeva, the ten āyatanas, that is, the five organs of consciousness and their objects, are solely primary matter. An inadmissible opinion.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tacca naivaṃ bhūtānāṃ catuṣṭva khakkhaṭādilakṣaṇāvadhāraṇāt sūtre / teṣāṃ spraṣṭavyatvāt /
column2: The Sutra teaches, in a limited manner, that there are four primary elements, and it defines them in a limited manner as being solidity, fluidity, etc. Now solidity, fluidity, etc. , are tangibles and solely tangibles: solidity is not perceived by the organ of sight.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi kāṭhinyādīni cakṣurādibhirgṛhyante nāpi varṇādayaḥ kāyendriyeṇa /
column2: Furthermore, each organ attains to the secondary matter which is appropriate to it: color is not perceived by the organ of touch.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ ca sūtre “cakṣurbhikṣo ādhyātmikamāyatanaṃ catvāri mahābhūtānyupādāya rūpaprasādo arupyanidarśanaṃ saprataighaṃ evaṃ yāvat kāyaḥ
column2: Further, that the tangible is primary matter and secondary matter, and that the nine other materials āyatanas are solely secondary matter, results from the same words of the Sūtra: “Oh Bhikṣus, the eye, the internal source of consciousness, a subtle matter derived from the primary elements, material sources, invisible, capable of being.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāṇi bhikṣo bāhyamāyatanaṃ catvāri mahābhūtānyupādāyarupi sanidarśanaṃ sapratigham / śabdo bhikṣo bāhyamāyatanaṃ catvāri mahābhūtānyupādāya rupyanidarśanaṃ sapratigham /
column2: The visible matter is an external sources of consciousness, deriving from the primary elements, material, visible, capable of being struck.
The same with respect to odor and taste.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: spraṣṭavyāni bhikṣo bāhyamāyatanaṃ catvāri mahābhūtāni catvāri mahābhūtānyupādāya rūpyanidarśanaṃ sapratighami“ti /
column2: But, with respect to the tangible: “Tangibles are an external source of consciousness, the four primary elements and matter deriving from the four primary elements.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: spraṣṭrvyāyatanikadeśenaiva bhūtānāṃ saṃgrahāccheṣaṃ na bhūtānīti spaṣṭamādarśitam /
column2: One can maintain that the five organs are primary matter, for the Sūtra says: “Eveṟything that is in the eye, a ball of flesh, is solid, resistant.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi sūtre uktaṃ “yaccakṣuṣi maṃsapiṇḍe khakkhaṭaṃ kharagatami“ti tenāvinirbhadivarttino maṃsapiṇḍsyaiṣa upadeśaḥ /
column2: Here the Sūtra refers to the ball of flesh which is not separable from the organ of sight, and not to the organ itself. But, according to the Gerbhāvakrāntisūra “a petson is the six ḍhātus,” the primary element of earth, the primary element of water, the primary element of fire, the primary element of wind, the space element and the v#ñāna element. Thus, in theThe body in embryonic state is made up of primary matter, not secondary matter.
For in this first phrase, "a person is the six dhatus," the Sutra means to describe the essence of a person, and it does not pretend to give an exhaustive definition.
In fact, the Sutra then says that a person is the six points of support of the mental dharma called contact, that is to say, the six organs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca yuktaṃ cittameva caittā ityabhyupetum /
column2: Further, to take this definition literally, "a person is the six dhatus," one would infer the non-existence of the mental states, for the mental states are not included within vijnanadhatu, which is the mind. Would one maintain that the mental states are the mind, and as a consequence are included within vijnanadhatu?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “saṃjñā ca vedanā ca caitasika eṣa dharmaścittānvayāccittaniśrita';
column2: One cannot, for the Sutra says "Sensation and ideas are dharmas which are mental states, dharmas associated with the mind, having the mind for their point of support;
and the Sutra speaks of a mind possessing desire;

thus desire, which is a mental state, is not the mind. It is thus proven that our definition is correct.
kati saṃcitāḥ katyasaṃcitāḥ / saṃcitā daśa rūpiṇaḥ //	The ten material ḍhātus are agglomerations.
pañcendriyadhātavaḥ pañca viṣayāḥ saṃcitāḥ / paramāṇusaṃghātatvāt śeṣā na saṃcitā iti siddhaṃ bhavati //	The five organs of sense consciousness, and their objects, are agglomerations of atoms.
aṣṭādaśānaṃ dhātūnāṃ kaśchīnatti kaśiciādyate ko dahati ko dahyate kastulayati kastulyate /	Among the eighteen dhātus, how many cut, and how many are cut; how many burn, and how many are burned; and how many weigh, and how many are weighed?
chinatti cchidyate caiva bāhyaṃ dhātue catuṣṭayam /	Four external dhātus cat, are cut;
rūpagandharasaspraṣṭavyākhyaṃ paraśudārvādisaṃjñakam /	Visible matter, smell, taste and tangible cut, when they bear the name of axe, etc. ;
chedo nāma ka eṣa dharmaḥ /	they are cut, when they bear the name of wood, etc. What is the dharma that is called “to cut?
saṃbandhotpādinaḥ saṃghātasrotaso vibhaktotpādanam /	” To cut is to produce the sectioning of the process of an agglomeration the nature of which is to continue itself in an uninterrupted series. The axe cuts a piece of wood which is a series, and makes of it two series which exist and which develop separately.
na kāyendriyādīni cchidyante /	The organs cannot be cut off.
niravaśeṣāṅgacchede tadadvaidhīkaraṇāt / na hīndriyāṇi dvidhā bhavanti /	For example, when all of the parts of the organ of touch or the body are cut off, they are not, for all this, multiple: the members which have been cut, that is to say, separated.
chinnasyāṅgasya nirindriyatvāt / na cāpi cchindanti / maṇiprabhāvadandhatvāt / yathā cchinattī cchiyate caiva bāhyaṃ dhātucatuṣṭayam /	The organs themselves do not cut, by reason of their translucidity, like the sparkle of a jewel.
dahyate tulayatyevaṃ	The same holds for being burned and weigh as for cutting off and being cut off. Four external dhātus alone are burned.
tadeva dahyate tadeva tulayati /	They weigh, for example, when they constitute a scales.
nendriyāṇyacchatvānmaṇiprabhāvat /	Not the organs, by reason of their translucidity, like the sparkle of a jewel.
na śabda ucheditvāt /	Sound does not cut off, is not cut off, is not burned, and does not weigh, for it does not exist in a series. There is no agreement with respect to that which is burbed and weighed.
vivādo dagdhṛtulyayoḥ //	There is no agreement with respect to what burns and what is weighed.
kecidāhuḥ tadeva dhātucatuṣṭayaṃ dāhakaṃ tulyaṃ ca	According to some, the same four external dhā$ur burn and are weighed.
kecidāhustejodhātureva dagdhā gurutvameva ca tulyamiti /	According to othets, only the primary element of fire burns, when it menifests its own manner of being in the flame; only weight, which is one type of secondary matter , is weighed: lightweight things, light, etc. , where nevertheless /%pa manifests its.
kati vipākajāḥ dhātavaḥ katyaupacayikāḥ kati naihṣyandikāḥ kati dravayuktāḥ kati kṣaṇikāḥ / āha /	Among the eighteen dhātus, how many are fruition, accumulation, or outflowing? How many are conjoined with material substances? And how many are momentary?
vipākajaupacayikāḥ pañcādhyātmaṃ / adhyātmaṃ tāvat pañca dhātavaḥ cakṣurādayo vipākajāścaupacayikāśca / naiḥṣyandikā na santi / tadvyatiriktaniṣyandābhāvāt /	Five internal dhātus are of fruition and accumulation.
tatra vipākahetorjātāḥ vipākajāḥ / madhyapadalopāt gorathavat /	Vipākaṭa, fruition," or literally, "arisen from fruition" instead of "arisen from the cause of fruition", by omission of the middle word, the same way that one says "ox-cart" for "ox-drawn cart. Or else, in the expression vipākaja, "arisen from vépāka," the word vipāka designates not the fruition, but the ripened action, the action arriving at the time period when it gives forth its fruit.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phalakālaprāptaṃ vā karma vipāka ityucyate / vipacyata iti kṛtvā / tasmājjātā vipākajāḥ /
column2: That which arises from ripened action, namely the fruit of retribution, is called "arisen from vipāka.
The fruit is furthermore also called vipāka, because it is cooked.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavatu phalahetau phalopacāro yathā phale hetūpacāraḥ / “ṣaḍimāni sparśāyatanāni paurāṇaṃ karma veditavyam“iti /
column2: Or else the expression vÉpākaja, "arisen from fruition," signifies "arisen from the causes of fruition," but one should not say that the word "cause" is omitted. In fact, a cause is often designated by the.
that which is accumulated nearby through certain foods, certain actions, certain sleep, or certain absorptions. According to one opinion, chastity is also a cause of accumulation;
but in reality, chastity causes there to be no diminution; it is not a cause of accumulation.

Matter "of accumulation" protects the matter "of retribution" as a wall does, by surrounding it. Five organs or internal dhatus, with the exclusion of the mental organ, are of fruition and accumulation. They are not outflowing, for they are outflowing only when they are fruition and accumulation.
Sound is accumulation, for the voice is in a weak state when the body is emaciated. It is also outflowing.
It is not a cause of fruition. For the voice proceeds from a desire for action.
Sound is not of retributionn.
Objection.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: īhātaḥ pravṛtteḥ / yattarhi prajñaptiśāstre uktaṃ “pāruṣyavirateḥ subhāvitatvād brahmasvaratā mahāpuruṣalakṣaṇaṃ nirvartta iti /
column2: The Prajñaptifāstra says, “This mark of the Mahāpuruṣa which is called ‘the voice of Brahmā’ résults from the perfect practice of abstaining from harrmful language.” Thus sound is fruition. Etiology of sound.
First opinion. One should distinguish three moments: action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: karmabhyo hi bhūtāni bhūtebhyaḥ śabdaḥ iti /
column2: primary elements arising from this action which are of retribution; and sound, which arises from the primary eḷements.
Second opinion. Oṉe should distinguish fire moments: action; primary elements of retribution; primary elements of accumuiation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: karmabhyo hi vipākajāni mahābhūtāni tebhyaścaupacayikāni tebhyo naiḥṣyandikāni tebhyaḥ śabda iti /
column2: primary elements of outflowing; and sound. Thus sound is not retribution, because it does not immediately proceed from action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evam tarhi śāhī hikyapi vedanā karmajabhūtasaṃbhūtatvānna vipākaḥ prapnoti /
column2: Objection. To reason thus, bodily sensation, not being ptoduced immediately through action but being immediately produced through the primary elements arisen from action, will not be retribution. Reply. But sensation is not provoked by a desire to experience such.
A sensation, whereas sound is provoked by a desire to speak. If it were provoked by desire, it would not be retribution.
The eight dhātus free from resistance are of outflowing and also of fruitioṇ.
The eight dhāeus not capable of resistance, namely the seven dhātus of mind and the dharmadhātu, are outflowing and retribution;
they are outflowing when they are produced by similar causes oṛ unṉiversal causes, retribution when they are produced by retributive causes.
They are not accumulation, because the non-material dhātus have nothing in common with agglomeration.
The others are of three types.
The other dhātus, that is, the four not mentioned above,—visible matter, smell, taste, and tangibles:—are of three types: retribution, when they are not separable from organic mmatter;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te vipākajā apyaupacayikā api naiḥṣyandrikā api /
column2: accumulation and outflowing.
A single dhātu "'s real.”
The unconditioned, being permanent, is a “real thing.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tacca dharmadhātāvastyato dharmadhātureko dravyayuktaḥ / kṣaṇikāḥ paścimāstrayaḥ /
column2: The unconditioned forms part of the dharmadhātu; the dharmadhātuThe last three dhātus are momentary.
The last three dhātus are the mental organ, the object of mental consciousness, and the mental consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te prathamānāsrave duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntikalāpe kṣaṇamekamanaiḥṣyandikā bhavantyataḥ kṣaṇikā ityucyante / anyasaṃbhūtasaṃskṛto nāsti kaścidanaiḥṣyandikaḥ /
column2: In the ḍharmas of the moment called dubkhe dharmajñānakṣānti, which is the first moment in the Path of Seeing the Truths and as a consequence the first moment which is pure, these three dhāius are “not produced by a cause similar to its effect” , for, in the series which constitutes the person under consideratioṉ, a pute dharma has not yet appeared which would be a “cause similar to its effect” of duhkhe dharmajñānakṣānti. This is why these three dhātus are called momentary, because, for a moment, they do not proceed from this type of cause.
In the group under consideṟation, the mind to which the kṛāṇti is associated is anodhātu aṇd manovijñānadhātu;
the dharmas which coexist with this mind are dharmadhātu: pure discipline ; sensations, ideas, volition and other mental states; plus the prāptis.
There is a problem to be examined.
Does he who obtains possession of the organ of sight where he had previously been lacking it, also obtain possession of the visual consciousness?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo vā cakṣurvijñānadhātunā cakṣurdhātunā 'pi saḥ / āha /
column2: And does he who obtains possession of the visual consciousness where he was previously lacking it, also obtain possession of the organ of sight?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣurvijñānadhātvoḥ syāt pṛthak lābhaḥ sahāpi ca //
column2: He can obtain the organ of sight and the visual consciousness either separately or together.

A person lacking the organ of sight takes possession of it without at the same time taking possession of the visual consciousness: a being of Kāmadhātu whose organs progressively appear, for, before the organ of sight appears within him, he is already in possession of his past and future visual consciousness; and a being who dies in Ārūpyadhātu and who is reborn in the heavens of the three higher Dhyānas, where the visual consciousness is lacking although the organ of sight exists there. A person devoid of the visual consciousness takes possession of.
It without at the same time taking possession of the organ of sight.
A being born in a heaven of the three higher Dhyānas can manifest a visual consciousness of the sphere of the First Dhyāna.
He does not take possession of the organ of sight which he possesses already. And a being who falls from one of the three higher Dhyánas and who is reboṟn in a lower sphere.
A person devoid of the two takes possession of the two.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārūpyadhātucyutaḥ kāmadhātau brahmaloke copapadyamānaḥ / nobhayena / etānākārān sthāpayitvā /
column2: A being who falls from Ārūpyadhātu and who is reborn either in Kāmadhātu or in the First Dhyāṇa. We have up to now understood the term that the stanza employs, “to obtain” in the sense of pratiambha, taking possession, but one can also understand it in the sense of prāptÉ, possession.
The question is thus posed: Is one who is endowed with the visual organ also endowed with visual consciousness?

Four cases are possible: a being born in a heaven of the three higher Dhyānas necessarily possesses the visual organ, but possesses only the visual consciousness if he manifests a visual consciousness of the sphere of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyā kāmadhātāvalabdhavihīna cakṣuḥ / tṛtīyā kāmadhātau labdhāvihīnacakṣuḥ prathamadhyānopapanno dvitīyādidhyānopapannaśca paśyan / catuṛthyetānākārān sthāpayitvā /
column2: he remains in possession of the visual consciousness acquired in the course of his intermediary existence or at conception, a being in Kāmadhātu who has taken possession of the organ of sight and who has not lost it, a being born in the heaven of the First Dhyāna, a being born in a heaven of the three higher Dhyāna who manifests a visual consciousness of the sphere of the First Dhyānas: these three categories of beings are endowed with both the organ and the consciousness; all other beings. beings of Ārūpyadhātu are devoid of both the organ of sight and visual consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ cakṣurdhāturūpadhātvoścakṣurvijñānarūpadhātvośca pratilambhasamanvāgamau yathāyogamabhyūhitavyau / etasya prasaṅgasya samuccayārthaścaśabdaḥ sahāpi ca iti / katyādhyātmikā dhātavaḥ kati bāhyāḥ /
column2: The taking possession of and possession, simultaneous or not, of the organ of sight and visible matter, of the visual consciousness and visible matter, of the organ of hearing and sound, etc. , shall be defined, as fitting, in each case.
Twelve are personal What are these twelve?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: hitvā rūpādan ṣaḍ vijñānāni ṣaḍāśrayā ityete dvādaśa dhātava ādhyātmakāḥ /
column2: With the exception of visible matter, etc. Twelve dhātus are personal, the six organs and the six consciousnesses;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpādayastu ṣaḍ viṣayadhātavo bāhyāḥ / ātmanyasati kathamādhyātmikaṃ bāhyaṃ vā /
column2: six dhātus are external, the six objects of consciousness, visible matter, etc. But how can one speak of personal dhātus, or of external dhātus, since there is no āman?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ahaṅkārasanniśrayatvāccittamātmetyupacaryate / “ātmanā hi sudāntena svargaṃ prāpnoti paṇḍitaḥ“ ityuktam /
column2: The mind is the object of the idea of self, the mind is what persons falsely grasp for their self.

This mind receives, metaphorically, the name of āsan. Compare, for example, these two lines of Scripture: “The sage obtains heaven, by means of a well subdued āman,” and “It is good to subdue the mind;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “cittasya damanaṃ sādhu cittaṃ dāntaṃ sukhāvaham” iti /
column2: the subdued mind brings happiness.”
Now the organs and the consciousnesses are close to the mind to which one gives the name of āman: they are in fact the point of support of them;
then one qualifies them as “internal,” or “personal,” whereas the visible and the other objects of the consciousness are held to be “external.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evam tarhi ṣaḍ vijñānadhātava ādhyātmikā na prāpnuvanti /
column2: But can one say that the six consciousnesses are the point ofThus they are not personal. This objection is worthless.
When the consciousnesses, having perished, becomes the point of support of the mind, it is indeed these consciousnesses themselves which become the point of support;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā tadā ta eva te bhavantīti lakṣaṇaṃ nātibarttante /
column2: thus, before becoming a point of support, they are not foreign to the quality of point of support. They ate thus personal by reason of their future quality of point of support.
If it were otherwise, the mental organ would be solely past; it would be neither present nor future.
Now it is well understood that the eighteen dhātus belong to the three time periods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cānāgatapratyutpannasya vijñānasya manodhātulakṣaṇaṃ na syāt atīte 'pyadhvani manodhāturna vyavasthāpyeta /
column2: Moreover, if the present or future consciousness does not have the characteristic of vanodhātu, it is absurd to attribute this characteristic to it once it is past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi lakṣaṇasyādhvasu vyabhicāro 'stīti // kati dhātavaḥ sabhāgāḥ kati tatsabhāgāḥ / ekāntena tāvat dharmasaṃjñakaḥ /
column2: For a dharṁma does not change its characterstics in the course of time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sabhāgaḥ yo hi viṣayo yasya vijñānasya niyato yadi tatra tadvijñānamutpantaṃ bhavatyutpattidharmi vā evaṃ sa viṣayaḥ sabhāga ityucyate /
column2: Among the eighteen dhātus,how many are sabhāga, “active” or “inAn object of consciousness is qualified as sabhāga when the consciousness which constitutes its proper sphere arises or is destined to atise with respect to it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca so 'sti kaściddharmadhāturyatra nānantaṃ manovijñānamutpannamutpatsyate vā /
column2: Now there is no dharma with respect to which an unlimited mental consciousness has not arisen or is destined to arise.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā hi sarvāryapudgalānāmidaṃ cittamavaśyamutpadyate “sarvadharmā anātmāna” iti /
column2: All the Saints in fact necessarily produce the thought "All dharma are impersonal".

It is true that this thought bears neither on itself, nor on the dharmas which are coexistent with it, but this thought and the dharmas which are coexistent with it are the object of a second moment of a thought of universal impersonality.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa punaścittakṣaṇo 'nyasya cittakṣaṇasyālambanamiti dvayoḥ kṣaṇayoḥ sarvadharmā hyālambanaṃ bhavanti /
column2: All the dharmas are thus included within the object of these two moments of thought.
Therefore the dharmaadhātu, the proper object of the mental consciousness, is, in its totality, sabhāga, active as an object.
The other ḍhātus are also tatsabhāga.
The word "also" shows that they are both sabhāga and tatsabhāga.
When are they sabhāga?
When they do not do their proper work.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ bhavati yaḥ svakarmakṛt sa sabhāga iti /
column2: This implies the definition: they are sabhāga when they do their proper work.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra yena cakṣuṣā rūpāṇyapaśyat paśyati drakṣyati vā taducyate sabhāgaṃ acakṣuḥ /
