column2: The organ of sight which has seen, does now see or shall see visible matter, is termed sabhāga.
The same with respect to the other organs, by indicating for each its own object and its own operation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatsabhāgaṃ cakṣuḥ kāśmīrāṇāṃ caturvidham / yad dṛṣṭvā rūpāṇi niaruddhaṃ nirudhyate nirotsyate vā yaccānutpattidharmi / pāścāttyānāṃ punaḥ pañcavidham /
column2: According to the Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmiīr, the organ of sight is sabhāga in four cases: the organ of sight which has perished, which is now perishing, which will perish without having seen, and the organ of sight destined to arise.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadevānutpattidharmi dvidhā kṛtvā vijñānasamāyuktaṃ cāsamāyusktaṃ ca /
column2: According to the Westerners, the organ of sight not destined to arise constitutes two categories depending on whether it is accompanied by visual consciousness or not.
The same with respect to the other organs of sense consciousness.
The mental organ is sabhāga only when it is not destined to arise; in fact, when it arises, it always has an object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāṇi ca yāni cakṣuṣā 'paśāyat paśyati drakṣyati vā tāni sabhāgāni / tatsabhāgāni caturvidhāni /
column2: It is sabhāga which will be seen by the organ of sight, is sabhāga.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yānyadṛṣṭānyeva niruddhāni nirudhyante nirutsyante vā yāni cānutpattidharmīṇi /
column2: It is when it has perished, is now perishing or shall perish without having seen, or when it is not destined to arise.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yāvat spraṣṭavyāni / svendriyakāritreṇa sabhāgatatsabhāgāni veditavyāni /
column2: The same with respect to the other objects of sense consciousness by indicating for each organ the function which corresponds to it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadekasya cakṣuḥ sabhāgaṃ tatsarveṣām / evaṃ tatsabhāgamapi /
column2: The organ of sight which is sabhāga or tatsabhāga īs such for everyone, foṛ the petson to whom this organ belongs, and for other persons.
The same for the other organs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpaṃ tu yaḥ paśyati tasya sabhāgaṃ yo na paśyati tasya tatsabhāgam / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: But a certain visible thing is sabhāga for the person who sees it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti hi saṃbhavo yadrūpamekaḥ paśyati taddhavo 'pi paśyeyuryathā candranaṭmallaprekṣāsu /
column2: In fact, the visible matter that a person sees can be seen by many, for exrample, the moon, a stage performance, or a contest, whereas two peṛsons do not see by means of the same oṟgan.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: natu saṃbhavo 'sti yadekena cakṣuṣā dvau paśyetām / ato 'syāsādhāraṇatvādekasantānavaśena vyavasthānam /
column2: Consequently, since one organ of sight is not general, it is though relationship with one person that it will be qualified as sabhāga or tatsabhāga; the organ of sight is sabhāga when he sees a visible thing, even though he has not seen, does not now see, or will.

On the contrary, the visible thing is general: one would qualify it as sabhāga and ¢atsabhāga by putting oneself in the point of view of numerous persons: it is szbhāga in relation to those who see it, tatsabhāga in relation to those who do not see it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā raupamevaṃ śabdagandharasaspraṣṭavyadhātavo veditavyāḥ / bhavatu śabda evam /
column2: The same holds for sounds, smells, tastes, and the tangible things as for visible matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gandhādayastu ya ekena gṛhyante na te 'nyena prāptagṛhaṇādityasādhāraṇatvādeṣāṃ cakṣurādivadatideśo nyāyyaḥ /
column2: Granted, one would say, with respect to sound which, like visible mmattet, is perceived at a diṣtaṅce and can be perceived by many persons . But smells, tastes and tangibles are not perceived at a distance, and are perceived only when they enter into a close relationship with the otrgan: thus the smell that one person perceives is not perceived by another. Thus these objects are not general, and we should compare them to the organs with respect to the qualification of sabhāga, or tatsabhāga: when they are sabhāga to one person, they are sabhāga to everyoṉe.
We would answer: We regard these objects as general, because theyIt can be so.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti hyeṣa saṃbhavo ya eva gandhādaya ekasya ghrāṇādivijñānamutpādayeyusta evānyeṣāmapi /
column2: It can be the case that smell—the same atomic group of a smell—which produces a consciousness of smell in one person, is also perceived by another.
Now this does not hold for the organs.
Consequently smells, tastes and tangibles should be compared to visible matter and sounds.
The six consciousnesses are sabhāga or tatsabhāga depending on whether they are destined to arise, or are not destined to arise, like the mental organ.
What is the meaning of the expressions sabhāga and ¢atsabhāga?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: indriyaviṣayavijñānānāmanyonyabhajanaṃ kāritrabhajanaṃ vā bhāgaḥ / sa eṣāmastīti sabhāgaḥ /
column2: Bhāga signifies the mutual seṟvices that the-organs, their objects and their consciousnesses, render one another in their quality of point of support of the consciousness, of objects of consciousness, of consciousness supporting itself on the organ. Or else bhāga signifies possession of the activity oṛ function;

the function of the oṟgan is to see, etc. ; the function of the object is to be the subject of the consciousness , of being seen, etc. ; the function of consciousness is to be the subject of consciousness, to be “the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye punarasabhāgāste teṣā sabhāgānāṃ jātisāmānyena sabhāgatvāt tatsabhāgāḥ /
column2: That which is not sabhāga, but is nevertheless analogous to sabhāga, is called tatsabhāga, that is to say “analogous to that,” that is, “analogous to sabhāga.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kati dhātavo darśanaheyāḥ kati bhāvanāheyāḥ katyaheyāḥ / rūpiṇastāvat
column2: How many ḍhātus can be abandoned by Seeing the Truths, in other words, by the Path of Seeing or through Seeing? How many can be abandoned by Meditation or repeated consideration of the Truths, in other words, by the Path of Meditation or by Meditation? How many dhātur are not to be abandoned, or cannot be abandoned? Ten and five are abandoned through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśa bhāvanayā heyāḥ pañca ca vijñānadhātavaḥ / antyāstrayastridhā / manodhāturdharmadhāturmanovijñānadhātuśca /
column2: The ten material dhātus, organs and objects, and the five sense.
From the point of view of abandoning them, the last three dhātus include three types of ḍharmas.
Eighty-eight anuśayas, with their coexistent dharmas, are abandoned by Seeing, with the prāptis of the said anuśayas and the said coexistents, with their following of the said prāptīs.
The other impure dharmas are abandoned by Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravā aheyāḥ / nanu cānyadapi darśanaprahātavyamasti pṛthagjanatvamāpāyikaṃ ca kāyavākkarma /
column2: The good-impure and undefiled-neutral saṁskāras and the impure avrñapti with its following are also abandoned.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āryamārgavirodhitvāt na tad daṛśanaprahātavyam / eṣa hi saṃkṣepaḥ / na dṛṣṭiheyamakliṣṭaṃ na rūpaṃ nāpyaḍaḍtḥajaṃ
column2: The pure dharmas, that is, unconditioned things and the dharmas which form part of the Path, are not to be abandoned.
Objection: not only the eighty-eight anuśayas, but also some other dharmas are abandoned by Seeing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akliṣṭavyākṛtaṃ ca pṛthagjanatvam / samucchinnakuśalamūlavītarāgāṇāmapi tatsamanvāmat rūpaṃ kāyavākkarma /
column2: The quality of Pṛthagjana is a dharma which is undefiled-neutral. bad roots, and the latter are not defiled in themselves.
Therefore, they cannot be abandoned by Seeing the Truths. Thus neither are abandoned by the Seeing of the Truths.
Further, if the quality of Pṛthagjana were abandoned by Seeing, it would follow that it would exist in the first state of the Path of Seeing—which is incorrect.
Nor that which has arisen from the non-sixth.
“Sixth” signifies the mental organ.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādanyatra jātamaṣaṣṭhajaṃ pañcendriyajaṃ ca yattadapi nāsti darśnaprahātavyam //
column2: “Arisen from the non-sixth” is what has arisen from an organ different from the sixth organ, that is to say, what has arisen from the five organs, the organ of sight, etc. This then refers to the visual consciousness, etc. These are also not abandoned by Seeing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭādaśānāṃ dhātūnāṃ kati dṛṣṭiḥ kati na dṛṣṭiḥ /
column2: Among the eighteen dhātus, how many are “view,” how many are not “view?”
The organ of sight and part of the dharmadhātu are view.
How many?
Eight parts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañca satkāyadṛṣṭyādikā dṛṣṭayaḥ laukikī samyag dṛṣṭiḥ śaiṅkṣī dṛṣṭiraśaikṣī dṛṣṭirityayamaṣṭaprakāro dharmadhāturdṛṣṭi ravraśiṣṭo na dṛṣṭiḥ tatra satkāyadṛṣṭyādīnāmanuśāyanirdeśe nirddeśaḥ prāptakālo bhaviṣyati /
column2: What are these eight parts of the dharmadhātu? The five false views, of which the first is belief in a self and Worldly correct views, that is to say, prajñā associated with the mental consciousness, good but impure. And the view of the. In the manner in which visible matter is seen at night and in the daytime, on a cloudy day and on a clear day, in this same way the dharmas are seen by defiled worldly views. Five false opinions.
By non-defiled worldly view or worldly correct views. By Śaīkṣī views.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śaikṣasyanāsravā dṛṣṭiḥ ṣaikṣī aśaikṣasya akśaikṣī / sameghāmegharatrindivarūpadarśanavat kliṣṭākliṣṭalaukikīśaikṣyaśaikṣībhirdṛṣṭibhirdharmadarśanam /
column2: By noṉ-Aśaikṣī views.
Why are correct worldly views understood solely as prajñā associated with the mental consciousness?
The prajñā which arises with the five sense consciousnesses, is not "view" because it is not judgment after deliberation.
View is judgment that precedes from the consideration of an object.
Now the prajñā which arises with the five sense consciousnesses does not present this characteristic.
Thus it is not "view.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva cānyā 'pi kliṣṭā 'kliṣṭā vā prājñā na dṛṣṭiḥ /
column2: For the same reason, it happens that prajña, even though mental, defiled or non-defiled, is not "view" when it is purely intuitive.
How do you then say that it is "view?
View" is understood here as the seeing of visible matter.
It is the organ of sight which sees visible matter. A Vijñānavādin is a master who attributes sight, not to the organ of sight, but to visual consciousness.
He says: If an organ sees, then the organ of a person occupied with hearing or touch consciousness, would see. When it is sabhāga.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na vai sarvaṃ cakṣuḥ paśyati / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: We do not say that all organs of sight see.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sabhāgaṃ savijñānakaṃ yadā bhavati tadā paśyatyanyadā neti /
column2: The oṛgan of sight sees when it is sabhāga, that is to say, when it is conjoined with visual coṉsciousness. It is not the consciousness of which this organ is the point of support.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evam tarhi tadeva cakṣurāśritam vijñānaṃ paśyatītyastu /
column2: But then, that which sees is indeed the consciousness which is supported by the organ of sight. For obscured visible matter is not seen. Such is the opinion of the Vaibhāṣikas.

Now the consciousness is non-material, not capable of being repulsed. Thus, if the visual consciousness were to see, it would see even the visible matter obscured by a screen. The visual consciousness does not arise with respect to obscured visible matter;
not arising with respect to them, it does not see them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ kāraṇam / dṛśyate rūpaṃ na kilāntaritaṃ yataḥ // yasmāt kila rūpaṃ kuḍyādivyavahitaṃ na dṛśyate /
column2: But why does it not arise with respect to these visible things?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi hi vijñānaṃ paśyettassyāpratighatvāt kuḍyādiṣu pratighāto nāsti ityvāṛtamapi rūpaṃ paśyet /
column2: For us, the Vaibhāṣikas, who attribute seeing to the organ and who admit that the organ, being sapratigha or capable of being arrested, does not exercise its activity with respect to obscured visible matter, we could easily explain how the visual consciousness does not arise with respect to obscured visible matter: the consciousness, in fact, exercises its activity on the same object that its point of support does.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva hāvṛte cakṣurvijñānamutpadyata ityanutpannaṃ kathaṃ drakṣyati / kiṃ khalu notpadyate /
column2: But if you believe that the consciousness sees, how would you explain the fact that it does not arise with respect to obscured visible matter?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya tu cakṣuḥ paśyati tasya cakṣuṣaḥ saparatighatvādvyayavahite vṛttyabhāva iti vijñānasyānutpatti rāśrayeṇaika viṣayapravṛttatvāt yujyate
column2: The author takes into consideration the opinion of the Vijñānavādin and responds to the last reply of the Vaibhāsika. Do you maintain that an organ of sight sees its object by entering into a close relationship with its object, in the manner in which the organ of touch feels a tangible object? In this hypothesis I would understand that the organ of sight, being capable of being arrested, does not see obscured visible matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ nu vai cakṣuḥ prāptaviṣayaṃ kāyendriyavat yata āvṛtaṃ na paśyet / sapratighatvāt /
column2: But you maintain that the organ of sight sees at a distance: you do not then have the right to say that, being capable of being arrested, it does not see obscured visible matter.
Moreover, one sees obscured visible matter through a glass, a cloud, a crystal and water: how would you explain this fact?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sapratighatvāccakṣuṣa āvṛtasya rūpasyādarśanam / kiṃ tarhi / yatrālokasyāpratibandha āvṛte 'pi rupe tatropapadyata eva cakṣurvijñānam /
column2: I would say then that the visual consciousness sees, it arises with respect to obscured visible matter when the screen does not form an obstacle to light;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatra tu pratibandhastatra notpadyata ityanutpannatvādāvṛtaṃ nekṣyate /
column2: it does not arise in the contrary case. The Vaibhāṣikas make an appeal to Scripture.
The Sūtra says, “Having seen visible matter through the organ of sight.” Thus the organ sees, not the visual consciousness. We would reply that the Sūtra intends to say, “Having seen visible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tenāśrayeṇetyayamatrābhisandhiryathā “manasā dharmān vijñāye” tyāha / na ca mano dharmān vijānāti / atītatvāt / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: ”In fact, the same Sūtra says, “Having discerned the dharmas through the mental organ”: now this organ, being past, does not discern;

it is through the mental consciousness that one discerns; therefore, if the text says “through the mental organ,” it means “by supporting itself on the mental organ, the point of support of mental consciousness.” The same for sight and the organ of sight.
Oṇne can also admit that the Sūtra attṛibutes to the point of support, to the organ, the action which belongs to that which grasps this point of support, that is to say, to the consciousness.
It is said in the world “the benches cry out,ʼ whereas the benches are actually the persons seated on the benches. This way of speaking is common to Scripture.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca sūtra uktaṃ “cakṣurvijñeyāni rūpāṇīṣṭāni kāntāni“ti /
column2: We read that “agreeable and disagreeable visible rmatter is discerned by the organ of sight.”
Now you do not maintain that the organ of sight discerns.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ ca sūtre “cakṣurbrāhmaṇa dvāraṃ yāvadeva rūpāṇāṃ darśanāya” ityato gamyate cakṣuṣā dvāreṇa vijñānaṃ paśyatīti /
column2: You attribute discernment to the consciousness of which organ of sight is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśane tatra dvārākhyā / nahyetadyujyate / cakṣurdārśanaṃ arūpāṇāṃ darśnāyeti /
column2: This text proves that the visual consciousness sees by this gate which is the organ of sight. You would not maintain that “gate” signifies “sight,” for it would be absurd to say “The organ of sight is the sight of the sight of visible matter.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi vijñānaṃ kpaśyati ko vijānāti kaścānayorviśeṣaḥ /
column2: If the visual consciousness sees, what it is that discerns?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadeva hi rūpasya vijñānaṃ tadevāsya darśnamiti /
column2: What is the difference between the two functions of seeing and discerning which would account for a single dharma not seeing and discerning at one and the same time?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā kācit prajñā paśyatītyapyucyate prajānātītyapyevaṃ kiñcidvijñānaṃ paśyatītyapyucyāte vijānātītyapi / anye punarāhuḥ /
column2: Is it not admitted that a certain type of prajñā sees and comprehends? In this same way a certain consciousness, the visual consciousness, sees and discerns. There is here only a single function designated by two names.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “yadi cakṣuḥ paśyati kartṛbhūtasya cakṣuṣaḥ kā 'nyā dṛśikriye“ti vaktavyam / tadetadacodyam / yadi hi vijñānaṃ vijānātītīṣyate /
column2: [Certain followers of the thesis “The visual coṉsciousness sees,” namely the Vatsīputrīyas, object:] If the organ of sight sees, what is then the separately existing action of seeing that you attribute to this.
In the same way that you would have it that the consciousness discerns, without admitting any difference between the agent and the action, in that same way we hold that an organ sees.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamatrāpi / apare punarbruvate / “cakṣurvijñānaṃ darśanaṃ tasyāśrayabhāvāccakṣuḥ paśyatītyucyate /
column2: According to another opinion, it is the visual consciousness which sees;
but, as the organ of sight is the point of support of this consciousness, one says that it sees, the same way one says that the bell rings, because it is the point of support of the sound.
But, according to this principle, one should also say that the organ of sight discerns, for it is the point of support of the visual consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na prāpnoti / tadvijñānaṃ darśanamiti ruḍhaṃ loke /
column2: For in the world one agrees to give the name of “seeing” to the visual consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā hi tasminnutpanne rūpaṃ dṛṣṭamityucyate na vijñātam /
column2: in fact, when this consciousness is produced, one says “The color is seen; ” one does not say that the color is discerned.

And the Vibhāṣā confirms; : “One terms 'seen’ that which is attained by the organ of sight, that which falls within its line of vision and is perceived by the visual consciousness.” One says then. In the world that the organ of sight sees, because it is the point of support of the visual consciousness which sees;

one does not say that it discerns, because the function attributed to the visual consciousness is seeing and not discernment. On the other hand, when one says that consciousness discerns, one does not mean that it discerns to the extent that it would be the point of support of a certain discernment, as one understands that the organ of sight sees because it is the point of support of the visual consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vijñānaṃ tu sānnidhyamātreṇa rūpaṃ vijānātītyucyate / yathā sūryo divasakara iti /
column2: One means that the consciousness discerns by itself, that it is in and of itself discernment, in the same way that one says that the sun creates the day.
Opinion of the Sautrantikas.
What an empty discussion!
The Sutra teaches: “By reason of the organ of sight and of visible matter there arises the visual consciousness”: there is not there either an organ that sees, or visible matter that is seen;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra kaḥ paśyati ko vā dṛśyate / nivryāpāraṃ hīdaṃ dharmamātraṃ hetuphalamātraṃ ca /
column2: there is not there any action of seeing, nor any agent that sees;
this is only a play of cause and.
In the light of practice, one speaks, metaphorically, of this process: “The eye sees, and the consciousness discerns.” But one should not cling to these metaphors.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ hi bhagavatā “janapadaniruktiṃ nābhiniviśeta saṃjñāṃ ca lokasya nābhidhāvedi“ti /
column2: The Blessed One has said that one should not take them in the manner of popular speech, that one should not seriously grasp an expression in use in the world.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa tu kāśmīravaibhāṣikāṇāṃ siddhāntaḥ / cakṣuḥ paśyati śrotraṃ śṛṇoti ghrāṇaṃ jighrati jihvā āsvādayati kāyaḥ spṛśati mano vijānātīti /
column2: According to the system of the Vaibhāṣikas of KaśmīT, the organ of sight sees, the organ of hearing hears, the organ of smell smells, the organ of taste tastes, the organ of touch touches, and the mental organ discerns.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyadi cakṣuḥ paśyati kimekena cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi paśyatyāhosvidubhābhyām / nātra niyamaḥ /
column2: Is visible matter seen by one eye or by both eyes?
Visible matter is seen by the two eyes also, as the clarity of sight demonstrates.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhābhyāmapi cakṣurbhyāṃ paśyatītyābhidhārmikāḥ / tathā hi dvayorvivṛtayoḥ paraiśāuddhataraṃ darāśanaṃ bhavati /
column2: The Ābhidhārmikas say: “Seen also by the two eyes;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekasmiṃścīnmīlite cakṣuṣi dvitīye cārdhanimīlite dvicandrādigrahaṇaṃ bhavati / naikatarānyathībhāvāt /
column2: the two eyes being open, sight is clearer.” Furthermore, when one eye is covered and the other half closed, one perceives two moons; but not when one completely closes or half closes that which was open, or when one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cāśrayavicchedād vicchedaparasaṅgo vijñānasya deśāpratiṣṭhitatvād raupavaditi /
column2: One should not conclude that the visual consciousness is twofold from the fact that its point of support is twofold, for the consciousness is not material like not having a mass it is not situated in a place.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cakṣuḥ paśyati śrotraṃ śṛṇoti yāvanmano vijānāti kimeṣāṃ prāpto viṣaya āhosvidaprāptaḥ /
column2: We have said that the organ of sight sees, that the organs of hearing, smell, taste, and touch each perceive their objects; and that the mental organ discerns. Do these organs attain their object, do they enter into a close physical relationship with their object?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣuḥśrotramano 'prāptaviṣayaṃ tathā hi dūrādrūpaṃ paśyatyakṣisthamañjanaṃ na paśyati /
column2: The organ of sight, the organ of hearing, and the mental organ know their object without attaining it. The organ of sight sees visible matter at a distance: it does not see the eye-salve placed on the eye;
the organ of hearing hears distant sounds. The mental organ, being non-material, does not enter into a close physical relationship with its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sati ca prāptaviṣayatve divyaṃ cakṣuḥśrotramiha dhyāyināṃ nopajāyeta / ghrāṇādivat /
column2: If the organs of sight and hearing must necessarily enter into a close relationship with their object, then ascetics in dḥyāna would notattain divine sight or divine hearing, in the same way that they do not attain a divine sense of smell.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyaprāptaviṣayaṃ cakṣuḥ kasmānna sarvamaprāptaṃ paśyati dūraṃ tiraskṛtaṃ ca /
column2: If the organ of sight sees an object with which it is not in a close relationship, why does it not see visible matter which is too distant or obscured?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ tāvadayskānto na sarvamaprāptamayaḥ karṣati / prāptaviṣayatve 'pi caitatsamānam /
column2: Why does a magnet not attract all iron?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasmānna sarvaṃ prāptaṃ paśyatyañjanaṃ śalākāṃ vā /
column2: Moreover, the same difficulty remains even if you suppose that the organ enters into a close relationship with the object: why does the organ of sight not see the eye salve, the brush, and all the objects with which it is in close relationship?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca ghrāṇādīnaṃ prāpto viṣayo na tu sarvaḥ / sahabhūgandhādyagrahaṇāt /
column2: Or else, let us say that the same rule applies to the organ of sight and to the organs of smell and taste: the organ of smell senses only the smell with which it is in close relationship, but it does not sense the odor which constitutes the organ itself;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ cakṣuṣo 'pyaprāptaḥ syānna tu sarvaḥ / manastvarūpitvāt prāptumevāśaktam /
column2: in the same way, the organ of sight sees only certain distant visible matter, but it does not see all distant visible matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kecit punaḥ śrotraṃ praptāprāptaviṣayaṃ manyayante / karṇabhyantare 'pi śabdaśravaṇāt /
column2: According to certain masters, from the fact that one hears noise from the interior of the ear, one can conclude that the organ of hearing. The other three organs, smell, taste, touch, perceive an object with which they are in close relationship.
For smell, this results from the fact that in-breathing is necessary to the perception of the smell.
For the other three organs, the opposite.
What should one understand by the expression “to attain” (to enter into a close relationship)?
What does one mean when one says that the nose “attains” its object, knows its object “after having attained it?”

To attain is “to arise in morantaratva’ in a state of non-separation. The object, which renews itself from moment to moment, is found to be arisen in moran$aratva with the organ and vice versa. What does nirantara⁴va mean? According to the Bhadanta, immediate juxtaposition, absence of interval; according to the Vaibhāsikas, immediate vicinity, absence of an interposed body.
The question is therefore posed whether the atoms do or do not.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na spṛśantīti kāśmīrakāḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam / yadi tāvat sarvānmanā spṛśeyurmiśrībhaveyurdravyāṇi /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmīr say that atoms do not touch one another;

if atoms touch one another in their totality, things, that is to say, the different atoms, would “mix with one another,” that is, they would only occupy one place; and if atoms touched each other in one spot, they would thus have parts: and atoms do not have any parts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: niravayavāśca paramāṇavaḥ / kathaṃ śabdābhiniśpattirbhavati / ata eva yadi hi spṛśeyurhasto haste 'bhyāhataḥ sajyeto palaścopale /
column2: But, if there is no contact among the atoms, how is sound produced? For the very reason that there is no contact, sound is possible: if atoms were to touch one aṉother, a hand in collision with a hand would dissolve into it, a rock in collision with another rock would dissolve into it, as gum dissolves into gum. And sound would not be produced.
But if atoms do not touch one another, why does an agglomeration of atoms not fall to pieces when it is struck?
Because the wind element holds it together.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaścidvāyudhāturvikiraṇāya pravṛtto yathā saṃvarttanyāṃ kaścit saṃdhāraṇāya yathā vivarttanyāmiti /
column2: A certain wind element has dispersion for its function, for example the wind of the period of the destruction of the world;
a certain wind element hasOne says that three organs attain their object, because their object is in a state of non-separation from them. What does non-separation consist of?
It consists of the fact that there is nothing which is in the interval between the two. This is also what is meant by "to attain,"
Furthermore, as agglomerations have parts, there is no difficulty in agglomerations touching one another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca kṛtvā 'yamapi grantha upapanno bhavati vibhāṣāyām / kiṃ nu spṛṣṭahetukaṃ spṛṣṭamutpadyate āhosvidaspṛṣṭahetukamiti praśnayitvāha“kāraṇaṃ prati /
column2: And, from this point of view the definitions of the Vabhāṣā are justified: "Does a thing-in-contact arise having for its cause a thing-in-contact, or does it arise having for its cause a thing-outside-of-contact? Same question with respect to a thing-outside-of-contact. "One cannot reply in an absolute manner.
Sometimes a thing-outside-of-contact arises from a thing-in-contact, as when a thing-in-contact falls to pieces.
Sometimes a thing-in-contact arises from a thing-outside-of-contact, as when a thing-outside-of-contact comes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kadācit spṛṣṭahetukaṃ spṛṣṭaṃ yadā cayavatāṃ cayaḥ /
column2: Sometimes a thing-in-contact arises from a thing-outside-of-contact, as when agglomerations come together.
And sometimes a thing-outside-of-contact arises from a thing-outside-of-contact, for example the particles of dust suspended in the void of a window.
The Bhadanta Vasumitra says: "If atoms touched one another, they would therefore endure two moments. Opinions of Vasubandhu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na spṛśanti / nirantare tu spṛṣṭasaṃjñeti bhadantaḥ /
column2: The Bhadanta says: "There is not, in reality, any contact. One says, metaphorically, that atoms touch one another when they are juxtaposed without interval" (Quoted in Vibhāṣā, TD 27, p.
see note 189, end).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hi sāntarāṇāṃ paramāṇūnāṃ śūnyeṣvantareṣu gatiḥ kena pratibadhyeta /
column2: This opinion is the correct one. In fact, if atoms were to allow an interval between themselves, since this interval would be empty, what would hinder the progress of atoms into this interval? For it is admitted that atoms are impenetrable.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yataḥ sapratighā iṣyante / naca paramāṇubhyo 'nye saṃghātā iti /
column2: Agglomerations are not anything other than atoms.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta eva te saṃghātāḥ paramāṇavaḥ spṛśyante yathā rūpyante /
column2: They are the same atoms which, in a state of aggregation, are a "thing-incontact," in the same way that they are rāpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi ca paramāṇordigbhāgabhedaḥ kalpyate spṛṣṭasyāspṛṣṭasya vā sāvayavatvaprasaṅgaḥ /
column2: It is thus absurd to. If you admit spatial division to the atom, then an atom certainly has parts, whether it enters into contact or not.
If you deny it, why would the atom, even if it enters into contact, have parts?

Should we think that the organs solely grasp an object of their dimension,—if one believes that one sees suddenly extended objects, a mountain for example, it is through illusion, it is because one rapidly sees parts of a mountain: it is evidently thus when one sees the circle of fire delineated by an ember;
:—or else do the organs indifferently grasp an object of their dimension and of a different dimension?
The three organs of which the organ of smell is the first, grasp an object of their dimension.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvanto hīndriyaparamāṇavastāvanto hi viṣayaparamāṇavaḥ sametya vijñānaṃ janayanti /
column2: A given number of atoms of an organ, attaining the same number of atoms of an object, produce consciousness. This also holds for smell, taste, and touch.
But there is no rule for seeing and hearing.
Sometimes the object is. smaller than the organ, as when one sees the end of a hair;
sometimes equal to the organ, as when one sees a grape;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kadācit bhūyāṃso yadā mahāntaṃ parvataṃ paśyatyunmiṣitamātreṇa /
column2: and sometimes larger than the organ, when, the eye being hardly open, one sees a mountain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evam śrotreṇa maśakameghādiśabdaśravaṇe ghoṣam / manastvamūrttivadeveti nāsya parimāṇaparicchedaḥ saṃpradhāryate /
column2: The same for sound; one hears the buzzing of a mosquito, the noise of thunder, etc. The question does not arise for the mental organ which is non-material.
How are atoms of the different organs arranged?
The atoms of the organ of sight are arranged on the pupil like the flower of the cumin, that is to say, on the surface;
they are covered again by a membrane, of translucent color, which prevents them from dispersing.
According to another opinion, they are arranged in depth, like a pill;
being translucent, like crystal, they do not obscure one another.
The atoms of the organ of hearing are arranged in the interior of the bhūrja, that type of birch leaf which is found within the ear.
The atoms of the organ of smell are arranged within the interior of the nostril.
These first three organs form a garland.
The atoms of the organ of taste are arranged on the upper surface of the tongue in the form of a half-moon.
In the middle of the tongue a space the dimension of the end of a hair is not occupied by the atoms of the organ. Such is the opinion expressed in Scripture.
The atoms of the organ of touch have the shape of the body.
The atoms of the female organ are like a drum.
The atoms of the male organ are like a thumb.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra cakṣurindriyaparamāṇavaḥ kadācit sarve sabhāgā bhavanti kadācittatsabhāgāḥ /
column2: The atoms of the organ of sight can be sabhāga in their totality;
£a$sabhāga in their totality; some sabhāga, others tatsabhāga.
The same for the organs of hearing, smell and taste.
But, it does not occur that the atoms of the organ of touch are all sabhāga;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pradīptanarakābhyantarāvaruddhānāmapi hyaparimāṇāḥ kāyendriyaparamāṇavastatsabhāgā bhavanti / sarvaiḥ kila vijñānotpattāvāśrayo viśīryeta /
column2: even when the body is enveloped in the flames of Pratapana hell, an infinite number of atoms are tatsabhāga; for, says the School, the body would fall to pieces if all the atoms of touch were to work at the same time.
It does not occur that consciousness is produced by one atom of organ, or by one atom of object.
In fact, the five categories of. Consciousness have agglomerations for their support and their object.
It results from this that atoms are not perceived; they are thus “imperceptible”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya ime ṣaḍvijñānadhātava uktāścakṣurvijñānaṃ yavanmanovijñānaṃ kimeṣāṃ yatha viṣayo varttamānaḥ pañcānāṃ caramasya trikāla evamāśrayo 'pi /
column2: The object of the first five consciousnesses is simultaneous with them; the object of the sixth consciousness is either earlier than it, simultaneous with it, or later than it; in other words, it is past, present, or future. Does the same hold for the point of support of the consciousness?
No, it does not.
Why is this? Relative to consciousness, the point of support of the sixth consciousness is past.
The sole point of support of the mental consciousness is the mental organ, this is, the consciousness which has just perished.
The point of support of the first five is also simultaneous.

The point of support of the five consciousnesses is also simultaneous with them: that is, it is both earlier than, and simultaneous to the consciousness. In fact, the point of support of these consciousnesses is twofold: 1.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra cakṣurvijñānasya cakṣuḥ sahaja āśārayo yāvat kāyavijñānasya kāyaḥ /
column2: the sense organ, organ of sight, etc. , which is simultaneous.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atītaḥ punareṣāmāśrayo mana ityapyete pañca vijñānakāyā indriyadvayāśrayāḥ /
column2: The five consciousnesses have two points of support.
One poses the question: is the point of support of visual consciousness also the immediately antecedent and parallel cause?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catuṣkotikaḥ / prathamā kotiścakṣuḥ / dvitīyā samanantarātītaścaitasiko dharmadhātuḥ /
column2: Four cases: the organ of sight is solely a point of support;

mental states that have just perished are solely the immediately antecedent cause; the consciousness or mental organ that has just perished is both a point of support and an immediately antecedent cause;
and other dharmas are neither.
The same applies to the consciousness of hearing, smell, taste, and touch.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: manovijñānasya pūrvapādakaḥ / yastāvadāśrayabhāvena samanantarapratyayabhāvenāpi saḥ / syātsamanantarapratyayabhāvena nāśrayabhāvena / samanantarābhyatītaścetasiko dharmadhāturiti /
column2: With respect to mental consciousness, the point of support is always the parallel and immediately antecedent cause, but items that have perished are not.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇamubhayādhīnāyāṃ vijñānotpattau cakṣurādayaḥ evāśrayā ucyante na rūpādayaḥ /
column2: Visual consciousness depends on the organ of sight and on visible matter. Why is the organ considered as the point of support of consciousness, to the exclusion of the object? The point of support of a consciousness is its organ, for consciousness changes according to the modality of the organ.

When the organ of sight is the object of attention (employment of eye salve, etc. ); when it is injured by dust, etc. ; when it is alert; when it is sluggish and weak, consciousness reproduces modality: it is accompanied by pleasure or by pain, it is alert or weak.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣurādīnāṃ hi vikāreṇa tadvijñānānāṃ vikāro bhavatyanugrahopaghātapaṭumandatānuvidhānāt na tu rūpādīnāṃ vikāreṇa tadvikāraḥ /
column2: The object, on the contrary, has no influence on the modality of consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt sādhīyastadadhīnatvat ta evāśrayā na rūpādayaḥ /
column2: Consequently, it is the organ, and not the object, which is the point of support of consciousness. Consciousness knows the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ rūpādayaśca tairvijñāyante cakṣurvijñānaṃ cocyate yāvanmanovijñānam / na punā rūpavijñānaṃ yāvaddharmavijñānamiti / ya ete cakṣurādaya āśrayā eṣām /
column2: Why is it designated by the name of its organ "eye consciousness", "manas consciousness", "dharma consciousness"? For this reason, and also because it is "its own", it is the.
The consciousness takes the name of an organ because the organ is its point of support.
Because the organ is “its own:” the organ of a certain person is the point of support of the visual consciousness of this person alone.
Visible matter, on the contrary, is general, for a certain visible thing is perceived by both the visual consciousness and the mental consciousness, by one person and by another person.
The same observation holds for the organs of hearing, smell, taste, and touch, and for their objects, sounds, smells, tastes, and tangibles.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādāśrayabhāvādasādhāraṇatvācca vijñānaṃ tenaiva nirdiśyate na rūpādibhiḥ /
column2: We conclude that the consciousness is named according to its organ because the organ is its point of support, and because the organ is its own thing. But the same does not hold for its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā bherīśabdo yavāṅkura iti / atha yatra kāye sthitaścakṣuṣā rūpāṇi paśyati kiṃ tāni kāyacakṣūrūpavijñānānyekabhūmikānyeva bhavantyāhosvidanyabhūmikānyapi / āha /
column2: One says in the world “sound of the drum,” and not “sound of the stick; ” “sprout of the wheat,” and not “sprout of the field.
”All can belong to different stages.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātūpapannasya svena cakṣuṣā svāni rūpāṇi paśyataḥ sarvaṃ svabhūmikam bhavati /
column2: When a being born in Kamadhātu sees, by means of an organ of sight of his stage, visible matter of his stage, then body, organ, visible matter and consciousness are in the same stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyaiva svāni rūpāṇi prathamadhyānabhūmīni paśyano rūpāṇi trīṇapi tadbhūmikāni / dvitīyadhyānacakṣuṣā svāni rūpoāṇi paśyataḥ kāyarūpe svabhūmike cakṣustadbhūmikaṃ vijñānaṃ prathamadhyāna bhūmikam /
column2: When this being sees visible matter of his stage, by means of an organ of sight of the First Dhyāna, then the body and visible matter are of Kamadhātu, but his organ and consciousness are of the First Dhyāna;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamadhyānabhūmīni paśyato vijñānarupe tadbhūmike kāyaḥ kāmāvacaraścakṣurdvitīyadyānabhūmikam /
column2: if he sees visible matter of the First Dhyāna by means of the same organ, then only the body is in Kāmadhātu;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyadhyānabhūmīni paśyataścakṣūarūpe tadbhūmike kāyaḥ kāmāvacaro vijñānaṃ prathamabhūmīkam /
column2: the other three are of the First Dhyāna. When this being sees visible matter of Kġāmadhātu by means of an organ of sight of the Second Dhyāna, then the body and visible matter are in Kāmadhātu, the organ is in the Second Dhyāna, and consciousness is in the First Dhyāna; if he sees, by the same organ, visible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tṛtīyacaturthadhyānabhūmikena cakṣuṣā tadbhūmikādharabhumikāni rūpāṇi paśyato yojayitavyam /
column2: When a being in the Second Dhyāna sees visible matter of his stage by means of an organ of sight of his stage, then body, organ, visible matter and consciousness are of the same stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathmadhyānopapannasya svena cakṣuṣā svāni rūpāṇi paśyataḥ sarvaṃ svabhūmikamadharāṇi paśyataḥ trayaṃ svabhūmikaṃ /
column2: If he sees visible matter of a lower stage by the same organ, then the body, organ, and consciousness are of his stage, the First Dhyāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyadhyānacakṣuṣā svāni rūpāṇi paśyatastrayaṃ svabhūmikaṃ cakṣustadbhūmikam /
column2: When this being sees visible matter of his stage by means of an organ of sight of the Second Dhyána, then three are of his stage (First Dhyāṇna), but the organ is in the Second Dhyāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacarāṇi paśyataḥ kāyavijñāne svabhūmike rūpāṇyadharāṇi cakṣustadbhūmikam /
column2: If he sees, by the same organ, visible matter of Kāmadhātu, then the body and consciousness are of his stage, visible matter is in a lower.
If he sees visible matter of the Second Dhyāna by the same organ, then the body and consciousness are of his stage, but the organ and the visible matter are in the Second Dhyāna.

Ope would explain in the same way these cases where a being in the First Dhyāna sees, by means of an organ of sight of the Third or the Fourth Dhyāṇna, visible matter of these stages or of a lower stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyādidhyānopapannasya svaparacakṣurbhyāṃ svaparabhūmikāni rūpāṇi paśyato yathāyogaṃ yojayitavyam /
column2: According to these same principles, we can explain those cases where a being in the Second, Third or Fourth Dhyāṇa, sees, by means of an organ of sight of his stage or of a different stage, visbble matter of his stage or of a different stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ayaṃ tu niyamaḥ / na kāyasyādharaṃ cakṣuḥ /
column2: The rule is the following: The organ of sight is not inferior to the body.
The body, the organ of sight, and visible matter can belong to five stages: Kāmadhātu, aṇd the Four Dhyānas.
The consciousness of sight is of two stages only: Kārmadhātu and the First Dhyāṇna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra yadbhūmikaḥ kāyastadbhūmikaṃ cakṣurūrdhvabhūmikaṃ vā cakṣurbhavati na tvadharabhūmikam /
column2: Thus stated, the organs of sight which a certain being uses can be.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadbhūmikaṃ cakṣustadbhūmikamadharabhūmikaṃ vā rūpaṃ viṣayo bhavati /
column2: Visible matter and consciousness, through relationship to the organ, is either of the same stage or lower, but never of a higher stage.
Visible matter is not higher than the organ.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi kadācidūrdhrvabhūmikaṃ rūpamadhobhūmikena cakṣuṣā draṣṭuṃ śakyate /
column2: Visible matter of a higher stage cannot be seen by an organ of sight of a lower stage.
Nor consciousness.
A visual consciousness of a higher stage cannot arise from an organ of a lower stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asya rūpaṃ tu kāyasyobhe ca sarvataḥ //
column2: Visible matter, in relation to consciousness, and visible matter as well as consciousness, through relation to the body, is of all types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asyetyanantaroktasya cakṣurvijñānasya rūpaṃ sarvato viṣayaḥ ūrdhvamadhaḥ svabhūmau ca /
column2: Visible matter, through relationship with the visual consciousness, is either equal, or higher, or lower.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyasya cobhe rūpavijñāne sarvato bhavataḥ / yathā cecaṃ cakṣuruttaṃ vistareṇa veditavyam
column2: Visible matter and the visual consciousness, through relationship to the body, are as visible matter is through relationship to the consciousness, this is to say, equal, higher, or lower.
The same holds for the organ of hearing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “na kāyasyādharaṃ śrotramūrdhvaṃ śabdo na ca śruteḥ /
column2: The organ of hearing is not lower than the body, sound is not higher than the organ of hearing, nor is auditory consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vijñānaṃ cāsya śabdastu kāyasyobhe ca sarvataḥ //“iti vistareṇa yojyam /
column2: sound, through relationship to this latter, and sound and consciousness through relationship to the body, can be of all types.
Three organs belong to their own stage.
With respect to the organs of smell, taste, and touch, the body, organ, object and consciousness belong exclusively to the stage where the being is born.
After having formulated this general rule, the author mentions one exception.
The consciousness of touch is of its own stage or of a lower stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyaḥ kāyadhātuḥ spraṣṭavyaṃ ca svabhūmikānyeva nityaṃ bhavanti /
column2: The body, the organ of touch and tangibles are always of the stage where the being is born.
But the consciousness of touch is of this stage, in the case of a being born in Kāmadhātu or in the First Dhyāṇna;
or is of a lower stage in the case of a being born in the Second Dhyána or above.
There is no restriction with respect to the mental organ.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kadācit kāyamanovijñānadharmaiḥ samānabhūmikaṃ mano bhavati kadācidūrdhvādhobhūmikam /
column2: Sometimes the mental organ is of the same stage as the body.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcabhūmike 'pi hi kāye sarvabhūmikāni mana ādīni bhavanti samāpattyupapattikāle yathāyogamiti vistareṇa samāpattinirdeśe kośasthāna etadākhyāyiṣyate atihahugranthabhāraparihārārthaṃ tu nedānīṃ punarākhyāyate / alpaṃ ca prayojanaṃ mahāṃśca śrama iti samāpta ānuṣaṅgikaḥ prasaṅgaḥ /
column2: If a body belongs to the first five stages—Kāmadhātu and the Four Dhyānas—, then the mental organ, the dharmadhātu, and the mental consciousness can be, in absorption or at conception, of any stage, all the stages not being moreover the same in each case.
This tions. We shall not speak here of this for the sake of brevity, the profit being small and the pains great.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭādaśānāṃ cdātūnāṃ ṣaṇṇāṃ ca vijñānānāṃ kaḥ kena vijñeyaḥ / āha /
column2: There are eighteen dhāus and six consciousness. Which dhātu is discerned by which consciousness?
Five external dhātus are discerned by two types of consciousness.
Visible matter, sounds, odots, tastes and tangibles are known respectively, by the consciousness of sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch. They are all discerned by the mental consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamete pratyekaṃ dvābhyāṃ vijñānābhyāṃ vijñeyā bhavanti /
column2: Each of these external dhātus is thus discerned by two consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣāstrayodaśa dhātavaḥ pañcānāṃ vijñānakāyānāmaviṣayatvādekena manovijñānena vijñeyā ityākhyātaṃ bhavati / eṣāmaṣṭādaśānāṃ dhātūnāṃ madhye kati nityāḥ katyanityāḥ /
column2: The thirteen other dhātus, not being of the sphere of the sense consciousness, are discerned by a single mental consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na kaśct sakalo 'sti nityo dhāturapi tu
column2: No dhātu is totally eternal.
But Unconditioned things are eternal. Unconditioned things form part of the dharmadhātu.
Thus one part of the dharmadhātu is eternal.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katīndriyaṃ kati nendriyam / dharmārdhamindriyaṃ ye ca dvādaśādhyātmikāḥ smṛtāḥ //
column2: The twelve internal dḥātus and one part of the dharmadhātu are indriyas.

column2: organ of hearing, 3. organ of smell, 4. organ of taste, 5. oṟgan of touch, 6. mental orgaṉ, 7. male oṟgan, 8.

column2: female oṟgan, 9. vital organ, 10. faculty of sensation of pleasure, or sensation of pleasure, 11.

column2: faculty of sensation of displeasure, or sensation of displeasure, 12. faculty of sensation of satisfaction, or sensation of satisfaction, 13. faculty of sensation of dissatisfaction, or sensation of dissatisfaction, 14.
