prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ābhidhārmikāstu ṣaḍāyatanavyavasthānamādṛtya jīvitendriyānantaraṃ manaindriyaṃ paṭhanti / sālambanatvāt /
column2: faculty of absorption, 19. faculty of discernment ofThe Ābhidhārmikas do not count the group that forms the six organs of consciousness, i. , the organs of sight, hearing, smell, taste, touch, and the mental organ. They do not place the mental organ after the organ of touch, but after the vital organ, for the reason that the mental organ, the same as the organs of sensation, also have an ālambana and not solely a visaya as do the organs of sense consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra dharmārdhaṃ jīvitendriyādīnyekādaśendriyāṇi trayāṇāṃ ca bhāgo dharmadhātupradeśatvāt /
column2: Among the twenty-two ⁴ndriyas, eleven—namely the vital organ, the five faculties of sensation, the five moral faculties—aṉnd one part of the last three, form part of the dharmadhātu.
The twelve internal dhātus are the five organs of sense consciousness which form five dhātus and five ‘ndriyas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sapta cittadhātavo manaindriyaṃ stripuruṣendriye kāyadhātupradeś iti paścād vakṣyati /
column2: the mental organ, that is to say, the sixth #ṉdriya, which make up seven dhātus; and one part of the last three ⁴ndriyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣāḥ pañca dhātavo dharmadhātupradeśaśca nendriyamiti siddham // abhidharmakośabhāṣye dhātunirdeśo nāma prathamaṃ kośasthānaṃ samāptam iti / ye dharmā hetuprabhavā hetuṃ teṣāṃ tathāgato hyavadat / teṣāṃ ca yo nirhodha evaṃvādīu mahāśramaṇaḥ // likhāpitamidaṃ śrīlāmāvākeneti / dvitīyaṃ kośasthānam
column2: The five remaining dhātus and one part of the dharmadhātu are. The Ināriyas O.
Hormage to the Buddha.
We have enumerated the organs or with regard to the dhātus.
What is the meaning of the word ndriya?
The root di signifies paramaiśvarya or supreme authority. Whatever exercises supreme power or authority is called an náriya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya indantīti indriyāṇi / ata ādhipatyārtha indriyārthaḥ /
column2: Thus, in general, indriya signifies adhipati or ruler.
What is the object of the predominating influence of each indriya?
According to the School, five are predominate with regard to things;

Each of the five ndriyas of which the organ of sight is the first—the five organs of sense consciousness—is a predominating influence with regard to the beauty of the person; with regard to the protection of the person; with regard to the production of a consciousness and the mental states associated with this consciousness;

and with regard to their special mode of activity (Vibhāṣāa, TD , p. The organs of seeing and hearing are predominating influences with regard to beauty, for the body in which they are missing is not. Beautiful.
With regard to protection, for by seeing and hearing, a person avoids that which would destroy him;
with regard to the production of the seeing and hearing consciousnesses, and of the mental states associated with them;
and with regard to their special activities, i. , seeing visible things and hearing sounds.
The organs of smell, taste, and sensation are predominating influences with regard to beauty, as above;
with regard to protection, through the consumption of solid foods;
with regard to the production of their three consciousnesses;
and with regard to their special activities, i. , perceiving smells, tasting tastes, and touching tangibles.
Four predominate with regard to two things;
Four indriyas, namely the two sexual organs, the vital organ, and the mental organ are each a predominating influence with regard to two things.
The sexual organs are the predominating influence with regard to the distribution of living beings: it is by reason of these two.
That living beings form the categories of male and female;

and with regard to the differentiation of living beings: by reason of these two organs, there are, among the sexes, differences of physical form, voice, and manner of being. Some other masters do not admit this explanation. In fact there are sexual differences among the gods of Rūpadhātu who, however, do not possess sexual organs, and their distribution into sexes results from these differences.

Thus, if the sexual organs are the predominating influences from two points of view, they are the predominating influences with regard to defilement and purification: in fact, the three types of eunuchs and bisexual beings are alien to the dharmas of defilement, lack of discipline, mortal transgression, the cutting off of the roots of good;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā hi tadviprayuktavikalpānāṃ ṣaṇḍha paṇḍakobhayavyañjanānāmasaṃvarānantāryakuāśalamulasamucchedā na bhavanti saṃvaraphalaprāptivairāgyāṇi ceti /
column2: and to the dharmas of purification, discipline, acquisition of the fruits, and detachment.

The vital organ is the predominating influence with regard to the “ḍoining” of the nikāyasabhāga, ie. , that which concerns. The arising of an existing thing; and with regard to “maintaining” this n/kayāsabhāga, ie.
, that which concerns the prolongation of an existing thing from its arising to its extinction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra punrbhavasaṃbandhe yathoktaṃ “gandharvasya tasmin samaye dvayościttayoranyatarānyataracittaṃ saṃmukhībhūtaṃ bhavatyanunayasahagataṃ vā pratighasahagataṃ ve“ti /
column2: The mental organ is predominate with regard to rebirth, as the Sūtra explains, “Then there is produced among the Gandharvas, beings in the intermediate existence, one or the other of two minds, a mind of desire or a mind of hatred.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vaśibhāvānuvarttane yathoktaṃ “cittenāyaṃ loko nīyata” iti vistaraḥ /
column2: ” With regard to domination: the world and the dharmas submit to the mind. As the stanza says: The world is lead by the mind, conducted by the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yat punaḥ sukhādīndriyapañcakaṃ yāni cāṣṭau śraddhādīni teṣāṃ
column2: The five ôndriyas of sensation (ie. , the five sensations of pleasure, displeasure, satisfaction, dissatisfaction, and indifference; 7,) and the eight indriyas of faith, (force, memory, absorption and discernment and the three pure faculties, ii.
10) are, respectively, predominant with regard to defilement and to purification.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ādhipatyaṃ yathākramaṃ pañcānāṃ sukhādīnāṃ saṃkleśe / rāgādīnāṃ tadanuśāyitvāt /
column2: The sensations are predominant with regard to defilement, for the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śraddhādīnāṃ vyavadāne / tai rvyavadāyate / vyavadāne 'pi sukhādīnāmādhipatyamityapare / “yasmāt sukhitasya cittaṃ samādhīyate” /
column2: Faith and the seven other faculties are predominant with regard to purification, for it is by them that one obtains purity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥdhupaniṣacchraddhāṣaṇnaiṣkramyāśritāḥ saumanasyādaya iti vaibhāṣikāḥ / apare punarāhuḥ /
column2: According to other masters, the sensations are also predominant with regard to purification, so that the Sūtra says: "swkhiasya cittaṁ samādhīyate, duḥkhopaniṣacchradḍhā aṇṉ naiṣkramyāfritaḥ saumamasyādhayaḥ (There are, by reason of visible things, etc. , six sensations of satisfaction, six sensations of dissatisfactioṉ, six sensations of indifference, favorable to naiṣkramyga. )" Such is the explanation of the Vaibhāsikas.
The sense organs, the eyes, etc. , are not predominant with regard to the protection of the petson.

Here predominance belongs to the consciousnesses, visual consciousness, hearing consciousness, etc. ; and it is after having distinguished that one has avoided anything harmful that one takes solid food.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāpi vijñānādanyadrūpadarśanaṃ śabdaśravaṇaṃ vā 'sti / yatastayorasādhāraṇakāraṇatve pṛthagādhipatyaṃ yujyeta /
column2: That which you understand as the "proper activity of the organ," namely the seeing of visible things, etc. , belongs.
The explanations relative to the predominance of the other Éndriyas are equally incorrect.
How then should one understand the predominance of the indriyas?

By reason of their predominance with regard to the perception of their special object, with regard to all objects, six organs. That is, by reason of their predominance through their affinity to the six consciousnesses.

The five organs, the first of which is the organ of sight, are predominant through their affinity to the five sense consciousnesses, visual consciousness, etc. , each one of which distinguishes its own object, visible things, etc. The mental organ is predominant with regard to the mental consciousness which distinguishes all objects.
It is in this way that the six sense organs are predominant.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu cārthānāmapyatrādhipatyam / nādhipatyam / adhikaṃ hi prabhutvamādhipatyam /
column2: But, we might say, the sense objects, visibles, etc. , are also predominant through their affinity to the consciousness, and as a consequence, should they not also be considered as ndriyas?

The eye is predominant, for it exercises this predominance with regard to the arising of the consciousness that knows visible things, being the common cause of all consciousnesses of visible things, whereas each visible thing merely aids the arising of but one consciousness;
the visual consciousness is clear or obscure, active or well, accordingly as the eye is active or weak: now visible things do not exercise a similar influence.
The same holds for the other sense organs and their objects.
It is by reason of their predominance in masculinity and femininity that one must distinguish two sexual organs within the body.
There are two separate sexual organs within the kāyendriya, or the organ of touch. These two organs are not distinct from the kāyendriya: they too cognize tangible things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaścidasau kāyendriyabhāga upastha pradeśo yaḥ strīpuruṣendriyākhyāṃ paratilabhate / yathākramaṃ strītvapuṃstvayyorādhipatyāt / tatra strībhāvaḥ striyākṛtiḥ svaraceṣṭā abhiprāyāḥ /
column2: But there is a part of the kāyendriya that receives the name of male organ or female organ because this part exercises predominance over masculinity or femininity.
Femininity is.
The physical form, the voice, the hearing, and the dispositions proper to women.

The same for masculinity. Since the differences of these two natures are due to these parts of the body, we know that these two parts are predominant through their two natures. Hence they constitute gnariyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nikāyasthitisaṃkleśavyavadānādhipatyataḥ / jīvitaṃ vedanāḥ pañca śraddhādyāścendriyaṃ matāḥ //
column2: It is by reason of their predominance with regard to the duration of existence, to defilement, to purification, that one considers the vital organ, the sensations, and the five the first of which is faith, as indriyas.

The vital organ is predominant with regard to the prolongation of existence from birth to death, but not, with regard to the connection of one existence with another: this connection depends on the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathāhi sukhāyāṃ vedanāyāṃ rāgo 'nuśete duḥkhāyāṃ pratigho 'duḥkhāsukhāyāmavidyetyuktaṃ sūtre /
column2: The five sensations are predominant with regard to defilement, for the Sutra says, “Lust finds its shelter in the sensation of pleasure; hatred, in the sensation of displeasure; confusion,-in the sensation of indifference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vyavadāne śraddhādīnāṃ pañcānām / tathāhi taiḥ kleśāśca viṣkabhyante mārgaścāvāhyate / ata ete 'pi pratyekamindriyamiṣṭāḥ /
column2: ” [On this point the Sautrantikas are in agreement with]The five faculties—faith, force, memory, absorption, and discernment—are predominant with regard to purification, for, through their power, the defilements are disturbed and the Path is brought about.
By reason of their predominance with regard to ascending acquisitions, with regard to Nirvāṇa, etc. , the anājñātamājñāsyāmīndriya, the ajñendriya, and the āgñātāvīndriya, are likewise.
“Likewise,” that is, these three are, likewise, considered as predominating influences or ndriyas.
These are the three pure indriyas, which will be defined ii. The first is predominant through the acquisition of the second. The second is predominant through the acquisition of the third.
The third is predominant through the acquisition of Nirvāṇa, or nrupadhiśeṣanirvāṇa.
For there is no Patinirvāṇa when the mind is not delivered.
The word “et cetera” indicates that there is another explanation: The first is predominant with regard to the extinctions of the defilements which are abandoned through Seeing the Truths.
The second, with regard to the extinction of the defilements which are abandoned through Meditation on the Truths.

The third, with regard to blessedness-in-this-life, that is, the experience of the satisfaction and the well-being that comes from deliverance from the defilements. Why are there only twenty-two ndriyas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avidyādīnāmapi hi saṃskārādiṣvādhipatyamata eṣāmapīndriyatvamupasaṃkhyātavyam / vāgādīnāṃ ca / vākyāṇipādapāyūpasthānāmapi cendriyatvamupasaṃkhyātavyam /
column2: If you regard a “predominating influence” as an indriya, ignorance and the other parts of pratityasamutpāda would be ondáriyas, for these causes are predominant with regard to their effects.
In the same way, the voice, hands, feet, the anus, and the penis are predominant with regard to words, grasping, walking, exctetioṉ, and pleasure.

We would answer that there is no reason to add ignorance, etc. , to the list proclaimed by the Blessed One. In enumerating the ndriyas, the Blessed One took into account the following characteristics: The support of the mind; that which subdivides, prolongs, and defiles this support;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmādiheṣṭam cittāśrayastadvikalpaḥ sthitiḥ saṃkleśa eva ca /
column2: that which prepares the purification.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃbhāro vyavadānaṃ ca yāvatā tāvadindriyam // tatra cittāśrayaḥ ṣaḍindriyāṇi /
column2: The support of the mind consists of the six organs of consciousness, from the organ of sight to the mental organ.
These are the six internal ġyatanas which are the primary constituents of a living being.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya strīpuruṣavikalpaḥ strīpuruṣendraiyābhyāṃ sthitirjīvitendriyeṇa saṃkleśo vedanā bhiḥ /
column2: This sixfold support is differentiated by reason of the sexual organs. It lasts for a time by reason of the vital organ. It is defiled by reason of the five sensations.

Its purification is prepared by the five moral faculties, faith, etc. It is purified by the three pure faculties. The dharmas that possess the characteristic of being predominant with regard to the constitution, the subdivision, etc. of a living being are considered to be ôndriyas.

This characteristic is missing in other dharmas, in voice, etc. Or rather there are fourteen ‘ndriyas, support of transmigration, origin, duration, enjoyment of this support; the other indriyas have the same function with regard to Nirvāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: matavikalpārtho vāśabdaḥ / apare punarāhuḥ / pravṛtteraśrayaḥ ṣaḍindriyāṇi /
column2: The expression “or rather” introduces the explanation of other.
It is through the sexual organs that the sadayatanas arise.
It is through the vital organ that the sadayatanas last.
It is through the five sensations that the sadayatanas enjoy.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata etāni caturdaśendriyāṇi / tenaiva prakāreṇa nivṛtteranyāni / śraddhadīni hi nivṛtterāśrayāḥ /
column2: The five faculties - faith, force, memory, absorption, discernment - are the support of Nirvana. Nirvana is generated, appears for the first time, through the first pure faculty, enajnatamajnyasyamindriya. Nirvana lasts, is developed, through the second pure faculty, ajnendriya. Nirvana is experienced by the third pure faculty, jnatavinaraya, for, through this faculty, one experiences the satisfaction and well-being of deliverance. This determines the number of Endriyas, as well as the order in which the Sutra places them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ājñāsyāmīndriyaṃ prabhavaḥ sthitirājñendriyam upabhoga ājñātāvīndriyeṇetyata etāvantyevendriyāṇi / ata eva caīṣāmeṣo 'nukramaḥ /
column2: The voice, hands, feet, the anus, and the sexual parts are not indriyas.
The voice is not predominant with respect to words, for words.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pāṇipādasya cādānaviharaṇādananyatvāt / tadeva hi tadanyathā 'nyatra cotpannamādānaṃ viharaṇaṃ cocyate /
column2: Hands and feet are not predominant with regard to grasping and walking, for grasping and walking are simply the hands and feet arising a second moment in another place and with a new figure.
On the other hand, we see that hands and feet are not indispensable for grasping and walking, for example with snakes.
The anus is not predominant with regard to the expulsion of matter, for heavy things always fall in a void;
further, wind pushes this matter and makes it go out.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upasthasyāpi nendriyatvamānande strīpuruṣendriyakṛtaṃ hi tat saukhyamiti /
column2: The sexual parts are not predominant with regard to pleasure for pleasure is produced by the sexual organs.

If you consider the hands, the feet, etc. , as indriyas, you must then place the throat, the teeth, the eyelids, and the joints, whose function it is to swallow, to chew, to open and close, to fold up and to extend the bones, among the indriyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvasya vā kāraṇabhūtasya svasyāṃ kariyāyāmityayukataṃ vāgādīnāmindriyatvam //
column2: In this way, everything that is a cause, which exercises its action with regard to its effects, would be an indriya.
But we must reserve the name of indriya to. We have defined the organs of consciousness and the sexual organs;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jīvitendriyasya viprayuktatvādviprayukteṣveva karisyate nirdeśaḥ / śraddhādīnāṃ caitteṣu kariṣyate /
column2: the vital organ will be explained with the cittaviprayuktas among which it is placed; the five faculties being mental states will be explained with the mental states: We shall examine here the organs of sensation and the pure faculties which are not found anywhere else.
Disagreeable bodily sensation is the indriya of pain.

Bodily is "that which relates to the body," that which is associated with the five sense consciousnesses, visual consciousness, etc. "Disagreeable" is that which does harm. Sensation in relation to the five organs of sense consciousness, and which does harm, is called dukkhenariya. Agreeable is the indriya of pleasure.
Agreeable is that which does good, which comforts, is beneficent.
Agreeable bodily sensation is termed sukha-indriya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śātetyanugrāhikā sukhetyarthaḥ / dhyāne tṛtīye tu caitasī sā sukhendriyam //
column2: In the Third Dhyana, agreeable mental sensation is also an indriya of pleasure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tṛtīye tu dhyāne saiva śātā vedanā caitasī sukhendriyam /
column2: Agreeable mental sensation of the Third Dhyāna is also called sukhendriya, an indriya of pleasure. This name, moreover, is reserved for agreeable bodily sensation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi tatra kāyikī vedanā 'sti / pañcavijñānakāyābhāvāt / anyatra sā saumanasyaṃ
column2: but in the Third Dhyāṇna, bodily sensation is absent because the five sense consciousnesses are not there.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tṛtīyāddhyānādanyatra kāmadhātau prathame dvitīye ca dhyāne sā caiatasikī śātā vedanā saumanasyendriyam /
column2: Then, when one speaks of the sukha or pleasure of the Third Dhyāna, one means agreeable mental sensation. Moreover, it is satisfaction. “Moreover,” that is, in the stages below the Third Dhyāna, in Kāmadhātu and in the first two Dhyānas, agreeable mental sensation is satisfaction or the ndriya of satisfaction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tṛtīye tu dhyāne prītivītarāgatvāt sukhendriyameva sā na saumanasyendriyam /
column2: In the Third Dhyāna, agreeable mental sensation is calm and tranquil, because the ascetic, in this Dhyāṇna, is detached from joy: hence it is pleasure and not satisfaction. Below the Third Dhyāna, agreeable mental sensation is gross and agitated, because, in the stages below the Third Dhyāna, the ascetic is not detached from joy: hence it is “satisfaction.”
Joy, is not distinct frorn satisfaction.
Intermediate bodily or mental sensation is equanimity.
Intermediate sensation, which neither comforts nor harms, is the sensation “neither-pain-nor-pleasure.” This is what is termed the sensation or ndaraya of equanimity.
Is this sensation bodily or mental?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhayī kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇamiyamabhisamasyai kamindriyaṃ kriyate /
column2: It is both. Either bodily or mental, intermediate sensation is a sensation of equanimity. The sensation of equanimity presents then a double characteristic, consequently it constitutes only one indriya, because there is no vikalpana here.
For it has no vikalpana. There is no vikalpana, or intellectual operation. Either bodily or mental, the sensation of equanimity is equally free from any intellectual element.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caitasikaṃ hi sukhaduḥkhaṃ prāyeṇa vikalpanādutpadyate na tu kāyikam / viṣayavaśādarhatāmapyutpatteḥ /
column2: As a general rule, agreeable or disagreeable mental sensation proceeds from a concept, from the concept of “dear” or “hateful,” etc. Contrarily, bodily. Arhats do not have sympathies and antipathies, they do not conceive of the idea of dear or the idea of hateful, and yet they are subject nevertheless to physical pain and pleasure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atastayorindriyatvena bhedaḥ / upekṣā tu svarasenāvikalpayata evotpadyate kāyikī caitasikī ce tyekamindriyam kriyate / anyathā ca kāyikam sukhamanugṛhṇātyanyathā caitasikam /
column2: Then we should distinguish ndriyas relative to agreeable and disagreeable sensations accordingly as these sensation are bodily or mental.

But the sensation of equanimity is produced spontaneously, exactly like a physical sensation; it is produced in a person who does not form any concept: hence we recognize that there is but one ndriya for the two sensations of bodily and mental indifference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upekṣāyāṃ tveṣa vikalpo nāstyata upekṣaṇaṃ pratyavikalpanādabhedaḥ /
column2: There is no vikalpana or difference. Accordingly as the agreeable or disagreeable sensations are bodily or mental, they do good or harm according to a mode of operation that is special to them, and they are not felt in the same way. The sensation of equanimity creates neither good or harm; it is not differentiated; mental or physical, it is felt in.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛgbhāvanā 'saikṣapathe nava trīṇi manaḥ sukhasaumanasyopekṣāḥ sraddhādīni ca pañca /
column2: The mental organ, the sensation of pleasure, the sensation of satisfaction, the sensation of equanimity, and faith, force, memory, absorption and discernment constitute the anajnatamajnasyaminariya for the saint who is on the Path of Seeing;
ajnendriya for the saint who is on the Path of Meditation on the Truths;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanamārge anājñātamājñāsyāmīndriyaṃ bhāvanāmārge ājñendriyam aśaikṣamārge ājñātāvīndriyamiti / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: and gnatavinariya for the saint who is on the path of the Asaiksa. On the Path of Seeing, the saint is engaged in knowing that which he does not know, namely the Four Truths: he thinks “I will know. ” His ndriya is then called the anajnatamajnasyaminariya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanamārge hyanājñātamājñātuṃ pravṛttaḥ / bhāvanāmārge nāstyapūrvamājñeyaṃ tadeva tvājānāti śeṣānuśayaprahāṇārtham /
column2: On the Path of Meditation on the Truths, the saint does not have anything new to know, he is a wise one or ina. But in order to cut off the defilements which remain in him, he newly knows and often repeats the Truths that he already knows. His ndriya is called the ajnenariya, the indriya of the wise one, or the wise indriya.
On the Path of the Aśaikṣa, the ascetic becomes conscious that he knows: he obtains the knowledge that the Truths are known.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'syāstīti ājñātāvī / ājñātamavituṃ śīlamasyeti vā / kṣayānutpādijñānalābhāt /
column2: Possessing ājñāta-ava, he is an ājñātāviṉ, and his indriya is called the jñātāvīndriya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “duḥkhaṃ me parijñātaṃ na punaḥ parijñātavyamiti” tathābhūtasyenriyamājñātāvīnriyam /
column2: Or rather, the saint who is an ġñātāvéṉ is one who has for his characteristics or habit knowing that the Truth is known: in fact, when the saint has obtained kṣayajñána aṇḍ anutpādajñāna, he knows in truth, “Pain is known; I have nothing more to know” and the rest.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svabhāvanirdeśāṃ kṛtvā prakārabhedo vaktavya kati sāsravāṇi katyanāsravāṇi inriyāṇityevamādi / tatra tāvadyadetadanantaroktamājñāsyāmīnriyādikametat /
column2: We have explained the specific characteristics of the ndriyasr. We must explain their different natures: are they pure, from retribution, good? To what sphere do they belong? How are they abandoned? How many are impuṟe? How many are pure?
Three are clean;
The last three indriyas are exclusively clean or pure.
Stain and vice are synonyms.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpīṇi saptendriyāṇi jīvitendriyaṃ dukhaḥdaurmanasyendriye caikāntasāsravāṇi / rūpīṇi punaḥ sapta cakṣuḥ
column2: The material organs, the vital oṟgan and the two painful sensations are impure; The material organs are seven in number: the five organs.
Together with the vital organ, the sensation of pain, and the sensation of satisfaction, ten indriyas in all are exclusively impure.
Nine are of two types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: manaḥsukhasaumanasyopekṣāḥ śraddhādīni ca pañca etāni navendriyāṇi sāsravāṇyanāsravāṇyapi /
column2: The mental organ, the sensation of pleasure, the sensation of satisfaction, the sensation of equanimity, and the five moral faculties are nine indriyas that can be either pure or impure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravāṇyeva śraddhādīnītyeke / uktaṃ hi bhagavatā “yasyemāni pañcendriyāṇi sarveṇa srvaṃ na santi tamahaṃ bāhyaṃ pṛthagjanapakṣāvasthitaṃ vadāmī“ti / nedaṃ jñāpakamanāsravāṇyadhikṛtya vacanāt /
column2: According to other masters, the five moral faculties are solely pure, for the Blessed One said: “Whosoever is completely lacking, to whatever degree, any of these five indriyas, faith, etc. , I declare him to be a person outside, one who belongs to the class of Pṛthagjanas.”

Hence anyone who possesses them, to whatever degree, is an Āryaṇ; hence they are pure. This text is not proof, for the Blessed One is speaking here of a person in whom the five pure moral faculties are absent. In fact, in the passage that precedes the quotation in question, the Blessed OneHence he is referring to only the five moral faculties belonging to the Āryans, that is, pure. Whosoever is lacking them is evidently a Pr̥thagjana.
Or rather, if this passage speaks of moral faculties in general, we would remark that there are two types of Pṛthagjana: those outside, and those inside;
the first have cut off the roots of good, whereas the second have not cut them off.
It is with reference to the first that the Blessed One said: “I declare him to be a person outside, one who belongs to the class of Pṛthagjanas.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ ca sūtre “santi ca sattvā loke jātā loke vṛddhāstīkṣṇendriyā api madhyendriyā api mṛdvindriyā apī” tyapravarttita eva dharmacakre /
column2: On the other hand, according to the Sūtra, even before setting into motion the Wheel of the Dharma, there were in the world persons of sharp, medium, and weak faculties.
Hence the moral faculties of faith, etc. , are not necessarily and exclusively pure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaścoktaṃ “yāvacchāhameṣāṃ pañcānāmindriyāṇāṃ samudayaṃ cāstagamaṃ ca svādaṃ cādīnavaṃ ca niḥsaraṇaṃ ca yathābhūtaṃ nādhyajñāsiṣaṃ na tāvadahamasmātsadevakāllokādi“ti vistaraḥ /
column2: Finally, the Blessed One said: “If I do not know truly the origin, the disappearance, the advantages, the disadvantages, the escape of the five. ”I shall not be liberated, gone out, disassociated, delivered from the world of gods, Māras, and Brahmās, of a worId wherein there are Brahmins and monks; I shall not reṣide with a mind free from error.

Now a similar description does not apply to pute dharmas, which are free from advantages, from disadvantages, and from escape. Hence the moral faculties of faith, force, etc. , can be either pure or impure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katīndriyāṇi vipākaḥ kati na vipākaḥ / ekāntena tāvat
column2: Among the ²ndriyas, how many are retribution, and how many are not retribution?
The vital organ is always retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha yadarhan bhikṣurāyuḥsaṃskārān sthāpayati tajjīvitendriyaṃ kasya vipākaḥ /
column2: Of what action is the vital organ thus stabilized or prolonged the retribution?
The Mātaśāstra says: “How does a Bhikṣu stabilize the vital energies? An Arhat in possession of supernormal power, in possession of the mastery of mind, ie.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: arhan bhikṣuḥ ṛddhimāṃścetovaśitvaṃ prāptaḥ saṃghāya va pudgalāya vā pātraḥ vā cīvaraṃ vā anyatamānyatamaṃ vā śrāmaṇakaṃ jīvitapariṣkāraṃ vā dattvā tat praṇidhāya prantakoṭikam caturthaṃ dhyānaṃ samāpadyate /
column2: , one who is asamayavimukta, gives, either to the Saṅgha or to a person, things useful to. hears the sound of the vital energies, and he knows that they are about to leave his body.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tasmāt vyutthāya cittamutpādayati vācaṃ ca bhāṣate yanme bhogavipākaṃ tadāyurvipākaṃ bhavatviti / tasya yat bhogavipākaṃ tadāyurvipākaṃ bhavati / [043/15-043/16 yeṣāṃ punarayamabhiprāyo vipākoccheṣaṃ vipacyata iti / ta āhuḥ pūrvajātikṛtasya karmaṇo vipākoccheṣaṃ / sa bhāvanābalenākṛṣya pratisaṃvedayata” iti / kathamāyuḥsaṃskārā nutsṛjati / tathaīva dānaṃ dattvā praṇidhāya prantakoṭikaṃ caturthaṃ dhyānaṃ samāpadyate/ yanme āyurvipākaṃ tat bhogavipākaṃ bhavatviti tasya tathā bhavati /
column2: He then produces the thought and pronounces the words: ‘'May the vital energies be transformed and produce a retribution-in-joyP Then the vital energies produce a retribution-in-joy.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhadantaghoṣakastvāha / tasminneva āśraye rūpāvacarāṇi mahābhūtāni dhyānabalena saṃmudhakarotyāyuṣo 'nukūlāni vaihodhikāni ca /
column2: ”The Bhadaūṇta Ghoṣaka said: By the force of the prāntakoṭika Dhyāṇna that this Arhat produced, the primary elements of Rūpadhātu are attracted and introduced into his body. These primary elements are favorable to, or contrary to, the vital energies.
It is in this manner that the Arhat prolongs or casts off his life.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samādhiprabhāva eva sa teṣāṃ tadṛśo yena pūrvakarmajaṃ ca sthitikālāvedhamindriyamahābhūtānāṃ vyāvrttayantyapūrvaṃ ca samādhijamāvedhamākṣipanti
column2: Along with the Sautṛāntikas, we say that the Arhats, through their mastery in absorption, cause the projection of the constitutive primary elements of the organs for a certain period of duration, a projection due to previous actions, to cease; inversely, they produce a new projection, born of absorption.
Thus the vital organ, in the case of the prolonged life of an Arhat, is not retribution. But in other cases, it is retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: praśnāt praśnāntaramupajāyate / kimarthamāyuḥsaṃskārānadhitiṣṭhanti / parahitārthaṃ śāsansthityarthaṃ vā /
column2: One question gives rise to another.
He sees that his life is going to end;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca tatrānyaṃ śaktaṃ paśyanti / atha kimarthamutsṛjanti /
column2: he sees that others are incapable of assuring these two ends.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: alpaṃ ca parahitaṃ jīvite paśyanti rogābhibhūtaṃ cātmabhāvam / yathoktaṃ “sucīrṇe brahmacarye 'smin mārge caiva subhāvite / tuṣṭa āyuḥkṣayāt bhavati rogasyāpagame yathā //“ iti / athaitadāyuḥ saṃskārāṇāṃ sthāpanārthamutsarjanaṃ vā kva kasya vā veditavyam / manuṣyeṣvevatriṣu dvīpeṣu strīpuruṣayorasamayavimuktasyārhataḥ prāntakoṭikadhyānalābhinaḥ / tasya hi samādhau vaśitvam / kleśaiścānupastabdhā santatiḥ /
column2: For two reasons: he sees that his dwelling in this world has only a small utility for the good of others, and so sees himself tormented by sickness, etc. In the three Dvīpas, male or female, a asamayavimukia Arhat who possesses prāntakoṭika Dhyāna: in fact, he possesses the mastery of absoṟrption and he is free from the defilements.
According to the Sūtra, the Blessed One, after having extended the jīvita saṁskāras, casts off the saṁskāras of āyus.
According to certain masters, there is no difference.
In fact, the Mūlaśāṣṭra says: “What is the vital organ?
It is the in the Three Dhātus.”

According to others the expression āyuḥ-saṁskāras designates life which is the result of actions in a previous life; the expression jāvita-saṁskāras designates life which is the result of actions in this life.
According to other masters, the āyuḥ-saṁskāras are that by which existence lasts;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaistu kālāntaraṃ jīvati te jīvitasaṃskārā iti /
column2: the jñvita-saṁskāras are that by which life is prolonged for a little while.
The Sūtra uses the plural because the Saint extends or casts off many saṁskāras.
There is no advantage, in fact, in extending a moment, or in casting off a moment: it is only by means of a series of moments that the Saint can procure the good of others;

on the other hand, a moment cannot be a cause of suffering. The termas jṝvia and āyus designate a number of saskāras existing simultaneously and belonging either to four or five séandhas according to their sphere of existence.
If it were otherwise, the Sūtra would not use the expression “the jāvita-skandhas; ” it would say “The Blessed One extends somne jṝvias, and casts off some āyus.”
Why does the Blessed One cast off and extend ?
With the aim of showing that he possesses mastery over death, he casts off death; with the aim of showing that he possesses mastery over life, he extends it.
He extends it for a period of three months, no more, no less;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaccāpi tat pratijñātam “evaṃbhāvitairahaṃ caturbhirṛddhi pādairākāṅkṣankalpamapi tiṣṭheyaṃ kalpāvaśeṣamapī“ti / tasyāpi saṃpādanārtham /
column2: after three months, there is nothing more to do for his followers, after his task is well achieved, for, short of three months, heOr rather, with the aim of realizing this vow: "Any Bhikṣu who has well cultivated the four supernormal powers, can live, if he so desires, a kalpa or more.
The Vaibhāṣikas say: The Blessed One casts off or extends with the aim of showing that he triumphs over the Māra who is the skandhas, and over the Māra who is death.
In the first watch of the night, under the Bodhi Tree, he has already triumphed over the Māra who is a demon, and, in the third watch, over the Māra who is the defilements.

Twelve are of two types.

śeṣāṇi vipākaḥ /	In other cases, they are retribution.

airyāpathikaśāilpasthānikanairmāṇikāni ca yathāyogam /	When, still being neutral, they are, according to their type, either aéryāpathika, śailpasthānika, or nairmāṇika.
śeṣāṇi vipākaḥ / jīvitendriyaṃ cakṣurādīni dvādaśa hitvā śeṣāṇyavipāka iti siddham /	In other cases, they are retribution. The last eight, faith, etc. , the aṉājñātamājñasyāmīndriya, etc. , are good and consequently are not retribution. But, we would say;

saumanasyavedanīyaṃ karma daurmanasyavedanīyaṃ karma upekṣā vedanīyaṃ karme“ti saṃprayogavedanīyatāmadhikṛtyoktam /	In fact, the Sūtra says, “There is an action liable to result in satisfaction, there is an action liable to result in dissatisfaction, and there is an action liable to result in a sensation of equanimity.
daurmasyena saṃprayuktaṃ karma daurmanasyavedanīyam /	” The expression daurmanasyavedanīya should be understood not as “an action that should be experienced, resulting in a sensation of dissatisfaction,” but rather as.
yathā sukhasaṃparayuktaḥ sparśaḥ sukhavedanīyaḥ /	In fact, the Sūtra says that contact is snmkha-vedanīya: now pleasure is not the retribution of contact.
saumanasyopekṣāvedanīye api tarhi karmaṇī evaṃ bhaviṣyataḥ / yathecchasi tathā 'stu /	From all evidence, swkhavendanīya contact is contact with which a sensation of pleasure is associated. Hence davrmanasya-vedanīya action is action with which a sensation of dissatisfaction is associated. You should explain the expressions saurnanasya-vedanīya aṇd upekṣa-vedanīya as you explain the expression daurmaṇaṣya-vendanīya, since the three expressions figure in the same context in the Sūtra. It follows that a sa#rmanasya-vedanīya action is an action “with which the sensation of satisfaction is associated,” not an action “liable to retribution in satisfaction; and it foḻlows that as a consequence, the sensation of satisfaction is not retributioṉ.
saṃprayoge 'pi na doṣaḥ vipāke 'pi na doṣaḥ / agatyā hyetadevaṃ gamyeta /	We see no problēm in explaining the expression sa#rmanasya-vedaniya either as “liable to retribution in satisfaction” or as “that with which satisfaction is associated. ” But theIt refers to an action with which dissatisfaction is associated.
kā punratra yuktirdaurmanasyaṃ na vipāka iti /	One could admit your interpretation of the Sūtra if there were no other issue, that is, if it had been rationally established that dissatisfaction is not retribution.
daurmanasyaṃ hi parikalpaviśeṣairutpādyate ca vyupaśāmyate ca /	Dissatisfaction is produced by the imagination, when one thinks of something that he fears; he is assuaged in the same way: when he thinks of something that he desires.
nacaivam vipākaḥ /	Now such is not the case with retribution.
saumanasyamapyevaṃ na syādvipākaḥ /	This is the case for satisfaction which will consequently not be retribution.
yadi tarhi daumanasyaṃ vipākaḥ syādānantaryakāriṇāṃ tannimittaṃ daurmanasyotpādāttatkarma vipakvaṃ syāt / saumanasyamapyevam /	If, as you maintain, dissatisfaction is retribution, when a person has committed a serious transgression and then experiences, with regard to it, dissatisfaction and remorse, one could say that the transgression has already brought forth a ripened result—which is inadmissible.
yadi saumanasyaṃ vipākaḥ syāt puṇyakāriṇāṃ tannimittaṃ saumanasyotpādāttatkarma vipakvaṃ syāt /	But you admit that satisfaction is retribution, and we would reason as you have just done: when a person has accomplished a meritorious.
vītarāgāṇāṃ tarhi daurmanasyāsaṃbhavāt /	Persons who are detached from desire do not experience dissatisfaction.
na caivaṃ vipākaḥ / saumanasyamapyeṣāmavyākṛtaṃ kodṛśaṃ vipākaḥ syāt / yādṛśaṃ tādṛśamastu /	They possess the organs of seeing and other senses, but not the organ of dissatisfaction, which is not considered retribution.

nahi tadavyākṛtamasti nāpyanāsravamasamāhitatvāt / ato nāstyavipākaṃ daurmanasyam / daśa dvidhā // savipākānyavipākāni ca /	Dissatisfaction always has retribution, for, on the one hand, it is never neutral, being the result of a concept, but, on the other hand, it is never pure, never being produced in a state of absorption.

śraddhādīni śraddhāvīryasmṛtisamāchiprajñāḥ /	The mental organ, and faith and its following.

On the other hand, the vīrāga, the person detached from all the defilements of Kāmadhātu, and who has obtained the result of Anāgāmin cannot fall from this result, because his detachment is obtained through two paths: it is produced through the worldly path and confirmed through the Pure Path.

column2: How many indriyas does the person possess who possesses such indriyas?
He who possesses the mental organ or the vital organ or the organ of equanimity necessarily possesses three indriyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya eṣāmupekṣādīnāmanyatamena samanvāgataḥ so 'vaśyaṃ tribhirindriyaiḥ samanvāgato bhavatyebhireva /
column2: He who possesses one of these three organs necessarily possesses.
The possession of the other ndriyas is not so determined.
He who possesses these three organs may or may not possess the others.
A being born in Ārūpyadhatu does not possess the organs of seeing, hearing, smelling, or taste.
A being in Kāmadhātu does not possess these organs when he has not yet acquired them (beginning of embryonic life) or when he has lost them (through blindness, etc. , or through gradual death).
A being born in Ārūpyadhātu does not possess the organ of touch.
A being born in Ārūpyadhātu or Rūpadhātu does not possess the female organ.
A being born in Kāmadhātu cannot possess it when he bad not acquired it or when he has lost it.
The same for the male organ.
A Prthagjana born in the Fourth Dhyana, in the Second Dhyana, or in the Ārūpyas, does not possess the organ of pleasure.
A Prthagjana born in the Fourth Dhyana, in the Third Dhyana, or in the Ārūpyas, does not possess the organ of satisfaction.
Being born in Rūpadhātu or in Ārūpyadhātu does not possess the organ of displeasure.
A detached person does not possess the organ of dissatisfaction.
A person who has cut off the roots of good does not possess the five moral faculties, faith, etc. Neither a Prṛthagjana nor a Saint in possession of a result possesses anājñātamājñāsyāmīndāriya.
The Pṛthagjana, the Saint who is in the Path of the Seeing the Truths and the Arhat do not possess ājṝñendriya.
The Pṛthagjana and the Śaikṣas do not possess ājñātavīndáriya.
This enumeration permits us to establish those 'ndréyas possessed by those categories of non-specified beings.
He who possesses the organ of pleasure or the organ of touch certainly possesses four organs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ sukhendriyeṇa samanvāgataḥ so 'vaśyaṃ caturbhirindriyaistaiśca tribhirupekṣādibhiḥ sukhendriyeṇa ca /
column2: He who possesses the organ of pleasure also possesses the vital organ, the mental organ, and the organ of equanimity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ kāyendriyeṇa so 'pi caturbhistaiśca tribhiḥ kāyendriyeṇa ca /
column2: He who possesses the organ of touch does possess these same three indriyas.
He who possesses one of the organs of sense consciousness necessarily possesses five organs.
He who possesses the organ of sight also possesses the vital organ, the mental organ, the organ of indifference and the organ of touch.
The same for him who possesses the organ of hearing, etc. The same for him who possesses the organ of satisfaction.
He who possesses the organ of satisfaction also possesses the vital organ, the mental organ, the organ of equanimity and the organ of pleasure.
But, one would ask, what sort of organ of pleasure can a being possess who is born in the heaven of the Second Dhyāna and who does not therein cultivate the absorption of the Third Dhyāna?
He possesses the organ of defiled pleasure of the Third Dhyāṇna.
He who possesses the organ of displeasure certainly possesses seven organs. This being evidently belongs to Kāmadhātu since he possesses the organ of displeasure.
He necessarily possesses the vital organ, the mental organ, the organ of touch and four organs of sensation: the organ of dissatisfaction is not in him when he is detached.

Whoever possesses the female organ, etc. , necessarily possesses eight organs. One should understand: Whoever possesses the female organ, or the male organ, or the organ of dissatisfaction, or one of the moral faculties, faith, force, memory, absorption, and discernment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ strīndriyeṇa samanvāgataḥ so 'vaśyamaṣṭabhiḥ taiśca saptabhiḥ strīndriyeṇaca / ādiśabdena puruṣendriyadaurmanasyaśaraddhādīnāṃ saṃgrahaḥ /
column2: He who possesses a sexual organ necessarily possesses, in addition to this organ, seven organs, which have been specified in for this being evidently belongs to Kāmadhātu.

He who possesses one of the moral faculties can be born in any of the three spheres of existence;
he necessarily possesses the five moral faculties, which are seen together, plus the vital organ, the mental organ, and the organ of indifference.

He who possesses ājñendriya ot ājñatavīndriya necessarily possesses eleven organs. These are the vital organ, the mental organ, the organs of pleasure, satisfaction, and equanimity; the five moral faculties;

He who possesses ājñásyāmīndriya necessarily possesses thirteen organs. In fact, it is only in Kamadhātu that one cultivates the Path of Seeing the Truths. Thus the possessor of this ⁴ṉdriya is a being in Kāmadhātu.

He necessarily possesses the vital organ, the mental organ, the organ of touch, the four organs of sensation, the five moral faculties and gñāsyāmīndriya. He does not necessarily possess the organ of dissatisfaction, nor the organs of sight, etc. ; in fact, he can be “detached,” in which case dissatisfaction is not in him;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha yaḥ srvālpaiḥ samanvāgataḥ sa kiyadbhirindriyaiḥ /
column2: he can be blind, etc. What is the smallest number of organs it is possible for a being to possess?
A being who is lacking any good at all possesses a minimum of eight organs, the organ of touch, sensations, the vital organ, and the mental organ.
A being who is lacking good is one who has cut off the roots of good. He necessarily belongs to Kāmadhātu; he cannot be “detached.”
Thus he necessarily possesses the organs enumerated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vedanā hi vit vedayata iti kṛtvā / vedanaṃ vā vit / yathā saṃpadanaṃ saṃpat / yathā ca niḥśāubhaḥ sarvālpairaṣṭābhirindriyairyuktaḥ
column2: That is one who feels by understanding kéartari kvip or sensation.
It is the same with an ignorant person who is born in Ārūpyadhātu.
The Prthagjana is termed ignorant because he has not seen the Truths.
He possesses eight organs, namely, equanimity, life, the mental oṟgaṉ, and the good orgaṉs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekāntakuśalatvāt śraddhādīni śubhagrahaṇena gṛhyante / ājñāsyāmīndriyādīnāmapi grahaṇaprasaṅgaḥ / na / aṣṭādhikārād dvālādhikārācca //
column2: The good organs are the moral faculties, faith, etc. Since it is a question of an ignorant person, and since the total is eight, the pure organs aṟe not aḻḷuded to here by the author.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha yaḥ sarvabahubhirindriyaiḥ samanvāgataḥ sa kiyadbhiḥ /
column2: What are the largest number of organs it is possible for a being to possess?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bahubhiryukta ekānnaviṃāśatyā 'malavarjitaiḥ / anā sravaṇi trīṇi varjayitvā / sa punaḥ /
column2: At the maximum, nineteen with the exception of the immaculate oṟgans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dviliṅgaḥ dvivyañjano yaḥ samagrendriyaḥ ekānnaviṃśatyā samanvāgataḥ /
column2: A bisexual being necessarily belongs to Kāmadhātu.
He is not detached;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āryo rāgī avītarāgo 'pi śaikṣaḥ sarvabahubhirekānnaviṃśatyā samanvāgataḥ / ekaliṅgadvayamalavarjitaiḥ // ekaṃ vyañjanaṃ dve cānāsrave varjayitvā /
column2: he can possess the moral faculties;
and he can possess all the organs of sense consciousness. But he is a Prthagjana: thus he necessarily lacks the pure organs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ukta indriyāṇāṃ dhātuprabhedaprasaṅgenāgatānāṃ vistareṇa prabhedaḥ / idamidānīṃ vicāryate /
column2: The pure organs are termed immaculate in the Kārikā. The ājñāṣyāmi, the ājñā and the ġjñāṭāvin. are puṟe because they are not in.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kimete saṃskṛtā dharmā yathā bhinnalakṣaṇā evaṃ bhinnotpādā utāho niyatasahotpādā api kecitsanti / santītyāha / [052/20-052/21
column2: The conditioned dharmas are, as we have seen, of different natures—physical matter, sensation, ideas, etc. One asks if, in the same way, they arise independently one from another; or rather if, in certain cases, they necessarily arise together.
Certain conditioned dharmas are divided into five categories: rāpa or physical matter; cāka or the mind;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpaṃ cittaṃ caitasikāścttaviprayuktāḥ saṃskārā asaṃskṛtaṃ ca /
column2: caitas, mental states or ḍharmas associated with the mind; côṭhaviprayuktas, i.
, saṁskāras not. we do not have to occupy ourselves with them here.
We shall first study the simultaneous arising of the material dharmas.
In Kāmadhātu, an atom into which there is no entry of sound, and into which there is no entry of any organ, is made up of eight substances;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvasūkṣmo hi rūpasaṃghātaḥ paramāṇur ity ucyāte / yato nānyataro vijñāyeta /
column2: By paramāṇu, we do not understand here a paramāṇu in its proper sense, a dravyaparamāṇu, an atom or monad which is a thing, a ṣsubstance , but a saṁghātaparamāṇu, a molecule, ie. , the most subtle among the aggregates of matter, for there is nothing, among the aggregates of matter, which is more subtle.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa kāma ghātāvaśabdako 'nindriyaścāṣṭadravyaka utpadyate nānyatamena hīnaḥ/
column2: In Kāmadhātu, the molecule into which sound does not enter, and into which no organ enters, is made up of eight substances, but of 1n0 less than eight: namely the four primary elements (ahābhāñtas, i.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭo dravyāṇicatvāri mahābhūtāni catvāri copādāyarūpāṇi rūpagandharasaspraṣṭavyāni /
column2: 12c), and the four derived elements,—visibles , odors, tastes, and tangibles .

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sendriyastu paramāṇuraśabdako navadravyaka utpadyate daśadravyako vā / tatra tāvat kāyendriyī navadravyaḥ kāyendriyamatrāstīti so 'yaṃ kāyendriyī / tatra navadravyāṇi / tāni cāṣṭau kāyendriyaṃ ca /
column2: When the organ of touch enters into it, it is made up ofThe molecule into which sound does not enter, but into which the organ of touch enters, admits of a ninth substance, the dravya which is the organ of touch.
When any other organ enters into it, it is made up of ten substances.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aparamindriyaṃ yatra paramāṇau tatra daśa dravyāṇi / tānyeva nava cakṣuḥśrotraghrāṇajihvendriyāṇāṃ cānyatamam /
column2: The molecule into which sound does not enter, but into which all other organs other than the organ of touch (the organ of sight, cakṣurindriya, etc. ) enter, consists of a tenth substance, the dravya that is this other organ : for the organs of seeing, hearing, etc. do not exist independently of the organ of touch nor do they constitute distinct gyatanas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saśabdā punarete paramāṇava utpadyamānā yathākramaṃ navadaśaikādaśa dravyakā utpadyante / asti hīndriyāvinirbhāgī śabdo 'pi ya upāttamahābhūtahetukaḥ /
column2: When sound enters into the aforementioned aggregates, the total rises to nine, ten, or eleven substances: in fact, sound which is produced by the primary elements that form part of the organism does rot exist independently of the organs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamihāvinirbhāge bhūtānāṃ kaścideva saṃghātaḥ kaṭhina utpadyate kaścideva drava uṣṇo vā samudīraṇo vā /
column2: If the four primary elements, earth element, etc. , are never dissociated, but coexist in every aggregate or molecule, how is it that, in any given aggregate, one perceives either solidity, or viscosity, orOne perceives in any given aggregate those substances that are most active in it, and not the others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyatra paṭutamaṃ prabhāvata udbhūtaṃ tasya tatropalabdhiḥ /
column2: In the same way, when one touches a pile of pieces of plants and needles, one perceives the needles;
when one eats some salted soup, one perceives the taste of salt.
How does one know that a given aggregate consists of the primary elements when their presence in it is not perceived?
All of the primary elements manifest their presence through their own actions, namely support, cohesion, maturing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratyayalābhe ca sati kaṭhinādīnāṃ dravaṇā dibhāvāt apsu śaityātiśayādauṣṇyaṃ gamyata ityapare / avyati bhede 'pi tu syācchaityātiśayaḥ /
column2: According to another opinion, that of the Bhadanta Śrīlabha, the aggregates are made up of the four primary elements, since, given the action of certain causes, solid things become liquid, etc. The fire element exists in water, since this latter is more or less cold, a fact which is explained by the presence of the element of fire in a more or less great quantity. But, we would say, whether cold is more or less active does not imply that there has been a mixture of a certain substance, the cold, with its opposite, heat.
So too sound and sensation, even though homogeneous, vary in intensity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bījatas teṣu teṣāṃ bhāvo na svarūpata ityapare /
column2: According to another opinion, the primary elements which are not perceived in a given aggregate exist in the state of potentiality, and not in action, and not in and of themselves. Thus the Blessed One was able to say (Semyuktagama, TD, p.

, a), “There are many dhaeus or mineral substances in this piece of wood.” The Blessed One meant that this piece of wood contained the seeds, the potentialities of many dhatu; for gold, silver, etc. , do not exist in the wood at the present time.
How does one prove the presence of color in wind?
This is an object of faith, and not of reasoning.
Or rather physical matter exists in the wind, since one perceives smell by reason of the contact of the wind with an object possessing an odor; now odor is never disassociated from physical matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpadhātau gandharasayorabhāva uktastena tatratyāḥ paramāṇavaḥ ṣaṭsaptāṣṭadravyakā ityuktarūpatvāt na punarucyante /
column2: We know that odor and taste are missing in Rūpadhātu; one must then reduce the number of molecules in Rūpadhātu. We will have six, seven, or eight substances, and when sound intervenes, seven, eight, or nine. We shall not explain this in detail.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaratra dravyameva dravyaṃ gṛhyate āhosvidāyatanam / kiṃ cātaḥ / yadi dravyameva dravyaṃ gṛhyate atyalpamidamucyate aṣṭadravyako navadaśādravyaka iti /
column2: Are we to understand dravyas as individual substances, as things that have their own characteristics, or as āyaṭanas that one can term dravyas, substances, since they each possess distinctive general characteristics? In the first hypothesis the numbers proposed are too few.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avaśyaṃ hi taddravyasaṃsthānenāpi bhavitavyam / tasyāpi paramāṇusaṃcitatvāt / gurutvalaghutvayoścānyatareṇa ślakṣṇatvakarkaśatvayośca /
column2: A molecule, you say, consists of four “derived elements,” r%pa first: it will consist of, we would say, not only of the rūpa of color (varṇa, blue or red dravya, etc. ) but also of the r%pa of figure, since many atoms are agglomerated in these. It consists of the “derived matter” called “tangible:” it will be, we should say, heavy or light, hard.

It could be cold or hunger, or thirst; it then consists of the dravyas that are either heaviness or lightness, softness or hardness, cold, hunger and thirst. Hence the numbers proposed above are too few.
But if, on the contrary, the Vaibhāṣikas mean to speak of dravyas as āyatanas, then the numbers are still too few, for the primary elements form part of the āyatana "tangible";

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturdravyako hi vaktavyo yāvatā bhūtānyapi spraṣṭavyāyatanam /
column2: one should then say that a molecule consists of four substances, visible, odor, taste, and touch. Our definition of a molecule is the best one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiñcidatra dravyameva dravyaṃ gṛhyate yadāśrayabhūtaṃ kiñcidatrāyatanaṃ dravyaṃ gṛhyate yadāśritabhūtam /
column2: The word dravya is to be understood, in this case, as substances properly so-called, and as āyatanas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamapi bhūyāṃsi bhūtadravyāṇi bhavantyupādāyarūpāṇāṃ pratyekaṃ bhūtacatuṣkāśritatvāt / atra punarjātidravyaṃ gṛhyate /
column2: Among the eight dravyas of a molecule, there are four substances properly so-called, the four primary elements, the supports and sources of derived matter;

and four āyatanas, four types of derived matter, supported by the primary elements: visibles, odors, tastes and tangibles. The molecule will then consist of twenty dravyas. No, for we are speaking of the nature of the primary elements, solidity, etc. The nature of all four of the primary elements remains the same, in that they support the derived element of odor or the derived elements of visibles, tastes, and tangibles.
But why do you express yourself in an ambiguous manner and use the word dravya in two different meanings?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cchandato 'pi hi vācāṃ pravṛttirarthastu parīkṣyaḥ / ukto rūpiṇāṃ sahotpādaniyamaḥ / śeṣāṇāṃ vaktavyastatra tāvat /
column2: Words are subject to caprice, but one must examine their meaning.
The mind and its mental states are necessarily generated together.
The mind and its mental states cannot be independently generated.
All things are necessarily generated with their characteristics.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatkiṃ cidutpadyate rūpaṃ cittaṃ caitasikā viprayuktā vā sarvaṃ saṃskṛtalakṣaṇaiḥ sārdhamutpadyate /
column2: All conditioned dharmas, physical matter, the mind, its mental states, and the sumséāras disassociated from the mind, are necessarily generated with their sarūskrtalakṣaṇas—arising, duration, old age, and impermanence.
Among the conditioned dharmas, those that are integral to living beings are necessarily generated with the prāpti relative to each one of them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prāptyā saha satvākhyamevotpadyate nānyaditi vikalpārtho vāśabdaḥ /
column2: There is no prāpi for the others.
That is why the Kārikā says “sometimes.
” What are the mental states?
The mental states are of five types, mahābhūmikas, etc. The mental states are the mahābhāmikas, those that accompany all minds; the euśalamahābhūmikas, those that accompany all good minds;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañca prakārāścaittā mahābhūmikāḥ kuśalamahābhūmikāḥ kleśamahābhūmikāḥ akuśalamahābhūmikāḥ parīttakleśamahābhūmikāśca /
column2: the kleśamahābhūmikas, those that accompany all defiled minds; the aknśalamahābhūmikas, those that accompany all bad minds; and the parītakleśabhūmikas, those that have small defilements for their sphere.
Bhūmi or sphere signifies “place of origin.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo hi yasya gativiśayaḥ sa tasya bhūmirityucyate / [054/15-054/16
column2: ” The place of origin of a dharma is the bhūmi of this dharma. The “great sphere” or mahābhāmi is so called because it is the sphere, the place of origin, of great dharmas (that is, of dharmas of great extension, that are found everywhere).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra mahatī bhūmireśāmiti mahābhūmikāḥ ye sarvatra cetasi bhavanti /
column2: The dharmas that areInherent in the mahābhūmi are called mahābhūmika, that is, the dharmas that are always found in all minds.
What are the mahābhūmikas, the mental states found in all minds?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vedanā cetanā saṃjñā cchandaḥ sparśo matiḥ smṛtiḥ / manaskāro 'dhimokṣaśca samādhiḥ sarvacetasi //
column2: Sensation, volition, motion, desire for action, contact, discernment, memory, the act of attention, approval, and absorption or concentration coexist in every mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ime kila daśa dharmāḥ sarvatra cittakṣaṇe samagrā bhavanti /
column2: According to the School, all the ten dharmas exist in every moment of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra vedanā trividho 'nubhavaḥ / sukho duḥkho 'duḥkhā sukhaśca /
column2: Vedanā is the threefold sensation, pleasant, painful, and neither painful-nor-pleasant.
Cetanā is that which conditions, informs, and shapes the mind.
Saṁjñā is saṁjñāna, that which grasps the marks of an object.
Chanda is the desire for action.

§parśa is the state of contact arisen out of the encounter of the organ, the object and the consciousness; in other words, the harṇa by virtue of which the organ, the object, and the consciousness are as if they were touching one another.
Prajñā, which the Kārikā designates under the name of 7muari, is.
Smrṭi is non-failing with regard to the object; a dharma by virtue of which the mind does not forget the object, by virtue of which it cherishes it in order to so express it.
Manaskāra īs the modification of the mind; in other words, “to bend” or “to apply” the mind towards an object.
Adhimukti īs approval.

Samadhi is the unity of the object with the mind: this is the dharma by virtue of which the mind, in an uninterrupted series, remains on an object. How do we know that these ten mental states, distinct in nature, coexist in one and the same mind?

Subtle, unquestionably, are the specific characteristics of the mind and its mental states. One discerns them, only with difficulty even when one is content to consider each of the mental states as developing in a homogeneous series;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa eva duḥparicchedaḥ pravāheṣvapi tāvat kiṃ punaḥ kṣaṇeṣu /
column2: how much more so when one envisions them in the moment in which they all exist.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpiṇīnāmapi tāvadoṣadhīnāṃ bahurasānāṃ kāsaṃcidindriyagrāhyā rasaviśeṣā duravadhārā bhavanti kiṃ punarye dharmā arūpiṇo buddhigrāhyāḥ /
column2: If the differences of the taste of vegetables, tastes that weKnow through a material organ, are difficult to distinguish, how much more so is this true with non-material dbarmas that are perceived through the mental consciousness. The “sphere” of the good dharmas of great extension is termed kuśalamāhabhūmi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalā mahābhūmireṣāṃ ta ime kuśala mahābhūmikā ye sarvadā kuśale cetasibhavanti / ke punasta iti /
column2: The mental states that arise from this sphere are termed kuśalamabhābhūmśkas: the dharmas that are found in all good minds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śraddhā 'pramādaḥ praśrabdhirupekṣā hrīrapatrapā / mūladvayamahiṃsā ca vīryaṃ ca kuśale sadā //
column2: Faith, diligence, aptitude, indifference, respect, fear, two roots, non-violence, and energy are found only in a good mind, and are found in all good minds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ime daśa dharmā kuśale cetasi nityaṃ bhavanti /
column2: These ten dharmas are always found in all good minds.
Śraddha or faith is clarification of the mind.

According to another opinion, it is adherence to the doctrine of the results of actions, to the Three Precious Ones, and to the Truths. Apramāda or diligence is bhāvanā, that is, the taking possession of, and the cultivation of good dharmas. The taking possession of and the cultivation of good dharmas is none other than the good dharmas being grasped and.
Diligence is application to good dharmas.
One says, by metaphor, that it is bhāvaná.
By this fact, it is the cause of bhāvaṇā.
According to another school, diligence is the guarding of the mind.
Prasrabdhi is the dharma through which the mind is clever, light, and apt.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca sūtre kāyapraśrabdhirapyuktā / na khalu noktā /
column2: But, does not the Sutra speak of the praśrabdbi of the body? The Sūtra speaks of the prasrabdhi of the body as it speaks of bodily sensation. All sensation is, in its nature, mental; sometimes the Sūtra terms the sensation that has for its support the five organs constituted of atoms a “bodily” sensation associated with the five sense consciousnesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sā tu yathā kāyikī vedanā tathā veditavyā /
column2: In the same way that prasrabdhi of the mind depends on the five organs, praśrabdhi of the five sense consciousnesses is termed “praśrabdhi of the body.”

How can the praśrabdhi of the body, thus understood, be counted among the parts of Bodhi (saṁbodhyaṁga, vi68)? In fact, the five sense consciousnesses are of the sphere of. Kāmadhātu, for they are not “absorbed,” that is, they are not produced in the state of absorption, whereas the parts of Bodhi are “absorbed”.
Thus, in our opinion, in the Sūtra alluded to, prasrabdhi of the body is aptitude of the body.
How can prasrabdhi of the body, thus understood, be a part of Bodhi? The aptitude of the body is, in fact, impure.
But it is propitious to prafrabdhi of the mind, which is a part of Bodhi;
for this reason it receives the name “part of Bodhi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti punaḥ svacit anyatrāpyevaṃ dṛśyate / astītyāha /
column2: ” The Sūtra often expresses itself in this manner.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā prītiḥ prītisthānīyāśca dharmāḥ prītisaṃbodhyaṅgamuktaṃ bhagavatā /
column2: For example, it teaches that joy constitutes the part of Bodhi called joy.
It teaches that hostility and the causes of hostility constitute the obstacle of wickedness.

It teaches that insight, resolution, and effort constitute “the element of speculative consciousness”: for neither resolution, which is by its nature discursive thought, nor effort, which is by nature energy, are speculative consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naca saṃkalpavyāyāmau prajñāsvabhāvau tasyāstvanuguṇāviti tāsyātvanuguṇāviti tācchaydyaṃ labhete /
column2: but they are favorable to this consciousness and are, consequently, considered as.
Prafrabāhi of the body, being a condition of prastabdhi of the mind, is placed, as are these, with these, among the parts of Bodhi.

Upekṣā or equanimity, is mental indifference, the dharma by which the mind remains equal, even, free from modification. If all minds are associated with attention, which is of the nature of “inflexion” or modification, how can all good minds be associated with equanimity, which is by its nature noninflexion? We have already remarked on this: the specific characteristics of the mind and its mental states are very difficalt to know and determine. This is not the point;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “tatraiva citte ābhogātmako manaskāro 'nābhogātmikā copekṣe“ti / nanu coktaṃ “durjñāna eṣāṃ viśeṣa” iti / asti hi nāma durjñānamapi jñāyate / idam tu khalvatidurjñānaṃ yadvirodhe 'pyavirodha iti /
column2: it is quite inadmissible that the same mind be associated with mental states which repudiate both modification and non-modification, and both pleasure and displeasure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyatrābhogo 'nyatrānābhoga iti ko 'tra virodhaḥ / na tarhīdānīmekālambanāḥ sarve saṃprayuktāḥ prāpnuvanti / evañjātīyakamatrānyadapyāyāsyatīti yastasya nayaḥ so 'syāpi veditavyaḥ /
column2: There is modification towatds a certain object, and non-modification with regard to another object: hence, there is no contradiction to the coexistence of modification and nonmodification. If this is so, then associated mental statesFor us, the dharmas that are contradictory, here manaskāra and upekṣā and otherwise vītarka and vicāra, do not exist simultaneously, but successively.
We shall explain respect and fear later.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mūladvayaṃ dve kuśalamūle alobhādveṣau / amoho 'pyasti sa tu prajñātmakaḥ /
column2: The two roots of good are absence-of-desire and absence-of-hatred.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prajñā ca mahābhūmiketi nāsau kuśalamahābhūmika evocyate /
column2: Absence-of-error, the third root of good, is "discernment," prajña, by nature: hence it is already named among the mahābhūmikas.
Non-violence is non-cruelty.
Energy is endurance of the mind.
Such are the mental states that are associated with all good minds.
The sphere of the mahākleśadharmas is termed mahākleśabhūmi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kleśā mahābhūmireṣāṃ ta ime kleśamahābhūmikā ye dharmāḥ sadaiva kliṣṭe cetasi bhavanti /
column2: The mental states that belong to this sphere, that is, the mental states that exist in all defiled minds, are kleśamahābhūmikas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ke punaste sadaiva kliṣṭe cetasi bhavanti /
column2: What are the defiled mental states?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mohaḥ pramādaḥ kauśīdyamā śraddhyaṃ styānmuddhavaḥ / kliṣṭe sadaiva
column2: Error, non-diligence, idleness, disbelief, torpor, and dissipation are always and exclusively in soiled minds.
Error, moha is ignorance, non-knowledge.
Non-diligence, pramādáa, the opposite of diligence, is the not taking possession of and the non-cultivation of good dharmas.
Idleness, kausīdya, is the opposite of energy.
Disbelief, āśraddhya, is the opposite of faith. Torpor, ṣ$yāna, is the opposite of aptitude.
The Abhidharma says: “What is torpor?
The weight of the body, the weight of the mind, inaptitude of the body, inaptitude of the mind.
Torpor of the body and torpor of the mind are termed torpor.
” Now torpor is a “mental state. ” How can one have torpor of the body?
In the same way that there is bodily sensation.
Dissipation, axddhatya, is non-calmness of the mind.
Only these six dharmas are kleśamahābhūmikas.
But the Mūla Abhidharma says, on the one hand that there are ten klefamaḥābhūmikas, but on the other hand, it omits torpor from its enumeration. What are these ten?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “āśraddhyaṃ kauśīdyaṃ muṣitasmṛtitā cetaso vikṣepaḥ avidyā asaṃprajanyamayoniśomanaskāro mithyādhimokṣa auddhatyaṃ pramādaśce” ti / praptijño devānāṃ priyo na tviṣṭijñaḥ /
column2: They are disbelief, idleness, default of memory, distraction, ignorance, non-observation, wrong judgment, wrong resolution, dissipation. How foolish you are, grasping the letter of the text and ignoring its intention!
What is its intention?

Five of the dharmas mentioned in the Abhidharma as elesamahabhūmikas, namely default of memory, distraction, nonobseṟvation, wrong jugment, and wrong resolution, have already been mentioned as vzahḥābhūmkas: there is no reason to name them again as kleśamahābhūmikas.

The same for the root of good non-error: even though it is a eusalamahabhūmika, it is not catalogued as such, because, being prajña by nature, it is classed as a mahabhūmika (as above, note In fact default of memory is nothing other than defiled memory is defiled samdhi.
Non-observation is defiled prajña. Wrong judgment is defiled judgment.
And wrong resolution is defiled resolution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evocyate “ye mahābhūmikāḥ kleśamahābhūmikā api ta” iti /
column2: This is why the Mula Abhidharma lists ten kJesamabhabhamikas in admitting the state of meahabhūmkas to a state of defilement. Is a mahabhūmika also a kleśamahābhūmika?
There are four alternatives: 1.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamā koṭirvedanā cetanā saṃjñā cchandaḥ sparśaśca / dvitīyā 'śrāddhyaṃ kauśīdyamavidyā auddhatyaṃ pramādaśca / tṛtīyā muṣitasmṛtyādayaḥ pañca kliṣṭā yaṭhoktāḥ / caturthyetānākārān sthāpayitveti /
column2: sensation, ideas, volition, contact andmemory, samāḍhi, prajñā, judgment, and resolution belong to both categories.
Certain Masters maintain that distraction is not wrong saemáādhi: the alternātives then are differently established: distraction is added to the second categoxy, and samādhi is put into the third.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: styānaṃ punariṣyate sarvakleśasaṃprayogīti kleśamahābhūmikeṣu tasyāpāṭhe kasyāparādhaḥ /
column2: As for the statement: “the Mūla Abhidharma omits toṟpor frorn its enumeration” of the kleśamaḥābhñūmika, it is admitted that torpor is associated with all defiled dharrnas. If torpor is omitted from the list, is this rny fault or the fault of the author of the Abhidharma? The Ābhidhārmikas explain the omission: toṟpor sbhould be named;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tvāhuḥ paṭhitavyaṃ bhavetsamādhyanuguṇatvāttu na paṭhitam /
column2: but it is not named because it is favorable to sarnādhi.
In fact, they claim, persons with a torpid disposition, or dull persons, realize meditation sooṉer than do dissipated persons.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaḥ punaḥ styānacarito yo nauddhatyacaritaḥ ko vā auddhatyacarito yo na styānacaritaḥ /
column2: But who is dull without being dissipated? Who is dissipated?
Torpor and dissipation always go together. Yes, torpor and dissipation go together. But the term carita indicates excess.

The person in whom torpor dominates is called “dull,” even though he is also dissipated. We know this as well as you do; but it is by reason of their nature that the dbarmas are classified into different categories.
It is then established that sīx dharmas are kleśamahābhāmikas, because only they are produced in all defiled rminds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ete hi sadā kleṣṭa eva cetasi bhavanti nānyatra // akuśale tvāhrīkyamanapatrapā //
column2: Disrespect and the absence of fear are always and exclusively found in bad minds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akuśale tu cetasyāhrīkyamanapatrāpyaṃ ca nityaṃ bhavata ityetau dvau dharmāvakuśalamahābhūmikāvucyete / tayośca paścāllakṣaṇaṃ vakṣyate /
column2: These two dharmas, which will be defined below are always found in bad minds. Consequently they are called aukuśalamahābhūmīkas.
Anger, enmity, dissimilation, jeaḻousy, stubbornness, hypocrisy, greed, the spirit of deception, pride-intoxication, the spirit of violence, etc. , are the parītakleśabhūmikas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: parīttakleśā bhūmireṣāṃ ta ime parīttakleśabhūmikā avidyāmātreṇa bhāvanāheyena manobhūmikenaiva ca saṃprayogāt /
column2: They are called this because they have parūtakleśas for their spheres. Parīṭṭakleśa, “small defilement,” meaṅs avidyā oṟ ignorance. They are only associated with ignorance, with the ignorance that is cast off through the Path of Meditation, ignorance of the sphere of mental consciousness.
This is why they are called parītak’eśabhāmikas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktā ime pañcaprakārāścaittāḥ / anye 'pi cāniyatāḥ santi vitarkavicārakaukṛtyamiddhādayaḥ /
column2: We have studied five categories of mental states.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra vaktavyaṃ kasmiṃścitte kati caittā avaśyaṃ bhavantīti /
column2: There are other mental states that are indeterminate, aniyata, which are sometimes associated with a good mind, and sometimes with a bad or a neutral mind: regret, apathy, vitarka, vicāra, etc. How many mental states are necessarily produced with each mind of each class—with a good, bad, or neutral mind? The mind in Kāmadhātu, when it is good, always consists of twenty-two mental states, as it is always associated with vitarka aṇḍ vicāra.
There are five classes of minds in Kāmadhātu: 1) the good mind constitutes one class;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrākuśalaṃ dvividhamāveṇikamanyakleśasaṃprayuktaṃ ca / avyākṛtaṃ dvividhaṃ nivṛtāvyākṛtam anivṛtāvyākṛtaṃ ca /
column2: 2-3) the bad mind constitutes two classes, accordingly as it is “independent,” that is, associated only with.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra tāvat kāmāvacaracittamavaśyaṃ savitarkaṃ savicāram / ato 'tra savitarkavicāratvāt kuśale kāmacetasi /
column2: The mind in Kāmadhātu is always associated with vitarka and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvāviṃśatiścaitasikāḥ avaśyaṃ bhavanti / daśa mahābhūmikā daśa kuśalamahābhūmikā vitarko vicāraśca / kaukṛtyamadhikaṃ kvacit //
column2: This mind, when it is good, consists of twenty-two mental states: ten mahābhūmikas, ten kuśalamahābhūṁmikas, plus two aniyatas, ṇamely vitarka and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi sarvatra kuśale cetasi kaukṛtyamasti / yatra tvasti tatra tadevādhikaṃ kṛtvā trayoviṃśatiścaittā bhavanti /
column2: When the good mind includes regret (kaukṛtya, the total rises to twenty-three.
What does the word kaxkṛtya mean?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kukṛtasya bhāvaḥ kaukṛtyam / iha tu punaḥ kaukṛtyālambano dharmaḥ kaukṛtyamucyate cetaso vipratisāraḥ /
column2: Kaukr̥tya is, properly, the nature of that which is wrongly done, but here éaukrṛ̥tya means a mental state that has for its object kaukrṛ̥tya in its literal sense, namely regret relative to an eṛror.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā śūnyatālalmvanaṃ vimokṣamukhṃ śūnyatetyucyate aśubhālambanaścālobho 'śubha iti /
column2: In the same way, vômokṣaṃukha which has óūnyatā or absence of ātman for its object is termed f#nyatā ; non-desire which has asubhā or the loathsome for its object is called 4swbhā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: loke 'pi ca dṛṣṭaḥ sthānena sthānināmatideśaḥ sarvo grāma āgataḥ sarvo deśa āgata iti /
column2: In the same way, inthe world, one says that the village, the town, the country, are all brought together, designating thus the inhabitants by the name of the location.
Kaukṛtya in its proper sense is the support, the raison d'être of regret; hence regret is termed kaukṛ̥tya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phale vā hetūpacāro 'yam / yathoktaṃ “ṣaḍimāni sparśāyatanāni paurāṇaṃ karma veditavyami“ti /
column2: For the result receives the name of its cause, for example in the text: “The six sparśāyatanas are previous actions.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi akṛtālambanaṃ tat kathaṃ kaukṛtyam / akṛte 'pi kṛtākhyā bhavati /
column2: But how can one designate “regret over errors,” regret relative to an action not done, by the name of kaxukrṛtya?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na mayā sādhu kṛtaṃ yanna kṛtamiti /
column2: Because one says “It is poorly done on my part not to have done this action,” thus designating an omission as “done” or “poorly done.”
When is regret good?
When it is relative to a good action omitted or to a bad action accomplished.
It is bad when it is relative to a bad action omitted or to a good action accomplished.
These two types of regret bear on the two categories of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āveṇike tvakuśale dṛṣṭiyukte ca viṃśātiḥ / yadakuśalaṃ cittamāveṇikaṃ tatra viṃśatiścaittāḥ /
column2: A bad mind consists of twenty mental states when it is independent of, or associated with views. An independent mind is a mind associated with ignorance. A bad mind associated with views is a mind associated with mithyādr̥ṣṭi, with dṛṣṭiparāmarśa, or with śūavrataparāmarśa; a mind associated with satkāyadrṭi and with antagrāhadrṣṭi is not bad, but defiled-neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśa mahābhūmikāḥ ṣaṭ kleāśamahābhūmikā dvāvakuśalamahābhūmikau vitarkovicāraśca / āveṇikaṃ nāma cittaṃ yatrāvidyaiva kevalā nānyaḥ kleśo 'sti rāgādiḥ / dṛṣṭiyukte 'pyakuśale viṃśatirya evāveṇike / nanu ca dṛṣṭyadhikatvādeka viṃśatirbhavanti /
column2: In these two cases, a bad mind consists of ten ahābhūmikas, six kleśfamahābhūmikas, two akuśalamaḥhābhūmikas, plus two anīyatas, namely vôtarka and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na bhavanti / yasmānmahābhūmika eva kaścit prajñāviśeṣo dṛṣṭirityucyate / tatrākuśalaṃ dṛṣṭiyuktaṃ yatra mithyādṛṣṭirvā dṛṣṭiparāmarśo vā śīlavrataparāmarśo vā /
column2: View itself is not counted, for a view is a ceṛtain type of prajñā, and prajñā is a mahābhūmika.
