prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kleśaiścaturbhiḥ krodhādyaiḥ kaukṛtyenaikaviṃśatiḥ // yatra punaścaturbhiḥ kleśaiḥ saṃprayuktamakuśalaṃ cittaṃ rāgeṇa va pratighena vā mānena vā vicikitsayā vā tatraikaviṃśatirbhavanti / sa ca kleśaḥ āveṇikoktāśca viṃśatiḥ /
column2: Twenty-one, when it is associated with one of the four defilements, with anger, etc. , with regret.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: krodhādibhirapyupakleśairyathoktaiḥ saṃprayukte citte ete ca viṃśatiḥ sa copakleśa ityekaviṃśatirbhavanti / kaukṛtyenāpyekaviṃśatiḥ / tadeva kaukṛtyamekaviṃśatitamaṃ bhavati /
column2: Assocūated with lust, hostility, pride, or doubt, a bad mind consists of twenty-one mental states, the same as above, plus lust or hostility, etc. Associated with anger, etc. , that is, with one of the minor defilements enumerated above.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāsata āveṇike cetasyakuśale dṛṣṭiyukte ca viṃśatiḥ / anyakleśopakleśasaṃprayukte tvekaviṃśatiḥ / nivṛte 'ṣṭadaśa
column2: A neutral mind consists of eighteen mental states when it is defiled;
In Kāmadhātu, a neutral mind, that is, a mind free of retribution, is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāṣṭādaśa caittāḥ / daśa mahābhūmikāḥ ṣaṭ kleśamahābhūmikāḥ vitarkavicārau ca / dṛṣṭiḥ pūrvavadeva nādhikā bhavati /
column2: This mind consists of ten wmeahābhūmikas, sīx kleśamaḥhābhūmikas, plus vitarēa and vicāra.
In the contraty case, twelve.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nivṛtādanyadavyākṛtamanivṛtāvyākṛtam / tatra dvādaśa caittā iṣṭāḥ / daśa mahābhūmikā vitarkavicārau ca /
column2: Not defiled, a neutral mind consists of twelve mental states: the teṉ ahābhūmikas, vitarka, aṅd vicāra.
The Foreigners believe that regret can be indefinite, for example, in a dream.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ tatsaṃprayukte cetasi trayodaśa bhavanti / middhaṃ sarvāvirodhitvādyatra syādadhikam hi tat //
column2: An indefinite-non-defiled mind associated with indefinite regret would consist of thirteen rnental states. Apathy is not in contradiction to any category; wherever it is found, it is added.
Apathy can be good, bad, or neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato tatra tatsyāt tatrādhikaṃ tadveditavyam / yatra dvāviṃśatistatra trayoviṃśatiryatra trayoviṃśatistatra caturviṃśatirityevamādi / ya eva kāmadhātau caittānāṃ niyama uktaḥ kaukṛtyamiddhākuśalānyādye dhyāne na santyataḥ / ato yathoktāt kaukṛtyaṃ middhaṃ ca sarvathā nāsti prathame dhyāne yat kiñcidakuśalam /
column2: The mind with which it is associated would then consist of twenty-three mental states instead of twenty-two, twenty-four instead of twentythree, etc. , accordingly as it is good and free from regret, or good and accompanied by regret, etc. The bad mental states, regret and apathy, aṟe absent from the First Dhyāṇna.

In the Fitst Dhyāna there is missing 1) hostility , 2)The series anger, etc. with the exception of hypocrisy, deception, and pride-intoxication. The two akśalamahābhūmikas, disrespect and the absence of fear, plus regret, since dissatisfaction is absent, and laziness, since food through the mouth is absent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyatsarva tathaiva / ya eva prathame dhyāne na santi ta eva
column2: The other mental states of Kāmadhātu exist in the First Dhyāṇa. Further on, vitarka is also missing absent from the intermediate ḍhyāna.
Furthermore, vifarka is absent from the intermediate dhyāna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vicāraścāpyataḥ param // dhyānāntarāt pareṇa dvitīyādiṣu dhyāneṣvārūpyeṣu ca yathāpratiṣiddhaṃ nāsti vicāraśca / māyā śāṭhyaṃ cetyapiśabdāt / śeṣaṃ tathaiva /
column2: Further on, again, vicāra, etc. In the Second Dhyāna and above, up to and including Ārāpyadhātu, vicāra, hypocrisy, and deception are also absent. Pride-intoxication exists in the three spheres of existence.
According to the Sūtra, hypocrisy and deception exist as far as the world of Brahmā, but not above the heavens where beings are in assembly.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa hi svasyāṃ parṣadyaśvajitā bhikṣuṇā praśnaṃ pṛṣṭaḥ “kutremāni brahman catavāri mahābhūtānyapariśeṣaṃ nirudhyante” iti / aprajānan kṣepamakārṣīt /
column2: Mahābrahmā, sitting in his assembly, was questioned by the Bhikṣu Aśvajit: “Where do the four primary elements completely disappear?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “ahamasmin brahmā īśvaraḥ kartā nirmātā sraṣṭā sṛjaḥ pitṛbhūto bhūtānāmi“ti /
column2: ” Incapable of responding, he boasted: “I am Brahmā, great. ”Finally, when Aśvajit was leaving the assembly, Brahmā counselled him to return to the presence of the Master and ask him.
We have seen how many mental states are associated with each type of mind of the three spheres of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idānīṃ keṣāñcideva caittānāṃ tantravihitaṃ nānākāraṇaṃ vakṣyate /
column2: We have to define the mental states enumerated above.
What is the difference between disrespect and absence of fear?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: guṇeṣu guṇavatsu cāgauravatā apratīśatā abhayamavaśavartitā āhrīkyaṃ gauravapratidvandvo dharmaḥ //
column2: Disrespect is lack of veneration. Lack of respect, that is, the lack of veneration, the lack of fearful submission with regard to the qualities of oneself and others, and with regard to persons endowed with these qualities, is āhtīkya; ahrī is a mental dharma opposed to respect.
Anapatrāpya ot atrapā is the dharma that causes a person not to see the unpleasant consequences of his transgressions.
Transgressions are what are scorned by good persons.

Unpleasant consequences are called in the Kārikā bhaya or fear. The condition of the person who does not see the unpleasant consequences of transgression, the dharma that produces this condition, is anapatrāpya or akrapā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamidaṃ vijñātavyam abhayasya darśanamabhayadarśitā āhosvit bhayasyādarśanam /
column2: What do you understand by the expression "does not see the unpleasant consequences" abhayadarfiva? Whether you interpret this phrase as abhayasya darśitvam, "he sees that there are no unpleasant consequences," or as bhayasya adarfitvam, "he does not see that there are unpleasant consequences, none of these explanations is satisfactory. In the first case, we have defiled prajñā, an inexact knowledge;
in the second case, we simply have ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhayasya darśanaṃ cet prajñā vijñāsyate bhayasyādarśanaṃ cedavidyā vijñāsyate / naiva hi darśanaṃ darśitā nāpyadarśanamadarśitā / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: The expression abhayadarfitvam signifies neither "view" (defiled prajñā), nor "non-view".
It describes a special dharma that is placed among the minor defilements, which has false views and ignorance for its cause, and which is termed anapatrāpya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye punarāhuḥ / ātmāpekṣayā doṣairalajjana māhrīkyaṃ parāpekṣayā 'napatrāpyamiti /
column2: According to other Masters, āḥrkya is the absence of shame vis-a-vis oneself, in the commission of a transgression; anapatrāpya is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamapi dve apekṣe yugapat kathaṃ setsyataḥ /
column2: But cannot one consider oneself and others at the same time?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na khalūcyate yugapadātmānaṃ paraṃ cāpekṣata ityapi tvastyasau kadācidalajjā yā ātmānamapekṣamāṇasyāpi pravartate sā āhrīkyam /
column2: We do not say that the two forms of the absence of shame are simultaneous. There is āhrīkya, an outflowing of lust, when the person does not experience the shame of transgression when considering oneself;
there īs anapatrāpya, an outflowing from mental confusion, when he does not experience the shame of transgression when considering others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: viparyayeṇa hrīrapatrāpyaṃ ca veditavyam / pratahamena tāvat kalpena sagauravatā sapratīśatā na bhayavaśavrtitā hrīḥ /
column2: Hrī and apatrāpya are opposed to these two bad dharma.
Their definition, according to the first theory, is "respect, veneration, fearful submission," or "fear of the consequence of transgression;
according to the second theory, modesty," "respect for humans.
Some think that affection and respect are the same thing.
Affection is faith.
Affection is of two types, defiled and non-defiled (Viébhāṣā, TD, p. The first is attachment;
for example, affection for wife and sons. The second is faith;
for example, affection for a master or for virtuous.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥdhasamudayālambanā śraddhā / syāt prema na śraddhā /
column2: All faith is not affection, namely faith with regard to the Truths of Suffering and the Arising of Suffering.
All affection is not faith, namely defiled affection.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhayaṃ nirodhamārgālambanā śraddhā / nobhayametānākārān sthāpayitvā / pudgaleṣu tu prema na gauravaṃ putradārasārdhaṃ vihāryantevāsiṣu / gauravaṃ na prema anyaguruṣu / ubhayaṃ svaguruṣu / nobhayam etānākārān sthāpayitvā /
column2: Faith can be affection, namely faith with regard to the Truths of the Extinction of Suffering and the Path. The other mental states, the dharmas disassociated from the mind, etc. , are neither faith nor affection.
According to another opinion, faith is a belief in qualities: affection is produced from this belief.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatpūrvikā ca priyatā prema / tasmānna saiva premetyapare /
column2: Affection is then not faith, but the result of faith.

Respect is hrī. As we have explained above, respect is veneration, etc. All brī is not respect, namely b1ī with respect to the Truths of Suffering and the Origin of Suffering. Hrī with respect to the Truths of the Extinction of Suffering and the Path is also respect.
According to another opinion, respect is veneration;
shame is born from respect and this shame is called.

Hence respect, the cause of hrī, is not hrī. Affectrion which is not respect, namely affection with regard to wife, to children, to companions in the religious life, to pupils. Respect which is not affection, namely respect with regard to someone else's master, to a person endowed with qualities, etc. Respect which is affection, namely respect with regard to one’s master, one’s father, mother, etc. Neither respect nor affection for other persons.
Both exist in Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu.
Affection and respect do not exist in Ārūpyadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca śraddhā hrīśca kuśalamahābhūmikatvāttatrāpi vidyete / dvividhā hi śraddhā dharmeṣu pudgaleṣu ca / evaṃ sapratīśatā 'pi / tatra ye pudgalālambane śraddhāhriyau te tatra na staḥ / te ceha premagaurave abhiprete / vitarkavicārayoḥ kiṃ nānākāraṇam /
column2: But you have said that affection is faith, and that respect is brī: now faith and hr are kuśalamaḥhābhūmikas : hence affection and respect should exist in Ārūpyadhātu, Affection and respect are of two types: relative to dharmas and relative to persons. The text refers to the second type; the first type does exist in all three spheres of existence.
Viṭarka and vicára aṟe grossness and subtlety of the miṇd.
The grossness, that is, the gross state of the mind is termed.
The subtlety, that is, the subtle state of the mind is termed vicāra.
How can vitarka and vicāra be associated with the mind at one and the same time?

Can the mind, at one and the same time, be both gross and subtle? According to one opinion, we may compare vicāra to cold water, the mind to cheese which floats on the surface of this cold water, and vitarka to the heat of the sun which operates on this cheese.
By reason of the water and sun, the cheese is not too runny nor too hard.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃvitarkavicārayogāccittaṃ nātisūkṣmaṃ bhavati nātyodārika mityubhayorapi tatrāsti vyāpāraḥ /
column2: In this same way, vitarka and vicāra are associated with the mind: it is neither too subtle, by reason of vitarka, nor too gross, by reason of vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi nimiṭtabhūtau vitarkavicārāvaudārika sūkṣmatayoḥ prāpnuto yathā payaścā tapaścasarpiṣaḥ śyānatva vilīnatvayornatu punastatsvabhāvau
column2: But, we would say, it follows from this explanation that vitarka and vicāra are not grossness and subtlety of mind, but the cause of its grossness and its subtlety: the cold water and the warm light of the sun are not the hard or the runny state of the cheese, but rather the cause of these states. Other objections present themselves.

Grossness and subtlety of. Mind are relative things. They admit of many degrees: a mind of the First Dhyāna is subtle in comparison with a mind in Kāmadhātu, but gross in comparision with a mind in the Śecond Dhyāna; the qualities and the defilements can be more or less gross or subtle in one and the same stage, for they are divided into nine categories.

Thus, if vūarka and vicāra are grossness and subtlety of the mind, we would have to admit that they both exist up to the highest stage of Ārūpyadhātu. Now they cease at the Second Dhyāna, and adding to this the fact that no specific or generic differences can be established between grossness and subtlety, one then cannot differentiate viśaréa and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye punarāhuḥ / vāksaṃskārā vitrkavicārāḥ sūtra uktāḥ /
column2: According to another opinion, vitarka and wvicāra are the “factors of voice.”

The Sūtra says in fact, "It is after having examined, after having judged that one speaks, not without having examined, not without having judged.” The factors of voice that are called gross are called vôtarkas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra ye audārikāste vitarkāḥ ye sūkṣmāste vicārāḥ /
column2: those that are subtle are called vicāras. (According to this explanation, we should)Understand vrtarka and vÉeāra not as two distinct dharmas, but rather a collection of mind and mental states which provoke speech, and which is sometimes gross, sometimes subtle.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi caikatra citte 'nyo dharma audāriko 'nyaḥ sūkṣmaḥ ko 'tra virodha iti /
column2: What contradiction is there in two dharmas, the first gross, and the second subtle, being associated with the same mind? There would not be any contradiction if these two dharmas were specifically different;
for example, sensations and ideas—although the first are gross and the second subtle—can coexist.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekasyāṃ jātau mṛdvadhimātratā yugapanna saṃbhavati / jātibhedo /pyasti /
column2: But two states of the same species, one in a strong state and the other in a weak state, one gross and one subtle, cannot coexist. But there is a specific difference between viṭarka aṇḍ vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tarhi vaktavyaḥ / durvaco hyasāvato mṛdvadhimātratayā vyajyate /
column2: What is this difference?
This difference is inexpressible; but it is manifested through the force or the weakness of the mind.
The force and the weakness of the mind do not demonstrate the presence of two specifically different dharmnas, for the same species is sometimes strong, sometimes weak.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva hi vitarkavicārāvekatra citte bhavata ityapare /
column2: According to another opinion, ours, vôarka and vicāra are not. The Vaibhāṣikas would object that the First Dhyāna has five parts among which are viarka and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamidānīṃ prathamaṃ dhyānaṃ pañcāṅgayuktam / bhūmitastat pañcāṅgayukataṃ na kṣaṇataḥ //
column2: We would answer that the First Dhyana has five parts in the sense that five parts are possible in the First Dhyāna: but any given moment of the First Dhyāna possesses only four parts, namely prii, sukha, and samādhi, plus vitarka or vicāra.
What difference is there between maṇa and wmada?
Māna, the error of pride, is arrogance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: madaḥ svadharme raktasya paryādānaṃ tu cetasaḥ //
column2: But mada, prideintoxication, is the abolition of the mind of one who is enamoured with his own qualities.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yena kenacit parato viśeṣaparikalpena cetasa unnatiḥ mānaḥ /
column2: It is arrogance of mind with respect to others. Measuring the superiority of qualities that one has, or that one believes to have over others, one becomes bhaughty and depreciates others.
Be reason of its attachment to its own qualities, the mind becomes puffed up, exhaults itself, and abolishes itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā madyaja evaṃ rāgajaḥ / saṃprahaṛśaṇaviśeṣo mada ityapare /
column2: Accoṟding to other Masters, in the same way that wine produces a certain joyous excitation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktāḥ saha cittena caittāḥ prakāraśa steṣāṃ punarimāḥ saṃjñāḥ paribhāṣyante / pravacana etābhiḥ sadvyavahārāt /
column2: We have seen in what categories the mental states are placed, in what numbers they are generated together, and what their different characteristics are. The mind and its mental states receive, in the Scriptures, different names.
The names mind, spirit, and consciousness designate the same thing.
The mind is termed citta because it accumulates;
it is termed manas because it knows, and it is termed vijnana because it distinguishes its object.
Some say that the mind is termed citta because it is spotted by good and bad elements.
To the extent that it is the support of the mind that follows, it is manas;
and to the extent that it grasps the support through the organ and its object, it is vijnana.
Hence these three names express different meanings, but they designate the same object;
in this same way.
The mind and its mental states "have a support," "have an object," "have an aspect," and are "associated.
These four different names, "have a support," etc. , designate the same object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta eva hi cittacaittāḥ sāśrayā ucyante indriyāśritatvāt /
column2: 'The mind and its mental states "have a support" because they rely on the organs;
have an object or "a subject of consciousness," because they grasp their "sphere;
have an aspect," because they take form according to their object;
and are "associated," that is, similar and united, because they are similar to one another and are not separated from each other.
How are they samprayukta or associated, that is, "similar and united?
In five ways.
The mind and its mental states are associated by reason of five equalities or identities, identity of support, of object, of aspect, of time, and equality in the number of dravyas.

That is: the mental states and the mind are associated because they have the same support, the same object, and the same aspect; because they are simultaneous; and because, in this association, each type is represented by only one individual substance : in any given moment there can be only one mind produced;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathaiva hyekaṃ cittamevaṃ caittā apyekaikā iti /
column2: to this one, unique mind there is found associated one sensation, one idea, or one mental state of each type.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirdiṣṭāścittacaittāḥ savistaraprabhedāḥ / viprayuktāstu saṃskārāḥ prāptyaprāptī sabhāgatā /
column2: We have explained the mind and its mental states, in full, with their characteristics. What are the sanskaras not associated with the mind?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āsaṃjñikaṃ samāpattī jīvitaṃ lakṣaṇāni ca // nāmakāyādayaśceti
column2: The dharmas "not associated with the mind" are prapti, aprapti, sabhagata, asanjnika, and two absorptions, life, characteristics, namakaya, etc. , and that which is of this type.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ime saṃskārā na cittena asaṃprayuktā naca rūpasvabhāvā iti cittaviprayuktāucyante / tatra tāvat
column2: These dharmas are not associated with the mind; they are not of the nature of r%pa or physical matter; they are included within the samskatraskandha: they are called the cittaviptayukta samskaras, because they are disjoined from the mind, and because, being non-material, they resemble the mind.
Prapti is acquisition and possession.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvividhā hi prāptiraprāptavihīnasya ca lābhaḥ pratilabdhena ca samanvāgamaḥ /
column2: Prapti is of two types: acquisition of that which has not been. obtained or of that which had been lost;
and possession of that which, having been obtained, has not been lost. Aprāpti is the opposite.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasya punarime prāptyaprāptī / prāptyaprāptī svasaṃtāna patitānāṃ
column2: There is prāpti and aprāpti of dharmas that belong to the person himself, when a conditioned dharma “falls into the personal series, there is prāprś ot aprāpti;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na parasaṃtānapatitānām / nahi parakīryaiḥ kaścitsamanvāgataḥ nāpyasaṃtatipatitānām /
column2: of this dharma, but not if it falls into the series of another person, for no one possesses the dharmas of another;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hyasatatvasaṃkhyātaiḥ kaścitsamanvāgataḥ / eṣa tāvat saṃskṛteṣu niyamaḥ /
column2: nor if it does not fall into any series, for no one possesses the dharmas “which are not of a living being”.
As for unconditioned dharmas, there is prāpti of pratisaṁkhyiānirodha and apratisaṁkhyānirodha.
And of the two extinctions.
All beings possess the apratisṁkhyānirodha of the dharmas that do not arise without a cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva hi cottamabhidharme “anāsravairdharmaḥ kaḥ samanvāgataḥ / āha /
column2: The Abhidharma expresses itself in this way: “Who possesses pure dharmas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvasattvā” iti / pratisaṃkhyānirodhena sakalabandhanādikṣaṇasthavarjyāḥ sarva āryāḥ pṛthagjanāśca kecitsamanvāgatāḥ / ākāśena tu nāsti kaścitsamanvāgataḥ / tasmādasya nāsati prāptiḥ / yasya ca nāsti prāptistastasyāprāptirapi nāstīti siddhāntaḥ / prāptirnāmāsti kiñcit bhāvāntarmiti / kuta etat / āha sūtrāt / sūtre hyustaṃ “sa eṣāṃ daśānāmaśaikṣāṇāṃ dharmaṇāmutpādāt pratilambhātsamanvāgamādaryo bhavati pañcāṅgaviprahīṇa” iti vistaraḥ / tena tarhi asattvākhyairapi samanvāgamaḥ prāpnoti parasattvaiśca / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: All beings possess pratisaṁkhyānirodha with the exception of the sakalabandhanaūdiégaṇasthas, that is, with the exception of the Āryans bound with all the bonds and who are found in the first moment of the Path, and withNo sentences to output.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra vacanāt / “rājā bhikṣavaścakravarti saptabhī ratnaiḥ samanvāgata” iti vistaraḥ / vaśitvamatra samanvāgamaśabdenoktam /
column2: the Cakravartin King possesses seven jewels. Now, among the jewels, there are the jewels of a wheel, a wife, etc. In this text, the expression "to possess" signifies "master of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya teṣu ratneṣu vaśitvaṃ kāmacāra iti / atra vaśitvaṃ samanvāgamo 'nyatra punardravyāntaramiti /
column2: One says that the Cakravartin King enjoys mastery over jewels, for they go as he wishes. But in the Sutra on the Possession of the Ten Dharmas of an Arhat, the word "possession" designates a thing in and of itself. If the word "possession" signifies "mastery" in the Cakravartisutra, how do you ascertain that, in another Sutra, this same word designates a supposed prapti;
a thing in and of itself?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ayam ayogaḥ yad asyā naiva svabhāvaḥ prajñāyate rūpaśabdādivad rāgadveṣādivad vā na cāpi kṛtyaṃ cakṣuḥśrotrādivat /
column2: In fact, this prapti is not directly perceived, as is the case for color, sound, etc. , and as is the case for lust, anger, etc. One cannot conclude the existence of prapri by reason of its effects, as is the case for the sense organs, the organ of sight, etc. : for a similar effect is not perceived. Possession has an effect. It is the cause of the arising of the dharmas. This answer is unfortunate. You maintain. As for the conditioned dharmas, there is not now, in any given person, possession of the dharmas that he has not yet acquired, nor does he any longer possess the dharmas whose possession he has abandoned through his changing of his sphere of existence or through “detachment; ” the possession of the first has never existed, and the possession of the second has perished.
Hence how can these dharmas arise if the cause of their arising is prāpti?

The arising of these dharmas has for its cause a prāpti which arises at the same time as they do. An unfortunate answer! If the dharmas arise by virtue of prāpti, arising and the arising-of-arising have no use; the dharmas “that do not belong to living beings” do not arise;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaṃskṛtasya na syāt / ye ca dharmā aprāptā ye ca tyaktā bhūmisaṃcāravaiarāgyatasteṣāṃ kathamutpattiḥ syāt /
column2: and how does one explain the difference in the degree of defilement,—weak, medium, and strong defilement,—among persons who are ‘bound to all bonds’?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sahajaprāptihetukā cet / jātiridānīṃ kiṅkarī jātijātirvā / sakalabandhanānāṃ khalvapi mṛdumadhyādhimātrakleśotpattibhedo na syāt prāptyabhedāt /
column2: : all in fact possess the same prāptis of all.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yato vā sa bhedastata evāstu tadutpattiḥ /
column2: Would you say that this difference proceeds from causes distinct from prāp#s? We would answer that these causes are the only cause of weak, medium, or strong defilements;
why would one want to assign it to prāpti?
Who maintains that prāpti is the cause of the arising of dharmas? Such is not the role that we attribute to it. For us, prāpti is the cause that determines the state or condition of beings.
Let us explain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asatyāṃ hi prāptau laukikamānasānāmāryapṛthagjanānāmāryā ime pṛthagjanā ima iti na syād vyavasthānam /
column2: Let us suppose the non-existence of prāptÉ: what difference would there be between an Āryan at the moment in which he produces a mundane thought and a Pṛthagjana? Now the difference consists solely in that the Āryan, even when he has a worldly thought, is in possession of a certain number of pure dharmas.
For us, there is this difference that the first has abandoned certain defilements, while the second has not yet abandoned thern. Without doubt;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etaccaiva kathaṃ bhaviṣyatyeṣāṃ prahīṇaḥ kleśa eṣāmaprahīṇa iti / praptau satyāmetatsidhyati tadvigamāvigamāt /
column2: but if we suppose the nonexistence of prāpti, how can we say that a defilement is abandoṉed orTo us, the abandoning or the non-abandoning of a defilement consists of a certain condition of the person.
The personality of the Āryan is modified, becoming different from what it was through the power of the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āśrayo hi sa āryāṇāṃ darśanabhāvanāmārgasāmarthyāttathā parāvṛtto bhavati yathā na punastatpraheyāṇāṃ kleśānāṃ prarohasamartho bhavati /
column2: The defilement, once it has been destroyed through the force of the Path, cannot be manifested again.

Like seed which is burned by fire and which becomes different from what it once was, and is no longer capable of germinating, we say that the Āryan has abandoned the defilement, because his person no longer maintains the seeds capable of producing a defilement.
The worldly path does not definitively destroy the defilement;

it only damages it or disturbs it: one would say that a Pṛthagjana who is able to practice only the worldly path has abandoned the defilement when his person no longer contains even the seeds of defilement. Contrarily one says that a person has not abandoned defilement when the seeds are neither burnt nor damaged. One says that a person is in possession of the defilement when he has not abandoned them in the manner that we have just explained;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaścāprahīṇastena samanvāgato yaḥ prahīṇastenā samanvāgata iti prajñapyate /
column2: we say that he is in non-possession of the defilements when he has not abandoned it. “Possession” and “non-possession” are not things in and of themselves, but designations. This then concerns possession and non-possession of defilement.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalā api dharmā dviprakārā ayatnabhāvino yatnabhāvinaśca ye ta ucyante utpattipratilambhikāḥ prāyogikāśceti / tatrāyatnabhāvibhirāśrayasya tadvījabhāvānupaghātāt samanvāgata upaghātādasamanvāgata ucyate samucchinnakuāśalamūlaḥ / tasya tūpaghāto mithyādṛṣṭyā veditavyaḥ /
column2: But concerning the possession and non-possession of good dharmas, we must distinguish the innate good dharmas, which do not entail any effort, and the good dharmas that are obtained through effort or cultivation. We say that a person possesses the first when his person possesses intact the quality of being a seed of these good dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tu khalu kuśalānāṃ dharmāṇāṃ vījabhāvasyātyantaṃ santatau samudghātaḥ /
column2: When this quality is damaged, we say that the person does not possess the good dharmas. In fact, while the seeds of defilement can be destroyed completely and definitively, as is the case among the Āryans, good. Dharmas never have their roots definitively cut off, with the restriction that one says of a person who has cut off the roots of good through false views that he has only abandoned these roots, because the quality of being a seed of these roots, a quality that belongs to his person, has been damaged through false views.

We say that a person possesses the second—the good dharmas produced through effort, through hearing, reflection, and meditation—when, these dharmas having arisen, his capacity to produce them is not damaged.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādvījamevātrānapoddhṛtamanupahatam paripṛṣṭaṃ ca vāśiatvakāle samanvāgamākhyāṃ tabhate nānyad dravyam /
column2: Hence what we understand by “possession” or the “fact of being endowed with” is not a dharma constituting a separate thing in and of itself, namely the supposed of the Sarvāstivādins, but a certain condition of the person: the seeds of defilement have not been uprooted through the Path of the Saints; the seeds of defilement have not been damaged by means of the worldly path; the seeds of innate good have not been damaged through false views; and the seeds of good “obtained through effort”.

are in good condition at the moment when one wants to produce this good, When the person is in such a condition, this is what we call "possession of defilements," etc. But what should we understand by "seeds"?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yannāmarūpaṃ phalotpattau samartha sākṣāt pāraṃparyeṇa vā / santatipariṇāmaviśeṣāt / ko 'yaṃ pariṇāmo nāma / santateranyathātvam / kā ceyaṃ santatiḥ/
column2: By seeds we understand nāmarāpa, that is, the complex of the five skandhas, capable of generating a result, either immediately or mediately, by means of the pariṇāma-viśeṣa of its series.

The series is the saṁskāras of the past, the present and the future, in relation to causality, that constitutes an uninterrupted series. The pariṇāma, or the evolution of the series, is the modification of this series, the fact that this series arises differently from itself at each moment. The viśeṣa, or culminating point of this evolution, is the moment of this series that possesses the capacity of immediately producing a result.
The Sūtra says, "He who is in possession of greed is not capable of producing the foundations of mindfulness.

In this text, we must understand by possession" of greed the "consenting to greed," or "not rejecting greed. "Sūtra does not say that a person who has the seeds of greed in him is incapable of producing the foundations of mindfulness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvaddhi tasyādhivāsako 'vinodako bhavati tāvat bhavyastāni bhāvayitum /
column2: it says rather that active greed renders this person presently incapable of producing these spiritual exercises.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamayaṃ samanvāgamaḥ sarvāthā prajñaptidharmo na tu dravyadharmaḥ /
column2: In short, in whichever manner it is that we understand possession, either as “cause of the arising of the dharmas,” or as “origin of the condition of beings,” or as "“special state of the person,” or as “consenting to,ʼ possession appears to us, not as an entity, a thing in and of itself, but as a “dharma of designation.”
This same holds for non-possession, which is purely and simply the negation of possession.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dravyameva tu vaibhāṣikāḥ ubhayaṃ varṇayanti / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas say that prāpti and aprāpti are things in and of themselves.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa hi naḥ siddhānta iti / sā kilaiṣā praptiḥ
column2: Because this is our teaching.
There is threefold prāpti of the dharmas of the three periods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atītānāṃ dharmāṇāmatītā 'pi prāptirastyanāgatyā 'pi pratyutpannā 'pi / evamanāgataparatyutpannānāṃ pratyekaṃ trividhā /
column2: Past dharmas can be the object of a threefold prāpti, past, present, and future. The same for present and future dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣubhādīnāṃ ṣubhādikā / kuśalākuśalāvyākṛtānāṃ kuāśalākuśalāvyākṛtaiva yathākramaṃ prāptiḥ /
column2: There is good prāpti, etc. , of good dharmas, etc. The prāpti of good, bad, or neutral dharmas is, respectively, good, bad, or neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svadhātukā tadāptānāṃ ye dharmāstaddhātvāptāsteṣāṃ svadhātukā prāptiḥ /
column2: The prāptis of the dharmas belonging to the spheres of existence are of their spheres. The dharmas belonging to the spheres of existence are impure dharmas.
The prāpii of a dharma in Kāmadhātu is, itself, in Kāmadhātu; and thus following.
There is fourfold prāpti of the āharmas that do not belong to the spheres of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravāṇāṃ dharmāṇāṃ caturvidhā praptiḥ / samāsena traidhātukī cānāsravā ca /
column2: In general, the prāpti of these dharmas—the pure dharmas—is fourfold: it belongs to the three spheres, and it is pure. But there are distinctions: The prāpti of apratisaṁkhyānirodha is of the sphere to which the person who obtains it belongs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāpraptiṃsaṃṅkhyānirodhasya traidhātukī pratisaṃkhyānirodhasya rūpārūpyāvacarī cānāsravā ca /
column2: The prāpti of pratisaṁkhyānôirodha is of Rāpadhātu, of Ārūpyadhatu, and pure.
The prāpti of the Path is Śaikṣa;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śaikṣāṇāṃ dharmāṇāṃ śaikṣaiva prāptiḥ akṣaikṣāṇāmaśaikṣānāśaikṣāṇāntubhedaḥ / sa nirdiśyate
column2: the prāpti of the Aśaikṣa ḍharmas is Aśaikṣa.
But there is Threefold prāpti of the dharmar which are neither Śaikṣa nor Aśaikṣa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naivaśaikṣānāśaikṣā dharmā ucyante sāsravā dharmā asaṃskāṛtaṃ ca /
column2: These dharmas—the naivaśaikṣanāśaikṣas—are the impure dharmas and the unconditioned dharmas; they are called this becauseThey differ from the dharmas of the Śaikṣa and from the dharmas of the Aśaikṣa.
In general, the prāpti of these dharmas is threefold. Their distinctions are: The prāpti of the impure dharmas is neither-śaikṣa-nor Aśaikṣa.

In this same way the prāpti of apratisaṁkhyānirodha and the prāpti of pratisaṁkhyānirodha are obtained by a non-Āryaṉ. The prāpti of pratisaṁkhyānirodha is Śaikṣa when this vérodha is obtained through the path of the Śaikṣas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apratisaṃkhyānirodhasya ca pratisaṃkhyānirodhasya cānāryeṇa praptasya / tasyaiva śaikṣeṇa mārgeṇa praptasya śaikṣī aśaikṣeṇāśaikṣī /
column2: it is Aśaikṣa when this nirodha is obtained through the path of the Aśaikṣas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanabhāvanāheyānāṃ yathākramaṃ darāśanabhāvanāheyaiva parāptiḥ / aheyānāṃ tu bhedaḥ /
column2: The prāpti of the dharmas to be abandoned either through Seeing, or through Meditation, is destroyed, respectively, either through Seeing or through Meditation;
it belongs then, from the point of view of abandoning them, to the category of these dharmas.
As for the dharmas which should not be abandoned, their prāpti presents difficulties: There is twofold prāptś of the ḍharmas that should not be abandoṉed.
These dharmas ate the pure ḍharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāmapratisaṃkhyānirodhasya bhāvanāheyā prāptiḥ anāryaprāptasya ca pratisaṃkhyānirodhasya /
column2: The prāpti of apratisaṁkhyānirodha is abandoned through the. But the prāpti of pratisaṁkhyānirodha obtained through the Path is pure and should not be abandoned.
The same for the prāpt of the Path.
We have established the general principal that the dharmas of the three periods are susceptible of a threefold prāpri. We must be more precise.
The prāpti of a neutral dharma is simultaneous to it.
The prāpti of an undefiled-neutral dharma is simultaneous to this dharma: one possesses it when it is present, not when it is past or future.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: durbalatvāt / tenateṣāmatītānāmatītaiva yāvat pratyutpannānāṃ pratyutpannaiva / kiṃ sarvasyaivānivṛtāvyākṛtasya /
column2: When it is past, the prāpti is past, and when it is future, the prāpti is future: this by reason of the weakness of this dharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na sarvasya / abhijñānairmāṇikādṛte // dve abhijñe avyākṛte nirmāṇacittaṃ ca varjayitvā /
column2: With the exception of the two supernormal faculties and apparition, This rule does not apply to all undefiled-neutral dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ hi balavattvāt prayogaviśeṣaniṣpatteḥ pūrva paścāt sahajā prāptiḥ / śailpasthānikasyāpi kasyacidīryāpathikasyā tyarthamabhyastasyecchanti / kimanivṛtāvyākṛtasyaiva sahajā praptirityāha
column2: The supernormal faculties of seeing and hearing and the mind capable of creating apparitional beings are strong, for they are realized through a special. Certain Masters maintain that the undefiled-neutral dharmas of craftsmanship and of attitude, when they have been the object of an intense practice, are also possessed in the past and future. The same for the prāpti of defiled rāpa. The prāpti of defiled-neutral /%pa is only simultaneous to this rūpa.
This rūpa is bodily action and vocal action resulting from a defiled-neutral mind.

This action, even though produced by a strong mind, is incapable, as is the mind itself, of creating avijñapti, hence it is weak. Thus one possesses it in the present, but not in the past or the future.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā 'vyākṛtānāṃ dharmāṇāmayaṃ praptibhedaḥ kimevaṃ kuśalākuśalānāmapikaścit prāptibhedo 'sti / astītyāha / kāme rūpasya nāgrajā /
column2: Is the tritemporal character of the prāpti of the good and the bad dharmas subject to any restriction, as is the case with the prāpt of the neutral dharmas?
The prāpti of the rūpa of Kāmadhātu is not previous to this rpa. This r%pa, good or bad, for example the prātérnokéṣa-sarvara (iv.
19 and following), is not possessed previous to its being produced.
TheCan non-possession be, like prāpti, good, bad, or neutral?
Aprāpti is undefiled-neutral.
Aprāpti īs atways anivṛtāvyākr̥ta.
Aprāpti of the dharmas of the past or the future is threefold.
Aprāpti of past or future dharmas can be past, present, or future. But one necessarily possesses the present dharmas: hence the aprāpti of present dharmas can be only past or future.
Aprāpti of the dharmas forming part of the spheres of existence, and of the immaculate dharmas, is threefold.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāptānāṃ kāmarūpārūpyāvacarī / evaṃ rūpārūpyāptānāmanāsravāṇāṃ ca nāstyanāsravā kācidaprāptiḥ /
column2: Aprāpti of the dharmas of the sphere of Kamadhātu belong either to Kāmadhātu, Rūpadhātu, or Ārūpyadhātu accordingly as the person endowed with this aprāptiÉ belongs to such a sphere of existence. The same for the aprāpti of pure dharmas. In fact, aprāpti is never pure. According to the School, a Prṛthagjana is a petson who has not acquired the Path. Now the state of Pṛthagjana is not pure; hence their nonpossession is not pure.
Let us examine this definition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pṛthagjanatvam “pṛthagjanatvaṃ katamat / āryadharmāṇāmalābha” iti śāstrapāṭhaḥ / alābhaśca nāmāprāptiḥ / naca pṛthagjanatvamanāsravaṃ bhavitumarhati /
column2: When the Śāstra says that the state of Prthagjana is the non-possession of the dharmas of the Āryans, which dharmas of the Āryans does it mean?
The dharmas beginning with duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣáānti and including the whole pure path or the Path of the Aryans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarveṣāmaviśeṣavacanāt / sa tu yo vinā lābhenālābhaḥ / anyathā hi cuddho 'pi śrāvakapratyekabuddhagotrakai rasamanvāgamādanāryaḥ syāt / evaśabdastarhi paṭhitavyaḥ /
column2: The Śāstra means all these dharmas, since it does not specify any.

Be careful! To believe you, a person in possession of duḥkhe kṣāṅṁti would be a Pr̥thagjana if he did not possess all of the other Āryan dharmas. The Śāstra means the non-possession that is not accompanied by possession: the person of whom you speak, although not possessing the other dharmas of the Āryans, is not a Pr̥thagjana because the non-possession of these other dharrmas is accompanied by the possession of the kgāṇt; This is quite evident, for, in the contrary interpretation, the Buddha the Blessed Oné, notVety well. But then the Śāstra would say “The state of Prthagjana is the absolute non-possession of the Āryaṉ dharmas” and not 'the non-possession.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekapadānyapi hyavadhāraṇāni bhavanti / tadyathā abbhakṣo vāyubhakṣa iti /
column2: The Śāstra expresses itself very well, for the ekapadas permit a restrictive sense and the particle eva is not necessary: for example abbhakṣa signifies “that which lives solely on watet,” and vāyubhakṣa, “that which lives solely on wind.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntitatsahabhuvāmalābha ityapare / na ca tadyogā danāryatvaprasaṅgaḥ /
column2: According to another opinion, the state of Prthagjana is the non-possession of the first stage of the Path of Seeing, duḥkhe ḍharmajñānakṣēānti and its concomitant dharmas. In this hypothesis, at the sixteenth moment, the saint will be a Prṛthagjana and not an Āryan, for at this moment, the initial kṣāt;
is lost. No, for the non-possession of the kṣānri which constitutes the state of Pṭthagjana has been absolutely destroyed in the first stage.
The éṣānti in question is threefold: of the family of. We mean to speak of three types of &ṣáānti.

Be careful! The Buddha, not possessing the three types of kṣānti, would then be a Pṛthagjana! We intend to speak of the non-possession of the kṛāni which is not accompanied by possession, and thus following, as above, to the example “that which lives solely on water,” “that which lives solely on wind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi sa eva doṣaḥ / punaḥ sa eva parihāraḥ /
column2: ” Hence the effort attempted in order to avoid the objection: “Be careful! To believe you, a person in possession of duhkhe dharmajñānakṣānti would be a Prṛthagjana.
” is in vain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tu sādhu yathā sautrāntikānām / kathaṃ ca sautrāntikānām /
column2: The best explanation is that of the Sautrāntikas.
To them, the state of Pr̥thagjana is a series in which the dbarmas of the Āryans have not arisen.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atheyamaprāptiḥ kathaṃ vihīyate / yasya yā dharmasya prāptirasau
column2: How does non-possession perish?
It is abandoned through acquisition, and through passing to another stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tāvadāryamārgasyālābhaḥ pṛthagjanatvaṃ tasya lābhāttadvihīyate bhūmisaṃcārācca /
column2: For example, the non-possession of the Path, which constitutes the.
The same holds for the non-possession of the other dharmas.

Non-possession is abandoned when one produces the non-possession of non-possession, that is to say, when, changing one’s stage of existence, one ceases to possess the state of Prthagjana; and when the possession of non-possession is cut off, that is to say, when, acquiring the Path, one cuts off the state of Prthagjana.
Does this mean that there is possession of possession and non-possession, and that there is non-possession of possession and nonpossession? Yes.

There is possession and non-possession of possession and non-possession, which is called “secondary possession”, or “secondary non-possession. ” One then distinguishes between laprāti aṇḍ anuprāpti ot prāptiprāpti.
Doesn't this doctrine lead to infinite progression? No, for one possesses possession through the fact of possession of possession and vice versa.
There is possession of the oné through the.
When a certain dharmua is produced in a given person, three dbarmar arise together, namely: this dharma itself, which is called the mladharma;
the prāpti of this ṁmladharma; and the prāpti of this prāpri.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra prāptyutpādāttena dharmeṇa samanvāgato bhavati prāptiprāptyā ca /
column2: The person in question possesses the rn%ūladharma and the prāpti of the prāpti by the fact of the arising of the prāprÉ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prāptiprāptyutpādāt punaḥ prāptyaiva samanvāgato bhavatyato nānavsthā /
column2: he possesses this prāpts by the fact of the arising of the prāpri. Hence there is no infinite progression.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca kṛtva ātmanā tṛtīyasya dharmasya kuśalasya kliṣṭasya kliṣṭasya vā dvitīye kṣaṇe tisraḥ prāptayo jāyante /
column2: When a good or a defiled dharma arises, at this very moment three dharmas aṟise together, inclusive of this good or defiled dharṇa, namely: the mūladharma, its prāpti, and the prāpti of this prāp which is the prāpti of the prāptiprāpti of the first moment, plus three anuprāptis through the fact that one is in possession of the three aforementioned prāptis.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāsāṃ ca punastisro 'nuprāptaya iti ṣaḍ bhavanti / tṛtīye kṣaṇe prathamadvitīyakṣaṇotpannānāṃ dravyāṇāṃ nava prāptayaḥ sārdhamanuprāptibhirityaṣṭādāśa bhavanti /
column2: In this third moment eighteen dharmas arise together, namely nine prāptis: the prāptis of the three dharmas produced in the first moment, prāptis of the sīx dharmas ptoduced in the second momenr.
Thus the prāptás continue increasing in number from moment to moment.

The prāpśy of present and future defilements and of innate good dharmas with the dharmas that are associated and co-existent with them throughout beginningless and endless transmigration, arise from moment to moment, in an infinite number.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekasya prāṇinaḥ kṣaṇe kṣaṇe upajāyante ityanantadravyāḥ pratisantānamātmabhāvakṣaṇāḥ
column2: If one considers the series of one single being in the course of transmigration, those prāpts which arise at each moment are infinite in number.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sattvānāṃ bhavanti / atyutsavo vatāyaṃ prāptīnāṃ varttate /
column2: Considering all beings together, they are without measure, and without limit.
Happily, they possess a great quality: they are non-material, and give way one to the other.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itarathā hyākāśe 'pyava kāśo na syāt dvitīyasya prāṇinaḥ //
column2: If they were material, there could not be found enough room in the universe for the prāptis of one single being, and even less for the prāptis of two beings!
What is "genre" or sameness of class designation?
Sabhāgatā is that which causes resemblance between living.
There exists an entity called sabhāgatā, a dharma by virtue of which living beings, as well as the dharmas “that fall into the series of living beings”, have resemblance between them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sattvānāṃ sākṛśyaṃ nikāyasa bhāga ityasyāḥ śāstre saṃjñā /
column2: The Śāstra designates this entity by the name of nōkāyasabhāga: the author uses the term sabhāgatā for metric reasons.
Sabhāgatā is of two types, general and particular.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhinnā sarvasattvānāṃ sattvasabhāgatā / pratisattvaṃ sarveṣu bhāvāt /
column2: The first is found in all living beings: by virtue of it, there is resemblance of any living being with all other living beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhinnā punasteṣāmeva sattvānāṃ dhātubhūmigatiyonijātistrīpuruṣopāsakabhikṣuśaikṣā śaikṣyādibhedena pratiniyatā dharmasabhāgatā /
column2: This is called satvasabhāgatā. The second has numerous subdivisions: each of these subdivisions is found only in certain beings. Living beings are differentiated according to their spheres of existence, the different stages of these spheres, their realm of rebirth, their wombs, their caste, their sex, the state of Upāsaka, Bhikṣu, Śaiksa, or Arhat, etc. This holds as well for sabhāgatās, by virtue of which each living being of a certain species resembles living beings of this same species.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaḥ skndhāyatanadhātutaḥ yadi satvasabhāgatā dravyamaviśiṣtaṃ na syāt anyonyaviśeṣabhinneṣu sattveṣu sattvasttva ityabhedena buddhirna syāt prajñaptiśca / evaṃ skandhādi buddhiprajñaptayyo 'pi yojyāḥ /
column2: In the absence of a separate entity, namely sabhāgatā, how does one explain general ideas and expressions, such as “living beings,” etc. , applied to some beings that differ one from another? In this same way, it is solely by reason of dharmasabhāgatā that the ideas and expressions, “skundha,” “dhātus,” etc. , are justified.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syāccyavetopapadyeta na ca sattvasabhāgatāṃ vijahyānna ca pratilabheteti /
column2: Do we conclude that one transmigrates, that one dies and is born without abandoning and without taking up a certain satṭvasabhāgatā?
There are four alternatives; to die in a place and be reborn in the same place: the sśabhāgatā remains the same, regardless of transmigratioṉ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyā niyāmamavkrāman / sa hi pṛthagjanasabhāgatāṃ vijahyādāryasabhāgatāṃ pratilabhate / tṛtīyā gatisaṃcārāt / caturthyetānākārān sthāpayitvā / yadi pṛthagjanasabhāgatā nāma dravyamasti kiṃ punaḥ pṛthagjanatvena /
column2: to enter into one’s predetermined realm of rebirth: without there being transmigration, there is yet the abandoning of the sabhāgaiā of the Pṛthagjanas and the acqnisition of the sabhāgatā of.
Ordinary people do not recognize sabhagata through the direct perception of the senses;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva ca lokaḥ sabhāgatāṃ paśyatyarūpiṇītvāt nacaināṃ prajñayā paricchinatti pratipadyate ca satvānāṃ jātyabhedamiti satyā api tasyāḥ kathaṃ tatra vyāpāraḥ /
column2: they do not infer the existence of the sabhagata through an operation of the intelligence, for rabhagata does not exercise any action by which one could know it: although people do not know anything of sattuasabhagata they recognize the non-difference of the species of beings. Hence, what.
Would be the use in supposing that a sabhāgatā exists?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śāliyavamudgamāsāmrapanasalohakāñcanādīnāṃ svajātisādṛśyāt tāsāṃ ca sabhāgatānāmanyonyabhinnānāṃ kathamabhedena sabhāgatā prajñaptiḥ kriyate
column2: Why does the School refuse rzbhāgatā to things that are not living beings, such as rice and coṟn, gold and iron, mango aṇd breadfruit trees? The different sabhāgatās that the School recognizes, sabhāgatās of living beings, of spheres, of realms of rebirth, etc. , are distinct one from another. Yet one has, for all of them, common ideas and designations: all are sabhāgatās.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vaiśeṣikāścaivaṃ dyotitā bhavanti / teṣāmapi hyeṣa siddhāntaḥ /
column2: The Šarvāstivādins are the proponents of the doctrine of the Vaiśeṣikas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sāmānyapadārtho nāmāsti yataḥ samānapratyayotpattiratulyaprakāreṣvapīti / ayaṃ tu teṣāṃ viśeṣaḥ / sa eko 'pyanekasmin varttate yadi dyotitā yadi na dyotitā /
column2: The Vaiśeṣikas admit a certain entity called "sameness", by virtue of which there is produced, with regard to things, similar ideas and designations; they believe also in another entity, called 'difference", from whence proceeds specific ideas and designations with regard to different species. Ṭhe Vaibhāṣikas protest that their theory is not to be confused with that of the Vaiśeṣikas, who believe that genre or sameness a unique substance, exists in a multitude of individuals.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: astyeṣā tu sabhāgatā sūtre vacanāditi vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: Hence even if they apptove of the Vaiśeṣikas admitting.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ustaṃ hi bhagavatā “sa ceditthantvamāgacchati manuṣyāṇāṃ sabhāgatāmi“ti /
column2: As for ṣabhāgatā, it exists in and of itself, for the Blessed One, speaking of a murderer who is reborn in hell, continues, saying, “If he is reborn here, if he obtains the sabhāgatā of humans.
By expressing itself in this way, the Sūtra does not teach the existence of a thing in and of itself called ṣabhágatā.
What then does the Sūtra designate by the word sabhāgatā?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta eva hi tathābhūtāḥ saṃskārā yeṣu manuṣyādiprajñaptiḥ śālyādiṣu sabhāgatāvat / tattvetanna varṇayanti /
column2: By the expression sabhāgatā of humaṇns,” etc. , the Sūtra means a similarity in the manner of being; in the same way, sabhāgatā of rice, corn, beans, etc. ‘This opinion is not admitted by the Vaibhāsikas.
What is non-consciousness?
Non-consciousness is that which, among the Nonconscious Ones, arrests the mind and its mental states.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaṃjñisattveṣu devepūpapannānāṃ yaścittacaittānāṃ nirodhastadāsaṃjñikaṃnāma dravyaṃ yena cittacaittā anāgate 'dhvani kālāntaraṃ saṃnirudhyante notpattuṃ labhante /
column2: Among the beings who take birth among the Non-Conscious Ones, ie. , the non-conscious gods, there is a dharma that arrests the mind and its mental states, and which is called “non-consciousness. ” By this áharma, the mind and future dharmas are, for a certain time.
This dharma is similar to what arrests the water of a river, that is, to a dike.
This dharma is exclusively Retribution.
It is exclusively the retribution of non-conscious absorption.
Where do these non-conscious gods reside?
They live in Bṛṭhatphala.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bṛhatphalā nāma devā yeṣāṃ kecidasaṃjñisattvāḥ pradeśe bhavanti dhyānāntarikāvat /
column2: In the heaven of the Bṛhatphalas there is a raised place which is the dwelling of the Non-Conscious Ones, in the same way as the dhyānāntarikā, the dwelling of the Mahābrahmā gods, is raised within the heaven of the Brahmapurohitas.
Are the Non-Conscious Ones called this because they are always non-conscious, or are they sometimes conscious?
They are conscious at birth and at death; they are called non-conscious because their consciousness is suspended for a very long time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “prakṛṣṭamapi kālaṃ sthitvā saha saṃjñotpādātteṣāṃ sattvānāṃ tatsthānāt cyutirbhavatī“ti sūtre pāthaḥ / te ca tato dīrghasvapnavyutthitā iva cyutvā kāmadhātāvupapadyante nānyatra /
column2: When, after this long time, they produce a consciousness again, they die. As it says in the Sūtra “When they produce consciousness again, they die, like a person awakening. In fact, the force of aśaṁjñisamāpatti, by which these beings are born among the NonConscious Ones, is exhausted;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvasamāpattisaṃskāraparikṣayāt apūrvānupacayācca kṣiptā iva kṣīṇavegā iṣavaḥ pṛthivīṃ patanti /
column2: they have not been in a positioṉ to practice asaṁjñisamāparti: hence they die, as arrows fall to the ground when their impetus is spent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yena ca tatropapattavyaṃ tasyāvaśyaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ karmāparaparyāyavedanīyaṃbhavati /
column2: On the other hand, beings who are reborn among the Non-Conscious Ones necessarily possess an action “retribative in Kāmadhātu” and “retributive in the second existence”.
In this same way beings who are reborn in Uttarakuru necessarily possesses an action retributive in a heavenly realm of rebirth immediately after their existence in Uttarakuru.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha samāpattī iti yaduktaṃ katame te samāpattī /
column2: The Mūlaśāstra says, “What are the two ṣamapāttis or absorptions?
They are asarhjñisamāpatt, the non-conscious absorption, and nirodhasamāpaiti, the absorption of extinctioṉ.”
What is the non-conscious absorption?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā 'saṃjñisamāpattiḥ asaṃjñināṃ samāpattirasaṃjñā ve tyasaṃjñisamāpattiḥ / sā 'pi cittacaittānāṃ nirodhaḥ /
column2: In the same way that āravṇjñiéka is a dharma that aṟrests the mindThe non-conscious absorption is an absorption in which the ascetic is non-conscious, or in an absorption free from consciousness.
The word “the same” shows that this absorption, like āsaṁjñika, arrests the mind and its mental states.
To which bhāmi does it belong?
In the Fourth Dhyáāna. In order to cultivate this absorption, the ascetic should have entered the Fouṟth Dhyāṇna.
Why does one cultivate it?
Through desire for deliverance.
The ascetic falsely imagines that āsanhjñika, the non-consciousness that constitutes the result of the non-conscious absorption, is true deliverance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āsaṃjñikaṃ vipākatvāt avyākṛtamiti siddham / iyaṃ tu
column2: Asaṁjñika, being retribution, is necessarily morally neutral.
As for the non-conscious absorption, it is good.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyā asaṃjñisattveṣu pañcaskandhako vipākaḥ / kuśalā satī upapadyavedyaiva
column2: It produces as its retributive result the five séandhas of a nonconscious god, who, as we know, is conscious at birth and at death. To what category does it belong from the point of view of retribution?
Solely retribution in the next existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'pyenāmutpādya parihīyate so 'pi kilāvaśyaṃ punarutpādyāsaṃjñisattveṣūpapadyata iti /
column2: Without doubt, an ascetic can fall from this absorption after having produced it; but, he will produce it again and be reborn among the Non-Conscious Ones.
This is to say that the ascetic who takes possession of this absorption will certainly not enter into a "predestined" realm of rebirth.
This absorption is cultivated only by Prthagjanas.
Not by Aryans.
The Aryans consider this absorption as a precipice, a calamity, and do not value entering it.

On the contrary, Prthagjanas identify non-consciousness with true deliverance; they have no idea of "going out" with respect to it; hence they cultivate the absorption that leads to it. But Aryans know that the impure cannot be true deliverance. Hence they do not cultivate this absorption.

When Aryans enter into the Fourth Dhyana, do they obtain the prapi of this past and future absorption, the same as one obtains the prapti of the Fourth Dhyana of the past and the future as soon as one.
Non-Āryans do not obtain the prāptÉ of the non-conscious absorption of the past and future.
Why?
Having cultivated it many times previously, this absorption can only be realized through great effort; as it is not mind.
It is obtained in one time period.
One takes possession of this absorption, not in the past, not in the future, but in one time period, that is, in the present, as is also the case for the prātimokṣa discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: labdhayā tu dvitaīyādiṣu kṣaṇeṣvatītayā 'pi samanvāgato bhavati yāvanna tyajati /
column2: In the second moment of this absorption, and in all the moments that follow the obtaining of this absorption until the moment when it ends, one possesses it in the past and in the present.
On the other hand, since this absorption is not mind, it is impossible for one to acquire a future prāprś of this absorption.
What is nôrodhasamāpatti or the “absorption of extinction?
” In the same way, the absorption that bears the name of mirodha or "extinction.

That is to say, the absorption of extinction is like āsa/ṅjñika, the. It is aharma that arrests the mind and its menta states.
tathāśabdena kaḥ prakāro gṛhyate / “nirodhaścittacaittānāmi“ti /	What are the differences between the non-conscious absorption and the absorption of extinction?
ayaṃ tvasyā viśeṣaḥ /	It is viewed as tranquility.
iyaṃ vihārārthaṃ śāntavihārasaṃjñāpūarvakeṇa manasikāreṇa enāṃ samāpadyante /	Āṛyaṉs cultivate this absorption because they consider it as the absorption of tranquility.
tāṃ tu niḥsaraṇasaṃjñā pūrvakeṇa / sā khalvapi caturthadhyānabhūmikā / iyaṃ tu	One cultivates the non-conscious absoxption because one regards non-consciousness as being deliverance.
bhavāgrajā /	Arisen from Bhavāgra.
naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatanabhūmikaiva / sā ceyaṃ	It belongs to the sphere of Bhavāgra, that is, one penetrates it upon leaving naivasaṁjñānāsaṁmjñāyatana absorption, whereas the non-conscious absorption belongs to the spbere of the Fourth Dhyāṇa.
śubhā	Good. It is good;
kuśalaiva na klilṣṭā nāvyākāṛtā / kuśalā satī	it is not neutral ot defiled, for its originatng cause is good.
dvivedyā 'niyatā ca /	Of two retributions and neutral.
dvayoḥ kālayorvedyā upapadyavedanīyā cāparaparyāyavedanīyā ca / aniyatā ca vipākaṃ prati kadācinna vipacyate /	It admits of two types of retribution, being either retributive in the next existence," or "retributive later" (aparaparyāyavedanīya, iv.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadīha pariniarvāyāt tasyā hi bhavāgre catuḥskandhako vipākaḥ / sā ceyamekāntena
column2: Its retribution is also unnecessary, for the ascetic who has practiced it can obtain Nirvāṇa in the present existence. This absorption produces the four séandhas of Bhavāgra, ie. , an existence in Bhavāgra.
It is produced only by Āryans, not by Pṛthagjanas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi pṛthagjanā nirodhasamāpattimutpādayituṃ śaknuvantyucchedabhīrutvādāryamārgabalena cotpādanāddṛṣṭadharmanirvāṇasya tadadhimuktitaḥ / āryasyāpi ceyaṃ na vairāgyalabhyā / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: These latter cannot produce it because they fear annihilation, and because this absorption can only be produced through the power of the Path: in fact, it is the ascetic who has seen Nirvāṇa who is determined to obtain it.
It is obtained through effort. Although obtained by the Āryans, it is not obtained merely through the fact of detachment.
It is only realized through effort.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cātītā labhyate nāpyanāgata bhāvyate / cittabalena tadbhāvanāt / kiṃ bhagavato 'pi parāyogikī /
column2: One does not possess this absorption in the past or in the future; this point has been explained in the matter of the non-conscious absoṟptioṅn.
In that which concerns the Muni, it is obtained through Bodhi itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣayajñānasamanaṃ kālaṃ buddhā bhagavanta enāṃ labhante nāsti kiñcidbuddhānāṃ prāyogikaṃ nāma /
column2: The Buddha obtains the absorption of extinction at the moment when he becomes a Buddha, that is, at the moment of kṣayajñāna. No quality of the Buddha is obtained through effort;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: icchāmātrapratibaddho hi teṣāṃ sarvaguṇasaṃpātsaṃmukhībhāvaḥ / tasmādeṣāṃ sarvavairāgyalābhikam /
column2: all of his qualities are acquired through the simple fact of detachment: as soon asHe desires it, the mass of qualities arise at will.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ khalvi dānīmanutpāditāyāṃ nirodhasamāpattau kṣayajñānakāle bhagavānubhayotobhāgavimuktaḥ sidhyati /
column2: How is it that the Blessed One, without having formerly produced this absorption, would become, at the moment of Bodhi, “twofold delivered,” that is, delivered from the obstacles of the defilements and delivered from the obstacles to absorption?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sidhyatyutpāditāyāmiva tasyāṃ vaśitvāt prāgeva tāṃ bodhisattvaḥ śaikṣyāvasthāyāmutpādayatīti pāścattyāḥ /
column2: He becomes “twofold delivered” exactly as if he had previously produced this absorption, for he possesses the power of realizing this absorption whenever he wishes. The Masters of the West maintain that the Bodhisattva first produced this absorption in the state of Śaikṣa, and then obtained Bodhi.
Why do we not adopt this opinion?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca sthaviropaguptasyāpīdaṃ netrīpadaṃ prāmāṇikaṃ bhaviṣyati / “nirodhasamāpattimutpādya kṣayajñānamutpādayatīti vaktavyaṃ tathāgata“iti /
column2: This would be to follow the Netrīpadasūs:ra of the Sthavira Upagupta, which says, “One who, after having produced the absorption of extinction, produces éṣayajñāna, should be called a Tathāgata.
” But not previously.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi pūrvaṃ tasyā utapādanaṃ yujyata iti kāśmīrakāḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmīr deny that the Bodhisattva produces the absorption of extinction before producing kṣayajñāna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ kāraṇam / catustriṃśatkṣaṇāptitaḥ / catusriṃśatā kila cittakṣaṇairbodhisattvo bodhimanuprāptaḥ /
column2: For the Muṇi conquers Bodhi in thirty-four moments.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satyābhisamaye ṣoḍaśabhirbhavāgravairāgye cāṣṭādaśabhirnavaprakārāṇāṃ kleśānāṃ prahāṇāya navānantaryavimuktimārgotpādanāt / ta ete catustriṃśat bhavanti / ākiñcanyāyatanavītarāgasyāsyaniyāmāvakramaṇādadhobhūmikā na punaḥḥ praheyā bhavanti /
column2: The School admits in fact that the Bodhisattva obtains Bodhi in thirty-four moments, namely sixteen moments that constitute the “comprehension of the Truths” and eighteen moments that constitute the abandoning of the defilements relative to Bhavāgra, ie. , nine āṉantaryamārgas and nine vimuktimārgas. The eighteenth moment is kṣayajñāna. These thirty-four moments suffice, for, before entering into the “comprehension of the Truths,” the Bodhisattva, still a Prṛthagjana, detaches himself through the worldly path from all spheres, with the exception of Bhavāgra. The eighteen moments form a path during the course of which the Saint does not produce a mind of a different nature, that is, a worldly, impure mind, for example the mind entering the absorption of extinction.

Hence the Bodhisattva, in the stage of Śaikṣa, that īs, before becoming an Arhat, enters the comprehension of the Truths and the eighteenth moment of the abandoning of Bhavāgra, but he does not produce the absorption of extinction.
The Foreigners say, "What harm is there in the Bodhisattva producing this impure mind?

In this hypothesis, the Bodhisattva oversteps his resolution, now the Bodhisattva does not overstep his resolution.
satyamavyutthānāśayā natu āsrava mārgāvyutthānāt /	This is true, he does not overstep his resolution; but this does not mean that he would not overstep the Pure Path in producing an impure mind.
kathaṃ tarhi “na tāvat bhetsyāmi paryaṅkamaprāpte āsravakṣaya” iti /	How, in this hypothesis, would he not overstep his resolution? He has taken upon himself the resolution, I shall not leave this sitting position before I obtain the destruction of all the defilements.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asyāśayasyāvyutthānā dekāyana eva sarvārthaparisamāpteriti bahirdeśakāḥ / pūrvameva tu varṇayanti kāśmīrāḥ /
column2: Now he does not overstep this resolution, for it is in one sitting" that he realizes his goal.
Although the two absorptions, the non-conscious absorption and the absorption of extinction, present many differences, they have this in common.
But these two absorptions take place in persons in Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhe api tvete asaṃjñinirodhasamāpattī kāmadhātau rūpadhātau cotpatsyete /
column2: To deny that the non-conscious absorption is produced in Rūpadhātu is to contradict the Mūlaśāstra, which says, "There is an.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye tvasaṃjñisamāpattiṃ rūpadhātau necchanti teṣāmayaṃ grantho virudhyate / syādrūpabhavo na cāsau bhavaḥ pañcavyavacāraḥ / syādrūpāvacarāṇāṃ sattvānāṃ saṃjñināṃ devānāṃ visabhāge citte sthitānāmasaṃjñisamāpattiṃ nirodhasamāparttiṃ ca samāpannānāmasaṃjñināṃ ca devānāmāsaṃjñike pratilabdhe yo bhava” iti /
column2: existence in Rūpadhātu that does not admit of the five sēandhas, namely the existence of beings in Rūpadhātu who, conscious by nature, enter into the non-conscious absorption and into the absorption of extinction, and the existence of beings in Rūpadhātu who aṟe in possession of āsaṁjñika, and who are born among the NonConscious Ones.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata ubhe apyete kāmarūpāśraye / tatrāpi tvayaṃ viśeṣaḥ /
column2: From this text it results that the two absoṟptions are cultivated by beings of Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu.

There is however this difference between the two absorptions: The absorption of extinction is, foṛ the first time, among humans. A person who has never produced the non-conscious absorption can produce this absorption either in Kāmadhātu or in Rūpadhātu;

but it is necessary to be a human in order to produce the absoṟption of extinction for the first time. A humen, an Āryan, who has produced this absorption can fall from it, and losing possession of it, can be reborṉ in Rūpadhātu and produce this absorption anew.
But the question is raised whether one can fall from the absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hi ndāyi sūtraṃ virudhyeta / “ihāyuṣmanto bhikṣuḥ śīlasaṃpannaśca bhavati samādhisaṃpannaśca prajñāsaṃpannaśca /
column2: Yes, to deny falling is to contradict the Udāyi-sātra which says, "Brothers, a Bhikṣu is endowed with morality, with absorption, and with discernment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'bhīkṣṇaṃ saṃjñāvedayita nirodhaṃ samāpadyate ca vyuttiṣṭhate cāsti caitat sthānamiti
column2: It is possible for him to enter many times into the absorption of extinction and leave it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti sa na haiva dṛṣṭa eva dharme pratipattye vājñāmārāgayati nāpi
column2: If, in this life, he does not attain āpñṁ nor attain it at the moment of his death;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: maraṇakālasamaye bhedācca kāyasyātikramya devān kavaḍīkārāhāra bhakṣānanyatarasmin divye manomaye kāya upapadyate /
column2: but after the destruction of his body, going beyond the gods of gross eating, he is reborn in a heavenly mental body;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tatropapanno 'bhīkṣṇaṃ saṃjñāveditanirodhaṃ samāpadyate ca vyuttiṣṭahate cāsti caitat sthānamiti yathābhūtaṃ prajānātī“ti /
column2: and thus reborn it is possible for him to then enter many times into the absorption of extinction and leave it. " This text shows in fact that one can fall from nrodhasamāpatti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atra hi divyo manomayaḥ kāyo rūpāvacara ukto bhagavatā /
column2: On the one hand the Buddha would have us understand that the mental body that Śāriputra speaks of belongs to Rūpadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: iyaṃ ca samāpattirbhāvāgrikī / tatkathamaparihīṇasya tallābhino rūpadhātau syādupapattiḥ /
column2: On the other hand, the absorption of extinction is of the realm of Bhavāgra, the highest state of Ārūpyadhātu. If a Bhikṣu who possesses it does not fall from it, and if he does not lose it, he will not be able to repeat his.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturthadhyānabhūmikāmapi nirodhasabhāpatiṃ nikāyāntarīyā icchanti / teṣāṃ vināpi parihāṇyā sidhyatyetat /
column2: According to another school, the absorption of extinction also belongs to the Fourth Dhyāna and is not subject to falling.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etadeva tu na sidhyati / caturthadhyānabhūmikā 'pyasāvastīti / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: This opinion is not correct.
This absorption does not belong to the Fourth Dhyāna, for the Sūtra teaches that one acquires nine absorptions one after the other.
How then do you explain the vyukrāntaka absorption in which the ascetic passes over different stages of absorption?
The rule of the successive production of the absorptions concerns the beginner.
He who has acquired mastery passes over the absorptions at will.
There are differences between these two absorptions: from the point of view of their spheres, the first is of the Fourth Dhyāṇna, the second of Bhavāgra;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prayogato 'pi niḥsaraṇavihārasaṃjñāpūrvakamanasikāraprayogāt / saṃtānato 'pi pṛthagjanāryasaṃtānatvāt / phalato 'pyāsaṃjñikabhavāgraphalatvāt / vedanīyato 'pi niyatāniyatopapadyobhayathāvedanīyatvāt /
column2: from the point of view of their antecedents or preparations, the first proceeds from the idea of deliverance falsely identified with non-consciousness, the second from the idea of stillness;
from the point of view of the person, the first is produced in a Prthagjana, the second in an Āryam.

The characteristic common to these two absorptions is the arresting of the mind and its mental states. Why is the first called "absorption free from ideas" and the second "absorption of extinction of ideas and sensations"?
Because the preparation from the first merely opposes ideas, whereas preparation for the second opposes both ideas and sensations.

In the same way paracitajñāna, "knowledge of the mind of another," bears on the mental states of someone else: it receives this restrictive name because its preparation alludes only to the mind of another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamidānīṃ bahukālaṃ niruddhāccittāt punarapi cittaṃ jāyate /
column2: In the two absorptions, the mind is interrupted for a long time. How, upon coming out of this absorption, can a new mind be born from a mind destroyed for a long time?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atītasyāpyastitvāt iṣyate vaibhāṣikaiḥ samanantarapratyayatvam / apare punarāhuḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas find no difficulty in this: past dharas exist. Consequently the mind previous to this absorption, the mind-in-absorption or "the mind of entry into the absorption" is the similar and immediate cause of the mind after the absorption or the "mind-of-leaving".

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ tāvad rūpopapannānāṃ ciraniruddhe 'pi rūpe punarapi rūpaṃ jāyate / cittād eva hi taj jāyate na rūpāt /
column2: When a person is born in Ārūpyadhātu, or matter is cut off for a long period of time: if this person is then reborn in Kāmadhātu or in Rūpadbātu, his new riūpa does not proceed from the series of %pa previously interrupted for a long time, but rather, from the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ cittam apy asmād eva sendriyāt kāyāj jāyate na cittāt /
column2: In the same way, the mind of leaving the absorption does not have for its cause the. It is born from “@ body possessing organs”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyonyabījakaṃ hy etadubhayaṃ yaduta cittaṃ ca sendriyaśca kāya iti pūrvācāryāḥ /
column2: This is why the Ancient Masters said, “Two dharmas are the seed one of the other: these two dharmas are a mind and a body possessing organs.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhadantavasumitrastvāha paripṛcchāyāṃ “yasyācittikā nirodhasamāpattistasyaiṣa doṣo mama tu sacittikā samāpattiri“ti /  ti /
column2: Vasurnitra says in the treatise entitled Paripṛcchā: “This difficulty, ie. , ‘How is the mind reborn after absorption? ’, interests those who consider the absorption of extinction as free from mind. But I maintain that this absorption is accompanied by a subtle mind. The difficulty does not exist for me.”
The Bhadanta Ghoṣaka regards this opinion as wrong.
In fact, if any consciousness resides in this absorption, there would be contact through the coming together of the three, consciousness, organ, and object;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sparśapratyayā ca vedanā saṃjñā cetan''etyuktaṃ bhagavatā /
column2: by reason of contact, there would be sensation and ideas. As the Blessed One teaches, “By reason of the mental organ and the dharmas, mental consciousness arises;
by the coming together of these three, there is contact, sensation, ideas, and volition arise at the same time.”
Hence, if one. admits that the mind continues to exist in this absorption, sensation and ideas will not be arrested in it. Now this absorption is called the extinction of sensation and ideas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā vedanāpratyayā tṛṣṇe“tyuktam / satyāmapi tu vedanāyāmarhato na tṛṣṇotpattirevaṃ satyapi sparśe vedannādayo na syuriti / tasyāviśeṣitatvāt /
column2: The Sūtra says, "By reason of sensation, there is thirst," and yet, although Arhats experience sensation, thirst does not arise in them. The same here: every contact is not a cause of seṇsation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avidyāsaṃsparśajaṃ hi veditaṃ pratītyotpannā tṛṣṇetyuktaṃ natu vedanotpattau sparśo viśeṣita ityasamānametat /
column2: This reasoning is not conclusive. The Sūtra, in fact, specifies, "Thirst arises by reason of sensation born of contact which is accompanied by ignorance". Whereas it says, "Sensation arises by reason of contact.
Hence, say the Vaibhāṣikas, the mind is interrupted in the absorption of extinction.

If this absorption is completely free of mind, how is it an absorption? It is called an absorption because it puts the primary elements into a state of equilibrium contrary to the production of the mind; or rather because ascetics penetrate it by the power of their minds: it is for this reason that the Dhyānas, etc. , are called.

Yes, for they thwart the arising of the mind. No, it is not what you term “absorption” that hinders the arising of the mind; rather, it is the “mind in absorption”, the mind that precedes the state of absorption: this mind, being opposed to the arising of the mind, causes other minds to not arise for a certain time. The mind of absorption renders the person or series contrary to, and unfitted to the arising of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāpatticittena ca tāṃ samāpadyante samāgacchantīti samāpattiḥ /
column2: What is called “absorption” is simply the non-existence of the mind for a certain period of time; not a thing in and of itself, but a “thing of designation”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punarete samāpattī dravyataḥ sta utāho prajñaptitaḥ / dravyata ityāha /
column2: How can an absorption be conditioned if it is not a thing in and of itself?
This “non-existence of the mind” was not realized before the mind of absorption;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāpatticittameva hi taccittāntaraviruddhamutpadyate yena kālāntaraṃ cittasyā pravṛttimātraṃ bhavati / tadviruddhāśrayāpādanāt /
column2: it ceases when the ascetic produces anew the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yā 'sau samāpattiriti prajñapyate taccāpravṛttimātraṃ na pūrvamāsīnna paścāt bhavati vyutthitasyeti saṃskṛtā 'sau samāpattiḥ prajñapyate /
column2: One can then, in a manner of speaking, designate it as being “conditioned,” since it begins and ends.
Or rather, what we call “absorption” is the condition of the. person, a condition that results from the mind of absorption.
The same holds for non-consciousness. Āsaṁjñikéa is not a thing in and of itself that hinders the arising of the mind;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cittamevāsau tatra cittapravṛttiviruddhaṃ labhate taccāpravṛttimātramāsaṃjñikaṃ prajñapyata iti tadetanna varṇayanti / vyākhyāte samāpattī //
