column2: but we designate by this term the state of non-consciousness of the Non-Conscious gods, a state that results from a certain mind. The Vaibhāṣikas do not agree with this opinion; they maintain that āsaṁjñika and the two absorptions are things in and of themselves.
What is the vital oṟgan?
Jīvita is life. In fact, the Abhidharma says, “What is the jṝvikendriya?
The āyus of the three spheres of existence.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etaccaiva na jñāyate āyurnāma ka eṣa dharma iti /
column2: What sort of dharma is the āyus?
The support of warmth and consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idamuktaṃ bhagavatā “āyurūṣmātha vijñānaṃ yadā kāyaṃ jahatyamī / apaviddhastadā śete yathā kāṣṭhamacetana” iti //
column2: For the Blessed One said, “When life, warmth and consciousness leave the body, the body lies abandoned, like wood, lacking feeling.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tad ya ūṣmaṇo vijñānasya cādhārabhūto dharmaḥ sthitihetustadāyuḥ /
column2: There exists then a distinct dharma, a support of warmth and of consciousness, a cause of the duration of the series, natmed āyu.

If the ġyur supports warmth and consciousness, what supports it? It is supported by warmth and consciousness. If these three dharmas,—life, warmth, and consciousness,—mutually support one another and continue to exist by means of this mutual support, how do they come to an end?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi parasparāpekṣyavṛttitvādeṣāṃ kaḥ pūrvaṃ nivartiṣyate /
column2: Which perishes first, the destruction of which entails the destruction of the others?
For if one of them does not perish first, then these three dharmas will be eternal and will not perish.
The āyus is supported by means of actions; the āyus has been projected through actions and continues to exist as long as the projection of action allows it to do so.
If this is so, why admit that warmth and consciousness are supported by actions? What do we have to do with the āyṇus? That which is supported by action is, in its nature, retribution.

If the consciousness were supported by action, all consciousness from the womb to death, would be retribution; and this is false. Hence the necessity of the āyus, supported by action, the support of warmth and consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ūṣmaṇastarhi karmādhārbhūtaṃ bhaviṣyati ūṣmā ca vijñānasya /
column2: You say then that action supporṟts warmth andThen the warmth supports consciousness. The āyus is necessary, for warmth is absent in Ārūpyadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamapyārūpyeṣvanādhāraṃ vijñānaṃ syādūṣmābhāvāt / tasya punaḥ karmādhāro bhaviṣyati / [073/28-074/01
column2: What is the support of consciousness in Ārūpyadhātu if the gyws does not exist?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na vai labhyate kāmacāro yat kvacidevoṣmā vijñānasyādhāro bhaviṣyati kvacideva karmeti / uktaṃ cātra /
column2: In Ārūpyadhātu, consciousness is supported by action.
Do you have the right to change your mind? Sometimes you maintain that the consciousness is supported by warmth, and sometimes you maintain that it is supported by actions.
But on the other hand, you have admitted that one should avoid the conclusion that all consciousnesses, from the womb to death, are retribution.
Consequently the āyus exists, and it is the support of warmth and consciousness.
We do not deny the existence of the āyus.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tarhi / traidhātukena karmaṇā nikāyasabhāgasya sthitikālāvedhaḥ /
column2: We only say that the ġyus is not a thing in and of itself. Then what is the dharma that you call āyus?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvaddhi karmaṇā nikāyasabhāgasyāvedhaḥ kṛto bhavatyetāvantaṃ kālamavasthātavyamiti tāvat so 'vatiṣṭhate tadāyurityucyate /
column2: It is a certain power that the action of a previous existence places in a being at the moment of its conception, a power through which the séandhas renew themselves for a determined length of time in this homogeneous series that constitutes an. existence, in the same way a seed places a certain power in the sprout by which the plant develops to maturity.
In this same way too a shot arrow has a certain power which causes it to travel for a certain period of time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastu manyate saṃskāro nāma kaścin guṇaviśeṣa iṣau jāyate yadvaśādgamanamāpatanād bhavatīti /
column2: a certain sort of guṇa or “quality,” called saṁskāra or vega arises in the arrow.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya tadekatvāt pratipannābhāvācca deśāntaraiḥ śīghra taratamaprāptikālabhedā nupapattiḥ patanānupapattiśca /
column2: By the force of this guṇa, the arrow travels without stopping until the moment it falls. The saṁskāra is unique; on the one hand, the arrow does not encounter any obstacle: hence no difference is possible in the speed of the arrow. On the other hand, the arrow will not fall.
Would you say the “wind” creates an obstacle to the sa/skāra?
The “wind'” which creates an obstacle is the same either far or near, and so the arrow would either fall at first, or it will never fall.
The Vaibhāṣikas maintain that the āyas is a thing in and of itself.
Does death take place solely through the exhaustion of life?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prajñaptāvuktam “āyuḥkṣayānmaraṇaṃ na puṇyakṣayādi“ti / catuṣkoṭiḥ / prathamā koṭirāyurvipākasya karmaṇaḥ paryādānāt / dvitīyā bhogavipākasya / tṛtīyobhayoḥ / caturthī viṣamāparihāreṇa / āyurutsargācceti vaktavyakm / na vaktavyam / āyuḥkṣayādeva tanmaraṇam / prathamakoṭyantargamāt /
column2: 'The Prajñaptiáfāṣ¢ra sags, “It happens that oṉe dies through the exhaustion of life without one dying through the exhaustion of merit.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣīṇe tvāyuṣi puṇyakṣayasya maraṇe nāsti sāmarthyam /
column2: When life is exhausted, the exhaustion of actions that ripen in the objects of enjoyment has no efficacy for death;
and vice versa. Consequently the third alternative should be understood as “death because the two types of actions are exhausted.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jñānaprasthāne 'pyuktam “āyuḥ santatyupanibaddhaṃ vartata iti vaktavyam / sakṛdutpannaṃ tiṣṭhanīti vaktavyam / āha /
column2: The Jñānaprasthāana says, “Should one say of the āyus that it is 'dependent on the series,' or that 'it lasts once it has arisen?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacarāṇāṃ sattvānāmasaṃjñisamāparttiṃ nirodhasamāparttiṃ ca samāpannānāṃ santatyupanibaddhaṃ varttata iti vaktavyam / samāpannānāṃ rūpārūpyāvacarāṇāṃ ca sattvānāṃ sakrdutpannaṃ tiṣṭhatīti vaktavyam” / ko 'sya bhāṣitasyārthaḥ /
column2: ' The āyus is of the first category for beings in Kāmadhātu who are not in one of the two absorptions, but it is of the second category for beings in Kamadhātu who are in the two absorptions, and for beings in. ”If the āyus is killed when the body is killed, then the āyes is "bound to the body-series.” If the body cannot be damaged, then the āyur lasts all the time for which it has been produced, and one says that the āyas lasts once it has arisen.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasyāśrayopaghātādupāghatastatsantatyadhīnatvāt prathamam / yasya tvāśrayopaghāta eva nāsti tadyatho tpannāvasthānāt dvitīyam / sāntarāyaṃ prathamaṃ nirantarāyaṃ dvitīyamiti kāśmīrāḥ /
column2: The Mastets of Kaśmiīr say that the first type of āyus is “subject to obstruction,” but that the second is not subject to obstruction.
Thus there is premature death.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra uktam “catvāra ātmabhāvapratilambhāḥ / astyātmabhāvapratilambho yatrātmasaṃcetanā kramate na parasaṃcetane“ti / catuṣkoṭikaḥ /
column2: According to the Sūtra, there are four modes of existence: existence that can be destroyed by oneself and not by another, etc. Four alternatives: 1.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmasaṃcetanaiva kramate kāmadhātau krīḍāpramoṣkāṇāṃ devānāṃ manaḥpradūṣakāṇāṃ ca / teṣāṃ hi praharṣamanaḥopradoṣābhyāṃ tasmāt sthānāccyutirbhavati nānyathā/ duddhānāṃ ceti vaktavyam / svayaṃmṛtyutvāt /
column2: existence destroyed by oneself: certain beings in Kāmadhātu, namely the Krīdāpradūṣika gods and the Manaḥpradūṣika gods destroy their own existence through their excess of joy or anger; we must also add the Buddhas who enter into Nirvāra;
existences destroyed by others: beings in the womb and in eggs;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhayamapyeṣāṃ kāmāvacarāṇāṃ prāyeṇa / nobhayaṃ sarveṣā mantarābhavikāṇāṃ rūpārūpyāvacarāṇāmanekajātīyānāṃ kāmāvacarāṇāṃ
column2: existences destroyed by oneself and by others: beings in Kāmadhātu inWe must exclude beings in bhell, beings in the intermediate state, etc. existences that are neither destroyed by oneself nor by others: beings in the intermediate state, all beings in Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu, and a part of the beings in Kāmadhātu: beings in hell, the inhabitants of Uttarakuru, petsons in the absorption of kindness, persons in the non-conscious absorption;
the Rājarṣi, that is, the Cakravarṛtin who has left the householders's life; a messenger of the Buddha;
persons whom the Buddha prophesized would live a certain length of time: Dharmila, Uttara, Gaṅgila, the son of the merchant Yaśas, Kumāra, Jīvaka, etc. ; the Bodhisattva in his last existence;
the mother of the Bodhisattva pregnant with the Bodhisattva; the Cakravartin; the mother of the Cakravartin pregnant with the Cakravartin.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kasmātsūtra uktaṃ katame te bhadanta sattvā yeṣāṃ nātmasaṃcetanā kramate na parasaṃacetanā /
column2: The Sūtra tells us of a question by Śariputra and the Blessed One's answer to it: “‘Lord, What are the beings whose existence cannot be destroyed either by themselves, or by others? ”How can you say, in the light of this passage, that the existence of all beings in Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu is protected from all destruction, either by themselves or others?

The School explains, “Beings in Rūpadhātu and the first three stages of Ārūpyadhātu can destroy their existence ‘by themselves,'” that is, by a course of action within their own realm, and ‘by others,' namely by a course of action belonging to the preliminary stages of a higher stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyeṣu kila dhyānarūpyedhvātmasaṃcetanāsvabhūmika āryamārgaḥ parasaṃcetanā uttarabhūmisāmantakastatra cobhayaṃ nāstīti /
column2: But in the last stage of Ārūpyadhātu a course of action belonging to this stage and also of actions of a superior stage are both absent; hence the existence of beings who reside therein cannot be modified either by themselves or by others. This answer appears weak to us;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu caivaṃ tatrāpi parabhūmika āryamārgaḥ parasaṃcetanā prāpnoti /
column2: in fact, one can, in the last stage of Ārūpyadhātu practice a course of action belonging to the immediately lower stage. One must then admit another explanation. In his response to Śāriputa, theBuddha intends to designate all beings in Rūpadhātu and Arūpyadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paryantagrahaṇāttarhi tadādisaṃpratyayaḥ / kvacidādisaṃpratyayaḥ kvacidādinā paryanto 'pi pratīyate / yadāha /
column2: We can demonstrate that such is the usage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “tadyathā devā brahmakāyikāḥ / iyaṃ prathamā sukhopapattiriti / kvacit paryantenādirapi pratīyate /
column2: Sometimes Scripture names the first term of a list the totality of which is alluded to, for example, “The first sukhopapaiti, namely the Brahmakāyika gods.
” We should then also understand, “the Brahmakāyikas, the Brahmapurohitas, and the Mahābrahmās.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā devā ābhāsvarāḥ / iyaṃ dvitīyā sukhopapattiri“ti
column2: ” Sometimes Scripture names the last term, “The second fukhopapatti, namely the Ābhāsvara gods. ” We should then understand, “the Parīttābhas, the Apramāṇābhas, and the Ābhāsvaras. ” But one can contest this explanation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ayamatra tadyathāśabdo dṛṣṭāntavācaka iti yukta etasmāccheṣasaṃ pratyayaḥ / eṣa hi dṛṣṭāntadharmo yadekamapi tajjātīyakaṃ dṛśyate /
column2: In the two passages given above the word £adyathā is used to introduce an example.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa ceha tadyathāśabdo nāstītyanupasaṃhāra eṣaḥ / yadyayaṃ tadyathāśabdo dṛṣṭāntavācakaḥ syādiha na prāpnuyāt /
column2: We must translate ¢adyathā not as “namely” but as “for example.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santi sattvā nānātvakāyā nānātvasaṃjñinastadyathā manuṣyastadekatyāścadevā iti / tasmādupadarśanārtha evāyaṃ draṣṭavya ityalamatiprasaṅgena / uktaṃ jīvitam //
column2: ” It is a rule concerning examples that when one names one case one designates all similar cases. And we admit that, in the two above passages on the sukhopapattis, the Scripture designated all the terms of the list by.
Their characteristics are arising, old age, duration, and impermanence.
These four dharmas, arising, old age, duration, and impermanence, are the characteristics of conditioned things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatraitāni bhavanti sa dharmaḥ saṃskṛto lakṣyate / viparyayādasaṃskṛtaḥ /
column2: A dharma in which these characteristics are found is conditioned; a dharma in which they are not found is unconditioned. Arising produces or causes to produce conditioned things; duration.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra jātistaṃ dharmaṃ janayati sthitiḥ sthapayati jarā jarayati anityatā vināśayati /
column2: Stabilizes them or causes them to last; old age makes them deteriorate; and impermanence destroys them.

Does not the Sūtra teach the existence of some three “conditioned characteristics' of conditioned things? The Sūtra says, in fact, “There are, oh Bhikṣus, three characteristics of conditioned things, which are themselves conditioned. What are these three? The production or origin of conditioned things is an object of consciousness; its disappearance and also its duration-modification is an object of consciousness.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturthamapyatra vaktavyaṃ syāt / kiṃ cātra noktam / āha /
column2: The Sūtra should enumerate four characteristics.
The characteristic that it omits is the characteristic of duration or sthiti.
Truth to tell, it does use shi in the compound, sthiṭyanyathātva, “duration-modification;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jarāyā eṣa paryāyastadyathā jāterutpāda ityanityatāyāśca vyaya iti /
column2: ” but srhityanyathātva is an expression that signifies “old age.” As the Sūtra says “production” in place of “arising” and “disappeaṟance” in place of “impermanence”, in this same way it also says sthityanyathātva in place of “old age”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye hi dharmāḥ saṃskārāṇāmadhvasaṃcārāya pravṛttāsta eva sūtre lakṣaṇānyuktānyudvejanārtham /
column2: If the Sūtra specifies only three characteristics, it is because, with aview to rousing disgust among believers, it points out as the characteristics of conditioned things those dharmas which cause conditioned things to pass through the three timne periods: the power of its arising causes it to pass from the future into the present;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jātirhi yā saṃskārānanāgatādadhvanaḥ pratyutpannamadhvānaṃ saṃcārayati / jarā 'nityate punaḥ pratyutpannādatītaṃ durbalīkṛtya pratighātāt /
column2: old age and impermanence cause it to pass from the present into the past, and, after old age has weakened it, impermanence finishes it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā kila gahanapraviṣṭasya puruṣasya trayaḥ śatravaḥ /
column2: The School gives a comparision : Suppose there is a man in a dark forest, and there are three enemies there who wish to kill him. The first causes this man to leave the forest;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tata eka enaṃ gahanādākarṣet dvau punarjīvitādvacyaparopayetāṃ tadvaditi /
column2: the second weakens him, and the third destroys his vital principle. Such is the role of the three characteristics with regard to conditioned things.
Duration, on the contrary, sustains conditioned things and causes them to last;
this is why the Sūtra does not count it among the characteristics.

Further, the unconditioned lasts eternally in its own nature: the characteristic of duration is not without resemblance to the persistence. So in order to avoid any confusion, the Sutra does not indicate duration as a characteristic of conditioned things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye punaḥ kalpayanti sthitiṃ jarāṃ cābhisamasya sthityanyathātvamityekaṃ lakṣaṇamuktaṃ sūtre /
column2: The Sutra does name duration; it names it by associating it with old age: sthityanyathatva, that is to say, "sthii and anyathatva.
What advantage is there, would you say, in making one single characteristic out of these two characteristics?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣā hyeṣu saṅgāspadamataḥ śriyamivaināṃ kālakarṇīsahitāṃ darśayāmāsa tasyāmanāsaṅgārthamiti /
column2: Persons are attracted to duration: in order to incite disgust with respect to duration, the Sutra names it together with old age, like prosperity associated with black ears.
Conclusion: there are four characteristics.
The arising, duration, etc. , of any sort of dharma is also conditioned.

They should also arise, last, grow old, and perish; they should then, in their turn, possess four characteristics: arising-of-arising, etc. , which will be the secondary characteristics of the dharma under consideration.

These secondary characteristics, being conditioned, have in their turn four characteristics, and so we have infinite. There is no infinite progression. They have in their turn characteristics termed arising-ofarising, duratioṉ-of-duṟatioṉ, etc. Four primary characteristics are as descṛibed above.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jātijātiḥ sthitisthitiḥ jarājarā anityatā 'nityatā iti / nanu caikasyaikasya caturlakṣaṇī prāpnoti aparyavasānadoṣaśca /
column2: The four secondary characteristics are arising-ofarising, duration-of-duṟation, old age-of-old age, and impermanenceof-impermaṅṇence. All conditioned things are conditioned by these primary characteristics;

these, in their turn, are conditioned by the four secondary characteristics. You say that each of the primary characteristics should have, exactly as the dharma that it characterizes, foar characteristics, and thus following: you do not understand that these are the activity, the operationṅ of the different chaṟacteristics.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te 'ṣṭadharmaikavṛttayaḥ / teṣāṃ jātyādīnāmaṣṭāsu dharmeṣu vṛttiḥ / kimidaṃ vṛttiriti / kāritraṃ puruṣakāraḥ /
column2: The primary characteristic refers to eight dharmas, the secondary characteristic to one dharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jātijātyādīnāṃ caikatra dharme kathaṃ kṛtvā ātmanā navamo hi dharma utpadyate / sārdhaṃ lakṣaṇānulakṣaṇairaṣṭābhiḥ / tatra jātirātmānaṃ virahayyānyānaṣṭau dharmān janayati /
column2: When a dharma arises—which we will term the principle dharma ot m#ladharma, a mind or a mental state—nine dharmas, including it, aṟise together: the principal dharma, tour primary characteristics, andThe first primary characteristic, primary arising causes the principle dharma, plus the three primary characteristics, plus the four secondary characteristics to arise: in all eight dharmas.

column2: But, the Sūtra says “The production of coṇditioned things is an object of consciousness . Ignorant! You are attached to the words and err with regard to their meaning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avidyāndhā hi bālāḥ saṃskārapravāhamātmāta ātmīyataścādhimuktā abhiṣvajante /
column2: Blinded by ignorance, foolish persons imagine that the series of conditioned phenomena is a “self” or belongs to a "self,”The Blessed One wanted to put an end to this erroneous imagination and to the attachment which results from it: he wanted to show that the series is conditioned, that is to say, “produced through successive causes” ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya mithyādhimokṣasya vyāvarttanārthaṃ bhagavāṃstasya saṃskārapravāhasyasaṃskṛtatvaṃ pratītyasamutpannatāṃ dyotayitukāma idamāha “triṇīmāni saṃskṛtasya saṃskṛtalakṣaṇāni” / na tu kṣaṇasya /
column2: and he taught the three marks of that which is produced through successive causes, saying that “Three savskṛ̥alaksaṉas of the saṁskṛta are the object of consciousness.

It is the series that the Blessed One means to designate as conditioned, for, quite clearly, he does not attribute the three marks to each moment of the series, since he says that these marks are the object of consciousness: in fact, the production of the momeart, its aging, and its disappearance, are not the objects of consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nacāprajñāyamānā ete lakṣaṇaṃ bhavitumarhanti / atha evātra sūtre “saṃskṛtasyotpādo 'pi prajñāyata” ityuktam /
column2: whatever is not the object of consciousness canvpot be a mark. If the Sūtra uses the word sa/ṁskṛta twice, “There are three saṁskr̥talakṣaṇas of the saṁsṣkr̥ta,” this is in order that one should know that these three marks are not marks showing the presence of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaḥ saṃskṛtagrahaṇaṃ saṃskṛtatve lakṣaṇānīti yathā vijñāye ta / maivaṃ vijñāyi saṃskṛtasya vastuno 'stitve lakṣaṇāni jalavalākāvat sādhvasādutve vā kanyālakṣaṇavaditi /
column2: According to us, what one should understand by production or arising is the fact that the series begins;
disappearance or impermanence is the end or cessation of the series;
duration is the series continuing from its beginning until its end;

evolution or old age is the modification of the continuous series, the difference between its successive states. It is from this point of view—that is, by considering arising, enduring, prolonging itself, and modifying itself—that theFine, my man!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca kṛtvoktaṃ “viditā eva nandasya kulaputrasya vedanā utpadyante viditā ava tiṣṭhante viditā astaṃ parikṣayaṃ paryādānaṃ gacchantī“ti / āha cātra
column2: You know that your sensations arise, last, end, and disappear.
We would then say, “Arising is the beginning of the series, disappearance is its rapture; duration is the series itself;
evolution is the difference between its successive states,” And again,
“Arising is existence following upon non-existence; duration is the series; impermanence is the rupture of the series;
and evolution is supposed to be the difference between the successive states of the series.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “kṣaṇikasya hi dharmasya vinā sthityā vyayo bhavet /
column2: “Since the dharmas are momentary, would you say that the dharmas will perish if duration is lacking?

column2: But they perish spontaneously: in vain you attribute duration to a momentary dharma.”
Consequently it is the series that the Sūtra refers to when it speaks of duration, and the definition of the Abhidharma is justified,
“What is duration?
The sa/īskāraṣ arisenThe nature of the moment cannot be arisen and not be destroyed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadapi ca jñānaprasthāna uktam “ekasmiṃścitte ka utpādaḥ / āha /
column2: Yet the Jñānaprasthāna says, "Relative to one mind, what is production?
It is arising.
What is disappearance? It is death.
What is evolution? It is old age.

But this passage of the Śāstra does not refer to a moment of the mind, but to the mind of a homogeneous existence.
pratikṣaṇaṃ cāpi saṃskṛtasyaitāni lakṣaṇāni yujyante vinā 'pi dravyāntarakalpanayā / kathamiti /	However, since one cannot consider characteristics as things in and of themselves, one can say that each moment taken separately possesses the four characteristics.
pratikṣaṇamabhūtvābhāva utpādaḥ /	In fact, each moment exists after having been non-existent: its existence, following upon its non-existence, is its arising;
bhūtvā 'bhāvo vyayaḥ /	after having existed, it does not exist anymore: this is its disappearance;
pūrvasya pūrvasyottarakṣaṇānuvandhaḥ sthitiḥ /	the duration of the moment is the concatenation or the process of successive moments: in fact, if the subsequent moment resembles the previous moment, it is then its substitute: the previous moment still. Thus the subsequent moment can be considered as the duration of the previous moment;
tasyāvisdṛśatvaṃ sthityanyathātvamiti / yadā tarhi sadṛśā utpadyante /	the dissimilitude of duration is its transformation.
na te nirviśeṣā bhavanti / kathamidaṃ jñāyate /	Would you say that there is no dissimilitude when the successive moments are similar?
kṣiptākṣiptabalidurbalakṣiptasya vajrādeścirāśutarapātakālabhedāttanmahābhūtānāṃ pariṇāmaviśeṣasiddheḥ /	There is dissimilitude, as this results from the difference in time of the slower or faster falling of a vajra that is or is not projected, and which is projected with or without force: difference due in each case to a transformation or a difference of the primary elements of the vajra. When the dharmas succeed themselves in a homogeneous series, the difference is small;
nātivahuviśeṣabhinnāstu saṃskārāḥ satyapyanyathātve sadṛśā eva dṛśyante /	that is why, although they differ, they are considered as similar. Your definition of characteristics does not hold for all conditioned dharmas. In fact, your definition of duration supposes a subsequent moment: but such a moment does not exist for the last moment of the mind of an Arhat.
antimasya tarhi śabdārciḥkṣaṇasya parinirvāṇakāle ca ṣaḍāyatanasyottarakṣaṇābhāvāt sthityahnyanyathātvaṃ nāstītyavyāpinī lakṣaṇavyavasthā prāpnoti	Hence the last moment of a sound, a flame, or an Arhat, has neither duration nor transformation.
na vai saṃskṛtasya sthitirevocyate /	We do not attribute duration to all conditioned dharras!
lakṣaṇamapi tu sthityanyathātvam /	We say rather, that all duration is subject to transformation. The Blessed One teaches three characteristics, because, in certain cases, there are three characteristics.
ato yasyāsti sthitistasyāvaśyamanyathātvaṃ bhavatīti nāsti lakṣaṇavyavasthābhedaḥ /	But, for the last moment of a flame, there is only producation and disappearance, and no duration or transformation. In short, conditioned dharmas exist after having existed; after having existed, they no longer exist;
samāsatastvatra sūtre saṃskṛtasyedaṃ lakṣaṇamiti dyotitaṃ bhagavatā “saṃskṛtaṃ nāma yadbhūtavā bhavati bhūtvā ca punarna bhavati yaścāsya sthitisaṃjñakaḥ prabandhaḥ so 'nyathā cānyathā ca bhavatī“ti /	the series of dharmas is their duration; dissimilarity of the series is their transformation. Such is the teaching that the Blessed One gives in the Sū⁸ra of the Three Characteristics.
kim atra dravyāntarair jātyādibhiḥ katham idānīṃ sa eva dharmo lakṣyas tasyaiva lakṣaṇaṃ yokṣyate /	This has nothing to do with things in and of themselves, arising, etc. According to you, arising is the dharma itself in so far as it exists after having been non-existent. The dharma which is the “thing characterized”, would then be the characteristic also. What is wrong with that?
kathaṃ tāvan mahāpuruṣalakṣaṇāni mahāpuruṣān nānyāni sāsnā-lāṅgūla-kakuda-śapha-viṣāṇādīni	The marks of a Mahāpuruṣa are not different or distinct from the Mahāpuruṣa himself.
ca gotvalakṣaṇāni gor nānyāni kāṭhinyādīni ca pṛthivīdhātvādīnāṃ lakṣaṇāni tebhyo nānyāni /	The horns, theThe hump, the fetlock, the hoof, and the tail of a cow, which are its marks, are not different from the cow.
yathā codhrvagamanena dūrāddhūmasya dhūmatvaṃ lakṣyate naca tattasmādanyat / sa evātra nyāyaḥ syāt /	The primary elements do not exist apart from their individual characteristics, solidity, etc. In this same way, for the Vaibhāṣikas who affirm the “momentariness” of the dharmas, the rising of smoke is none other than the smoke itself. Let us look at this a bit closer.
naca saṃskṛtānāṃ rūpādīnāṃ tāvat saṃskṛtatvaṃ lakṣyate / gṛhṇatāpi svabhāvaṃ yāvat prāgabhāvo na jñāyate paścācca santateśca viśeṣaḥ /	Although I grasp the individual nature of visible things, etc. , which are conditioned, yet as long as I do not know the fact that they did not exist previously, that they will not exist later, and that their series transforms itself, then I shall not know their quality of being conditioned.
tasmānna tenaiva tallakṣitaṃ bhavati naca tebhyo dravyāntarāṇyeva jātyādīni vidyante /	Consequently, the quality of being conditioned does not have for a mark the quality of being conditioned, but rather previous non-existence, etc. And there do not exist characteristics, things in and of themselves, distinct from visible things and other conditioned things.
athāpi nāma dravyāntarāṇyeva jātyādīni bhaveyuḥ / kimayuktaṃ syāt /	If we admit the reality of characteristics, then since they are.
eko dharmaḥ ekasminneva kāle jātaḥ sthito jīrṇo naṣṭaḥ syādeṣāṃ sahabhūtvāt / kāritrakālabhedāt / anāgatā hi jātiḥ kāritraṃ hi karoti /	Given as simultaneous, we would have to admit that obe harma arises, lasts, grows old and perishes at one and the seme time.
yasmānna jātaṃ janyate janite tu dharme varttamānāḥ kṣityādayaḥ kāritraṃ kurvantīti na yadā jāyate tadā tiṣṭati jīryati vinaśyati vā /	It is in vain that the Sarvāstivādins pretend that the characteristics do not exercise their activity at one and the same time; that arising engenders before being born itself, being still in a future state, and that once it is born it does not engender any longer; that duration, old age, and impermanence exercise their activity when they are present and not in a future state; and that, consequently, the last three characteristics are active in a moment when the fitst is no longer active, so the four characteristics can be simultaneous without contradiction.
idaṃ tāvadiha saṃpradhāryaṃ bhavet /	Let us first consider arising which, being future, engenders.
kimanāgataṃ dravyato 'sti nāstīti paścājjanayati vā naveti sidhyet /	One must examine whether a future dharma, supposing that it does exist, can be active.
satyapi tu tasmin jātiḥ kāritaraṃ kurvatī kathamanāgatā sidhyatītyanāgata lakṣaṇaṃ vaktavyam /	If future arising produces the operation of engendering, how can one say that it is future? In fact, accoṟding to the Vaibhāṣikas, a future ḍharma is one that does not exercise its activity.
uparatakāritrā cotpannā kathaṃ varttamānā sidhyatīti varttamānalakṣāṇaṃ vaktavyam /	You wouldOn the other hand, when a dharrma has arisen, has been engendered, and the operation of arising is past, how can you say that arising is then of the present? You would have to define present.
sthityādayo 'pi ca yugapat kāritre varttamānā ekakṣaṇa eva dharmasya sthitajīrṇavinaṣṭatāṃ prasañjeyuḥ /	And either the activity of the other characteristics is exercised simultaneously, or their activity is exercised in succession.
yadaiva hyenaṃ sthitiḥ sthāpayati tadaiva jrā jarayati anityatā vināśayatīti /	In the first hypothesis, whereas duration makes a dharma last, old age makes it age and impermanence destroys it: the dharma lasts, ages and perishes at the same time. As for the second hypothesis, to admit that the activity of these characteristics is not simultaneous is to admit three moments, and this is to renounce the doctrine of momentariness.
kimayaṃ tatra kāle tiṣṭatvāhosvijjīryatu vinaśyatu vā yo 'pi hi brūyāt sthityādīnāmapi kāritraṃ krameṇeti tasya kṣaṇikatvaṃ bādhyate /	For us, the kṣaṇa or moment is the time during which the characteristics have achieved their operation. Then explain why, in this hypothesis, duration, arising at the same time as old age and impermanence, accomplishes its operation of making last that which should last" before old age and impermanence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athāpyevaṃ brūyāt eṣa eva hi naḥ kṣaṇo yāvataitat sarvaṃ samāpyata iti / evamapoi tābhyāṃ sahotpannā sthitistāvat sthāpayati na jrā jarayati anityatā vā vināśyatīti / kuta etat / sthiterbalīyastvāt / punaḥ kenāvalīyastvam / yadaināṃ saha dharmeṇānityatā hanti /
column2: If you answer that duration, being stronger, accomplishes its operation first, then we would ask how duration is weakened later in such a manner that, encountering old age and impermanence, it ages and perishes, not alone, but with the dharma that it should have made last.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṛtakṛtyā punaḥ karttuṃ notsahate jātivat / sthaturyuktamanutsoḍhum /
column2: You say perhaps that duration, having achieved its task, cannot perform it again, in the same way that arising, having engendered something, engenders no more. The comparison is not legitimate. The operation of arising consists of attracting the dharma that it should engender from the future and causing it to enter into the present;

once the dharma has entered into the present, arising is incapable of making it enter therein again. But the operation of duration is to make the dharma “which should be made to last” last, of hindering the dharma which makes old age and perishing last.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śakyaṃ tu khalu sthityā sthāpyamatyantamapi sthāpayitum /
column2: Duration is capable of making that which lasts last indefinitely.
Consequently, duration isBy reason of what obstacle or from what adverse forces would the activity of duration cease once it has begun?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ko vā 'tra pratibandhaḥ / te eva jarā 'nityate / yadi hi te balīyasyau syātāṃ pūrvameva syātām /
column2: Would these forces be old age and impermanence, old age weakening duration which impermanence then kills? Since, in this hypothesis, old age and impermanence are stronger than duration, it is proper then that they exercise their activity first. Further, according to your conception of duration and its role, it is through the activity of duration that, not only the principal dharma, but also old age and impermanence, last. Hence, when the activity of duration ends, the principal dharma, as well as old age and impermanence, cease their duration.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nivṛttakāritrāyāṃ khalvapi sthitau ta cāpi na tiṣṭataḥ sa cāpi dharma iti kathaṃ kutra vā kāritraṃ karttumutsahiṣyete kiṃ vā punastābhyāṃ karttavyam
column2: We ask how, and with regard to what object, old age and impermanence exercise their activity of aging and causing to perish? We do not see what it is that old age and impermanence have to do.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sthitiparigrahāddhi sa dharma utpannamātro na vyanaśyat /
column2: It is through duration that one dharma, once it arises, does not perish for a certain time, does not perish as soon as it arises. IfWe well understand the duration and impermanence of the dharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tu tayā vyupekṣyamāṇo niyataṃ na sthāsyatyayamevāsya vināśaḥ /
column2: A dharma, after having arisen, does not perish.
A dharma, after having lasted, perishes. But how can one attribute old age to a dharma?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jarā tu khalu sarvathātvena na tathā / pūrvāparaviśeṣāt vipariṇāmācca /
column2: Old age is a transformation, a dissimilarity between two states.
Now, can one say of a single dharma that it becomes different from itself?
If it remains this, it is not that;
if it is transformed, it is no longer this.

Hence the transformation of a dharma is impossible. According to another school, it is with the cooperation of external causes of destruction, fire or a hammer, etc. , that the characteristics of impermanence causes certain dharmas to perish, as wood or a pot.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'pyāha nikāyāntarīyo “vināśa kāraṇaṃ prāpyānityatā vināśāyatī“ti tasya harītakīṃ prāpya devatā virecayatītyāpannaṃ bhavati kiṃ punastāṃ kalpayitvā
column2: This is a theory as absurd as a sick person, who, after having taken a medicine, begs the gods to render it efficacious!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat evāstu vināśakāraṇādvināśaḥ cittacaittānāṃ ca kṣaṇikatvābhyupagamāttadanityatāyā
column2: In the logic of this system, it is the external causes of destruction which destroy, and the. The same School admits that the mind and its mental states, like sound or a flame, perish immediately, without any foreign causes intervening, through the characteristic of impermanence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vināśakāraṇānapekṣatvāt sthityanityate kāritramabhinnakālaṃ kuryātāmityekasyaikatra kāle sthita vinaṣṭatā saṃprasajyeta /
column2: Impermanence and duration accomplish their operation at one and the same time: a dharma lasts and perishes at the same time. This is inadmissible. We conclude that it is with regard to the series that the Blessed One teaches the characteristics of conditioned things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt pravāhaṃ pratyetāni saṃskṛtalakṣaṇānyuktānītyevametatsūtraṃ sūnītaṃ bhavati /
column2: Thus understood, the Sūtra does not invite criticism, "There are three characteristics that show that the conditioned is conditioned, that it is produced through successive causes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apica yadyanāgatā jātirjanyasya janikā kimarthaṃ sarvamanāgataṃ yugapannotpadyate / yasmāt
column2: If arising engenders, in a future state, the dharma that it should engender, why do not all future dharmas arise at one and the same time?
Arising engenders the dharma that it should engender, but not without the cooperation of causes and conditions. Isolated arising does not have the force of engendering the dharma.
If this is the case, we rather believe that it is the cause that engenders, and not arising;
this characteristic accompanies the dharma since the beginning of time and causes the dharma to arise when, finally, the cause of this dharma encounterṛs another!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sati sāmargya bhāvādasati cābhāvānna jāteriti hetupratyayā eva jana kāḥsantaḥ /
column2: When the causes are completed, the dharma arises; when they are not completed, it does not arise: what efficacy can we attribute to aṟising?
Do you pretend to know all the dharmas that exist?
The nature of dharmas is subtle! Even though one sees them, one does not know their nature.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jātamityeva tu na syādasatyāṃ jātau ṣaṣṭhivacanaṃ ca rūpasyotpādaḥ iti yathā rūpasya rūpamiti /
column2: Moreover, in the absence of the characteristic “arising,” the idea of “biṟth” would be absent. Aṇḍ if arising is nothing other than the dharma itself exisitng after having been nonexistent, the genitive “the arising of warmth” or “the arising of sensation” would not be justified;
for this amounts to saying “the warmth of warmth” or “the sensation of sensation.” This is the same.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tena tarhy anātmatvam apy eṣṭavyam anātmabuddhi-siddhyartham /
column2: This theory leads you very far afield: in order to justify the idea of empty, or the idea of the impersonal, you would admit the existence of an entity called “emptiness” or the existence of an entity called “non-self.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃkhyā-parimāṇa-pṛthaktva-saṃyoga-vibhāga-paratva-aparatva-sattādayo 'pi tīrthakara-parikalpitā abhyupagantavyā eka-dvi-mahadaṇu-pṛthak-saṃyukta-viyukta-parāpara-sadādi-buddhi-siddhyartham / ṣaṣṭīvidhānārthaṃ ca rūpasya saṃyoga iti / eṣā ca ṣaṣṭo kathaṃ kalpyate / rūpasya svabhāva iti /
column2: And again, in order to justify the ideas of one and two, large and small, separate, associated and disassociated, this and that, existent, etc. , you would admit, in agreement with the Vaiśeṣikas, a long series of entities: number, extension, individuality, conjunction, disjunction, quality of being that, quality of being this, existence, etc. It obliges you to create a “pot-ness” in order to justify the idea of a pot. As for the genitive, you do not admit that the individual nature of warmth and warmth are different things, and yet you speak of the individual nature of warmth.

Hence you have not proven that “arising” is a thing in and of itself; you have not proven that this is not merely a designation of a dharma in so far as it exists after having been non-existent. When I want to teach someone that a certain dharma exists which formerly did not exist, I say to him, “This dhara has arisen,” and I designate this dharma as being born. Many dharmas—warmth, sensation, etc. ,. —arise, that is to say, “exist after having been nonexistent.”
Hence there are many arisings, that is, many dharmas arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya viśeṣaṇārthaṃ rūpasyotpāda iti ṣaṣṭīṃ kurvanti yathā rupasaṃjñaka evotpādaḥ pratīyeta mā 'nyaḥ pratyāyīti /
column2: Since arising is multiple, in order to distinguish it from other arisings, so that my questioner knows that it refers to an arising having the name “warmth” and not to an arising having the name “sensation,” I will employ the genitive, “the arising of warmth,” or “the arising of sensation,” although the arising of warmth is only the warmth arising.
In the same way one says, in the world, “the odor of sandalwood,” although sandalwood is only odor, or “the body of the bust,” although a bust is only its body.
We hold to the existence of the characteristic “arising,” which belongs to conditioned things and does not belong to unconditioned things, and we can easily explain this by.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi jātyā vinā jāyate kasmādasaṃskṛtamapyākāśādikaṃ na jāyate /
column2: But if conditioned things arise without "arising," why do unconditioned things, space, etc. , not arise?
We say that conditioned things arise, for they exist after having been non-existent.
But how can unconditioned things arise, since they are eternal?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca dharmatayā na sarvaṃ jātimadiṣyate tathā na sarvaṃ jāyata ityeṣṭavyam /
column2: You explain that certain dharmas, the unconditioned dharmas, are devoid of the characteristic "arising," because, you say, such is the nature of things: we say, rather, that by virtue of the nature of things, none of the dharmas are susceptible of arising. Moreover, according to you, all conditioned things equally possess the characteristic "arising" that you refuse to unconditioned things: yet you admit that certain causes are capable of producing warmth but incapable of producing sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca tulye jātimattve tadanye pratyayāstadanyasyotpādane na samarthā bhavantyevamevāsaṃskṛtasyotpādane sarve 'pyasamarthāḥ syuḥ / siddhā eva tu dravyabhāvena jātyādaya iti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: In the same way, according to you, since conditioned and unconditioned things are equally devoid of the characteristic of "arising," all causes that produce conditioned things are inefficacious with regard to unconditioned things. Why should we abandon the Āgamas for the sole reason that there are persons who object to them?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi dūṣakāḥ santītyāgamā apāsyante nahi mṛgāḥ santīti yavā noṣyante nahi makṣikāḥ patantīti modakā na bhakṣyante /
column2: One does not renounce sowing for fear of deer, and one does not renounce eating dainties because of flies.
One must refute objections and adhere to the Doctrine.
What is nāmakāya, padakāya, and vyañjanakāya?
Nāmakāya, etc. , are collections of saṁġjñās, vākyas, and akṣaras.

Nāmam, “name” or “word” is understood as “that which causes ideas to arise,” for example the words “warmth,” “sound,” “odor,” etc. Pada or “phrase” is understood as vākya, a discourse, a phrase allowing the development necessary for a complete sentence, for example the stanza, “Impermanent are the sarséāras .
” and the rest.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vākyaṃ padaṃ yāvatā 'rthaparisamāptistadyathā “anityā vata saṃskārā” ityevamādi yena kriyāguṇakālasaṃbandhaviśeṣā gamyante /
column2: Or rather, one should understand pada as that which causes one to comprehend the different modalities of activity, quality, and time which concern a certain person: for example, he cooks, he reads, hehe cooks, he will cook, or he cooked.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vyañjanamakṣaraṃ tadyathā a ā ityevamādi / nanu cākṣarāṇyapi lipyavayavānāṃ nāmāni /
column2: Vyañjana is understood as gkṣara or phoneme, vowels and consonents, for example, etc. But are not the gkṣaras the names of the letters?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na vai lipyavayavānāṃ pratyāyanārthamakṣārāṇi praṇītānyakṣarāṇāmeva tu pratyāyanārthaṃ lipyavayavāḥ praṇītāḥ /
column2: One does not make or one does not pronounce phonemes with a view to designating, or of giving an idea of the letters;
but one makes or one writes the letters with a view to giving an idea of the phonemes, so that, when one does not understand them, one still has an idea of them through writing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣāṃ ca saṃjñādīnāṃ samuktayo nāmādikāyāḥ / uca samavāye paṭhanti /
column2: Consequently the phonemes are not the names of letters.
Kāya or “body” means “collection;
” samukti, in fact, has the sense of samavāya according to the Dhātupāṭha, iv.
Hence we have: nāmakāya = color, sound, odor, etc. ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: padakāyaḥ tadyathā “sarvasaṃskārā anityāḥ sarvadharma anātmānaḥ śāntaṃ nirvāṇami” tyevamādi /
column2: padakāya = “The saṁskārar aṭe impeṟmanent, the dharmas are impersonal, Nirvana is tranquil. ” etc;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vyañjanakāyastadyathā ka kha ga gha ñetyevamādi /
column2: and vyañanakāya = ka, kha, ga, gha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu caite vāksvabhāvatvācchabdātmakā iti rūpasvabhāvā bhavanti / kasmāccittaviprayuktā ityucyante /
column2: Are not words, phrases, and phonemes “voice” by nature, and consequently “sound”? Hence they form part of the.
They are not “voice.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ghoṣo hi vāk naca ghoṣāmātrenārthāḥ pratīyante / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: Voice is “vocal sound,” and a vocal sound only; for example, a cṛy does not cause one to attain to or comprehend an object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vāṅnāmni pravrttate nāmārthaṃ dyotayati naiva ghoṣamātraṃ vāg yena tu ghoṣeṇārthaḥ pratīyate sa ghoṣo vāk / kena punarghoṣeṇārthaḥ pratīyate /
column2: But a word which moreover is a function of vocal sound, illumines, causes one to attain to, or signifies the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'rtheṣu kṛtāvadhirvaktṛbhistadyathāgaurityeṣa śabdo navasvartheṣu kṛtāvadhiḥ / “vāgdigbhūraśmivajreṣu paśvakṣisvargavāriṣu /
column2: What I call “voice” is not merely vocal sound, but a vocal sound that causes one to attain to an object, that is, a vocal sound with regard to which persons who are speaking are in agreement as to what a certain thing signifies.

It is thus that the Ancients have invested the sound go with the power to signify nine things: “The sages have established the sound go in nine things, that is, caṟrdinal region, cattle, land, a beam of light, a word, a diamond, an eye, a haven, and water.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'pi hi manyate nāmārthaṃ dyotayatīti tenāpyetadavaśyamabhyupagantavyaṃ yadi pratīpadārthakaṃ bhavatīti /
column2: The philosopher for whom “it is the word which illumines the object” should admit that the sound go has been endowed by convention with these different meanings. If a given object is signified to the hearer by a certain word, it is indeed vocal sound and nothing else, that signifies it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taccaita cchabdamātrādeva pratītapadārthakāt sidhyatīti kimartharaṃ nāma kalpayitvā /
column2: What advantage is there in supposing the existence of an entity you call "word?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idaṃ cāpi na jñāyate kathaṃ vāṅnāmni pravarttata iti / kiṃ tāvadutpādayatyāhosvit prakāśayati / yadyutpāda yati /
column2: A word is either produced by the voice or revealed by the voice.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ghoṣasvavatvādvācaḥ sarvaṃ ghoṣamātraṃ nāmotpādayiṣyati yādṛśo vā ghoṣaviāśeṣa iṣyate nāmna utpādakaḥ sa evārthasya dyotako bhaviṣyati / atha prakāśayati /
column2: In the first hypothesis, since voice is vocal sound by nature, any vocal sound whatsoever, even the cry of an animal, would produce a word.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ghoṣasvabhāvatvādvācaḥ sarvaṃ ghoṣamātraṃ nāma prakaśayiṣyati yādṛśo vā ghoṣaviśeṣa iṣyate nāmnaḥ parakāśakaḥ sa evārthasya dyotako bhaviṣyati
column2: If you answer that a word is produced solely through a vocal sound of a certain nature—the articulation of sound, varṇātmaka—we would say that this sort of vocal sound which is capable of producing a word would be quite capable of designating an object also. In the second hypothesis, this same criticism holds by replacing the verb "to produce" with the verb "to manifest. But it is absurd to suppose that the voice produces a word.
In fact, sounds do not exist at the same time—one has, for example, r-i-p-a—whereas the word, which you define as a dharmna, an entity, cannot arise in parts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na caikasya bhāgaśa utpādo yukta iti kathamutpādayantī vāṅnāmotpādayet /
column2: Then how can the voice, when it produces a word?
You say that the case is analogous to that of zvijñapti: the last moment of the vsjñapti, a coṟpoṟeal oṟ vocal act, creates avijñapti by reason of its previous moments.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi paścima eva de nāmna utpādādyo 'pi tamevaikam śṛṇoti so 'pyarthaṃ pratipadyeta /
column2: But, we would say, if the last moment of the sound of the voice creates the word, it would suffice to understand the last sound in order to attain or comprehend the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athāpyevaṃ kalpyeta vāgvyañjanaṃ janayati vyañjanaṃ tu nāmeti /
column2: It is not an evasion to suppose that voice engenders the phoneme, that a phoneme engenders a word, and that a word causes comprehension of objects.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atrāpi sa eva prasaṅgo vyañjanāṃ sāmargyābhāvāt / eṣa eva ca prasaṅgo nāmnaḥ prakāśakatve vācaḥ /
column2: In fact, the same objection is present, “The phonemes do not exist at the same tirpe, etc. ” For these same reasons, it is absurd to suppose that the voice manifests a word.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vyañjanāṃ pi vāgviśiṣṭaprajñā apyavahitacetaskā lakṣaṇataḥ paricchettum notsahanta iti vyañjayāpi vāk naivotpādikā na prakāśikā yujyate /
column2: Moreover, the voice neither engenders nor manifests the phoneme, for the same reasons that allow that the voice neither engendets nor manifests a word. Since the "yoice" is vocal sound by nature, all vocal sound would engender or manifest phonemes.

If you reply that phonemes are only engendered or manifested by the vocal sound of a certain nature as above ad 2a2, a word arises with its object, like the characteristic "arising. The question of knowing whether it is produced or manifested by the voice, disappears.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ satyatītānāgatasyārthasya varttamānaṃ nāma na syād /
column2: In this hypothesis, no present word would designate a past or future thing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apatyānāṃ pitṛbhiryatheṣṭaṃ nāmāni kalpyanta iti katamannāma tatsahajaṃ syāt asaṃskṛtānāṃ ca dharmāṇāṃ kena sahajaṃ nāma syādityaniṣṭireveyam
column2: Moreover, a father, a mother, or other persons arbitrarily fix the word that is the proper name of a son, etc. : how can you admit that the word, like the characteristic "ariṣing," arises simultaneously with the object? Finally, unconditioned things would not have any ṇame, since they do not arise: a consequence that the Sarvāstivādins cannot admit.
The Blessed One said, "A stanza depends on words, and a poem depends on.

A stanza is a certain arrangement of words: it is in this sense that it, according to the Blessed One, depends on words.
atrārtheṣu kṛtāvadhiḥ śabdo nāma nāmnā ca racanāviśeṣo gātheti nāmasaṃnitābhavati racanāviśeṣāśca dravyāntaraṃ nopapadyate / paṅktivaccittānupūrvyavacca /	To admit an entity in and of itself called pada, is a very superfluous hypothesis.
astu vā vyañjanamātrasya dravyāntarabhāvaparikalpanā /	You might as well maintain that there exists, distinct from ants and minds, things in and of themselves termed “a row of ants” or “a succession of minds.
tatsamūhā eva nāmakāyādayo bhaviṣyantītyapārthikā tatprajñaptiḥ /	Recognize then that only the phonemes, which are sounds, exist in and of themselves.
santyeva tu viprayuktasaṃskārabhāvanā nāmakāyā dravyata iti vaibhāṣikāḥ / nahi sarva dharmāstarkagamyā bhavantīti /	The Vaibhāṣikas admit āmakāya, padakāya, and vyañjanakāya, as saṁskāras disassociated from the mind, for, they say, none of these dharmas serve as a gate of understanding. Wie ask: to which sphere of existence do the phonemes, words, and phrases belong?
atha kiṃpratisaṃyuktā ete nāmakāyādayaḥ sattvākhyā asattvākhyā vipākajā aupacayikā naiḥṣyandikāḥ kuśalā akuśalā avyākṛtā iti vaktavyam / āha kāmarūpāptasattvākhyā niḥṣyandāvyākṛtāḥ /	Do they belong to living beings (sattvākbhya, i. Are they of retribution, of accumulation or of out-flowing? and Are they good, bad, or neutral?
kāmāptā rūpāptāśceti /	They exist in Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu; they belong to. The phonemes belong to two spheres of existence.
ārupyāptā api santi te tvanabhilāpyā ityapare /	According to one opinion, they also exist in Ārūpyadhātu, but there they are unpronounceable.

They belong to living beings, being produced through the efforts of living beings and consisting of articulated sounds, etc. In fact, they belong to the person who speaks, not to the things that they designate.
yaśca dyotayati sa taiḥ samanvāgato na yo dyotyate /	They are an out-flowing, being produced through sabhāgahetu; they are not of retribution, since they proceed from the desire of the person who speaks; they are not of accumulation, since they are not material.
naiḥṣyandikā anivṛtāvyākṛtāśca /	They are non-defiled-neutral.
yathā caite nāmakāyādayaḥ sattvākhyā naiḥṣyandikā anivṛtāvyākṛtāśca /	We shall briefly explain the characteristics, not as yet mentioned, of the other dharmas disassociated from the mind.
tathā //	The same for genre," which is also from retribution, and which belongs to the three spheres of existence. "The same for," that is to say, like phonemes, words, and phrases, sabhāgatā is of the first two spheres of existence; it belongs to living.
But sabhāgatā is not only from out-flowing; it is also of retributiony;
it not only belongs to the first two spheres of existence, it also belongs to the third.
Possession is of two types.
It is of out-flowing and of retribution.
Its characteristics also.
Its characteristics, arising, etc. , are of two types, like possession.
The absorptions and non-possession are of out-flowing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dve acittasamāpattī asamanvāgamaśca naiḥṣyandikā eva / śeṣameṣāṃ vaktavyamuktam /
column2: The two absorptions and non-possession are only out-flowings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣayoścāsaṃjñikajīvitayorato na punarbrumaḥ / kathaṃ prāptyādīnāṃ sattvākhyatoktā samanvāgamavacanāt /
column2: As for their spheres, their relationship with living beings, their moral qualifications, the explanations have been given above.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ lakṣaṇānāṃ sattvāsattvākhyatoktā / sarvasaṃskṛṭasahabhūtvāt // uktā viprayuktāḥ //
column2: The characteristics belong to all conditioned things, hence they belong to living beings and to non-living beings. For the āsanjñika and the āyus, see i4ld and 45a.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaktūktaṃ “janyasya janikā jātirna hetupratyayairvinā” iti ka ime hetavaḥ keca pratyayāḥ /
column2: We have seen that arising, in order to engender the dharma that it should engender, needs the cooperation of hetas or causes, and prayayas or conditions. What are the hetus, and what areThe hetus are sixfold: kāraṇahetu, sahabhū sabhāga, saṁġprayūtaka, sarvatraga, aṅd vipāka.
Kāraṇabetu is reason for existence; sahabhūhetu is coexistent cause; sabhāgahetu is parallel cause; sarprayuktakahetu is associated cause;
sarvatragahetu is universal cause, and vipākahetu is retributive cause;
such are the six types of causes that the Ābhidhārmikas recognize.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāraṇahetuḥ sahabhūhetuḥ sabhāgahetuḥ saṃprayuktakahetuḥ sarvatragahetuḥ vipākaheturiti / tatra
column2: All dharmas are kāraṇahetu with regard to all, with the exception of themselves.
A dharma is not a kāraṇahetu of itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃskṛtasya hi dharmasya svabhāvavrjyāḥ sarvadharmāḥ kāraṇaheturutpādayati /
column2: With this exception, that all of the dharmas are kāraṇahetu with regard to all other conditioned dharnas, because no dharma constitutes an obstacle to the arising of the dharmas susceptible of arising. It results from this definition that the dharmas that are sahabhūhetu, etc. , are also kāraṇahetu: all other heṭus are included within kāraṇahetu.

The hetu that does not receive a special name, which is simply ēāraṇa, 'reason for existence,' without any other qualification is kāraṇahetu: it receives as its particular name the name that suits all. Kāraṇahetu calls for the following observations: Vices are produced among the ignorant;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca ye 'syājānata udapatsyantāsravā jānato 'sya te notpadyanta iti jñānameṣāṃ
column2: once the Truths are known, they are not produced, as the stars are not visible when the sun shines.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vighnamuatpattau karoti sūryaprabhāvajjyotiṣāṃ darśanasyeti kathaṃ svabhāvavarjyāḥ
column2: Hence the consciousness of the Truths, or the sun, causes an obstacle to the vices, or to the stars.
Then it is false to say that all conditioned dharmas are kāraṇahetu because they create no obstacle to aṟiṣing.

We understand that the consciousness of the Truths and the clarity of the sun create no obstacle to the arising of the dharma which is “arising” , that is to say of the dharma, which, its causes being completed, continues to exist.
What is called cause or reason for existence, may be what is capable of causing, or of not causing, an obstacle!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā anupadrotāraṃ bhojakamadhikṛtya grāmīṇā bhavanti vaktāraḥ svāminā smaḥ sukhitā iti /
column2: In fact, when their lord does not oppress them, villagers say, “We are fortunate through the actions of our master.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya punarnāstyeva śaktirvighnayituṃ tasya kathaṃ hetubhāvastadyathā nirvāṇasyānutpattidharmakāṇāṃ ca sarvotpattau nārakādīnāṃ carūpyasattva skandhotpattau / asanto 'pi hyete tathaiva vidhnaṃ karttumasamarthaḥ syuḥ /
column2: ” But caṉ one call cause that which, being incapable of cansing an obstacle,does not cause an obstacke? Nirvāṇa isCan one consider them as causes? They are causes;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asamarthe 'pi hi bhojake tathā vaktāro bhavantīti sa evātra dṛṣṭāntaḥ sāmānyenaiva nirdeśaḥ /
column2: for, even when the lord is incapable of harming them, the villagers express themselves as we have said; but not about a non-existent lord.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastu pradhānaḥ kāraṇahetuḥ sa utpādane 'pi samartho yathā cakṣūrūpe cakṣurvijñānasya āhāraḥ śarīrasya vījādayo 'ṅkurādīnāmiti /
column2: The definition that we have given of kāraṇahetu is a general definition and includes that which is kāraṇahetu par excellence and that which is simply kāraṇahetu. Kāraṇahetu par excellence is the generating cause: in this sense, eye and color are the kāranahetu of the consciousness of sight; as food is with regard to the body, the seeds, etc. , with regard to the sprout, etc. If all the dharmas are the causes of other dharmas because they do not cause any obstacle, why do not all the dharmas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastvevaṃ codayati anāvaraṇabhāvena cetsarva dharmahetavo bhavanti kasmānā sarvasyotpādo yugapadbhavati prāṇātipātena ca ghātakavat sarve tadbhājo bhavantīti /
column2: Why, when one murder is committed, are not all creatures, like the murderer himself, guilty of the crime of murder?
This objection is useless.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmādanāvaraṇabhāvena sarvadharmāḥ hetuḥ pratijñāyante na kārakabhāveneti /
column2: In fact, all the dharmas receive the name of hāraṇahetu because they do not create any obstacle; it is not that they are all agents.
According to other masters, all kāraṇahetus possess a real efficacy with regard to all dharmas.
Fot example Nirvāṇa and the consciousness of sight: a mental consciousness, good or bad, arises having Nirvāṇa as its object;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tena hyālambanāt manovijñānamutpadyate kuśalākuśālaṃ yataḥ krameṇa paścāccakṣurvijñānamiti kāraṇaparaparayā tasyāpi pratyayībhāvādasti sāmarthyam evamanyasyāpi pratipattavyam / eṣā hi dik /
column2: from this mental consciousness there later arises a consciousness of sight; then Nirvāṇa has efficacy, albeit mediately, with regard to the consciousness of sight.

The same argument applies to future dharmas, to beings in hell, etc. Sahabhūhetu, coexistent causes, namely the elements, the mind and the companions of the mind, characteristics and the thing characterized, are the dharmas that are causes one of the other.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mithaḥ pāraṃparyeṇa ye dharmāḥ parasparaphalāste parasparaḥ sahabhūheturyathā / katham /
column2: The dharmas that are causes one of the.
For example, the primary elements are among themselves sahabhūhetu.
The same for the mind and its companions;
the same for the characteristics, atising, etc. , and the dharmas that they characterize.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca kṛtvā sarvameva saṃskṛtaṃ sahabhūheturyathāyogam /
column2: In the category of sahabhūhetu are then included all conditioned dharmas which are in a mutual relationship of causality. We have reason not to complete the above definition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vināpi cānyonyaphalatvena dharmo 'nulakṣaṇānāṃ sahabhūheturna tāni tasyetyupasaṃkhyātavyam //

In regard to time, they have the same arising, the same duration, and the same destruction as does the mind. They are of the same time period as the mind. When we say “the same arising,” we understand the word “same” in the sense of concomitance: the companions arise, last, and perish at the same time as does the mind; but their arising is distinct. The minds that are not destined to arise do not arise, nor last, nor perish: the same for their companions. This is why the phrase, “The companions are of the same time period as the mind” is added. The mind which should arise is future until the moment when it arises if it is to arise: its companions are hence future; it is past after the moment when it shall perish if it arose: its companions are then past.

In regard to the result, etc. Result means phala and visaṁyogaphala; and “et cetera” refers to. The companions have the same result, the same vipāka, and the same niṣyanda as the mind: “same” indicates identity.
In regard to goodness, etc. , the companions are good, bad, or neutral, like the mind which they accompany.
There are then ten reasons why the companions are termed companions.
