The quality of sabhāgahetx sesults from a condition or state: a future harma is not sabhāgahetu;
but when it enters into a present or a past condition, it becomes sabhāgahetu. Its qnality of retributive cause results from the nature of the dharrna itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaduktaṃ svabhūmikaḥ sabhāgaheturbhavatīti kimeṣa niyamaḥ sarvasya sāsravasyaiṣa niyamaḥ /
column2: We have said that a dharma is a similar cause of only those dharmas that belong to its stage. Does this restriction apply to all the dharmas? It applies only to impure dharmas, not to pure dharmas.
The Path is sabhāgahetu to the Path, without distinguishing the nine stages.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgamye dhyānāntarikāyāṃ caturṣuraneṣu triṣu cārūpyeṣu mārgasatyamanyo 'nyaṃ sabhāgahetuḥ /
column2: The Path is of nine stages or spheres—the anāgamya, the dhyānāntara, the Four primary Dhyāṇnas, and the three inferior, ptimary Ārūpyas—in the sense that an ascetic, abiding in these nine states of absorption, can cultivate the Path. The ḍharmas that constitute the Path are similar causes of the dharmas that constitute the Path, frorn stage to stage. In fact, the Path resides in the different stages as a visitor, without forming part of the. Spheres of existence to which these stages belong are not on the Path. The Path, whatever be the stage upon which the ascetic relies in order to cultivate it, stays of the same nature; the Path is hence a similar cause of the Path.
Nevertheless, the complete Path is not a similar cause of the complete Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āgantuko hyasau tāsu bhūmiṣu na taddhātupatitastadbhami kābhistṛṣṇābhirasvīkṛtatvāt / ataḥ mānajātīyasyānyabhūmikasyāpi sabhāgaheturbhavati /
column2: One does not have to take into account the stage in which it is cultivated, but rather the characteristics proper to the Path itself. The Path is sabhāgahetu to an eqnal or superior Path. Not of an inferior Path, because the Path is always acquired through effort.
Let us define the terms, “inferior,” “equal,” and “superior Path.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntistasyā evānāgatāyāḥ sabhāgahetuviśiṣṭasyaca yāvadanutpādajñānasya /
column2: When past or present duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣānti is a similar cause of this same éṣānti of the futuṟe, the caused Path is equal to the causing Path. When this kṣānti is a similar cause of dwbkhe dharmajñāna the secoṇnd moment of the Path of Seeing. caused Path is superior to the causing Path.
And thus following up to enumépādajñāna which, pot having a superior, can only be the similar cause of an equal Path, namely a future anutpādajñāna.

To state it more precisely, the Path of Seeing is a similar cause of the Path of Seeing, the Path of Meditation, and the Path of the Aśaikṣas; the Path of Meditation is a similar cause of the Path of Meditation and the Path of the Aśaikṣa; and the Path of the Aśaikṣa is a similar cause of an equal or superior Path of the Aśaikṣa.
Any Path can be cultivated by an ascetic of weak faculties or active faculties: a Path of weak faculties is the similar cause of the same Path of weak faculties and of active faculties;
a Path of active faculties is the similar cause of the same Path of active faculties.
Consequently the Paths of fraddhānusārin. , fraddhādhimukta and samayavimukta are, respectively, the similar causes of six, four, and two Paths;
the Paths of dharmānusārin, dṛṣṭiprāpti and asamayavimukta are, respectively, the similar.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ punarūrdhvaṃbhūmikasyādhobhūmmikomārgaḥ samo vā bhavati viśiṣṭo vā /
column2: When a Path cultivated in a higher stage is the similar cause of a Path cultivated in a lower stage, how can it be the cause of an equal or higher Path?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: indriyato hetūpacayataśca / tatra darśanādimārgāṇāṃ mṛdumṛdvādīnāṃ cottarottara hetūpacitatarāḥ /
column2: The Path cultivated in a lower stage can be equal or higher from the point of view of the faculties which can be weak or active in any stage, or from the point of view of the accumulation of causes.
It does not follow that the same person successively grasps śraddhānusārin and dharmánusãrin Paths; yet the first, in the past or present, is a similar cause of the second, the later one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ mārga eva samaviśiṣṭayoḥ sabhāgaheturbhavati / netyāha / laukikā api hi prayogajāstayoreva
column2: Does the rule of equal or higher results apply only to the pure dharmas, that is, to the dharmas that form part of the Path?

The dharmas acquired through cultivation are sabhāgahetu of the same two classes, the equal and the higher. Worldly ḍharmas acquired through effort or exercise are sirnilar causes of equal or higher dharmas, but not of inferior dharmas.
What are the dharmas acquired through effort? The dharmas “acquired through effort” are the opposite of the “innate” dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ete hi prāyogikāḥ śrutacintābhāvanāmayā guṇāḥ samaviśiṣṭayoreva heturnanyūnānām /
column2: These former dharmas are qualities proceeding from hearing, that is, from the Word of the Buddha, from reflection, and from meditation. Since they are acquired through effort, they are the similar cause of greater or of equal, but not of lesser, good.
The dharmas of hearing in Kāmadhātu are similar causes of the dharmas of hearing and reflection in Kāmadhātu;
but not of the dharmas of meditation, because these dharmas do not exist in Kāmadhātu, and because a dharma is a similar cause of dharmas of the same sphere of existence.

The dharmas of hearing in Rūpadhātu are similar causes of the dharmas of hearing and meditation in Rūpadhātu; but not of the dharmas of reflection, because these dharmas do not exist in this sphere of existence: in Rūpadhātu, as soon as one begins to reflect, one immediately enters into absorption.
The dharmas of meditation in Rūpadhātu are similar causes of the. The dharmas of meditation in Rūpadhātu, but not of the dharmas of hearing in Rūpadhātu, because these are less good.

The dharmas of meditation in Ārūpyadhātu are the similar causes of the ḍharmas of meditation in Ārūpyadhātu. The dharmas of hearing and of reflection do not exist in this sphere of existence. Furthermore, one must consider that the dharmas acquired through effort are of nine classes: weak-weak, medium-weak, etc. The weak-weak are the similar causes of dharmas of nine classes;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāmapi navaprakārabhedāt mṛdumṛdavaḥ sarveṣāṃ mṛdumadhyā aṣṭānāmityeṣānītiḥ /
column2: the medium-weak, of dharmas of eight classes, with the exception of the weak-weak; and thus following.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upapattipratilambhikāstu kuśalā dharmāḥ sarve navaprakārāḥ paraspara sabhāgahetuḥ /
column2: The nine classes of the “innate” good dbarmas are similar cause of one another.
The same holds for the defiled ḍharrnas.
The undefiled-neutral dharmas are of four categories, the following being “better” than the preceding: dharmas arisen from retribution;
dharmas relative to lying down, to sitting attitudes, etc. , dharmmas relative to professional work; and the mind that can create fictive beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te yathākramaṃ catustrīdvekeṣāṃ sabhāgahetuḥ nirmāṇacittamapoi kāmāvacara caturdhyanaphalam /
column2: These four. categories are, respectively, the similar cause of four, three, two, and one category. Furthermore, as a mind capable of creating fictive beings of the sphere of Kamadhātu can be the result of each of the Four Dhyanas, there is reason to establish here the same distinctions: the minds capable of creating fictive beings constitute four classes, and are, according to their class, similar causes of four, three, two, or one mind capable of creating fictive beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra nottaradhyānaphalamadharadhyānaphalasya / nahyābhisaṃskārikasya sabhāgahetorhīyamānaṃ phalaṃ bhavati / tadyathā śāliryavādīnāṃ mā bhūnniṣphalaḥ prayatna iti /
column2: In fact, since it is a result of a higher Dhyanas, the mind capable of creating fictive beings is not the similar cause of a mind capable of creating fictive beings which is the result of a lower Dhyanas: from one similar cause a mind capable of creating fictive beings realized with the greatest effort, there cannot proceed a dharma less good, realized with less effort. Once these principles have been established, the following questions are stated and resolved: 1. 1 is there a pure dharma, already arisen, which is not the cause of aPure dharma not destined to arise?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva cāhuḥ syādutpanno 'nāsravo 'nutpannasyāsravasya na hetuḥ syāttadyathā duḥkhe dharmajñānamutpanāmanutpannānāṃ duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntīnām/ sarvaṃ ca viśiṣṭaṃ nyūnasya na hetuḥ /
column2: Yes. Duḥkhe dharmajñāṇa already arisen is a cause of duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntis not destined to arise. Furthermore, a better good is not the cause of lesser good.
Is there, in a series, a pure dharma, previously acquired (of which one has first obtained the prāpti), which is not the cause of a pure dharma arisen later?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syādanāgatāḥ duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntayo duḥkhe dharmajñānasyayasmānna pūrvataraṃ phalamastyanāgato vā sabhāgahetuḥ /
column2: Yes. Future duhkhe dharmajñānakṣānti [whose possession has been obtained in the first moment of the Path] are not the cause of duḥkhe dbarmajñāna already arisen.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syāt pūrvotpanno 'nāsravo dharmaḥ paścādutpannasyānāsravasya na hetuḥ /
column2: This is because a result cannot be anterior to its cause, and because a future dharma is not a similar cause. Is there a pure ḍharma, arisen previously, which is not the cause of a pure ḍharmna arisen later? Yes.
The best is not the cause of less good.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathottaraphalaparihīṇasyāvara phalasaṃmukhībhāve duḥkhe dharmajñānaprāptiścottarottara kṣaṇa sahotpannānāṃ duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntiprāptīnāṃ nyūnatvāditi / uktaḥ sabhāgahetuḥ /
column2: For example, when one realizes an inferior result after having fallen from a superior result, the superior result was not the cause of this inferior result. Furthermore, possession of duḥkhe dharmajñāna which has previously arisen is not.
The mind and its mental states are only causes through association. Mind and mental states are causes.
Is this to say that minds and mental states, arisen at different moments and in different series, are among themselves?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekākārā lambanāstarhi / evamapi sa eva prasaṅgaḥ /
column2: Would you then say that the mind and mental states of the same aspect, that is, having the same aspect of blue, etc. , and of the same object, that is, having for their object the same blue, etc. , are causes? This definition gives rise to the same criticism: minds and mental states of different time periods and of different series can have the same aspect and the same object.
Would you say that the mind and mental states of the same aspect and the same object, can be, furthermore, of the same time period?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi sati bhinnasantānajānāmapi prasaṅgo navacandrādīni paśyatām / tasmāttarhi samāśrayāḥ // samāna āśrayo yeṣāṃ te cittacaittāḥ anyonyaṃ saṃprayuktakahetuḥ /
column2: 'This still does not suffice: for many persons can see a new moon atThe mind and mental states which have the same support are, among themselves, sanprayuktakahetu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāna ityabhinnastatadyathā ya eva cakṣurindriyakṣaṇaścakṣurvijñānasyāśrayaḥ sa eva tatsaṃprayuktānāṃ vedanādīnāmeva yāvanmanaḥ /
column2: Same signifies single or undivided. For example, a given moment of the organ of sight is the support of a visual consciousness, and of the sensation and the other mental states which are associated with this consciousness.
And the same for the other organs until vanas: a certain moment of the mental organ is the support of a mental consciousness and of the mental states associated with this consciousness.
Whatever is samprayuktakahetu is also sahabhuhetu.
What is the difference between these two causes?

Some dharmas are called sahabhuhetu because they are mutually the results of one another. As companions in a caravan travel thanks to the support that they give one another, in this same way the mind is the result of mental states, and the mental states are the result of the mind. Some dharmas are called samprayuktakahetu, mutual cause.
The travel of the companions in a caravan is assured by the mutual support that they give one another;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāmeva sārthikānāṃ samānānnapānādiparibhogakriyāprayogavat / ekenāpi hi vinā sarveṇa na saṃprayujyanta ityayameṣāṃ hetubhāvaḥ /
column2: furthermore, they use the same food, the same drinks, etc. In this same way, the mind and its mental states use the same support, have the same aspect, etc. if one of these five identities is missing, they no longer function in the same way and are not associated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaḥ saṃprayuktakahetuḥ / sarvatragahetuḥ katamaḥ / sarvatragākhyaḥ klilṣṭānāṃ svabhūmau pūrvasarvagāḥ /
column2: Former universals are sarvatragahetu or universal causes of the defiled dharmas of their own stage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svabhūmikāḥ pūrvotpannāḥ sarvatragā dharmāḥ paścimānāṃ kliṣṭānāṃ dharmāṇāṃ sarvatragahetuḥ / tān punaḥ paścādanuśayanirdeśakośasthāna eva vyākhyāsyāmaḥ /
column2: ment, arisen previously, that is, of the past or present, and belonging to a certain stage, are the universal cause of later defiled dharmas, of the same stage, which are defiled by nature, either through association or through their origin.
Universals are only the cause of defiled dharmas; they are the cause of defiled dharmas in their own category and in other categories.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nikāyāntarīyāṇāmapi hetutvādeṣāṃ hi prabhāveṇānyanaikāyikā api kleśā upajāyante /
column2: It is through their power that there arises, with their following, defilements belonging to categories different from them. They then constitute a cause different from sabhāgahetu.
When would the defiled dharmas of an Āryan (rāga or lust, etc. ) have the universals for their cause?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarva eva kliṣṭā dharmā darśanaprahātavyahetukā iti kāśmīrāḥ /
column2: Yet the Āryan has abandoned all universals, for these are abandoned by seeing the Truths. The Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmīr admit that all defiled dharmas have the dharmas abandoned through seeing the Truths for their cause.
For the Prakaraṇapāda expresses itself in these terms: “What dharmas have for a cause the dharmas abandoned through seeing the Truths?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kliṣṭā dharmāḥ yaśca darśanaprahātavyānāṃ dharmāṇāṃ vipāka iti /
column2: Defiled dharmas and the retribution of the dharmas abandoned through seeing the Truths.
” “What dharmas have for a cause neutral?
Neutral conditioned dharmas and bad dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhasatyaṃ syāt satkāyadṛṣṭihetukaṃ na satkāyadṛṣṭerheturiti vistaro yāvanna satkāyadṛṣṭeḥ
column2: ” “Is there a dukkhasatya which has for its cause a belief in self and which is not in turn the cause of a belief in self?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ ca dharmāṇāṃ jātiṃ jarāṃ sthitimanityatāṃ ca sthāpayitvā yattadanyat kliṣṭam duḥkhasatya“miti /
column2: ” and the rest to: “with the exception of the arising-old age-duration-impermanence of the belief in a future self and its following, and of”If some bad dharmas have for their causes not only some bad dharmas but some neutral dharmas as well, how should one explain this bhāṣyam of the Prajñapti, “Is there a bad dharma which has only a bad dharma for its cause?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idaṃ tarhi prajñaptibhāṣyaṃ kathaṃ nīyate “syāddharmo 'kuśalo 'kuśalahetuka eva /
column2: Yes;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syādāryapudgalaḥ kāmavairāgyāt parihīyamāṇo yāṃ tatprathamataḥ klilṣṭāñcetanāṃ saṃmukhīkarotī“ti / aprahīṇahetumetat saṃdhāyoktam /
column2: the first defiled volition that an Āryan produces upon falling from detachment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanaprahātavyo hi tasyā hetuḥ prahīṇatvānnoktaḥ / uktaḥ sarvadagahetuḥ / vipākahetuḥ katamaḥ /
column2: ” The neutral dharmas, which are abandoned through Seeing the Truths, are the cause of this bad volition. If the Prajñapti does not mention it, it is because it intends to name only the causes that have not been abandoned.
Bad dharmas and impure good dharmas are retributive causes.
Bad dharmas—which are all impure—and impure good dharmas are only retributive causes, because their nature is to 1ipen.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasmādavyākṛtā dharmāḥ vipākaṃ na nirvarttayanti / durbalatvāt / pūti bījavat / kasmānnānāsravāḥ / tṛṣṇānabhiṣyanditatvāt /
column2: Neutral ḍharmas are not retributive causes, because they are weak: as rotten seeds, even though moistened, do not grow.

Pure dharmas are not retributive causes because they are not moistened through desire : as intact seeds, not moistened, do. The dharmas that are neither neutral nor pure possess the two qualities necessary for retribution, the proper force, and the moistening of thitsr, the same as intact and moistened seeds. What is the meaning of the expression vápākahetu?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apratisaṃyuktā hi kiṃpratisaṃyuktaṃ vipākamabhinirvarttayeyuḥ / śeṣāstūbhayavidhatvānnirvarttayanti / sārābhiṣyanditabījavat /
column2: You have a choice between two interpretations of this compound: vipākahetu signifies either “cause of vipāka” or “ctause which is vipāka.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamidaṃ vijñātavyaṃ vipākasya heturvipākaheturāhosvidvipāka eva heturvipākahetuḥ /
column2: In the first casē, the suffix @ marks the state : the vipāka is the result of the operation indicated by the root vi-bpac. In the second case, the suffix @ marks the operation : the vipāka is that which become ripe , that is to say, the action arrives at the moment when it gives forth a result.
To which of these two interpretations do you hold?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi vipākasya heturvipākahetuḥ “vīpākajaṃ cakṣuri“ti etanna prāpnoti /
column2: If you accept the first, how would you justify the text “The eye arises from vÉpāka?” If you accept the second, howWe have shown that both explanations of the word vipāka are correct. When one examines results, one must understand the word vipāka according to the first explanation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha vipāka eva heturvipākahetuḥ “karmaṇo vipāka” ityetanna prāpnoti / naiṣa doṣaḥ / “ubhayathāpi yoga” ityuktaṃ prāk //
column2: the meaning is result of retribution. The text, “The eye arises from vipāka” should be understood as “The eye arises from the cause of vipāka.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha vipāka iti ko 'rthaḥ / visadṛśaḥ pāko vipākaḥ / anyeṣāṃ tu hetūnāṃ sadṛśaḥ pākaḥ /
column2: What is the meaning of the compound vipāka?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekasyobhayatheti vaibhāṣikāḥ / naiva tu teṣāṃ pāko yuktaḥ /
column2: The prefix vi indicates difference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pāko hi nāma santatipariṇāmaviśeṣajaḥ phalaparyantaḥ / na ca sahābhūsaṃprayuktahetvoḥ santatipariṇāmaviśeṣajaṃ phalamasti / na cāpi sabhāgahetvādīnāṃ phalaparyanto 'sti / punaḥ punaḥ kuśalādyāsaṃsāraphalatvāt /
column2: Vipāka is a pāka or result dissimilar from its cause. How is that?
In Kāmadhātu, a retributive cause consisting of only one skandha can produce a single result: possession with its characteristics;
a retributive cause consisting of two skandhas can produce a single result: bodily and vocal action with its characteristics;
a retributive cause consisting of four skandhas can produce a single result: the mind and its mental states, good and bad, with their akṣaṇas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpadhātāvekaskandhako vīpākaheturekaphalaḥ prāptirasaṃjñisamāpattiśca saha jātyādibhiḥ / dviskandhaka ekaphalaḥ prathame dhyāne vijñaptiḥ saha jātyādibhiḥ /
column2: In Rūpadhātu, a retributive cause consisting of a single skandhacan produce a single result possession with its characteristics that is asamjnisamapatti with its characteristics a retributive cause consisting of two skandhas can produce a single result vrñapti of the First Dhyana with its characteristics a retributive cause consisting of four skandhas can produce a single result a good mind not of absorption for the mind of absorption always consists of r7pa and discipline iv and is thus five skandhas with its characteristics a retributive cause consisting of five sandhas can produce a single result the mind of absorption with its characteristics in Arupyadhatu a retributive cause consisting of a single skandha can produce a single result possession nirodhasamuaapatti with their respective characteristics a retributive cause consisting of four skandhas can produce a single result the mind and its mental states with their characteristics there is action the retribution of which is included in a singleIn fact, action that has the vital organ for its retribution necessarily has the vital organ and its characteristics for its retribution; both form part of the dharmāyatana.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catuskandhaka ekaphalaḥ kuśale cetasyasamāhite / pañcaskandhaka ekaphalaḥ samāhite //
column2: Action that has the mental organ for its retribution necessarily has two āyatanas for its retribution, namely the /manaāyatana and the dharmāyatana (which embraces sensations, etc. , and the characteristicss which necessarily accompany the mental oṟgan).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārūpyadhātāvekaskandhako vipākaheturekaphalaḥ prāptirnirodhasamāpatiśca saha jātyādibhiḥ / catuskandhakaḥ kuśalāścittacaittāḥ tajjātyādayaśca /
column2: Retribution necessatily has two āyatanas for its retribution, namely the tangible things and the dbarmāyatana.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti karma yasyaikameva dharmāyatanaṃ vīpāko vipacyate jīvitendriyam / yasya mana āyatanaṃ tasya dve manodharmāyatane / evaṃ yasya spraṣṭavyāyatanaṃ yasya kāyāyatanaṃ tasya trīṇi kāyaspraṣṭavyadharmāyatanāni /
column2: Action that has the organ of touch for its tetribution necessarily has three āyatanas fot its retribution, the oṟgan of touch, tangibles, and the dharmāyatana.
In the same way, action which has either physical matter, odots, or taste for its retribution, necessarily has three āyatanas for its retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya cakṣurāyatanaṃ tasya catvāri cakṣuḥkāyaspraṣṭavyadharmāyatanāni / evaṃ yasya śrotragrāṇajihvāyatanāni /
column2: Action which has either the eye, the ear, the nose, or the tongue for its retribution, necessarily has four āyatanas for its retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti tat karma yasya pañca ṣaṭ saptāṣṭau nava daśaikādaśāyatanāni vipāko vipacyate /
column2: An action can have five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, or eleven āyataṉas for its retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vicitrāvicitraphalatvāt karmaṇo bāhyabījavat / tadyathā bāhyāni vījāni kānicidvicitraphalāni bhavanti / tadyathā padmadāḍimanyagrodhādīnām / kānicidavicitraphālāni tadyathā yavagodūmādīnām /
column2: Action, in fact, is of two types: of varied result and of noṉ-varied result.
The same holds for seeds: lotus, pomegranate, fig, millet, corn, etc. The retribution of an action can belong to a single time period or to three time periods;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tu dvaiyadhvikasyāpyekādhviko mā bhūdatinyūnaṃ hetoḥ phalamiti /
column2: but the reverse is not true, for a result cannot be inferior to its cause.
The retribution from an action lasting an instant can last numerous instants;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca karmaṇā saha vipāko vipacyate nāpyanantaraṃ samanantarapratyayākṛṣṭatvāt samanantarakṣaṇasya /
column2: but the reverse is not true, for the same reason. Retribution is not simultaneous to the action which produces it, for. A retributive result is not experienced at the moment when the action is accomplished.

Retribution does not immediately follow an action, for it is the immediately antecedent condition that attracts the moment that immediately follows the action: in fact, the retributive cause depends on the development of the series for the realization of its result.
To which time period should a dharma belong in order that it might be each of these six causes?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ukta eṣāmarthato 'dhvaniyamaḥ natu sūtrita ityataḥ sūtryate /
column2: We have implicitly stated this rule, but we have not yet taught it in the Kārikā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvatragaḥ sabhāgaśca dvayadhvagau atītapratyutpannāveva anāgatau na staḥ /
column2: Sarvatragahetu and sabhāgaheṭu are of two time periods;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ cātra kāraṇam / tryadhvagā strayaḥ / sahabhūsaṃprayuktakavipākahetava strikālāḥ /
column2: three causes are of three time periods. A past and present dharma can be sarvatraga and sabhāgahetu. Past, present, and future dharmas can be sarṁprayuktaka, sahabhū, and vipākahetu.
The Kārikā does not speak of kāraṇahetu: the conditioned dharmas of the three time periods are kāraṇahetu; the unconditioned dharmas are outside of time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktā hetavaḥ / kiṃ punastatphalaṃ yasyaite hetavaḥ / saṃskṛtaṃ savisaṃyoga phalaṃ phalaṃ dharmāḥ /
column2: Which causes correspond to which results?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katame / “saṃskṛtā dharmāḥ pratisaṃkhyānirodhaśce“ti śāstram / evaṃ tarhi phalatvādasaṃskṛtasya hetunā bhavitavyaṃ yasya tat phalaṃ hetutvācca phalena bhavitavyaṃ yasya taddhetuḥ /
column2: By reason of which.
Only conditioned things, have cause and result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāsaṃskṛtasya te // kiṃ kāraṇam / ṣaḍvidhahetvasaṃbhavāt pañcavidhaphalāsaṃbhavācca /
column2: The unconditioned has neither cause nor result.
Why not admit that the part of the Path which is called ānantaryamārga is the kāraṇahetu of the result of disconnection?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāsmāt sa utpādāvighnabhāvena vyavasthāpito na cāsaṃskṛtamutpattimat /
column2: We have seen that kāraṇaheṭu is a cause that does not create any obstacles to arising; but disconnection, being unconditioned, does not arise. Thus one cannot attribute a kāraṉṇpahetu to it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasyedānīṃ tatphalaṃ kathaṃ vā mārgasya phalam /
column2: Then how is disconnection a result? Of what is it the result?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadbalena prāpteḥ / prāptireva tarhi mārgasya phalaṃ prāpnoti / tasyāmeva tasya sāmarthyānna visaṃyogaḥ /
column2: It is the result of the Path, for it is obtained due to the force of the Path: in other words, it is through the Path that an ascetic obtains possession of disconnection. Hence it is the obtaining or the possession of disconnection which is the result of the Path, and not disconnection itself: for the Path is efficacious with regard to the obtaining of disconnection, but not with regard to disconnection.
Wrong! The efficacy of the Path possesses diversity with regard to both obtaining and disconnection.
The Path produces obtaining;
the Path causes one to obtain disconnection.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prapaṇāt / tasmānna tāvadasya mārgaḥ kathañcidapi hetuḥ / phalaṃ cāsya visaṃyogaḥ /
column2: Hence, although the Path is not the cause of disconnection, one can say that it is the result of the Path.
Since no unconditioned thing has adhipatiphala, how can one define it as kāraṇahetu?
Any unconditioned thing is kāraṇahetu, for it does not create an obstacle to the arising of any ḍharma;
but it does not have any result, for, being outside of time, it can neither project nor produce a result.
An unconditioned thing is a cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ tu paryāyeṇa heturiti sautrāntikāḥ / kathamuktam /
column2: In fact, the Sūtra does not say that a cause can be unconditioned;
it says that a cause is only conditioned, “All the hetus, all the pratyayas which have for a result the production of physical matter of the consciousness, are also impermanent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anityān khalu hetupratyayān pratītyotpannaṃ rūpaṃ kuto nityam bhaviṣyati“
column2: Produced by impermanent hetus and pratyayas, how can physical matter and consciousness be permanent? ” If a permanent thing, that is, an unconditioned thing is not a cause, it will not be “an object as condition” of the consciousness that it refers to. The Sūtra declares that the hetus and the pratyayas which are capable of producing are impermanent.
It does not say that all conditions of the consciousness are impermanent.
An unconditioned thing could then be “an object as condition” of the consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: utpādāyetyavadhāraṇāt / prāpnoti / “ye hetavo ye pratyayā vijñānasyotpādāya te 'pyanityā” ityuktaṃ natūktaṃ ye vijñānasya pratyayāḥ tepyanityā iti /
column2: for “an object as condition” is not itself productive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca hetavo 'pi ya utpādāya ta evānityā iti vacanādasaṃskṛtasyānāvaraṇabhāvamātreṇa kāraṇahetutvāpratiṣedhaḥ /
column2: The Sūtra says that productive causes are impermanent: hence the Sūtra does not deny that an unconditioned thing is éáēraṇahetu, that is, a cause that does not create an obstacle.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ukta ālambanapratyayaḥ sūtre na tvanāvaraṇaheturiti na sūtre sidhyatyasaṃskṛtasya hetubhāvaḥ /
column2: It is not proven that an unconditioned thing is a cause. In fact, the Sūtra does not say that that which does not create an obstacle is a cause;
but it does not contradict this.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtrāṇi ca bahūnyantarhitānīti kathametannirdhāryate nokta iti /
column2: Many Sūtras have disappeared. How can you be sure that some Sūtra does not attribute the quality of araṇahetu to unconditioned things?
What is the dharma that is called visanryoga or disconnection?
The Sarvāstivadins says that disconnection is pratisaṁkhyānirodha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadānīṃ “pratisaṃkhyānirodhaḥ katamo yo visaṃyoga” ityuktamidānīṃ isaṃyogaḥkathamaḥ /
column2: When I asked you what pratisaṁkhyāmirodha is, you answered, “It is disconnection;
” I asked you what disconnection is, and you answered, It is pratisaṁkhyānirodha!”
The two answers are circular and do not explain the nature of the dharma, the unconditioned, to which they refer. You owe us another explanation.
This dharma, in its nature, is real, but.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āryaireva tatsvabhāvaḥ pratyātmavedyaḥ / etāvaktu śakyate vaktum nityaṃ kuśalaṃ cāsti dravyāntaram / tadvisaṃyogaścocyate pratisaṃkhyānirodhaśceti /
column2: It is only possible to indicate its general characteristics, by saying that there is a real entity, distinct from others, which is good and eternal, and which receives the name of pratisarṅkhyānirodha, and which is also called disconnection or visanyoga.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvamevāsaṃskṛtamadravyamiti sautrāntikāḥ / nahi tadrūpavedanādiyat bhāvāntaramasti / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: The Sautrāntikas affirm that the three types of unconditioned things are not real.

The three dharmas that it refers to are not distinct and real entities like color, sensation, etc. What is called “space” is solely the absence of any tangible thing, that is, the absence of a resistant body.
Persons say, in their obscurity, that there is space when they do not encounter any obstacle.

What is called pratisanṁakhyānirodha or Nirvāṇa is—when both the defilements already produced and the existence already produced are destroyed—the absence of any other defilements or any other existence, and that by reason of the force of the consciousness. When independent of the force of consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vinaiva pratisaṃkhyayā pratyayavaikalayādanutpādo yaḥ so / pratisaṃkhyānirodhaḥ / tadyathā nikāyasabhāgaśeṣasyāntarāmaraṇe / nikāyāntarīyāḥ punarāhuḥ / anuśayānāmutpattau prajñāyāḥ sāmarthyamato 'sau pratisaṃkhyānirodhaḥ /
column2: and by reason of the mere absence of causes there is an absence of arising dharmas, this is what is called apratisarkhyānirodha. For example, when premature death interrupts existence, there is apratisaṁkhyānirodha of the dharmas which would have arisen in the course of this existence if it had continued. According to another school, pratisaṁkhyānirodha is the future non-arising of the defilements by reason of consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastu punaḥ duḥkhasyānutpādaḥ saḥ utpādakāraṇānuśayavaikalyādeveti na tasminprajñāyāḥ sāmarthyamastyato 'sāvapratisaṃkhyānirodha iti /
column2: apratisamkhyānirodha is the future non-arising of suffering, that is, of existence, by reason of the disappearance of the defilements, and not directly by reason of consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'pi tu nāntareṇa pratisaṃkhyāṃ sidhyatīti pratisamkhyānirodha evāsau /
column2: (The first would then be sopadhiśeṣa nirvāṇadhātu, and the second would be nirupadhiseṣa ntrvāaṇadhātu). But, the future non-arising of suffering supposes consciousness; it is then included within pratisaṁkhyānirodha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya evotpannasya paścādabhāvaḥ sa eva svarasa nirodhādapratisaṃkhyānirodha ityapare /
column2: Another School defines apratisaṁkhyānirodha as “later nonexistence of the dharmas which have arisen” by virtue of their spontaneous destruction.

In this hypothesis, apratisamkhyānirodha would not be eternal, since it is non-existent as long as the dharma as cause has not perished. But does not pratisaṁkhyānirodha have a certain consciousness, the pratisamṁkhya, for its antecedent?

Consequently it too would not be eternal, for, if its antecedent were absent, its consequence would also be absent. You cannot say that pratisaṁkhyānirodha is not eternal because its antecedent is pratisaṁkhyā;
in fact, it does not have pratisaṁkhyā for its antecedent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na vai sa pratisaṃkhyāpūrvako nahi poūrvaṃ pratisaṃkhyā paścādanutpannānāmanutpādaḥ /
column2: One cannot say that pratisaṁkhyā is earlier, or that the "no-arising of the non-arisen dharmas" is later.
Let us explain.
Nonarising always exists in and of itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vinā tu pratisaṃkhyayā ye dharmā utpatsyante tadutpannāyāṃ pratisaṃkhyāyāṃ punarnopapadyanta iti /
column2: If pratisarkhyā is absent, the dharmas would arise; but if pratisaṁkhyā arises, the dharmas would absolutely not arise.
The efficacy of pratisamṁkhyā with regard to their non-arising consists in this: 1) that before pratisaṁkhyā, there is no obstacle to their arising;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi narhi anutpāda eva nirvāṇamidaṃ sūtrapadaṃ kathaṃ nīyate “pañcemānīndriyāṇi āsevitāni bhāvitāni bahulīkṛtānyatītānāgatapratyūtpannasya duḥkhasya prahāṇāya saṃvarttanta” iti /
column2: 2) but given pratisaṁkhyā, the dharmas, the. If Nirvāga is simply non-arising, how does one explain the Sūtra which says, “The cultivation of the five faculties,; —faith, etc,--has for its result the abandoning of past, present, and future suffering”?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prahāṇaṃ hi nirvāṇamanāgatasyaiva cānutpādo nātītapratyutpannasyete / astyetadevam /
column2: In fact, this abandoning is nothing other than Nirvāṇa, and there can only be non-arising of a future dharma, not of a past or present dharma. This Sūtra does not contradict our definition of Nirvāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tu tadālambanakleśaprahāṇāt duḥkhasya prahāṇamuktaṃ bhagavatā “yo rūpe cchandarāgastaṃ prajahīta /
column2: In fact, “the abandoning of past and present suffering” means the abandoning of the defilements bearing past and present suffering. Our interpretation is justified by another text which says, “Abandon desire relative to rāpa, to sensation, and to consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cchandarāge prahīṇe evaṃ vastadrūpaṃ prahīṇaṃ bhaviṣyati pārijñātaṃ vistareṇa yāvad vijñānami“ti /
column2: When desire is abandoned, rāpa, and consciousness will be abandoned and comprehended by you.”
It is in this manner that we should understand “the abandoning of past and present suffering” of which the Sūtra speaks when it speaks of the faculties.
The cultivation of the faculties has for its result the abandoning of past, present, and future defilements, the explanation is the same.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atrāpyeṣa nayaḥ / athavā 'yamabhiprāyo bhavedatītaḥ kleśaḥ paurvajanmikaḥ pratyutpannaḥ kleśa aihajanmiko
column2: Or rather, past defilement is the defilement of a previous existence; present defilement is the defilement of the present existence; these do not refer to the defilement of a given past or present moment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tṛṣṇā vicariteṣvaṣṭādaśa tṛṣṇāvicaritānyatītamadhvānamupādāyetyatītaṃ janmādhikṛtyoktamevaṃ yāvat pratyutpannam /
column2: The same for the eighteen r̥ṣṇāvicaritas or modes of thirst: the modes that are related to a past existence are called past modes, those that are related to a present existence are called present modes, and those thar are related to a future existence are called future modes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tenā ca kleśadvayenāsyāṃ santatau bījabhāva āhito 'nāgatasyotpattaye / tasya prahāṇāttadapi prahīṇaṃ bhavati / yathā vipākakṣayātkarmaṃ kṣīṇaṃ bhavati /
column2: Past defilements and present defilements place in the present series seeds that bring forth the arising of future defilement: when these seeds are abandoned, past and present defilement is abandoned: in the same way as one says that an action is exhausted when its retribution is exhausted.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgatasya punarduḥkhasya kleśasya vā bījābhāvāt atyantamanutpādaḥ prahāṇam /
column2: The abandoning of future suffering and future defilement is the.
How does one otherwise understand the abandoning of past or present suffering?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi niruddhe nirodhābhimukhe ca yatnaḥ sārthako bhavatīti /
column2: There is no good reason to make an effort to destroy that which has perished or that which is perishing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyasaṃskṛṭaṃ nāstyeva, yaduktaṃ bhagavatā “ye keciddharmāḥ saṃskṛtā vā 'saṃskṛtā vā virāgasteṣāmagra ākhyāyate” iti kathamasatāmasannagro bhavitumarhati /
column2: If unconditioned things do not exist, how can the Sutra say "Detachment is the best of all conditioned and unconditioned dharmas? How can a dharma which does not exist be the best among the dharmas which do not exist?
We do not say that unconditioned things do not exist.
They exist in fact in the manner in which we say that they exist. Let us explain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā asti śabdasya prāgabhāvo 'sti paścādabhāva ityucyate /
column2: Before sound is produced, we say "There is non-existence prior to the sound;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha ca punarnābhāvo bhāvaḥ sidhyati / evamasaṃskṛtamapi draṣṭavyam /
column2: after the sound has perished, we say There is non-existence after the sound," and yet it had not been proven that non-existence exists: the same holds for unconditioned things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhāvo 'pi ca kaścit praśasyatamo bhavati yaḥ sakalasyopadravasyātyantamabhāva ityanyeṣāṃ so 'gra iti praśaṃsāṃ labdhumarhati /
column2: Although it is non-existent, one unconditioned thing merits being praised, namely detachment, the absolute future nonexistence of any wrong. This non-existent thing is the most distinguished of all non-existent things. The Śūtra praises it by saying that it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vineyānāṃ tasminnupacchandanārtham / yadyapyasaṃskṛtamabhāvamātraṃ syānnirodha āryasatyaṃ na syāt / nahi tatu kiñcidastīti /
column2: If believers shall conceive joy and affection with regard to it.
If pratisaṁkhyānirodha or Nirvāṇa is non-existent, how can it be one of the Truths.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhayamapi caitadaviparītaṃ dṛṣṭamāryairyaduta duḥkhaṃ ca duḥkhameveti duḥkhābhāvaścābhāva eveti ko 'syāryasatyatve virodhaḥ kathamabhāvaśca nāma tṛtīyaṃ cāryasatyaṃ syāt /
column2: How can it be the Third Noble Truth? What should we understand by “Noble Truth” or ārayasatya? Without doubt the sense of sa$ya is “not incorrect” The Āryans see that which exists and that which does not exist in a not incorrect manner: in that which is suffering, they see only suffering, and in the non-existence of suffering, they see the non-existence of suffering. What contradiction do you find between the non-existence of suffeting and pratisaṁkhyānirodha being a Truth?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ustaṃ yathāryasatyaṃ dvitīyasyānantaraṃ dṛṣṭamuddṛṣṭaṃ ceti tṛtīyaṃ bhavati /
column2: And this non-existence is the Third Truth, because the Āryans see it and proclaim it imrmmediately after the Second Truth.
But if unconditioned things are nonexistent, the consciousness that has space and the two extinctions for its object would have a non-thing for its object.
We do not see any inconvenience in this, as we shall explain in the discussion on the past and future.
What harm do you see in maintaining that unconditioned things really exist?
What advantage do you see in this?
This advantage that the Vaibhashika doctrine is found to be safeguarded.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: devatā enaṃ pālayiṣyanti pālanīyaṃ cet maṃsyate /
column2: May the gods be charged with defending this doctrine, if they judge that it is possible!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhūtaṃ tu parikalpitaṃ syāt / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: But to maintain the existence of unconditioned things in and of themselves is to affirm a non-existent thing to be real.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi tasya rūpavedanādivat svabhāva upalabhyate nacāpi cakṣurādivatkarma /
column2: In fact, unconditioned things are not known through direct perception, as is the case for physical matter, sensation, etc. ; and they are not known through inference, by reason of their activity, as is the case for the sense organs. Furthermore, if nirvana or extinction is a thing in and of itself, how do you justify the genitive, dukkhasya nirodhaḥ, "the extinction of suffering," as the extinction of the defilement, or the extinction of the object of defilement?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: amuṣya ca vastuno 'yaṃ nirogha iti ṣaṣṭhīvyavasthā kathaṃ prakalpyate /
column2: In our system, the extinction of a thing is simply the non-existence of this thing. "Extinction of suffering" means that "suffering will not exist any more.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi tasya tena sārdhaṃ kaścitsaṃbandho hetuphalādibhāvāsaṃbhavāt /
column2: But we cannot conceive of any.
We affirm that extinction is a thing in and of itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhāvāntaratve 'pi yasya kleśasya prāptivicchedāydyo nirodhaḥ prāpyate sa tasyeti vyavadiśyate /
column2: Yet we can specify extinction as being in a relationship with such things, for one takes possession of extinction at the moment when one cuts off the possession of a certain thing.
But we would answer, what is it that determines or specifies the taking of possession of extinction?
The Sutra speaks of the Bhiksu who has obtained Nirvana in this life.
If Nirvana is non-existence, how could he obtain it?

The Bhiksu, through the possession of the adverse force of the antidote, that is, through the possession of the Path, has obtained a personality contrary to the defilements, and contrary to a new existence. This is why the Sutra says that he has obtained Nirvana. Moreover we have a text that shows that Nirvana is pure non-existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āgamaścāpyabhāvamātraṃ dyotayati / evaṃ hyāha / “yat svalpasya duḥkhasyāśeṣaprahāṇaṃ pratiniḥsargo vyantībhāvaḥ kṣayo virāgo nirodho vyupakṣamo 'staṅgamaḥ anyasya ca duḥkhasyāprati sandhiranutpādo 'prādurbhāvaḥ /
column2: The Sutra says, “The complete abandoning, the purification, the exhausting, the detachment, the extinction, the abatement, the definitive passing away of this suffering;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣā dharmāstau vipākasarvatragahetū hitvā śeṣebhyaścaturbhryo jāyante /
