prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamānāsravāstau ca vipākasarvatragahetū sabhāgahetuṃ ca hitvā śeṣebhyaḥ tribhyo jāyante / katame ime dharmāścaturvidhā nirdiṣṭā ityāha cittacaittāḥ atha ye cittaviprayuktā rūpiṇaśca dharmāste kathamityāha / tathā 'nye 'pi saṃprayuktakavarjitāḥ /
column2: when they are pure for the first time, they arise from three causes, with the exclusion of the aforementioned two causes and the similar cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prayuktakahetunaikena varjitāḥ anye 'pi kliṣṭādayo dharmāstathaivotpadyante yathā cittacaīttāḥ / tatra kliṣṭāścatubhryo vipākajāśca /
column2: The dharmas that are not mind or mental states, namely the material dharmas and the saṁskāras not associated with the mind, accordingly as they fall into one of four categories, arising from causes proper to this category with the exclusion of the associated causes are: defiled and retributive, four causes;
different, three causes. Pure for the first time, two causes.
“These is no dharma that comes from a single cause: the reason for being and the mutually coexistant cause are never absent.
We have explained causes.
What are conditions?
The pratyayas are said to be four.
Where is this said?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtre / “catasraḥ pratyayatāḥ / hetupratyayatā samanantarapratyayatā ālambanapratyayatā adhipatipratyayatā ce“ti /
column2: In the Sūtra, it says “There are four conditions, namely causes as a condition, an equal and immediately antecedent condition, an object as condition, and a predominating influence as condition.”
Pratyayaṭā means. “a type of pratyaya.” What is “cause as a condition”?
The pratyaya that bears the name of hetu is five hetus.
Excepting kāraṇahetu, the five remaining herus constitute hetnpratyayatā, causes as condition. What is “an equal and immediately antecedent condition”?

The mind and its mental states that have arisen, with the exception of the last ones, are an equal and immediately antecedent condition. If one excepts the last mind and the last mental states of the Arhat at the moment of Nirvāṇa, all minds and mental states which have.
Only mind and mental states are equal and immediately antecedent conditions. Of what dharmas are they the equal and immediately antecedent conditions?

This type of condition is called samanantara because it produces equal and immediate dharmas. The prefix sarn is understood in the sense of equality. Consequently orily minds and their mental states are equal and immediately antecedent conditions, for there is no equality between a cause and its result with respect to the other dharṁas, for example the material dharmas. In fact, after a rūpa of the sphere of Kāmadhātu, there can arise at the same time two rūpar, one of Kāmadhātu, the other from Rūpadhātu, oṟ two r%pas, one from Kāmadhātu, the otheṛ pure; whereas one mind in Kāmadhātu and one mind in Rūpadhātu can never arise at the same time after a mind in Kāmadhātu. The appearance of the rāpar is confused: now an equal and immediately antecedent condition does not produce confused. Vasumitra says: A second rūpa of accumulation can arise in the ṣame body, without which the series of a rupa of accumulation would be broken;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva rūpaṃ na samanantarapratyayo viṣamotpatteḥ /
column2: hence rupa is not an equal and immediately antecedent condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathāhi kāmāvacarasya rūpasyānantaraṃ kadācit kāmāvacaraṃ rūpāvacaraṃ cāvijñaptirūpamutpadyate kadācitkāmāvacaraṃ cānāsravaṃ ceti vyākulo rūpasaṃmukhībhāvaḥ avyākulastu samanantarapratyayaḥ aniruddha evaikasminnaupa cayikarūpasantāne dvitīyotpatteriti bhadantavasumitraḥ /
column2: The Bhadanta says: A rupa dharma is immediately followed by more or by less. Hence it is not an equal and immediately antecedent condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: alpabahutarotpatteriti bhadantaḥ / kadāciddhi mahato rūpādalpamutpadyate / tadyathā palālarāśerbhasma / kadācidalpādvahūtpadyate / tadyathā vaṭanikāyāḥ krameṇa yāvadanekaśākhāvaroho nyagrodha iti /
column2: Less arises from more: as when a great mass of straw, burned, becomes ash.

More arises from less: as when a small seed produces the roots of a fig tree, its trunk, its branches, and its leaves. When minds immediately succeed one another, do they always admit the same number of types of associated mental states? The earlier mind admits of a larger number of types of mental states, and the following mind, a lesser number; and vice versa.

Minds, good, bad, or neutral, succeed one another; but they do not admit of the same number of associated mental states. Hence there is no equality for the mental states as well as for the material dharmas. That is true;
there is a succession from less to more, and vice versa; but only by the accumulation or the diminution of the number of types of mental states.

There is never any inequality with respect to a determined type: more numerous sensations never arise after less numerous sensations, nor vice versa; this means that a mind accompanied by a single sensation is never followed by a mind associated with two or three sensations. The same for ideas and the other mental states. ‘Thus is it only in relation to its own type that an earlier mental state is an equal and immediately antecedent condition of a later mental state?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ svajātereva samanantarapratyayo bhavati / naitadasti / sakala eva kalāpaḥ sakalasya kalāpāntarasya samanantarapratyayo natvalpakādvedanādidravyāt prabhūtaṃ vedanādi dravyamutpadyata ityetāvadevātrottam
column2: Is sensation then the equal and immediately antecedent condition of a single sensation? In a general way the earlier mental states are equal and immediately antecedent conditions of the mental states that follow.
But there is no succession from less to more with respect to one type, and vice versa: this justifies the expression sramanantara, “equal and immediate.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā cittaṃ cittasyaiva vedanā vedanāyā eve“ti vistaraḥ /
column2: The Ābhidhārmikas who take the name of Sāṁtāṇasabhāgīkas maintain on the contrary that a dharma of a certain type is only an equal and immediately antecedent condition of a dharma of that same type: mind arises from mind, sensation arises from seṇsation, etc. In this hypothesis, when a defiled dharma arises after an undefiled dharma, this defiled dharma does not proceed from an equal and immediately antecedent condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā tvakliṣṭāntaraṃ kliṣṭamutpadyate tasya kleśasya pūrvaniruddhaḥ kleśaḥ samanantarapratyayastadyathā nirodhasamāpatticittaṃ vyutthānacittasyeti
column2: It is a previously destroyed defilement that is the equal and immediately antecedent condition of the defilement that defiles this second dharma. The previous defilement is considered as immediately preceeding the later defilement, even though it is separated by an undefiled dharma, separation by a dharma of a different nature does not constitute separation, as the leaving-mind of the absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadetanna vatsryate / prathamānāsravacittānutpattiprasaṅgat cittaviprayuktā api saṃskārāḥ /
column2: We think that the theory of the Sāṁtānasabhāgikas is inadmissible, for, in this theory, a pure mind produced for the first time would not have any equal and immediately antecedent condition.

The saṅskāras dissociated from the mind, like the material dharnas, are produced disparately: hence they are not equal and immediately antecedent conditions. In fact after possession in the sphere of Kāmadhātu, possession relative to the dharvmas of the three spheres of existence and to pure dharmas etc. , can be produced at the same time.
Why deny that the future dharmas are equal and immediately antecedent conditions?
Future dharmas are disparate: there is not, among them, any early and later.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ tarhi bhagavān jānāti amuṣyānāgatattyānantaramidamanāgataṃ bhāvīti /
column2: Then how does the Blessed One know that such and such a future dharma will arise first, and that such and such a dharma will. He knows the order of the arising of all that arises until the end of time.
His consciousness results from an inference drawn from the past and the present.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atītaṃ kilādhvānaṃ paśyati bhagavānevañjātīyakātkarmaṇaḥ evañjātīyako vīpākaḥ utpanno dharmādvā dharmaḥ / idaṃ cāpi saṃpratyevañjātīyakaṃ karma /
column2: He sees the past: “From such a type of action such a retributive result arises; such a dharma proceeds from such a dharma;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādato 'pyevañjātīyako vipāka utpatsyate dharmādvā dharma iti jānāti /
column2: ” and he sees the present: “Here is such a type of action: such a retributive result shall arise in the future from this action; here is such a dharma: such a dharma shall proceed from this dharma.”
However the consciousness of the Blessed One is called pranidhijñana, and is not a consciousness from inference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmādatītasāṃpratānumānena bhagavān vikīrṇānyanāgatāni dravyāṇi pratyakṣamīkṣitvā jānātyanena pudgalenaivaṃvidhaṃ karma kurvatedamanāgataṃ phalaṃ parigṛhītamiti /
column2: By means of inferences drawn from the past and from the present, the Blessed One immediately sees the dharma that resides, disparately, in the future, and he produces the consciousness, “This man, having accomplished such an action, shall certainly receive such a future retribution.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi bhagavān pūrvāntamadṛṣṭvā 'parāntaṃ na jānīyāt /
column2: To believe you, if the Blessed One does not consider the past, then he does not know the future. Hence he is not omniscient.

According to other Masters, there is in the series of beings a certain dharma which is the indication of the results which will arise in the future, namely a certain sanskara disassociated from the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phalacihnabhūtaḥ sattvānāṃ santatau cittaviprayuktaḥ saṃskāraviśeṣo 'sti yaṃ vyavalokya bhagavānanāgataṃ jānātyasaṃmukhīkṛtvāpi dhyānamabhijñāṃ ceti /
column2: The Blessed One contemplates it, and he knows future results without his having cultivated the Dhyanas and the Abhijnas for it. The Sautrantikas: If this is the case, then the Blessed One would be an interpreter of signs;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naimiktiko hi nāma bhagavān syādevaṃ sati na punaḥ sākṣātkārī /
column2: he would not be a "seer.

Consequently the Blessed One knows immediately and at his will all things, not by inference, and not by divination.
“acintyo hi buddhānāṃ buddhiviṣaya” ityuktaṃ bhagavatā /	This is the opinion of the Sautrantikas, justified by the word of the Blessed One The qualities of the Buddhas, the spheres of the Buddhas, are incomprehensible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha asatyanāgatasya kramaniyamāvasthāne kasmādagradharmānantaraṃ duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntirevotpadyate nānyo dharmaḥ /
column2: If the future does not have any earlier or later division of time, how can one say, Only duhkhe dharmajnanaksanti arises immediately after the Jaukika agradharmas, and not any other dharma"?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yāvadvarjo pamānantaraṃ kṣayajñānamevotpadyate nānyo dharma iti /
column2: Thus following until "Kṣayajñāna arises immediately after vajropamasaṁādhi?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya yatpratibaddha utpādaḥ sa tasyānantaramutpadyate / tadyathā vījādīnāmaṅkurādayo vināpi samanantarapratyayeneti /
column2:
If the arising of this dharma is bound to that dharma, then immediately after that, this arises, as a bud arises after the seed without any equal and immediately antecedent condition intervening.
kasmādarhataścaramāścittacaittā na samanantarapratyayaḥ /	Why are the last mind and the last mental states of the Arhat equal and immediately antecedent conditions?
anyacittāsaṃbandhanāt /	Because no mind or mental states arise after them. But you have said that the anas is the mind that is disappearing and which serves as the support of the following mind.
nanu caivaṃ samanantaraniruddhaṃ cittaṃ mano bhavatītyanantara vijñānābhāvāt mano 'pi caramaṃ cittaṃ na prāpnoti /	Since no mind follows the last mind of an Arhat, this last mind should not receive either the name of %anas, or the name of equal and immediately antecedent condition; and yet you consider it as being ṁmanas. The case is not the same.
āśrayabhāvapratibhāvitaṃ mano na kāritraprabhāvitamityastyevāśrayabhāvaḥ /	That which constitutes the anṇas is not its activity, the fact of supporting the subsequent mind; rather, it is the quality of being a support for this mind; whether his (latter mind) arises or does not arise is of little importance. The last mind of.
kāraṇāntaravaikalyāttu vijñānāntaraṃ notpadyata iti /	if a subsequent mind, which would be supported by this support, does not arise, it is through the lack of other causes necessary to its arising. On the contrary, what constitutes an equal and immediately antecedent condition is its activity.
kāritraprabhāvitastu samanantarapratyayastena yo dharmaḥ phalaṃ kpratigṛhītaḥ sa sarvairapi dharmaīḥ sarvaprāṇibhirvā na śakyaṃ pratibnddhuṃ yathā notpadyate /	Once this condition has grasped or projected a result, nothing in the world can hinder this result from arising. Hence the last mind of an Arhat is justly called maṇas, but not an equal and immediately antecedent condition.
ye dharmāścittasamanantarāścittanirantarā api te /	Does a dharma which is cittasamanantara, that is, which has a certain mind for its equal and immediate antecedent condition, immediately follow this mind?
catuṣkoṭikaḥ /	There are four alternatives: 1.
prathamā koṭiracittakāyāḥ samāpattervyutthāna cittaṃ dvitīyādayaśca samāpattikṣaṇāḥ /	The mind and the mental states of leaving of the two absorptions free from mind, and all the moments of these two absorptions with the exception of the first, have the mind entering into absorption for their equal and immediately antecedent condition, but they do not immediately follow this mind.
dvitīyā koṭiḥ prathamasya samāpattikṣaṇasya sacittakāyāścāvasthāyā jātyādayaḥ /	The characteristics of the first moment ofThe two absorptions, and of all minds and all mental states of a conscious state, immediately follow a mind, but do not have any equal and immediately antecedent condition.
tṛtīyā koṭiḥ prathamaḥ samāpattikṣaṇaḥ sacittikā cāvasthā / caturthī koṭi dvīrtīyādīnāṃ samāpattikṣaṇānāṃ jātyādayo vyutthānacittasya ca /	The first moment of the two absorptions, and all minds and mental states of a conscious state, have the mind that they immediately follow for their equal and immediately antecedent condition.
ye dharmāścittasamanantarāḥ samāpattinirantarā api te / catuṣkoṭikaḥ / ye tṛtīyāvaturthyau te prathamādvitīye ye prathamādvitīye te tṛtīyācaturthyau karttavye / kathamidānīṃ dūrāntaravicchinnaṃ vyutthānacittaṃ samāpatticittasya samanantaramityucyate /	The characteristics of all the moments of the two absorptions with the exception of the first, and of the mind and the mental states of leaving these two absorptions, have no equal and immediately antecedent condition, for they are dharmas disassociated from the mind;
cittāntarāvyavahitatvāt //	and they do not immediately follow a mind.
uktaḥḥ samanantarapratyayaḥ //	What is an object as condition?
ālambanaṃ sarvadharmāḥ /	All dharmas are the objects of consciousness. All the dharmas, conditioned as well as unconditioned, are objects of consciousness" of the mind and its mental states, but not indiscriminately so.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathāyogaṃ cakṣurvijñānasya sasaṃprayogasya rūpam / śrotravijñānasya śabdaḥ / grāṇavijñānasya gandhaḥ / jihvāvijñānasya rasaḥ / kāyavijñānasya spraṣṭavyam /
column2: For example, the visual consciousness and the mental states, sensation, etc. , which are associated with it, have all.
The mental consciousness and the mental states that are associated with it have all the dbarmnas for their objects.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo dharmo yasya dharmasyālambanaṃ na kadācitsa dharmastaddharmasya nālambanam/
column2: When a dharmais the object of a mind, it is not possible that this dharma, at any moment, is not the object of this mind.

This means that even if a visible object is not grasped as an object by the visual consciousness, it is an object, for, whether it is grasped or not grasped as an object, its nature remains the same, as fuel is combustible, even when it is not on fire. We can establish a threefold determination in considering the problem fror the point of view of the mind that grasps a dharma as its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta ete cittacaitā dharmā āyatanadravyalakṣaṇaniyamenālambane yathāsvaṃ niyatāḥ / kimāśrayaniyamenāpi niyatāḥ / omityāha /
column2: The mind is determined 1) with regard to its āyakana: for example, a visual consciousness is supported only on a visible thing ; 2) with regard to the dravya or substantial thing; aCertain visual consciousness is supported by colors such as blue and red. The mind is determined by its support, which includes the organ of sight.
The mind is bound to its support in the present, but not in the past or future.
Some argue that the mind is bound to its support in both the past and present.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāraṇākhyo 'dhipaḥ smṛtaḥ // ya eva kāraṇahetuḥ sa evā dhipatipratyayaḥ / adhiko 'yaṃ pratyaya ityadhipatipratyayaḥ /
column2: A predominating condition, or kāraṇa, is the cause that is considered predominant.
The predominating condition belongs to the greatest number of dharmas and is exercised with respect to the greatest number of dharmas. All the dharmas are of the mental consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na jātu sahabhuvo dharmā ālambanaṃ bhavanti /
column2: However the dharmas coexisting with a certain mind are not the object of this mind, whereas they are kāraṇahetu of it.
Thus the dharmas, without exception, are predominating conditions as kāraṇahetu, not as an object as condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: adhikasya vā pratyayaḥ / sarvaḥ sarvasya saṃskṛtasya svabhāvavarjyasya /
column2: Every dharma has all dharmas for its kāraṇahetu, with the exception of itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syāddharmo dharmasya caturbhirapi pratyayairna pratyayaḥ / syātsvabhāvaḥ svabhāvasya parabhāvo 'pi /
column2: No dharma of any type is a condition of itself.
And a conditioned dharma is not a condition of an unconditioned dharma, and vice versa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athaite pratyayāḥ kāritraṃ kurvantaḥ kimavasthe dharme kurvanti /
column2: In what state, past, present, or future, are the ḍharmas found with regard to which the diverse conditions exercise their activity?
Let us first examine cause as condition, that is, as five causes, with the exclusion of kāraṇahetu.
Two causes exercise their activity with regard to a petishing dharma.
“Perishing” means “of the present.
” A present dharma is called “perishing,” “in the act of perishing,” because, having arisen, it is turned towards its destruction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra sahabhūsaṃprayuktakahetu kāritraṃ kurutaḥ / sahotpanne 'pi phale tayorvyāpāraḥ /
column2: Sahabhūbhetu and saṁprayuktakahetu operate with regard to a present dharma, because they operate with regard to a dharma that arises at the same time as they do.
Three, with regard to an arising dharma.
“An arising dharma” means a future dharma, because a future dharma, not having arisen, is ṭurned towards arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra sabhāgasarvatragavipākahetavaḥ kāritraṃ kurvanti / evaṃ tāvaddhetupratyayaḥ /
column2: The three causes in question are sabhāgahetu, sarvatragahetu, and vipākahetu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato 'nyau tu pratyayau tadviparyayāt // yena kāritranyāyena hetupratyayau dvidhā kṛtvoktastadviparyayātsamanatarapratyayālambanapratyayau veditavyau /
column2: Concerning the other conditions: Two other conditions, in reveṟse order.

First in the list of conditions there comes the equal and immediately antecedent condition: it exercises it activity as do the three causes, namely with regard to an arising dharmna, fot the minds and mental states of a given moment cede their place to the mind and mental states which are arising.

Next in the list there comes an object as condition: it exercises its actīvity as do the two causes, namely with regard to a perishing dharma: this perishing dbarma is mind and mental states, the “subjects of the consciousness” , which, perishing.
The activity of predominant influence as a condition only consists in not creating any obstacle either to a past, present, or future.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktāḥ sakāritrāḥ pratyayāḥ // atha katamo dharmaḥ katibhiḥ pratyayairutpadyate /
column2: The different types of dharmas arise by reason of how many conditions?
The mind and its mental states arise by reason of four conditions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra hetupratyaya eṣāṃ sarve pañca hetavaḥ /
column2: Causes as conditions: the five causes;
equal and immediately antecedent condition: the earlier mind and mental states, which have arisen not separated by other minds or mental states;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ālambanapratyayo yathāyogaṃ pañca viṣayāḥ sarve dharmāśca /
column2: an object as condition: the five objects of which physical matter is the first, or, in the case of the mental consciousness, all the dharmas;
and a predominating influence as condition: all the dharmas, except the mind and its mental states whose arising is under consideration.
The two absorptions, by reason of three.
One must exclude the object as condition, because the absorption of non-consciousness and the absorption of extinction do not grasp an object.
We have.
Causes as conditions: two causes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sahabhūhetuśca jātyādayaḥ sabhāgahetuśca pūrvotpannā samānabhūmikāḥ kuśalā dharmāḥ /
column2: the good former dharmas, already arisen, belonging to the stage of absorption, that is, to the Fourth Dhyāna or to Bhavāgra, according to the case. an equal and immediately antecedent condition, the mind of entry into the absorption and the mental states that are associated with this mind;
the mind of entry is not separated by any mind of any of the moments of the absorption.
the predominating influence as condition, as above.
These two absorptions arise from an application, from an inflection of the mind: they then have the mind as an equal and immediately antecedent condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cittotpattivibandhakatvāt na samanantarapratyayaḥ / dvābhyāmanye tu jāyante
column2: They hinder the arising of the mind: thus they are not equal and immediately antecedent conditions of the mind leaving the absorption, even though they are immediately contigous to it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye tu viprayuktā rūpiṇaśca dharmā hetvadhipatipratyayābhyāṃ jāyante yathāvihitameva /
column2: The other dharmas, namely the other saṁskāras disassociated form the mind and the material haras, arise by reason of the causes as conditions and the predominating influence as condition. Ali the dharmas that atise arise by reason of the five causes abd the four conditions that we have just explained.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āha tu “pratyayebhyo bhāvā upajāyante na punaḥ sarvasyaiva jagataḥ īśvarapuruṣapradhānādikaṃ kāraṇamiti /
column2: The world does not proceed from a single cause that is called God, or Puruṣa, or Pradhāṇna, or any other name.
How do you prove this thesis?
If you think that the thesis is proven through arguments, you betray your doctrine that the world arises from a single cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca atha evāsya vādasya vyudāsaḥ prāpnotyekaṃ kāraṇamīśvarādikaṃ sarvasyeti / apica neśvarādeḥ kramādibhiḥ //
column2: Ṉot from God or from any othet cause, since there is a suūccession, etc. That things are produced by a single cause, by God, Mahadeva, or Váāsudeva, is inadmissable for many reasons.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi hyekameva kāraṇamīśvaraḥ syādanyadvā yugapatsarveṇa jagatā bhavitavyaṃsyāt / dṛśyate ca bhāvānāṃ kramasaṃbhavaḥ /
column2: If things were produced by a single cause, they would arise all at the same time: now each of us knows that they arise successively. They arise successively by virtue of the desires of God, who says, “May this arise now! May this perish now!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tarhi cchandavaśā dīśvarasya syādayamidānīmutpadyatāmayaṃ nirudhyatāmayaṃ paścāditi /
column2: May this arise and perish later!”
If this were the case, then things do not arise from a single cause, since the desires are multiple.
Moreover these multipleThe desires of God are not simultaneous, because God, in order to produce his desires, takes into account other causes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāraṇāntarabhedāpekṣaṇe vā neśvara eva kāraṇaṃ syāt /
column2: If this were so, then God is not the single unique cause of all things.

And the causes that God takes into account are produced successively: they depend then on causes which are themselves dependent on other causes: an infinite regression. It is admitted that the series of causes has no beginning.
This would admit that sa/sára does not have an origin. You then abandon the doctrine of a single cause and return to the Buddhist theory of causes and conditions.

The desires of God are simuitaneous, but things do not arise at the same time because they arise as God wishes them to ariṣe, that is, in succession. This is inadtmissible. The desires of God remain what they are. Let us explain.

Suppose that God desires "May this arise now! May that arise now! These desires would have to be simultaneous, since God, the cause of these desires, is not multiple, and things would all arise at the same time.
We do not see why the second desire, at first nonefficacious, will be efficacious later; why, if it is efficacious later, it will not be so initially.
What advantage does God obtain from this great effort by which he produces the world? God produces the world for his own satisfaction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi prītistāṃ tarhi nāntareṇopāye śaktaḥ kartumiti na tasyāmīśvaraḥ syāttathaiva cānyasmin /
column2: He is then not God, the Sovereign, in what concerns his own satisfaction, since he cannot realize it without a means. And if he is not sovereign with regard to his own satisfaction, how can he be sovereign with regard to the world?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi ceśvaro narakādiṣu prajāṃ bahubhiścetibhirūpasṛṣṭāṃ sṛṣṭvā tena prīyate namo 'stu tasmai tādṛśāyeśvrāya /
column2: Further, do you say that God finds satisfaction in seeing the creatures that he has created in the prey of all the sufferings of existence, including the tortures of the hells? Homage to this God!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sugītaścāyaṃ tamārabhya śloko bhavati / “yannirdahati yattīkṣṇo yadugro yatpratāpavān / māṃsaśoṇitamajjādo yattato rudra ucyata” iti /
column2: Well said, in truth, is the popular stanza, “He is called Rudra because he burns, because he is excited, ferocious, terrible, an eater of flesh, blood, and marrow.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekaṃ khalvapi jagataḥ kāraṇaṃ parigṛhṇatā 'nyeṣāmarthānāṃ pratyakṣaḥ puruṣakāro nihgṛhṇtaḥ syāt /
column2: The followers of God, the single cause of the world, deny visible causes,—causes and conditions,—the efficacy of the seed with regard to. If modifying their position, they admit the existence of these causes, and pretend that these causes serve God as auxiliaries, this then is no more than a pious affirmation, for we do not maintain any activity of a cause besides the activity of the so-called secondary causes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sahāpi ca kāraṇaiḥ kāraka mīśvaraṃ kalpayatā kevalo bhaktivādaḥ syat /
column2: Furthermore, God would not be sovereign with regard to auxiliary causes, since these cooperate in the production of the effect through their own efficacy.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāraṇebhyo 'nyasya tadutpattau vyāpārādarśanāt / sahakāriṣu cānyeṣu kāraṇeṣvīśvaro neśvaraḥ syāt / athādisarga īśvarahetukaḥ /
column2: Perhaps, in order to avoid the negation of causes, which are visible, and in order to avoid the affirmation of present action by God, which is not visible, the Theist would say that the work of God is creation: but creation, dependent only on God, would never have a beginning, like God himself, and this is a consequence that the Theist rejects.
We would refute the doctrine of Puruṣa, of Pradhāna, etc. , as we have refuted the theist doctrine, mutatis mutandis.
Thus, no dharma arises from a single cause. Alas, persons are unclear! Like the birds and the animals, truly.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svānyevaiṣāṃ karmāṇi tasyāṃ tasyāṃ jātau janayanti /
column2: Worth of pity, they go from existence to existence, accomplishing diverse actions;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akṛtabuddhayastu varākāḥ svaṃ svaṃ vipākaphalaṃ cānubhavanta īśvaramaparaṃ mithyā parikalpayanti /
column2: they experience the results of these actions and falsely believe that God is the cause of these results. (We trust explain the Truth in order to put an end to this false conception.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gatametadyattu khalu taduktaṃ “dvābhyāmanye tu jāyanta” iti /
column2: ) We have seen that the material dharmas arise by reason of two conditions, causes as conditions and predominating influences as conditions.

We must specify and see how the primary elements (bhas ot mahābhūtas), and the dharmas of derived matter (upādāyarpa oṛ bhautikas), are causes as conditions, either among themselves, or one from the other.

The primary elements are the cause of the derived elements in two ways. The four primary elements of earth, etc, are causes of the four primary elements in the quality of similar causes, and of mutually coexistant causes.
And of the derived elements, in five ways.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhautikasya tu bhūtāni pañcaprakāro hetuḥ / katham / “jananānniḥśrayāt sthānādupastambhogavṛṃhaṇāt“
column2: The four primary elements are causes of the derived elements—color, taste, etc—in five ways, in the quality of janana, niśraya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'yaṃ kāraṇahetureva punaḥ paṇycadhā bhinnaḥ / jananahetustebhya utpatteḥ /
column2: Jananahety ot generating cause, because the derived elements arise from them, like a child from his parents.
Niśrayahetu or tutelage cause, because the bhautikas, once arisen, submerge their influence, as a monk is under the tutelage of his Ācārya and his Upādhyāya.
Pratiṣṭhāhetu or supporting cause, because the derived elements aṟe supported by them, as a picture is supported by a wall.

Upastambhahetu or maintaining cause, because the primary elements are the cause of the non-interruption of the derived elements. Upabṛṁhaṇahetu or growth cause, because the primary elements are the cause of the development of the derived elements.

This means that the primary elements are, with regard to the derived elements , the cause of arising , the cause of transformation , the supporting cause , the cause of duṟation , and the cause of development .

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tridhā bhautikamanyonyaṃ / hetusahabhūsabhāgavipākahetubhiḥ kāraṇaheturaviśeṣayattitvāt na sarvadā gaṇyate /
column2: Derived elements are the cause of the derived elements in three ways. In the qualtīy of sahabhā, sabhāga and vipākahetu. We do not. For any dharma is a kāraṇahetu of any other dharma.
The actions of the body and voice of the category described in ii5la, which are derived elements, are sahabhūhetu.
All the derived elements which have arisen, are, with regard to similar derived elements, sabhāgahetu.
The actions of the body and voice are vipākahetu: the eye is produced through retribution of action, etc. And the cause of the primary elements, in one way.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhūtānāṃ tu tadbhūtikaṃ rūpaṃ vipākahetureva yasya kāyavākkarmaṇo bhūtāni vipākāḥ /
column2: The actions of the body and voice produce the primary elements as a retributive result: they are then vipākahetu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhedena cittacaittāḥ samanantarapratyaya uktā niyamastu noktaḥ kasya cittasyānantaraṃ kasyotpaktiriti /
column2: We have seen that antecedent minds and mental states are the equal and immediately antecent condition of subsequent minds and mental states. But we have not explained how many types of mind arise immediately after each type of mind.
In order to define its role, we must first establish a classification of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra tāvat samāsena dvādaśa cittāni / kimarthamityāha kuśalākuśalaṃ kāme nivṛtānivṛtaṃ manaḥ /
column2: First, we must distinguish twelve categories.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātau catvāri cittāni / kuśalamakuśalaṃ nivṛtāvyākṛtamanivṛtāvyākṛtaṃ ca / rūpārūpyeṣvakuśalādanyatra
column2: Good, bad, defiled-neutral, undefiled-neutral minds inFour types of minds belong to Kāmadhātu: good, bad, defiled-neutral, and undefiled-neutral.
Good defiled-neutral, undefiled-neutral minds in Rūpadhāṭu and in Ārūpyadhātu.
Three types of minds are in the two higher spheres: all of the above, excluding the bad mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamārūpyadhātau / ityetāni sānusravāṇi daśa cittāni bhavanti /
column2: And two pure minds.
The two pure minds are those of the Śaikṣa and the Arhat or Aśaikṣa.
In all, these constitute twelve minds.
Nine types of minds can arise after a good mind in Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātau yatkuśalaṃ cittaṃ tasmādanantaraṃ nava cittānyutpadyante / svabhūmikāni catvāri /
column2: Immediately after a good mind in Kāmadhātu there can arise nine minds, namely the four minds in Kāmadhātu;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāvacare dve / samāpattikāle kuśalaṃ pratisandhikāle nivṛtam / ārūpyāvacaraṃ nivṛtameva pratisandhikāle /
column2: two minds in Rūpadhātu: good, when a ascetic enters into absorption, and defiled-neutral, when a person who dies in Kāmadhātu with a good mind passes into the intermediate existence of Rūpadhātu; a mind in Ārūpyadhātu, a defiled-neutral mind, when one dying in Kāmadhātu is reborn in Ārūpyadhātu;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ativiprakṛṣṭatvāt na kuśalam / ārūpyā hi kāmadhātoścatasṛbhirdūratābhirdūre / āśrayākārālambanapratipakṣadūratābhiḥ / śaikṣamaśaikṣaṃ ceti /
column2: not good, for, since Ārūpyadhātu is estranged from Kāmadhátu by four estrangements, one.
Such a mind can arise after eight types of minds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra punaḥ kāmāvacaraṃ kuśalaṃ cittamaṣṭābhyaḥ samanantaramutpadyate / svabhūmikebhyaścaturbhyo rūpāvacarābhyāṃ dvābhyām / kuśalācca vyutthānakāle /
column2: A good mind can arise immediately after eight minds, namely: the four minds in Kāmadhātu, two minds in Rūpadhātu, good and defiled-neutral minds, upon leaving an absorption.
It happens in fact that an ascetic, bothered by a defiled absorption, leaves this absorption: after the defiled mind, which is this absorption, he produces a good mind of a lower stage;
and two pure minds, of Śaikṣa or Aśaikṣa, upon leaving the Understanding of the Truths.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśabhyo 'kuśalaṃ śaikṣāśaikṣe hitvā kāmadhātau hi pratisandhimukhataḥ sarvebhyo rūpārūpyacittebhyaḥ samanantaramakuśalaṃ cittamutpadyate / tasmāccatvāri /
column2: A bad mind can arise after ten types of minds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akuśalāccittāt samanantaraṃ cittānyutpadyante svabhūmikānyeva / yathā 'kuśalamuktaṃ kāmadhātau nivṛtaṃ tathā // daśabhya eva samanantaram /
column2: A klśṣṭa mind, that is to say, a bad and a defiled-neutral mind can arise after ten minds—excluding the two pure minds, for a mind of rebirth into Kāmadhātu is defiled and can follow any kind of mind belonging to the three spheres of existence.
Four types of minds can arise after such a mind. Four minds can arise after a mind, namely the four minds of Kāmadhātu. The same for a defiled-neutral mind.
An undefiled-neutral mind can arise after five minds.
An undefiled-neutral mind can arise after five types of mind.

Namely the four minds in Kāmadhātu, plus a good mind in Rūpadhātu: for a mind capable of creating fictive beings in Kāmadhātu, a mind that has for its object the creation of an object of Kāmadhātu, follows a good mind in Rūpadhātu.
Seven types of mind can arise after an undefiled-neutral mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anivṛtāvyākṛṭātkāmāvacarātsvabhūmikāni catvāri / rūpāvacare dve / kuśalaṃ nirmāṇacittādanantaram / kliṣṭam pratisandhikāle /
column2: After an undefiled-neutral mind there can arise seven minds, namely: the four minds in Kāmadhātu, two minds in Rūpadhātu, good minds, for, after the aforementioned mind of creation, a good mind reappears in Rūpadhātu, and a defiled-neutral mind, when a person, dying with this mind, is reborn in Rūpadhātu the first mind of which is necessarily a defiled-neutral mind;
a mind of Ārūpyadhātu, a defiled-neutral mind, when a person, dying with this mind, is reborn in Ārūpyadhātu.
In Rūpadhātu eleven types of minds can arise after a good mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpe dhātau yatkukśalaṃ cittaṃ tasmādanantaramekādaśa cittānyutpadyante / ārupyāvacaramanivṛtāvyākṛtaṃ varjayitvā /
column2: Eleven minds, excluding an undefiled-neutral mind in Ṛūpadhātu, can arise immediately after a good mind in Rūpadhātu.
A good mind can arise after nine types of minds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāvacaraṃ tu kuśalaṃ cittaṃ navabhyaḥ samanantaramutpadyate / kāmāvacaraṃ kliṣṭadvayamārupyāvacaraṃ cānivṛtāvyākṛtaṃ hitvā /
column2: A good mind can arise after nine minds, excluding the two defiled minds in Kāmadhātu and an undefiled-neutral mind in Ārūpyadhātu.
A defiled-neutral mind can arise after eight types of minds.
A defiled-neutral mind can arise after eight minds, excluding the two defiled minds in Kāmadhātu and the two pure minds. Śix types of minds can arise after a defiled-neutral mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacaraṃ kliṣṭadvayaṃ śaikṣāśaikṣe ca sthāpayitvā / tasmāt ṣaṭ rūpāvacarānnivṛtāvyākṛtādanantaraṃ ṣaṭ / svabhūmikāni trīṇi kāmāvacarāṇi cānivṛtāvyākṛtaṃ muktvā /
column2: Six minds can arise after a defiled-neutral mind, namely the three minds in Rūpadhātu, and the good, bad, and defiled-neutral minds in Kāmadhātu.
An undefiled-neutral mind can arise after three types of mind.
An undefiled-neutral mind can arise after the three minds in Rūpadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt ṣaṭ svabhūmikāni trīṇi / kāmāvacare ca kliṣṭe / ārūpyāvacaraṃ ca / yathā rūpadhātāvanivṛtāvyākṛtamuktam / evamārūpye tasya nītiḥ /
column2: Six types of mind can arise after such a mind.
Six minds can arise after an undefiled-neutral mind, namely:An undefiled-neutral mind in Ārūpyadhātu can arise after the three minds of this sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādapi ca ṣaḍevotpadyante / svabhūmikāni trīṇi adharadhātukāni ca kliṣṭāni /
column2: Six minds can arise after an undefiled-neutral mind in Ārūpyadhātu, namely: the three minds of this sphere, and the defiled minds in Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu.
Nine types of minds can arise after a good mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārūpyāvacarātṛ kukśalānnava cittānyutpadyante / kāmāvacaraṃ kukśalaṃ kāmarūpāvacare cānivṛtāvyākṛte hitvā /
column2: Nine minds can arise after a good mind, with the exception of a good mind in Kāmadhātu and an undefiled-neutral mind in Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu.
Such a can arise after six types of mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārūpyāvacaraṃ kukśalaṃ svebhyastribhyo rūpāvacarāt kukśalācchaikṣāśaikṣābhyāṃ ca / nivṛtātsapta
column2: A good mind can arise after six minds, namely the three minds in Ārūpyadhātu, a good mind ia Rūpadhātu, and the two pure minds. Seven types of minds can arise after a defiled-neutral mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārūpyāvacarānnivṛtātsvabhūmikāni trīṇi rūpāvacaraṃ kuśalaṃ nivṛtaṃ ca kāmāvacaraṃ kliṣṭadvayam / tattathā / tadapi saptabhya evotpadyate /
column2: Seven minds can arise after a defiled-neutral mind, namely the three minds in Arāpyadhātu, a good mind in Rūpadhātu, two defiled minds in Kāmadhātu, and a defiled mind in Ṛūñpadhātu.
A defiled-neutal mind can arise after seven minds, with the exception of the two defiled minds in Kāmādhatu, a defiled mind in Rūpadhātu and the two pure minds.
A Śaikṣa mind can arise after four types of minds.
A Śaikṣa mind, the mind belonging to the saint who is not an Arhat, can arise after four minds, namely a Śaikṣa mind and a good mind in each of the three spheres.
But five types of minds can arise after such (a Śaikṣa mind).
Five minds can arise after a Śaikṣa mind, namely the four that have just been named and an Aśaikṣa mind.
An Aśaikṣa mind can arise after five types of minds. An Aśaikṣa mind can arise after five minds, namely after a Śaikṣa mind, an Aśaikṣa mind, aṇnd a good mind of each of the three spheres.
Four types of minds can arise after such (an Aśaikṣa mind).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmātpunaraśaikṣāccittātsamanantaraṃ catvāri cittānyutpadyante / traidhātukāni kuśalānyaśaikṣaṃ ca //
column2: Four minds can arise after an Aśaikṣa mind, namely an Aśaikṣa mind and a good mind of each of three spheres.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāptāni dvādaśa cittāni // punaḥ kriyante dvādaśaitāni viṃśatiḥ / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: The twelve types of mind succeed one another in conformity with.
By dividing the good mind of the three Dhātus into two, the acquired and the innate minds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: triṣu dhātuṣu kuśalaṃ cittaṃ dvidhā bhidyate / prāyogikaṃ copapattilābhikaṃ ca vipākajaiyapithikaśailpasthānikanairmitam / caturdhā 'vyākṛtaṃ kāme bhittveti varttate /
column2: A good mind of each of the three spheres is divided into two categories, that acquired through effort and that acquired by birth. We then have six types of good mind corresponding to three types of the fist list.

An undefiled-neutral mind of Kāmadhātu is divided into four categories: atisen from a retributive cause, relative to attitudes, walking, standing, sitting, lying down, relative to the arts, and relative to fictive creations.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vipākajamairyāpathikaṃ śelpasthānikaṃ nirmāṇacittaṃ ca / rūpe śilpavivarjitam //
column2: The mind by which a possessor of supernatural power creates visible things, etc, is called the result of 4bhiñā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpadhātau tridhā bhidyate śailpasthānikaṃ varjayitvā / tatra śilpābhāvāt / evametāni dvādaśa cittāni punarviśartirbharvanti /
column2: An undefiled-neutral mind in Rūpadhātu is divided into only three categories, for Failpasthānika does not exist in this sphere.
We then have seven types of undefiled-neutral mipds corresponding to the two undefiled-neutral minds of the ficst list. By taking into account the good minds, we obtain a total of twenty.
Three undefiled-neutral minds, the éryāpathia mind and following, have visible things, odors, taste, and tangible things for their object.
The śai/pasthānika mind, furthermore, has sound for its object.
These three undefiled-neutral minds are solely mental consciousnesses.
However the five sense consciousnesses preceed and prepare the aéryāpathika aṅd śailpasthāntka minds.
According to another opinion, there is a mental consciousness produced by the airyāpathika mind, which has the twelves āyatanas, from the organ of sight to the dharmāyatana, for its object.
Twenty minds arise one after another, in conformity with the following rules:
Kāmadhātu: eight types of mind of the sphere of Kāmadhātu, namely two good minds, two k/isṭa minds, and four undefiled-neutral minds. Good Acquired through Effort.
Followed by ten: seven minds of the same sphere, with the exception of abhijñāphala.
a mind of Rūpadhātu acquired through effort; and a Śaikṣa mind and an Aśaikṣa mind.
It follows seven: four minds of the same sphere, the two good minds and the two bliy« minds;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svebhyaḥ kuśalakliṣṭebhyaḥ rūpāvacarābhyāṃ prāyogika kliṣṭābhyāṃ śaikṣāśaikṣābhyāṃ ca /
column2: a mind acquired through effort and an undefiled mind of Rūpadhātu; a Saikṣa mind and an Aśaikṣa mind.
Good Acquired through Birth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svabhūmikāni sapta 'nyatrābhijñāphalādrūpā rūpāvacare ca kliṣṭe / tat punarekādaśānantaram /
column2: Followed by ten: seven minds of the same sphere, with the exception of abhiñāphala; undefiled-neutral minds of Rūpadhātu and Arūpyadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svebhyaḥ saptabhyaḥ pūrvavat rūpāvacarābhyāṃ prāyogikakliṣṭābhyāṃ śaikṣāśaikṣābhyāṃ ca /
column2: It follows eleven: seven minds of the same sphere, with the exception of abhijñāphala; a mind acquired through effort and an undefiled-neutral mind of Rūpadhātu; a Śaikṣa mind and an Aśaikṣa mind.
Bad and defiled-neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te punaścaturdaśacittānantaram / svebhyaḥ saptabhyaḥ rūpāvacarebhyaścaturbhyo 'nyatra prāyogikābhijñāphalābhyām / ārupyāvacarebhyastribhyo 'nyatra prāyogikāt /
column2: They follow fourteen: seven minds of the same sphere, with the exception of abhiñāphala, four minds of Rūpadhātu, with the exception of a mind acquired through effort and abhijñāphala, three minds of Arūpyadbhātu, with the exception of a mind acquired through effort. Vipākaja aṇd aéryāpathika.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ prāyogikacittānantaraṃ vīpākajaiyāpathikaśailpasthānikānicittānyutpadyante na punrebhyaḥ prāyogikam /
column2: A vipākaja mind is not favorable to a mind acquired through effort, because it is weak, and because it develops spontaneously.
Airyāpa'hika ahd failpasthānika minds are not favoṛable to a mind acquired through effort because their reason for being is the creation of an attitude or a created thing.

Contrarily, the niṣkramnaṇacita ox the mind of leaving,—that is, any mind, a vipākaja mind, etc. , by which a Yogin leaves the series of. The mind of leaving can then immediately follow a mind acquired through effort.

Objection: If a mind acquired through effort does not arise immediately after the vipākaja, etc. , because these are not favorable to it, still less will it arise after a defiled mind which is contrary to it.
A defiled mind is contrary to a mind acquired through effort.

Yet, when an ascetic is exhausted from the activity of the defilements, a mind acquired through effort arises from the fact that the ascetic lays hold of a perfect consciousness of this activity. The innate good mind of Kāmadhātu is sharp;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacaramupapattipratilambhikaṃ paṭutvāt śaikṣāśaikṣābhyāṃ rūpāvacaraprāyogikāccānantaramutpadyate / anabhisaṃskāravāhitvāttasmādetāni notpadyante /

An innate good mind of Kāmadhātu, being sharp, can arise after a defiled mind of Rūpadhātu;
but an innate good mind of Rūpadhātu. Not being sharp, cannot arise after a defiled mind of Arūpyadhātu. We must then study the act of attention.

We can distinguish three acts of attention: Svalakṣaṇamanaskāra, an act of attention to specific characteristics, for example the judgments “Rāpa has rūpaṇa for its characteristic. Viṭñāna has prativijñapti for its characteristic”.

Sāmānyalakṣaṇmanaskāra, an act of attention to common or general characteristics, to the sixteen aspects of the Truths, impermanence, etc. , and “The conditioned dharmas are impermanent” (see vii. Adhimuktimanaskāra: this act of attention is not, like the first two, directed to that which exists; rather, it proceeds from adhimakti, that is, from constructive imagination (adhimuktyā.
Manaskāraḥ, see p.

it presides over the contemplations of asfubhā, the apramāṇas, the vimokṣas, the abhibhvāyatanas, the kṛtsnāyatanas, etc. The innate good mind of Kāmadhātu is sharp; hence it can arise after the two pure minds and also after a mind of Rūpadhātu acquired through effort, but, as it develops spontaneously, it is not followed by these same minds. An innate good mind of Kāmadhātu, being sharp, can arise after a defiled mind of Rūpadhātu; but an innate good mind of Rūpadhātu, not being sharp, cannot arise after a defiled mind of Ārūpyadhātu.

He will not produce an act of attention to general characteristics of the sphere of one of the three higher Dhyānas, because he has not previously obtained conscious acts of attention, except in the course of the practice of the nirvedhabhāgīyas.

there is, by virtue of the Path, entry into the Path and detachment from Kāmadhātu and Ārūpyadhāta.
One obtains these same minds with the other minds.

What are these three realms?
Kāmadhātu consists of hell, the Pretas, animals, humans, and six gods.
Kāmadhātu consists of four complete realms of rebirth.

How many places are there in Kāmadhātu?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātuḥ paranirmitavaśavartibhyo yāvadavīciḥ sabhājanagrahaṇena tu yāvadvāyumaṇḍalam / etasmācca kāmadhātoḥ
column2: Hence, from Avici hell up to the heaven of the Paranirmitavaśavartins, there are twenty places which constitute, with the physical world which rests on the circle of wind, Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ūrdhvaṃ saptadaśasthāno rūpadhātuḥ kathamityāha pṛthak pṛthak
column2: Above is Rūpadhātu, of seventeen places.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānaṃ tribhūmikaṃ tatra prathamadvitīyatṛtīyadhyānāni pratyekaṃ tribhūmikāni /
column2: The seventeen places of Rūpadhātu are above Kāmadhātu, made up of dhyānas which are each of three stages.
But the fourth is of eight stages. Each of the dhyānar contains three stages or spheres, with the exception of the fourth.
The First Dhyāṇa is made up of the Brahmakāyikas, the Brahmapurohitas, and the Mahābrahmanus.
The Second Dhyāṇna is made up of the Parīttābhas, the Apramāṉābhas, and the Ābhāsvaras.
The Third Dhyāna is made up of the Parīttaśubhas, the Apramāṇaśubhas, and the Śubhakṛtsnas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturthamanabhrakāḥ puṇyaprasavāḥ bṛhatphalā abṛhā atapāḥ sudṛśāḥ sudarśanā akaniṣṭhā ityetāni saptadaśa sthānāni rūpadhātuḥ /
column2: The Fourth Dhyāna is made up of the Anabhṛakas, the Puṇyaprasavas, the Brhatphalas, Avrhas, Atapas, Sudrśas, Sudarśanas, Akanisthas. These seventeen places constitute Rūpadhātu.
But the Kāśmīrians say that Rūpadhātu is made up of only sixteen places.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: brahmapurohiteṣveva kila sthānamutkṛṣṭataraṃ mahābrahmaṇaḥ parigaṇa ivābhinirvṛttamekanāyakaṃ natu bhūmyantaramiti /
column2: In the heaven of the Brahmapurohitas there rises, they say, a lofty dwelling which is named the Heaven of Brahmā, inhabited by a single ruler—such as a teṟrace or a high place—but which does not constitute a stage.
Ārūpyadhātu is not a place.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atītānāgatāvijñaptyarūpiṇo hi dharmā ādeśasthā iti niyamaḥ /
column2: In fact non-material dbarmas do not occupy a place: likewise the material dharmas when they are past or future, gviñāpt and the nonmmaterial dharmas, do not occupy a location.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tu upapattyā caturvidhaḥ / upapattibhedena caturvidha ārūpyadhātuḥ / yaduta ākāśānantyāyatanaṃ vijñānānantyāyatanamākiñcanyāyatanaṃ naivarāñjñānāsaṃjñāyatanamiti / natveṣāṃ deśakṛtamauttarādharya bhidyate / yatraiva hi deśe tatsmāpattilābhinaścyavante tatraivopapadyante iti / punaśca tasmāccyavamānānāṃ tatraivāntarābhavo 'bhinirvarttate /
column2: But.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā rūpiṇāṃ sattvānāṃ rūpaṃ niśritya pravarttate cittasaṃtatirevamārūpyeṣu kiṃ niśritya pravrttate / nikāyaṃ jīvitaṃ cātra niśritā cittasantatiḥ //
column2: The mental series, the mind and mental states of material beings is supported on physical matter, and in this way can exist. What is the support of the mental series of beings in Ārūpyadhātu?

According to the Ābhidhārmikas, the mental series of beings in Ārūpyadhātu has for its support two dharmas disassociated from the mind, ṅkāyasabhāgatā, genre or genus, and jñvibendriya, the vital organ.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rupiṇāmapi tarhi sattvānāṃ kimartha na tadeva dvayaṃ niśritya pravarttate cittasantatiḥ / durbalatvāt / tasyāḥ kena balavattvam /
column2: The mental series of material beings is not supported by these two dharmas, because they lack force;
but the mental series of nonmaterial beings possess the necessary force, because they proceed from an absorption from whence the idea of physical matter has been eliminated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tata eva tarhi balavattvāt pravarttiṣyate kim punarniśrayeṇa / idaṃ cāpi vaktavyam / yathā rūpiṇāṃ sattvānāṃ rūpaṃ niśritya pravarttate nikāyasabhāgo jīvitendriyaṃ ca evamarūpiṇāṃ sattvānāṃ kiṃ niśritya pravarttate /
column2: But, one would say, genre and the vital organ of material beings is supported by physical matter: but what is the support of genre and the vital organ for nonmaterial beings?

These two support one another. Among material beings, genre and the vital organ do not have the force necessary to support one another, but they have this force among nonmaterial beings, because they proceed from a ceṛtain absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpiṇāmapi tarhi kimarthaṃ na tadeva dvayamanyonyam / durbalatvāttayoḥ / tatredānīṃ kena balavattvām / samāpattiviśeṣajatvāt /
column2: According to the Sautrāntikas, the mental series, mind and mental states, does not have, among nonmaterial beings, any support which is.
Or rather, we say that the mind is supported by the mental states, and the mental states by the mind, in the way that you say that genre and the vital organ support one another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmānnāstyarūpiṇāṃ sattvānāṃ cittasantateranyonyam niśraya iti sautrāntikāḥ /
column2: The series of minds of a new existence is “projected”' by a certain cause ; if this cause is not free from attachment to physicalmatter, the mind will be reborn with matter, and its series will be supported by matter;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: api tu yasyāścittasantaterākṣepaheturavītatṛṣṇo rūpe tasyāḥ saha rūpeṇa saṃbhavādrūpaṃ niśritya pravṛttiryasyāstu heturvītatṛṣṇo rūpe tasyā anapekṣya rūpaṃ pravṛttiḥ / hetostadvimukhatvāditi /
column2: if this cause is free from attachment to physical mattero—as in the case for absorption which is the cause which projects an existence in Ārūpyadhātu—the mind willbe reborn and will exist without relation to physical matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmapratisaṃyuktodhātuḥ kāmadhātuḥ rūpapratisaṃyukto dhātū rūpadhāturmadhyapadalopādvajrabālakavat maricapānakavacca /
column2: Kāmadhātu can be understood as “adhā associated with kāmas,” by ommitting the middle word “assocated with” , as weIn the same way Rūpadhātu signifies "a dhātu associated with matter.
We have the adjective gr%pa or free from matter," from whence the abstract noun ārāpya, absence of matter. Or rather rpa is that which is susceptible to being struck, to resistance;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: arūpasya bhāva ārupyam / rūpaṇīyo vā rūpyaḥ /
column2: arāpa, by absence of rūpa, ārūpya, the fact of being such.
Ārūpyadhātu is that which is associated with āripya. OṬ rather these terms are compounds the first term of which is a genitive: Kāmadhātu, the receptacle of bātu of the kāmas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatpratisaṃyukto dhāturārūpyadhātuḥ / kāmānāṃ dhātuḥ kāmadhātuḥ kāmān yo dadhāti /
column2: Rūpadhātu, the receptacle of matter;
Ārūpyadhātu, the receptacle of ārpya.
What is kāma?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāsātaḥ kavaḍīkārāhāra maithunopasaṃhito rāgaḥ / “na te kāmā yāni citrāṇi loke saṃkalparāgaḥ puruṣasya kāmaḥ / tiṣṭhanti citrāṇi tathaiva loke aṭhātra dhīrā vinayanti kāmam” // iti
column2: Concupiscence, the desire to eat by mouthfuls (éavaḍīṝkārāhāra, iii39) and sexual desire.

column2:
kāma is the desire that the imagination nourishes among humans. The objects of the universe are of litle importance;

The Ājīvika answered, ‘If the fine things of this wotld are not éamas, if kāma iīs the desire that is nourished by the imagination, thesame Bhikṣu would be a ‘taster of the kāmas’ when he produces bad imaginations.”
āryaśāriputra āha te cetkāmā yāni citrāṇi loke saṃkalparāgo yadi te na kāmaḥ / śāstā 'pi te bhavitā kāmabhogī dṛṣṭvaiva rūpāṇi manoramāṇi”//	Śāriputra answered, “If the fine things of this wotld are éāmas, if kāma is not desire which the imagination nourishes, then the Master himself would be a taster of the kāmas when he sees objects.”
kiṃ punarye kecana dharmāḥ kāmarūpārupyadhātuṣu samudācaranti sarve te kāmarūpārūpyapratisaṃyuktāḥ / netyāha / kiṃ tarhi /	Should one consider as “intergral’ to one Dhātu, all the dbarmas that are produced in this Dhātu?
yeṣu kāmarūpārupyarāgā anuśerate /	No, but merely thedharma with regatrd to which there develops, and in which there resides craving proper to this Dhatu, craving of Kāmadhātu, Rūpadhātu, and ĀĀrūpyadhātu.
ke punaramī kāmarūpārūpyarāgāḥ /	What is the craving proper to each Dhātu?

yasyāyamaśvabandhaḥ /	“To the owner of this tether.
ityubhayamapi na jñāyate / nedamaśvabandhīyam /	This answer does not teach us anything.

teṣvavītarāgasya yo rāgaḥ sa kāmarāgaḥ / yatrānuśete so 'pi dharmaḥ kāmapratisaṃyuktaḥ /	“Craving proper to Kāmadhātu” is the craving of the being who is not detached from this place, who has not rejected craving with regard to the āharmas of this place.
evaṃ rūpārūpyarāgāvadhovītarāgasya yathāyogaṃ veditavyau /	The same for the other two Dhātus.
asamāhitabhūmiko vā rāgaḥ kāmarāgaḥ /	Or rather, “craving proper to Kāmadhātu” is the craving of a being who is not absorbed;
dhyānārūpyeṣu rāgo rūpārūpyarāgaḥ /	“craving proper to Rūpadhātu, to Ārūpyadhātu” is craving relative to the absorption of dhyāna, to the absorptions of ārāpya. The mind by which one creates magical objects in the sphere of Kāmadhātu is the result of a dhyāna. But this mind is produced only among beings detached from Kāmadhātu.
nirmāṇacitte kathaṃ kāmarāgaḥ / śrutvā parihāya ca tadāsvādanāt /	How can one say that this mind is of the sphere of Kāmadhātu?
nirmāṇavaśena vā nirmāyaka citto 'pi rāgaḥ / gandharasanirmāṇādvā /	In fact, this mind is not produced among a being not detached from Kāmadhātu, and, when this mind is produced among a being detached. This mind is hence of the sphere of Kāmadhātu without there being, with regard to it, any craving of the order of Kāmadhātu: this is a difficulty that contradicts your definition of the Dhātus.
tasya kāmavacaratvam /	‘This mind is of the sphere of Kāmadhātu because a craving of the order of Kāmadhātu is produced with regard to it in a person who intends to speak of this mind as belonging to another, or who remembers having possessed it previously, or who sees magic creations.
rūpāvacareṇa tayoranirmāṇāt /	Or rather because this mind creates some odors or tastes: now a mind of the sphere of Rūpadhātu cannot create odo1s or tastes because beings in Rūpadhātu are detached from both of these.
kiṃ punarekameva traidhātukam /	Is this triple Dhātu unique?
traidhātukānāmanto nāsti / yāvadākāśaṃ tāvanto dhātavaḥ / atha eva ca nāstyapūrvasattvaprādurbhāvaḥ /	The triple Dhātus are infinite, like space;
pratibuddhotpādaṃ cāsaṃkhyeyasattvaparinirvāṇe 'pi nāsti sattvānāṃ parikṣaya ākāśavat /	although there has not been any production of new beings, and although innumerable Buddhas convert innumerable beings and cause them to obtain Nirvāṇa, the beings of innumerable Dhātus are never exhausted.
kathamavasthānaṃ lokadhatūnāṃ /	How are the three Dhātus arranged?
tiryaksūtra uktaṃ tadyathā “īṣādhāre deve varṣati nāsti vīcirvā antarikā va antarīkṣādvāridhārāṇāṃ prapatantīnām / evaṃ pūrvasyāṃ diśi nāsti vīcirvā antarikā vā lokadhātūnāṃ saṃvarttamānānāṃ vivarttamānāṃ ca /	Horizontally, as the Sūtra proves, “as when the cloud rains, there is no interval or discontinuity of the drops of water that fall from space, so too towards the East there is no interval or discontinuity of universes in a state of creation and of dissolution;
yathā pūrvasyāṃ diśi evaṃ dakṣiṇāsyāṃ paścimāyāmuttarasyāmi“ti / natūktamūrdhvamadhaśceti / ūrdhvamapyadhho 'pītyapare /	as towards the East, the same towards the South, the West and the North.” The Sūtra does not add “toward the zenith and the nadir.”
nikāyāntarapāṭhād /	According to another opinion, the universe superimposes itself toward the zenith and the nadir, for, according to other Sūtras, the universes are arranged towards the ten cardinal points.
akaniṣṭhādūrdhvaṃ punaḥ kāmadhātuḥ / kāmadhātoścādhaḥ punarakaniṣṭhāḥ /	There is then a Kāmadhātu above Akaniṣṭha and an Akaniṣṭha below Kāmadhātu.
yaścaikasmāt kāmadhātorvītarāgaḥ sa sarvebhyaḥ /	Whoever is detached from one Kāmadhātu is detached from the Kāmadhātus of all the universes;
evaṃ rūpārūpyebhyaḥ /	the same for the other two Dhātus.
yaśca prathamadhyānasaṃniśrayāddhi utpādayati sa yatra lokadhātau jāta utpādayati tatratyameva brahmalokamupāgacchati nānyam / ya ete trayo dhātava uktāḥ /	Whoever produces the abhiñā or higher knowledge of magical power in the First Dhyāṇa, creates a magical being that can only be the Brahmaloka of the universe wherein the creator of this magical being is.
narakādisvanāmoktā gatayaḥ pañca teṣu	In these Dhātus, there are five realms of rebirth that have been designated by their names.
narakāstiryañcaḥ pretā devā manuṣyā iti / svaireva nāmabhisteṣu pañca gatayaḥ proktāḥ /	The five gatis or realms of rebirth are hellish beings, animals, Pretas, humans, and gods.
kāmadhāto catasro gatayaḥ pañcamyāśca pradeśaḥ / rūpārūpyadhātvorekasyā devagateḥ pradeśaḥ /	In Kāmadhātu there are the first four realms of rebirth and a part of the heavenly realm of rebirth; the other parts of the heavenly realm of rebirth exist in the other two Dhātus. ‘The stanza speaks of “five realms of rebirth” in the Dhātus.
kiṃ punargatinirmuktāḥ santi dhātavo yata dhātuṣvityucyante /	Is there then a part of the Dhātus that are not included in the realms of rebirth? Yes.
santi kuśalakliṣṭabhājanāntarābhavasvabhāvā api dhātavaḥ /	The good, the bad, the physical world, and intermediate existence are included in the Dhātus.
yāstu pañca gatayaḥ / tāḥ /	Whereas, as for the five destinies.
akliṣṭāvyākṛtā eva sattvākhyā nāntarābhavaḥ //	They are undefiled-neutral, they are the world of beings, and they do not include intermediate existence.
anivṛtāvyākṛtā eva gatayaḥ /	The realms of rebirth are undefiled-neutral, being the result of retribution.
anyathā hi gatisaṃbhedaḥ syāt /	In the contrary hypothesis, the five realms of rebirth would be confounded. [in fact, a person can do actions which are]repaid through a hellish rebirth, or by a heavenly rebirth: but if action were to be integral to the realms of rebirth, the human realm of rebirth would be at one and the same time hellish and heavenly. A being born in Kāmadhātu is filled with the defilements of this sphere and can be filled with the defilements of higher spheres.
sattvākhyā eva ca nacāntarābhavasvabhāvāḥ /	They are sat$vākhya, only pertaining to living beings: the physical world is not included within the realms of rebirth. Intermediate existence is not a realm of rebirth. The nature of the realms of rebirth is illustrated by many texts: 1.
prajñyaptipūktam “catasṛbhiryonibhiḥ pañca gatayaḥ saṃgṛhītā natu pañcabhirgatibhiścatasro yonayaḥ /	The Prajñāpti says, The four wombs exist in the five realms of rebirth;
but do the five realms of rebirth contain all four wombs?

column2: Subtle matter derived from the primary elements which, in hell, among animals, among the Pretas, among the >Among humans and beings born in an absorption, and among intermediate beings, is eye, eye-organ, eye-source of knowledge, eye-element.

column2: The Sūtra itself says that intermediate existence is not included among the realms of rebirth: “There are seven bhavas or existences: existence in hell, animal, Preta, heavenly, humanṉ, plus ézrmabhava and intermediate existence.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atra hi pañca gatayaḥ sahetukāḥ sahāgamanāścoktāḥ / atha eva cānivṛtāvyākṛtāḥ sidhyanti / taddhetoḥ karmabhavasya tābhyo bahiṣkaraṇāt / kāśmīrāśca sūtraṃ paṭhanti /
column2: This Sūtra indicates the five realms of rebirth with their cause, namely action or karmabhava, and their access, namely intermediate existence through which a being arrives at a reams of rebirth.

At the same time, this Sūtra shows that the realms of rebirth are undefiled neutral, since it distinguishes the realms of rebirth (hellish, etc. , existences), from the causes of these realms of rebirth, namely action which is non-neutral. This last point is again proved by a Sūtra which the Kāśmīrians read: “Śāriputra said, ‘Venerable One, when the hellish cankers become active, one does and one accumulates actions which. should be renumerated by hell.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāmāyuṣman kāyavāṅmanovaṅkānāṃ kāyavāṅmanodoṣakaṣāyāṇā narakeṣu rūpaṃ saṃjñā vedanā saṃskāro vijñānaṃ vipāko vipacyate /
column2: These action of the body, voice, and mind, torturous, corrupted, ‘tainted’ action have for retribution rupa, vedana, samjna, samskaras and vijnana in hell.

Does your reasoning apply to the intermediate existence which would then be a realm of rebirth?

” Now the intermediate existence begins in the place where death has taken place.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirvṛtte vīpāka ityuktaḥ natu vipāka eveti /
column2: it does not say that the realm of rebirth is part retribution, part non-retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhyaktaṃ “tatrāyuṣmannārako nopalabhyate 'nyatra tebhyo dharmebhya” iti / gatigāminaḥ pudgaladravyasya pratiṣedhaṃ karoti nānyatra skandhebhya upalabhyate nāraka iti na tu skandhāntarapratiṣedham /
column2: The text says that there does not exist any being in hell outside of these dharmas, rāpa, etc. its intention is to negate the reality of any person passing from one realm of rebirth into another, not to affirm that the s&andhas of the beings in hell are solely retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avyākṛtā eva tu gatayo varṇyante vaibhāṣikaiḥ /
column2: For the Vaibhāṣīkas, the realms of rebirth are exclusively undefiledneutral dharmas.
Among the Vaibhāṣikas, some think that they are.
In the three Dhātus with their five realms of rebirth, there is, in ascending order, Seven abodes or types of consciousnesses, namely: beings different in bodies and ideas;
beings of different bodies but similar in ideas;
beings similar in body but different in ideas;
beings similar in body and ideas; and three classes of non-material beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtre uktaḥ “rupiṇaḥ santi sattvā nānātvakāyā nānātvasaṃjñinastadyathāmanuṣyāstadekatyāśca devāḥ / iyaṃ prathamā vijñānasthitiḥ /
