prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yuvāntyasyāṃ sattvā miśrībhavanti prasavasāmyāditi yoniḥ / aṇḍajā yoniḥ katamā /
column2: in bitth—birth being common to all creatures—beings are mixed together in confusion.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye sattvā aṇḍebhyo jāyante / tadyathā haṃsakroñcacakravākamayūraśūkaśārikādayaḥ / jarāyujā yoiḥ katamā / ye sattvā jarāyorjāyante / tadyathā hastyaśvagomahiṣakharavarāhādayaḥ / saṃsvedajā yoniḥ katamā / ye sattvā bhūsaṃsvedājjāyante /
column2: Womb of beings born from eggs are those beings who arise from eggs, geese, cranes, peacocks, paṟrots, thrushes, etc. "Womb of beings born from wombs" are those beings who arise from a womb, elephants, horses, cows, buffalos, asses, pigs, etc. "Wombs of beings born from moisture" are those beings who arise.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā kṛmikīṭapataṅgamaśakādayaḥ / upapādukā yoniḥ katamā / ye sattvā avikalā ahīnendriyāḥ sarvāṅgapratyaṅgopetāḥ sakṛdupajāyante / ata eva upapadane (read: upapādane)
column2: “Womb of apparitional beings” are beings who arise all at once, with their organs neither lacking nor deficient, with all their major and minor limbs.
These are called wupapāduka, apparitional, because they are skillful at appearing, and because they arise all at once;
such as gods, beings in hell, or beings in an intermediate existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kasyāṃ gatau kati yonayaḥ saṃvidyanta ityāha
column2: How are the wombs distributed among the realms of rebirth?
Humans and animals are of the four types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṇḍajāstāvadyathā kroñcīniryātau śailopaśailau sthavirau mṛgāramātuśca dvātriṃśat putrāḥ pañcālarājasya ca pañca putraśatāni / jarāyujā yathedānīm /
column2: Humans can be born from an egg, such as Śaila and Upaśaila who were born from the eggs of a ctane; the thirty-two sons of, the mother of Mrgāra; and the five hundred sons of the King of Pañcāla.
Humans can be born from moisture, such as Māṇḍhātar, Cāru Upācaru, Kapotamalinī, Ānṛapālī, etc. Apparitional humans are humans at the beginning of the cosmic period.
Animals are also of four types.
These types are known through common experience.
Nāgas and Garuḍas are also apparitional.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: antarābhavadevāśca sarve nārakā antarābhavikāḥ devāścopapādukā eva /
column2: Beings in hell, intermediate beings, and the gods are apparitional too. These three classes of beings are exclusively apparitional.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pretā api jarāyujāḥ // apiśabdādapyupapādukā iti / āyuṣmate mahāmaudgalyāyanāya pretī nivedayate
column2: Pretas are also born from a womb. They are of two types, apparitional and born from a womb.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “pañca putrānahaṃ rātrau divā paña tathā parān / bhakṣayāmi janitvā tān nāsti tṛptistathāpi me //“
column2: That they are born from a womb results from a discourse that a Pretī had with Maudgalyāyana, “I gave birth to five sons a night, to five sons a day:Iate them and was not satisfied.
” What is the best womb?
The apparitional womb. But the Bodhisattva in his last birth evidently possesses “mastery relating to arising”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kimarthaṃ caramabhaviko bodhisattvaḥ prāptopapattivaśitve 'pi jarāyurjāṃ yorni bhajate /
column2: Why did he then choose to be born from a womb? There are two answers to this question.
The Bodhisattva sees great advantage in it: by reason of their relationship with hirn, the great Śūākya clan enters into the Good Law;
and, recognizing in him a member of the family of the Cakravartins, persons experience a great respect towards him;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cānyeṣāṃ bahumānādarāvarjanārthaṃ manuṣyabhūtā api caināṃ siddhiṃ gacchantīti vineyānā mutsāhārtham /
column2: persons are encouraged seeing that, being a man, he has realized this perfection. If the Bodhisattva were not born from the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itarathā hyaprajñāyamānakulagotraḥ ko 'pyayaṃ māyāpuruṣa ityevaṃ parikalpayeyurdevaḥ
column2: we would not know his family, and persons would say, “What is this magician, a god or a Piśāca?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: piśāca iti vā yathā 'nyatīrthyā apabhāṣante kalpaśatasyātyayādevaṃvidho māyāvī loke prādurbhūya māyayā lokaṃ bhakṣayatīti /
column2: ” In fact non-Buddhists masters calumniously say that at the end of one hundred cosmic periods there would appear in the world such a magician who devours the world through his magic.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apare tvāhuḥ / śarīradhātūnāmavasthāpanārthaṃ yeṣumanuṣyā anye ca prajāṃ vijñāya sahasraśaḥ svargaṃ
column2: Others explain that the Bodhisattva has taken up the womb in order that his body remains as relics after his Nirvāṇa: through the adoration of these relics, humans and other creatures by the thousands obtain heaven and deliverance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ca prāptā apavargaṃ ceti upapādukānāṃ hi sattvānāṃ bāhyabījābhāvān mṛtānāṃ kāyo nāvatiṣṭhate niśānta iva tailapradyoto 'ntardhīyate /
column2: In fact, the bodies of apparitional beings, not having any external seed, do not continue to exist after their deaths, like a flame which disappears without remnant.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ādhiṣṭhānikīmṛddhiṃ bhagavata icchatāṃ na yukta ekṣa parihāraḥ /
column2: But we see indeed that this explanation cannot be admitted by the masters who attribute rádhi ādhiṣṭhānikī to the Buddha.
One question arises from another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyapyupapādukānāṃ kāyanidhanaṃ na prajñayate kathamuktaṃ sūtre “upapādukaḥ suparṇī upapādukaṃ nāgamuddharati bhakṣārthami“ti /
column2: If the bodies of apparitional beings disappear at their deaths, how can the Sūtra say, “The apparitional Garuḍa seizes the apparitional Nāga in order to eat it?
”The text says that he seizes the Nāga in order to eat it, not that he does eat it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhakṣayati vā yāvanna mṛto bhavati na pounrmṛtasyāsya tṛṣyatīti /
column2: Or rather he eats the Nāga as long as the Nāga is not dead: but he does not feast on the dead Nāga.
What is the least desirable of the wombs?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sā hi dvigatī tisṛṇāṃ ca pradeśaḥ sarve cāntarābhāvikā iti /
column2: The apparitional womb, for it embraces all hellish realms of rebirth, all heavenly realms of rebirth, plus one part of the three other realms of rebirth, plus intermediate beings.
What is an intermediate being, and an intermediate existence?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: maraṇabhavasyopapattibhavasya cāntarā ya ātmabhāvo 'bhinirvarttate deśāntaropapattisamprāptaye so 'ntarābhava ityucyate /
column2: Intermediate existence, which inserts itself between existence at death and existence at birth, not having arrived at the location where it should go, cannot be said to be born. Between death—that is, the five rkandhas of the moment of death—and arising—that is, the five skaṉdhas of the moment of rebirth—there is found an existence—a “body” of five seandhas—that goes to the place of rebirth.
This existence between two realms of rebirth is called intermediate existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamayaṃ jātaśca nāma nacopapanno bhavati / gamyadeśānupetatvānnopapanno 'ntarābhavaḥ //
column2: ‘This existence is produced: why not say that it arises ;
We say that it is arising;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: padergatyarthatvāt / nacāyaṃ gamyadeśamupagatontarābhavastasmānnopapannaḥ / kaḥ punarasau deśo gantavyaḥ /
column2: but it is not born.

In fact, as its etymology indicates, to be born is to arrive. Intermediate existence, when it begins, has not arrived at the place where it should go, namely to the place where the retribution of actions is manifested and achieved.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vicchinna evopapattibhavo maraṇabhavātsaṃbhavatīti nikāyāntarīyāḥ / tadetanneṣyate / kiṃ kāraṇam / yuktitaśca āgamataśca / tatra tāvat yuktiṃ niśrityocyate /
column2: According to other sects, there is a cutting off, a discontinuity between death and birth: but there is no intermediate existence. This opinion is false, as reasoning and Scripture prove.
Being similar to the series of rice, existence does not reproduce itself after having been interrupted. The momentary dharmas exist in a series;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santānavarttināṃ hi dharmāṇāmavicchedena deśāntareṣu prādurbhāvo dṛṣṭastadyathā vrīhisantānasya /
column2: when they appear in a place distant from that in which they have been found, it is because they are reproduced without discontinuity in intermediate places, such as the series that constitutes a grain of rice and which one transports to a distant village by passing through all the villages in the interval.
In the same way, the mental series takes up birth after being reproduced.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vicchinno 'pi dṛṣṭaḥ prādurbhāvastadyathā ādarśādiṣu bimbāt pratibimbasya /
column2: But, one would say, a reflection arises on a mirror, on the water, etc. , without being continuous to the image with which it forms a series.
Hence the elements of arising do not depend on the elements forming an uninterrupted series between the place of death and the place where they reappear.
The existence of the reflection is not proved; should it be proved, the reflection is not similar; hence it does not serve as an example.
A reflection is a thing in and of itself, namely a certain type of color.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: siddhāvapi ca satyāmasāmyādanidarśanaṃ bhavati / kathaṃ tāvadasiddham /
column2: The existence of the reflection is not proved.
For two things do not exist in the same spot.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatraiva hi deśe ādarśarūpaṃ dṛśyate pratibimbaṃ ca /
column2: In one and the same spot, a person placed to the side of a mirror perceives the r%pa or physical matter of this mirror, matter derived from the primary elements; a person placed facing (the mirror) perceives his own reflection, which is a “certain type of color,” derived matter. Now one can admit only that two derived matters exist.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na caikatra deśe rūpadvayasyāsti sahabhāva āśrayabhūtabhedāt /
column2: at the same time in the same spot, for each of them should have as its support two distinct groups of primary elements.
Two persons who both look at the same object, a jar, etc. , see it at the same time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: 'nyaṃ pratibimbakamupalabhyate natvekatra rūpe dvayoḥ paśyatoḥ sahadarśanaṃ na bhavatīti na tatra rūpāntaropapattiryuktā /
column2: Now two persons placed at the two sides of a pond see the reflection of the object that faces them: the same reflection is not seen at the same time by both of them.
Shade and sunlight do not coexist in the same spot.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upalabhyate ca chāyāstha ādarśe sūryasya prativimbakamiti na yukto 'sya tatra prādurbhāvaḥ /
column2: Now, if one places a mirror in the shade, in a shed situated close to a pond lit by the sun, one would see in this mirror the reflection of the reflection of the sun on the surface of the water. It is thus proved, by these three observations, that a reflection is not a real, substantial thing. The Kārikā is iable to another interpretation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athavā “sahaikatra dvayābhāvādi“ti katamasya dvayasya / ādarśatalasyendupratibimbakasya ca /
column2: “For the two things do not exist in the same spot”: the “two things” are the surface of the mirror and the reflection of the moon.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyatraiva hi deśe ādarśatalaṃ bhavatyanyatraivāntargataṃ candrapratibimbakaṃ dṛśyate kūpa ivodakam /
column2: We do not see, in the same spot, the surface of the mirror and the reflection of the moon, reflected in the. This reflection appears recessed, at a depth, like the water in a well.
Now if a real physical matter, the reflection, should arise, it would arise on the surface of the mirror, and would be perceived as being on the surface of the mirror.
A reflection is thus only an illusory idea taking the form of the reflection (pratikimbākāraṁ bhrāntaṁ vijñānam).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sāmagryāstu sa tasyāstādṛśaḥ prabhāvo yattathā darśanaṃ bhavati //
column2: Such is the power of this complex, mirror and object, that it produces the seeing of a reflection, of an image resembling the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: acintyo hi dharmāṇāṃ hi dharmāṇāṃ śaktibhedaḥ /
column2: Incomprehensible is the power of the dharmas and the variety of this power. Let us admit nevertheless the real existence of the reflection.
It still cannot serve as an example in your reasoning, for it cannot be compared to arising.
It is not similar to arising.
For it does not form a series.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi vimvasya pratibimbakaṃ santānabhūtamādarśasantānasaṃvaddhatvāt sahabhāvācca / yathā maraṇasyopapattibhavaḥ / santānaṃ ca pratyavicchedena deśāntareṣu prādurbhāva udāhṛato nāsantānamityasāmyaṃ dṛṣṭāntasya pratibimbasya ca /
column2: The reflection does not form a series with the object reflected, because the reflection arises supported by the mirror, and because the reflection is simultaneous to the object reflected.
But on the contrary. For it arises from two causes.
It is by reason of two causes that a reflection arises, by reason of the mirror and of the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bimbāccādarśā cceti yat prādhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ tadāśrityotpadyate /
column2: The principal of these two causes is the cause upon which it takes its support in order to arise, namely the mirror. But it happens that arising, or birth, proceeds from only one cause;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nacaivamupapattibhavasyāpi dvābhyāṃ kāraṇābhyāṃ saṃbhavo maraṇabhavāccānyataśca pradhānabhūtādityato 'pyayamasamāno dṛṣṭāntaḥ /
column2: and it never has a principal cause which is not death. Arising has no external support in the case of apparitional beings, because they appear suddenly in space.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca yuktamuktaṃ bāhyameva cetanaṃ śukraśoṇitaṃ pradhānakāraṇamiti / yatra cāndhakāṇa eva prādurbhāva upapādukānāṃ tatra kiṃ parikalpyate /
column2: And these external elements cannot be the principal cause for the beings that arise from semen, blood, or mud, since these items are absent from the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tāvadyuktito neṣyate / na marāṇabhavādvicchinna upapattibhavaprādurbhāvaḥ /
column2: Reasoning thus proves the existence of an intermediate being since arising proceeds from death without there being any discontinuity between these two existences. Scripture also proves the existence of an intermediate being.
The intermediate being is called by its name.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaṇṭhokteścāsti sūtra uktaṃ “sapta bhavāḥ / narakabhavastiryagbhavaḥ pretabhavo devabhavo manuṣyabhavaḥ karmabhavo 'ntarābhava iti /
column2: The Sūtra says, “There are seven existences : existence in hell, as an animal, as a Preta, as a heavenly being, and as a human, as well as karmabhava and antarābhava.”
If the school that we are combating does not read this Sūtra, at least they read the texts pertaining to Gandharvas.
It is the Gandhaṭva.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “trayāṇāṃ sthānānāṃ saṃmukhībhāvāt mātuḥ kukṣau garbhasyāvakrāntirbhavati / mātā kalyā spi bhavati ṛtumatī ca / mātāpitarau raktau bhavataḥ sanipatitau ca /
column2: We read in the Sūtra, “Three conditions are necessary for an embryo to descend: the woman must be in good health and fertile, the pair must be united, and a Gandharva must be ready.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gandharvaśca pratyupasthito bhātī“ti / antarābhavaṃ hitvā ko 'nyo gandharvaḥ /
column2: What is the Gandharva if not an intermediate being?
But our opponents do not read the Sūtra in these terms!
They replace the third condition by a text that says, “a dissolution of the ṣkandhas must be made ready.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyevamāśvalāyanasūtraṃ kathaṃ nīyate / “jānanta bhavanto yo 'sau gandharvaḥ pratyupasthitaḥ / kṣatriyo vā 'sau brāhmaṇo vā vaiśyo vā śūdro vā /
column2: Very well, but one doubts if they could explain the Āśva’āyanasāṭra, which says, “This Gandharva which is made ready,—do you know if it is a Brahmin, a Kṣatriya, a Vaiśya, or a Śūdra?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi vā pūrvasyā diśa āgato yadi vā dakṣiṇasyā paścimāyā uttrasyā” iti / nahi skandhabhedasyāgamanaṃ yujyate / athaitadapi na paṭhacyate / itastarhi /
column2: Do you know if it comes from the east, the south, the west, or the north?
” ‘ThisAn intermediate being is proved by the text relative to the Five.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “pañcānāgāmina” ityuktaṃ bhagavatā / antarāparinirvāyī upapadyaparinirvāyī anabhisaṃskāraparinirvāyī sābhisaṃskāraparinirvāyī ūrdhvastrotāśceti / asatyantarābhave kathamantarāparinirvāyī nāma syāt /
column2: The Blessed One teaches that there are five types of Anāgāmins: one who obtains Nirvāṇa in an intermediate existence, one who obtains Nirvāṇa as soon as he is reborn, one who obtains Nirvāṇa without effort, one who obtains Nirvāṇa by means of effort, and one who obtains Nirvāṇa by going higher.
Certain masters maintain that an antarāparinirvāy⁸n is a saint who obtains Nirvāṇa after having been reborn among some so-called Antara gods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upapadyādayo 'pi hi nāma devā evaṃ sati prasajyate / tasmānyeyaṃ kalpanā sādhvī / itaśca
column2: But they should then admit the existence of Upapadya gods, etc. An absurd opinion.
Abṇd by the Sūtra of the gat⁴s.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “sapta satpuruṣagatayaḥ” ityatra sūtre / antarāparinirvāyiṇastraya uktāḥ / kāladeśaprakarṣabhedena / tadyathā parīttaḥ sakalikāgnirabhinivarttamāna eva parinirvāyādevaṃ prathamaḥ / tadyathā 'yaḥ prapāṭikā utpatantyeva nirvāyādevaṃ dvitīyaḥ / tadyathā 'yaḥprapātikā utplutya pṛthivyāmapatitaiva nirvāyādevaṃ tṛtīyaḥ /
column2: By the Sūtra of the Seven Sa²puruṣagatis.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nacaivamantarā nāma devāstriprakārāḥ kāladeśaprakarṣabhinnāḥ santīti kalpanaiveyaṃ kevalā //
column2: This Sūtra teaches that one should distinguish three types of antarāparinirvāyins on the basis of their differences of duration and place: the first is similar to a spark thatGiven this text, it is pure fantasy to suppose that an antarāparinirvāyiṉ is an inhabitant of a heaven of the Antara gods, for these Antaras cannot be divided into three classes by reason of duration and place.
But yet other scholars—present the explanation here.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āyupramāṇāntare vā devasamīpāntare vā yaḥ kleśān prajahāti so 'ntarāparinirvāyī /
column2: An antarāparinirvāyin obtains Nirvāṇa, that is, eliminates the defilements, either in the interval of his lifetime, or in the interval of his cohabitation with the gods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa punardhātugato vā parinirvāti saṃjñāgato vā vitarkagato vā /
column2: He is threefold: he is termeda dhārngata if he obtains Nirvāṇa having just arrived in the Dhātu;

he is called a sajñāgata if he obtains Nirvāṇa later, at aIn this way we would have three entarāparinirvāyins conforming to the definitions of the Sūtra and who obtain Nirvāṇa in the interval of the duration of their life, that is, withoutachieving the end of their life as gods of the heaven where they were reborn.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamo vā rūpadhātau nikāyasabhāgaparigrahaṃ kṛtvā parinirvāti /
column2: Or rather, the first antarāparinirvāyén obtains Nirvāṇa as soon as he has taken possession of a certain divine existence;
the second after having experienced a heavenly bliss;

and the third, after having entered into company or conversation with the gods. An objection: if an antarāparinirvāyiṉ is a saint who is reborn, experiences bliss,and enters into the company of the gods, what will an upapadhypariṅirvāyén be, liteṟally “one who obtains Nirvāna as soon as he is reborn?”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upapadyaparinirvāyī punaḥ prakarṣayuktāṃ saṃgītimanupraviśya parinirvāti bhūyasā vā āyurūpahatya nopapannamātra eveti ta ete sarve 'pi śakalikādidṛṣṭāntairna saṃvadhyante / deśagativiśeṣābhāvāt /
column2: We answer that an wpapadyaparinirvāyin enters entirely into theirBut we must observe that all these persons, the dhātugata, etc. , go to the same place. Thus they do not correspond to the examples of the Sūtra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārupyeṣvapi cāntarāparinirvāyī paṭhyetāyuḥpramāṇāntare parinirvāṇāt / na ca paṭhyate /
column2: On the other hand, there are saints in Ārūpyadhātu who obtain Nirvāṇa without having fully lived their lives to the end, and yet no antarāparinirvāyins are there.
This point is illustrated in the metrical formula, By the dhyānas, four decades; by the ārāpyas, three heptades;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃjñayā ṣaṭṭikāṃ kṛtvā vargo bhavati samuditaḥ // ityetasyāyurdānagāthāyām / tasmādetadapi sarvaṃ kalpanāmātram /
column2: by ideas, one hexade: thus is the group bound.
Yet if our adversaries do not read this Sūtra, what can we do about it? The Master has entered Nirvāṇa, and the Good Law no longer has a leader.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kimidānīṃ kurmo yacchāstā ca parinirvṛtaḥ śāsanaṃ cedamanāyakaṃ bahudhā bhinnaṃ bhidyate cādyāpi yathecchaṃ granthataścārthataśca /
column2: Many sects have been formed that change the meaning and the letter to their fantasies.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yeṣāṃ tu tāvadayamāgamaḥ pramāṇaṃ teṣāmāgamato 'pi siddho 'ntarābhavaḥ /
column2: We say that, for the masters who admit these Sūtras, the existence of an intermediate being or the “shanāáhas in theinterval is proved both by Scripture and reasoning. Yet there are some difficulties: a. We must reconcile the doctrine of an intermediate being with the Sūtra on Māra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi sūtra uttam “atha ca punardūṣī māraḥ svaśarīreṇāvicau mahānarake prapatita” iti / tat kathamiti / sa hi jīvanneva nārakībhirjvālābhirāliṅgitaḥ / kālalṃ kṛtvā 'ntarābhavenāvīciṃ prāpta ityayaṃ tatrābhiprayaḥ /
column2: This Sūtra says, “The Māra called Dūṣin, fell, with his own body, into great Avīci Hell.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atyudīrṇaparipūrṇāni hi karmāṇi kāyasya nikṣepaṃ na pratīkṣante /
column2: ” Actions very grave and complete ripen before death itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato 'sya dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ karma pūrvaṃ vīpakvaṃ paścādupapadyavedanīyamiti /
column2: Māra then felt a retribution in this life before feeling a retribution in hell The text thus means that Māra was enveloped, while still alive, by the fires of hell, that he dies;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idamidānīṃ kathaṃ nīyate “pañcānantaryāṇi karmāṇi yāni kṛtvopacitya samanantaraṃ narakeṣūpapadyata” iti /
column2: and that he then takes up an intermediate existence which leads to hell where birth in hell takes place. According to the Sūtra, there are five ānaniarya transgressions:he who commits them is immediately born in hell.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyāṃ gatimagatvetyabhiprāyaḥ / upapadyavedanīyatvaṃ tatra karmaṇo dyotitam / atha yathārutaṃ kalpyate /
column2: We hold that the expression "immediately” signifies “without intermediary,” without passing through another realm of rebirth which is an action “retributable in the next.

column2: If you take the Sūtra literally, you come to absurd conclusions: you would have to say that one must have committed the five crimes in order to be reborn in hell and you would have to say that the transgressor is reborn in hell immediately after the transgression, or that he is reborn there without dying here.
Moreover, according to our doctrine, rebirth in hell is immediate; it is not preceded by a “birth” as an intermediate being.
We maintain that, by its nature, the intermediate being is “arising’ because he is turned towards the birth that follows death;

There is then in activity concupiscence relative to the objects of desire, visible things, etc. , and sexual union.
Upādāna or attachmeṉnt is the state of one who runs around in search of the pleasures.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasyāmavasthāyāṃ viṣayaprāptaye paryeṣṭimāpannaḥ sarvato dhāvatyasāvavasthā upādānamityucyate /
column2: One runs everywhere in order to acquire these pleasures.
Running around in this manner.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa bhaviṣyat bhavaphalaṃ kurute karma tat bhavaḥ / sa viṣayāṇāṃ prāptihetoḥ paridhāvan paunarbhavikaṃ karmopacinoti so 'sya bhavaḥ /
column2: He does actions which will have for their result future existence: this is bhava.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tena hi karmaṇā punaritaḥ pracyutasyāyatyāṃ pratisaṃdhirbhavati / yo 'sau
column2: Action done and accumulated in the search for pleasures will produce reexistence. The period during which one does this action constitutes bhava.
Jāti is the new reincarnation.
The “part” that receives the name of consciousness in a present existence is called 7ā:i in a future existence.
Old age-and-death lasts until sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jāteḥ pareṇa yāvadedanāvasthā jarāmaraṇam / yānyeveha catvāryaṅgāni nāmarūpaṣaḍāyatanasparśavedanāstānyevānyatra jarāmaraṇamityetāni dvādaśāṅgāni /
column2: From jāt until sensation, there are four parts of the present existence, māmarñpa, the sīx āyatana, contact and sensation which are, in a future existence designated by the expression old age and death, the twelfth part of this twelvefold series.
It is also said that pratāyasamutpāda is fourfold: momentary or of one moment;

prolonged (prākarṣika: extending over many moments of many existences); serial (śṁbandhika, through the union of causes and effects); and static (āvas¢hika: embracing twelve states, or periods, of the five skandhas).
How is pratīyasamupāda momentary?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekasmin khalvapi kṣaṇe dvādaśāṅgāni bhavanti / tadyathā lobhavaśena prāṇinaṃ jīvitād vyaparopayet /
column2: When a person in prey to the defilements commits murder, the twelve parts are realized in one and the same moment.
His 20b4 is ignorance;
his "volition" are the saṁskāras;
his distinct consciousness of a certain object is consciousness;
the four sáandhas coexisting with the consciousness is nāmarāpa;
theoṟgans in relation to nāmarūpa are the six āāyataṉas;
the application of the six āyatanas is contact;
to experience.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo lobhaḥ sa tṛṣṇā / tatsaṃprayuktāni paryavasthānāni upādānam /
column2: the paryavasthānas associated with thirst are attachment.
bodily or vocal action that proceeds is bhava.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ dharmāṇāmutsarjanaṃ jātiḥ parīpāko jarā bhaṅgo maraṇamiti / punarāhuḥ /
column2: the emergence of all these dharmas is jāti. their maturity is old age; and their rupture is death.

It is also said that pratāyasamutpāda is both momentary and serial at the same time. The Prakaraṇa says, "What is pratāyasamutpāda? All the conditioned dharmas. What are the dharmas produced through dependence?
All the conditioned dharmas.
Static pratītyasamutpādas made up of the twelve states embracing the five skandhas.
It is also prolonged, extending itself over three consecutive existences.

Among these four, what is the type of pratītyasamutpāda that the Blessed One has here—in the Śūéra of the Twelve Parts—the intention to teach? According to the School, it is static pratīyasamutpāda. According to the School the Blessed One distinguishes the twelve parts only with respect to static pratīyasamuṭpāda.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āvasthikaḥ kileṣṭo 'yaṃ yadyaṅgamaṅgaṃ pañca skandhāḥ kiṃ kāraṇamavidyādīneva dharmān kīrttayati sma / prādhānyattvaṅgakīrtanam / avidyāpradhānāmavasthāmavidyāṃ jagāda saṃskārapradhānāṃ saṃskārānyāvajjarāmaraṇamityadoṣaḥ / kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ sūtre dvādaśāṅga uktaḥ prakaraṇeṣvanyathā “pratītyasamutpādaḥ katamaḥ / sarve saṃskṛtā dharmā” iti /
column2: But if each of the parts is a complex of the five skandhas, why use the designations “ignorance,” etc. ?

Because the Sutra expresses itself in an intentional manner, whereas the Abhidharma teaches the characteristics of things. On the one hand pratīyasanapāda is given as static, prolonged, and pertaining to living beings;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathāvasthikaḥ kṣaṇikaḥ prākarṣikaḥ sāṃbandhikaḥ sattvākhyo 'sattvākhyaśceti bhedaḥ /
column2: and on the other hand, as momentary, serial, and pertaining to both living and non-living beings.
Why does the Sutra teach pratūyasamutpāda as only pertaining to living beings?
In order to have aberration cease with regard to the past, the future, and the interval in between.
And it is for this same reason that it teaches apratīyasamutpāda in three sections.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra pūrvāntasaṃmoho yata iyaṃ vicikitsā kiṃ nva hamabhūvamatīte 'dhvani āhosvinnābhūvaṃ ko nvahamabhūvaṃ kathaṃ nvahamabhūvamiti / aparāntasaṃmoho yata iyaṃ vicicitsā kiṃ nu bhaviṣyāmyanāgate 'dhvanīti vistaraḥ /
column2: Ignorance or aberration relating to the past, as when one asks, “Did I exist or not exist in the past? How and as what did I exist?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: madhyasaṃmoho yata iyaṃ vicikitsā kimsvididaṃ ke santaḥ ke bhaviṣyāma iti /
column2: ” Relating to the future: “Will I exist in the future? ” Relating to the interval in between: “What is this? How is this? What are we? What will we be?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etasya trividhasya saṃmohasya vyāvarttanārthaṃ sattvākhya eva trikāṇḍaśca pratītyasamutpāda
column2: ” This threefold aberration is destroyed by the teaching of the.

column2: For its is said in the Sūtra, “Whoever, Oh Bhikṣus, knows, through prajñā, praūyasamutpāda aṇd the dharmas produced through dependence, will not turn himself towards the past by asking if he existed.”

According to others, the last three terms of the middle section, —thirst, attachment, and bhava,—are also taught in order to cause aberration relating to the future to cease; for they are the causes of future existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyaiva hyete hetava iti sa punareṣa dvādaśāṅgaḥ pratītyasamutpādastrisvabhāvo veditavyaḥ / kleśakarmavastūni / tatra kleśāstrīṇi
column2: This twelvefold pratīyasamu$pāda is also threefold, defilement, action, and foundation; it is twofold, cause and result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trīṇyaṅgāni kleśasvabhāvānyavidyātṛṣṇepādānāni / dvayaṃ karma aṅgadvayaṃ karmasvabhāvaṃ saṃskārā bhavaśca /
column2: Three parts are defilement, two are action;
seven are foundation and also result. Ignorance, thirst, and attachment are, by their nature, defilements; the sanṁskāras and bhava are action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saptāṅgāni vastusvabhāvāni vijñānanāmarūpaṣaḍāyatanasparśavedanājātijarāmaraṇāni / kleśakarmāśrayatvāt / yathā ca vastu saptāṅgāni
column2: consciousness, nāmarpa, the six āyatana, conṇtact, sensation, ār², and old age and death are foundation, so called because they are the support of the defilements and action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phalaṃ tathā / saptaivāṅgāni phābhūtāni / śeṣāṇi pañca hetubhūtāni /
column2: The parts that are foundation are result: the five.
That are not foundation are cause, being both defilement and action in nature.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ madhye phalahetū viśālitau / vastunaḥ pañcadhā bhedāt / kleśasya dvidhā /
column2: Why are cause and result taught at length in the section of present existence—two parts of defilement, two parts of action, five parts of foundation—whereas, a similar exposition is absent for the past and future?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgate 'dhvani phalaṃ saṃkṣiptaṃ dvidhā bhedāt / atīte 'dhvani heturekamukhakleśopadeśāditi /
column2: In the future, one has two parts for result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phalahetvabhisaṃkṣepo dvayormadhyānumānataḥ // madhyenaiva hi pūrvāntāparāntayorapi hetuphalavistaraḥ śakyo 'numānumiti noktaḥ /
column2: In two sections, cause and result are abbreviated, for one can infer them from the teaching of the middle. From the teaching of the defilements, action and foundation, relating to present existence, one can deduce the complete exposition of cause and result in past and future existences.
All useless descriptions should be omitted.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi khalu dvādaśāṅga eva pratītyasamutpāda evaṃ satyavidyāyā anupadiṣṭahetukatvādādimān saṃsāraḥ prāpnoti jarāmaraṇasya cānupadiṣṭaphalatvādantavān
column2: But if pratītyasamutpāda has only twelve parts, transmigration would have a beginning, since the cause of ignorance is not indicated; and it would have an end, since the result of old age and death is not indicated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṅgāntaraṃ vā punarupasaṃkhyātavyaṃ tasyāpyanyasmāditya navasthāprasaṅgaḥ / nopasaṃkhyātavyam /
column2: Thus one must add new parts, and to infinity.
No, for the Blessed One has implicitly indicated the cause of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kleśāt kleśaḥ kriyā caiva tato vastu tataḥ punaḥ /
column2: From defilement there arises defilement and action; from whence foundation;
from whence a new foundation and defilement: such is the manner of existence of the parts of existence or bhavāṇgas.
Defilement arises from defilement, as attachment arises from desire.
Action arises from defilement,as consciousness from attachment, or the saṁskārar from ignorance.
A foundation arises from action, as vrñāṇa from the sa? skāras, or birth from existence. A foundation arises from a foundation, as māmarāpa from consciousness; the six āyatanas from nāṃarūpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vastuno vastuvijñānānāmarūpaṃ yāvat sparśādvedanā jāteśca jarāmaraṇam /
column2: sensation from contact, or old age and death from birth.
Defilement arises from a foundation, as desire from sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmādeṣa nayo vyavasthito bhavāṅgānāṃ tasmādavidyā 'pi kleśasvabhāvā vastunaḥ kleśādveti jñāpitaṃ bhavati /
column2: Since such is the manner of existence of the various parts of dependent orgination it is clear that ignorance has either adefilement or a foundation for its cause;

column2: it is clear that old age and death (=the rest of the foundation from consciousness to sensation, above, p. 404, line 6, has)Thus the teaching is complete.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “evamasya kevalasya mahato duḥkhaskandhasya samudayo bhavatī“ti vacanāt /
column2: That the Blessed One wanted to illustrate this manner of existence of the parts results from the conclusion of the Śūtra, “Thus there takes place the production of this great mass which is nothing but suffering.”
But there is another explanation:

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ayoniśomanaskārahetukā 'vidyoktā sūtrāntare / avidyāhetukaścāyoniśomanaskāraḥ / sa cehāpyupādānāntarbhūtatvādukto bhavatīti apare /

Consequently ignorance is not without a cause and one avoids the objection of infinite regression. But incorrect judgment is not named in the Sūtra in question, the Pratīṭyasamutpādasūtra. Without doubt; but it is included in attachment: thus one does not have to separately name it here. This explanation is without value.
How is incorrect judgment included in attachment?
Indeed, it is associated with attachment, but it can as equally well be associated with ignorance or with desire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satyapi cāntarbhāve kathamatredaṃ jñāpitaṃ bhavatyayoniśomanaskārahetukā avidyeti /
column2: Let us admit that it may be included in attachment, but caṉIn other words, I indeed hold that incorrect judgment is included in attachment; but it does not follow that the Sūtra could dispense with terming it a separate part, the cause of ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tarhyantarbhāvenaiva hetuphalabhāvo vijñāyate tṛṣṇā 'vidyayorapi tarhi tatrāntarbhāvā daṅgantaratvaṃ śakyamakarttum /
column2: One could just as well omit ignorance and desire.
Another master speaks next.
A Śūtra teaches that ignorance has incorrect judgment for its cause.

column2: A Sūtra teaches that incorrect judgment has ignorance for its cause and observes that it is produced at the moment of contact, "By reason of the eye and a visible thing there is produced a defiled judgment which arises from error.

column2: A Sūtra explains the origin of desire, Desire arises by reason of a sensation which itself arose from a contact wherein there is ignorance.

atra tu sautrāntikā vijñāpayanti / kiṃ khalvetā iṣṭaya ucyante yā yasyeṣṭirāhosvitsūtrārthaḥ /	The Sautrāntikas criticize: are these personal theses, fantasies, or the sense of the Sūtra?
sūtrārtha ityāha / yadi sūtrārtho naiṣa sūtrārthaḥ /	You say in vain that it is the sense of the Sūtra.
kathaṃ kṛtvā /	You.

As the Blessed One said in the Sarva, “What is attachment?
It is chandarāga.
” Because of attachment, accumulated action produces a new existence.
this is bbava.
The Sūtra says, “Ānanda, action that produces a new existence is the nature of bhava.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavapratyayaṃ punarvijñānāvakrāntiyogena / anāgataṃ janma jātiḥ pañcaskandhikā /

column2: ” This is also impossible, for an absence is not a thing and avśdyā must be a thing, since it is a cause.
Thus 28c-d.

column2: The non-friend is the opposite of a friend, not a non-friend, that is, anyone other than a friend, not the absence of the friend.

column2: Non-truth is speech contrary to true speech;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamavidyā 'pi vidyāyāḥ pratidvandvabhūtadharmāntaramiti draṣṭavyam / kuta etat /
column2: Thus avidya—"non-knowledge"—is the opposite of vidya, a real separate dharma.
The Sutra defines it as the cause of the sanskaras, from whence it results that it is not a mere negation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: api ca saṃyojanādivacanāt saṃyojanaṃ bandhanamanuśaya ogho yogaścāvidyocyate sūtreṣu /
column2: Further, the Sutra regards ignorance as a separate yoke, a bond, a latent defilement, a canker, a torrent or flood, and a yoke.
Thus ignorance cannot be a mere negation;
it cannot be everything that is not vidya, the eyes, etc. Yet the prefix "a"—the privative a—has a pejorative sense.
One terms a bad wife a "non-wife", and a bad son, a "non-son".
Should we not think then that vidya is bad vidya, that is, bad?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuprajñā cenna darśanāt / kutsitā hi prajña kliṣṭā /
column2: Avidya is not bad prajna, as it is not seeing.

column2: Bad prajna would be a type of seeing.

column2: Avidya is the defiled prajna which is not seeing by nature.
This is impossible because views are associated with ignorance. Moha, which is defined as avidya, is among the mahabhumi kleśas. All the mahabhumi kleśas are associated with them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avidyā cet prajñā 'bhaviṣyanna dṛṣṭistayā yujyate saṃprāyokṣyata /
column2: Thus avidya is associated with seeing which is prajna in nature.
Avidya is not prajna, for two items of prajna cannot be associated.
Ignorance is defined as a defilement of prajna.

column2: We have defined the sixfold contact, contact of the eye, etc. Six sensations arise from contact.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāsāṃ punaḥ pañca kāyikī caitasī parā / cakṣuḥśrotraghrāṇajihvākāyasaṃsparśajāḥ pañccavedanāḥ kāyikī vedanetyucyate / rūpīndriyāśritatvāt /
column2: The five sensations that arise from the contact of the eye and from the other bodily organs, having for support the bodily organs, are bodily.
The sixth sensation arises from contact with the zanas: its support is the mind so it is mental or cittasī.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kiṃ sparśāduttarakālaṃ vedanā bhavatyāhosvit samānakālam /
column2: Ask if the sensation is later than, or simultaneous to contact.
The Vaibhāṣikas maintain that sensation and contact are simultaneous, being sahabhūhetu, "reciprocal causes".
How can two things arisen together be "that which produces" and "that which is produced"?
Why would they not be?
When two things arise together, how could the dharma "which produces" have any efficacy with regard to the dharma "to be produced," which has already arisen?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadeva hīdaṃ sahotpannayorjanyajanakabhāvo nāstīti tadevedaṃ jāte dharme dharmasya nāstīti /
column2: This argument only repeats the thesis that two things arisen together cannot be "that which produces" and "that which is produced.
We would say then that, in your hypothesis, there would be reciprocal causality of two dharmas arisen together. But this is not a fault, for we admit this consequence.
We define suhabhāhetu as ye mithabphalāḥ, "The dharmas that are results of one other are a sahabhṁ cause. So be it, that is your system.
But the Sūtṛa condemns this system.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “cakṣuḥsaṃsparśa pratītya utpadyate cakṣuḥsaṃsparśajā vedanā na tu cakṣuḥpaṃsparśajāṃ vedanāṃ pratītyotpadyate cakṣuḥsaṃsparśa” iti vacanāt janakadharmātikramāvcāyuktam /
column2: It says, "By reason of the contact of the eye, there atises a sensation which arises from the contact of the eye; " it does not say, "By reason of the sensation which arises from the contact of the eye, the contact of the eye arises.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo hi dharmo yasya dharmasya janakaḥ prasiddhaḥ sa tasmāt bhinnakālaḥ prasiddhaḥ /
column2: And again the thesis that "Two things"It is taken for granted that the dharma which produces another dharma is not simultaneous to this other dharma: a seed precedes its shoot; milk precedes dadhi; a bbow precedes the noise;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā pūrvaṃ vījaṃ paścādaṅkuraḥ pūrvaṃ kṣīraṃ paścāddadhi pūrvamabhighātaḥ paścācchandaḥ pūrvaṃ manaḥ paścāt manovijñānamityevamādi / anyathā paraṃparāpekṣatvāt kāryakāraṇayoḥ sarvaṃ vā yugapadutpadyate na vā kadācit paścādviśeṣābhāvāt /
column2: and the znas precedes the mental consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi na siddhaḥ kāryakāraṇayoḥ pūrvāparābhāvaḥ / sahabhāvo 'pi tu siddhaḥ /
column2: We do not deny that a cause is sometimes earlier than its result; but we affirm that a cause and its result can be sirmultaneous: for ekample, the visual organ and color, and the visual consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā cakṣurvajñānādīnāṃ cakṣurūpādibhirbhūtabhautikānāṃ ca tatrāpi pūrvamindriyārthau paścādvijñānam /
column2: or the primmary elements and 'secondary matter. We do not admit your examples: the visual organ and color precede the visual consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvakācca bhūtabhautikasamudāyāduttara utpadyata itīṣyamāṇe kaḥ pratiṣedhaḥ //
column2: but the primary elements and derived matter, which are simultaneous, arise together from a complex of earlier causes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tarhi cchāyāṅkurayorevaṃ sparśavedanayo riti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas: Contact and sensation are simultaneous, like the shoot and its shade.
According to another opinion, : Sensation is later than contact.
There is first the organ and the object. The consciousness contact is the "coming together," that is, the quality of cause and result of these three: oṟgan and object, and consciousṉess;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'sau trayāṇāṃ saṃnipātaḥ sparśaḥ sparśapratyayātpaścādvedanā tṛtīyakṣaṇa iti /
column2: finally there arises sensation which has contact for its cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi na sarvantravajñāne vedanā prāpnoti na ca sarvaṃ vijñānaṃ sparśaḥ / naiṣa doṣaḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas: In this theory, there is no sensation wherever there is consciousness: for there is consciousness in the second and third moment, but sensation only in the third.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvasparśahetukā hyuttaratra sparśe vedanā sarve ca sparśāḥ sarvavedanakāḥ sarvaṃ ca vijñānaṃ sparśa iti / idamayuktaṃ varttate /
column2: And all consciousness is not contact, for there is contact only in the first two moments. One sensation, having for its cause an earlier contact, exists at the moment of a later contact: thus all contact is accompanied by sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kimatrāyuktam / yaduta bhinnālambanayorapi sparśayoḥ pūrvasparśaitukottarasya vedaneti /
column2: According to you, there would thus be simultaneous contact and a sensation of different objects: a sensation produced by earlier contact of color would exist at the moment of a second contact of sound.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ nāmānyajātīyālambanasparśasaṃbhūtā vedanā 'nyālambanā bhaviṣyati yena vā cittena saṃprayuktā tato bhinnālambaneti /
column2: Now a sensation produced by a contact of color should have this color for its object, for a sensation cannot have an object different from the object of the consciousness with which it is associated. Thus you are forced to an inadmissible conclusion.

Let us say then that consciousness is not always contact, and that it is not always accompanied by sensation. The consciousness of color, contemporaneous with the contact of sound, is not contact, but is accompanied by sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmācca yat pūrvaṃ vijñānaṃ savedanakaṃ tanna sparśaḥ / pratyayavaidhuryādityevaṃ sati ko doṣaḥ /
column2: The consciousness of the sound is contact, but it is not accompanied by sensation.
This theory is incompatible with the rule of the universal or mahābhñmika dharmas.
This rule establishes that ten dharmas,—sensation, contact, idea, etc—are associated with every mental state.
Upon what authority does this rule rest?
Oṉ the Śāstra or Abhidharma.
We recognize Sūtra and not Śāstra as authority.
For the Blessed One said that recourse is to the Śūtra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na vā eṣa mahābhūmikārthaḥ sarvatra citte daśa mahābhūmikāḥ saṃbhavantīti /
column2: Oṛ rather we propose for the doctrine of the ahābhūmikas an interpretation different from yours.
What then is the meaning of the expression ṁmahābhūmika?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tisro bhūmayaḥ / savitarkā savicārā bhumiḥ avitarkā vicāramātrā avitarkā vicārā bhūmiḥ punaśtisra kusalā bhūmiḥ akuśalā 'vyākṛtā bhumiḥ /
column2: There are three bhāmis or spheres, 1.
saviarkasavicāra: Kāmadhātu and the First Dhyāna, 2.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadya etasyāṃ sarvasyāṃ bhūmau bhavanti te mahābhūmikāḥ /
column2: gsvitarka-savicāra: theThe mental dharmas found in various bhāmis are called mahābhmika.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye kukśalāyāmeva te kukśalamahābhūmikāḥ / ye kliṣṭāyāmeva te kleśamahābhūmikāḥ /
column2: Those found only in a good bhṁūmi are called kuśalamahābhūmika, and those found only in a defiled bhūmi are called kleśamahābhūmika.
However, it is false that they are necessarily found all at once.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akuśalamahābhūmikāstu pāṭhaprasaṅge nāsañjitāḥ / idānīṃ pūrvaṃ na paṭhyante sma /
column2: Certain masters observe that the category of the akuśalamahābhūmikas has been added later. The Sūtras.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tarhi sparśāduttarakālalṃ vedanā sūtraṃ parihāryaṃ “cakṣuḥ pratītya rūpāṇi cotpadyate cakṣurvijñānaṃ trayāṇāṃ saṃnipātaḥ sparśaḥ sahajātā vedanā saṃjñā cetane“ti /
column2: If sensation is later than contact, you have to take into account the Sūtra, “By reason of the eye and visible things there arises visual consciousness; the coming together of the three is contact; together there arises sensation, ideas, volition. ” This Sūtra says that sensation, ideas and volition arise together;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sahajātā ityucyate na sparśasahajātā iti kimatra parihāryam /
column2: it does not say that they arise together with contact: we say that they arise together among themselves.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samanantare 'pi cāyaṃ sahaśabdo dṛṣṭastadyathā “maitrīsahagataṃ smṛtisaṃvodhyaṅgaṃ bhāvayatī” tyajñāpakametat /
column2: Let us observe also that the word “together” is used, not only to indicate simultaneity, but also to indicate immediate succession. The Sūtra, for example, says, “He cultivates the part of Bodhi called mindfulness together with compassion. ” Now compassion, which is always “worldly,” evidently cannot be simultaneous to a part of Bodhi: for the parts of Bodhi are always transworldly.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi sūtra uktaṃ “yā ca vedanā yā ca saṃjñā yā ca cetanā yacca vijñānaṃ saṃsṛṣṭā ime dharmā nāsaṃsṛṣṭā” ityato nāsti vedanābhirasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ vijñānam /
column2: Thus the Sūtra not only does not prove that sensation is simultaneous to contact; it does not even prove that sensation, ideas and volition are associated with, and simultaneous to. From this Sūtra we conclude that there are no sensations, ideas or volitions which are not simultaneous.
But what is the meaning of the word “mixed”, samshrsta?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra hi sūtra evamuktaṃ “yadvedayate taccetayate yaccetayate tastsaṃprajānīte yatsaṃprajānīte tadvijānātī“ti /
column2: We read in the Sūtra that you have just quoted, “That which he feels, he thinks of; that about which he thinks, he grasps an idea of; that about which he grasps an idea of, he discerns. ” In other words, the same thing is the object of sensation, volition, and consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tanna vijñāyate kim tāvadayameṣāmālambananiyama ukta utāho kṣaṇaniyama iti /
column2: The question is thus posed whether sensation, volition and ideas are called mixed because they have the same object—which is our opinion—or because they are simultaneous, as you say.

The word samshrsta refers to simultaneous things. It is said in fact that life and warmth are samshrta. They cannot be samshrsta except through simultaneity, not by the fact that they would have a common object, since they do not have.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaccāpi sūtra uktaṃ “trayāṇāṃ saṃnipātaḥ sparśaḥ” iti /
column2: Any object. Furthermore the Sutra says, "The coming together of the three is contact.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat kathaṃ vijñānaṃ cāsti na ca trayāṇāṃ saṃnipāto na ca sparśa iti /
column2: How "could there be a consciousness without there being a coming together of the three? How could there be encounter of the three without there being contact?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādavaśyaṃ sarvatra vijñāne sparśaḥ sparśasahajā ca vedanaiṣṭavyā /
column2: Thus all consciousness is accompanied by contact and all contact is accompanied by sensation, etc. But this discussion is carrying us too far afield.
Let us return to our subject.
We have explained, in summary, mental sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaścāṣṭādaśavidhā sā manopavicārataḥ // saiva caitasikī vedanā punarāṣṭadaśa manopavicāravyavasthānādaṣṭādadhā bhidyate / punaḥ saṃdhikaraṇaṃ cātra draṣṭavyam / aṣṭādaśamano pavicārāḥ katame /
column2: This same sensation is of eighteen types by reason of the objects of the mind.

Mental sensation is made up of eighteen types, because there are six upavicaras of satisfaction, six of dissatisfaction, and six of indifference: these are the upavicaras of satisfaction relating to visible things, sounds, color, tastes, tangible things, and the dharmas; the same for the upavicaras of dissatisfaction and indifference.
How does one distinguish these eighteen?
In considering their nature, their quality of being sensation, the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trayo bhaviṣyanti / saumanasyadaurmanasyopekṣāvicārāḥ / atha saṃprayogataḥ / eko bhaviṣyati /
column2: Upavicāras are three of satisfaction, dissatisfaction, and indifference;
considering their quality of associates, they are one, all being associated with the mental consciousness;
and considering their objects, they are six: having visible things, sounds, etc. , for their objects.
We answer then that one must take into account, at one and the same time, these three qualities.

There is no variety in the object of the first fifteen pavicāras: the object of manopavicāra relating to visible things is only these visible things. But, as for the three dharmopavicāras—the three upavicāras relating to the dharmas—one would distinguish: they can arise relating to the distinct dharmas of the five sense objects; in this case, their object presents no variety, and is not mixed;
they can bear on one, two, three, six categories of dharmas (visible things, sounds, dharmas); in this case, their object is mixed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: manopavicārā iti ko 'rthaḥ / manaḥ kila pratītyaite saumanasyadayo viṣayānupavicarantīti / viṣayeṣu vā mana upavicārayantītyapare /
column2: What is the meaning of the expression manopavicāra? Why are the different types of mental sensation?

According to another opinion, "Because satisfaction, dissatisfaction, and indifference cause the manas to reconsider visible things, etc. " For it is by reason of sensation (sensation of satisfaction, etc. ) that the manas repeatedly considers visible things, etc. Objections or difficulties.

Why not define bodily sensation as manopavicāra. Without doubt bodily sensation has the anas for its support, but it also has the material organs for its support. It is free from vikaḷpa (like the visual consciousness, etc. , to which it is associated, i33, trans.
and it is no longer #pavicārikā, [that is, susceptible of "consideration," sartīrikā].

But why is the s#kha of the ThirdDhyāna, which is of the sphere of a single zanas, not placed among the anopavicāra? "Because, initially, that is, inKāmadhātu, there is no sukhauwpavicāra which is of the sphere of the anas.
And because there does not exist any duwbkha-upavicāra which would oppose the sukhauwpavicāra that you imagine.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi manobhūmikā evaite / yattarhi sūtra uktaṃ “cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvā saumanasyasthānīyāni rūpāṇyupavicarantītyevamādiḥ / katham /
column2: But, if the pavicāras are only of the sphere of the manas, you have to take into account the Sūtra which says, “Having seen visible things through the eye, he considers the visible things which satisfy. ” The relationship is characterized, in the Sūtra, by the visual organ and by pavicāra.

The Blessed One expresses himself in this manner because he takes into consideration the fact that the upavicāras can be produced by the five sense consciousnesses. The upavicāras are no less that the sphere of the single vanas: in the same way, for example, that the zfwbhās (meditation on a cadaver turning blue, etc. , vi.
9), which are produced by the visual consciousness, are of the sphere of the wanas: these meditations, in fact, suppose absorption;
on the other hand, the Sūūtra says, “Having seen visible things .

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: acodyamevaitat / ye 'pya dṛṣṭvā yāvadaspṛṣṭvopavicarnti te 'pi manopavicārāḥ / itrathā hi kāmadhātau rūpadhātvālambanā rūpādyupavicārā na syuḥ kāmadhātbalamvanāśca rūpadhātau gandharasaspraṣṭavyopavicārāḥ /
column2: There is pavicāra of the visible things, etc. , without having seen them, etc. II it were otherwise, a being in Kāmadhātu could not "consider" the visible things, sounds and tangible things of Rūpadhātu, and a being of Rūpadhgtu would not be able to consider the smells and tastes of Kāmadhātu. The Sūtra says, "Having seen visible things. he considers visible things," because his "consideration" is "clearer" when it bears on an object which is "experienced.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tu yaktataraṃ tathoktaṃ yo 'pi rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvā śabdānupavicarati so 'pi manopavicāraḥ /
column2:
It is not doubtful that, having seen a visible thing, one cannot consider the sound;
yathā tvanākulaṃ tathoktamindriyārthasya vyavacchedataḥ /	there is here consideration" or pavicāra, of a sound not experienced: but the text, in order to avoid any confusion, makes a correspondence between the organs and the objects which correspond to them. The objects are given, in the Sūtra, as samanasyasthānya, etc. No.
The same object can be sawmanasthānīya for one person, but daurmanasyasthānāya for another.
It all depends on the series, on the dispositions of the mind itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athaiṣāṃ manopavicārāṇāṃ kati kāmapratisaṃyuktāsteṣāṃ ca kati kimālambanā evaṃ yāvadārūpyapratisaṃyuktā vaktavyāḥ / āha
column2: Among the manopavicāras, how many are in Kāmadhātu? Which Dhātu takes the manopavicāras of Kāmadhātu for its object? The same questions for the other two Dhātus.
In Kāmadhātu all of the anopavicāras have theit own Dhātu for their object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āmadhātau sarve 'ṣṭādaśa santi sa ca teṣāṃ sarveṣāmālambanam / teṣāmeva
column2: The eighteen manopavicāras are produced among beings in Kāmadhātu, but all can have Kāmadhātu for their object.
Rūpadhātu is the object of twelve.
Twelve of them can have Rūpadhātu for their object, with the exception of the three wanopavicāras relative to odor and the three relative to taste, since odors and tastes do not exist in Rūpadhātu.
The highest Dhātu is the object of three.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārupyadhātustrayāṇāṃ dharmopavicārāṇāmālambanam / tatra rūpādyabhāvāt // uktāḥ kāmapratisaṃyukatāḥ /
column2: Three, namely the dharmanopavicāras, ca have Ārūpyadhātu for.
In Rūpadhātu, one must distinguish the first two Dhyāṇas and the last two.
In two Dhyānas, twelve. In Rūpadhātu the xpavicāras of dissatisfaction are completely absent. All have Kāmadhātu for their object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te ca dvādaśa kāmagāḥ // kāmān gacchantīti kāmagāḥ / kāmadhātumālabanta ityarthaḥ / dṛṣṭo hi viṣayāṇāṃ grahaṇārthe gamiprayogaḥ / kathametat gamyate / evametat gamyata iti /
column2: These twelve can have Kāmadhātu for their object.
Eight have their own Dhātu for their object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa eva rūpadhātusteṣāṃ svaḥ / svo 'ṣṭānāṃ manopavicārāṇāmālambanaṃ gandharasopavicārāṃścaturo hitvā /
column2: Eight of them can have Rūpadhātu for their object, with the exception of the #pavicāras of odor and taste. Two have Ārāpyadhātu for their object.
Two can have Ārūpyadhātu for their object, namely the dharmopavicāras of satisfaction and indifference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānadvaye tu ṣaṭ / tṛtīyacaturthayordhyānyoḥ ṣaḍupekṣopavicārā eva santi nānye /
column2: But, in the other two Dhyānas, six.
The wpavicāras of dissatisfaction and satisfaction are absent in the last two Dhyāṇnas.

Kāmadhātu is the object of six. There remains then the six #pavicāras of indifference which have. In the visible things, sounds, odors, tastes, tangible things, and dharmas of Kāmadhātu for their object.
Of their own Dhātu, four.
The visible things, sounds, tangible things, and dharmas of Rūpadhātu.
The highest Dhūtu is the object of one.
The dharmas of Ārūpyadhāātu.
In Ārūpyadhātu, one must distinguish the preliminary absorption of Ākāśānantyāyatana and the absorption which follows it.
In the preliminary stage of Ārūpyadhātu, the word "urāpásāmanta" signifies Ākāśānantyāyatanasāmantaka.
Four upavicāras: the upavicāras of indifference with regard to visible things, sounds, tangible things and dharmas of the Fourth Dhyāṇa are produced in this absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te ca rūpagāḥ caturthaṃ hi dhyānameṣāmālambanam / yeṣāṃ tat vyavacchinnālambanamasti yeṣāṃ punaḥ paripiṇḍitālambanaṃ teṣāṃ tatraika eva saṃbhinnālambano dharmopavicāraḥ /
column2: Four have Rūpadhātu for their object. This is the opinion of the masters who think that the mind of this absorption is vyavacchinnālambana, that is, that it considers visible things, sounds, etc. , separately. According to other masters, this mind is paripiṇḍiālambana. It considers the five skandhas of the Fourth Dhyāna without any.
One has the highest sphere for its object.
In this same absorption, in Ārūpyadhātu, there is only the dharmopavicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: maule punarārūpye dharmopavicāra evaiko 'sti nānyaḥ / sa cāpi svaviṣayaḥ
column2: In Ārūpyadhātu itself, one, In the principle Dhāṭu, or Ārūpyadhātu itself, there is only one pavicāra, dharmopavicāra which has its own Dhūātu for its object, which has Ārūpyadhātu for its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārupyadhātvālambana eva / nahi maulānāmārupyāṇāmadharo dhāturālambanamiti paścāt prativedaviṣyāmaḥ / ete ca manopavicārāḥ
column2: As we shall see, the mind, in the principle absorption of Ārūpyadhātu, does not grasp lower Dhātus for its object.
All of these eighteen are impure.
There is no upavicāra which is pure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātūpapanno rūpāvacarasya kuśalasya cittasyālābhī kāmāvacaraiḥ sarvaiḥ prathamadvitīyadhyānabhūmikairaṣṭābhiḥ tṛtīyacaturthadhyānabhūmikaiścaturbhiḥ kliṣṭairgandharasālambanān paryudasya ārūpyāvacareṇaikena kliṣṭenaivālābhī rūpāvacarasya kuśalasya cittasyā vitarāgaḥ sarvaiḥ kāmāvacaraiḥ
column2: A being born inKāmadhātu who has not taken possession of a good mind of Rūpadhātu by penetration into Anāgamya, is in possession of: the eighteen upavicāras of Kāmadhātu;
the eight pavicāras of the First and Second.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturbhiḥ saumanasyopavicāraiḥ kliṣṭairgandharasālambanau vyudasya ṣaḍbhirūpekṣopavicārairanāgamyabhūmikaiḥ / dvitīyadhyānabhūmikairaṣṭābhiḥ /
column2: The upavicāras of satisfaction and indifference, having for their object the odors and tastes of Kāmadhātu, which are produced in the Dhyāṇnas, are not defiled hence the being in question is not filed with these wpavicāras.

The four upavicāras of the last two Dhyāṇas and an upavicāra of the sphere of Ārūpyadhātu, also defiled. When this being has obtained a good mind of Rūpadhātu by penetrating into Anāgamya, but is not detached from Kāmadhātu, he is filled with the eighteen wpavicāras of Kāmadhātu, the ten upavicāras of the First Dhyāna, and as above for the other.
One can decide any other case on the basis of these principles.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānopapannastu kāmāvacareṇaikenopekṣādharmopavicāreṇa nirmāṇacittasaṃprayuktena samanvāgato veditavyaḥ / apara āha /
column2: A being in one sphere of Dhyāna is in possession of a single upavicāra of Kāmadhātu, the dharmopavicāra of indifference associated with a mind capable of creating fictive beings.
ĒE Another master: It is in this way that the Vaibhāṣikas understand the upavicāras;
but we understand the Sūtra in a different way.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi yo yasmādvītarāgaḥ sa tadālambanamupavicaratīti yuktam /
column2: One cannot say of one who is detached from an object, a visible thing, etc. , that he produces pavicāras with regard to this object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ataḥ sāsravā api na sarve saumanasyādayo manopavicārāḥ / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: All the satisfactions, etc. , ate not pavicāras, though they are impure.
They are pavicāras when they are “defiling” , following the expression of the Sūtra, “when one has sympathy, antipathy, or indifference not proceeding from exact consciousness.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anunīyate ca pratihanyate cāpratisṅkhyāya copekṣate yeṣāṃ pratipakṣeṇa ṣaṭ sātatā vihārā bhavanti / cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvā naiva sumanā bhavati na durmanā upekṣako viharati smṛtimān saṃprajānan evaṃ yāvanmanasā dharmān vijñāyeti /
column2: And it is in order to combat these pavicāras that the six “manners of being, or perpetual methods” are taught, “Having seen a visible thing with the eye, there is no sympathy and no antipathy: be remains indifferent in full mindfulness and conscious.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahyarhato laukikaṃ nāsti kuśalaṃ dharmālambanaṃ saumanasyaṃ yattu tatsāṃkleśikaṃ manasa upavicārabhutaṃ tasyaiva pratiṣedho lakṣyata iti /
column2: We canshow that our interpretation is correct by observing that the Aṛhat is not without experiencing a satisfaction of a worldly order but good, having a dharma for its object. What he arrests is the satisfaction which, being defiled, is pavicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punasta eva saumanasyādayaḥ ṣaṭtriṃśacchāstṛpadāni bhavanti / gardhanaiṣkramyāśritabhedena / tadbhedasya śāstrā gamitatvāt / tatra gardhāśritāḥ kliṣṭā naiṣkramyāśritāḥ kuśalāḥ / evametadvedanākhyaṃ bhavāṅgamanekaprakārabhedaṃ veditavyam /
column2: By distinguishing those states of satisfaction, dissatisfaction, and indifference on the basis of those which have craving for their principle component and those which have “leaving” for their principal component, we have the thirty-six “points of the Master”, so called because this distinction has been taught by the Master.
The divisions of the parts of existence called sensation, and which we have just described, are still very numerous.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ ca vakṣyate cānyat kiñcidatrāṅgamuktaṃ kiñcit paścadvakṣyate /
column2: The other parts of existence will not be explained here.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra vijñānaṃ tāvaduktaṃ “vijñānaṃ prativijñaptirmana āyatanaṃ ca tadi“ti / ṣaḍāyatanamapyuktaṃ “tadvijñānāśrayā rūpaprasādāścakṣurādaya” iti / saṃskārā bhavaśca karmakośasthāne vyākhyāsyante / tṛṣṇopādānāni kleśakośasthāne /
column2: The consciousness and the six āyatanas have been explained in the rsfīk.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa caiṣa pratītyasamutpādaḥ samāsataḥ kleśakarmavastūnīti prāk jñāpitam /
column2: We have said that pratīyasamutpāda is defilement.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atra tu kleśa iṣyate / bījavannāgavanmūlavṛkṣavattuṣavattathā // kimasya vījādibhiḥ sādharmyam /
column2: It is explained that defilement is like a seed, a Nāga, a root, a tree, a husk of grain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā vījādaṅkurakāṇḍapatrādīnāṃ prabhavo bhavatyevaṃ kleśāt kleśakarmavastūnām /
column2: As a stalk, leaves, etc. , arise from a seed, so too defilement arises from defilement, action, and a real, substantial entity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā nāgādhiṣṭitaṃ saro na śuṣyatyevaṃ kleśanāgādhiṣṭhitaṃ janmasaraḥ /
column2: A pond where Nāgas live does not dry up; in the same way the ocean of births where this Nāga which is defilement remains does not dry up.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā cānapoddhṛtamūlā vanaspatayaśchinnāśchinnāḥ punarapi prarohantyevamanapoddhṛtakleśamūlā gatayaḥ /
column2: The tree whose root is not cut off continues to grow even though one cuts and re-cuts its greenery; in the same way, as long as this root, defilement, is not cut off, the realms of rebirth continue to grow.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca vṛkṣāḥ kālena kālalṃ puṣpaphalānāṃ prasotāro bhavantyevaṃ kleśā apyasakṛt kleśakarmavastūnāṃ heturbhavanti / yathā ca tuṣāvanaddhāstaṇḍulāḥ prarohaṇasamarthā bhavanti na kevalā evaṃ kleśaprāptatuṣāvanaddhaṃ
column2: A tree gives forth flowers and fruits at different times; in the same way it is not at one and the same time that this tree, the defilement, gives forth a defilement, action and a substantial entity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: karma janmāntaravirohaṇe samarthaṃ bhavati na kevalamityevaṃ tāvat kleśo bījādivadveditavyaḥ /
column2: Grain, even though intact, does not germinate when it is stripped of its husk; in the same way action must be associated with this husk which is defilement in order to bear fruit in a new existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tuṣitaṇḍulavat karma tathaivauṣadhipuṣpavat / tuṣau 'syāstīti tuṣī / tuṣasthānīyaḥ kleśa uktaḥ /
column2: Action is like grain with its husk, grass, flower.
Action is like grain with its husk.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santyoṣadhayaḥ phalapākāntā evaṃ karmāṇi vipacya punarvipākānabhinirvarttayante /
column2: It is like grass that dies when the fruit is ripe: in the same way, when the action has matured, it no longer matures any more.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca puṣpaṃ phalotpattavāsannaṃ kāraṇamevaṃ karmāṇi vipākotpatto veditavyāni / siddhānnapānavadvastu
column2: It is like a flower, the immediate cause of the arising of the fruit. In the same way it is the immediate cause of retribution. The substantial entity is like food and drink.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pathā siddhamannaṃ pānaṃ ca kevalaṃ paribhogāya kalpyate na punarvirohāya evaṃ vipākākhyaṃ vastu /
column2: Food and drink are not reproduced in food and drink: they are not good except by being consumed: so too the “entity” which is retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi punarvipākādvipākāntaraṃ janmāntareṣu pravarhate / yadi hi pravardheta mokṣo na syāt / na khalveṣa janmasaṃtāna evaṃ pratītyasamutpadyamāno bhavacatuṣṭayaṃ nātikrāmati /
column2: A new retribution does not preceed from retribution, for, in this hypothesis, deliverance would then be impossible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadutāntarābhavamupapattibhavaṃ pūrvakālabhavaṃ maraṇabhavaṃ ca / te ca vyākhyātāḥ / tasmin bhavacatuṣṭaye // upapattibhavaḥ kliṣṭaḥ
column2: The series of the skandhas, in its continual process, is only a succession of the four existences that we have defined, namely intermediate existence, existence as arising, existence in and of itself, and existence at death. Among the four existences, existence as arising is always defiled, and by all the defilements of the sphere to which.
It belongs.
It is always defiled, never good or neutral.
When arising takes place in a certain sphere, all the defilements of this sphere defile it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi sa kleśo 'sti yena pratisamdhibandhaḥ pratividyate ityābhidharmikāḥ /
column2: The Ābhidhārmikas say, "Among the defilements, there is not a single one that does not defile the mind at rebirth;
but rebirth takes place solely through defilements, not by the wrappings called svatantra, through jealousy, egoism, anger, or hypocrisy, which are only associated with ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyapi sā 'vasthā mandikā yastu yatrābhīkṣṇaṃ carita āsannaśca tasya tadānīṃ sa eva kleśa upatiṣṭhate / pūrvāvedhāt / antarabhavapratisaṃdhirapyevamavaśyaṃ kliṣṭo veditavyaḥ /
column2: Although this state—the state of death—is bodily and mentally "weak", when a person has habitually practiced a certain defilement, this defilement, thus "projected," becomes active at the moment of death.
The other existences are of three types.
Intermediate existence, existence in and of itself, and existence at death can be good, bad, or neutral.
Are the four existences produced in all the Dhātus?
Three in the Ārūpyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: antarābhavaṃ varjayitvā / nahyārūpyadhātuḥ sthānāntaraparicchinno yasya prāptyarthamantarābhavo 'bhinirvarteta /
column2: With the exception of intermediate existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmarūpadhātvoraparisaṃkhyānāt sarva eva catvāro bhavāḥ santītyanujñāpitaṃ bhavati /
column2: All four existences exist in Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu.
We have finished the exposition of pratīyasamutpāda.
Now how do beings, once they are born, last?
Everyone lasts through food.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eko dharmo bhagavatā svayamabhijñāyābhisaṃbadhyākhyāto “yaduta sarvasttvā āhārasthitikā” iti sūtrapadam / ke punarāhārāḥ /
column2: A Sūtra says, “A dharma has been proclaimed by the Blessed One who knows and sees, that all beings last through food.”
There are four foods, food by the mouthful, contact, mental volition, and consciousness.
Food by the mouthful is coarse or subtle.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūkṣmo 'ntarābhavikānāṃ gandhāhāratvāt / devānāṃ prāthamakalpikānāṃ ca niḥṣyandābhāvāt /
column2: Food by the mouthful of intermediate beings, the food of the gods, and the food of humans at the beginning of the cosmic age is subtle.
This food, like oil poured out into the sand, completely penetrates into the body and does not give forth any excrement.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūkṣmāṇāṃ vā sūkṣmo bālakasaṃsvedajantukādīnām / sparśo dvitīyaḥ / manaḥsaṃcetanā tṛtīyaḥ / vijñānamāhāraścaturthaḥ / tatra punaḥ kavaḍīkāra āhāraḥ kāme na rūpārūpyadhātvostadvītarāgasya tatropapatteḥ / sa ca
column2: Or rather the food of subtle beings is subtle, for example a being born from moisture, one newly-born, etc. Food by the mouthfuls exists in Kāmadhātu;
it consists of three āyatanas. Only beings free from desire with regard to this food arise in the two.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacarāṇi gandharasaspraṣṭavyāyatanāni sarvāṇyeva kavaḍīkāra āhāraḥ / kavaḍīkṛtyābhyavaharaṇāt /
column2: It consists of odors, tastes, and tangible things. In fact, odors, tastes and tangible things are put in the mouth—that is, in piṇḍas or small balls—and then swallowed.
This twofold operation is made by the mouth and the nose which separate the morsels.

But how does one attribute the quality of food to odors, etc. , which are also found in shade and warm light, in flames, and in the light? But such odors, etc. , are not put in the mouth and swallowed.
According to the School, the definition, “Food consists of three āyatanas,” refers to the generality of the cases.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yānyapi tu nābhyavahniyante sthitiṃ cāharanti tānyapi sūkṣma āhāraḥ /
column2: But we think that, even though they are not swallowed, like the others, since they contribute to the duration of a being, these odors are included in the category of subtle food;
as for example bathing and unguents.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasmānna rūpāyatanamāhāraḥ / tadapi kavaḍīkṛtyābhyavahriyate / na rūpāyatanaṃ tena svākṣamuktānanugrahāt //
column2: But why is rāpāyatana, a visible thing not a food?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āhāro hi nāma ya indriyamahābhūtānāmanugrahāya saṃvarttate /
column2: Food is that which comforts the organs and the primary elements which are the support of the organs. Now a visible thing, at the moment when it is swallowed—when this food, introduced into the mouth, is eaten—does not comfort either its organ, or the primary elements which are the support of the eye.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāyatanaṃ cābhyavaharaṇakāle svamindriyaṃ tanmahābhūtāni vā nānugṛhṇāti /
column2: Nor does it comfort the other organs, since it is not their object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuta evānyānyaviṣatvāt / yadāpi ca dṛśyamāne sukhasaumanasye ādadhāti tadāpi tadālambanaḥ sukhavedanīyaḥ sparśa āhāro bhavati na rūpam /
column2: Without doubt, as long as one sees it, it causes pleasure and satisfaction, it comforts: but, what is comfort and food in this case is not the visible thing, but the agreeable contact which has the visible thing for its object.

The explanation that we formulate here is confirmed by the fact that an agreeable visible thing does not comfort those liberated beings who see it. If visible thing were to perform the function of food when one sees it, it would comfort persons delivered from the desire for mouthfuls of.
In the three Dhātus, contact, volition, and consciousness, when they are impure, are food.
Contact is what arises from the cooperation of the three;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cetanā manaskarma vijñānaṃ ca sāsravāṇyevāhārāḥ triṣvapi dhātuṣu saṃvidyante /
column2: mental volition is mental action; and consciousness is the consciousness skandha.
Why are they not food when they are pure?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmāt bhavāpoṣaṇārtha āhārārthaḥ / tāni ca bhāvakṣayāyotthitānīti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas say, “Food signifies that which makes existence grow; now if it were pure, it have the destruction of existence for its result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: api tu sūtra uktaṃ “catvāra ime āhārā bhūtānāṃ sattvānāṃ sthitaye yāpanāyai saṃbhavaiṣiṇāṃ cānugrahāye“ti / na caivamanāsravā dharmā iti nāhārāḥ /
column2: ” It is a doctrine conforming to that of the Sūtra, that food has for a result causing to endure, causing to go “those that exist”, of favoring “those desiring re-existence. ” Now contact, volition, and consciousness, when they are pure, do not produce any of these two results.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhūtā hi tāvatsattvā upapannā iti vijñāyante /
column2: “Those that exist” signifies beings who have been born;
but what is the meaning of the expression “desiring re-existence? " It refers to antarābhava, intermediate existence or being, which the.
Mind created, desiring re-existence, Gandharva, intermediate existence, and arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: antarābhavo hyebhirabhidhānairukto bhagavatā / sa eva manonirjātatvāt manomaya uktaḥ / śukraśoṇitādikaṃ kiñcidbāhyamanupādāya bhāvāt / saṃbhavaiṣaṇaśīlatvāt saṃbhavaiṣī / gandharvaṇāt gandharvaḥ / upapattyadbhimukhatvādabhinirvṛttiḥ /
column2: An intermediate being is called manomayau, because he is produced by the anas alone, and because he exists without being supported by any exterior element, semen, blood, flower, etc. He is called abhinirvrṣti, because his nsrvṛtti or arising is with a view to arising proper.
That abhinirvrtti signifies an intermediate being results from the Sūtra “After having realized a painful body, he will be reborn in a painful world;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “tathāsti pudgalo yasyābhinirvṛttisaṃyojanaṃ prahīṇaṃ nopapattisaṃyojanam” iti sūtra catuḥkoṭikāt /
column2: ” and also from the Sūtra that says, “Such a person has abandoned the bonds which cause abhiānirvṛtti, without having abandoned the bonds which cause papatti or existence.” There are four cases: 1.

An ascetic detached from Kāmadhātu andRūpadhātu, when he is an Anāgāmin: he has abandoned the bonds which cause abhinirvṛtti or intermediate existence, since he will no longer be reborn in the Dhātus where existence itself is preceded by an intermediate existence; but he has not abandoned the bonds which cause upapatṭi, existence proper, for he will be reborn in Ārūpyadhātu.

An Anāgāmin destined to obtain Nirvāṇa in an intermediate existence (an amtarāparinirvāy⁸n, iii. 387): he is bound with the bonds of abhinirvr̥ti, but freed from wpapatti, an Arhat, who has abandoned the two types of bonds;
and all other persons who are not included in the preceding categories, who have not abandoned any of the two types of bonds.
According to another explanation, the bhātas are the Arhats: the word saṁbhavaiṣin designates all beings who desire, and who are as a consequence reborn.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha katyāhārāḥ sattvānāṃ sthitaye kati saṃbhavaiṣiṇāmanugrahāya /
column2: What are the foods that fulfill these two functions of causing to last and “favoring?
” According to the Vaibhāṣikas, the four foods perform these two.
Food by the mouthful has for its result the re-existence of those who are attached to it.
This is proved by the Sūtra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhagavatā “atvāra ime āhārā rogasya mūlalṃ gaṇḍasya śalyasya jarāmaraṇasya pratyaya” iti /
column2: The Blessed One said, “The four foods are the root of sickness, abcesses, and thorns. And are the condition of old age and death.” It is evident that food by the mouthful causes living beings to last.
