But how does mental intentional action, or volition, possess this power? Once upon a time there was a man, who in a time of poverty desired to go to another land.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ hi varṇayanti durbhikṣābhyāhatena kīla pitrā putrakau saktava iti bhasmanā bhastrāṃ paripūrya kīlake āsajyāśvāsitau /
column2: But he was exhausted by his hunger and his two sons were young. Feeling that he was going to die, he filled a sack with ashes, placed this sack on a wall, and encouraged his sons by telling them that this sack contained grain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tau ca tāṃ parikalpayantau ciramapyāsitau kenāpi codghāṭitāyāṃ bhasmeti nairāśyamāpannau vyāpannāviti /
column2: The two children, through hope, lived a long time. But another man came and took the sack and opened it. So too once upon a time some merchants travelled by ship on the open sea; tormented by hunger and thirst, they saw in the distance a mass of foam and believed that it was a river; hope gave them the force to go to that place and prolong their life;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaśca mahāsamudre bhagnayānapātrāḥ puruṣāḥ sthalamiti mahāntaṃ phenapiṇḍaṃ pradrutāḥ āmṛśya cainaṃ nirāśā uparemuriti /
column2: but, arriving, they found out what it was, and their hopes being crushed, they died.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃgītiparyāye coktaṃ mahāsamudrādaudārikāḥ prāṇino jalāt sthalamabhiruhya sikatāsthale 'ṇḍāni sthāpayitvā sikatābhiravaṣṭabhya punarapi mahāsamudre 'vataranti /
column2: We also read in the Samgriparyaya, “Large marine animals reach firm ground, lay their eggs on the beach, bury them in the sand, and go back to the ocean.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra yāsāṃ mātṛṇāmaṇḍānyārabhya smṛtirna muṣyate tānyaṇḍāni na pūtībhavanti yāsāṃ tu muṣyate tāni pūtībhavanti / tadetanna varṇayanti sautrāntikāḥ /
column2: If the mother forgets the eggs, they will perish.
” This edition cannot be correct, for it is impossible that the mind of another would be food.
Thus we should read, “If the eggs think of their mother, they will not perish;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yeṣāmaṇḍānāṃ mātaramārabhya smṛtirna muṣyate tāni na pūtībhavanti / yeṣāṃ tu muṣyate tāni pūtībhavanti / tasyāḥ sparśāvasthāyāḥ smarantīti / atha kasmāccatvāra evāhārāḥ /
column2: but if they forget their mother, they will perish.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca sarva eva sāsravā dharmā bhavānāṃ poṣakāḥ / yadyapyetadevaṃ tathāpi pradhānyenoktam
column2: ” Yet one cannot doubt that all the impure dharmas increase bhava or existence. Why did the Blessed One teach that the foods are four in number? Because he refers to the essentials.
The āśraya and the āśrita are affected by certain foods, while others affect the projection and production of a new existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āśrayo hi sendriyaḥ kāyaḥ / tasya puṣṭaye kavaḍīkārāhārāḥ /
column2: The āśraya is the body and its organs, which support the mind and its mental states.
Food makes the body grow, while contact makes the mind grow.
Two foods cause that which is born to live and are similar to a wet-nurse.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: manaḥsaṃcetanayā punarbhavasyākṣepaḥ ākṣiptasya punaḥ karmaparibhāvitādvijñānavījādabhinirvṛttirityanayoranutpannasya bhavasyākaraṇe prādhānyam ataścatvāra uktāḥ /
column2: Mental volitional action projects a new existence, produced from the seed of consciousness "informed" through action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvakau hi dvau dhātrīsthānīyau jātasya poṣakatvāt / uttarau mātṛsthānīyau janakatvāditi /
column2: Mental volitional action and consciousness are the two foods that cause birth, similar to a mother, and are major items for the production of the existence of a being who has not yet been born.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ kaścit kavaḍīkāraḥ sarvaḥ sa āhāraḥ /
column2: Is everything "by the mouthful" food?
There are “mouthfuls” which ate notfood. Four cases:

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamā koṭiryaṃ kavaḍīkāraṃ pratītyendriyāṇāmapacayo bhavati mahābhūtānāṃ ca paribhedaḥ /
column2: kavaḍīkāra which is not food: that which, being taken in the mouth, has for its result the diminution of the organs and the destruction of the primary elements which support them;
food without being kavaḍikāra: namely contact, mental volitional action, and the consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tṛtīyā yaṃ kavaḍīkāraṃ pratītyendriyāṇāmupacayo bhavati mahābhūtānāṃ ca vṛddhiḥ /
column2: kavaḍīkkāra which is food: that which, being taken in the mouth, has for its result the growth of the orgaos and the increase of the primary elements;
and
neither kavaḍīkāra nor food: sound, etc. The same, by changing the terms, for the other foods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syāt sparśādīn pratītyendriyāṇāmupacayo mahābhūtānāṃ ca vṛddhirna ca ta āhārāḥ /
column2: Is there contact, mental volitional action, and consciousness, which has for its result the growth of the organs and the increase of the elements, without this contact, etc. , being food?
Yes: those which belong to a sphere different from the sphere in which the being in question is born, and, in all the spheres, those which are pure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'pi hi paribhukto bhokturbādhāmādadhāti so 'pyāhāra eva /
column2: That which consumed is harmful to one who has consumed it nevertheless receives the name of food.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āpāte 'nugrahāt / dvayorhi kālayorāhāra āhārakṛtyaṃ karoti paribhujyamāno jīryaṃśceti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: According to the Vaibhāṣikas, in fact, it is for two moments that the thing consumed performs the function of food:  as soon as it is consumed, it dispels hunger and thirst; and digested, it increases the organs and the primary elements.
This leads to another question. How many foods are there is the different ealms of rebirth, and in the different wombs?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvāsu sarve / evaṃ yoniṣvapi / kathaṃ narakeṣu kavaḍīkāra āhāraḥ /
column2: All are in all How can you say that there is, in the hells, food by the mouthful?
‘The red balls of fire and molten copper are food.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyūpaghātako 'pyāhāro bhavati catuḥkoṭikaṃ bādhyate prakaraṇagranthaśca “kavaḍīkāra āhāraḥ katamaḥ /
column2: If this is the case, if that which is harmful is food, then the theory of the four cases is rejected, as well as the definitions of the Prakaraṇagrantha which says, “What is food by the mouthful?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaṃ kavaḍīkāraṃ pratītyendriyāṇāmupacayo bhavati mahābhutānāṃ ca vṛddhiryāpanā 'nuyāpaneti vistareṇa yāvadvijñānam /“
column2: Mouthful by reason of which there is inctease of the organs, and the increase and maintainance of the primary elements,” and the rest.
‘The doctrine of the existence of food by the mouthful in the hells is not in contradiction with the definitions that you appeal to. These.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apacayāhārastu narakekṣu lakṣaṇaprāptatvāt / so 'pi hi jighatsāṃ pipāsāṃ hantuṃ samartha iti /
column2: But the objects of consummation which have for their result to diminish, nevertheless possess, in the hells, the characteristics of food: they dispel, at least for a time, hunger and thirst.
Further, in the prādefika Ḥells, food by the mouthful exists as among humans. Hence food by the mouthful exists in the five realms of rebirth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ bhagavatā “yaśca bāhyakānāmṛṣīṇāṃ kāmebhyo vītarāgāṇāṃ śataṃ bhojayedyaścaikaṃ jambūṣaṇḍagataṃ pṛthagajanam / ato dānādidaṃ dānaṃ mahāphalatarami“ti /
column2: With respect to food by the mouthful, let us examine the Sūtra: There is one who feeds one hundred non-Buddhist Ṛṣis detached from Kāmadhātu, and there is one who feeds a single iambuṣaṇḍagata prthagjana: but this last gift is much more fruitful that the first.
” What does the expression Ś/ambuṣaṇḍagata pṛthagjana’” mean?

According to the first opinion, jambuṣaṇḍa signifying Jambudvīpa, so this signifies, “All beings inhabiting Jambudvīpa who have a storhach. ” This explanation is inadmissable; for the expression “a Pr̥thagjana .
” cannot designate “allbeings .

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syādyadi bhūyasaḥ pṛthagjanān bhojayitvā bhūyaḥ puṇyaṃ syāt nālpīyaso vītarāgāniti /
column2: ” Were it to have such a value,We do not see why the Sūtra would teach that a gift made to an infinite number of Pṛthagjanas is more meritorious that one made to a smaller number, to one hundred Ṛṣis: for such would stand of itself, and there would be nothing surprising about it.
According to the second opinion, the Pṛthagjana in question is the Bodhisattva close to Bodhi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadetanna varṇayanti “bahutaraṃ hi tasmai datvā puṇyaṃ nārhatkoṭibhya” iti /
column2: According to followers of the third opinion, the second opinion is unsustainable: in fact a gift made to such a Bodhisattva is of incalculable merit, and is of a merit superior to a gift made to one hundred éo¢is of Arṟhats. The terms of the comparison would be much too low.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato nirvedhabhāgīyalābhī pṛthagjana eṣo'bhipretaḥ iti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: Thus, say the Vaibhāṣīkas, this Prthagjana is the person who has obtained the so-called nôrvedhabhāgīya roots of good. In our opinion, the expression jambuṣaṇḍagata does not etymologically signify “possessor of the nsrvedhabhāgīyas; ” the usage does not give that sense to this expression;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: natviyamanvarthā saṃjñā nāpikvacitparibhāṣitā sūtre śāstre vā / jambūṣaṇḍagato nirvedhabhāgīyalābhīti parikalpa evāyaṃ kevalaḥ /
column2: neither the Sūtra nor the Śāstra uses it in this sense: the word jambuṣaṇḍagata, “seated under the Jambu”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bodhisattva eva tveṣu jambūdvīpaṣaṇḍeṣu niṣaṇṇo yujyate /
column2: The Bodhisattva Sarvārthasiddha sat at the foot of a jambu tree and entered into the First Dhyāna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa hi pṛthagjana kāmavairāgyasaṃbandhena tadānīṃ tebhyo viśiṣyamāṇa ukta iti /
column2: The Bodhisattva is detached from Kāmadhātu and a gift made to him is more meritorious than a gift made to Ṛṣis.
A gift made to this Bodhisattva is more meritorious than a gift made to an infinite number of Ṛṣis.
The Sūtra explains the gradation of merit by multiples of one hundred.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itthaṃ caitadevaṃ yadevaṃ paryudasya bāhyakebhya eva srotāpatti phalapratipannakaṃ viśeṣayāṃbabhūva /
column2: To proceed with these comparisons, the Sūtra does not further speak of a fambuṣaṇḍagata.
It does not say, “A gift made to a candidate for the results of Srotaāpanṇna is incomparable greater than a gift made to ajambuṣaṇḍagata.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ukto yathā sattvānāṃ pratītyasamutpādo yathāvasthitiścyutirapyuktā yathāyuḥkṣayādibhiḥ / idamidānīṃ vaktavyam /
column2: ”We have seen what the pratīyasamutpāda of beings is, and how beings last.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katamasmin vijñāne vartamāne cyutyupapattī bhavata ityāha
column2: We have seen also how death results from the exhaustion of life, etc. It remains for us to say which consciousness is present at the moments of death and birth.
Breaking, taking up again, detachment, loss of detachment, death and birth are regarded as proper to the mind consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalalmūlasamucchedaḥ kuśalamūlapratisaṃdhānaṃ dhātubhūmivairāgyaṃ parihāṇiścyutirupapattiśca / ete ṣaṭ dharmā manovijñāna eveṣyante nānyatra / upapattivacanādantarābhavapratisaṃdhirapyuktarūpo veditavyaḥ / vedanāyāṃ tu
column2: It is through a single mental consciousness that the breaking and the taking up again of the roots of good take place; the detachment either from a Dhātu, or from a bh%mi, and the loss of this detachment;
and death and birth. What is true of birth is evidently true of the beginning of the intermediate existence: it is useless to speak of.
The term çyuea is the equivalent of cyati or death; the term xudbhava is the equivalent of wpapatti, arising.
The mind consciousness, at death and at birth, is associated with the sensation of indifference, xpekṣa, that is, with the sensation that is neither agreeable nor disagreeable.
This sensation is not active;
the other sensations are active and, as a consequence, an aṛising and a dying consciousness cannot be associated with them, for, in this hypothesis, it would itself be active.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāpi ca manovijñāne 'pi naikāgrācittayoretau cyutodbhavāviti vartate /
column2: Death and birth take place in the mind consciousness ,[for andby the manovijñāna).

But death canṉot take place ina person whose mind īs absorbed. An absorbed mind is found in a sphere—First Dhyāna, etc—dissimilar to Kāmadhātu where we suppose the one dying and the one being born is found.
On the other hand, if we consider a being who dies or who is born in aIf his mind is not absorbed, then it is always active.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā cāsyāśrayo vipariṇantumārabhate tadāvaśyamasya tadāśrayapratibaddhaṃ cittaṃ saṃmukhībhūya paścāt pracyaveta nānyathā /
column2: An absorbed mind tends to last and cause to last, making it unsuitable for cutting off the series. One without thought, who has entered into nśrodhasamāpatti and asaṁjñisamāpaiti, experiences no death or birth. When the body decays, the mind bound to the body becomes present and dies.
The state of non-thought is incompatible with birth, lacking any cause for cutting off the mind and because there cannot be birth without defilement.
Existence at death can be good, bad, or neutral.
Namely, in an airyāpathia mind or in a vipākaja mind.
At least according to the masters who believe that, in Kāmadhātu, a vipākaja mind can be indifferent;
but, for the masters of an opposing opinion, one cannot obtain Nirvāṇa in an aryāpathika mind.
Why is the last mind of the Arhat necessarily neutral?
Because this type of mind, being very weak, is suitable to the cutting off of the mind, that is, to the definitive cutting off of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha mriyamāṇasya kasmin śarīrapradeśe vijñānaṃ nirudhyate /
column2: In which part of the body does the consciousness perish at death?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sakṛnmaraṇe samanaskaṃ kāyendriyaṃ sahasā'ntardīyate / yadi tu krameṇa cyavate tataḥ
column2: When death or “falling” takes place at once, the kāyendriya perishes at the same time as does the ṁmanṅās.
When death is gradual, the anas dies in the feet, at the mavel, in the heart, accordingly as the being goes below, among humans, among the Suras, or is not reborn.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: adho gacchantītyadhogā apāyagāminaḥ / nṛn gacchantīti nṛgā manuṣyagāminaḥ /
column2: Adhoga, “who goes below,” is one who should be reborn in the painful should be reborn in the human realms of rebirth;
sxraga, “who goes”Among the gods, is one who should be reborn in a heavenly realm of rebirth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ yathāsaṃkhyaṃ pādayornābhyāṃ hṛdaye ca vijñānaṃ saṃnirudhyate /
column2: The consciousness of these beings dies respectively, in the feet, the navel, or in the heart.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na punarjāyanta ityajā arhantaḥ / teṣāmapi hṛdaye vijñānaṃ nirudhyate /
column2: Aja, who is not reborn, is the Arhat: his consciousness also dies in the heart;

but according to another opinion, is the head. How does the consciousness die in a certain part of the body? Because it is in such a part that the destruction of the organ of touch takes place. The activity of the consciousness which is nonmaterial and outside of space, is bound to this organ—which alone remains as its support or asraya. The consciousness dies through the destruction of the organ of touch, which takes place in a certain place.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyendriyasya teṣu nirodhāt kāyendriyaṃ hi mriyamāṇasya tapta ivopale jalaṃ niṣṭhyūtaṃ saṃkocamāpadyamānaṃ pādādiṣvantardhīyata iti /
column2: Towards the end of life, the organ of touch perishes bit by bit; at the end it remains only in a certain part of the body where it finishes by disappearing; in the same way water placed on a hot rock diminishes gradually and finishes by disappearing in a certain place.
It is thus that gradual death takes place;
in general, the dying person.
is afflicted by some sensations which break the vital parts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śarīrapradeśāḥ kecidupahanyamānā maraṇamānayanti / te hyetaducyante marmāṇīti /
column2: The vital parts are split by water, etc. Marmāṉṇi oṟ vital parts, are those parts of the body which cannot be damaged without death ensuing.
When one of the elements,̥—water, fire or wind,—is extremely troubled, the vital parts are as if they were split by terrible sensations which are like sharp knives.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: chidyanta iva na ca punastāni kāṣṭhādivacchidyante chinnabadvā punarna ceṣṭanta iti cchinnānyucyante /
column2: By saying that the vital parts are split, we do not mean to say that they are split like wood. Rather one should understand that they are henceforth incapable of activity quite as if they were split.
Why are the vital parts not split by trouble of the earth element?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vātapittaśleṣmāṇo hi trayo doṣāḥ / te cāptejovāyudhātupradhānā yathāyogamiti / bhājanalokasaṃvarttanīsādharmyeṇetyapare /
column2: Because there are only three doṛar, namely bile, phlegm, and wind, which are in order the elements of water, fire, and wind. According to another opinion, since the world perishes by these three elements, death also takes place by these three elements.
The vital parts of the gods are not split.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tu cyavanadharmaṇo devaputrasya pañcopanimittāni prādurbhavanti /
column2: But five premonitory signs appear to a god being approached by death: 1.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vastrāṇāmābharaṇānāṃ ca manojñaḥ śabdo niścarati śarīraprabhā mandībhavati snātasyodabindavaḥ
column2: some of his clothes andsome of his ornaments give off unpleasant sounds. the light of his body diminishes. some drops of water remain attached to his body after his bath,

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāye saṃtiṣṭhante capalātmanā 'pyekatra viṣaye buddhiravatiṣṭhate unmeṣanimeṣau cākṣṇoḥ saṃbhavataḥ / etāni tu vyabhicārīṇi /
column2: in spite of his natural mobility, his mind is fixed o an object; and his eyes, naturally fixed, are troubled, opening and closing.
And there are five signs of death: his clothes become dirty; his aura fades; sweat appears in his armpits;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vāsāṃsi kliśyanti mālā mlāyanti kakṣābhyāṃ svedo mucyate daurgandhyaṃ kāye'vakrāmati sve cāsane devaputro nābhiramate /
column2: his body emits a bad odor; and the god no longer enjoys his seat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so'yaṃ sattvaloka evamutpadyamānastiṣṭhan cyavamanaśca triṣu rāśiṣu sthāpito bhagavatā / trayo rāśayaḥ / samyaktvaniyato rāśirmithyātvaniyato rāśiraniyato rāśiriti / tatra punaḥ
column2: The Blessed One classified beings who arise, last, and die, into three categories: those predestined to health, predestined to loss, and not predestined.
An Āryan and one guilty of ānantarya transgressions are predestined, the first to health, the second to loss.
What is “health,” samyaktua?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattatparyādāya rāgaprahāṇaṃ paryādāya dveṣaprahāṇaṃ paryādāya mohaprahāṇaṃ paryādāya sarvakleśaprahāṇamidamucyate samyaktva“miti sūtram /
column2: According to the Sūtra, the complete abandoning of affection, hatred, error, and all of the defilements, .
What is an Āryan?
One in whom the Path arises, that is, the Pure Path.
He is an Āryan because he “has gone far” from evil, since he possessesdisconnection from the defilements. How is the Āryan predestined to health?
Because he will certainly obtain Nirvāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ete hi kleśakṣaye niyatatvāt samyaktvaniyatāḥ mokṣabhāgīyalābhino 'pyavaśyaṃ parinirvāṇadharmāṇa iti /
column2: But a person who acquires the mokṣabhāgīyas will also certainly obtain Nirvāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasmānna samyaktve niyatāḥ / te hi mithyātve'pi niyatā bhaveyuḥ /
column2: Why not consider him predestined to health? Because he can commit transgressions which make him "predestined to loss;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca te kālaniyamena samyaktve niyatā yathā saptakṛtvaḥ paramādayaḥ /
column2: or rather because, if he is in fact predestined for Nirvāṇa, the moment of his arrival at Nirvāṇa is not fixed, as is the case for the Āryans beginning with he who, at a maximum, will be reborn seven times".
What is loss, mithyātva?
The hellish, animal, and Preta realms of rebirth.
A person who commits āṉantaryatraṇsgressions will certainly be reborn in hell; he is thus predestined to loss. One who is not predestined is one who is not predestined to health or loss.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: niyatebhyo'nye'niyatā iti siddham / pratyayāpekṣaṃ hi teṣāmubhayabhāktvamanubhayabhāktvaṃ ca /
column2: Whether he becomes predestined to one or the other, or whether he continues to not be predestined, depends in fact on his future actions.
We have described the world of human beings; let us pass to a.
Here is how it is thought that the receptacle world is arranged: at the bottom there is a circle of wind, immeasurable, with a height of sixteen hundred thousand leagues.
The great chiliocosm is arranged as we shall explain.
At its bottom there arises, through the force of the predominant actions of beings, a circle of wind which rests on space.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: karmādhipatyena tasya yojanalakṣāṇāṃ ṣoḍaśakamudvedhaḥ pariṇāhenāsaṃkhyaṃ tathā ca dṛḍhaṃṃ yanmahālagno'pi vajreṇa bhettumaśaktaḥ /
column2: It is sixteen thousand yojanas thick; it is immeasurable in circumference; and it is solid: a ahānagna could strike at it with his vafra and his vajra would break without the circle of wind being scratched.
The circle of water, eleven hundred twenty thousand high.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: maṇḍalamiti varttate / tasmin vāyumaṇdale sattvānāṃ karmabhirmeghāḥ saṃbhūyākṣamātrābhirdhārābhirabhivarṣanti /
column2: By the predominant actions of beings, there falls from massed clouds, upon the circle of wind, a rain the drops of which are like the shafts of a carriage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat bhavatyaṣāṃ maṇḍalam / tasya yojanānāmekādaśalakṣāṇyūrdhve'dho viṃśatiśca sahasrāṇi /
column2: This water forms a circle of water, with a thickness of eleven hundred twenty thousand yojanas.
How do these waters not flow over the edge?
Some say that the waters are sustained by the force of the actions of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā hi bhuktaṃ pītamannaṃ pānaṃ ca nāpakvaṃ pakvāśayamāpatatī tyeke /
column2: Beings, as food and drink which do not fall in the intestines before being digested.
According to another opinion, the waters are sustained by the wind, like grain in a basket.
Then the water, agitated by a wind which the force of actions gives rise to, becomes gold in its upper part, as churned milk becomes cream.
Then, the circle of waters is no more than eight hundred thousand leagues in height;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭalakṣocchrayaṃ paścāccheṣaṃ bhavati kāñcanam // kiṃ ca śeṣam /
column2: the rest becomes gold.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trayo laklṣāḥ sahasrāṇi ca viṃśatiḥ / sā kāñcanamayī mahī bhavatyapāmupariṣṭāt ukto jalakāñcanamaṇḍalocchrāyaḥ /
column2: Then there is above the circle of water now reduced to eight hundred thousand yojanas, a sphere of gold, three hundred twenty thousand yojanas thick.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tiryak trīṇi sahasrāṇi sārdhaṃ śatacatuṣṭayam / lakṣadvādaśakaṃ caiva jalakāñcanamaṇḍalam // samānaṃ hyetadubhayaṃ vistārataḥ /
column2: The circle of water and gold have a diameter of twelve hundred three thousand four hundred and fifty leagues;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samantatastu triguṇaṃ samantataḥ parikṣepeṇa tu parigaṇyamānaṃ triguṇaṃ jāyate ṣaṭtriṃśallakṣā daśasahasrāṇi sārdhāni ca trīṇi śatāni yojanānām /
column2: triple for its perimeter.
These two circles have the same dimensions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra meruryugandharaḥ / īśādhāraḥ khadirakaḥ sudarśanagiristathā // aśvakarṇo vinitako nimindharagiriḥ
column2: On the circular sphere of gold which thus rests on the water, there are Meru, Yugandhara, Īṣādhara, Khadiraka, Mount Sudarśana, Aśvakarṇa, Vinataka, and Mount Nimindhara; beyond are the continents; on the edge is Cakravāḍa.
Nine great mountains rest on the sphere of gold.
In the center there is Meru;
concentrically, the other seven are arranged around Meru;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyānyasaptaparvataprākāraparikṣiptasya yo bāhyaḥ parvate nimindharagiriḥ / tataḥ /
column2: Nimindhara forms the exterior rim that envelops Meru and the six inner wall-mountains.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvīpāḥ tato bahiścatvāro dvīpāḥ / tebhyaḥ punaḥ
column2: Beyond lie the four continents.
Enveloping all is Cakravāḍa, thus named because it encircles the universe with its four continents and also because it has the form of a wheel.
Seven mountains are made of gold; the last is made of iron; and Meru is made of four jewels.
Yugandhara and the six mountains that surround it are made of gold; Cakravāḍa is made of iron;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catūratnamayo meruḥ suvarṇamayo rūpyamayo vaidūryamayaḥ sphaṭikamayaśca yathāsaṃkhyaṃ caturṣu pārśveṣu /
column2: Meru has four faces which are respectively, from north to west, made of gold, silver, lapis, and crystal.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yacca yanmayaṃ pārśvaṃ sumerostasyānubhāvena tadvarṇa tasyāṃ diśi nabho dṛśyate /
column2: Each of these substances gives its own color to the part of space which faces it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jāmbūdvīpakamasya pārśvaṃ vaidūryamayaṃ varṇayanti / tasyeha prabhānurāgeṇa vaidūryamayaṃ nabho dṛśyata iti /
column2: Since the face of Meru which is turned towards Jambudvīpa is made of lapis, our heaven is thus similar in color to lapis.
What is the origin of the different substances that make up Meru?
The waters which have fallen on the sphere of gold are rich in.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tā hyāpo nānāvidhabījagarbhā bahuvidhaprabhāvabhinnairvāyubhirmathyamānāstāṃ tāṃ jātiṃ pariṇamayanti /
column2: They disappear and make room for different jewels.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca punaḥ pariṇamayanti yadbhinnajātīyasya kāryaviśeṣotpattāvasamavadhānena pratyayībhavanti /
column2: It is thus that the waters are transformed into jewels: the water is the cause, the jewels are a result different from the cause, and there is no simultaneity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tu khalu yathā sāṃkhyānāṃ pariṇāmaḥ /
column2: This is quite different from the concept of transformation that the Sankhyas imagine.
What do the Sankhyas understand by parinama?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avasthitasya dravyasya dharmāntaranivṛttau dharmāntaraprādurbhāva iti / kaścātra doṣaḥ /
column2: They admit that dharmas arise and disappear within a permanent substance. How is this incorrect?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa eva hi dharmī na saṃvidyate yasyāvasthitasya dharmāṇāṃ pariṇāmaḥ kaspyeta /
column2: One cannot admit the simultaneous existence of a permanent dharmin, and of dharmas arising and disappearing. But the Sankhyas do not hold that there is adharmin separate from the dharmas;
they say that a dharma, when it is transformed, becomes the support of different characteristics: this dharma they call dharmin.
In other words, transformation is only the modification of a substance.
This thesis is not correct.
Why is it not correct?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadeva cedaṃ na cedaṃ tatheti apūrvaiṣā vāyo yuktiḥ /
column2: Because there is a contradiction in terms: you admit that that.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca punaḥ saṃbhūtāḥ suvarṇādayaḥ karmaprabhāvāt preritairvāyubhiḥ samāhṛtya rāśīkriyante / ta ete parvatāśca bhavanti dvīpāśca /
column2: The gold, silver, jewels and the land thus formed are brought together and piledin heaps by the winds which are produced by the force of actiohs.
They meke up the mountains and the continents.

Meru is immersed in the water to a depth of twentyfour thousand leagues and rises above the water some eighty thousand leagues. The immetsion of the eight other mountains diminishes each by a half. The mountains have equal width and height.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: magnāḥ kāñcanamayyāḥ pṛthivyā uparyaśītiyyojanasahasrāṇyudakaṃ tatra te magnāḥ / ūrdhvaṃ jalāt merurbhūyo 'śītisahasrakaḥ //
column2: The mountains rest on the sphere of gold and are in the water to a depth of eighty thousand yo/anas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: iti hi meroḥ ṣaṣṭi yojanaśatasahasraṃ samucchrayaḥ / ardhārdhahāniraṣṭāsu
column2: Meṟu rises out of the water for the same number of yojanas, and is thus, both in and out of the water, one hundred sixty thousand Jojanas in beight.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jalādūrdhvaṃ yāvānsumerustato'rdhena yugandharaścatvāriṃśadyojanasahasrāṇi / tato 'rdhena īśādhara ityevamanyeṣvapyardhārdhahānirveditavyā yāvannimindharārdhenārdhatrayodaśottarāṇi trīṇi yojanaśatāni cakravāḍaḥ / samocchrāyaghanāśca te / yāvāneva caiṣāṃ jalādūrdhvaṃ samucchrāyastāvāneva ghano vistāra ityarthaḥ /
column2: Yugandhara rises out of the water for forty thousand yojanas,Īṣādhara for twenty thousand yojanas and thus following until Cakravāḍa which rises out of the water for three hundred twelve yojanas and a half.
The mountains are as wide as they.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣāṃ ca nimindharāntanāṃ parvatānāṃ saptāntarāṇi sapta śītā ucyante pūrṇā aṣṭāṅgopetasya pānīyasya / taddhi pānīyaṃ śītalaṃ ca svādu ca laghu ca mṛdu cācchaṃ ca niṣpratikaṃ ca pibataśca kaṇṭhaṃ na kṣiṇoti pītaṃ ca kukṣiṃ na vyābādhate / tāsāṃ ca punaḥ ādyāśītisahasrikā // sumeruyugandharāntaraṃ prathamā śītā / aśītiryojanasahasrāṇi vaipulyena /
column2: The seven Sītās, of which the first is of eighty thousand leagues, form the interval between the mountains.
This is the inner ocean, triple in circumference. The other Sītās diminish by a half.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvau hi samudrāvābhyantaro bāhyaśca / tadā'sau śītā'bhyantaraḥ samudraḥ triguṇaḥ sa tu pārśvataḥ /
column2: The rest is the great outer sea, of three hundred twenty-two thousand leagues. The Sītās are located between the mountains, from Meru to Nimindhara: the ītās are full of water endowed with the eight qualities: cold, clear, light, tasty, sweet, not fetid, and harming neither the throat nor the stomach.
The first, between Meru and Yugandhara, is eighty thousand leagues in width.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pārśvatasriguṇo bhavati yugandharatīreṇa gaṇyamānaḥ catvāriṃśat sahasrāṇi lakṣadvayaṃ ca /
column2: In exterior circumference, to the shore of Yugandhara, it is triple this, thus two hundred forty thousand yojanas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ardhārdhenāparāḥ śītāḥ yugandharasyeṣādhārasya cāntaraṃ dvitīyā śītā ardhena prathamāyāścatvāriṃśat yojanasahasrāṇi / tato 'rdhena punastṛtīyetyevamardhārdhenāparāḥ śītāḥ bhavanti /
column2: The size of the other Sītās diminishes by a half: the second Sītā, between Yugandhara and Īṣādhara, is forty thousand yojanas in width.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvadardhatrayodaśaśatāni saptamī śītā / dairdhyaṃ tu tāsāṃ na parisaṃkhyātamatibahuprakarṣavisarpaṇāt /
column2: The seven Śītās are the inner ocean.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣaṃ bāhyo mahodadheḥ // kiṃ śeṣam / nimindharacakravāḍayorantaram /
column2: The rest, that is, the water between Nimindhara and Cakravāḍa, is the great outer sea;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taddhi bāhyo mahāsamudro lavaṇaṃ pūrṇaḥ hṣārodakasya / sa khalu vistāreṇa yojanānāṃ
column2: it is full of salt water, and is three hundred twenty-two thousand yojanas wide. There is Jambudvīpa, three sides of two thousand, in the form of a carriage, and one side of three and a half;
eastern Videha, like a half-moon, three sides like Jambu, and one side of three hundred fifty; Godānīya, of seven thousand five hundred, round, with a diameter of two thousand five hundred;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra catvāro dvīpāścaturṣu sumerupārśveṣu / tatra tu /
column2: and Kuru, of eight thousand, square, parallel In the outer sea, corresponding to the four sides of Meru, there are four continents.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jambūdvīpo dvisāhasrastripārśvaḥ śakaṭākṛtiḥ // sāhasrāṇi trīṇi pārśvānyasya śakaṭasyevākṛtiḥ /
column2: Jambudvīpa has three sides of two thousand yojanas in length, one side of three yojanas and a halft¹ it thus has the shape of a carriage.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya ca madhye kāñcanamayyāṃ pṛthivyāṃ vajrāsanamabhinirvṛttaṃ yasminniṣadya sarve bodhisattvā vajropamaṃ samādhimutpādayanti // nahi tamanya āśrayaḥ pradeśo vā soḍhuṃ samarthaḥ / sārdhatriyojanaṃ tvekaṃ cturthamasya pārśvaṃ sārdhāni trīṇi yojanāni / ata eva hyasau śakaṭākṛtiḥ /
column2: In its center, resting on the sphere of gold, is the “diamond throne”. Where the Bodhisattva sits to attain vajropamasamādhi and so to become an Arhat and a Buddha: no other place, and no other person can support the vajropamasamādhś of the Bodhisattva.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prāgvideho'rdhacandravat / itaḥ pūrveṇa sumerupārśve pūrvaṃ videho dvīpaḥ / so 'rdhacandra ivābhinirvṛttaḥ / parimāṇatastu
column2: Eastern Videha or Pūrvavideha has the shape of a half-moon;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pārśvatrayaṃ tathā 'sya yathā jambūdvīpasya dve dve yojanasahasre / ekaṃ sārdhaṃ triśatayojanam // caturthaṃ pārśvaṃ sārdhāni trīṇi yojanaśatāni / godānīyaḥ sahasrāṇi sapta sārdhāni maṇḍalaḥ / itaḥ paścimena sumerupārśve 'paragodānīyo dvīpaḥ sārdhāni sapta yojanasahasrāṇi sākalyena /
column2: it has three sides of two thousand yojanas, thus of the same dimension as the long side of Jambu, and one side of three hundred fifty yojanas.
Godānīya, which faces the western side of Meru, is round like the moon;
it is seven thousand five hundred yo/anṇas, and two thousand five hundred through the center.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭau caturasraḥ kuruḥ samaḥ // iha uttareṇa sumerupārśve uttarakurudvīpaḥ /
column2: Facing the northern side of Meru is Kuru or Uttarakuru which has the shape of a seat;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'ṣṭau yojanasahasrāṇi sākalyena caturasraḥ / kṛtyāpīṭhikāvat / sarveṣu ca pārśveṣu samo yathaikaṃ pārśvaṃ dviyojanasahasre / tathā 'nyāni stokamapi nādhikam /
column2: it is square: its sides, of two thousand yojanṇar each, form a circumferance of eight thousand yojanas. To say that Kuru is “parallel’ means that its four sides are of the same dimension.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaśca dvīpo yadākṛtistadākṛtīnyeva tatra manuṣyāṇāṃ mukhāni / teṣāṃ khalu dvīpānāmantarāle 'ntaradvīpā abhinirvṛttāḥ / ke punaste kati cetyāha dehā videhāḥ kuravaḥ kauravāścāmarāvarāḥ /
column2: Such is the shape of the continents, and such is the shape of the faces of the persons who reside in them.
There are eight intermediate continents: Dehas, Videhas. These continents are designated by the name of their inhabitants.
Dehas and Videhas are located on both sides of Pūrvavideha;
Kurus and Kauravas on the sides of Uttarakuru;
Cāmaras and Avaracāmaras on the sides of Jambudvīpa; and Śāṭhas and Uttaramantrins on the sides of Godāṇnīya.
All of these continents are inhabited by human beings.
Nevertheless, according to one opinion, one of them is reserved for Rakṣasas.
Here, to the north of the nine ant-Mountains, lie the Hirmavat; beyond it, but on this side of the Mountain of Perfume, is a lake deep and wide by fifty leagues.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ihaiva jambūdvīpe uttareṇāsya jambūdvīpasya kṛṣṇaparvatāstrayastānatikramyāpare trayaḥ punaśca traya iti navabhyaḥ kīṭaparvatebhyaḥ pareṇa himavān parvataḥ /
column2: By going toward the north in this Jambudvīpa, one encounters three ant-Mountains, then three other ant-Mountains; then three other again; and finally the Himavat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ / pañcāśadvistṛtāyāmaṃ saro 'rvāggandhamādanāt // tasmāddhimavataḥ pareṇānavataptaṃ nāma saro gandhamādanādarvāk yataścatasro nadyaḥ sravnti gaṅga sindhuḥ śītā vakṣuśca /
column2: Beyond that, this side of the Gandhamādana (“the Mountain of Perfume”), lies Lake Anavatapta from whence there flows out four great rivers, the Gaṅgā, the Śindhu, the Vakṣu and the Sītā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya pañcāśadyojanāni vistāraḥ pañcāśadāyāmaḥ / pūrṇamaṣṭāṅgasyāṅgopetasyāmbhasaḥ / durgamaṃ ca manuaṣyāṇāmanṛddhimatām /
column2: This lake, fiftyYojanas wide and deep, is full of water endowed with the eight qualities.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyaiva cāntike jambūrabhinirvṛttā madhurasvādūni yasyāḥ phalāni tasyā adhikāreṇāyaṃ jambūdvīpa iti khyātaḥ /
column2: The Jambu tree is located near this lake.
Our continent receives its name of Jambudvīpa, either from the tree, or from the fruit of the tree which is also called Jambu.
Where are the hells, and what are their dimensions?
At the bottom, at twenty thousand leagues, is Avīci, of this same dimension; above; the seven hells; all eight have sixteen utsadas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asyaiva jambūdvīpasyādho viṃśatyā yojanasahasrairavīcirmahānarako viṃśatisahasrapramāṇa evodvedhavistārābhyāmevamasyādharatalamitaścatvāriṃśatā yojanasahasrairbhavati /
column2: Beneath Jambudvīpa, at a distance of twenty thousand yojanar, lies the great hell Avīci. It is twenty thousand yojanas high and wide; its sun is thus found forty thousand yojanas below the sun of Jambudvīpa. Why is this hell named Avīci? Two explanations: 1. because there is not, in this hell, any interruption of suffering.
Suffering is interrupted in the other hells. In Saṁjīva, for example, bodies are first crushed and reduced to dust;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyeṣu sāntaraṃ duḥkham taddyathā saṃjīve cchinnāvabhinnasaṃpiṣṭaśarīrāṇāṃ śītalā vāyavo vānti punarapi tān sattvān saṃjīvayanti / ata eva saṃjīvaḥ / nāsmin sukhavīcirastītyavīcirityapare /
column2: then a cold wind revives them and gives them feeling: frombecause there is no agreeable state there.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyeṣvapi sukhā vedanā vipāko nāsti / naiḥ ṣyandikī na vāryate / tadūrdhvaṃ sapta narakāḥ
column2: In the other hells all agreeable sensation which arises from retribution is absent; but here there is some agreeable sensations which are “an outflowing”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādavīcerūrdhvaṃ sapta narakāḥ uparyupari saṃniviṣṭāḥ / pratāpanastāpano mahārauravo rauravaḥ saṃghātaḥ kālasūtraḥ saṃjīvaśca /
column2: Above Avīci are seven hells one above the other: Pratāpaṇa, Tapana, Mahāraurava, Raurava, Sarṁghāta, Kālasūtra, and Saṁjīva. According to another opinion, these seven hells are placed at the same level as Avīci.
Each of the eight hells has sixteen wṣsadas.
This results from a declaration of the Blessed One, “.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “ityete narakā aṣṭāvākhyātā duratikramāḥ / raudrakarmabhirākīrṇāḥ pratyekaṃ ṣoḍaśotsadāḥ //
column2: There are eight hells there that [have revealed, difficult to get out of, full of cruel beings, each having sixteen wÉsadas;
they have four walls and four gates; they are as high as they are wide;
they are encircled by walls of fire;
their ceiling is fire; their sun is burning, sparkling fire;
and they are filled with flames bundreds of yojanas high.
” What are the sixteen Ésadas?
Kukūla, Kuṇapa, Kṣuramārga, etc. , and the River are.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ caturdiśaṃ / dvāre dvāre teṣāṃ catvāra utsadāḥ /
column2: located at the four cardinal points of these hells.
At each gate of these hells there is found: The Kukūla, a fire where one is pushed down to ones knees.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatra teṣāṃ sattvānāṃ nikṣipte saṃśīryate tvaṅmāṃsaśoṇitamutkṣipte pāde punarapi saṃjāyate tvaṅmāṃsaśoṇitam /
column2: When beings put their feet in there, they lose their skin, flesh and blood, which rearises when they take their feet out.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuṇapaṃ gūthamṛttikā yatra nyaṅkuṭā nāma prāṇinaḥ prativasanti sarvaśvetāḥ kṛṣṇaśirasaḥ sūcimukhāsteṣāṃ sattvānāṃ yāvadasthīni bhindanti /
column2: The Kuṇapa, a mire of excrements, where there are water beasts called Sharp-mouthes, whose bodies are white and heads black, which can bite the damned through to their bones. The Kṣuramārga, or Kṣuradhārāmārga, the great road of razor blades;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣuradhārācito mahāpathaḥ yatra teṣāṃ sattvānā manvākrāmatāṃ nikṣipte pāde saṃchidyate tvaṅmāṃsaśoṇitamiti pūrvavat /
column2: here beings lose their skin, flesh, and blood when they put their feet on it. Asipattravana, the forest whose leaves are swords;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asipatravanaṃ yatra teṣāṃ sattvānāṃ tīkṣṇā asayaḥ saṃnipatanti aṅgapratyaṅgānyavakṛntanti śyāmaśabalāśca śvāno bhakṣayanti /
column2: when these swords fall, they cut off major and minor parts of the body, which are then devoured by the Śyāmaśabala dogs.
Ayaḥśalmalīvana, the forests of thorns, thorns sixteen digits in length.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ sattvānāmabhirohatāṃ kaṇṭakā avāṅmukhībhavantaḥ kāyaṃ bhindanti avataratāṃ cordhvībhavantaḥ /
column2: When beings climb these trees, the thorns turn downwards, but they turn upward when they descend the tree.
Birds, Iron-beaks, tear out and eat the eyes of the damned.
These three places of suffering constitute a single Ésada because they have in common punishment through injury.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturtha utsado nadī vaitaraṇi pūrṇa taptasya kṣārodakasya yasyāṃ te sattvā asiśaktiprāsahastaiḥ
column2: The fourth wtsadaḶs the river Vaitaraṇī of boiling water loaded with burning ashes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: puruṣairubhābhyāṃ tīrābhyāṃ prativāryamāṇā ūrdhvamapi gacchantaḥ svidyante pacyante
column2: On both sides there are persons armed with swords, lances and javelins, who push back the damned who would get out.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: adhastiryagapi gacchantaḥ svidyante pacyante / tadyathā bahūdakāyāṃ sthālyāmagnāvadhiśritāyāṃ tilataṇḍuilādayaḥ /
column2: Whether they plunge into the water or emerge, whether they go up or down the current, whether they traverse in the two directions or are tossed about, the damned are boiled and cooked, as the grains of sesame or corn poured into a cauldron placed over the fire.
The river encircles the great hell like a moat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta ete catvāra utsadā digbhedena ṣoḍaśocyante /
column2: The four wsadas are sixteen in number by reason of their difference of place, since they are located at the four gates to the great hell. What is the meaning of the word uésada?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: adhikayātanāsthānitvādutsadāḥ ityucyante / narakeṣu hi patitā eteṣu punaryātyante / narakā varodhādurdhvameteṣu sīdantyutsadā ityapare /
column2: They are called wsadas because they are places of supplementary torment: in the hells the damned are tormented, but they are additionally so in the wsadas. According to Manoratha, after having been shut.
One question leads to another. We have just spoken of the "persons" who stand on the banks of the Vaitarani.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ te narakapālāḥ sattvasaṃkhyātā utāho neti / netyeke /
column2: Are the "guardians of hell" beings? They are not beings.
Then how do they move?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sattvānāṃ karmabhirvivarttanīvāyubījavat / yattrhi bhadantadharmasubhūtinoktaṃ “krodhanāḥ krūrakarmāṇaḥ pāpābhirucayaśca ye /
column2: Through the actions of beings, like the wind of creation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhiteṣu ca nandanti jāyante yamarākṣasā” iti //
column2: Then how do you explain what the Venerable Dharmasubhuti said, "Those who are angry, who take pleasure in cruel actions and transgressions, who rejoice in the sufferings of others, are reborn as Yamarakshasas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye te yamenānuśiṣṭāḥ sattvān narakeṣu prakṣipanti ta ete yamarākṣasā uktā na tu ye kāraṇāḥ kārayantīti /
column2: The demons who torment the beings in hell are not termed Yamarakshasas, the "guardians of hell' as you think; but rather the servants of Yema who, on the order of Yama, throw the damned into hell.
According to another opinion, the "guardians of hell' are beings.
Where does the retribution of the cruel acts take place that these guardians commit in the hells?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣveva narakeṣu hi ānantaryakāriṇāṃ vipākāvakāśastatra teṣāṃ ko vipratibandhaḥ /
column2: In the same hells.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamagninā na dahyante / agnernūnaṃ karmabhiḥ kṛtāvadhitvāt / bhūtaviśeṣanirvṛttervā / ime tāvaduṣṇā aṣṭau mahānarakā ucyante / śītā anye 'ṣṭāvarvudādayaḥ //
column2: Since the retribution of gnantarya transgressions takes place in these hells, why would the retribution of theBecause the force of action marks a boundary to the fire and prevents it from reaching the guardians, or rather because this same force causes the bodies of the guardians to be made up of primary elements of a special nature.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye śītanarakā aṣṭau / tadyathā arvudo nirarvudaḥ aṭato hahavaḥ huhuvaḥ utpalaḥ padmo mahāpadmaśca /
column2: There are eight other hells, the cold hells, Arbuda, etc. These hells are called Arbuda, Nirarbuda, Aṭaṭa, Hahava, Huhuva, Utpala, Padma, and Mahāpadma.
Among these names, some (Arbuda, Nirarbuda, Utpala,Padma, and Mahāpadma) indicate the form that the beings in hell take: they take the foṟmof an zrbuda,a lotus .
, the others indicate the noise that the damned make under the bite of the cold: @#aṟa These cold helis are located under Jambudvīpa, on a level with the great hells.
How is there place, under a single Jambudvīpa, for the hells which are indeed wider than Jambudvīpa?
The continents,like piles of grain,are wider at their bases.
The greatOcean does not sink into a deep, steep cavity around the continents.
The sixteen hells are created through the force of the actions of beings;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratyekaṃ narakāstu svaiḥ svaiḥ karmabhirabhinirvṛttāḥ / bahūnāṃ sattvānāṃ dvayorekasya vā /
column2: there are hells created through the force of individual actions, the actions of one being, of two beings, of many beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāmanekaprakalpo bhedaḥ sthānaṃ cāniyataṃ nadīparvatamarupradeśeṣvanyeṣu vā 'dhaśca bhāvāt /
column2: Their variety is great; their place is not determined: river, mountain, desert, and elsewhere.
The principal place of the hells is below.
As for the animals, they have three places, the land, the water, and the air.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ kila mūlaṃ sthānaṃ mahāsamudrastato 'nyatra visṛtā iti /
column2: Their principal place is the Great Ocean; the animals that are elsewhere are the surplus of the animals.
The king of the Pretas is called Yama;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya jambūdvīpasyādhastāt pañcayojanaśatāntaraparicchinnā rājadhānī teṣāṃ mūlasthānaṃ tato 'nyatra visṛtāḥ /
column2: his residence, which is the principal dwelling of the Pretas, is located five hundred leagues under Jambudvīpa; it is five hundred leagues deep and wide. The Pretas that are found elsewhere are the surplus of the Pretas. The Pretas differ much one from another;
certain of them possess supernatural powers and enjoy a glory similar to that of the gods;
see the Avadānas of the.
Upon what do the sun and the moon rest?
Upon the wind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vāyavo'ntarīkṣe sarvasattvasādhāraṇakarmādhipatyanirvṛttā āvartavat sumeruṃ parivartante / candrārkatārāṇāṃ vordhvacāraḥ /
column2: The collective force of the actions of beings produces the winds which create the moon, the sun and the stars in heaven. All these astral bodies revolve around Meru as if transported by a whirlpool.
What is the distance from here to the moon and the sun?
At mid-Meru lie the moon and the sun.
The moon and the sun move at a level with the summit of Yugandhara.
What are their dimensions?
Respectively.
Fifty and fifty and one leagues.
The disk of the moon is of fifty yojanas;
the disk of the sun is of fifty-one yojanas.
The smallest among the “houses” of the stars is of one krośa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūryavimānasyādhastāt vahiḥ sphaṭikamaṇḍalaṃ taijasamabhinirvṛttaṃ tāpanaṃ prakāśanaṃ ca /
column2: The force of the actions of beings forms, smaller than and external to the house of the sun, a disk of fire-stone, hot and luminous;
and, for the house of the moon, a disk of water-stone, cold and luminous.
Their function, according to circumstances, is to cause to arise and last the eye, the body, fruits, flowers, crops, and herbs;
and to destroy them. In a universe with its four continents there is a single sun and a single moon.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaścaturdvīpeṣu sūryo yugapat kṛtyaṃ karoti / netyāha / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: Yet the sun does not fulfill its function at the same time in the four continents.
Midnight it sets, midday it rises at the same moment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadottarakurāvardharātraṃ tadā pūrvavidehe sūryasyāstaṅgamanaṃ jambūdvīpe madhyāhno godānīye udayaḥ / evamanyeṣvapi yojyam /
column2: When it is midnight in Uttarakuru, the sun sets in Pūrvavideha, it is midday in Jambudvīpa, and it rises in Godānīya, and so on.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūryasyeha gatibhedena rātridivānāṃ vṛddhihrāsau / tatra punaḥ
column2: By reason of the variety of the progress of the sun, the days and nights grow longer and shorter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prāvṛṇmāse dvitīye 'ntyanavamyāṃ vardhate niśā / varṣāṇāṃ dvitīye māse bhādrapade dvitīyasya pakṣasya navamyāṃ vardhate rātriḥ / hemantānāṃ caturthe tu hīyate saiva hemantānāṃ caturthe māse punarhīyate /
column2: The nights grow longer after the ninth day of the second quarter of the second month of the rains, and they grow shorter after the ninth day of the second quarter of the fourth month of winter.
Reverse for the days. The days and the nights grow longer little by little accordingly as the sun goes towards the south or towards the north.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phālgunamāsasya dvitīyapakṣanavamyām / aharviparyayāt // yadā rātrirvardhate tadā divaso hīyate /
column2: The nights grow longer from the ninth day of the clear quarter of Bhādrapada on, and grow shorter from the ninth day of the clear quarter of Phālguna on.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā rātrirhīyate tadā divaso vardhate / kiyatyā mātrayā vardhate / lavaśo rātryaharvṛddhī
column2: Reverse for the days: when the nights become longer.
The days become shorter, and vice versa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te ca hānivṛddhī yathākramaṃ dakṣiṇottarage ravau / jambūdvipasya dakṣiṇaṃ pārśvaṃ gacchati bhāskare rātrivṛddhiḥ uttaraṃ gacchatyaharvṛddhiḥ /
column2: The days and the nights grow longer and shorter gradually, in proportion to the sun going towards the south or towards the north of Jambudvīpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śuklapakṣasyādau candramaso vikalaṃ maṇḍalaṃ dṛśyate / kiṃ tatra kāraṇam /
column2: Why does the disk of the moon not appear completely full at the beginning of the bright quarter?
The moon is covered by its shadow by reason of its proximity to the sun, and one sees it incompletely.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā hi saurasya vimānasyāsanne cāndramasaṃ vimānaṃ vahati tadā kila sauryo bhāsastasmin vimāne patanti /
column2: This is the teaching of the Prajñāpti, "When the house of the moon moves in the vicinity of the house of the sun, then the light of the sun falls on the house of the moon.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato 'parapārśve chāyā patantī vikalaṃ maṇḍalaṃ darśayatīti prājñaptiko nirdeśaḥ /
column2: Consequently, the shadow falls on the opposite side, and the disk appears incomplete.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vāhayogaḥ sa tādṛśo bhavati yatkadācidvimānasyārdhaṃ dṛśyata iti pūrvācāryāḥ /
column2: But, according to the ancient masters, the Yogācārins, the manner of its moving is such that the moon appears sometimes complete, sometimes incomplete.
EJ 'To what class of beings do the inhabitants of the houses of the sun, the moon and the stars belong?
These are the Cāturmahārājakāyikas, and the only ones among these gods who inhabit houses;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhūminivāsināṃ punaḥ sumerūpariṣaṇḍādīni / kati cāsya pariṣaṇḍāḥ kiyatyo vā /
column2: but there is a great number ofCāturmahārājakāyikas who inhabit the earth, in the parisaṇḍās—the stages or terraces—of Meru and elsewhere.

There are four terraces, the distance between them being ten thousand leagues,extending out sixteem, eight, four and two thousand leagues. They are the Karoṭapāṇis, the Mālādharas, the Sadāmattas and the two Mahārājikas; and also on the seven mountains.
The first terrace is ten thousand leagues above the water, the second ten thousand leegues above the firstandso on.
They thus reach up to the middle of Meru.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣoḍaśāṣṭau sahasrāṇi catvāri dve ca nirgatāḥ // prathamā pariṣaṇḍā ṣoḍaśa sahasrāṇi yojanānāṃ sumerornirgatā /
column2: The first terrace extends out from Meru sixteen thousand leagues;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyā 'ṣṭau tṛtīyā catvāri caturthī dve / karoṭapāṇayastāsu mālādhārāssadāmadāḥ / mahārājikadevāśca
column2: the others, in their order extend out eight, four, two thousánd leagues.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamāyāṃ pariṣaṇḍāyāṃ karoṭapāṇayo nāma yakṣāḥ prativasanti / dvitīyāyāṃ mālādhārāstṛtīyāyāṃ sadāmadāḥ sadāmattāḥ /
column2: On the first terrace reside the Yakṣas “Pitcher in their Haṇd”: on the second, the “Wearers of Crowns;
” on the third the “Always Intoxicated” : all these gods belong to the Cāturmahārājakāyikas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturthyāṃ tu catvāro mahārājāḥ svayaṃ prativasanti tatparicārāśca / atastasyāṃ mahārājakāyikā devā ityuktam / yathā pariṣaṇḍāsu caturmahārājakāyikā devā evaṃ parvateṣvapi saptasu // yugandharādiṣu parvateṣu teṣāṃ grāmanigamāḥ /
column2: At the fourth terrace are the Four Kings in person with their attendants: these gods are called the Cāturmahārājakāyikas, the Four Great Kings.
Also the gods of this class are the most numerous of the gods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: merumūrdhni trayastriṃśāḥ atha kiyānmerumūrdhā / sa cāśītisahasradik /
column2: The Thirty-three Gods are at the summit of Meru, the sides of which are eighty thousand.

At the corners, four peaks which the Vajrapāṇis inhabit. In the middle, with sides of two thousand five hundred, with a height of one and a half, is a village called Sudarśana, of gold, with a variegated and smooth sun.
There is Vaijayanta, with sides of two hundred fifty.
On the outside, this village is adorned with Caitraratha, Pāruṣya, Miśra and Naṇdana;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekaikaṃ pārśvaṃ viṃśatiryojanasahasrāṇi samantāt parikṣepeṇāśītiriti // tasya ca vidikṣu kūṭāścatvāra uṣitā vajrapāṇibhiḥ //
column2: at a distance of twenty thousand leagues from these Parks, at the four sides, there are excellent fields.
At the northeast Pārijāta, in the southwest Suḍharmā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāsu pañcayojanaśatapramāṇāścatvāraḥ kūṭā abhyudgatā yeṣu vajrapāṇayo nāma yakṣāḥ prativasanti / tasya ca merumūrdhnaḥ madhye sārdhadvisāhasrapārśvamadhyardhayojanam / puraṃ sudarśanaṃ nāma haimaṃ citratalaṃ mṛdu //
column2: At the corners, there are peaks, five hundred yojanas high and wide, where the Yakṣas called Vajrapāṇis reside.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sumerutalasya madhye sudarśanaṃ nāma nagaram dairdhye sārdhatṛtīyayojanasahasre ekaikaṃ parśvamucchrāyeṇādhyardhayojanam /
column2: In the middle of the plateau of Meru there is the royal city of Śakra, the chief of the gods, a city called “Beautiful to Look At”. Its sides are two thousand five hundred yojanas; its circumference is ten thousand; its height one yo/ana and a half;
it is of gold; it is adorned with one hundred and one types of colors; and the same for its sun.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tacca bhūmitalaṃ tūlapicuvat mṛdusaṃsparśaṃ pādakṣepotkṣepābhyāṃ natonnataṃ śakrasya devānāmindrasya rājadhānī / sārdhadviśatapāśrvo 'tra vaijayantaḥ
column2: This sun is soft to the touch, like the leaf of the cotton tree;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śakrasya devānāmindrasya vaijayanto nāma prāsādo nagarasya madhye nānāratnasthānavidhānasaṃpadā sarvānyabhavanaśrīmahimnā hrepaṇo dairdhyeṇārdhatṛtīye yojanaśate pārśvaṃ pārśvam / iyaṃ tāvannagarasyābhirāmatā / bahiḥ punaḥ /
column2: it rises and falls to facilitate its progress. In the middle of this city there is the palace of Śakra, the chief of the gods, called Vaijayanta: it makes all the other residences blush by its richness and its gems. Its sides are two hundred fifty yojanas.
Such are the adornments of the city itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya hi nagarasya bahiścaturṣu pārśveṣu catvāryudyānādīni devānāṃ kriḍābhūmayaḥ / caitrarathamudyānaṃ pāruṣyakaṃ miśrakāvaṇaṃ nandanavanaṃ ca / taistannagaraṃ bahiralaṅkṛtam / viṃśatyantaritānyeṣāṃ subhūmīni caturdiśam /
column2: Ornaments outside of the city are the four Parks: Caitraṟatha, Pāruṣyaka, Miśraka, and Nandana, fields of play for the gods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣāṃ codyānānāṃ caturdiśaṃ catvāri sumūmīni viṃśatiyojanāntaritāni krīḍāsthānānyeva devānāṃ parasparaspardhayaiva śobhāṃ vitanvanti / vahireva nagarasya pārśve pūrvottare pārijātaḥ sudharmā dakṣiṇāvare //
column2: At the four sides of these Parks, from a distance of twenty yojanas on, there are four fields of play with a marvellous sun, delightful and which appears to rival them.
The magnolia tree called Pārijātaka is, for the Thirty-three Gods, the place par excellence for pleasure and for love;
its roots go down fifty yojanas; it is one hundred yojanas high;
with its branches, leaves and petals, it covets fifty yojanas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya khalu sarvapariphullasya yojanaśatamanuvātaṃ gandho vāti pañcāśadyojana yojanāni prativātam / yuktaṃ tāvadanuvātam /
column2: The fragrance of its flowers spreads one hundred yojanas away with the wind, fifty against the wind.

So be it, it can spread to one hundred yojanas with the wind, but how can it go against the wind? According to one opinion, one says that it spreads to fifty yojanar against the wind, because it does not go beyond the tree.
The text says that it goes against the wind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi nāma sprativātaṃ vāto vāti / tasyaiva tu sā gandhasya tādṛśo prabhāvasaṃpadeṣṭavyā yāt pratibadhyamāno'pi divyairmṛdumārutairgandhāntaraṃ saṃtanoti / mandataratamasamārambhāttu saṃtāna āśveva samucchidyate yato na tathā viprakṛṣṭamadhvānaṃ prasarpati /
column2: We say then that the fragrance does not go against the wind, that it perishes where it arises: but such is the quality of this fragrance that, even though it would be arrested by the lightest divine wind, it gives. Nevertheless, the fragrances become weak, weaker, entirely weak and are completely arrested, incapable of going as far as itdoes when the wind is favorable. Does the series of this fragrance have for its support only its own primary elements which constitute the fragrance?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ svabhūtāśrita evamapuṣpagandhasaṃtāno vartate utāho vāyuradhivāsito jāyate /
column2: Or rather should one suppose that the wind becomes perfumed?
The opinion of the masters is not fixed on this.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi bhagavatoktaṃ “na puṣpagandhaḥ prativātameti na maulikastāgaraścāndano vā /
column2: Yet the Blessed One said, “The fragrance of flowers does not go against the wind, neither does the fragrance of good go against the wind;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satāṃ tu gandhaḥ prativātameti sarvā diśaḥ satpuruṣaḥ pravātī“ti /
column2: but the sapurusa goes in all directions.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mānuṣyakaṃ puṣpagandhaṃ saṃdhāyoktam / taddhi pratītaṃ loke /
column2: How do you reconcile this statement with the theory that fragrance “goes against the wind?”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca tasya tādṛśī śaktiḥ mahīsāsakāstu pathanti “yojanaśatamanuvātaṃ gandho vāti pañcāśadyojanāni prativātamiti /
column2: This statement refers to odors of the world of humans, which, it is quite evident, does not go against the wind. The Mahisasakas read, “The fragrance of the flowers of the”the Parijataka tree goes with the wind for a hundred yojanas in the absence of wind to fifty.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sudharmā nāma devasabhā dakṣiṇapaścime digbhāge yasyāṃ niṣadya devāḥ kṛtyākṛtyaṃ samarthayanti /
column2: In the southeast lies Sudharma the room where the gods come together in order to examine the good and the evil deeds committed by human beings.
Such is the arrangement of the receptacle or physical world of the Thirty-three Gods.
Above the gods reside in houses.
The gods higher than the Thirty-three Gods reside in vomanas or aerial abodes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te punaryāmāstuṣitā nirmāṇaratayaḥ paranirmitavaśavartinaśca brahmakāyikādayaśca pūrvoktāḥ ṣoḍaśasthānāntaragatāḥ /
column2: These gods are the Yamas, the Tusitas, the Nirmāṇaratis, and the Paranirmitavasavartins, plus the gods of Rupadhatu, namely sixteen categories of gods beginning with the Brahmakayikas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ityete dvāviṃśatidevanikāyāḥ samāsena yeṣāṃ bhājanaṃ prajñāyate /
column2: In all, twenty-two types of gods live in the physical world and occupy set residences. There are six gods who taste pleasure they unite through coupling, an embrace, the touch of hands, a smile, and a look.
The Cāturmahārājakāyikas, Trāyastriṁśas, Yāmas, Tuṣitas, Nirmāṇaratis and Paranirmitavaśavartiḥs are the gods of Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ tu ṣaṭ kāmāvacarā devanikāyāḥ kāmān paribhuñjate na śeṣāḥ / tadyathā caturmahārājakāyikā yāvat paranirmitavaśavartinaḥ / te punaḥ dvandvāliṅganapāṇyāptihasitekṣitamaithunāḥ // dvandvena maithunaṃ bhūmisambaddhavāsinām /
column2: The higher gods are not in Kāmadhātu.
The Cāturmahārājakāyikas and the Trāyastrithśas live on the ground; thus they unite by coupling, like humans;
but they appease the fire of their desire through the emission of wind, since they do not have any semen.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āliṅganena maithunaṃ yāmānāmāliṅganamātreṇa dāhavigamāt / pāṇisaṃprāptyā tuṣitānāṃ hasitena nirmāṇaratīnāṃ prekṣitena paranirmitavaśavartinām / svavartināṃ sarveṣāṃ dvandvasamāpattyā /
column2: The Yāmas appease the fire of their desire by embracing, the Tuṣitas by the touch of hands, the Nirmāṇaratis by smiling, and the Paranirmitavaśavartins by looking at each other. Such is the doctrine of the Prajñapti.
According to the Vaibhāṣikas, these expressions of the Prajñapti, "embracing," "touching of the hands," etc. , do not indicate the mode of union—for all the gods couple—but the duration of the act.
The more ardent the desire by reason of the more pleasurable object, so much shorter is the duration of the union.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya devasya devyā vā utsaṅge devakumāro devakanyā vā jāyate sa tayoḥ putro bhavati sā ca duhitā / kiyatpramāṇo jāyate /
column2: A small god or goddess appears on the knees, or from out of the knees of a god or goddess; this small god or goddess is their son or. Among these gods, their newborn are similar to infants of five to ten years.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcavarṣopamo yāvat daśavarṣopamaḥ śiśuḥ / saṃbhavatyeṣu yathāsaṃkhyaṃ ṣaṭsu devanikāyeṣu /
column2: From five to ten years according to the category of the gods.
Young gods grow up quickly.
The gods of Rūpadhātu are complete and clothed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāvacarā devāḥ saṃpūrṇakāyāḥ vastreṇa saṃvītā upapadyante /
column2: The gods of Rūpadhātu, from their birth, are complete in their development; they are born fully clothed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarve devā āryabhāṣābhāṣiṇaḥ / tadatra kāmadhātau veditavyāḥ
column2: All the gods speak the Āryan language.
In Kāmadhātu, there are three “arisings” of the objects of desire: the gods of Kāmadhātu together with humans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santi sattvāḥ pratyupasthitakāmāḥ pratyupasthiteṣu kāmeṣvaiśvaryaṃ vaśe vartayanti /
column2: There are beings whose objects of desire are placed at their disposition; but they are able to dispose of these objects.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā manuṣyāstadekatyāśca devāḥ / te punaścatvāro devanikāyāḥ /
column2: These are humans and certain gods—namely the first four classes of gods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santi sattvā nirmitakāmā nirmāya kāmānaiśvarya vaśe vartayanti /
column2: There are beings whose objects of desire are created by themselves; and they dispose of these objects which they create.
These are the Nirmāṇaratis.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santi sattvāḥ paranirmitakāmāḥ paranirmiteṣu kāmeṣvaiśvarya vaśe varttayanti /
column2: There are beings whose objects of desire are created by others but who themselves dispose of these objects created by others. These are the.
The first enjoy the objects of desire which are presented to them; the second enjoy objects of desire which they create at their will;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tā etā yathot pannaparibhogitvāt yathecchātmanirmitaparibhogitvādyathecchātmapara nirmitaparibhogitvācca tisraḥ kāmopapattaya ityucyante /
column2: and the third enjoy objects of desire that they create or have others create at their will. These are the three arisings of the objects of desire.
In Rūpadhātu, 71c-d.
There are three "arisings of pleasure": the nine spheres of three Dhyānas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: triṣu dhyāneṣu yā nava bhūmayaḥ tāstisraḥ sukhopapattayaḥ /
column2: The nine spheres of the first three Dhyānas are the three "arisings of pleasure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te hi devā vivekajena samādhijena ca prītisukhena ca niṣprītikena ca sukhena sukhaṃ viharanto dīrghamadhvānaṃ tiṣṭhanti /
column2: The gods of the first three Dhyānas, for long periods, pass their time pleasantly through pleasure born from separation from the defilements, through pleasure consisting of joy arising from absorption and through pleasure free from joy (nirupritikasukha, seeing the disappearance of satisfaction or rawmanasya).
By reason of their absence of suffering, and by reason of their duration, these arisings are indeed "arisings of pleasure.
In dhyānāntara there is no pleasure consisting of joy. Is this an "arising of pleasure?

At what height are the twenty-two heavenly residences situated, starting from the Cāturmahārājikas to the highest gods of Rūpadhātu?
naitat sarvaṃ yojanaparisaṃkhyayā sukaraṃ parisaṃkhyātum /	It is not easy to calculate this height in yojanas, but 72a-b.
api tu sthānāt sthānādadho yāvattāvadūrdhvaṃ tatastataḥ /	To the extent that there is descent from one residence, to this extent there is ascent towards a higher residence.
jambūdvīpāt prabhṛti yaduttaraṃ sthānaṃ tasmādyāvadadho jambūdvīpastāvat punastasmādūrdhvaṃ sthānāntaram /	In other words, to the extent that a residence is above Jambudvīpa, to that extent it is below its next higher residence.
tadyathā caturthī pariṣaṇḍā caturṇāṃ mahārājānāṃ mūlasthānamitaścatvāriṃśadyojanasahasrāṇi /	For example, the fourth house of the Cāturmahārājikas, the dwelling of the Cāturmahārājikas themselves is forty thousand yojanas above here;
tasmādyāvadadhojambūdvīpastāvadūrdhvaṃ tridaśānāṃ sthānam tasmādapi yāvadadho jambūdvīpastāvadūrdhvaṃ yāmānāṃ sthānam /	to the extent that this residence descends to here, to that extent this residence ascends to the residence of the Trāyatriṁśas, [on the summit of Meru, eighty thousand yojanas from here]. As many yojanas as there are from Trāyastrithśas to here, that many are there from Trāyastriṁśas to the Yāmas.
tato'pi yāvadadho jambūdvīpastāvadūrdhvaṃ tuṣitānāṃ sthānamiti / evaṃ vistareṇa sarvamanukramya sudarśanebhyo yāvadadho jambūdvīpastāvadūrdhvaṃmakaniṣṭhānāṃ sthānam /	And thus following: the Akaniṣṭhas are above the Sudarśanas the same number of yojanas that the Sudarśanas are above Jambudvīpa.
tasmādūrdhvaṃ na punaḥ sthānamasti / ata eva jyeṣṭhabhūtvādakaniṣṭhā ucyante /	Above the Akaniṣṭhas, there are no more residences.
aghaniṣṭhā ityapare / aghaṃ kila cittasthaṃ rūpaṃ tanmātraniṣṭheti /	This is because this residence is higher than the others, no residence is superior to it, and so it is called niṣrha. Accoṟding to another opinion, this residence is called agha-nisṭha, because agha signifies assembled matter", and this residence is the limit of this matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaradharasthānopapannā urdhvāni vimānāni gatvā paśyanti
column2: Can a being born in an inferior residence go to a higher house and see its superior beings?
The gods do not see their superiors without magic or the assistence of another.
When they possess magical powers, or when they are assisted by a being possessing magical powers or by a Yāma god, the Trāyastriṁśas can go to the Yāmas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gaccheyuḥ / parāśrayeṇa vā yadvṛddhimatā nīyeran devena vā tatratyena / evaṃ śeṣāḥ /
column2: and thus following.
A being born in an lower residence can see a being born in a higher residence who makes a visit to an inferior residence, but not if this being belongs to a higher Dhātu, or to a higher óh%mi.
In the same way that one cannot feel a tangible things, because it is not of the sphere. This is why beings higher.
through their Dhātu or bhmi do not descend with their own bodies, but with a magic body of the sphere of the bhāmi to where they wish to descend.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tarhi nirmitenādharabhūmikena tadicchayā paśyedihatyamiveti nikāyāntarīyāḥ /
column2: According to another school, if a being of a higher bhāmi so desires, lower beings can see him in the same way as they see a being of their own bhāmi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athaiṣāṃ yāmādivimānānāṃ kiyat pramāṇam / caturṇāṃ tāvadyāvatsumerumūrdhnaḥ ityeke / dviguṇottaramityapare /
column2: What are the dimensions of the houses of the Yāmas and the other According to one opinion, the houses of the four types of higher gods of Yāma have the dimension of the summit of Meru.
According to others, the dimension of the First Dhyāna is the dimension of the universe with its four continents;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīyaṃ yāvān sāhasraścūḍiko lokadhātuḥ / tṛtīyaṃ yāvān dvisāhasraḥ /
column2: that of the Second, the Third, and the Fourth Dhyāna is, respectively, the dimension of a small, medium and great chiliocosm.
According to another, the first three Dhyāṇnas have, respectively, the dimension of a small, medium and great chiliocosm;
the Fourth Dhyāṇna is without measure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha ko'yaṃ sāhasraścūḍiko lokadhātuḥ ko dvisāhasrastrisāhasro vā /
column2: What is a small, a second, and a third chiliocosm?
One thousand four-continents, moons, suns, Merus. The destruction and the creation of the universes lasts the same time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sahasrañjaṃbūdvīpānāṃ pūrvavidehānāmaparagodānīyānāmuttarakuruṇāṃ sahasraṃ sūryāṇāṃ candrāṇāṃ sumerūṇāṃ sahasraṃ cāturmahārājakāyikānāṃ devānāṃ yāvat paranirmitavaśavartināṃ
column2: A small chiliocosm is made up of one thousand Jambudvīpas, Pūrvavidehas, Avaragodānīyas, Uttarakurus, moons, suns, Merus, dwellings of the Cāturmahārājakāyikas and the other gods of Kāmadhātu, and worlds of Brahmā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sahasraṃ brahmalokānāmayamucyate sāhasraścūḍiko lokadhātuḥ / tatsahasraṃ dvisāhasro lokadhātustu madhyamaḥ / teṣāṃ cūḍikānāṃ lokadhātūnāṃ sahasraṃ dvisāhasro madhyamo lokadhātuḥ /
column2: One thousand universes of this type make a dichiliocosm, a middle universe.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatsahasraṃ trisāhasraḥ teṣāṃ dvisāhasrāṇāṃ lokadhātūnāṃ sahasraṃ trisāhasramahāsāhasro lokadhātuḥ / eṣa hi kṛtsnaḥ
column2: One thousand universes of this type make a trichilomegachiliocosm.
The periods of destruction and creation are equal in length. The stanza uses the word sa?
%bhava in the sense of vivarta.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ khalu yathā bhājanānāṃ pramāṇabheda evaṃ tadvāsināmapi sattvānāṃ pramāṇabhedo'sti / astītyāha /
column2: In the same way that the dimensions of the physical worlds differ, in that same way the dimensions of the beings inhabiting them differ.

The inhabitants of Jambudvīpa have a height of four, or of. The bodies of the gods of Kāmadhātu increase by quarters of krosśa, until a ér052 aṇḍ a half. The bodies of the gods of Rūpadhātu are at first a half yojana; then increase by a half; beyond the Parīttābhas, the bodies double, and reduce three yojanas from the Anabhṛrakas on.
Humans of Jambudvīpa generally are three elbows and a half, sometimes four elbows in height;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dviguṇottaravṛddhyā tu pūrvagodottarāhvayāḥ // pūrvavidehakā godānīkā uttarakauravāśca manuṣyā aṣṭaṣoḍaśadvātriṃśaddhastakā yathākramam / pādavṛddhyā tanuryāvatsārdhakrośo divaukasām / kāmināṃ pādaḥ krośasya caturtho bhagaḥ /
column2: the Pūrvavidehakas, the Avaragodānīyakas, and the Auttarakauṟavas are reṣpectively eight, sixteen, and thirty-two elbows in height.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tanmātraṃ śarīraṃ cāturmahārājakāyikānāṃ dvau pādau trāyastriṃśānāṃ trayo yāmānāṃ catvārastuṣitānāṃ pañca nirmāṇaratīnāṃ adhyardhaḥ krośaḥ paranirmitavaśavartinām
column2: The Cāturmahārājakāyikas are a quarter of a érosa in height; the height of the other gods of Kġāmadhātu increases successively by this same quarter: the Trāyastriṁśas,by half a éroa; the Yāmas, by three quarters ofa krośa; the Tuṣitas,by one érośa;
the Nī irmāṇaratis, by a krośa and a quarter; and the Parinirmitavasśavartiṉs, by a krośz and a half.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpiṇāṃ devānāṃ prathame sthāne brahmakāyikānāmardhayojanamātraṃ śarīram / tataḥ param //
column2: The Brahmakāyikas, who are the first gods of Rāpadhātu, are a half-yojana in height;
the Brahmapurohitas, one yojana in beight;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: triṣu sthānesu brahmapurohitānāṃ yojanaṃ mahābrahmaṇo 'dhyardhaṃ parīttābhānāṃ dve yojane / urdhvaṃ tu parīttābhebhya āśrayaḥ /
column2: theMahabrahmans, one yojana and a half in height;
and the Parittabhas, two yojanas in height.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apramāṇābhānāṃ catvāri yojanāni / ābhāsvarāṇāmaṣṭau / evaṃ dviguṇavṛddhyā yāvacchubhakṛtsnānāṃ catuḥṣaṣṭiḥ /
column2: Beyond the Parittabhas, the dimensions double: Apramanabhas are four, Abhasvaras, eight, and the same until the Subhakrtsans, who are sixty-four yojanas in height.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anabhrakāṇāṃ tato yojanatrayeṇa hīnaṃ dviguṇaṃ pañcaviṃśatiyojana śatam /
column2: For the Anabhrakas, one doubles this number but subtracts three: they are then one hundred twenty-five gojanas in height.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt pareṇa punaḥ puṇyaprasavānāṃ dviguṇaṃ dviguṇaṃ yāvadakaniṣṭhānāṃ ṣoḍaśayojanasahasrāṇi śarīram /
column2: One continues doubling, from the Punyaprasavas on who are two hundred fifty yojanas in height, to the Akanisthas, who are sixteen thousand yojanas in height.
The length of life of these beings also differs.
With regard to humans: Life, among Kurus, is one thousand years in length;
in the two continents, it diminishes twice by half; here, it is indeterminate: nevertheless it is ten years at the end and incalculable at the beginning.
The lifespan of beings in Godanaiya is half the lifespan of beings in Uttarakuru, thus five hundred years in length;
the life of beings in Purvavideha is two hundred and fifty years in length.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ihāniyatam jambūdvīpe nāstyāyuṣo niyamaḥ kadācit bhūyo bhavati kadācidalpīyaḥ /
column2: In Jambudvīpa, length of life is not determined, sometimes it is long, sometimes short.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ante tu daśābdāḥ abdaḥ saṃvatsaraḥ / ante hīyamānaṃ daśa varṣāṇyāyurbhavati / ādito'mitam //
column2: At the end of the cosmic age or kalpa, at its minimum, it is ten years;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āditaḥ prāthamakalpikānaṃ manuṣyāṇāmaparimāṇamāyurbhavati / sahasrādisaṃkhyayā parimātuṃ na śakyate / uktaṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ devānāṃ vaktavyam / taccāhorātraṃ vyavasthāpya śakyaṃ vaktumiti sa eva caiṣāṃ vyavasthāpyate /
column2: whereas the lifespan of humans at the beginning of the cosmic age is incalculable: one cannot measure it by counting in thousands, etc. ‘The lifespan of the gods of Kāmadhātu is an integral of the length of a day: 79a-80b.
Fifty human years make a day-and-night for the lowest gods of Kāmadhātu, and these gods live a life of five hundred years. For the higher gods, double the day and the life.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāni manuṣyāṇāṃ pañcāśadvarṣāṇi tāni kāmadhātāvadharāṇāṃ devānāṃ cāturmahārājakāyikānāmekaṃ rātrindivam / tenāyuḥ pañcavarṣaśatāni tu // tena tatastenāhorātreṇa teṣāṃ triṃśadrātrakeṇa māsena dvādaśamāsakena saṃvatsareṇa divyāni pañcavarṣaśatānyāyuḥ pramāṇam / dviguṇottaramūrdhvānāmubhayaṃ ūrdhvānāṃ devānāmubhaya dviguṇottaramahorātraścāyuśca / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: Fifty human days make a day in the life of the Cāturmahārājakāyikas, whose lifespan is of five hundred years of twelve month of thirty days.
For the Trāyastrithśas, one day equals one hundred human years, and their lifespan is one thousand years in length;
for the Yāmas, one day equals two hundred human years and their lifespan is two thousand years in length;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yāmādīnāṃ yathākramam / mānuṣyakāṇi dve catvāryaṣṭau ṣoḍaśa varṣaśatānyekaṃ rātrindivam / tena rātrindevena dve catvāryaṣṭau ṣoḍaśa divyāni varṣasahasrāṇyāyuṣaḥ pramāṇam /
column2: and so on.
But there is no sun or moon above Yugandhara;
how is a day of the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: puṣpāṇāṃ saṃkocavikāsātkumudabandhu vat śakunīnāṃ kūjanākūjanāt middhāpagamāgamācca ālokakṛtyaṃ svayaṃprabhatvāt / uktamāyuḥ kāminām /
column2: Day and night are marked by the flowers which open or close, like the kumuda and the padma in the world of humans; by the birds that sing or that are silent; and by sleep which ends or begins. Furthermore the gods themselves are luminous.
As for the gods of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu: There is no day and night for the gods of Rūpadhātu;
