their lifespans are calculated in £lpas whose number is fixed by the dimensions of their bodies.
In Ārūpyadhātu, a lifespan of a thousand éapas which increases as much.
These kalpas are, from the Parīttābhas on, mahākalpas; below, halves. The gods of Rūpadhātu whose bodies are half a yojana in height— the Brahmakāyikas—live a half kalpa;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yasya yāvadyojanamāśrayastasya tāvatkalpamāyuryavadakaniṣṭhānāṃ ṣoḍaśakalpasahasrāṇyāyuḥ pramāṇam /
column2: and thus following to the Akaṇniṣṭhas, whose bodies are sixteen thousand yojanas in height, and whose lifespan is thus sixteen thousand éa/pas in length.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārūpye viṃśatiḥ kalpasahasrāṇya dhikādhikam / ākāśānantyāyatane viṃśatikalpasahasrāṇyāyuṣaḥ pramāṇam /
column2: In Ākāśānantyāyatana, a lifeṣpan is twenty thousand kalpas in length;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vijñānānantyāyatane tasmādadhikaṃ viṃśatiḥ sahasrāṇi / ākiñcanyāyatane tasmādadhikaṃ viṃśatiḥ / bhavāgre tasmādadhikaṃ viṃśatiḥ / evaṃ teṣāṃ yathākramaṃ viṃśatiścatvāriṃśat ṣaṣṭiraśītiḥ kalpasahasrāṇyāyuḥpramāṇam /
column2: fifty thousand ka/pas in length in Vijñānānantyāyatana, sixty.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katamo'tra kalpo veditavyaḥ kimantarakalpo'tha saṃvartakalpo'tha vivarttakalpo'tha mahākalpaḥ /
column2: But to which kalpas does this refer to intermediate kalpas, to kalpas of destruction, to kalpas of creation, or to great kalpas?
From the Parīttābhas on, they refer to the great kalpas;
below they refer to half great kalpas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādadho mahākalpasyārdha kalpīkṛtya mahābrahmādīnāmāyurvyavasthāpitam / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: In fact, there are twenty amtarakaḻpas during which the world is created: Mahābrahmā appears from the beginning;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yacca loko viṃśatimantarakalpān vivartate yacca loko viṃśatimantarakalpānvivarta
column2: then twenty entarakalpas during which the world lasts;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āste yacca viṃśatimantarakalpānsaṃvartate ime ṣaṣṭirantarakalpā mahābrahmaṇo'dhyardhaḥ kalpaḥ uktaḥ /
column2: and then twenty amtarakalpas during which the world is destroyed. Thus the life of Mahabrahma lasts sixty intermediate antarakalpas: these sixty make a kalpa and a half; half a great kalpa is considered to be a kalpa. What is the length of a lifespan in the painful realms of rebirth?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca kṛtvā mahākalpasyārdhaṃ catvāriṃśadantarakalpān kalpīkṛtya teṣāmāyuḥ pramāṇamuktam / uktaṃ sugatāvāyuḥ pramāṇam / durgatāvidānīṃ vaktavyam / tatra tāvat
column2: Let us examine in order the first six hot hells, the lest two hot hells, animals, Pretas, and the cold hells.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadevāyuṣā tulyā ahorātrā yathākramam / saṃjīvādiṣu ṣaṭsu
column2: In six hells, Saṁjīva, etc. , a day and night has the length of the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvat ṣaṇṇāṃ kāmāvacarāṇāṃ devanikāyānāmāyuruktaṃ tena tulyā ahorātrāḥ ṣaṭṣu narakeṣu yathākramaṃ veditavyāḥ / saṃjīve kālasūtre saṃghāte raurave mahāraurave tāpane ca / āyustaisteṣāṃ kāmadevavat // tairidānīṃ svairahorātraisteṣāṃ yathā ṣaṇṇāṃ kāmāvacarāṇāṃ devānāmāyustathaiva yathākramaṃ veditavyam / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: A day in the six hells is equal to the life of the gods of Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaddhi cāturmahārājakāyikānāmāyuḥ pramāṇaṃ tatsaṃjīvane mahānarake ekaṃ rātrindivaṃ / tena yāvat dvādaśamāsakena saṃvatsareṇa tatratyāni pañcavarṣaśatānyāyuḥ / yattrāyastriṃśānāmāyuḥ pramāṇaṃ tat kālasūtre mahānarake ekaṃ rātrindivam / tena rātrindivena tasminvarṣasahasrāṇyāyuḥpramāṇaṃ /
column2: The damned in Saṁjīva have a life of five hundred years of twelve months of thirty days, but each of these days has the length of the total lifespan of the Cāturmahārājakāyikas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamanyeṣvapi yathāyogaṃ yojyaṃ yāvat paranirmitavaśavartināmāyuḥpramāṇaṃ tattulyenāhorātreṇa tāpane ṣoḍaśa varṣasahasrāṇyāyuḥpramāṇam /
column2: Same relationship between the damned of Kālasūtra and the Trāyastriṁhśas, and between the damned of Tapana and the Paranirmitavaśavartinṇs.
In Pratāpana, a lifespan of a half;
in Avīdi, a lifespan of one antaḥkalpa. In Pratapana, a lifespan lasts one half of an ansarakalpa;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avīcāvantaḥkalpaṃ tiraścāṃ tu niyamo nāsti / paraṃ punaḥ /
column2: in Avīci, one antarakalpa.
The life of animals is one kapla in length at most;
the life of the Pretas is five hundred years with its days the duration of a month. The animals that live the longest time live one ansarakalpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ hi bhagavatā “aṣṭāvime bhikṣavo nāgā mahānāgāḥ kalpasthā dharaṇidharā” iti vistaraḥ / pretānāṃ māsāhnā śatapañcakam //
column2: The Blessed One said, “There are, Oh Bhikṣus, eight great Nāga Kings who live a kalpa and who sustain the eaṟth.”
'The days of the Pretas have a length of one human month;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tenāhorātreṇa pañca varṣaśatānyāyuḥ / śītanarakeṣvāyuṣaḥ kiṃ pramāṇam /
column2: they live five hundred years made up of days of this length.
Life in the Arbudas is the time of the exhaustion of avāha, by taking a grain of sesame every one hundred years;
the others by multiplying each time by twenty.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upamānamātreṇa teṣvāyurākhyātaṃ bhagavatā “tadyathā bhikṣavaḥ iha syādviṃśatikhārīko māgadhakastilavāhaḥ pūrṇastilānāṃ cūḍikāvaddhaḥ /
column2: The Blessed One has indicated the length of a lifespan in the cold hells only through comparisons, “If, Oh Bhikṣus, a Magadhan vāha of sesame of eighty khāris were full of sesame seeds;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ kaścideva varṣaśatasyātyayādekaṃ tilamapanayate kṣiprataraṃ bhikṣavaḥ saviṃśatikhārīko māgadhastilavāho'nenopakrameṇa parikṣayaṃ paryādānaṃ gacchet / na tvevāhamarvudopapannānāmāyuṣaḥ paryantaṃ vadāmi /
column2: if one were to take one grain each one hundred years, this vāha would be empty before a lifespan of beings born in the Arbuda hell would end: this is what I say.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā khalu bhikṣavo viṃśatirvudā evameko nirarvudo vistareṇa yathā khalu bhikṣavo viṃśatiḥ padyā evameko mahāpadma” iti /
column2: And, Oh Bhikṣus, twenty Arbudas make, Oh Bhikṣus, one Nirarbuda.”
Do all beings, whose length of lifespan has just been indicated, live the full length of this lifespan?
With the exception of Kuru, there is death before their.
The life of beings in Uttarakuru is fixed; they necessarily live one thousand years: their length of life is complete.
Everywhere else there is antarāmr̥tyu, death in the course of, in the middle of, a complete life,” or premature death.

Nevertheless certain persons are sheltered from premature death, namely the Bodhisattva who, in Tusṣita, is no longer bound to birth; a being in his last existence who will not die before having obtained the state of Arhat; one who has been the objectof a prediction by the Blessed One; one who is sent by the Blessed One;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tuṣitastharsyakajātibaddhasya bodhisattvasya caramabhavikasattvasya jinādiṣṭasya jinabhutasya śraddhādharmānusāriṇo bodhisattvacakravarttimātrośca tadgarbhayorityevamādinām /
column2: a Śraddhānusārin and a Dharmānusārin who will not die before having become a Śraddhādhimuktika and a Drṣṭiprāpta;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yojanapramaṇena sthānāni śarīrāṇi cotkāni varṣapramāṇenāyuruktaṃ tayośca pramāṇaṃ noktamiti vaktavyaṃ nānā ca sarveṣāṃ vavasthānamatastasyāpi paryanto vaktavyaḥ /
column2: a woman pregnant with the Bodhisattva or with a Cakravartin, etc. We have explained the residences and the bodies by measuring them in terms of yojanas, and lifespans by measuring them in terms of years; but we have not explained yo/anas and years.
These can be explained only through the means of words.
An atom, a syllable, and an instant is the limit of matter, of words, and of time.
A paramāṇu īs the limit of physical matter; so too a syllable is the limit of words, for example, go;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kālasya paryantaḥ kṣaṇo nāmnaḥ paryanto'kṣaraṃ tadyathā gauriti /
column2: and an instant, the limit of time.
What is the dimension of an instant?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samagreṣu pratyayeṣu yāvatā dharmasyātmalābhaḥ gacchanvā dharmo yāvatā paramāṇoḥ paramāṇvantaraṃ gacchati /
column2: If the right conditions are present, the time that it takes for adharma to arise; or rather the time that it takes for a dharma in progress to go from one paramāṇu to another paramāṇu.
According to the Ābhidhārmikas, there are sixty-five instants in the time that it takes a healthy man to snap his fingers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: lohāpaśaśāvigocchidrarajolikṣāstadudbhavāḥ / yavastathāṅgulīparva jñeyaṃ saptaguṇottaram // etatparamāṇvādikaṃ saptaguṇottaraṃ veditavyam / sapta paramāṇavo'ṇuḥ /
column2: j̃ṇu, aṇu, loharajas, abrajas, faśarajas, avirajas, gorajas, chidrarajas, likṣā, that which comes out of thekā, yava, and aṅñguliparvan, by multiplying each time by seven;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saptāṇavo loharajaḥ / tāni saptāvrajastāni sapta dāśarajastāni saptaiḍakarajaḥ / tāni sapta gorajaḥ tāni sapta vātāyanacchidrarajaḥ / tāni sapta likṣāstadudbhavā yūketyarthaḥ / sapta yūkā yavaḥ / sapta yavā aṅgulīparva trīṇi parvāṇyaṅgurīti prasiddhameveti noktam /
column2: twenty-four añguls make one hasta;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pārśvākṛtāstu / caturviṃśatiraṅgulyo hasto hastacatuṣṭayam / dhanuḥ vyāsenetyarthaḥ / pañcaśatānyeṣāṃ krośo raṇyaṃ ca tanmatam //
column2: four hastas make one dhanus;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: manuṣāṃ pañca śatāni krośaḥ / krośamātraṃ ca grāmādi raṇyamiṣṭam /
column2: five hundred dhanus make one krośa, the distance a hermitage should be located;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te'ṣṭau yojanamityāhuḥ / uktaṃ yojanasya pramāṇam / varṣasyedānīmucyate /
column2: and eight krośas make what is called one.
A hermitage, ṣraṇya, should be located one krośx from a village.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatkṣaṇaḥ kṣaṇānāṃ viṃśaṃ śatamekastatkṣaṇaḥ / te punaḥ ṣaṣṭirlavaḥ /
column2: One hundred and twenty kṣaṇar make one tatkṣaṇa;
sixteen tatkṣaṇas make one lava; we obtain a muhrta or hour, an ahorāa or one day and night, and a wmāsa or month, by multiplying the preceeding termby thirty;
a sarvatsara or yeat, is of twelve months by adding the narātras.
One muhūrta equals thirty Javas.
Thirty muh/rias make oṉe day and night;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kadācittu rātriradhikā bhavati kadācidūnā kadācitsamā / tridaśāhorātrā māsaḥ / dvādaśamāsakaḥ / saṃvatsaraḥ sonarātraḥ
column2: a night is sometimes longer, sometimes shorter, and sometimes equal to a day.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catvāro māsā hemantānāṃ catvāro grīṣmāṇāṃ catvāro varṣāṇāmityete dvādaśa māsā saṃvatsaraḥ sārdhamūnarātraiḥ /
column2: There are four months of winter, of heat, and of rain; twelve months which, with the days called @narāras, make a year.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃvatsareṇa hi ṣaḍūnarātrā nipātyante / kathaṃ kṛtvā / “hemantagrīṣmavarṣāṇāmadhyardhe māsi nirgate / śeṣe'rdhamāse vidvadbhirūnarātro nipātyate //“
column2: The ānarātras are the six days which, in the course of the year, one should.
We have explained the year;
we must explain the kalpa or cosmic period.
There are different types of kalpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: antarakalpo saṃvarttakalpo vivartakalpo mahākalpaśceti / tatra tāvat
column2: There is a distinction between a small kalpa, a kalpa of disappearance, a kalpa of creation, and a great kalpa.
A kalpa of disappearance lasts from the non-production of the damned to destruction of the receptacle world.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: narakeṣu hi sattvāsaṃbhavāt prabhṛti yāvat bhājanasaṃkṣayaḥ /
column2: The period that extends from the moment when beings cease being reborn in hell until the moment when the world is destroyed is called a samvartakalpa, a kalpa of destruction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dve hi saṃvarttanyau / gatisaṃvartanī dhātusaṃvartanī ca / punardve saṃvartanyau /
column2: Destruction is of two types: destruction of the realms of rebirth, and destruction of the Dhātu.
It is again of two types: destruction of living beings, and destruction of the physical world.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavati sa kālo yannarakeṣu sattvāścyavante nopapadyante / sa ārambhaḥ saṃvartakalpasya / yadayaṃ loko viṃśatyantarakalpān vivṛtto'sthāt tanniryātaṃ vaktavyam / yadviṃśatimantarakalpān saṃvartiṣyate tat pratipannaṃ vaktavyam /
column2: When no being is reborn in hell—even though beings in hell continue to die—the period of twenty small kalpas during which the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā narakeṣvekasattvo nāvaśiṣṭo bhavati iyatā 'yaṃ lokaḥ saṃvṛtto bhavati / yaduta narakasaṃvarttanyā yasya tadānīṃ niyataṃ narakavedanīyaṃ karma ghriyate sa lokadhātvantaranarakeṣu kṣipyate /
column2: When not a single being remains in the hells, the destruction of beings in hell is achieved, and the world has been destroyed to that extent: if a being of this universe has committed any actions which should be retributed in hell, the force of these actions causes him to be reborn in the hell of another universe not in the process of destruction.
o too is the destruction of animals and Pretas.
The animals that reside in the greatocean disappear first;
those that live with humans will disappear at the same time as do humans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa kālo yanmanuṣyeṣvanyatamaḥ sattvaḥ svayamanācāryakaṃ dharmatāprātilambhikaṃ prathamaṃ
column2: Among humans of Jambudvīpa, a person enters by himself, without a teacher, by reason of dharmatā, into the First Dhyānṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānaṃ samāpadyate sa tasmāt vyutthāya vācaṃ bhāṣate sukhaṃ vata vivekajaṃ prītisukhaṃ
column2: Coming out of this Dhyāna, he exclaims, “Happy is the pleasure and the joy that arise from detachment!
Calm is the pleasure and joy that arise from detachment!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taṃ ca śabdaṃ śrutvā anye'pi sattvāḥ samāpadyante / kālaṃ kṛtvā brahmaloka upapadyante /
column2: ” Understanding these words, other persons also enter into absorption and, after their death, pass into the world of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā jambūdvīpa ekasattvo'pi nāvaśiṣṭo bhavati iyatā'yaṃ lokaḥ saṃvṛtto bhavati yaduta jambūdvīpasaṃvartanyā /
column2: When, by this continual process, there does not remain a single person in Jambudvīpa, the destruction of the persons of Jambudvīpa is finished.

The same for the inhabitants of Pūrvavideha and Avaragodānīya. The inhabitants of Uttarakuru are incapable of detaching themselves from Kāmadhātu and, as a consequence, of enteting into dhyāna: they are also reborn, not in the world of Brahmā, but among the gods of Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā manuṣyeṣvekasattvo'pi nāvaśiṣṭo bhavati iyatā'yaṃ lokaḥ saṃvṛtto bhavati yaduta manuṣyagatisaṃvarttanyā /
column2: When a single human being no longer remains, the destruction of humans is finished, and the world has been destroyed to this extent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: auttarakauravāstu kālaṃ kṛtvā kāmāvacareṣu deveṣūpapadyante / tatra vairāgyābhāvāt / evaṃ cāturmahārājakāyikeṣvapi deveṣu prathamaṃ dhyānaṃ samāpadya brahmaloka upapadyante / yadā tatraikasattvo'pi nāvaśiṣṭo bhavati iyatā'yaṃ lokaḥ saṃvṛtto bhavati yaduta cāturmahārājakāyikasaṃvartanyā / evaṃ yāvat paranirmitavaśavartisaṃvarttnyo vaktavyāḥ /
column2: The same then holds for the gods of Kāmadhātu, from the Cāturmahārājakāyikas to the Paranirmitavaśavartins, who enter into dhyāna and are reborn in the world of Brahmā, and who successively disappear.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadaikasattvo'pi kāmāvacareṣu deveṣu nāvaśiṣṭo bhavati iyatā'yaṃ lokaḥ saṃvṛtto bhavati yaduta kāmadhātusaṃvartanyā /
column2: When a single god no longer remnains in Kāmadhātu, the destuction of Kāmadhātu is finished.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: brahmaloke'pyanyatamaḥ sattvo dharmatāprātilambhikaṃ dvitīyaṃ dhyānaṃ samāpadyotthāya vācaṃ bhāṣate sukhaṃ vata samādhijaṃ prītisukhaṃ śāntaṃ vata samādhijaṃ prītisukhamiti /
column2: It then happens,by reason of dharmatā, that a god of the world of Brahmā enters into the Second Dhyāna. Coming out of this Dhyāna, he excaims, “Happy is the pleasure and joy that arise from absorption! Calm is the pleasure and joy that arise from absorption!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taṃ śabdaṃ śrutvā'nye'pi sattvāḥ samāpadyante kālaṃ ca kṛtvā ābhāsvareṣu deveṣūpapadyante /
column2: Understanding these words, other gods of the world of Brahma enter into the Second Dhyana and after their death, are reborn in the heaven of the Abhasvaras.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā brahmaloka ekasattvo'pi nāvaśiṣṭo bhavati iyatā'yaṃ lokaḥ saṃvṛtto bhavati yaduta sattvasaṃvartanyā /
column2: When a single being no longer remains in the world of Brahma, the destruction of beings is finished and the world has been destroyed to that extent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ śūnye bhājane ita eva sāmantakāt sattvānāṃ tadākṣepake karmaṇi parikṣīṇe sapta sūryāḥ prādurbhūya krameṇa yāvat pṛthivīṃ sumeruṃ ca niḥśeṣaṃ dahanti /
column2: Then, by reason of the exhaustion of the collective action which has created the physical world, and by reason of the emptiness of the world, seven suns successively appear, and the world is entirely consumed from this sphere with its continents to Meru.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādevaṃ prajvalitādarcirvāyunā kṣiptaṃ śūnyaṃ brāhmaṃ vimānaṃ nirdahat paraiti / tacca tadbhūmikamevārcirveditavyam / nahi visabhāgā apakṣālāḥ kramante / tatsaṃbaddhasaṃbhūtatvāttasmāttadityuktam /
column2: From this world thus inflamed, the flame, conducted by the wind, burns the houses of the world of Brahma.

Even though it is well understood that the flame that burns these houses is a flame of Rupadhatu, the destruction of Kamadhatu has not yet taken hold of Rupadhatu. But it is said that the flame goes from this world and burns the world of Brahma, because a new flame arises in relation to the first one.
So too, mutatis mutandis, is the destruction through water and through wind, which are similar to destruction through fire but which extend higher.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: narakeṣu sattvānāṃ cyutyanutpādāt prabhṛti yāvat bhājanānāṃ saṃkṣaya eṣa kālaḥ /
column2: The period that extends from the moment when beings cease to be born in the hells until the moment when the physical world has been destroyed is what is called a saṃvartakalpa, a kalpa of disappearance.
The kalpa of creation lasts from the primordial wind until the production of hellish beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: thamādvāyoḥ prabhṛti yāvannarakeṣu sattvasambhavaḥ eṣa kālo vivartakalpa ityucyate /
column2: From the primordial wind until the moment when beings arise in hells. The world, which has been destroyed as we have seen, stays destroyed for a long time—during twenty small kapas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā saṃvṛte hi loka ākāśamātrāvaśeṣaścira kālaṃ tiṣṭhati yāvat punarapi sattvānāṃ karmādhipatyena bhājanānāṃ pūrvanimittabhūtā ākāśe mandamandā vāyavaḥ syandante /
column2: There is only space where the world once was. When, by reason of the collective action of beings, there appears the first signs of a future physical world; when some very light winds arise in space, then this period of twenty small kapas during which the world remained destroyed is finished;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadā yadayaṃ loko viṃśatimantarakalpān saṃvṛtto'sthāttanniryātaṃ vaktavyam / yadviṃśatimantarakalpān vivarttiṣyate tadupayātaṃ vaktavyam /
column2: and the period, also of twenty small kalpas, during which the world is created, begins.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataste vāyavo vardhamānā yathoktaṃ vāyumaṇḍalaṃ jāyate /
column2: The winds come gradually and, finally, constitute a circle of wind;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ śanairyathoktakramavidhānaṃ sarvaṃ jāyate apmaṇḍalaṃ kāñcanamayī mahāpṛthivī dvīpāḥ sumervādayaśca / prathamaṃ tu brāhma vimānamutpadyate /
column2: then there arises all of the receptacles as we have just described: a circle of water, a sphere of gold, Meru, etc. The mansion of Brahmā appears firstand then allthe mansions until those of the Yamas.
But this is only after the circle of wind arises.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: iyatā'yaṃ loko vivṛtto bhavati yaduta bhājanavivartanyā /
column2: The physical world is thus created, and the world is now created to this extent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athānyataraḥ sattva ābhāsvarebhyaścyutvā śūnye brāhme vimāna utpadyate /
column2: Then a being, dying in Ābhāsvara, is born in the mansion of Brahmā which is empty;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye'pi sattvāstataścyutvā brahmapurohiteṣūpapadyante / tato brahmakāyikeṣu paranirmitavaśavartiṣu /
column2: other beings, dying one after the other in Ābhāsvara, are born in the heaven of the Brahmapurohitas, the Brahmakāyikas, the Paranirmitavaśavartins and the other gods of Kāmadhātu;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: krameṇa yāvaduttarakurau godānīye pūrvavidehe jambūdvīpe preteṣu tiryakṣu narakeṣūpapadyante /
column2: inUttarakuru, Godānīya, Videha, andJambudvīpa; among the Pretas and animals; and in the hells.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dharmatā hyeṣā yat paścāt saṃvartate tat pūrvaṃ vivarttate /
column2: The rule is that the beings who disappear last reappear first.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā narakeṣvekaḥ sattvo'pi prādurbhūto bhavati tadā yadayaṃ loko viṃśatimantarakalpān vivartate tanniryātaṃ bhavati / yadviṃśatimantaralpān vivarttaḥ sthāsyati tadupayātaṃ bhavati /
column2: When a being is born in the hells, the period of creation, of twenty small kalpas, is finished, and the period of duration begins. During the nineteen small apas that complete this period, until the appearance of the beings in hell, the lifespan of humans is infinite in length.
A small kapa, in the course of which a lifespan, from infinite, becomes a lifespan ten years in length.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vivartamāne loke ekānna viṃśatirantarakalpā aparimitāyuṣāṃ manuṣyāṇāmatikrāmanti /
column2: Humans, at the end of the period of creation, have an infinitely long lifespan;
their lifespan diminishes when creation is achieved, until it is not more than ten years in length.
The period in which this diminution takes place constitutes the first small apa of the period of destruction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: utkarṣā apakarṣāśca kalpā aṣṭādaśāpare // tasmādapare'ṣṭādaśotkarṣā apakarṣāścāṣṭādaśāntarakalpā bhavanti / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: The eighteen eapas which are of augmentation and of diminution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tebhyo hi daśavarṣāyuṣkebhya utkarṣaṃ gacchantaḥ krameṇāśītivarṣasahasrāyuṣo bhavanti /
column2: A lifespan, which is now ten years in length, increases until it is eighty thousand years in length;
then it decreases and is reduced to a length of ten years.
The period in the course of which this increase and this decrease takes place is the second small kapa.
This eapa is followed by seventeen similar ones.
One, of augmentation.
The twentieth small &a/pa is only of increase, not of decrease.
The lifespan of humans increases from ten years to eighty thousand years in length.
How high, by increase, do these increases go?
They go to a lifespan of eighty thousand. But not beyond.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nātaḥ pareṇa vardhante yāvāneva cānyeṣāmantarakalpānāmutkarṣāpakarṣakālastāvāneva prathamasyāpakarṣakālaḥ paścimasya cotkarṣakāla iti samānakālāḥ sarve bhavanti /
column2: The time required for the increase and the decrease of the eighteen kalpas is equal to the time that the decrease of the first kalpa and the increase of the last take.
In this way then the world stays created for twenty kalpar.
The world remains created fox twenty small kalpas thus calculated.
As long as this period of duration lasts,
During the same length of time, the world is in the process of creation, in the process of disappearance, and in a state of disappearance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: viṃśatimevāntarakalpān vivartate viṃśatiṃ saṃvartate viṃśatiṃ saṃvṛtta āste /
column2: The creation, the disappearance, and the period when the world disappears lasts a total of twenty small ka/pas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyapi tadānīmutkarṣā apakarṣāśca na pravartante kālastu samānaḥ parisaṃkhyāyate /
column2: There are not, during these three periods, any phases of increase and decrease of lifespan, but these periods are equal in length to the period during which the world. The physical world is created in one small éalpa; it is filled during. nineteen; it is emptied during nineteen;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatraikenāntara kalpena bhājanānyabhinivartante ekānnaviṃśatyā 'ntarakalpairāvāsyante ekenāntarakalpena bhājanāni vidhvasyante ekānnaviṃśatyā śūnyī bhavanti /
column2: and it perishes in one small kalpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tā etā antarakalpānāṃ catasro viṃśatyo'śītirbhavanti / te hyaśītirmahākalpaḥ
column2: Four times twenty small ka/pas make eighty: These eighty make a great kalpa.
This is the extent of a great kalpa.
Of what does a kalpa consist?
The kalpa is by nature the five séandhas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaducyate tribhirasaṃkhyeyaiḥ kalpānāṃ budhatvaṃ prāpyata” iti /
column2: It is said that the quality of Buddhahood is acquired through cultivation that last three asaṁkhyeya kalpas.
To which among the four types of kalpas does this refer? The quality of Buddhahood results from three of these.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya eva mahākalpo nirdiṣṭaḥ / tadasaṃkhyatrayodbhavam // buddhatvam saṃkhyeyānāṃ kalpānāṃ trayeṇa /
column2: Of these great kalpas that we have just defined.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamasaṃkhyeyasyāsati saṃkhyeyāvasāne punastritvamucyate / naiadevaṃ veditavyaṃ / kiṃ tarhi / “ṣaṣṭiḥ sthānāntarāṇyasaṃkhyeyami“ti muktakasūtraṃ paṭhyate /
column2: But the wordasaṁkhya signifies “incalculable; ” how can one speak of three “incalculables?” One should not understand it in this manner, for, in an isolated Sūtra, it is said that numeration is to the sīxteenth place.
What are these sixteen places?
One, not two, is the first place;
ten times one is the second place;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśa daśakāni śataṃ tṛtīyam / daśa śatāni sahasram / daśa sahasrāṇi prabhedaḥ / daśa prabhedā lakṣam / daśa lakṣā atilakṣaḥ / daśātilakṣāḥ kauṭiḥ / daśa kauṭyo madhyaḥ/
column2: ten times ten is the third;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśa madhyā ayutam / śāyutā mahāyutam / daśa mahāyutā niyutam / daśa niyutā mahāniyutam / daśa mahāniyutāḥ prayutam / daśa prayutā mahāprayutaḥ / daśa mahāprayutāḥ kaṅkaraḥ / daśa kaṅkarā mahākaṅkaraḥ / daśa mahākaṅkarā visvaraḥ / daśa visvarā mahāvisvaraḥ / daśa mahāvisvarā akṣobhyaḥ / daśākṣobhyā mahākṣobhyaḥ / daśa mahākṣobhyā vivāhaḥ / daśa vivāhā mahāvivāhaḥ / daśa mahāvivāhā utsaṅgaḥ / daśotsaṅgā mahotsaṅgaḥ / daśa mahotsaṅgā vāhanaḥ / daśa vāhanāni mahāvāhanam / daśa mahāvāhanāni taṭibhaḥ / daśa tiṭibhā mahātiṭibhaḥ / daśa mahātiṭibhā hetuḥ / daśa hetavo mahāhetuḥ / daśa mahāhetavaḥ karabhaḥ / daśa karabhā mahākarabhaḥ / daśa mahākarabhā indraḥ / daśendrā mahendraḥ / daśa mahendrāḥ samāptam / daśa samāptāni mahāsamāptam / daśa mahāsamāptāni gatiḥ / daśa gatayo mahāgatiḥ / daśa mahāgatayo nimbarajaḥ / daśa nimbarajāṃsi mahānimbarajaḥ / daśa mahānimbarajāṃsi mudrā / daśa mudrā mahāmudrā / daśa mahāmudrāḥ balam / daśa balāni mahābalam / daśa mahābalāni sajñā / daśa saṃjñā mahāsaṃjñā / daśa mahāsaṃjñā vibhūtaḥ / daśa vibhūtā mahāvibhūtaḥ / daśa mahāvibhūtā balākṣam / daśa balākṣā mahābalākṣam /
column2: ten times one hundred or one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśa mahābalākṣāṇyasamkhyam / aṣṭakaṃ madhyādvistṛtam / ityeteṣāṃ ṣaṣṭisthānāntaragatāṃ saṃkhyāmanuprāptāḥ kalpā asaṃkhyeyānityucyante /
column2: A great kalpa successively numbered to the sixteenth place is called an asanúéhyeya;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato vyāvṛtya punargaṇyante / evaṃ trīṇi asaṃkhyeyānītyucyante /
column2: if one begins again, one has a second, and a third asanvkhyeya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tu naiva parisaṃkhyātuṃ śakyanta iti /
column2: An asaṁkhyeya does ṉot receive its name from the fact that it is incalculable.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kintu khalu kālaprakarṣeṇaiva kṛtapraṇidhānā bodhisattvā bodhimabhisaṃbudhyante / kimetadeva bhaviṣyati /
column2: But why do the Bodhisattvas, once they have undertaken the resolution to obtain supreme Bodhi, take such a long time to obtain it?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mahatāṃ hi puṇyajñānasaṃbhāreṇa ṣaḍbhiḥ pāramitābhiḥ bahubhirduṣkaraśatasahasraistribhiḥ kalpāsaṃkhyeyairanuttarāṃ samyaksaṃbodhimabhisaṃbudhyante bodhisattvāḥ /
column2: Because supreme Bodhi is very difficult to obtain: one needs a great.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyapyanyathā'pyasti mokṣāvakāśaḥ kimarthaṃ ta iyantaṃ yatnamārabhante /
column2: One would understand that the Bodhisattva searches out this Bodhi so difficult to obtain, if this Bodhi were the sole means of arriving at deliverance;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: parārthaṃ ta iyantaṃ yatnamārabhante kathaṃ parānapi mahato duḥkhaughāt paritrātuṃ śaknuyāmiti /
column2: but such is not the case. Why then do they undertake this infinite labor? For the good of others, because they want to become capable of pulling others out of the great flood of suffering.
But what personal good do they find in the good of others?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa eva teṣāṃ svārtho yaḥ parārthastasyābhimatatvāt /
column2: The good of others is their own good, because they desire it.
Who believes this?
In truth, persons devoid of pity and who think only of themselves believe with difficuly in the altrnism of the Bodhisattvas; but compassionate persons believe in it easily.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāruṇikaistu śraddhitamevaitat yathā ceha kecidabhyastanairdhṛṇyā asatyapi svārthe paravyasanābhiratā upalabhyante /
column2: Don't we see that ceṛtain petsons, confirmed in the absence of pity, find pleasure in the suffering of others even when it is not to their benefit? In the same way one must admit that the Bodhisattvas, confirmed in pity, find pleasure in doing. Good to others without any egoistic concerns.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā punarabhyastakāruṇyā asatyapi svārthe parahitakriyābhirāmāḥ santīti saṃbhāvyam /
column2: Don't we see that certain persons, ignorant of the true nature of the conditioned dharmas (ie. , the saṁskāras) that constitute their pretended “self,” are attached to these dharmas through the force of habit, as completely devoid of personality as these dharmas are, and suffer a thousand pains by reason of this attachment?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathaiva cābhyāsavaśādanātmabhūteṣu saṃskāreṣu saṃskṛtalakṣaṇānabhijñā ātmasnehaṃ niveśya taddhetorduḥkhānyudvahanti evaṃ punarabhyāsavaśādātmasnehaṃ tebhyo nirvartya pareṣvapekṣāṃ vardhayitvā taddhetorduḥkhānyudvahantīti saṃbhāvyam /
column2: In the same way one must admit that the Bodhisattvas, through the force of habit, detach themselves from the dharmas that constitute the pretended “self, no longer consider these dharmas as “ṛṇe” and “mine,” increase compassionate solicitude for others, and are ready to suffer a thousand pains because of this solicitude.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gotrāntarameva hi tattathājātīyaṃ nirvartate yat pareṣāṃ duḥkhena duḥkhāyate sukhena sukhāyate nātmana iti /
column2: In a few words, there is a certain category of persons, who, indifferent to what concerns them personally, are happy through the well-being of others, and are unhappy through the suffering of others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na te punaḥ svārthamanyaṃ paśyanti / āha cātra
column2: For them, to be useful to others is to be useful to themselves.
A stanza says, “An inferior person searches out, by all means, his personal.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: madhyo duḥkhanivṛttimeva na sukhaṃ duḥkhāspadaṃ tadyataḥ /
column2: ”A mediocre person searches out the destruction of suffering, not well-being, because well-being is the cause of suffering;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śreṣṭhaḥ prārthayate svasaṃtatigatairduḥkhaiḥ pareṣāṃ sukhaṃ duḥkhātyantanivṛttimeva ca yatastadduḥkhaduḥkhyeva saḥ //“
column2: an excellent person, through his personal suffering, searches out the well-being and the definitive destruction of the suffering of others, for he suffers from the suffering of others.
During what periods do the Buddhas appear, during a period of increase or during a period of decrease?
They appear during the decrease to one hundred.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aśītivarṣaśatāyupi prajāyāmapakarṣe ārabdhe yāvadvarṣaśatāyuṣo manuṣyā bhavantyetasminnantare buddhā utpadyante / kasmānnotkarṣakāle / tadā hi duḥsamudvejāḥ sattvā bhavanti /
column2: The Buddhas appear during the period of the decrease of lifespan, when the length of life decreases from eighty thousand years to one hundred years in length.
Why do they not appear when life decreases from one hundred to ten years?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadā hi pañca kaṣāyā abhyutsadā bhavanti / tadyathā'yuṣkaṣāyaḥ kalpakaṣāyaḥ kleśakaṣāyaḥ dṛṣṭikaṣāyaḥ sattvakaṣāyaśca /
column2: Because the five corruptions then become very strong.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apakarṣasyādhastāt pratyavarā āyurādayaḥ kiṭabhūtatvāt kaṣāyā ucyante /
column2: In the final period of the decrease of lifespan, the length of life becomes bad, base; being corrupted, it is called a kasaya or “corruption; ” the same for the other corruptions.
The first two corruptions deteriorate the vitality and the means of subsistence.
The next two corruptions deteriorate the good; the corruption of defilements deteriorate beings through laxity; the corruption of views through the practice of painful asceticism;

or rather the corruption of defilement and the corruption of views deteriorate respectively the spiritual good of householders and of wanderers. The corruption of beings deteriorates beings from the physical and the mental point of view;
it deteriorates their height, beauty, health, force, intelligence, memory, energy, and firmness.
During what periods do the Pratyekabuddhas appear?
The Pratyekabuddhas appear in the course of two periods.
They appear during the period of increase and during the period of decrease of lifespan.
One distinguishes in fact two types of Pratyekabuddhas: those that live in a group, and who also appear during the period of increase, and those who live like a rhinoceros.
The first are the ancient Śrāvakas [who will obtain the first or.
Acrording to another opinion, there are also Pṛthagjanas who have realized, in the vehicle of the Śrāvakas, the nôrvedhabhāgīyas ;
in the course of a subsequent existence, by themselves, they will realize the Way.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathāhi pūrvayogaṃ paṭhanti “parvate kila pañcaśatāni tāpasānāṃ kaṣṭāni tapāṃsi tapyante
column2: The masters who follow this opinion find an argument in the Pārvakathā where they read, “Five hundred ascetics cultivated painful austerities on a mountain. A monkey who had lived in the company of Pratyekabuddhas imitated the attritudes of the Pratyekabuddhas in front of them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sma yāvat pratyekabuddhasahoṣitena markaṭenāgamya tadīryāpathasaṃdarśanāt pratyekabodhimabhisaṃbanddhā” iti / nacāryāḥ santaḥ kaṣṭāni tapāṃsi tapyeran / khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpāḥ punarekavihāriṇaḥ /
column2: These ascetics then imitated the monkey and, they say, obtained the Bodhi of the Pratyekabuddhas.” It is clear, say these masters, that these ascetics were not Āryans, Śrāvakas; for, if they bad previously obtained the result of the Śrāvakas, namely liberation from rules and rituals , they would not have given themselves up later to painful austerities.
The Pratyekabuddhas who are “like a rhinoceros” live alone.
The Ṛhinoceros by reason of one hundred éa/pas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mahākalpānāṃ śataṃ bodhisaṃbhāreṣu caritaḥ khaḍgaṃ viṣāṇakalpo bhavati /
column2: The Rhinoceros has cultivated for one hundred great kapas in his preparation for Bodhi. He obtains Bodhi without the help of the teaching or āgama, but alone.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vinopadeśenātmānamekaṃ pratibudhā iti pratyekabuddhāḥ / te hyekamātmānaṃ damayanti nānyān /
column2: He is a Pratyekabuddha because he himself brings about his salvation without converting others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaratra kāraṇam / nahi tāvadaśaktā dharmaṃ deśayituṃ pratisaṃvitprāptatvāt /
column2: Why does he not apply himself to the conversion of others?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śakyaṃ ca taiḥ pūrvabuddhānāṃ śāsanamanusmṛtyāpi dharmaṃ deśayitum / nāpi niṣkaruṇāḥ /
column2: He is certainly capable of teaching the Law: he possesses the comprehensions, he can remember the teachings of the ancient Buddhas.
He is no longer deprived of pity, for he manifests his supernormal power with a view to being of service to beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāpi sattvānāmabhavyatvāt / tathā hi laukikamārga vītarāgāḥ saṃvidyante /
column2: He can no longer say that beings are “unconvertible” in the period in which he lives, for, in this period—the period of decrease of life—beings can detach themselves from Kāmadhātu by the worldly path.
Why then does he not teach the Law?

By reason of his previous habit, he finds pleasure in, and aspires to absence of turmoil; he does not have the courage to apply. He himself is concerned with making others understand the profound Dharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anusroto gāminīnāṃ hi prajānāṃ duṣkaraṃ pratisroto nayanam /
column2: He knows that in order to do so, he would have to make disciples and conduct the multitude who follow the current against the current, which is a difficult thing.
However, he fears being distracted from his absorption and entering into contact with humans.
The Cakravartin Kings do not appear when lifespan is under eighty thousand years in length.

They have a wheel of gold, a wheel of silver, a wheel of copper, and a wheel of iron. In inverse order, he reigns over one, two, three, or four continents, but never two at once like the Buddhas. They triumph through spontaneous default, personal influence, fighting, or the sword, but always without doing evil.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: amite cāyuṣi manuṣyāṇāṃ yāvadaśītisahasrake cotpattiścakravarttināṃ nādhaḥ / tasyāḥ sasyasaṃpadastadūnāyuṣāmabhājanatvāt /
column2: The Cakravartin Kings appear from the period when the lifespan of humans is infinite to the period when their lifespan is eighty thousand years in length.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rājyaṃ cakreṇa vartayituṃ śīlameṣāmiti cakravarttinaḥ / te punaścaturvidhāḥ /
column2: They are called Cakravartins because their nature is to reign (rāġyaṁ).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: suvarṇarūpyatāmrāyaścakriṇaḥ suvarṇarūpyatāmrāyaścakrkāṇi yeṣāṃ santi / prathama eṣāmuttamo dvitīya upottamaḥ tṛtīyo madhyamaścaturtho 'dhamaḥ / te 'dharakramāt //
column2: There are four types of Cakravartin Kings, Suvarṇcakravartin, Rūpyacakravartin, Tāmracakravartin, and Ayaścakravartin, accordingly as their wheel is of gold, silver, copper, or iron: the first is the best, the second is almost best, the third is mediocre, and the fourth is inferior.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekadvitricaturdvīpāḥ yasyāyasaṃ cakraṃ sa ekadvīpādhipatiḥ / yasya tāmramayaṃ sa dvayoḥ / yasya rūpyamayaṃ sa trayāṇām / yasya suvarṇmayaṃ sa caturdvīpādhipatiḥ /
column2: The Cakravartin whose wheel is iron reigns over one continent, the Cakravartin whose wheel is copper reigns over two continents, and so on.
This is the doctrine of the Prajñāpti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtre tu pradhānagrahaṇādekameva sauvarṇaṃ cakram / “yasya rājñaḥ kṣatriyasya mūrdhābhiṣiktasya tadaīva poṣadhe pañcadaśyāṃ śiraḥsnātasyopoṣadho poṣitasyopariprāsādatalagatasyāmātyagaṇaparivṛtasya pūrvasyāṃ diśi cakraratnaṃ prādurbhavati sahasrāraṃ sanābhikaṃ sanemikaṃ sarvākāraparipūrṇaṃ śubhakarmārakṛtaṃ divyaṃ sarvasauvarṇaṃ sa rājā bhavati cakravartī“ti /
column2: A Sūtra, in fact, speaks only of a Cakravartin King having a wheel of gold, by reason of his greater importance, “When, to a king of royal and consecrated race—who, even in the days of his youth, on the fifteenth day, having washed his head, having undertaken the obligations of youth, ascends accompanied by his ministers to the terrace of his palace—there appears in the east the jewel of a wheel having a thousand rays, a wheel having a rim, having a hub, complete in all ways, beautiful, not made by the hand of an artisan.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ caite cakravartina utpadyante / na ca dvau saha buddhavat /
column2: Two Cakravartins and two Buddhas cannot appear at the same time, according to the Sūtra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra ukta” masthānamanavakāśo yadapūrvācaramau dvau tathāgatāvarhantau samyaksaṃbuddhau loka utpadyeyātāṃ nedaṃ sthānaṃ vidyate sthānametadvidyate yadaikastathāgataḥ / yathā tathāgata evaṃ cakravarttināvi“ti / idamatra saṃpradhāryam /
column2: It is impossible for two Tathāgatas, Arhats, perfect Buddhas to appear in the world without one preceding and the other following. There is only one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kimatra trisāhasramahāsāhasro lokadhāturloka iṣṭa utāho sarvalokadhātava iti /
column2: What is the meaning of "in the world"? Does it mean "in a great Trisāhasra universe" or "in all the universes?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nānyatra buddhā utpadyante ityeke / kiṃ kāraṇam / mā bhūt bhagavataḥ śaktivyāghātaḥ iti /
column2:
According to one opinion, the coexistence of two Buddhas would create an obstacle to the power of the Blessed Ones.
eka eva hi bhagavān sarvatra śaktaḥ /	A single Blessed One applies himself wheresoever.
yatra buddha eko na śaktaḥ syād vineyān vinetuṃ tatrā'nyo'pi na śakta iti / uktaṃ ca sūtre “sa cettvāṃ śāriputra kaścidupasaṃkramyaivaṃ pṛcchet asti kaścidetarhi śramaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā samasamaḥ śramaṇena gotamena yadutābhisaṃbodhāya	Where a Blessed One does not apply himself to the converting of beings, other Blessed Ones do not apply themselves either.
evaṃ ca pṛṣṭaḥ kiṃ vyākuryāḥ /	If someone comes and asks you if there now exists someone.
sa cenmāṃ bhadanta kaścidupasaṃkramyevaṃ pṛcchettasyāhaṃ pṛṣṭa evaṃ vyākuryā nāsti kaścidetarhhi śṛamaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā samasamo bhagavatā yadutābhisaṃbodhāya	If someone were to interrogate me thus, Oh Venerable One, I would answer him that there does not exist now anyone, Bhikṣu or Brāhmin, who is the equal of the Blessed One.
tatkasya hetoḥ /	And why would I respond in this manner?
saṃmukhaṃ me bhagavato'ntikācchrutaṃ saṃmukhamudgṛhītaṃ asthānamanavakāso yadapūrvācaramau tathāgatau loka utpadyeyātāṃ nedaṃ sthānaṃ vidyata” iti /	Because I have heard and understood of the Blessed One, that it is impossible, both in the present and in the future, for two Blessed Ones, Arhats, perfect Buddhas to appear in the world without one preceding and the other following.
yattarhi bhagavatoktaṃ brahmasūtre “yāvattrisāhasramahāsāhasrako loko vaśe me'tra vartata” iti /	Objection: How then are we to understand what the Blessed One said in the Brahmasūra, `I exercise my power even over a great Trtisāhasra universe?”
ābhiprāyika eṣa nirdeśaḥ / ko'trābhiprāyaḥ tāvato'nabhisaṃskāreṇa vyavalokanāt /	‘This text should not be taken literally;
abhisaṃskārena tvananto buddhānāṃ cakṣurviṣayaḥ /	it means that without making an effort, the Buddha sees as far as this limit. When he desires it, his seeing goes wherever he wills it without limit.
santyevānyalokadhātuṣu buddhā iti nikāyāntarīyāḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam / bahavo hi samaṃ saṃbhāreṣu pravartamānā dṛśyante /	According to other schools, the Buddhas appear at the same time, but in many universes. Here are their arguments.
na caikatra bahūnāṃ buddhānāṃ yugapat yoga utpattuṃ na cāsti tadut pattau kakścit pratibandhaḥ iti niyataṃ lokadhātvantareṣūtpadyante /	One sees that manyPersons apply themselves at the same time to the preparations for Bodhi. Certainly, it is not proper that many Buddhas should appear at the same time in the same spot; but, on the other hand, nothing prevents many Buddhas from appearing at the same time: thus they appear indifferent universes.
