samānajātīyebhyaḥ eva hi dravyebhyaḥ samānajātīyānāṃ dṛṣṭa utpādastadyathā vīraṇebhyaḥ kaṭasya tantubhyaḥ paṭasyeti / idamayuktaṃ vartate / kimatrāyuktam yadasiddhaṃ sādhanāyodāhriyate / kimatrāsiddham /	You say that a thing arises from a similar thing, since a mat arises from vṝaṇa threads: but, a. mat is the vṝaṇa threads themselves disposed in a certain manner and which take the name of mat;
anyo vīraṇebhyaḥ kaṭo'nyaśca tantubhyaḥ paṭa iti / ta eva hi te yathāsaṃniviṣṭāstāṃ tāṃ saṃjñāṃ labhnte /	cloth is threads disposed in a certain manner.
pipīlikāpaṅktivat /	In the same way a row of ants is only ants.
kathaṃ gamyeta /	How do you prove that cloth is not a thing distinct?
ekatantusaṃyoge paṭasyānupalambhāt /	When an organ is in relation with a thread, the cloth is not perceived.
ko hi tadā sataḥ paṭasyopalabdhau pratibandhaḥ / akṛtsnavṛttau paṭabhāgo'tra syānna paṭaḥ / samūhamātraṃ ca paṭaḥ syāt /	Now, if the cloth exists why would it not be perceived?
kaśca tantubhyo'nyaḥ paṭabhāgaḥ /	You say that the cloth does not exist, integrally, in each thread: this is to acknowledge that the cloth is only the collection of its parts which are each constituted by a thread: for how would you prove that the parts of a cloth are a thing other than the threads?
anekā śrayasaṃyogāpekṣaṇe daśāmātrasaṃyoge paṭopalabdhiḥ syānna vā kadācit /	You say that the cloth exists integrally in each thread, but that one does not perceive it in each thread because the perception of the cloth supposes a union of the organ and the cloth in such a way that the numerous creative elements of the cloth are perceived: in this hypothesis, it would suffice to see the fringe in order to see the cloth.
madhyaparabhāgānāmindriyeṇāsaṃnikarṣāt / kramasaṃnikarṣe cāvayavānāṃ cakṣuḥsparśanābhyāmavayavavijñānaṃ na syāt /	You say that, if one does not see the cloth when one sees the fringe, it is because the central parts are not in relation with the organ: this is to admit then that one would never see the cloth, for the central parts and the extremes which are supposed to create the cloth. You say that they are perceived successively: this is to acknowledge that the whole is not perceived; and this is to acknowledge too that the idea of cloth or of mat has for its sole object the parts of the cloth or the mat.
tasmātkrameṇa saṃnikarṣādavayavivyavasāyādavayaveṣveva tadbuddhiralātacakravat /	How do we have, from all evidence, the idea of a circle from the circle formed from the circular trajectory of a brand?
bhinnarūpajātikriyeṣu tantuṣu paṭasya rūpādyasaṃbhavāt /	Further, cloth cannot be a thing other than thread, for, in the hypothesis where it would be otherwise, when the threads are different in color, different in nature, and different in disposition, one could not attribute either color, or nature, or disposition to the cloth. You say that the cloth is different in color: this is to acknowledge that different creates different;
citrarūpāditve vijātīyārambho'pi syāt acitre ca pārśvāntare paṭasyādarśanaṃ citradarśanaṃ vā /	further, to suppose that one of the sides is not variegated, in looking at it one would not see the cloth, but rather would see it variegated. But do you dare say that the cloth, made of threads of different dispositions, is of different dispositions?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kriyā'pi citretyaticitram / tāpaprakāśabhede vā'gniprabhāyā ādimadhyānte tadrūpasparśayoranupapattiḥ /
column2: It would be truly too diverse to be an entity!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paramāṇvatīndriyatve'pi samastānāṃ pratyakṣatvaṃ yathā teṣāṃ kāryārambhakatvaṃ cakṣurādīnāṃ ca taimirikāṇāṃ ca vikīrṇakeśopalabdhiḥ /
column2: Consider again. For us, the atoms, although suprasensible, become sensible when they come together: the Vaiśeṣikas also attribute the power to create coarse bodies to the united atoms; the factors of visual consciousness should be united in order to produce a consciousness;
and persons who suffer from ophthalmia see masses of hair, not hairs one by one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpādiṣveva ca paramāṇusaṃjñāniveśā ttadvināśe siddhaḥ paramāṇuvināśaḥ /
column2: What one understands by atom is physical matter, etc. , it is thus certain that atoms perish at the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dravyaṃ hi paramāṇuranyacca rūpādibhyo dravyamiti na teṣaṃ vināśe tadvināśaḥ siddhyati / ayuktamasyānyatvaṃ yāvatā na nirdhāryate kenacit imāni pṛthivyaptejāṃsi ima eṣāṃ rūpādaya iti /
column2: An atom is a thing in and of itself; a thing in and of itself is distinct from physical matter, etc. and physical matter can perish without an atom perishing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣuḥsparśanagrāhyāṇi ca prajñāyante dagdheṣu corṇākarpāsakusumbhakuṅkumādiṣu tadbuddhyabhāvādrūpādibhedeṣveva tadbuddhiḥ /
column2: The distinction between a thing and its attributes is inadmissible: for no one distinguishes, "This is earth, water, fire: these are the attributes of earth, namely, its color, its taste, etc. " And yet you affirm that a thing, earth, etc. , is perceptible to the eye, etc. Further, when wool, cotton, opium juice, or incense is burned, one no longer has the idea of wool, cotton, etc. , with regard to its ashes: thus the idea has for its object, not a thing in and of itself whose color would be an attribute, but its color, its taste, etc. You say that when an unfired clay jug has been submitted to the action of fire, we say that it has always been the same jug; and that, as a consequence, the jug is a thing other than its color, that it stays the same even though its color changes.
But, inif we were to recognize the unfired jug in the fired jug, it is because its figure remains similar: as one recognizes a row of ants.
In fact, who would recognize the jug if one does not see in it certain characteristics observed initially?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ko vā bālapralāpeṣvādaraḥ iti tiṣṭhatu tāvadevāpratiṣedhaḥ /
column2: Let us here stop this discussion of these infantile theories.
What is the upper limit of the destructions?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānatrayaṃ dvitīyādi śīrṣa tāsām yathākramam // trīṇi saṃvartanīśīrṣāṇi /
column2: Three Dhyāṇnas, beginning with the second, are, in order, the top of the destructions; by reason of the community of the nature of destructions and the vices of the first three Dhyānas. As for the Fourth Dhyāṇa, no destruction, by reason of its non-agitation: this is not that it is eternal, for its mansions are produced and perish along with the beings who live therein.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tejaḥsaṃvartanyā dvitīyaṃ dhyānaṃ śīrṣaṃ bhavatyadho dahyate /
column2: The Second Dhyāna is the limit of the destruction by fire: everything below it is burned;
the Third Dhyāna is the limit of the destruction by water: everything below it is dissolved;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vāyusaṃvarttanyāścaturthaṃ dhyānaṃ śīrṣaṃ bhavatyadho vikīryate / yaddhi saṃvartanyā upariṣṭāttacchīrṣamityucyate /
column2: the Fourth Dhyāṇna is the limit of the destruction by wind: everything below it is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ prathamadvitīyatṛtīyadhyānāni tejojalavāyubhirdhvasyante / tadapakṣālasādhamryāt
column2: The heaven of the First Dhyāna then perishes by fire;
in fact, the vice or imperfection of the First Dhyāna is vitarka-vicāra;
these burn the mind and are thus similar to fire.
The Second Dhyāṇna perishes by water: in fact, it has joy for its vice. This, being associated with physical well-being, rends the body soft and flabby: it is similar to water.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evatasmin kṛtsnakāyakrauryāpagamāt duḥkhendriyasya nirodha uktaḥ sūtre /
column2: This is why the Sūtra teaches that the sensation of suffering is destroyed by the suppression of all solidity of the body.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tṛtīye dhyāne āśvāsapraśvāsāḥ / te ca vāyava eva /
column2: The ThirdDhyāna perishes by wind: in fact, it has inbreathing and outbreathing, which are wind,for its vice.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: iti yasyāṃ dhyānasamāpattau yathābhuta ādhyātmiko'pakṣālastasyām dhyānopapattau tathābhūto bāhya iti / kasmāt pṛthivīsaṃvartanī na bhavati /
column2: The external vices of a Dhyāna are of the same order as the internal vices which affect the person who has entered into this Dhyāna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pṛthivyeva hi bhājanākhyā tasyāṃ tejojalavāyubhirvirodho na pṛthhivyeti / atha caturthadhyāne kathaṃ na saṃvartanī /
column2: What one calls the physical world is earth, and as a consequence can be opposed by fire, water, and wind, but not by earth itself.
The Fourth Dhyāna is not subject to destruction, because it is free from agitation.
The Buddha said in fact that this Dhyāna, being free from internal vices, is non-movable.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato'tra bāhyo'pakṣālo na pravartata iti nāstyatra saṃvartanī /
column2: The external vices have thus no hold on it and, as a consequence, it is not subject to destruction.
According to another opinion, the non-destruction of the Fourth Dhyāna is explained by the force of the Śuddhāvāsakāyika gods whose abode it is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi taiḥ śakyamārupyān praveṣṭuṃ nāpyanyatra gantumiti / nityaṃ tarhi caturthadhyānabhājanaṃ prāpnnoti /
column2: These gods are incapable of entering into Ārūpyadhātu, and are also incapable of going elsewhere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na nityaṃ saha sattvena tadvimānodayavyayāt // nahi caturthaṃ dhyānamekabhūmisaṃbaddham / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: The receptacle world of the Fourth Dhyāṇa is not eternal, but by this fact, it does not constitute a “sphere;
” like the stars, it is divided into diverse residences;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāpyayaṃ sattva upapadyeta cyaveta vā / sa sārdhaṃ vimāneneti nāstyasya nityatvam /
column2: these different mansions, the abodes of beings, arise and perish with these beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kena punaḥ krameṇaitāḥ saṃvartanyo bhavanti / nirantaraṃ tāvat
column2: What is the order of succession of these three destructions?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saptāgninā sapta saṃvartanyastejasā bhavanti / tataḥ / adbhirekā saptānāṃ tejaḥsaṃvartanīnāmanantaramadbhiḥ saṃvartanī bhavati /
column2: Seven by fire, one by water;
and when seven destructions byWater have thus taken place, followed by the destruction by wind.
After seven series of seven successive destructions by fire, destruction is then done seven times by water;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etena krameṇāpsaṃvartanīnāṃ gate saptake punaḥ tejaḥsaṃvartanīnāṃ saptako bhavati / paścādvāyusaṃvartanī tataḥ //
column2: the eighth series of seven destructions by fire is followed by one destruction by wind.
The physical worlds, in fact, last by reason of the duration of the gods who are reborn therein by the force of their absorptions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathiva hi teṣāṃ sattvānāṃ samāpattiviśeṣādātmabhāvānāṃ sthitiviśeṣastathā bhājanānāmapāmiti tā etā bhavanti ṣaṭpañcāśattejaḥ saṃvartanyaḥ saptāpsaṃvarttanyaḥ ekā vāyusaṃvarttanī / evaṃ ca prajñaptibhāṣyaṃ sunītaṃ bhavati “catuḥṣaṣṭi kalpāḥ śubhakṛtsnānāṃ devānāmāyuḥpramāṇami“ti / “ye dharmā hetuprabhavā hetum teṣāṃ tathāgatohyavadat / teṣāṃ ca yo nirodha evaṃvādī mahāśramaṇa” // iti / abhidharmakośabhāṣye lokanirdeśo nāma tṛtīyaṃ kośasthānam samāptamiti / caturthaṃ kośasthānam
column2: There are fifty-six destructions by fire, seven by water, and one by wind: this is what justifies the declaration of the Prajñāpti that the Śubhakrtsṇa gods live sixty-four kalpas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: oṃ namo buddhāya / atha yadetatsattvabhājanalokasya bahudhā vaicitryamukta tat kena kṛtam /
column2: Karma OR Homage to the Buddha Who created the variety of the world of living beings and the receptacle-world which we have described in the preceding chapter?
It was not a god who intelligently created it. The variety of the world arises from action.
The variety of the world arises from the actions of living beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi karmajaṃ kasmātsattvānāṃ karmabhiḥ kuṅkumacandanādayo ramyatarā jāyante na teṣāṃ śarīrāṇi /
column2: But, in this hypothesis, how does it happen that actions produce at one and the same time, pleasing things, saffron, sandalwood, etc, on.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: karmāṇyeva tānyevañjātīyāti vyābhiśrakāriṇāṃ sattvānāṃ yadāśrayāśca vraṇabhūtā jāyante bhogāśca ramyāstatpratīkārabhūtāḥ /
column2: The actions of beings whose conduct is a mixture of good and bad actions produce bodies resembling abscesses whose impurities flow out through the nine gates, and, in order to serve as a remedy to these bodies, they also produce objects of pleasing enjoyment, colors and shapes, odors, tastes and tangibles.
But the gods have accomplished only good actions: their bodies and their objects of enjoyment are equally pleasing.
What is action?
It is volition and that which is produced through volition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra uktaṃ “dve karmaṇī cetanā karma cetayitvā ce“ti / yattaccetayitvā cetanākṛṭaṃ ca tat /
column2: The sutra says that there are two types of action, volition and the action after having been willed. Action after having been willed is what the karika designates by the words "that which is produced through volition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te ete dve karmaṇī trīṇi bhavanti / kāyavāṅmanaskarmāṇi /
column2: These two actions form three actions: bodily action, vocal action, and mental action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathameṣāṃ karmaṇāṃ vyavasthānam / kimāśrayataḥ āhosvit svabhāvataḥ samutthānato vā /
column2: How do you establish this division, according to the support of its action, according to its nature, or according to its original cause?
If one were to regard its support, there is nothing but an action, for all actions are supported on a physical support, a body.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarveṣāṃ kāyāśritatvāt svabhāvataścedvākkarmaikaṃ prāpnoti / vacasaḥ karmasvabhāvatvāt /
column2: If one were to regard its nature, there is only vocal action, for, of these three, body, speech and anas, only the voice is ultimately action by its nature.
If one were to regard its original cause, we have only mental action, for all actions have their origin in the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathākramaṃ tribhiḥ kāraṇaistrayāṇāmiti vaibhāṣikāḥ / tatra punaḥ
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas say that the three types of action are established by reason of all of these three causes, support, nature and original cause, in this order.
Volition is mental action: it gives rise to two actions, bodily and vocal action.
Volition is called mental action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tajjaṃ vākkāyakarmaṇī // yattaccetanājanitaṃ cetayitvā karmetyuktaṃ kāyavākkarmaṇī te veditavye /
column2: that which arises from volition, namely action which has been willed, is made up of the two other actions, bodily and vocal action.
These two actions are informative and non-informative.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te tu kāyavākkarmaṇī pratyekaṃ vijñaptyavijñaptisvabhāve veditavye /
column2: Bodily action and vocal action are informative and noninformative;
we then have bodily informative. What action is “bodily informative action?

” Bodily vrjñapti is shape. It is not movement because all conditioned things are momentary, since they perish: on the other hand, pothing does not perish without a cause and the creative cause would be at the same time destructive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cittavaśena kāyasya tathā tathā saṃsthānaṃ kāyavijñaptiḥ / gatirityapare / prasyandamānasya hi kāyakarma no 'prasyandamānasyeti / ta ucyante
column2: Bodily viñapti is such and such a shape of the body by reason of a volition According to others, bodily vijñapti is displacement, for it takes place when there is movement, and not when there is no movement.
The author answers: This is not so, because all conditioned things áre Tṉnoeṇtary.
What is understood by “momentary” ?
Kṣaṇa means to perish immediately after having acquired its being;
ksaṇika īs a āharma that has kṣaṇa, as a daṇḍika is one who has a staff.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarva hi saṃskṛtamātmalābhā dūrdhvaṃ na bhavatīti yatraiva jātaṃ tatraiva dhvasyate /
column2: A conditioned thing does not exist beyond the acquisition of its being;
it perishes on the spot where it arises; it cannot go from this spot to another.
Consequently bodily v/ñapti is not movement.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syādetadeva yadi sarvasya ṣkṇikatvaṃ sidhyet / siddhamevaitat viddhi / kutaḥ / saṃskṛtasyāvaśyaṃ /
column2: If conditioned things are momentary, we would admit that they are not susceptible of displacement.
It is proven that they are momentary, "since they necessarily perish;

Destruction is a negation: how can a negation "be done" or "created? " Therefore destruction does not depend on a cause. Destruction does not depend on a cause: hence a conditioned thing perishes as soon as it arises;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'sāvākasmikok vināśo yadi bhāvasyotpannamātrasya na syāt paścādapi na syādbhāvasya tulyatvāt /
column2: if it did not perish immediately, it would not perish later, since it would then remain the same. Since you admit that it perishes, you must admit that it immediately perishes. Would you say that a conditioned thing changes and that, consequently, it is later subject to destruction? It is absurd to say that a certain thing changes, becoming another thing, staying the same thing that you say shows its modified characteristics.
There are many remarks to make with respect to this.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nyathātvam / na hi sa eva tasmādvilakṣaṇo yujyate / dṛṣṭo vai kāṣṭhādīnāmagnyādisaṃyogādvināśaḥ /
column2: In fact, people do not directly perceive the destruction of kindling by reason of fire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca dṛṣṭādgariṣṭhaṃ pramāṇamastīti / na ca sarvasyākasmiko vināśaḥ kathaṃ tāvat bhavān kāṣṭhādīnāmagnyādisaṃyogādvināśaṃ paśyāmīti manyate / teṣāṃ punaradarśanāt /
column2: If you think that kindling perishes through its relationship to fire because we no longer see the kindling when this relationship has taken place, then your thesis rests on an inference, and not on direct perception, and your reasoning is not conclusive. The fact that we no longer see kindling after its relationship with fire is open to two interpretations: either the kindling perishes by reason of this relationship, or itunceasingly perishes in and of itself, and under normal conditions isunceasingly reborn in and of itself, but stops renewing itself by virtue of its relationship with the fire.
You admit that the destruction of the flame is spontaneous.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kimagnisaṃyogātkāṣṭhādayo vinaṣṭā ato na dṛśyante utāho svayaṃ vinaṣṭā anye ca punarnotpannā ato na dṛśyante /
column2: When, after a relationship with wind, the flame is no longer visible, you admit that this relationship is not the cause of the destruction of the flame;

but you admit that the flame, by virtue of this relationship, stops renewing itself. The same for the sound of the bell: a hand, laid on the bell, prevents a renewing of its sound; but it does not destroy the sound that you admit is momentary.
Therefore it is inference that should determine this question.
The Vatsīputrīyas: What reasons do you bring to bear in favor of the thesis of spontaneous destruction?
We have already said that destruction, being a negative state, cannot be caused.
We would further say that if destruction is the effect of a cause, nothing would not perish without a cause.
If, like arising, destruction proceeds from a cause, it would never take place without a cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣaṇikānāṃ ca buddhiśabdārciṣāṃ dṛṣṭa ākasmiko vināśa iti nāyaṃ hetumapekṣate /
column2: Now we hold that intelligence, a flame, or a sound, which are momentary, perish without their destruction depending on a cause.
Hence the destruction of the kindling, etc. , is. The Vaibhāṣikas maintain that an earlier thought perishes by reason of a later thought, that earlier sound perishes by reason of later sound.
But the two thoughts in question are not simultaneous.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi śaṃsayaniścayajñānayoryuktaṃ samavadhānaṃ sukhaduḥkhayo rāgadveṣayorvā /
column2: Some contradictory thoughts:—doubt and certainty, pleasure and suffering, love and hate,—do not displace one another; and the same holds for non-contradictory thoughts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā ca paṭubuddhiśabdānantaramapaṭubuddhiśabdāvutpadyete tadā kathamapaṭuḥ samānajātīyo dharmaḥ paṭīyāṃsaṃ hiṃsyāt /
column2: And if you suppose that they do contradict one another, then how can weak dharmas destroy strong dharmas of the same type—as when weak thoughts or sounds immediately follow strong thoughts or sounds?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: antyayośca kathaṃ yo 'pyarciṣāmavasthānahetvabhāvāddharmādharmavaśādvā vināśaṃ manyate tadapyayuktam /
column2: Some think that a flame perishes through the absence of a cause of duration.

But an absence cannot be a cause. According to the Vaiśeṣikas, flame perishes by reason of dharma anṇd adharma, merit and demerit. This explanation is inadmissible. Dharma and adharmma would both be causes of arising and of destruction: harma would cause the flame to arise and cause it to perish, accordingly as the flame is favorable orAccordingly as it is unfavorable or favorable.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cāpyutpādavināśahetvordharmārdharmayoḥ kṣaṇe kṣaṇe vṛttilābhapratibandhau bhavitumarhataḥ /
column2: Now we cannot admit that dharma and adharma enter into activity and cease being active from moment to moment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sakyaṣcaiṣa kāraṇa parikalpaḥ sarvatra samskṛte kartumityalaṃ vivādena /
column2: Furthermore since this manner of explaining destruction would hold for all conditioned things, it is useless to pursue the discussion. You do not have the right to say that kindling perishes through its relationship with the flame.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi ca kāṣṭhādīnāmagnyādisaṃyogahetuko vināśaḥ syādevaṃ sati pākajānāṃ guṇānāṃ pakvataratamotpattau hetuḥ syācca vināśakaḥ / hetureva ca vināśakaḥ syāt / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: If one holds that the destruction of the kindling, etc. , has for its cause the relationship of this kindling with fire, one would then be forced to acknowledge that a cause that engenders is at the same time a cause that destroys.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ghāsādyagnisaṃbandhā guṇāḥ pākajā utpannāstata eva tādṛśādvā punaḥ pakvataratamotpattau teṣāṃ vināśa iti hetureva teṣāṃ vināśakaḥ syāddhetvaviśiṣṭo vā /
column2: Cooking, or a relationship with fire, produces different products, of deeper and deeper color. The same cause that produces the first color destroys this first color, or, at least—if you object that it refers to a new relationship with fire, since the fire is momentary—the cause that destroys the first color is similar to the cause that produces it. Now it is impossible that a certain cause would.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca yuktaṃ yata eva tādṛśāddvā teṣāṃ bhāvastata eva tādṛśācca teṣāṃ punarabhāva iti /
column2: Produce a certain effect and that later this same cause, ora parallel cause, would destroy this same effect.
Would you say that, if the successive flames are different—long, short, large and small,—our conclusion does not become indispensable? Let us use another example.

By the prolonged action of ashes, snow, caustics, sun, water, or earth, there arises and disappears in turn different “products of cooking.” But you do not attribute the characteristic of momentariness to these diverse factors of cooking.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhyāpaḥ kvāthyamānāḥ kṣīyante kiṃ tatrāgnisaṃyogāḥ kurvanti /
column2: Some ask why water diminishes when it is heated if a relationship with fire is not destruction of the water?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tejodhātuṃ prabhāvato vardhayanti yasya prābhāvādapāṃ saṃghātaḥ kṣāmakṣāmo jāyate yāvadatikṣāmatāṃ gato 'nte na punaḥ saṃtānaṃ saṃtanoti /
column2: By reason of its relationship with fire, through the force of the fire, the heat element—which is present in water—increases and, increasing, causes the mass of water to be reborn in quantities more and more reduced, until being totally reduced, the water ceases renewing itself. This is what a relationship with fire does to water.
This is what a relationship with fire does to water.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmānnāsti bhāvānāṃ vināśahetuḥ svayameva tu bhaṅguratvādvinaśyanta utpannamātrā vinaśyantīti siddha eṣāṃ kṣaṇabhaṅgaḥ kṣaṇabhaṅgācca gatyabhāvaḥ gatyabhimānastu deśāntareṣu nirantarotpattau tṛṇajvālāvat /
column2: Things perish on their own because it is their nature to do so, and as they perish upon arising, they are momentary. Thus, there is no movement or displacement, only arising in another place of the second moment of the series. This is even true for fire consuming firewood. The idea of movement is a false conception.
Bodily vôiñapti is not displacement or movement, but rather shape.
The Sautrāntikas say that shape is not a distinct thing, but only a designation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekadiṅmukhe hi bhūyasi varṇa utpanne dīrghaṃ rūpamiti prajñapyate /
column2: When there arises a large mass of color in one direction, this mass is called "long.

When a mass of color is small by comparison, it is.
caturdiśaṃ bhūyasi caturasramiti /	When a color arises in a great quantity in the four directions, it is called square.
When it arises equally in all directions, it is called "circular.
The other figures - high, low, etc. - are explained in the same manner.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā 'lātamekasyāṃ diśi deśāntareṣvanantareṣu nirantaramāśu dṛśyamānaṃ dīrghamiti pratīyate sarvato dṛśyamānaṃ maṇḍalamiti / na tu khalu jātyantaramasti saṃsthānam / yadi hi syāt dvigrāhyaṃ syāt
column2: When a color arises in a great quantity in the direction of the zenith, it is called "high," etc. Shape is thus not a thing in and of itself, a npa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣuṣā hi dṛṣṭvā dīrghamityavasīyate kāyendriyeṇāpi spṛṣṭveti dvābhyāmasya grahaṇaṃ prāpnuyāt / na ca rūpāyatanasya dvābhyāṃ grahaṇamasti /
column2: If shape were a thing in and of itself, it would be perceived by two organs. In fact, seeing through the organ of sight, one has the idea of length, etc. ; touching through the tactile organ, one has the idea of length.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā vā spraṣṭavye dīrghādigrahaṇaṃ tathā varṇe saṃbhāvyatām /
column2: Thus if length, or any other shape, were a thing in and of itself, it would be perceived by two organs.

Now, according to the scriptural definition, rupayaana, the visible physical matter, is perceived by only the eye. The Vaibhashikas answer that touch does not perceive length relative to softness or hardness, arranged in a certain manner, without length forming part of the tangible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tu sāhacaryāt bhavati na tu sākṣāt grahaṇam /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas: When we have the idea of length after having touched something, we are not perceiving shape through touch;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā 'gnirūpaṃ dṛṣṭvā tasyoṣṇatāyāṃ smṛtirbhavati puṣpagandhaṃ ca ghrātvā tadvarṇa iti /
column2: we remember the shape, because it is associated with a tangible. It is the same when we see the color of fire, for we then remember heat; and when we smell the odor of flower, we then remember its color. In the two cases that you allege, one imagines that a color recalls a tangible, or that an odor recalls color, because the dharmas as cause are closely associated: all fire is hot, and certain odors belong to certain flowers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yuktamatrāvyabhicāratvādanyenānyasya smaraṇaṃ natu kiñcit spraṣṭavyaṃ kvacit saṃsthāne niyataṃ yatastatra smaraṇaṃ niyamena syāt /
column2: But a tangible is not invariably associated with a certain shape: how then does the perception of a tangible provoke the remembrance of a certain shape?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athāsatyapi sāhacaryaniyame saṃsthānasmaraṇaṃ niyamena syāt / varṇe 'pi syāt varṇavaddhā saṃsthāne 'pyaniyamena syāt /
column2: If a similar remembrance is produced without there having been an invariable association between a tangible and its shape, one would in this same manner remember color after. Having touched something.
But such is not the case.
Hence, one must not say that the perception of a tangible provokes the remembrance of its shape. Second argument.

One sees many shapes in a multicolored piece of cloth. Thus, there would be, according to you, many rpas, in the category of shape inone and the same piece: this is impossible, as itwas for color. If shape were a real thing, that which, in the cloth, forms part of a long line cannot at the same time form a part of a short line. Third argument. All "real' r%%pa, susceptible of being struck,-blue, etc. .
-is made up of real atoms of a certain nature: color rpa necessarily exists in the octuple atom, etc. Now.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaccāpi kiñcit sapratighaṃ rūpamasti tadavaśyaṃ paramāṇau vidyate /
column2: Shape does not exist in an atom.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cāṇau tat na ca saṃsthānaṃ paramāṇau vidyate dīrghādi /
column2: There is no atom of length. In fact, when a long mass diminishes, we arrive at the moment when we no longer have the idea of long with regard to it, but rather the idea of short: hence this idea does not proceed from a rūpa "shapeʼ existing in the thing.
Therefore what we designate.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha mattaṃ saṃsthānaparamāṇava eva tathā saṃniviṣṭā dīrghādisaṃjñāṃ labhanta iti / so 'yaṃ kevalaḥ pakṣapātasteṣāmasiddhatvāt / siddhasvalakṣāṇānāṃ hi teṣāṃ saṃcayo yujyate /
column2: If you maintain that the expressions, "long," etc. refer to some atoms of shape arranged in a certain manner, and that some atoms that would not be "shape" by nature could not be designated as "long," etc—this is merely repeating your affirmation without the support of any argument.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca saṃsthānāvayavānāṃ varṇādivat svabhāvaḥ siddha iti kuta eṣāṃ saṃcayaḥ /
column2: In fact, if the existence of special atoms of shape were proved, you would be able to maintain that united, arranged in a certain fashion, they constitute length: but since the existence of these atoms has not been proved, as the existence of the atoms of color has been proved, how could they be united and arranged?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi varṇaścābhinno bhavati saṃsthānaṃ ca bhinnaṃ dṛśyate mṛdbhājanānām /
column2: If a shape is not distinct in color, if a shape is nothing other than a certain color, then shapes would not differ when their color is the same: now some jugs of the same color have different shapes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu coktaṃ yathā kṛtvā varṇe dīrghādisaṃjñā prajñapyate tathā ca pipīlikādīnāmabhede paṅkticakrādīnāṃ bhedaḥ prajñāyate tathā saṃsthānasyāpi
column2: Have we not said that one designates a number of real things arranged in a certain manner as "long? Some ants, all similar, arrange. In the same way the shapes of jugs differ without their color differing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi tamapi dūrādvā varṇamapaśyantaḥ sthāṇvādīnāṃ dairghyādīni paśyanti varṇameva te tatrāvyaktaṃ dṛṣṭvā dīrghādiparikalpaṃ kurvanti /
column2: But, in darkness or at a distance, one sees the shape of an object,—a column, a person, etc. ,— without seeing its color. Hence shape exists separate from color. In fact, one first sees color in an indistinct manner;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paṅktisenāparikalpavat / itthaṃ caitadevam / yatkadācidanirdhāryamāṇaparicchedaṃ saṃghātamātramavyaktaṃ dṛśyate kimapyetaditi /
column2: one then forms—through the mental consciousness—the idea of shape, in the same way that one forms the idea of a line, or the idea of an army accordingly as one has seen, indistinctly, some birds, some ants, some elephants, etc: “This army is arranged in a circle”. Or rather it happens that one does not clearly distinguish either color or shape; one only knows—through the mental consciousness—a mass.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athedānīṃ kāyasya gatiṃ nirākṛṭya samsthānaṃ ca tatra bhavantaḥ sautrāntikāḥ kāṃ kāyavijñarptiṃ prajñapayanti /
column2: You Sautrantikas negate both movement and shape. Then what is designated by the term “bodily vrjñapñ?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃsthānameva hi te kāyavijñarpti prajñapayanti / natu punardravyataḥ /
column2: ” 'We say that bodily vrjñapi is shape [thus separating ourselves from the Vatsiputriyas-Sarmitiyas] but we do not say that shape is a thing in.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāṃ ca prajñapayantaḥ kathaṃ kāyakarma prajñapayanti /
column2: If you maintain that bodily vs/ñapti is not a real thing, but solely a shape that exists as designation, what then is the real dharma that constitutes bodily action?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyādhiṣṭhānaṃ karma kāyakarma yā cetanā kāyasya tatra tatra praṇetrī /
column2: Bodily action is the action which has for its object the body: that is to say, the volition that puts a body into motion in diverse ways: it proceeds by being supported on this gate which is the body, and is thus called bodily action.

Other actions should be defined according to their natures: ie. , vocal action is the action which has the voice for its object; mental action is the action of the anas or action associated with the manas. If bodily action and vocal action are volition, what difference is there between the two types of action defined in this scripture? There are two types of volition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi “cetanā karma cetayitvā ce“tyuktaṃ saṃkalpacetanā pūrvaṃ bhavatyevaṃ saṃkalpacetanā pūrvaṃ bhavatyevaṃ caivaṃ ca kariṣyāmīti /
column2: First, the initial or preparatory stage, wherein one produces a volition which is pure volition, I must do such and such an action”;
this is what the Scripture calls cetanākarman.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yayā kāyaḥ preryate sā 'sau cetayitvā karmetyucyate /
column2: One produces a volition of action, the volition of doing an action in conformity with what has been previously willed, to move the body or to emit a voice: this is what the Scripture calls ce¢ayitvā karmam, action after having been willed, or willed action. If this is the case, then informative action does not exist: bodily-vocal action, according to you, is only volition; there is no place for the vrñap#i which is matter by its nature.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi vijñaptyabhāvādavijñaptirapi kāmāvacarī nāstīti mahānto doṣā anuṣajyante / anuṣaṅgānāṃ punaḥ pratyanuṣaṅgā bhaviṣyanti /
column2: And if viñapti does not exist, then v/jñapti,“non-information”” of the sphere of Kāmadhātu,does not exist. From whence there would be a great number of difficulties which will be enumerated later (ie. , saṁvarāsaṁvarābhãáva, etc. , see below 4a-b). These difficulties can be refuted. Av#ñapri is explained very well in our system.

We admit two types of volition bearing on bodily actions and vocal sounds which are the bodily and vocal vṝjñaptis. These two types of volitions—which bear the names of bodily action and vocal. Where is the difficulty in this?
This s% generis volition is subordinate to the mind, like the eviñapti which in our system arises from dhyāna, for the avijñapti of Kāmadhātu develops during sleep, etc. No, for this s%.
generis volition is projected by a certain volition of decision, its distant cause, and by a certain volition of action and voice, its near cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sā 'pi ca vijñaptiḥ satī tadākṣepe cetanāyā balaṃ nibhālayate /
column2: Now however you would have it that the vijñapti, if it exists, would depend, like the projection of the evġjñapti, on the force of the thought: for it is itself nonintelligent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jaḍatvāt / dravyameva tu saṃsthānaṃ vaibhāṣikā varṇayanti saṃsthānātmikāṃ tu kāyavijñaptim /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas say that shape exists in and of itself, and that bodily vijñapti is shape.
Vocal vijñapti is vocal sound.
Sound whidch is discourse by nature—that is, articulated sound (ii. 47)—is vocaḻ viñapti.
Avijñapti has already been defined.
The Santrāntikas say that the avsjñapt# does not really exist as a substance: because it solely consists of not doing an action after.
because one designates a thing which would exist by reason of past primary elements as evijñapti; now past dharmas no longer exist;
and because avijñapti does not have the nature of rupa, the nature of rupa is rupyate and since the aviñapti is not "susceptible of destruction", it cannot be rupa.
Scripture says that rupa is of three types and that there is a pure rupa; there is increase of merit;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “tribhiḥ sthānai rūpasya rūpasaṃgraho bhavati / asti rūpaṃ sanidarśanaṃ sapratigham /
column2: and there is a course of action for him who is not concerned with himself, etc. A scripture says that there are three types of rupa: "Rupa is embraced within a threefold rupa: there is visible rupa susceptible of destruction;
there is an invisible rupa susceptible of destruction;
and there is an invisible rupa, free from destruction," and this latter can only be the avijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravaṃ ca bhagavatā rūpamuktam / “anāsravāḥ dharmāḥ katame /
column2: The Blessed One said in a scripture that there is pure rupa: "What are the pure dharmas? All rupa of the past, the future and the present.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmin rūpe 'tītānāgatapratyutpanno notpadyate 'nunayo vā pratigho vā yāvadyasminvijñāne / ima ucyante 'nāsravā dharmā” iti /
column2: all consciousness of the past, future, present, concerning which there.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cā vijñaptiṃ virahayyāsti rūpamanidarśanamapratighaṃ nāpyanā sravam /
column2:
Now, apart from avÉjñapti, there exists no rpa which can be invisible and free from destruction, and no rāpa which is pure. [For bodily and vocal action does not pertain to one who has entered into the Truth of the Way, mārgasatyasamāpanna.

“ebhiḥ saptabhiraupadhikaiḥ puṇyakriyāvastubhiḥ samanvāgatasya śrāddhasya kulaputrasya	, There are seven material meritorious works, .
kuladuhiturvā carato vā svapato vā tiṣṭhato vā jāgrato vā satatasamitamabhivardhata	when a believer, son or daughter of good family, who is endowed, walks, stands still, sleeps or is awake, his merit increases with intensity, without ceasing;
eva puṇyamupajāyata eva puṇyam /	merit continues adding to itself. What are these seven material works?
evaṃ niraupadhikairi“ti //	In this same way there are seven non-material meritorious works .”
na cāvijñaptimantareṇānyamanaso 'pti puṇyasyābhivṛddhiryujyate /	By reason of what dharma, other than the avġjñapti, could merit increase even when the mind is not good, or when one is without thought?
akurvataśca svayaṃ paraiḥ kārayataḥ karmapathā na sidhyeyurasatyāmavijñaptau /	1f avijñapti does not exist, he who does not himself act, who gives orders to others, will not be endowed with a course of action.
nahyājñāpanavijñaptiḥ maulaḥ karmapatho yujyate /	A vocal action that consists of giving an order cannot constitute a course of action, killing etc. ;
tasya karyaṇo 'kṛtatvāt /	this action in fact does not actually accomplish the action to be accomplished. Would one say that when the action is accomplished the action that consists of giving the order becomes a course of action?

uktaṃ ca bhagavatā “dharmā bhikṣavo bāhyamāyatanamekādaśabhirāyatanairasaṃgṛhītamanidarśanamapratighami“ti /	The Blessed One said, “Monks, the dharmas, the external sources of consciousness not included within the eleven āyatanas, are invisible, and are free from destruction”.
na tvarūpītyuktam /	He did not say that the dharmāyatana īs non-rūpa.
tatra kiṃ prayojanaṃ syādyadi dharmāyatanāntargatamavijñaptirūpaṃ naśyeta /	If the Blessed One did not intend to refer to the avġiñapti, which is rūpa and so included in the dharmāyatana, then what is the rāpa that is included in the dharmāyatana?
aṣṭāṅgaśca mārgo na syādavijñaptimantareṇa / samāpannasya samyagvākkarmāntājīvānāmayogāt /	If avijñap does not exist, the Way no longer has eight parts, for the parts, samyagvākc, samyakkarmānta, and samyagājīva (correct speech, correct action, and correct livelihood, iv. 86), are incompatible. with absorption. yattarhīdamuktaṃ “tasyaivaṃ jānata evaṃ paśyataḥ samyagdṛṣṭirbhāvanāparipūriṃ gacchati samyak saṃkalpaḥ samyak vyāyāmaḥ samyak smṛtiḥ samyak samādhiḥ /	One would answer, a scripture says, When he knows thus, when he sees thus, samyagdrṣṭi, samyaksaṁkalp gvyāyãma, samyaksmrti, and samyaksamādhi are cultivated and achieved;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvameva cāsya samyak vāvakrmāntājīvāḥ pariśuddhā bhavanti paryavadātā” iti /
column2: sangyagvāc, samyakkarmānta and samṣyagājīva have been previously purified. " Thus the last three are considered as véññapti and as previous to absorption.

This text, the Vaibhāṣikas say, does not refer to the last three parts of the Way, but rather to speech, action, and livelihood in a state of detachment which have been obtained through the worldly path.
This does not prevent speech, etc. , from not forming part of the Way under the aspect of avijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi samādānādurdhvaṃ tadasti yenānyamanasko 'pyayaṃ bhikṣuḥ syāt bhikṣuṇī veti /
column2: For a person who has assumed the vows of religion is still a Bhikṣu or Bhikṣuṇī, when his mind is bad or neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: setuśca sūtre viraktiruktā / dauḥśīlyavivandhatvāt / na vā bhavantī seturbhavitumarhatītyastyevāvijñaptiḥ / atra sautrāntikā āhuḥ bahvapyetaccitramapyetat /
column2: A scripture teaches that the renouncing of sin is a dike which.

An “absence” cannot be a dike: vôrati is thus a real dharma, and not the mere fact of no longer accomplishing an action which one has renounced, as the Sautrāntikas maintain. These arguments are numerous and diverse, but are not conclusive.
Let us examine them one by one.
The Sūtra teaches that rāpa is of three types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra yogācārā upadiśanti / dhyāyināṃ samādhiviṣayo rūpaṃ samādhiprabhāvādutpadyate / cakṣurindriyāviṣayatvāt anidarśanam /
column2: The Yogācārins say that in the Dhyānas, through the force of absorption, a r%pa arises which is the object of the absorption, that is, which is perceived by the person in the absorption, ‘This rpa is not seen by the eye; it is thus invisible.
It does not “cover,” it does not occupy a place: it is thus “free from destruction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha matam / kathamidānīṃ tat rūpam iti /
column2: ” If you ask how this object of absorption can be r%pa, you forget that the existence of gvġiñapti would give rise to the same question. The scripture says that there is a pure r%pa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etadavijñaptau samānam / yadapyuktamanāsravarūpokteriti tad eva samādhiprabhāvasaṃbhūtaṃ rūpamanāsrave samādhāvanāsravaṃ varṇayanti yogācārāḥ / arhato yadrūpaṃ bāhyaṃ cetyapare /
column2: The Yogācārins maintain that the/pa that arises through the force of the absorption is.

pure, since the absorption is pure. But other masters maintain that the rpa of the Arhats and external rpa, namely the five objects of the senses, are pure because they are not a support of the vices.
To this one can object that the scripture expresses itself, "What are the impure dharmas?
All that which is organ of sight, all that which is visible.

The Drstantikas answer that all the dharmas referred to in this scripture are qualified as impure because they are not opposed to the vices: in fact, only the mind and its mental states can oppose the vices and destroy them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paryāyeṇa tarhi tadeva sāsravaṃ cānāsravaṃ ca syāt / kiṃ syāt / lakṣaṇasaṃkaraḥ syāt /
column2: To this one could object that the same dharmas would be impure, because they are not opposed to the vices, and at the same time pure, because they are not a support of the vices, with the unpleasant consequence that the characteristic of pure and impure would be confused.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tat sāsravaṃ tathā na kadācidanāsravamiti ko 'tra saṃkaraḥ /
column2: No, answer the Drstantikas, for these dharmas are not pure from the same point of view in which they are impure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi ca rūpāyatanādīni ekāntena sāsravāṇi syuriha sūtre kimartha viśeṣitāni syu“ryāni rūpāṇi sāsravāṇi sopādānīyāni cetaḥkhilamrakṣavastvi“ti vistaraḥ /
column2: Further, if the visibleThe impure and upādāna-provoking rūpas, the impure and upādāna-provoking dharmas are the cause of the hardening of the mind and of hypocrisy.
The scripture says that merit increases.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā dātṝṇāṃ dāyāḥ paribhujyante tathā tathā bhoktṝṇāṃ guṇaviśeṣādanugrahaviśeṣāccānyamanasāmapi dātṝṇāṃ tadālambanadānacetanā bhāvitāḥ saṃtatayaḥ sūkṣmaṃ pariṇāmaviśeṣaṃ prāpnuvanti yenāyatyāṃ bahutaraphalābhiniṣpattaye samarthā bhavanti /“
column2: The ancient masters say: It is in the nature of things that merit increases when persons who have received a gift utilize this gift: by reason of the qualities of these persons (dhyāna, absorption of benevolence, etc. ), by reason of the benevolence that they get out of the gift for themselves and for all creatures, the mental series of the givers, be they of bad or of neutral minds, is found to be perfumed by the volition of giving which has for its object the person who receives: their series undergo a subtle ascending transformation and arrives at the state where they are finally capable of bringing forth many results.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “idamabhisaṃdhāyoktaṃ” bhavedabhivardhata eva puṇyamupajāyata eva puṇyam iti / atha mataṃ kathamidānīṃ saṃtānāntaraviśeṣādanyamanaso 'pi saṃtānāntarasya pariṇāmaḥ setsyatīti / etadavijñaptau smānam / kathamidānīṃ saṃtānāntaraviśeṣātsaṃtānāntare dharmāntaramavijñaptiḥ setsyatīti nirūpadhikeṣvidānīṃ puṇyakriyāvastuṣu kathaṃ bhaviṣyatīti /
column2: It is in this sense that the text says, “Merit increases in an intense and uninterrupted manner, merit adds to itself.

”Even during dreams these volitions are linked together. On the contrary, we do not see how the partisans of an avirñapti can explain the growth of merit in the case of nonmaterial meritorious work. This does not consist of bodily or vocal action, but merely the joy experienced with regard to the Tathāgata or the Śrāvakas; it does not consist of an absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avijñaptivādinastu niraupadhike yatra vijñaptirnāsti tatra kathāmavijñaptiḥ syāt /
column2: Now according to the Vaibhāṣikas, the vijñapti can only give rise to the véjñapti or to an absorption. Hence it is impossible here.
But according to other masters, in the case also of material meritorious works, merit proceeds from the repetition of a volition having for its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi sūtra uktaṃ “yasyograbhikṣuḥ śīlavān kalyāṇadharmā piṇḍakaṃ paribhujyāpramāṇaṃ
column2: But this opinion is inadmissible in light of the scripture which says, “When an energetic Bhikṣu, endowed with morality, possessor of good dharmas, eats the alms of a donor, he then enters into and dwells in the.
”Now does the donor whose merit thus continues to increase, have a special volition whose object is the person who receives?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: puṇyābhiṣyandaḥ kuśalābhiṣyandaḥ sukhāsvādadhāraḥ pratikāṅkṣitavya” ityatra tadānīṃ dātuḥ kaścetanāviśeṣaḥ / tasmātsaṃtatipariṇāmaviśeṣa eva nyāyyaḥ /
column2: In the case of material meritorious works, the merit proceeds from a transformation of the series.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadapyuktaṃ “kārayataḥ kathaṃ karmapathāḥ setsyantī“ti tatrāpyevaṃ varṇayanti / tatprayogeṇa pareṣāmupaghātaviśeṣātprayoktuḥ sūkṣmaḥ saṃtatipariṇāma viśeṣo jāyate
column2: According to the Vaibhashikas, if the vijnapti does not exist, he who has an action accomplished by another will not be endowed with the course of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yata āyatyāṃ samante 'pi bahutaraphalābhinirvarttanasamarthā bhavatīti svayamapi
column2: When an emissary charged with murder accomplishes the murder, it is in the nature of things that the mental series of the author of the instigation will submit to a certain subtle transformation by virtue of which his series will bear a result later. This holds likewise when one acts for oneself;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ca kurvataḥ kriyāphalaparisamāptāveṣa eva nyāyo veditavyaḥ /
column2: when the course of action is achieved, at this moment the series.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'sau saṃtatipariṇāmaviśeṣaḥ karmapatha ityākhyāyate / kārye kāraṇopacārāt / kāyikavācikatvaṃ tu tatkriyāphalatvādyathā vijñaptivādināmavijñapteriti /
column2: This transformation is called “course of action, and consequently the person whose series is transformed is endowed with the course of action—for the effect receives the name which belongs more properly to the cause, and this transformation is called bodily or vocal accordingly as it results from an action of the body or the voice. It is by virtue of these same principles that the partisans of evijñapti consider the avjñapti as a bodily or vocal course of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upātteṣu skandheṣu trikālayā cetanayā prāṇātipātāvadhvena spṛśyata iti bhadantaḥ /
column2: The Bhadanta proves in a different manner the nonexistence of gvrjñapti: “A person is touched by the sin of murder by reason of a tritemporal volition with regard to the skandhasr which constitute a living being, that is, when he thinks, ‘I shall kill;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: haniṣyāmi hanmi hatamiti cāsya yadā bhavatīti / na tviyatā karmapathaḥ parisamāpyate / mā bhūdahate 'pi mātrādau hatābhimānināmānantaryaṃ karmeti /
column2: I kill; he is killed. The course of action is complete when there is preparatory action, principal action, and consecutive action, consisting solely of cetanā, iv.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svayaṃ tu ghnata etāvāṃścetanāsamudācāra ityayamatrābhiprāyo yuktarūpaḥ syāt /
column2: But this triple volition does not necessarily bring about theNevertheless all this exercise of volition, "I shall kill, I kill, he is killed" applies only to the person who kills: the intention of the Bhadanta is to refer to this type of murder.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ka idānīmeṣa pradveṣo yadavijñaptiḥ prakṣipyate saṃtatipariṇāmaviśeṣaścābhyupagamyate tathaivāprajñāyamānaḥ /
column2: But, why do you, in your antipathy, deny the existence of the gvyapti and yet admit a transformation of the mental series?
I thus have no antipathy.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kintu cittānvayakāyaprayogeṇa kriyāparisamāptau tābhyāṃ pṛthagbhūtaṃ dharmāntaraṃ prayojayiturutpadyata iti notpadyate paritoṣaḥ /
column2: But, to say that there arises at the moment of the achieving of the course of action by a bodily operation dependent on a mind, a certain dharma, called avyapti, either from the mind of him who has ordered the course of action, or separate from the. The body of him who has accomplished the murder, is a hypothesis that cannot satisfy us;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatkṛtaprayogasaṃbhūtā tu kriyāparisamāptistasyaiva tannimittaḥ saṃtatipariṇāmo bhavatīti bhavati paritoṣaḥ /
column2: but to say that there is produced at the moment of the achievement of the course of action by an operation ordered by a certain person, a transformation of the mental series of this person, is a hypothesis that satisfies us.
And it also satisfies us that the result arises from a transformation of the series and not from an av/jñapti.
“If the viñaptúÉ does not exist, how could there be zvijñapti²?” “The avijñapti consists solely in no longer doing a certain action,”
“The gvġjñapti cannot depend on past primary elements.”
The dharmāyatanais not defined as nonmaterial.

The response to this objection is as has been given above: there is an invisible r%pa free from destruction, forming part of the dharmāyatana: this is not the avijñapti; this is a pṁpa which is the object of the absorption and which arises from the force of the absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadapyuktamaṣṭāṅga āryamārgo na syāditi / aṅgaṃ tāvadācakṣva /
column2: The Way, say the Vaibhāṣikas, would not have eight parts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ mārgasamāpannasya samyagvākkarmāntājīvā bhavantīti / kimasau vācaṃ bhāṣyate kriyāṃ vā karoti cīvarādīn vā paryeṣate / netyāha / kiṃ tarhi / tadrūpāmanāsravāmavijñaptiṃ pratilabhate /
column2: How does the saint, when he has attained the Way, [when he sees or >Does he pronounce correct speech, act in a correct manner, and correctly ask for the robes of a monk?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasyāḥ pratilambhādvyutthito 'pi na punarmithyāvāgādiṣu pravartate samyagvāgādiṣu ca pravartate /
column2: In the Pat, the saint takes possession of certain pure avijñaptii, so that, when he leaves the contemplation, it is by the force of these pure gviñaptis that he produces correct speech, actions, and livelihood, and does not produce incorrect speech, actions, and livelihood. A cause takes the name of its result;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato nimitte naimittikopacārādavijñaptau tadākhyā kriyate / yadyevamihāpyevaṃ kiṃ na gṛhyate mārgasamāpanno vināpyavijñaptyā tadrūpamāśayaṃ ca āśrayaṃ ca pratilabhate yasya pratilambhāt vyutthito 'pi na punarmithyāvāgādiṣu pravartate
column2: thus speech, action and livelihood are designated as avijñapti. If this is so, why not accept my theory? There is no avijñapti;

but the saint, when he finds himself in the Path, takes possession of a certain intention and of a certain personality so that, when he comes out of this contemplation, by reason of the force of these two factors he henceforth produces correct speech, actions and livelihood. One gives to the cause the name of their result;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato nimitte naimittikopacāraṃ kṛtvā aṣṭau mārgāṅgāni vyavasthāpyanta iti /
column2: and we can thus affirm that the Path possesses eight parts.
What is non-commission? The person who is in absorption acquires, through the force of the Path, definite absolute abstention.
This abstention, which is acquired having the pure Path as its support, is pure. This is a part of the Path.
Without doubt, the part is not a "thing", being only abstention: but these are not the only real and distinct things which constitute the dharmuas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyāthā 'ṣṭau lokadharmāḥ lābho 'lābhaḥ yaśo 'yaśaḥ nindā praśaṃsā sukhaṃ duḥkhamiti /
column2: there are for example, the eight worldly dharmas: possession and non-possession; glory and non-glory; praise and blame; pleasure and suffering.

Non-possession of clothes, of food, etc. , is not a thing. If the aviñapti does not exist, say the Vaibhāṣikas, the Prṛātimokṣa discipline would disappear. One refutes this objection according to the same principles, by making a state out of the force of the intention. Discipline is volition which, after it has been translated into the positive action of abstaining from transgression, into the pledge of no longer committing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prātimokṣasaṃvaro 'pi syāt yayā cetanayā vidhipūrvaṃ kṛtvā 'bhyupagamaḥ pratiṣiddhātkarmaṇaḥ kāyavācau saṃvṛṇoti /
column2: Transgression, arrests bad actions and disciplines the body and the voice: the Prātimokṣa discipline should be understood in this manner.

‘The Vaibhāṣikas object that, if the Prātimokṣa discipline is volition, the monk who thinks a thought other than this thought of volition would cease being “disciplined,” for he does not then possess the volition which disciplines.
This objection is worthless.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadbhāvanayā kriyākāle smarataḥ tatpratyupasthānāt setubhāvo 'pi syādakriyāṃ pratijñāṃ saṃsmṛtya saṃsmṛtya lajjito dauḥśīlyākaraṇāt ityarthameva ca tasyāḥ samādānam /
column2: In fact, the mental series is perfumed in such a way that, when a thought of transgression starts to appear, the memory of the vow undertaken also appears: the volition of abstention is then found to be present. And this volition has the characteristic of a dike. When one is obliged not to commit transgression, one remembers this obligation, shame is present, and one constrains oneself in such a manner that one does not violate morality.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi punaravijñaptereva dauḥsīlyaṃ pratibadhnīyāt na kaścitmuṣitasmṛtiḥ śikṣāṃ bhindyāt /
column2: In your system, on the contrary, if immorality is dammed up by an aviñapti independent of memory, then even a person who has a faulty memory would not be able to commit a transgression, since the. avijñapti is always there. Let us stop this discussion here.
The Vaibhāṣikas say that there exists a certain substantial thing, sui generis, which is avrñaptirūpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyasti tacca mahābhūtānyupādāyetyuktam tat kim vijñaptimahābhūtānyevopādāyāvijñaptirutpadyate athānyāni /
column2: We have seen that the avsjñapti arises dependent on the primary elements: the question is then posed whether it derives from the same primary elements which are the support of the v4iapti, that is, the primary elements of the body through which the action termed vġjñapti is accomplished;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyānyeva sā mahābhūtānyupādāyotpadyate / na hi saiva sāmagrī sukṣmaphalā caudārikaphālā ca yujyate /
column2: or if it deṟives from other primary elements. The avijñapti derives from primary elements different from those which serve as the support for the v²jñapti: for it is impossible that one and the same complex of four primary elements would produce both a subtle, derived pa,—the avġjñapti—, and at the same time a gross, derived rūpa, the vijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ khalu yadātanī vijñaptistadātanānyeva sā mahābhūtānyupādāya vartate /
column2: The vijñapti is simultaneous to the primary elements from whence it derives; is such also the case for the avsjñapti?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvamupādāyarūpaṃ prāyeṇaivaṃ kiñcittu vartamānamanāgataṃ cātītāni mahābhūtānyupādāya / kiṃ punastaditi /
column2: The general rule is that all derived r%pa is simultaneous to its primary elements.

But certain derived %pa,—of the present and theFrom the first moment, the vijnapti of Kamadhatu arises derived from past primary elements. The moment the avijnapti arises, it arises derived from primary elements simultaneous to its arising.

From this first moment on, avijnapti of the sphere of Kamadhatu in opposition to the av/jñapti arisen from the dhyana, and pure avijnapti arises, that is, it continues to be reborn, being derived from the same primary elements of the first moment, which are now past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tānyasyā āśrayārthena bhavanti / pratyutpannāni śarīramahābhūtāni saṃniśrayārthena /
column2: These past primary elements constitute, from the second moment onward, the support of the vijnapti, for they are the cause of its pravritti, they are its projecting cause.
The primary elements simultaneous to each of the moments from the second moment onward are the support of the ev#jñapti, for they are the cause of its anuvriti, they are its supporting cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakrasyeva bhūmau saparivartamānasya pāṇyāvedhabhūmipradeśau / atha kutastyāni mahābhūtānyupādāya kutastyaṃ kāyavākkarma /
column2: In the same way, the hand that has hurled the wheel and the ground that supports the wheel are the causes, respectively, of the pravritti and the anuvritti of the.
When impure, bodily and vocal action derive from the primary elements of the sphere to which they belong.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacaraṃ kāyavākkarmaṃ kāmāvacarāṇyeva mahābhūtānyupādāya evaṃ yāvaccaturthadhyānabhūmikaṃ tadbhūmikānyevopādāya /
column2: Bodily and vocal actions of Kāmadhātu derive from the primary elements of Kāmadhātu, aṇd so on to the bodily and vocal actions of the Fourth Dhyāna which derives from primary elements of the Fourth Dhyāṇṉa.
When they are pure, they are from the primary elements of the sphere to which the person who has produced them belongs.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asravaṃ tu kāyavākkarma yasyāṃ bhūmau jātastadutpādayati tadbhūmikānyupādāya tadveditavyam / dhātvapatitatvādanāsravāṇāṃ ca bhūtānāmabhāvāttadvalena cotpatteḥ /
column2: When they are pure, bodily and vocal action derives from the primary elements of the sphere where the person who produces arises: for the pure dharmas are transcendent to the sphere of existence. For there does not exist any pure primary elements from whence one could derive a pure action. For the pure bodily or vocal action arises by reason of the primary elements, and not only through.
What are the characteristics of these two actions, vijñapti and avijñapti? What are the characteristics of the primary elements from whence they derive?
The aviñapti is not integral to the organism, it is also an outflowing;
it belongs solely to living beings.

Not of absorption, it derives from the primary elements which are an outflowing, which are integral to the organism, which are differentiated. The avijñapti is a derived rūpa exempt from mass, non-extended;
thus it cannot be a support of the mind and of mental states; thus it is aseparate, not integral to the sense organism. The aviñapti is never morally neutral: hence it is not arisen from retribution;
it is not of increase;

it remains then that it is an outflowing, that is, produced by sabhāgahetu. The text says, “also of outflowing,” because the avijñapti can be also kṣaṇika: the first pure aviñapti is not an outflowing.
Not absorbed or, in other words belonging to Kāmadhātu, it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sā samādhisaṃbhūtānyaupacayikānyanupātāni ca mahābhūtānyupādāyotpadyate abhinnāni ca yānyeva ca bhūtānyupādāya prāṇātipātādviratirutpadyate tānyeva yāvat saṃbhinnapralāpāt / kiṃ kāraṇam / cittavat bhūtābhedāt /
column2: Derives from primary elements which are an outflowing, and which are integral to the organism.

These primary elements are differentiated, because each of the seven avġñaptis, the renouncing of killing, etc. , which form the Prātimokṣa discipline, derive from a distinct group of the four primary elements. Arisen from absorption, it derives from non-differentiated primary elements, not integral to the organism, and increase. Avjñapti which arises from samādhi, is divided into two types, that is, absorption, and pure discipline. These two both arise from sa/ādhi, are of increase, and not integral to the sense organism. They are both arisen from undifferentiated primary elements. In the same way that the mind which engenders these renouncings is a unity, the primary elements upon which the renouncings are based constitute a unity.
The vijñapti is an outflowing;
being bodily, it is integral to the organism.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punariyaṃ vijñaptirutpadyamānā pūrvakasya saṃsthānasya saṃtānaṃ bādhitvotpadyate utāho na /
column2: Does bodily vjñapti, by arising, destroy or not destroy the preexistent bodily figure which is retribution ?
The twoHypotheses create difficulties.
That it destroys it, is impossible;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vipākarūpasyocchinnasya punaḥ pravandhādavaibhāṣikīyaṃ prāpnoti / athābādhitvā / kathamekasminbhūtasaṃghāte saṃsthānadvayaṃ sidhyati /
column2: for it is contrary to the principles of the Vaibhāṣikas that a rpa, retribution by nature, continues again, after having been interrupted. If on the contrary, bodily vsjñaptá does bot destroy the previous figure, two figares,—the first of retribution, the second of outflowing,—would be found to coexist in one and the same spot.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyānyeva tāni naiḥṣyandikāni tadānīmupajāyante yānyupādāya vijñaptirbhavati /
column2: We must admit that bodily viñapti arises deriving from new primary elements, outflowing in its nature, and that it does not destroy the previous figure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi yadyadevāṅgaṃ niśrityotpadyate vijñaptistena tenāṅgena mahīyasā bhavitavyam / tanmahābhūtairabhivyāpanāt /
column2: If this is the case, the part by means of which a bodily vrñapti is produced would be greater than has existed previously, being penetrated by new primary elements from whence this véiñapti derives.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anabhivyāpane ca punaḥ kathaṃ kṛtsnāṅgena vijñapayet /
column2: If the part has not been penetrated by these new elements, one could not say that the váĩñap# is cteated by the whole part.
We could answer that the body—retribution in nature—presents some voids: thus place is found for the new prirnary elements. Outflowing by nature, from whence the vjñapti derives.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat khalvetat karma paryāyeṇa dvividhaṃ trividhaṃ pañcavidhaṃ cottam / cetanā cetayitvā ceti / cetayitvā punardvidhā /
column2: We have said that action is of two types, cetanā and cetanākṛ̥a, volition and action created by the volition;
of three types, mental, bodily, vocal;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyakarma punaḥ dvividhaṃ vijñaptyākhyamavijñaptyākhyaṃ ca / evaṃ vākkarma cetanā ceti pañcavidhaṃ bhavati /
column2: of five types, cetana, bodily vijñapti, bodily avijñaptśi, vocal vi̥jñapti, and vocal avijñapti.
The avijñapti is never neutral.
It is either good or bad.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avyākṛtaṃ hi cittaṃ durbalamato na śaktaṃ balavatkarmākṣeptuṃ yanniruddhe 'pi tasminnanuvadhnīyāt / tridhā 'nyat
column2: In fact, neutral volition is weak; it is not capable of engendering a powerful action as is the @vrñapti, which continues reproducing itself after its initial cause has disappeared.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhikṣusaṃvaraḥ śramaṇerasaṃvara upāsakasaṃvara upavāsasaṃvaraśca / ityeṣa caturvidhaḥ prātimokṣasaṃvarastu dravyataḥ / pratiniyatalakṣaṇatvāt /
column2: Four types that present distinct characteristics: the discipline of the Bhikṣu, the Śrāmaṇera, the Upāsaka and the Upavāsastha.

In fact, the discipline of the Bhikṣuṇī does not differ, does not exist separately from the discipline of the Bhikṣu; the discipline of the Śikṣamāṇā and the Śrāmaṇetikā do not differ from the discipline of the Śrāmaṇera;
and the discipline of the Upāsikā does not differ from that of the Upāsaka.
The name changes with the gender.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: liṅgamiti vyañjanasyākhyā yena strīpuruṣau liṅgyete / liṅgato hi bhikṣubhikṣuṇyādīnāṃ nāmasaṃcāro bhavati / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: Liṅga is yyañjana, that which distinguishes men and women.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: parivṛtte hi vyañjane bhikṣurbhikṣuṇītyucyate bhikṣuṇī ca punarbhikṣuḥ /
column2: When their gender is modified, the Bhikṣu becomes a Bhikṣuṇī; the Bhikṣuṇī, a Bhikṣu; the Śrāmaṇera, a Śrāmaṇerikā;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śrāmaṇerītyucyate śrāmaṇerī ca punaḥ śikṣamāṇā ca śrāmaṇeraḥ /
column2: the Śrāmaṇerikā, like the Śīkṣamāṇā, becomes a Śrāmaṇera; the Upāsaka, an Upāsikā;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca vyañjanaparivṛttau pūrvasaṃvaratyāge kāraṇamasti nāpyapūrvasaṃvarapratilambhe /
column2: Now one cannot admit that a person, by changing his gender, abandons the former discipline and acquires a new one; the change of gender cannot have this influence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādabhinna eṣāṃ caturṇā saṃvarāṇāṃ tribhyaḥ svabhāvaḥ / ya upāsakasaṃvarācchrāmaṇerasaṃvaraṃ samādatte tasmācca punarbhikṣusaṃvaraṃ kiṃ te
column2: Thus the four female disciplines are identical with the three male disciplines. When the disciplines are undertaken successively, i.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃvarā virativṛddhiyogādanyo 'nya ucyante pañcadaśa viṃśativat dīnāraśateravacca āhosvit pṛthageva te sakalā jāyante / āha /
column2: , the discipline of the Upāsaka with its five precepts, the discipline of the Śrāmāṇera with its ten precepts, and the discipline of the Bhikṣu with its two hundred and fifty precepts, do these disciplines differ solely through the successive additions of new precepts, as the numbers five, ten, twenty differ, as one coin and two coins differ?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: triṣu saṃvareṣu tisraḥ prāṇātipātaviratayo yāvanmadyapānaviratayaḥ / evaṃ śeṣāḥ / ko nu tāsāṃ viśeṣaḥ /
column2: They are not mixed, for in the parts that are common to them all—Upāsakas, Śrāmaṇeras and Bhikṣus all renounce killing, stealing, ilicit sexuality, lying, intoxicating liquors—the three disciplines have some distinct characteristics.
Their differences lie in the difference of the occasions of transgression.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā yathā hi vahutarāṇi śikṣāpadāni samāditsate tathā tathā bahutarebhyo maddapramādapadebhyo
column2: In fact, the person who undertakes the observation of a greater number of rules, avoids by this action itself a greater number of occasions of intoxication-pride and of non-diligence;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nivartamāno bahutarebhyaḥ prāṇātipātādīnāṃ nidānebhyo nivartate viratīnāṃ ca nidāneṣu pravartata iti nidānaviśeṣādviratīnāṃ viśeṣaḥ /
column2: he avoids, by this action, a greater number of occasions of transgression, killing, etc. Consequently the three series of renouncings are not identical with one another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ cāsati bhikṣusaṃvaraṃ pratyācakṣāṇastrīnapi saṃvarānvijahyāddayorapi tatrāntarbhāvāt /
column2: If it were otherwise, that is, if the disciplines of Upāsaka and Śrāmaṇera were integral to the discipline of a Bhikṣu, then the Bhīkṣu who renounces the discipline of a Bhikṣu would renounce at the same time all three disciplines;
a thesis that is not admitted.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt pṛthageva te saṃvarāḥ / te cāvirodhinaḥ // te ca trayo 'pi saha vartante /
column2: Hence the disciplines exist separately.
They can coexist:by undertaking the following disciplines,one does not abandon the preceeding ones.
Thus the fact that a Bhikṣu who renounces his quality of Bhikṣu remains in possession of the discipline of Upāsaka and Śrāmaṇera is explained.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ cāyamupāsako bhavati kathamupavāsastho yāvat bhikṣuḥ /
column2: How does one become an Upāsaka, an Upavāsastha, a Śrāmaṇera, or a Bhikṣu?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcāṣṭadaśasarvebhyo varjyebhyo viratigrahāt / upāsakopavāsasthaśramaṇoddeśabhikṣutā // yathāsaṃkhyamanudeśo veditavyaḥ /
column2: By undertaking the renouncing of the five things to avoid, of the eight, the ten, of all the things to avoid, one obtains the quality of Upāsaka, Upavāsastha, Śrāmaṇera, and Bhikṣu.
By undertaking the renouncing of five items: murder, stealing, illicit sexuality, yng,and intoxicating liquors,one places himself in the discipline of an Upāsaka.

By undertaking the renouncing of eight items: killing, stealing, anchastity, lying, intoxicating liquors, scents, garlands, and unguents; dances, songs, music; high beds, broad beds, and 8. meals at forbidden times, one places himself in the discipline of an.
One places himself in the discipline of a Śrāmaṇera by undertaking the renouncing of these same items and, further, gold and silver, which make ten.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ebhya eva jātarūparajatapratigrahācca / nṛtyagitavāditragandhamālyavilepanaṃ cātra dvayīkṛtya daśa bhavanti /
column2: These make ten items, for one counts “scents, garlands, and unguents” separately from “dances, songs, and music.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvebhya eva varjanīyebhyaḥ kāyavākkarmabhyaḥ viratisamādānāt bhikṣurityucyate /
column2: By undertaking the renouncing of all the actions of the body and the voice which should be avoided, one is a Bhikṣu.
The Pṛātimokṣa discipline is 16a-b.
Morality, good conduct, action and discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śītalatvāditi niruktiḥ / “sukhaśīlasamādānaṃ kāyo na paridahyata” iti gāthāvacanāt /
column2: Etymologically, because it cools, as it says in the stanza, “Happy is the undertaking of morality, because morality does not burn.
Good conduct, because it is praised by the wise.

evaṃ tāvadaviśeṣeṇa prātimokṣasaṃvaraḥ saṃśabdyate / punaḥ /	KL The expression Prātimokṣa discipline" designates all Pṛātimokṣa discipline since its origin.

The expression "Prātimokṣa" designates the first vrñapti and the fitst gvijñapti of the undertaking of the discipline.

The Prātimokṣa is called prā⁴imokṣa, for through it there takes place pratimokṣaṇa, that is, the abandoning of transgression: such is the efficacy of the first moment of the undertaking of discipline.
This viñapti and avijñapti are also "Pṛātimokṣa discipline" because they discipline the body and the voice. They are courses of action, that is "courses of action properly so.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: maulasaṃgṛhītatvāt / dvitīyādiṣu kṣaṇeṣui prātimokṣasaṃvara eva na prātimokṣaḥ /
column2: There is no longer any Prātimokṣa in the moment which follows the first moment and in the moments which follow, for the transgression is not rejected by the second moment, having been rejected by the first, there is prātimokṣasañvara, that is, discipline of the Prātimokṣa type" or discipline "arisen from Prātimokṣa;
there are no longer courses of action properly so-called, but solely consecative action".
Who possesses each of the three disciplines?
Eight persons possess the Prātimokṣa.
Eight persons, the Bhikṣu, Bhikṣunī. The Upavāsatha, possess the Prātimokṣa discipline.
Does this mean that non-Buddhists cannot possess a morality that they have undertaken?
They can possess a morality, but they cannot possess the Prātimokṣa discipline. In fact, the morality that they undertake ("I shall abstain from killing," etc. ), tests on an idea of existence;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi tadatyantaṃ pāpasya pratimokṣaṇāya saṃvartate / bhavasaṃniśritatvāt /
column2: even when they have in view, not a heavenly existence, but that which they call "deliverance", they conceive of deliverance as a certain type of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānajena tadanvitaḥ / dhyānāddhyāne vā jāto dhyānajaḥ /
column2: He who possesses dhyana possesses the discipline which arises from dhyana.
Which arises from dhyana, that is, which arises from dhyana or by means of dhyana.
Dhyana means not only the Four Principal Dhyanas, but also the absorptions which are close to them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā grāmasāmantakamapi grāma ityucyate / astyasmin grāme śāleyaṃ kṣetramasti vraiheyamiti /
column2: In the same way, when one says, "There is a field of rice or a field of wheat in this village," one means the village and its environs.
