column2: The Aryans, the Shaiksas and Ashaiksas, possess pure discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaduktaṃ “sahabhūhetāvucyamāne dvau saṃvarau cittānuvartināvi“ti / katamo tau / eṣāmeva trayāṇām
column2: We have seen, in the definition of sahabhhetu, that two disciplines "accompany the mind.
The last two disciplines are concomitants of the mind.
The discipline that arises from dhyana and the pure discipline are concomitants of the mind;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na prātimokṣasaṃvaraḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam / anyacittācittakasyāpyanuvṛtteḥ / punastāveva dhyānānāsravasaṃvarau prahāṇasaṃvarākhyāṃ labhete / kasyāmavasthāyāmityāha
column2: not of the Pratimoksha discipline, for this latter continues to exist in a person whose mind is bad or neutral, or.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgamye prahāṇākhyau tāvānantaryamārgajau / anāgamye tau dhyānānāsravasaṃvarau navasvānantaryamārgeṣu prahāṇasaṃvarāvityucyete / tābhyāṃ dauḥśīlyasya tatsamutthāpakānāṃ ca kleśānāṃ prahāṇāt /
column2: In the nine ġnantaryamārgas of anāgamya these two disciplines, the discipline of dḥyāna and pure discipline, are “abandoning disciplines”, for through them one abandons immorality and the defilements which produce them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva syāddhyānasaṃvaro na prahāṇasaṃvara iti catuṣkoṭikaṃ kriyate //
column2: There are thus disciplines arisen from dhyāna which are not abandoning-discipline. Four cases: i.
Discipline arising from dhyāna, impure, with the exception of what arises from the ānantaryamārgas of anāgamya: discipline arisen from dhyāna which is not abandoning;
Pure discipline obtained in the ānantaryamārgas of anāgamya: abandoning, but not discipline arisen from dhyāna;
Impure discipline in the ānantaryamārgas of anāgamya: discipline arisen from dhyāna which is abandoning;
Pure discipline arisen outside of the ānantaryamārgas of anāgamya: discipline not arisen from dhyāna which is notabandoning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ syādanāsravasaṃvaro na prahāṇasaṃvara iti catuṣkoṭikaṃ yathāyogaṃ veditavyam /
column2: According to the same principles, one would establish four cases.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi bhagavatoktaṃ “kāyena saṃvaraḥ sādhu sādhu vācā 'tha saṃvaraḥ / manasā saṃvaraḥ sādhu sādhu sarvatra saṃvaraḥ / iti /
column2: The Blessed One said, “Good is discipline of the body, discipline of the voice, discipline of the mind, discipline in all things;
” and again, “He lives disciplined through the discipline of the organ of sight.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etau manaindriyasaṃvarau kiṃsvabhāvau / naitāvavijñaptiśīlasvabhāvau / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: ” What is the nature of these two disciplines, discipline of the mind, and discipline of the organs? Neither are, by their nature of fa.
But on the contrary, Discipline of the mind and discipline of the organs are, each of them, two things: attentive consciousness and mindfulness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratyekaṃ dvisvabhāvajñapanārthaṃ punardvigrahaṇaṃ mā yathāsaṃkhyaṃ vijñāyīti manaḥsaṃvaro 'pi smṛtisaṃprajñānasvabhāva iti / indriyasaṃvaro 'pi /
column2: In order that the reader should not come to believe that the first discipline is consciousness and the second mindfulness, the author says that each of them is two things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idaṃ vicāryate / kaḥ katamayā vijñaptyā 'vijñaptyā vā kiyantaṃ kālaṃ samanvāgata iti / tatra
column2: Let us examine who possesses v#ñapts and avi ñapt and to what period these belong in each case.
He who is in Prātimokṣa always possesses avsjñapti of the present moment, as long as he does not reject the gvijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avijñaptyā 'nvitaḥ yaḥ prātimokṣāsaṃvarasthaḥ pudgala uktaḥ sa yāvattāmavijñaptir na tyajati tāvattayā vartamānayā nityaṃ samanvāgataḥ /
column2: As we have said previously, the person who dwells in the Prātimokṣa discipline, always possesses present avjñapti as long as he does not reject the avijñapti which constitutes this discipline.
After the first moment, he also possesses avijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamāt kṣaṇādūrdhvamatītayā 'pi samanvāgataḥ / atyāgāditi sarvatrādhikṛtaṃ veditavyam /
column2: After the first moment, which is designated by the expression Prṛātimokṣa, he also possesses earlier, past avjñapti: this of course, as long as he does not reject the discipline.
As he who dwells in the Prātimokṣa discipline, 20a.
So too is he who dwells in undiscipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaṃvarastho 'pi yāvadasaṃvaraṃ na tyajati tāvannityamavijñaptyā vartamānayā samanvāgataḥ /
column2: He who dwells in undiscipline, always possesses avijñapti of the present moment as long as he does not reject it;
he also possesses vijñapti of the past, and from the second moment on, of undiscipline.
He who possesses discipline arisen from dhyāna always possesses past and future avsjñapti.

He who possesses the discipline arisen from dhyāna always possesses avsjñapti of the past, and vijñapti of the future as long as he does not lose it, for the vijñapti in question—namely the discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathame hi kṣaṇe sa janmāntaratyaktaṃ dhyānasaṃvaramatītaṃ labhate /
column2: From the first moment when he acquires the discipline of dhyana, he takes possession of the discipline of former dhyanas, either of this existence, or of a previous existence, that he had lost.
The Aryan, at the first moment, does not possess past avijnapth.

The Aryan possesses pure avijnapti, which constitutes his pure discipline, in the manner in which he who possesses the discipline arisen from dhyana possesses the avijnapti arisen from dhyana: he possesses his past and future avijnapti;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa prathame kṣaṇe nātītayā samanvāgato mārgasya pūrvamanutpāditatvāt /
column2: but with the difference that, when in the first moment of the Way he takes possession of pure avijnapti for the first time, he cannot, evidently, possess pure avsjñapti of the past.
The person who is in a state of absorption, the person who is placed in the Way, possesses avijnapti of the present moment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tau dhyānānāsravasaṃvarānvitau samāhitaryamārgasamāpannau vartamānayā avijñaptyā samanvāgatau yathākramaṃ na tu vyutthitau / saṃvarāsaṃvarasthānāṃ tāvadeṣa vṛttāntaḥ /
column2: The person who is absorbed, the person who is cultivating the Way, possesses, at present, the vijnapti which is proper to him, arisen from dhyana, and pure. When he leaves the absorption, he does not possess this present avijñapti, for this avijñapti only accompanies an absorbed mind.

As for the intermediary, who does not possess discipline like the Bhikṣu, nor undiscipline like the transgressor, the intermediary, at the first moment, possesses, medially, gvójñapti, when the avijñapti is produced.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo naiva saṃvare nāsaṃvare sthitaḥ sa madhyasthaḥ /
column2: Medially means the present, situated between the past and the future.
Action does not necessarily produce avġjñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya tvasti dauḥśīlyaśīlāṅgādisaṃgṛhītā sa ādau madhyayā samanvāgataḥ /
column2: The intermediary does not necessarily possess avijñapti: if there is avijñapti—either avijñapti created by an act of immorality, or aviñapti created by an act of morality, or avijñapūi is created by some other good or bad acts, the worship of a Śtūpa, hitting and wounding—he possesses this aviñapti of the present, at the moment when it arises.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vartamānā hyavijñaptiratītānāgatayormadhyād ūrdhvaṃ dvikālayā // prathamāt kṣaṇādūrdhvamatītayā vartamānayā ca / ātyāgāditi vartate /

column2: At the moment of the action in question, the agent possesses avij ñapri of the present;
then he possesses aviiñapti of the present and of the past.

column2: Those who have created one viñapti possess it always, in the present.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarve saṃvarāsaṃvaramadhyasthā yāvadijñaptiṃ kurvanti tāvattayā vartamānayā samanvāgatāḥ / atītayā kṣaṇādūrdhvamātyāgāt
column2: All those who accomplish a bodily or vocal action whether they are disciplined, undisciplined, or intermediaries, so long as they are accomplishing this action, possess it in the present.
From the second moment onward, they possess vijñapti. One cannot possess future vijñapti.

column2: No one possesses future vijñapti, because such vijñapti does not now accompany the mind.
One does not possess past vjñapti of the nivṛta and anivṛ̥śa classes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: durbalasya hi dharmasya prāptirapi durbalā nānubandhībhavati /
column2: One does not possess these actions, once they are past, because the possession of a weak dharma, being weak itself, is not prolonged.
Why is this dharma, a neutral action, weak?
By reason of the weakness of the mind which gives rise to it.
But then the possession of this mind too will not be prolonged.
No: the case is not the same.
The vijñapti, in effect, is stupid, for it does not know an object; furthermore it is dependent, for it depends upon the mind.
Such is not the case with the mind itself.
Thus the vijñapti produced by a neutral mind is weaker than this mind itself;
the possession of the vjñapti is not prolongued, whereas theWe have spoken of an undisciplined person, one who is in undiscipline.
What is undiscipline?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaṃvaro duścaritaṃ dauḥśīlyaṃ karmaṃ tatpathaḥ // asaṃvarasyeme paryāyaśabdāḥ /
column2: Undiscipline, bad conduct, immorality, action, course of action.
It is undiscipline, because there is no constraining of the body and voice.
It is bad conduct, because it is blamed by wise men, and because it produces painful results.
It is immorality, because it opposes morality.
It is an action, as it is created by the body and the voice.
It is a course of action, as it is included in the principal action.
He who possesses viñapti can also possess avjñapti. Four cases present themselves.
The intermediary, acting with a weak volition, possesses a single vjñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mṛdvyā cetanayā kuśalamakukśalaṃ vā kurvannaivasaṃvaranāsaṃvarasthito vijñaptyaiva samanvāgato bhavati nāvijñaptyā prāgevāvyākṛte anyatraupadhikapuṇyakriyāvastukarmapathebhyaḥ
column2: He who is in neither-discipline-nor-nondiscipline and who, with a weak volition, does good or bad action, possesses solely this act, and does not possess any avġñapti. All the more reason that there is no possession of aviñapti by an agent when his action is prolonged. Nevertheless, even accomplished with a weak volition, material meritorious works and a course of action always create cvijñapti.
The Āryan possesses a single vijñapiá when he has not produced, or has abandoned, the vijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avijñaptyaiva samanvāgato na vijñaptyā yenāryapudgalena janmāntaraparivṛttau na tāvadvijñaptaṃ vā punarvihīnam /
column2: When an Āryan has changed his existence or when he has not created vijñapi, or when he has lost the ufñapti, he póssesses only avijñapti, and not vsṝñapt.
The two other cases, the possession of vġjñapti and avijñapti, and the non-possession of either, are set up according to the same principles.
How does one acquire the disciplines?

The discipline that arises from dhyāna is acquired by one thought of the sphere of the dhyāna. It is through one thought of the sphere of the dyāna, that īs,of the mauladhyāna and the sāmamtakas, and with an impure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā dhyānabhūmikaṃ cittaṃ pratilabhyate maulīyaṃ sāmantakīyaṃ vā sāsravaṃ tadā dhyānasaṃvaro 'pi sahabhūtatvāt /
column2: Mind, that is, with a mind not forming part of the Way, that the discipline of dhyana is acquired; this is a discipline concomitant with this type of mind. Pure discipline, by the same mind, when it is Aryan.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravastayā / āryayā tayaiva dhyānabhūmyā 'nāsravayā labhyamānayā 'nāsravaḥ saṃvaro labhyate /
column2: Aryan means pure, forming part of the Way.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra ṣaṭ dhyānabhūmayo 'nāsravā bhavanti catvāri dhyānāni anāgamyasyānantaraṃ ceti paścātpravedayiṣyāmaḥ /
column2: We will explain below that the Aryan mind exists in six spheres of dhyana, namely the Four Dhyanas, the dhyanantaras and the anagamya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prātimokṣākhyaḥ paravijñapanādibhiḥ // prātimokṣasaṃvarastu paravijñaptito labhyate / yadyenaṃ paro vijñapayati asau ca param / sa punaḥ saṃghādvā pudgalādvā /
column2: That which is called Pratimoksa, through paravijnapan, etc. "Paravijnapan" is informative action to or from another: the candidate makes known something to another, and another makes something known to him. "Another" is the Sangha, through the acquisition of the disciplines of Bhiksu, Bhiksuni, or Siksamana;
or a person, the acquisition of the five other praimoksa disciplines.
According to Vinaya scholars of the Vaibhasika School, there are six types of ordination.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya ūpasaṃgrahaṇārthamādiśabdaḥ / svayaṃbhūtvena buddhānāṃ pratyekabuddhānāṃ ca niyāmāvakrāntyā pañcakānām ehibhikṣukayā yaśaḥprabhṛtīnām śāsturabhyupagamānmahākāśyapasya praśnārādhanena sodāyinaḥ gurudharmābhyupagamena mahāprajāpatyāḥ dūtena dharmadinnāyāḥ vinayaddharapañcamena pratyantimeṣu janapadeṣu daśavargeṇa madhyeṣu janapadeṣu śaraṇagamanaṃ traivācikena ṣaṣṭibhadravargapūgopasaṃpāditānāmiti
column2: In order to include them all within his definition, the author says, ". from the information of another etcetera.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ nāvaśyaṃ vijñaptyadhīnaḥ prātimokṣasaṃvaraḥ / sa punareṣa prātimokṣāsaṃvaraḥ samādīyamānaḥ kiyantaṃ kālaṃ samādātavyaḥ /
column2:
One sees that, according to these scholars, the Pratimoksha discipline is not necessarily acquired by means of a vjñapti, for example the ordination of the Buddha, etc. When one undertakes the Prātimokṣa discipline, for how long a time does one undertake it?
yāvajjīvaṃ samādānamahorātraṃ ca saṃvṛteḥ /	One undertakes the discipline for a lifetime or for a day and a night.
saptanaikāyikasya prātimokṣasaṃvarasya yāvajjīvaṃ samādānam upavāsasaṃvarasyāhorātramityeṣa niyamaḥ /	The first seven categories of the Prātimokṣa discipline are undertaken for a lifetime; the fasting discipline is undertaken for a day and a night. Such is the rule.
kiṃ kāraṇam /	Why?
dvau hi kālaparyantau / ahorātraparyanto jīvitaparyantaśca /	Because there are two limits of time, the period of a lifetime, and the period of a day and a night.
ahārotrāṇāṃ paunaruktyena pakṣādayaḥ /	As for the fortnight and the other durations of time, they consist in additions of day and night periods.
kālo nāma ka eṣa dharmaḥ / saṃskāraparidīpanādhivacanametat /	What is the dharma that we term time"? This is not an eternal substance, as some believe.
The word "time" is an expression by which the raṅṁskāras are designated as past, present, or future. When it is light in the four continents, it is daytime;
when it is dark it is night.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yuktaṃ tāvajjīvitādūrdhvaṃ satyapi samādāne saṃvarasyānutpattiḥ / visabhāgatvādāśrayasya tena ca tatrāprayogādasmaraṇācca /
column2: Discussion: We admit, say the Sautrāntikas, that the Prātimokṣa discipline is solely produced for the duration of a lifetime.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athāhorātrādūrdhvaṃ pañcarātraṃ daśarātraṃ vā upavāsasamādānasya kaḥ pratibandho bahūnāmupavāsasaṃvarāṇāmutpattau /
column2: In fact, even if one were to undertake to observe these rules in a future life, one wouldBut if a person assumes the duties of a faster for more than a day and a night, for five days, or for ten days, what obstacle would this be to his producing in himself many disciplines of the fast?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itthamasti pratibandho yadbhagavānahorātrikamevopavāsaṃ sūtre śāstisma / idamidānīṃ saṃpradhāryam /
column2: It needs be that there would be an obstacle since the Blessed One, in a Sīūtra, says that one undertakes the fast for a day and a night.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tāvadahorātrādūrdhvaṃ saṃvarasyānutpartti paśyatā tathāgatenāhorātrika upavāso deśita utāho durbalendriyāṇāmahorātrake 'pi saṃvarasamādānena saṃniyojanārthamiti / kutastvetadevaṃ tarkyate /
column2: Why did the Blessed One express himself in this manner: did he think that the discipline of fasting could not be produced for a longer duration? He thought that persons in whom the senses are difficult to subdue would be well capable of undertaking the fast for a day and a night.
But, in truth, nothing is wrong with producing the discipline of the fast for more than one day.
As the Blessed One does not speak of the fast as lasting any longer.
What is the duration of undiscipline?
There is undiscipline for a day and a night.
Undiscipline never lasts longer than a day and a night, like the discipline of the fast, for it is produced by the acceptance of transgression for one's entire life.
How is this?
For, says the School, one does not undertake it thus.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na kila kaścidevamasaṃvaraṃ samādatte yathopavāsaṃ kaccidahamahorātramasaṃvṛtaḥ syāmiti /
column2: No one undertakes undiscipline in the manner in which one undertakes the fast, by saying, "I wish to remain a day and a night in undiscipline.
Rather, he carries out, in effect, shameful actions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ caiva na kaścidādatte kaccidahaṃ yāvajīvamasaṃvṛtaḥ syāmiti /
column2: Objection: No one undertakes undiscipline by saying, "I wish to remain for my life undisciplined.
Thus one does not undertake undiscipline for an entire lifetime.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyapi naivamādatte tathāpyatyantavipannenāśayena tāṃ kriyāṃ prakurvannasaṃvaraṃ pratilabhate na kālāntaravipannena /
column2: Answer: It is not in this manner, in fact, that one undertakes undiscipline. One does not undertake undiscipline by means of a ritual. One acquires undiscipline by acting with the intention of always acting badly; one does not acquire undiscipline by the intention of acting badly. In the case of the fast, the intention is not "for always;

nevertheless one obtains the discipline through the force of the action which consists of saying, I wish to remain a day and a night in the discipline of the fast," and one accomplishes this action because one desires to acquire this discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi punaḥ kaścidasaṃvareṇāpyarthī kālāntaramasaṃvaraṃ samādadīta so 'vaśyaṃ labheta /
column2: If someone desires undiscipline, he could without doubt give himself over to undiscipline for this period of time.
But the case does not present itself; hence we do not recognize undiscipline "for a time.
According to the Sautrantikas, undiscipline does not exist in and of itself apart from volition.
Undiscipline is the intention to commit evil, that is, a certain volition with the traces which allow this volition.
And, as long as this volition with its traces has not been destroyed by a contrary volition, the person, even when he has a good thought, remains filled with undiscipline, a person undisciplined.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athāhorātraṃ gṛhyamāṇa upavāsaḥ kathaṃ grahītavyaḥ / kālyaṃ grāhyo 'nyato nīcaiḥ sthitenoktānuvāditā /
column2: How should one undertake the discipline of a day and a night, or theOne should undertake the fast in a humble attitude, speaking after, with ornaments removed, until the morrow, complete, the morning, from another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upavāsaḥ samagrāṅgo nirbhuṣeṇāniśākṣayāt // kālyaṃ tāvatsūryodayakāle ahorātrikatvātsaṃvarasya / yastu pūrvakṛtasamādāno nityamaṣṭabhyāmupaceṣyāmīti sa bhuktvāpi gṛhṇīyāt / anyataśca grahītavyo na svayamevāparāpekṣayā satsvapi pratyayeṣvanatikramārtham /
column2: In a humble attitude, squatting or kneeling;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nīcaiḥ sthitenotkuṭṭakena vā jānupātena vā kapotakamañjaliṃ kṛtvā 'nyatra sthāsyāt /
column2: with the hands joined in kapotaka or in the position of eñal; except in the case of sickness.
Without a respectful attitude, discipline is not produced.
The candidate does not speak before the ordainer or the giver, the person who “gives” the fast;
nor at the same time.
In this way, it is from another that one undertakes the fast;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hi dānagrahaṇaṃ na sidhyet / samagrāṅgaścāṣṭāṅga eva grahītavyo na vikalāṅgaḥ /
column2: otherwise, there would be neither receiving nor a thing received.
The candidate does not wear any ornaments;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ājasrikamabhyalaṅkāraṃ muktvā / ājasriko hyalaṅkāro nātyarthaṃ madamādadhāti /
column2: he wears his normal dress, because he does not draw forth vanity from it.

One undertakes it until the morrow, until the rising of the sun. One undertakes the complete fast, with its eight rules, and not with any rules missing. He who previously has formed the undertaking, "I will always practice the fast, the eighth day of the fortnight, etc. ," undertakes the fast, even though he eats. From another, nor from oneself. If one encounters a cause of transgression, through honesty with regard to the giver, he will not violate the obligations undertaken.
When these rules are not observed, one has nevertheless done a good action, but one does not obtain the discipline of the fast.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca kṛtvā aurabhrikapāradārikayo rātridivasopavāsakayoḥ sāphalyaṃ prayujyate /
column2: When the rules are observed, the fast is even more useful for the person who commits transgressions by day and by night (hunting, murder, stealing, adultery).
The fast is termed pavasa because, embracing a way of life conforming to that of the Arhats, he places himself near the Arhats.
According to another opinion, it is because he places himself near the "lifelong discipline".
It has for its end procuring an increase of the roots of good. Persons who have only small roots of good.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “poṣaṃ dadhāti manasaḥ kuśalasya yasmāduktastato bhagavatā kila poṣadho 'yami“ti /
column2: As it procures an increase of good, the Blessed One said, “It is called poṣadha.”
Why is the discipline of the fast undertaken with eight parts?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śīlāṅgānyapramādāṅgaṃ vratāṅgāni yathākramam / catvāryekaṃ tathā trīṇi
column2: Part of morality, part of vigilance, parts of ascetic vows, have respectively four, one, three parts.
Four parts:—the renouncing of killing, stealing, adultery and lying-—constitute the parts of morality by which what is transgression by nature is abandoned.

One part, the renouncing of intoxicating drinks, constitutes the rule of vigilance by which non-vigilance is arrested, For even if a person who has undertaken morality drinks intoxicating liquor, he will be no vigilant.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāttaśīlo 'pi madyapaḥ pramādyeta / trīṇi vṛtāṅgāni yāvadakālabhojanādviratiḥ / saṃvegānuguṇatvāt /
column2: Three parts,:—the renouncing of high beds, music, etc. , and meals at forbidden times,—constitute the rule of asceticism, for they are favorable and conform to disgust.
What necessity is there for undertaking the rules of vigilance and of asceticism?
In order to avoid weakness of mindfulness and arrogance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: madyaṃ hi pivataḥ kāryā kāryasmṛtireva naśyet /
column2: When one drinks intoxicating liquor, one loses one's mindfulness of what one should and should not do.
When one uses high and wide beds, when one attends dances, singing and music, the mind becomes arrogant.
In both cases, one is not far from violating morality.
When one observes the rule of eating at the proper times, and when one avoids eating outside of this time, one retains a mindfulness of the obligations of the fast, and disgust is produced.
In the absence of the eighth rule, mindfulness and disgust would be absent.

According to certain masters, the fast or pavāsa consists of the fast proper, and the renouncing of food at forbidden times; whereas the other renouncings are the rules or parts of the fast. The abstention from food is not a part;
thus, with an end to the obtaining the number of eight parts, one should distinguish two parts in the seventh rule;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nṛtyagotavāditraṃ gandhamālyavilepanaṃ ca dvayaṃ kṛtvā / evaṃ tu sati sūtrapāṭho na yujyeta / akālabhojanādvirati muktvā “anenāhamaṣṭamāṅgena teṣāmāryāṇāmarhatāṃ śikṣāyāmanuśikṣe anuvidhīya” iti /
column2: first, the renouncing of dancing, singing, and music; and the second, the renouncing of perfumes, garlands, and unguents.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kastarhi so 'nya upavāso yasyemānyaṅgāni / samudāyasyāvayavā aṅgāni / yathā sthasyāṅgāni caturaṅgo balakāyaḥ pañcāṅgaṃ tūryaṃ tathā 'ṣṭāṅga upavāso draṣṭavyaḥ /
column2: Then what would the fast be, distinct from its rules, and yet embracing eight parts? According to the Vaibhāṣikas, the abstaining from food at forbidden times is at one and the same time the fast and a part of the fast.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akālabhojanāt prativiratirūpavāsa upavāsāṅgaṃ ca yathā samyagdṛṣṭirmārgo mārgāṅgaṃ ca / dharmapravicayasaṃbodhyaṅgaṃ bodhirvodhyaṅgaṃ samādhirdhyānaṃ dhyānāṅgaṃ ceti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: In the same way that Right Views are at one and the same time the Pathand a part of the Path ; in the same way that Investigation into the Dharmas is at one and.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: natu teṣāmeva samyagdṛṣṭyādīnāṃ ta evāṅgatvāya kalpanta iti /
column2: But we would say that it is impossible for Right Views, Investigation into the Dharmas, and Samādhi to be parts of themselves.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvakāḥ samyagdṛṣṭyādaya uttareṣāmaṅgaṃ yadi syuḥ prathamakṣaṇotpanna āryamārgo nāṣṭāṅgaḥ syāt /
column2: Would you say that earlier Right Views, etc. , are parts of later Right Views, etc. ? This would be to admit that the first moment of the Path does not have eight parts. This would be to admit that the last moment of the parts of Bodhi is itself not a part.
Is the possession of the discipline of the fast kept only by Upāsakas?
Others can possess the fast, but not without taking the Refuges.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anupavāsako 'pi yastamahorātraṃ buddhadharmasaṃghān śaraṇaṃ gatvopavāsaṃ gṛhṇāti tasyotpadyate upavāsasaṃvaro nānyathā /
column2: When a person who is not a Upāsaka, takes, in the same day and night, the Three Refuges before he undertakes the rules of the fast, then the discipline of the fast is produced within him.
But not without taking the Refuges;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra uktaṃ “yataśca mahānāman gṛhī avadātavasanaḥ puruṣaḥ puruṣendriyeṇa samanvāgato buddhaṃ śaraṇaṃ gacchati dharmaṃ saṃghaṃ śaraṇaṃ gacchati vācaṃ ca bhāṣate upavāsakaṃ ca māṃ dharaya / iyatā upāvāsako bhavatī“ti /
column2: on the condition that there has been no error, etc. The Mahānāma-sūtrasays,“Oh Mahāṇāma, the layman with whiteClothes, male and possessing the male organ, who, after having taken refuge in the Buddha, in the Dharma, and in the Saṅgha, pronounces these words, ‘Consider me as an Upāsaka:’ only through this does he become an Upāsaka.
Does this mean that one becomes an Upāsaka by only taking the Three Refuges?
The Aparāntakas answer yes.
The Kaśmīreans affirm that one cannot be an Upāsaka when one does not possess the Upāsaka discipline.
But does this not contradict the Sūtra?
Because 30c-d.
The discipline is produced through the fact that he accepts the qualities of an Upāsaka.
The discipline of the Upāsaka is produced in him by the mere acceptance of the quality of the Upāsaka, when he says, “Consider me, from today onwards, for the rest of my life, as a prāṇāpeta Upāsaka.
” One should understand, prāṇātépātāpeta through ellipis, as free from killing, having renounced killing. ‘Thus, by accepting the quality of an Upāsaka, one undertakes the discipline.
Yet, in order that he understands the points of the rule.
One explains them to him, as is also the case for a Bhikṣu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathaivaṃ bhikṣurlabdhasaṃvaro 'pi punaḥ śikṣāpadāni grāhyate śrāmaṇeraśca vyutpādanārthamita ścāmutaśca te saṃvara iti tathopavāsako 'pi na tu vinā saṃvareṇopāsako 'sti /
column2: Through an ecclesiastical action the Bhikṣu has acquired the discipline of the Bhikṣu: yet he is made to undertake the most important rules: “You are to abstain from this, from that. Your co-religionists will tell you the rest.” The same holds for the Śrāmaṇpera. The same holds for the Upāsaka: he obtains the discipline by undertaking once, twice, three time the Three Refuges; he is then made to undertake the rules, “Abandoning killing, I renounce killing.”
Thus one is not an Upāsaka without possessing the discipline of the Upāsaka. If allUpāsakas possess the discipline of the Upāsaka, how can an Upāsaka be an ekadefakāriṇ, etc. ?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi sarva evopāsakā upāsakasaṃvarasthāḥ kathaṃ bhagavatā ekadeśakārī pradeśakārī yadbhūyaḥkārī pūripūrṇakārī copāsaka uktaḥ /
column2: If all Upāsakas place themselves within the discipline of the Upāsaka, why did the Blessed One describe four types of Upāsakas, the Upāsaka of one rule, of two rules, of three or four rules, and of five rules?
These terms, say the School, refer to the fact of observing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo hi yacchikṣāpadaṃ pālayati sa tatkārītyuktaḥ /
column2: The Upāsaka who in fact observes one of the rules is said to practice this rule.
Yet all the Upāsakas are equally placed within this discipline.
The Sautrāntikas object: Your doctrine contradicts the Sūtra.
In what way does it contradict the Sūtra?
You say that one acquires the discipline by the mere fact of accepting the quality of a prāṇāpeta Upāsaka, “Consider me as a prānāpeta Upāsaka.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hyevaṃ sūtrapāṭhaḥ ukto yathā mahānāmasūtre pāṭhaḥ / tatraiva copāsakalakṣaṇopadeśo nānyatra /
column2: ” But, such is not the text of the Sūtra. In fact, the Sūtra that interests us is the Mahānāma-sūtra which gives the definition of an Upāsaka, and not another Sūtra. And the Mahānāma-sūtra does not have the expression “prāāṇāpeta.
” You hold that you are authorized by another Sūtra, which has, “From today, for the rest of my life, risking my life, having taken refuge, believing perfectly.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra te dṛṣṭasatyā “avetyaprasādānvayaṃ prāṇairapi saddharmopagamanaṃ darśayanti sma /
column2: ” Now this text refers to persons who have seen the.

Truths, who have acquired the faith of intelligence, and who, as a consequence, adhere to the Good Law even at the price of their lives: “We are incapable of abandoning the Dharma, even in order to save our lives.”
This text does not give a definition of the Upāsaka discipline.
Further, the expression prāṇáāpeta, npoṉ which you establish your theory, is nowhere to be found, either in the Mahānāma-sūra, nor the Dṛṣṭasatya-sutra.

Who could admit a similar expression the sense of which is lacking in precision? Who, based on faith in this expression, would admit that the Upāsaka has undertaken the five renouncings before he has undertaken them ritually?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekadeśakāryādīṃstu khaṇḍitaśikṣānadhikṛtya praśna eva na yujyate / kuto visarjanamāveṇikadharmāṇām /
column2: If the expression ekadeśakārṣnṉ designates a person who violates the discipline, the question raised in the Sūtra is not justified, nor its answer.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ko hyapāsakasaṃvaraṃ jānan etanna jñāsyate yo hi yacchikṣāpadaṃ na khaṇḍayati sa tatkārī bhavatīti /
column2: In fact, who is it that, being acquainted with the discipline of an Upāsaka and knowing that it is made up of five rules, would be incapable of explaining, “He who does not violate a rule”?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upāsakasaṃvarasya tu parimāṇānabhijñāṃstanmātraśikṣākṣamān pratyeṣa praśno yujyate / “kiyatā bhadantopāsaka ekadeśakārī bhavati yāvat paripūrṇakārī bhavati /“
column2: On the contrary, someone who does not know the extent of the discipline of an Upāsaka, seeing the persons capable of observing one, or two, or three, or all the rules, would he be able to pose the question, “What does one do to become an Upāsaka of all the rules?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tarhi vinā saṃvareṇopāsakaḥ syādvikalena vā bhikṣuśrāmaṇerāvapi syātām /
column2: ” The Vaibhāṣikas answer: If one were an Upāsaka without possessing the discipline of an Upāsaka, one could also as well be a Bhikṣuor a Śrāmaṇera with an incomplete discipline.
Answer: How can we know the extent, the number of the rules of the disciplines of the Upāsaka,theŚrāmaṇera,or theBhikṣu?
Evidently through the teaching of the Master.
Now the Master speaks of the Upāsaka not possessing the discipline in its entirety;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vināpi hi saṃvareṇopāsakaḥ prajñaptito na tu bhikṣuśrāmaṇerāviti te tvetannecchanti kāśmīrāḥ /
column2: but he does not speak of an incomplete discipline of the Bhikṣus or of the Śrāmaṇeras. The Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmīr do not admit this opinion.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarveṣāṃ tu saṃvarāṇām / mṛdvāditvaṃ yathā manaḥ //
column2: All the disciplines are weak, etc. , according to the mind.
The weakness, the mediocrity, and the force of the eight rules depend on the weakness, on the mediocrity, or on the force of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca kṛtvā 'rhato 'pi mṛduḥ prātimokṣasaṃvaraḥ syāt pṛthagjanasyādhimātraḥ /
column2: But if such is the case, the Pratimoksha discipline of an Arhat could be weak, and that of a Prthagjana could be strong.
Is one an Upasaka if one solely undertakes the discipline without undertaking the Refuges?
except in the case of ignorance by the person who gives and by the person who receives.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo buddhadharmasaṃghāñcharaṇaṃ gacchati kimasau śaraṇaṃ gacchati /
column2: When a person takes refuge in the Buddha, the Dharma, and in the Sangha, what does he take refuge in?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: buddhasaṃghakarāndharmānaśaikṣānubhayāṃśca saḥ / nirvāṇaṃ ceti śaraṇaṃ yo yāti śāraṇatrayam //
column2: He who takes the Refuges takes refuge in the dharmas which form the Buddha, in the two types of dharmas which form the Sangha, and in Nirvana.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo buddhaṃ śaraṇaṃ gacchati aśaikṣānasau budhakarakāndharmāñcharaṇaṃ gacchati yeṣāṃ prādhānyena sa ātmabhāvo budhā ityucyate yeṣāṃ vā lābhena sarvāvabodhasāmarthyādbuddho bhavati / ke punaste / kṣayajñānādayaḥ saparivārāḥ / rūpakāyasya pūrvaṃ paścāccāviśeṣāt / kiṃ sarvabuddhānathaikam /
column2: He who takes Refuge in the Buddha takes refuge in the dharmas of the Arhat which form a Buddha, the dharneas which are the causes of the designation "Buddha," that is, the dharmas by reason of which, as principle cause, a certain person is called a Buddha; or rather the dharmas by the acquisition of which a certain person, understanding all things, is called a Buddha. These dharmas are the Knowledge ofAs for the material body of the Buddha, that is not subject to modification through the acquisition of the quality of Buddha. Thus one does not take refuge in the material body of the Buddha which is, in fact, the material body of the Bodhisattva.
According to the nature of things, and in the absence of an explicit declaration, in all the Buddhas.
For the Buddhas have always followed the same path, a worldly path and a transworldly path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ saṃghaṃ śaraṇaṃ gacchati śaikṣāśaikṣānasausaṃghakarakānharmān gacchati yeṣāṃ lābhenāṣṭau pudgalāḥ saṃghībhavanti / abhedatvāt /
column2: He who takes Refuge in the Saṅgha takes refuge in both the Śaikṣa and the aśaikṣa ḍharmas, of the non-Aṟhat and of the Arhat, which form the Saṅgha, that is, the dharmas through the acquisition of which the Eight Saints become a Saṅgha; becoming unanimous they cannot be divided with regard to that which concerns the Path.
Does one take refuge in all the Saṅghas or in one Saṅgha?
According to the nature of things, in all: for the Path followed by the Saints is always the same.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattu sūtra uktaṃ “yo 'pyasau bhaviṣyatyanāgate 'dhvani saṃgho nāma tamapi śaraṇaṃ gacchatami “ti / tatpratyakṣabhāvinaḥ saṃvaratvasyodbhāvanārtham /
column2: Without doubt, the Buddha said to the two merchants, "Also take refuge in the Saṅgha which shall exist in the future," but the Master expressed himself in this manner in order to exalt the qualities of the Jewel of the Saṅgha which would soon be visible to the merchants.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo dharmaṃ śaraṇaṃ gacchati asau nirvāṇaṃ śaraṇaṃ gacchati pratisaṃkhyānirodham /
column2: He who takes Refuge in the Dharma takes refuge in Nirvāṇa, that is to say, in pratisaṁkhyānirodha.

He takes refuge in all Nirvāṇa, for Nirvāṇa has for its unique characteristic the cessation of the defilements and suffering of oneself and others (see vi. 73c, the meaning of the word dharma in dharma avetyaprasāda). Discussion.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyaśaikṣā dharmā eva buddhaḥ kathaṃ tathāgatasyāntike dukṣṭacittarudhirotpādanādānantaryaṃ bhavati /
column2: If the Buddha is none other than the afxikṣa dharmas, the dharmas pertaining to an Arhat, how could the fact of wounding the Buddha with a bad thought constitute a mortal transgression?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āśrayavipādanātte 'pi vipāditā bhavantīti vaibhāṣikāḥ / śāstraṃ tu naivaṃ vācakamaśaikṣā dharmā eva buddha iti / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas answer: "When one wounds the material elements which are the support of these dbarmas,"But the Śāstra does not say that the Buddha is solely the dharmas.

It says that the Buddha is the dharmas that form a Buddha, that is to say, either the worldly or transworldly dharmas which are the object of the designation “Buddha,” are the Buddha. Thus the Śāstra does not deny that the āôraya—the organism, the support made up of the five worldly sēxndhas—forms part of the quality of Buddha.
Hence the objection taken from wounding the Buddha is without value.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hi laukikacittastho na buddhaḥ syānna saṃghaḥ śīlameva ca bhikṣukarakaṃ bhikṣuḥ syāt /
column2: If it were otherwise, if the Buddha was only asu kṣadharmas, and if the Sañgha were only fxikṣa and aśaikṣadharmas, a person whose mind is presently “worldly” would not be able to be either a Buddha or a Saṅgha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tu yo bhikṣūn pūjayati bhikṣukarakamasau śīlaṃ pūjayati /
column2: And by virtue of these same principles, one would have to say that a Bhikṣu is only morality, the discipline of a Bhikṣu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yo buddhaṃ śaraṇaṃ gacchatyaśaikṣānasau buddhakarakāndharmān śaraṇaṃ gacchati /
column2: But, say the Vaibhāṣikas, if the body is, ītself, among the dharmas which form the Buddha, why does the Śāstra say,“He who takes refuge in the Buddha, takes refuge in the afaikṣa dharmas which form the”?
According to another opinion, one who takes refuge in the Buddha takes refuge in the eighteen āveṇikadharmas of the Buddha.
What is the nature of the undertakings of the Refuges?
They are vocal vġñaptś.
What is the meaning of “Refuge”?
The Three Refuges are so named because, by going to them for refuge one obtains definitive deliverance from all suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ hi bhagavatā “bahavaḥ śaraṇaṃ yānti parvatāṃśca vanāni ca ārāmānvṛkṣāṃścaityāṃśca manuṣyā bhayavarjitāḥ //
column2: The Blessed One said in fact, “Tormented by fear, persons most frequently take refuge in mountains, in forests, in woods, and in sacred trees.
This is not a good refuge, the supreme refuge;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naitaccharaṇamāgamya sarvaduḥkhātpramucyate // yastu buddhaṃ ca dharmaṃ ca saṃghaṃ ca śaraṇaṃ gataḥ /
column2: it is not by taking refuge in these that one is delivered from all suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catvāri cāryasatyāni paśyati prajñayā yadā // duḥkhaṃ duḥkhasamutpādaṃ duḥkhasya samatikramam / āryaṃ cāṣṭāṅgikaṃ mārgaṃ kṣemaṃ nirvāṇagāminam // etaddhi śaraṇaṃ śreṣṭhametaccharaṇamuttamam / etaccharaṇamāgamya sarvaduḥkhāt pramucyate //“iti /
column2: But one who takes Refuge in the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha, when one sees through wisdom the Four Noble Truths,—Suffering, the Arising of Suffering, the Extinction of Suffering, and the Holy Eightfold Path which leads to Nirvāṇa,—this is the good refuge, this is the.
The undertaking of the Refuges is the entrance to the undertaking of all the rules of discipline. The other rules of discipline contain the renouncing of all sexual activity;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇamanyeṣu saṃvareṣvabrahmacaryādviratiḥ śikṣāpadaṃ vyavasthāpitam upāsakasya tu kāmamithyācārāt /
column2: but the discipline of the Upāsaka only contains the renouncing of sexual misconduct.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mithyācārātigarhyatvātsaukaryādakriyāptitaḥ / kāmamithyācāro hi loke 'tyantaṃ garhitaḥ / pareṣāṃ dāropaghātādāpāyikatvācca / na tathā 'brahmacaryam /
column2: Sexual misconduct is much censured in the world because it is the corruption of another’s wife, and because it leads to retribution in a painful realm of rebirth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukarā ca kāmamithyācārādviratirgṛhānadhyāvasatāṃ duṣkarātvabrahmacaryāditi duṣkaraṃ karttuṃ notsaheran /
column2: It is easy for householders to abstain from it, but it is difficult for them to abstain from all sexual activity: householders do not leave the world because they are not capable of difficult things.

The Āryans possess akaraṇasaṁvara with regard to sexual misconduct, that is, they have obtained definite abstention from it. In their future existence, they will be incapable of violating this precept. Such is not the case concerning all sexual activity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: janmāntareṣvapyanadhyācaraṇānnatvabrahmacryādityupāsakasyāpi tasmādeva viratiḥ śikṣāpadaṃ vyavasthāpitaṃ mā bhūt parivṛttajanmāntaraḥ śaikṣa upāsakasaṃvarāṅgeṣvasaṃvṛta iti /
column2: As a consequence, the rules of discipline of the Upāsaka contain only the renunciation of sexual misconduct: it is inadmissible in fact that the Āryaṇns, in a subsequent existence, would be capable of violating the discipline of an Upāsaka which could happen if this contained the renunciation of all sexual activity.
Akaraṇasaṁvara means akriyāniyama, (that is akriyāyam ekāntatā, the certain abstention from one action).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya upāsakāḥ santo bhāryāḥ pariṇayanti kiṃ taistābhyo 'pi saṃvaraḥ pratilabdho 'tha na / pratilabdho mā bhūt prādeśikasaṃvaralābha iti /
column2: Has the man who marries after having undertaken the Upāsaka discipline, undertaken renouncing with regard to the woman whom he marries?
Yes, answer the Vaibhāṣikas;
for, in the contrary hypothesis, this man would have undertaken a restraining discipline. But then this man violates the discipline when he gets married!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathābhyupagamaṃ lābhaḥ saṃvarasya na saṃtateḥ // yathā hyeṣāmabhyupagamastathā saṃvaralābhaḥ /
column2: They have acquired it as they have accepted the discipline; they have not accepted it with regard to some persons.
They have acquired it as they have undertaken the discipline.
They undertake it by saying, “I renounce sexual misconduct,” that is, “I renounce all sexual activity with all prohibited females;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tvatra saṃtāne mayā brahmacaryaṃ na kartavyamityata evaiṣāṃ tadadhiṣṭhātkāmamithyācārāṅgādeva saṃvaralābho nābrahmacaryāditi nāsti bhāryībhūtāyāṃ saṃvarakṣobhaḥ /
column2: ” they do not undertake it by saying, “I shall refrain from all sexual activity with such persons.” Consequently, they do not violate the discipline by getting married.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kasmāt mṛṣāvādād viratirevopāsakasaṃvaraśikṣāpadaṃ na paiśunyādiviratiḥ / ebhireva ca tribhiḥ kāraṇaiḥ /
column2: Among the transgression of speech, why does the renouncing of lying constitute one of the rules of the Upāsaka, whereas the renouncing of other transgressions of speech are omitted?
For the same reasons: because lying is much censured in the world, because householders abstain from it easily, and because the Āryans are not capable of lying;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mṛṣāvādaprasaṅgācca sarvaśikṣāvyatikrame / sarvatra hi śikṣātikrame samanuyujyamānasyopasthitamidaṃ bhavati nāhamevamahārṣamiti
column2: and also for a fourth reason: Because, having violated any other rule he would lie.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mṛṣāvādasya prasaṅgo bhavatyato mṛṣāvādādviratirvidhīyate kathaṃ kṛtātikramo 'pyātmani māviṣkuryāditi / kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ pratikṣepaṇasāvadyācchikṣāpadasya na vyavasthāpitam /
column2: He would lie when he violates any other rule, saying, “I have not done it.”
Consequently the Upāsaka should renounce lying, thinking, `I shall confess what I transgress.

Why are not the transgressions of disobedience included in theOne renounces strong liquor, which is a transgression of disobedience, Why should the Upāsaka renounce a single transgression of disobedience and not others?
In order that the other rules may be kept.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: madyaṃ pivato 'nyānyapyaṅgānyaguptāni syuḥ / kathaṃ punarmadyapānaṃ pratikṣepaṇasāvadyaṃ gamyate /
column2: One who drinks strong liquor will not keep the other rules.
The Ābhidhārmikas maintain that strong liquor does not have the characteristic of being a transgression by its nature.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prakṛtisāvadyaṃ hi kliṣṭenaiva cittenādhyācaryate / śakyaṃ tu madyaṃ pratīkārabuddhyaiva pātuṃ yāvanna madayet /
column2: A transgression by its nature is committed only by a person whose mind is defiled: now it happens that, as a remedy, one can drink strong liquor in a quantity where it is not inebriating.
But the mind of one who drinks knowing that such a quantity is inebriating is defiled;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tat kliṣṭaṃ yadamadanīyamātrāṃ viditvā pibati /
column2: the mind is not defiled when one drinks knowing that such a quantity is not inebriating.
Such is not the opinion of the Vinayadharas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “kathaṃ bhadanta glāna upasthātavyaḥ / prakṛtisāvadyamupālin sthāpayitvā” ityuktaṃ bhagavatā /
column2: To Upāli, who asked him, “How should one attend to illnesses? ”The Blessed One answered, "Except, Upāli, by transgression of nature.
And, the Blessed One did not permit strong liquors to sick Śākyans: "Those who recognize me as their master should not drink any strong liquor, even a drop on the point of a blade of grass.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idaṃ coktaṃ māṃ bhikṣavaḥ śāstāramuddiśadbhiḥ kuśāgreṇāpi madyaṃ na pātavyami” tyataḥ prakṛtisāvadyamiti jñāyate / āryaiśca janmāntaragatairapyanadhyācārāt / prāṇivadhādivat /
column2: Since the Blessed One forbade only transgression by nature in the case of illness (as in the Upāsūra) and yet does not permit strong liquor, it is clear that strong liquor is a transgression by its very nature.

The Āryans, even in a following existence, do not drink strong liquor, not any more than they would commit the other transgressions of nature, killing, etc. Scripture—the Nandikasūra and elsewhere—places strong liquor among the misdeeds of the body. The Ābhidhārmikas answer: In general, the transgression of disobedience is permitted to the ill, as the answer to Upāli proves.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: netyābhidhārmikāḥ / utsargavihitasyāpi glāneṣu prajñaptisāvadyasya punarmadyasyāpavādaḥ prasaṅgaparihārārthaṃ madnīyamātrānīyamanāt/ ata eva kuśāgrapānapratiṣedhaḥ / āryairanadhyācaraṇaṃ hrīmattvāttena ca smṛtināśāt /
column2: But strong liquor is an exception: though solely a transgression of disobedience, it is forbidden to the ill, and this with a view to preventing the unpleasant consequence of strong. If the Āryans certainly abstain from strong liquor, it is not because it is a transgression by its very nature, but because they are filled with the force of modesty.
This is because strong liquor makes mindfulness fail, even if they do not drink a drop, this is because the inebriating quantity is not determined, as for poison.

Scripture considers strong liquor as a bodily misdeed, because strong liquor is a “cause of non-vigilence. ” In fact, the rule of training relative to strong liquor includes the expression, “Abandoning the pramādasthāna which is strong liquor, s#rā and maireya, 1 renounce pramādasthāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evātra pramādasthānagrahaṇaṃ nānyeṣu teṣāṃ prakṛtisāvadyatvāt /
column2: ” This is not the case for the other transgressions: one does not say “I renounce the pramādasthāna which is killing,” and that is because the other transgressions are transgressions by their very nature.
The Scripture says that one is reborn in hell through the practice of strong liquor.
As a consequence of strong liquor, there is continual.
Swrā is a fermented drink of rice;
mzaireya is a fermented drink of various ingredients.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te ca kadācidaprāptacyutamadyabhāve bhavataḥ ityato madyagrahaṇam /
column2: At a certain moment, the liquor is no longer inebriating; at a certain moment, it is no longer that; this is why the word adya has been added. Even the areca-nut, the paspale are termed sy/rā and maireya when they inebriate.
Strong liquor is only a transgression of disobedience.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prajñaptisāvadyasyāpyādareṇa praheyatve kāraṇajñāpanārthaṃ pramādasthānavacanam / sarvapramādāspadatvāditi / ya ime trayaḥ prātimokṣadhyānānāsravasaṃvarāḥ kimeṣāṃ yata eko labhyate tataḥ śeṣau / netyāha / kiṃ tarhi / sarvobhayebhyaḥ kāmāpto vartamānebhya āpyate /
column2: The formula thus contains the words pramādasthāna in order to have one understand that one should renounce strong liquor because it is the cause of all failures of mindfulness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vartamānebhya eva skandhāyatana dhātubhyaḥ kāmāpta iti prātimokṣasaṃvaraḥ /
column2: The discipline of Kāmadhātu is the Prātimokṣa discipline.
This discipline is relative to all actions, preparatory actions, actions themselves, and consecutive action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhayebhya iti sattvāsattvākhyebhyaḥ prakṛtipratikṣepaṇasāvadyebhyaśca vartamānebhya eva skandhāyatanadhātubhyo labhyate /
column2: This discipline is relative to living beings and to non-living beings, for example persons and trees.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sattvādhiṣṭānapravṛttatvāt nātītānāgatebhyaḥ / teṣāmasattvasaṃkhyātatvāt / maulebhyaḥ sarvakālebhyo dhyānānāsravasaṃvarau // maulebhya eva karmapathebhyo dhyānānāsravasaṃvarau labhyete na prayogapṛṣṭhebhyaḥ
column2: This discipline is relative to the transgressions by nature and to the transgression of disobedience, both of which are capable of relating to living beings or to non-living beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuta eva prajñaptisāvadyebhyaḥ sarvakālebhyaśca skandhāyatanadhātubhyo labhyete atītānāgatebhyo 'pi / ata eva catuṣkoṭikaṃ kriyate /
column2: This discipline is relative to things—skandhas, āyatanas and dhātus—of the present, for the things of the past and of the future are neither living beings, nor non-living beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: santi tāni skandha dhātvāyatanāti yebhyaḥ prātimokṣasaṃvaraḥ eva labhyate na dhyānānāsravasaṃvarāviti vistaraḥ /
column2: There are thus some skandhas, āyatanas and dhātus relative to which one acquires the Pṛātimokṣa discipline and not the two others. Four cases:
Preparatory and consecutive actions, transgressions of disobedience, of the present—alluded to by the Prātimokṣa.
Courses of action of the pastand future—alluded to by the last two disciplines.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tṛtīyā pratyutpannebhyo maulebhyaḥ karmapathebhyaḥ / caturthyatītānāgatebhyaḥ sāmantakapṛṣṭhemyaḥ iti /
column2: Courses of actions of the present—alluded to by the three disciplines. Preparatory and consecutive actions of the past and the future, with regard to which one cannot undertake any of the three disciplines.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: natu saṃvarakāle vartamānāḥ karmapathāḥ santīti vartamānādhiṣṭhānebhyaḥ iti vaktavyam /
column2: Objection: It is not correct to say that one undertakes the discipline relative to the course of action of the present time: for, when one undertakes the discipline, no bad course of action is present relative to which one could undertake the discipline.

One should say, “One undertakes the discipline relative to the course of action whose object isI can abstain from a future action relative to a person or to a thing existing at the present time, but I cannot abstain from a past or future action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kiṃ saṃvarāsaṃvarau sarvasattvebhya eva labhyete sarvāṅgebhyaḥ sarvakāraṇaiśca āhosvidasti bhedaḥ /
column2: Does one acquire discipline or undiscipline with regard to all beings, relative to all of their parts, and by reason of all causes?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: niyataṃ tāvat labhyate / saṃvaraḥ sarvasattvebhyo vibhāṣā tvaṅgakāraṇaiḥ /
column2: One acquires discipline with regard to all beings; one must distinguish regarding the parts and the causes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvasattvebhya eva saṃvaro labhyate kebhyaścit aṅgebhyastu vibhāṣā / kaścit sarvebhyo labhyate /
column2: One acquires discipline with regard to all beings, not with regard to only some of them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhikṣusaṃvaraḥ / kaściccaturbhyaḥ / tato 'nyaḥ / karmapathā hi saṃvarasyāṅgāni /
column2: The discipline of the Bhikṣu is acquired relative to all parts: abstention from the ten courses of action. The other disciplines are acquired relative to four parts: abstention from killing, from stealing, from forbidden sexuality, from lying, for, by parts of the discipline, one should understand abstention from the courses of action.
If, by cause of the acquisition of discipline, one understands the three roots of good, then the discipline is acquired by reason of all these causes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kena tāvatsarvaiḥ / yadyalobhādveṣāmohāḥ kāraṇānīṣyante / kenai kena /
column2: If one understands by.
The discipline is acquired by reason of one of these three minds. From this last point of view, four alternatives can be distinguished.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paścimaṃ paryāyaṃ niyamayyocyate asti saṃvarasthāyī sarvasattveṣu saṃvṛto na sarvāṅgaiḥ na sarvakāraṇaiḥ / yo mṛdunā cittena madhyenādhimātreṇa vā upāsakovāsa śrāmaṇerasaṃvaraṃ samādatte /
column2: There is a person abiding in discipline, disciplined with regard to all beings, but not disciplined relative to all the parts, nor disciplined by reason of all causes: he who, through a strong, or mediocre, or weak mind, has acquired the discipline of the Upāsaka, the Upavāsastha or the Śrāmaṇera.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti sarvasattveṣu saṃvṛtaḥ sarvaṅgaiśca na tu sarakāraṇaiḥ / yo mṛdunā cittena madhyenādhimātreṇa vā bhikṣusaṃvaraṃ samādatte /
column2: There is a person abiding in the discipline, disciplined with regard to all beings and relative to all the parts, but not disciplined by reason of all causes: he who has acquired the discipline of the Bhīkṣu through a strong, mediocre, or weak mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti sarvasattveṣu sarvaṅgaiḥ sarvakāraṇaiśca / yastrividhena cittena trīn saṃvarān samādatte /
column2: There is a person residing in discipline, disciplined with regard to all beings, relative to all the parts, by reason of all the causes: he who has acquired each of the three.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti sarvasattveṣu sarvakāraṇaiśca na tu sarvāṅgaiḥ / ya upāsakopavāsaśrāmaṇerasaṃvarānmṛdumadhyādhimātraiḥ samādatte /
column2: There is a person residing in discipline, disciplined with regard to all beings, disciplined by reason of all the causes, but not disciplined relative to all the parts: he who has acquired each of the three disciplines of the Upāsaka, the Upavāsastha and the Śrāmapera through minds which are, respectively, weak, mediocre, and strong.
No one abides indiscipline who is not disciplined with regard to all beings: he acquires the discipline through a good mind having for its object all beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmātsarvasattvānugate kalyāṇāśaye sthitaḥ saṃvaraṃ pratilabhate nānyathā pāpāśayasyānuparatatvāt /
column2: The person who makes a restriction is not completely rid of the intention of transgression.
The Prātimokṣa discipline includes the absence of the fivefold restriction.
With regard to beings, "I renounce transgressions with regard to certain beings; With regard to parts of the discipline, "T renounce certain actions;
With regard to place, "I renounce committing transgressions in a certain place;

With regard to time, "I renounce transgressions committed at a certain time; With regard to the object, "I renounce transgressions committed with regard to a certain object. "renounce transgressions for a month;
with regard to circumstances, "I renounce transgressions except in the case of a quarrel. He who undertakes such undertakings does not acquire the discipline;
rather, he does a good action similar to the acquisition of the discipline.
How can one acquire the discipline with regard to all beings?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi punaḥ śakyebhya eva saṃvaro labhyate cayāpacayayuktaḥ syāt /
column2: How can one acquire the discipline with regard to beings who are out of range, or with regard to beings whom one cannot kill?
Because, we believe, one acquires the discipline through the intention of not killing any being.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca sati vināpi lābhatyāgakāraṇābhyāṃ saṃvarasya lābhatyāgau syātāmiti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: The Vaibhashikas give a different explanation. If the discipline was acquired only with regard to beings who are within range, the discipline would be liable to augmentation and to diminution: for some humans, who are now within range, will be reborn as gods, which are out of range;

and vice versa. The discipline would thus be acquired with regard to gods who become human, and lost with regard to humans who become gods, without there being any cause either of the acquisition, or of the loss of. the transmigration of beings within range and out of range does not entail the augmentation or the diminution of the discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā hyapūrvatṛṇādyutpattau śoṣe vā saṃvarasya vṛddhihlāsau na bhavatastathā śakyāśakyasaṃcāre 'pi na syātām /
column2: For the discipline that one undertakes with regard to grass neither increases nor diminishes when new grass arises, nor when old grass dries up. The Vaibhāṣikas deny the value of this comparison.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na sattvānāṃ pūrvaṃ paścācca bhāvāttṛṇādīnāṃ tvabhāvāt /
column2: Grass exists after having been nonexistent, and no longer exists after having existed. Living beings, on the contrary, continue to exist, sometimes as humaṉs, and sometimes as gods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ko nvatra viśeṣo na vā bhavedasatsu tṛṇādiṣu saṃvarastadvadaśakyo vā bhavet /
column2: Humans, becoming gods, only pass out of range, whereas grass is annihlated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā ca parinirvṛtā na bhavantyeva tadā kathaṃ saṃvarahlāso na syāditi naiṣa yuktaḥ parihāraḥ /
column2: But when living beings enter into Nirvāṇa, they no longer exist, exactly like grass, so the discipline acquired with regard to living beings is subject to diminution.
Thus the explanation of the Vaibhāṣikas is invalid.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi pūrvabuddhaparinirvṛtebhya uttareṣāṃ buddhānāṃ pratimokṣasaṃvarasyā lābhātkathaṃ śīlanyūnatā na prasajyeta / sarveṣāṃ sattvebhyo lābhāt /
column2: If one objects, “In the case where the Prātimokṣa discipline would be acquired with regard to all beings, then the discipline of later Buddhas would be reduced in comparason with that of former Buddhas, for itWe would reply: all the Buddhas discipline all beings;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi hi te 'pyabhaviṣyaṃ stebhyo 'pi te 'lapsyanta / uktaṃ yataḥ saṃvaro labhyate /
column2: and if former Buddhas were to exist again, later Buddhas would be disciplined by them.
Undiscipline, with regard to all, relative to all parts, and not by reason of all causes.
One acquires undiscipline with regard to all beings and relative to all courses of action.
No one is undisciplined with an incomplete undiscipline.
One is not undisciplined by reason of all causes, undiscipline being undertaken by a weak, mediocre, or strong mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo mṛdunā cittenāsaṃvaraṃ pratilabhate so 'dhimātreṇāpi cittena prāṇinaṃ jīvitādvyaparopayanmṛdunaivā saṃvareṇa samanvāgato bhavatyadhimātrayā tu prāṇātipātavijñaptyā / evaṃ madhyādhimātreṇa yojyam /
column2: Let us suppose that an undisciplined person has undertaken his undiscipline with a weak mind and commits a murder with a strong mind: his undiscipline remains weak, but he is adorned with a strong vijñapti, with a strong murder. The term "undisciplined" is explained etymologically as one "who resides in undiscipline, one who possesses undiscipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatreme āsaṃvarikāstadyathā aurabhrikāḥ kaukkuṭikāḥ saukarikāḥ śākunikā mātsikā mṛgalubdhakāścaurā vadhyaghātakā bandhanapālakā nāgabandhakāḥ śvapākā vāgurikāśca /
column2: The butchers of sheep, bird-catchers, the butchers of pigs, fishermen, hunters, bandits, executioners, jailers, elephant hunters.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rājāno daṇḍanetāro vyāvahārikāścārthata āsaṃvarikāḥ asaṃvare bhavatvāt tatrashatayā asaṃvara eṣāmastīti āsaṃvarikā vā /
column2: It also holds that kings, office holders, judges, etc. , are undisciplined.
A butcher of sheep is the person whose profession is to kill sheep.
The same etymology holds for the names of the other professions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yuktastāvat saṃvarasya sarvasattvebhyo lābhaḥ / sarvasattvahitādhyāśayena grahaṇāt /
column2: We understand that discipline, undertaken with the intention of universal benevolence, would be acquired with regard to all beings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aurabhrikādīnāṃ tu mātāpitṛputradārādiṣvavipannāśayānāṃ jīvitahetorapyahantukāmānāṃ kathamasaṃvaraḥ sarvasattvebhyo yujyate /
column2: But the butchers of sheep do not have the intention of maltreating their parents, their children, or their servants; they would not want to kill them, even at the price of their lifes. How can one say that they are undisciplined with regard to all beings?
The Vaibhāṣikas: Because they have the intention of killing with regard to their parents who have become sheep through transmigration.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi tāvatte ta eva iti vidvāṃso hanyuḥ /
column2: But they do not kill their parents who have become sheep knowing that they are their parents!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āryībhūtānāṃ ca punaḥ paśu bhavituṃ nāstyavakāśa iti tebhyaḥ kathaṃ syāt / yadi cā nāgatātmabhāvāpekṣayā varttamānādasaṃvṛtaḥ syādurabhrādīnapi te putrībhūtāt sarvathā na hanyuriti ina syāttebhyyo 'saṃvaraḥ /
column2: Furthermore, if their parents obtain the quality of an Āryan, these parents will not be reborn as sheep or asFinally, the argument turns against you: if the butcher is undisciplined with regard to his present parents because he will kill his parents who have become sheep, one would say as well that he is not undisciplined with regard to some other sheep since he is not disposed to kill the sheep which are reborn as humans, as his own children.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ hi nāma jighāṃsatāmeva tebhyo na syādasaṃvaraḥ / etanmātrādiṣu samānam /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas: He who has the intention to kill his parents who have become sheep is certainly undisciplined with regard to them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ hi nāmājighāṃsatāmeva tebhyaḥ syādasaṃvara iti / yaścaurabhriko janmanāpyādatte svadāraparituṣṭo mūkaśca /
column2: But, he who does not have the intention of killing the sheep who have become his children is certainly not undisciplined in their regard.
Another point: how can the butcher who does not steal, who is not an adulterer, and who is mute, be undisciplined relative to all these transgressions?
The Vaibhāṣikas: Because his intention is perverted.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mūko 'pi ca vākprāpaṇīyamarthaṃ kāyena prāpayituṃ śakta iti /
column2: A mute can express himself through gestures.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastarhi dve trīṇi vā śikṣāpadāni samādatte /
column2: But what is there to say of a man who has accepted two or three parts of morality?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvathā nāsti vikalaḥ prādeśikaścāsaṃvarika iti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: For the Vaibhāṣikas, nondiscipline is never incomplete, that is, relative only to certain parts; nor is it partial, that is, including restrictions in the practice of a certain transgression.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā bhyupagamaṃ vikalo 'pi syāt prādeśiko 'pyasaṃvaraḥ saṃvaraścānyatrāṣṭavidhāditi sautrāntikāḥ /
column2: For the Sautrāṇtikas, discipline and undiscipline with the exception of the Prātimokṣa discipline can be incomplete and partial.
This depends on the manner in which one undertakes discipline or undiscipline: one “binds” oneself to a part of immorality, or to a certain part of morality.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ tu lābha iti noktam / tata idamucyate /
column2: How does one acquire undiscipline? How does one acquire the avijñaptis which are neither discipline, nor undiscipline?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaṃvarasya kriyayā lābho 'bhyupagamena vā / dvābhyāṃ kāraṇābhyāmasaṃvaro labhyate /
column2: One acquires undiscipline through action or through accepting it.
Persons born in a family of undisciplined persons acquire undiscipline when they accomplish the actions preparatory to killing.
Persons born in other families acquire undiscipline when they adopt such a style of life, thinking “We too shall live in this manner.”
One acquires the other avijñaptis by reason of the field, of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣetraṃ vā tadrūpaṃ bhavati yatrārāmādipradānamātreṇāvijñaptirutpadyate / yathaupadhikeṣu puṇyakriyāvastuṣu /
column2: Certain persons are a field of such a nature that by offering them a garden, etc. , one reduces vijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athavā samādānamādatte buddhamavanditvā na bhokṣye tithimāsārdhamāsabhaktāni vā nityaṃ kariṣyāmītyādi / ādareṇa tadrūpeṇa kriyāmīhate kuśalāmakuśalāṃ vā yato 'syāvijñaptirutpadyate / uktametadyathā saṃvarāsaṃvaretarāṇāṃ pratilambhaḥ /
column2: One produces vikalpa by undertaking vows, for example, "I shall not eat unless I have paid homage to the Buddha," "I shall give alms food on the fast day, for a fortnight, for a month, for a year," etc. Action undertaken seriously, with a burning faith, with a burning passion, produces nirvikalpa.
How does one lose discipline? The Prātimokṣa discipline is lost through abjuration, through death, through hermaphroditism, through the cutting off of the roots, and by the night coming to an end.
The stanza calls the Prātimokṣa discipline derna because it subdues the six organs.
Excluding the discipline of the fast, the Prātimokṣa discipline is lost: 1.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śikṣāpadānāṃ vijñapuruṣasyāntike pratyākhyānadāśayataḥ nikāyasabhāgatyāgāt yugapadu bhayavyañjanaprādurbhāvāt kuśalamūlasamucchedācca /
column2: through abjuration, intentionally renouncing the rule in the presence of a person capable of understanding it; through the death.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upavāsasaṃvarasya tvebhiścaturbhirārātrikṣayācca / tānyetānyabhisamasya pañca tyāgakāraṇāni bhavanti / kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇamebhiḥ kāraṇaistyāgo bhavati /
column2: The discipline of fast is lost through four causes: abandonment of the n²kāyasabhāga, appearance of male or female organs, cutting off of roots of good, and when night comes to an end.

Abjuration contradicts the undertaking, death and hermaphroditism abandon and overturn the personality who undertook the Prātiṁmokṣa, and cutting off the roots is the foundation of the discipline itself. The discipline of the fast is created for a day and a night and ends when the night is finished.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: patanīyena cetyeke anye punarāhuścaturṇāṃ patanīyānāmanyatamena bhikṣuśrāmaṇerasaṃvaratyāga iti / saddhamantirdhito 'pare /
column2: Some say it is lost through a patanīya, and according to the Sautrāntikas, the discipline of the Bhikṣu and the novice is also lost through any one of the four patan#yas, or transgressions involving a falling away. Some other masters say it is lost through the disappearance of the Good Law.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saddharmasyāntardhānādityapare / yasmādantarhite saddharme sarvaśikṣāsīmākarmāntāḥ pratiprasrabhyanta iti /
column2: According to the Dharmaguptakas, the Prātimokṣa discipline is lost.
The Kaśmīreans believe that the transgressor possesses morality and immorality, in the manner thata person can have riches and debts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāśmīrāstu khalu vaibhāṣikāḥ evamicchanti / na maulīmadhyāpattimā pannasyāsti bhikṣusaṃvaratyāgaḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmīr say: A monk guilty of a grave transgression, that is,of apa³anīya,does not lose hisBhikṣu discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hyekadeśakṣobhāt kṛtsna saṃvaratyāgo yukta iti /
column2: It is notadmissible that one loses the entire discipline by destroying only a part of the discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva cānyāmapyāpatti māpannasyāsti śīlacchedaḥ / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: He who comrnits a transgression other than a patanya is not immoral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvayamasya bhavati śīlaṃ dauḥśīlyaṃ ca / yathā kasyaciddhanaṃ syādṛṇaṃ ca /
column2: He who commits a pa$an#ya is at one and the ṣame time moral and immoral: as a person who has both riches and debts;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āviṣkṛtāyāṃ tu tasyāmāpattau śīlavānbhavati na duḥśīlo yathā ṛṇaṃ śodhayitvā dhanavānbhavati na tvṛṇavāniti /
column2: but when this transgressor has confessed his transgression, he is no longer immoral,but solely moral: as a person who has paid his debts.
But the Blessed One has said, “He is not a Bhikṣu, he is not a monk; he no longer belongs to the sons of Śākya;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katamasya bhavati śrāmaṇyaṃ dhvastaṃ patitaṃ parājitamiti / paramārthabhikṣutvaṃ saṃdhāyaitaduktam / idamabhisāhasaṃ vartate / kimatrābhisāhasam /
column2: he falls from the quality of Bhikṣu;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yat bhagavatā nītārthaṃ punaranyathā nīyate / dauḥśīlyāya ca bahukleśebhyaḥ pratyayā dīyante /
column2: his quality of monkhood is cut off, falen, eṟased,An inadmissible explanation: you avoid the question that the Blessed One made "in a clear sense:" furthermore, you lead defiled persons to the practice of immorality.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathameta nītārtham / eṣa hi vinaye nirdeṣaḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣīkas: How can you prove that this quotation is of clear sense and should be taken literally? The Blessed One has explained this himself.

There are four Bhikṣus: a saṁñābhūṣu, a Bhīkṣu in name only, is a person who is called Bhikṣu without his having been ordained; a pratáñābhikṣu, a self-styled Bhikṣu, is one who is immoral, unchaste, etc;
saṃjñābhikṣuḥ pratijñābhikṣurbhikṣata iti bhikṣurbhinnakleśatvāt bhikṣuḥ /	a person called Bhikṣu because he begs, is a beggar only; and the person who is called Bhikṣu because he has cut off the defilements, that is to say, the Arhat. In the text which concerns us (He is not a Bhikṣu, he is not a monk.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asmiṃstvarthe jñapticaturthakarmopasaṃpanno bhikṣuri“ti / na cāsau pūrvaṃ paramārthabhikṣurāsīdyataḥ paścādabhikṣurbhavet yaccoktamekadeśakṣobhāditi atra śāstraiva datto 'nuyoga “stadyathā tālo mastakācchinno 'bhavyo 'ṅkuritatvāya abhavyo viruḍhiṃ vṛddhiṃ vipulatāmāptu” mityupamāṃ kurvatā /
column2:
), this refers to a fifth Bhikṣu, namely a person who hasIt is certainly not a question of his being a true Bhikṣu, an Arhat, for one capable of a patanāya is not a true Bhikṣu, an Arhat, but is susceptible of losing the quality of being a true Bhikṣu.
kaḥ punarūpamārthaḥ / evamekadeśa syāpi mūlabhūtasya cchedādabhavyaḥ saṃvaraśeṣo viroḍumiti / sa ca gurvīṃ bhikṣubhāvamaryādābhedinīṃ maulīmāpattimāpadyamānastīvrānapatrāpyayogātsaṃvarasya mūlaṃ cchinattīti yuktaḥ kṛtsnasaṃvaratyāgaḥ	The argument that one does not lose the entire discipline through the losing of one part of it, is refuted by the Master himself who in fact compares a transgressor monk to a palm tree whose head is cut off, henceforth incapable of becoming green, of growing, of developing, or of growing larger: this means that, when one part of the discipline, the part which is the root of the discipline, is cut off, the rest of the discipline is incapable of growing. duḥkhavedyamihāśubham //	Bad action, here below, is of disagreeable sensation.
akuśalaṃ karma duḥkhavedanīyam /	Bad action is of disagreeable sensation.
ihagrahaṇaṃ kāmadhātāveva tadbhāvajñāpanārtham /	The ārkā says 'here below” in order to indicate that this action exists only in Kāmadhāta.
na caiṣāṃ vedanaiva phalam / kiṃ tarhi / sasaṃbhārā /	Is the result of all these actions only sensation? they also have the apparatus of sensation as their result.
adho 'pi madhyamastyeke /	According to some, intermediary action also exists.
anye punarāhuḥ tadetanmadhyamaduḥkhāsukhavedanīyaṃ karmoktametaccaturthadhyānādadho 'pyasti / kiṃ kāraṇam / dhyānāntaravipākataḥ /	According to others, intermediary action—that is, action which has for its retribution neither agreeable nor disagreeable sensation—also exists below the Fourth Dhyāna.
itarathā hi dhyānāntarakarmaṇo vipāko na syāddhyānāntaraṃ vā kasyacitkarmaṇaḥ / tatra sukhaduḥkhayorabhāvāt /	Since there is no retribution with regard to dhyānāntara, if intermediary action is absent below the Fourth Dhyāṇna, there would not be any retribution of dhyāanāntara action, or rather, there would not be any retribution of any action whatsoever in dhyānāntara, for there are no agreeable and disagreeable sensations therein.
dhyānāntarakarmaṇo dhyāna eva sukhendrīyaṃ vipāka ityeke /	Some say that the retribution of dḍhyānāntara action is the sensation of pleasure of the dhyāna itself;
naiva tasya vedanā vipāka ityapare / tadetaducchāstram /	some others say that the retribution of this action is not sensation.
śāstre hi paṭhitaṃ “syātkarmaṇaścaitasikyeva vedanā vipāko vipacyeta /	These two opinions are in contradiction to the Śāstra, “Does it happen that an action is solely mental sensation?
syātkuśalasyāvitarkasya karmaṇa” iti / apurvācaramaḥ pākastrayāṇāṃ ceṣyate yataḥ //	Yes, the retribution of a good action which was free from vsitarka. ”Because it is admitted that the retribution of the three types of action takes place at the one and same time. This is the second reason why one should admit that intermediary action exists below the Fourth Dhyāṇa.
yataścoktaṃ sūtre “syāttrayāṇāṃ karmaṇāmapūrvācaramo vipāko vipacyeta /	The Śāstra says in the same place, “Does it happen that there is at oṉe and the same time retribution of the three types of action? Yes.
syātsukhavedanīyasya rūpaṃ duḥkhavedanīyasya cittacaittā dharmāḥ /	There can take place at the same time: the retribution of an action of agreeable sensation, namely of materialdharmas, [the organ of seeing, etc. ]; the retribution of an action of disagreeable sensation, namely the mind and the mental states ;
aduḥkhāsukhavedanīyasya cittaviprayuktā” ityato 'pyastyaduḥkhāsukhavedanīyaṃ karmādhastāt /	the retribution of an action of neither agreeable nor disagreeable sensation, namely thedbarmas dissociated from the rnind, [vital organ, etc. , iii35].
nahi kāmadhātoranyatrāsti yugapatkarmatrayasya vipāke saṃyogaḥ / kimidānīṃ tatkukśalamāhosvidakuśalaṃ /	” Now, the three types of action cannot be retributed simultaneously outside of Kāmadhātu, for the retribution of action of disagreeable sensation takes place only in Kāmadhātu.
durbalaṃ tu tat / evaṃ tarhi “sukhavedyaṃ śubhaṃ dhyānādātṛtīyā” “diṣṭa-vipākaṃ ca kuśala” mityasya virodhaḥ / bāhulika eṣa nirdeśo draṣṭavyaḥ /	It is good, but of weak force.
kathaṃ punaravedanāsvabhāvaṃ karma sukhādivedinīyamityucyate /	But how can one say that action is of agreeable sensation? Action, by its nature, is not sensation.
sukhavedanāyai hitaṃ sukhavedanoyaṃ sukho 'sya vedanīya iti vā / kaśca vedanīyaḥ / yo vipākaḥ /	One expresses oneself in this way because action is favorable to agreeable sensation;
sa hyasau vidyate sukhasya vā vedanīyaṃ yena sukhaṃ vedayate /	or rather, because its retribution is agreeably sensed.
snānīyakapāyavat / evaṃ duḥkhavedanīyamaduḥkhāsukhavedanīyaṃ ca draṣṭavyam /	In the same way that one calls bathing clothes, snānāyakāṣāya, “the clothes with which one bathes,” in that same way one terms “to be sensed” action through which one senses a retribution.
api ca / svabhāvasaṃprayogābhyāmālambanavipākataḥ / saṃmukhībhāvataśceti pañcadhā vedanīyatā //	There are five ways of being vedanīya, “sensed,” “experienced:” of itself, through sensation, as an object, by being retributed, and by the fact of its presence.
svabhāvavedanīyatā vedanānām /	Sensation, by its nature, is feeling.
svabhāvenaiva vedanīyatvāt / saṃprayogavedanīyatā sparśasya / “sukhavedanīyaḥ sparśaḥ” iti / ālambanavedanīyatā viṣayāṇām /	Agreeable sensation is agreeable experience, etc. Contact is feeling because it is associated with sensation.
yathoktaṃ “cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi dṛṣṭvā rūpapratisaṃvedī bhavati notu rūparāgapratisaṃvedī“tyevamādi /	The six objects of the six organs are feeling in the role of object, Seeing color with the eye, he experiences, he feels the color, but he does not feel the color with affection.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vedanayā hi tāmālambamānaḥ pratisaṃvedayate / vipākavedanīyatā karmaṇaḥ /
column2:
Color is thus the object of sensation.
“dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ karme“ti vistaraḥ /	Action is feeling in its role of being retributed, an action experienced in the present existence".
Sensation is feeling through the fact of its appearance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathoktaṃ “yasmin samaye sukhāṃ vedanāṃ vedayate dve asya vedane tasminsamaye niruddhe bhavata” iti / nahi yasminsamaye sukhā vedanā vartate tasminpunaranyā vedanā 'sti sa yāṃ tāṃ vedayate /
