column2: When he feels, when he experiences agreeable sensation, two sensations, the disagreeable and the neutral, are then found to be obstructed by it: hence when agreeable sensation is functioning, there is no other sensation through which one would feel it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃmukhīkurvastu tāṃ vedayata ityucyate / ato vipākasya vedanīyatvāt karmāpyucyate sukhavedanīyamityevamādi /
column2: Thus if one says that this sensation is "to be felt", this is because it is present.
This action is determinate or indeterminate.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taccaitatsukhavedanīyādi trividhaṃ karma niyataṃ cāniyataṃ ca veditavyam /
column2: The action that we have just described is either determinate, that is, "which will necessarily be felt," orDeterminate action is of three types, to be experienced in the present life, etc. Determinate action is: to be experienced in the present life;
to be experienced after having been reborn, in other words in the next immediate life;
and to be experienced later.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyamupapadyavedanīyamaparaparyāyavedanīyaṃ cetyetattrividhaṃ karma niyatamityetaccaturvidhaṃ karma bhavati sahāniyatavedanīyena
column2: By adding indeterminate action, this makes, from the point of view of the modality of retribution, four types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcadhā karma kecana // apare punaḥ pañcavidhaṃ karmecchanti /
column2: According to one opinion, action is of five types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aniyatavedanīyaṃ dvidhā kṛtvā / vipākena niyatamaniyataṃ ceti /
column2: By dividing indeterminate action into two categories: that which is indeterminate with regard to the period of its retribution, but whose retribution is in any case certain; and that which is indeterminate with regard to its retribution, which can be not retributed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ yatra janmani kṛtaṃ tatraiva vipacyate /
column2: Action experienced in the present life is action which ripens or is retributed in the same existence in which it was accomplished. Action experienced after being reborn is action which is retributed in the existence which follows that in which it was accomplished. Action.
Experienced later is action which is retributed in a later existence, from the third existence on. But, some other masters, cannot admit that a very strong action has a weak retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aparaparyāyavedanīyaṃ tasmātpareṇa / janmāntare 'pyasti dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyasya karmaṇo vipāka ārambhavaśāttannāmavyavasthānamityapare /
column2: Consequently, the retribution of an action experienced in the present life can continue into other existences;
yet, as this retribution begins in the present life, this action is said "to be experienced in the present life.
The Vaibhāṣikas do not accept this way of looking at it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti hi karma saṃnikṛṣṭaphalaṃ na viprakṛṣṭaphalamasti viparyayādbāhyabījavat /
column2: There is, they say, some actions whose results are near, and some actions whose results are distant.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tripakṣā suvarcalā tribhiḥ pakṣaiḥ phalaṃ dadhāti yavagodhūmādayaḥ ṣaḍbhirmāsairiti /
column2: In the same way flax bears its fruit after two and a half months, but wheat and godhāma after six months.
Others distinguish four alternatives.
The Dārṣṭāntikas distinguish four cases: 1.

Action determined with regard to the period of its retribution, but indeterminate with regard to its retribution. If this action is retributed, it will certainly be retributed at such a moment, but it is not necessarily retributed: this is.
Action determined with regard to its retribution, but indeterminate with regard to the period of its retribution.

This action will be retributed, but the period of its retribution remains undetermined: néyabavipāka, but ansyatavedanīya. Action determinate from two points of view: náyatavipāka and niyatavedanāyaá. Action indeterminate from two points of view: aniyatavipāka and aniyatavedanṅīya. According to this system there are eight types of actions: 1.
action experienced in the present existence and of certain retribution, 2.
action experienced in the present existence and of possible retribution.
action which can be experienced in any existence, but of certain retribution; and 8. action which can be experienced in any existence and of only possible retribution.
But actions defined in Scripture as "to be experienced in this life," etc. , are always of certain retribution; action defined as "indeterminate" may not be retributed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yāvadaniyatavedanīyam / niyatameva tu dṛṣṭadharmādivedanīyamaniyataṃ caturthamiti varṇayanti /
column2: Yes. Suppose that a man has murder, stealing, and lying committed by another person; he himself commits adultery;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syādekasmin kṣaṇe caturvidhaṃ karmākṣipet / syāttriṣu paraṃ prayojya kāmamithyācāre svayaṃ prayuktasteṣāṃ yugapatsamāptau / eṣāṃ ca punaścaturṇāṃ karmaṇāṃ /
column2: and that these four actions, which belong respectively to the four types, are committed at the same instant.
Three types of actions project existence.
Action experienced in the present existence does not project the present existence; this has been projected by a former action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katamasmindhātau katividhaṃ karmākṣipyate kasyāṃ vā gatau /
column2: How many types of action can be produced in the different spheres of existence and in the different realms of rebirth?
Fourfold production throughout.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarveṣu triṣu dhātuṣu sarvāsu ca gatiṣu caturṇāṃ karmaṇāmākṣepaḥ kuśalānāmakuśalānāṃ ca yathāsaṃbhavam / asyotsargasyāyamapavādaḥ /
column2: In the three spheres of existence and in all of the realms of rebirth the four types of good or bad action can be produced. But this general rule has some restrictions. On the one hand, there is no bad action above Kāmadhātu;
on the other hand: Good action, in the hells, is solely of three types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: narakeṣu kuśalasya karmaṇastrividhasyā kṣepo na dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyasya / tatreṣṭavipākābhāvāt /
column2: In the hells, one can produce good action to be experienced in the.
When he is firm, the fool does not produce any action to be experienced, at the stage from whence he is detached, in his next existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yato bhūmeḥ vītarāgapṛthagjano bhavatyasau ca sthiro bhavatyaparihāṇadharmā sa tatropapadyavedanīyaṃ karma na karoti / kimanyatkaroti /
column2: “When he is firm,” that is, when he is not subject to falling away. “The fool” refers to a Prthagjana. “When he is detached from a certain stage,” that is, when he is delivered from attachment with regard to a certain plane of existence, in this stage he never produces action to be experienced in his next rebirth.
The Āryaṉ no longer produces any action to be experienced in a later existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āryapudgalastu yato vītarāgo na ca parihāṇadharmā sa tatropapadyadanīyaṃ cāparaparyāyavedanīyaṃ ca karma na karoti /
column2: When he is firm, the Saint does not produce, in the stage from whence he is detached, any action to be experienced either in the next existence or in a later existence. In fact, the Prthagjana incapable of falling away is not reborn.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hyasau bhavyaḥ punarādhastanīṃ bhūmimāyātumaniyataṃ kuryāddṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ cātropapannaḥ /
column2: Both produce relative to the stage wherein they are born, actions to be experienced in the present existence and indeterminate action.

The Āryan, not firm, when he is detached from Kāmadhātu or from Bhavāgra, the same. An Āryan detached from Kāmadhātu is an Anāgāmin. An Āryan detached from Bhavāgra or naivasaṁjñānāásaṁjñāyatana, the last stage of Ārūpyadhātu, is an Arhat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: parihāṇadharmāpi tvāryapudgalaḥ kāmadhātorbhavāgrā dvītarāgaḥ tayorūpapadyāparaparyāyavedanīyaṃ karmābhavyaḥ karttum / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: Even when they are subject to falling away, that is to say, susceptible of losing the results obtained, these Saints do not produce action to be experienced in the next existence, nor in a subsequent existence, either in Kāmadhātu or in Bhavāgra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phalāddhi sa parihīṇo bhavati / na cāsti laparihīṇasya kālakriyeti paścātpravedayiṣyāmaḥ /
column2: We shall explain how the Saint, subject to falling away, always reacquires the results before dying.
Does the intermediate being produce any actions?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvāviṃśatividhaṃ kāmeṣvākṣipatyantarābhavaḥ / gāmāvacaro hyantarābhavo dvāviṃśatividhaṃ karmākṣipati / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: The intermediate being, in Kāmadhātu, produces twenty-two types of actions.
The embryo passes through five states, kalala, arbuda, pesin, ghana.
A human being passes through five states, as an infant, an adolescent, a grown person, a mature person, and an old person.
The intermediate creature produces determinate actions to be experienced as an intermediate being, as kalala, as arbuda.
as an infant, as an adolescent. there are eleven types of determinate actions. In this same way, he produces eleven indeterminate actions.
These actions bear their results in the present existence.
The eleven determinate actions of the intermediate being belong to the category "to be experienced in the present existence.

Why?
nikāyo hyeka eva saḥ //	For all these states form, together with the intermediate existence, only a single existence.
eka eva hyasau nikāyasabhāga ekakarmākṣipto yaścāntarābhavo yāśca tadanvayā daśāvasthāḥ /	The intermediate existence and the ten states which follow it are projected by a single action.
ata evānyadantarābhavavedanīyaṃ karma noktam / upapadyavedanīyena ca tasyākṣepāt /	Thus one does not distinguish an action to be experienced in the intermediate existence:" this is projected, in fact, by the action itself which is to be experienced in the life which follows the intermediate existence.
By virtue of what characteristics is an action determinate, that is to say, necessarily retributed?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tīvrakleśaprasādena sātatyena ca yatkṛtam / guṇakṣetre ca niyataṃ tatpitrorghātakaṃ ca yat //
column2: Action accomplished through intense defilement or through intense faith, with regard to the field of qualities, continually, and the murdering of a father and a mother, are determinate.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaddhi karma tīvreṇa kleśena kṛtaṃ yacca tīvreṇa prasādena yacca sātatyena gunakṣetre ca tanniyataṃ veditavyam /
column2: Action accomplished through intense defilement, action accomplished through intense faith, action accomplished with regard to a field of qualities, and action continually accomplished, are determinate.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra guṇakṣetraṃ trīṇi ratnāni / pudgalaviśeṣo vā kaścitphalasamāpattiviśeṣaprāptaḥ /
column2: “Field of qualities” signifies either the Three Jewels, or certain persons, namely the possessors of the results, or Saints, and the possessors of certain absorptions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra hyantareṇāpi tīvrakleśaprasādānāṃ sātatyaṃ ca kuśalamakuśalaṃ ca karma niyataṃ saṃpadyate /
column2: Action accomplished with regard to these fields, even in the absence of an intense thought of defilement or of faith, or of continuity, is determinate, whether it is good or bad.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pitarau punarmātā ca pitā ca / tayoścāpi yatra ghātikaṃ karma yathā tathā vā tanniyataṃ saṃpadyate nānyat / atha dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ karma kīdṛśaṃ veditavyam / dṛṣṭadharmaphalaṃ karma kṣetrāśayaviśeṣataḥ /
column2: The same for the murder of one’s father or mother, with whatever intention it was committed.
Action bears result in the present existence by reason of certain characteristics of the field and the intention.
By reason of the excellence of the field, even though the intention may be weak: for example, the Bhikṣu who becomes a woman through having insulted the Saṅgha, “You are nothing but women!
” By reason of the excellence of the intention: for example the eunuch who delivered bulls from the danger of being castrated, and so regained his own sexuality.
Or still further: And also, when one is definitively detached with regard to the stage in which the action appears.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadbhūmyatyantavairāgyāt tasya vā karmaṇo yā bhūmiḥ kuśalasyākuśalasya vā tato 'tyantavairāgyāttatkarma dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ karma saṃpadyate / tasyāṃ bhūmau jātasya kīdṛśaṃ karmetyāha
column2: When a person is definitively detached from a ceṟtain stage , he cannot anymore be reborn in this stage: as a consequence, action retributable in this stage, but in another existence,whether it is good or bad, changes its nature and becomes retributable in the present.
This refers to action having a necessary retribution, but indeterminate with regard to the period of its retribution: this action will be retributed in the present life.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaddhi karma niyataṃ vipāke na tvavasthāyāṃ nāpyaniyataṃ tatyaiṣa niyamaḥ /
column2: As for action determinate with regard to the period of its retribution, it will be retributed in the period for which it is determinate: the person for whom actions should be retributed, in this first rebirth, in a certain stage, cannot be definitively detached from this stage.
As for action non-determinate with regard to the retribution itself, it will not be retributed if one detaches himself from the stage where it could have been retributed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaccāniyataṃ tasyāvipāka evātyantavairāgyāt / kīdṛśaṃ punaḥ kṣetraṃ yatrāvaśyaṃ dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ karma saṃpadyate / āha /
column2: Which field confers on an action which is in a relationship with it, the quality of being necessarily retributed in the present existence?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: buddhapramukho bhikṣusaṃghaḥ pudgalāstu pañca / ye nirodhāraṇāmaitrīdarśanārhatphalotthitāḥ / teṣu kārāpakārasya phalaṃ sadyo 'nubhūyate //
column2: In general, it is the Sangha of Bhikshus having at its head the Buddha;

to enumerate its persons, there are five types of persons: Persons who have left either norodha, or maitri, ot arana, orThe person who leaves the absorption of extinction: in this absorption he has obtained an extreme tranquility of thought, for this absorption is similar to Nirvāṇa.
When he leaves it, it is as if he had gone to Nirvāṇa and has returned from it.

The person who leaves the absorption which arrests the defilemeants of another: in this absorption, his mental series is endowed with the intention of placing an infinite number of beings into the absence of defilement; when he leaves it, his series is penetrated with an intense and measureless merit.

The person who leaves the absorption of compassion: in this absorption, his series is endowed with the intention of increasing the well-being of an infinite number of beings; when he leaves it, his series is penetrated with an intense and measureless merit.
The person who leaves the Path of Seeing the Ttuths: in this Path, he has abandoned all the defilements which are abandoned.

When he leaves it, his series is thus pure, since his personality has just been renewed. The person who leaves the result of Arhat, that is to say, who has just acquired the result of Arhat; he has just achieved the abandoning of all the defilements which are abandoned through Meditation on the Truths. His series is pure, since his personality has just been renewed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eteṣu kṛtānāṃ kārāpakārāṇāṃ phalaṃ dṛṣṭa eva dharme niyataṃ prāpyate /
column2: This is why good or bad actions, well or badly done, with regard to these five persons, bear a result in the present existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣasya tu bhāvanāmārgasyāparipūrṇasvabhāvaphalatvācca tadvyutthitānāṃ na tathā pratyagrāśrayaparivṛttiśuddhāśayasaṃtatirvartata iti na te tathā puṇyakṣetraṃ bhavati / vipākaḥ punarvedanāpradhānaḥ / tadidānīṃ vicāryate /
column2: The Paths of Meditation through which one obtains the results of Sakr̥dāgāmin and of Aṇāgāmin, are incomplete in themslves and in their result. Persons who leave the conquest of these two results are not fields of merit comparable to an Arhat. Their series is not pure; their personalities have not been recently renewed. The essential element of retribution is sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syāt karmaṇaścaitasikyeva vedanā vipāko vipacyeta na kāyikī / syāt kāyikyeva na caitasikī syādityāha kukśalasyāvitarkasya karmaṇo vedanā matā /
column2: Can the retribution of a certain action be excusively mental sensation, and not bodily sensation?
And can theSensation, the result of good action free from viéarka, is exclusively mental.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avitarkaṃ karma dhyānāntarāt prabhṛti yāvat bhavāgre /
column2: Actions of the sphere of dhḥyānāntara, the interval between the First and Second Dhyānas, and the actions of the higher stages are free from vitarka.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyāvitarkasya kuśalasya karmaṇaścaitasikyeva vedanā vipākaḥ / kasmānna kāyikī / tasyā avaśyaṃ savitarkavicāratvāt /
column2: Like bodily sensation, that is to say, associated with the five sense consciousnesses, which always embraces vitarka and vicāra, it cannot be the result of a retribution of an action free from vñarka.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyikyevāśubhasya tu // akuśalasya karmaṇaḥ kāyikyeva vedanā vipākaḥ / kasmānna caitasikī /
column2: Sensatioṉ, which is the result of a bad action, is exclusively physical.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya hi duḥkhā vedanā vipākaścaitasikī ca duḥkhā vedanā daurmanasyaṃ na ca daurmanasyaṃ vipāka iti vyākhyātametat / yattarhi sattvānāṃ cittakṣepo bhavati /
column2: A sensation, the result of retribution of a bad action, is painful; painful mental sensation is what is termed a sensation of dissatisfaction. We have established that dissatisfaction is never the result of retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katamasminnasau citte bhavati kena vā kāraṇena /
column2: But if dissatisfaction, or painful mental sensation, is not retribution, in which consciousness—visual consciousness, etc. , mental consciousnēss—is mental trouble or trouble-of-the-mind, which is painful.
Mental-trouble is produced in the mental consciousness.
The expression that the Kārikā uses, manascita, “mental thought,” is equivalent to the expression wanovijñāna, “mental consciousness, consciousness of the anas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi pañcasu vijñānakāyeṣu cittaṃ kṣipyate / avikalpakatvāt /
column2: ” The five sense consciousnesses cannot be troubled because they are free from imagining, inquiry and memory, and mental trouble is the imagining of that which does not exist.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa ca karmavipākajaḥ / sa caiṣa cittakṣepaḥ sattvānāṃ karmajaḥ /
column2: Mental trouble arises from the retribution of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye hi dravyamantraprayogeṇa vā pareṣāṃ cittaṃ kṣepayanti akāmakaṃ vā viṣaṃ madyaṃ
column2: The person who troubles and deranges the mind of another through curses and formulas; the person who causes another to drink poison or alcohol when he does not want to drink it;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vā pāyayanti trāsayanti vā mṛgayādiṣvagnim vā dāveṣutsṛjanti prapātādvā pātayantyanyena
column2: the person who frightens game, either in the hunt, or by setting the jungle on fire, or by the hollowing out of traps;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vā kenacitpareṣāṃ smṛtiṃ bhraṃśayanti teṣāṃ tasya karmaṇo vipākenāyatyāṃ cittaṃ kṣipyate / bhayopaghātavaiṣamyaśokaiśca kathaṃ tāvadbhayena /
column2: and the person who, by whatever means, troubles the memory and the presence of mind of another, will have his own mind troubled, deprived of the aid of his memory through the effect of the retribution of these actions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: amanuṣyādayo manuṣyānvirūpeṇa rūpeṇopasaṃkrāmanti / tebhyo bhītānāṃ cittaṃ kṣīpyate / kathamupaghātena /
column2: Demon beings with horrible features will approach such a person: seeing them, the person is frightened and his mind is troubled.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: amanuṣyā eva kupitā manuṣyāṇāṃ marmasu praharanti / kathaṃ mahābhūtavaiṣamyeṇa /
column2: Furious at the evil conduct of humans, demon beings will hit them in their vital parts.
The primary elements of the body will lose their equilibrium: the wind, heat and liquid will be irritated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā vāsiṣṭhīprabhṛtīnām / yadi mano vikṣipyate karmavipākajaśca cittakṣepaḥ / kathaṃ na caitasikī vedanā vipākaḥ prāpnoti /
column2: Fear also troubles the mind, for example in the case of Vāsiṣṭhī, etc. But, one would say, if mental trouble, or trouble of the mental consciousness, arises from the retribution of action, how can one say that this mental sensation is not retribution?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi brūmastadeva cittavipāka ityapi tu yo mahābhūtānāṃ prakopaḥ sa vipākaḥ /
column2: We do not say that trouble of the mind—a troubled mind—is retribution of action, but that it arises from the retribution of action. The primary elements in a state of disequilibrium are retribution: the troubled mind proceeds from it;
thus arises from retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: karmajena hi dhātunā vaiṣamyeṇa vyākulamavaśaṃ bhraṣṭasmṛtikaṃ cittaṃ vartata iti kṣiptamityucyate / evaṃ cedaṃ catuṣkoṭikaṃ yujyate /
column2: One says that the mind is troubled when, by reason of the disequilibrium or the. irritation of the humors which results from action. The mind is deranged, anarchic, devoid of mindfulness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti cittaṃ kṣiptaṃ na vikṣiptamiti vistaraḥ /
column2: Four alternatives: The mind troubled without being disturbed: the mind undefiled but troubled;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣiptaṃ tāvanna kṣiptaṃ vikṣiptacittasya / kliṣṭaṃ cittaṃ vikṣiptaṃ na kṣiptaṃ svasthacittasya kliṣṭam /
column2: the mind disordered without being troubled: the mind defiled, but tranquil;
the mind troubled and disordered.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katameṣāṃ punaḥ sattvānāṃ cittaṃ kṣipyate / akurukāminām //
column2: Among whom is trouble of the mind produced? Among beings in Kāmadhātu, with the exception of the Kuṟus.
Among the gods of Kāmadhātu, there are two madnesses;
all the more so is there madness among humans, Pretas, and animals.
Beings in hell always have troubled minds: their vital parts are incessantly hurt by thousands of different torments; they are crushed down by suffering;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te hi vividhayātanāsahasravyatibhinnamarmāṇastīrvābhirvedanābhirabhitunnā ātmānamapi tāvannābhicetayanti kiṃ punaḥ kāryamakāryaṃ vā /
column2: they do not recognize themselves, so they do not distinguish that which they should do and that which they should avoid.
We give as an example a being in hell who laments by saying, "Ah! The mind!

With the exception of the Buddha, the Āryans are not free from trouble of the mind: their thoughts can be troubled following the.
na karmaṇā niyatasya pūrvaṃ vipākādaniyatasyāvipākāt /	But their disequilibrium of the elements is never retribution for determinate" actions where retribution could produce trouble of the mind are retributed before they have obtained the Path, and "indeterminate" actions will not bear their results due to the fact that the Path is obtained.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na bhayena / pañcabhayasamatikramāt / nopaghātena / manuṣyaprakopakāraṇasyāprāsādikasyākaraṇāt / na śokena / dharmatābhijñatvāt /
column2: Neither terror, nor the attack of demon beings, nor fear can trouble the mind of the Āryaṇms, for they are above the five fears, they do no disobedient actions which excite the fury of demon beings, for they completely know the nature of things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punastrayo vaṅkā uktāḥ sūtre / kāyavaṅkok vāgvaṅko manovaṅkaḥ / trayo doṣāḥ / kāyadoṣo vāgdoṣo manodoṣaḥ /
column2: The Sūtra teaches that there are three crookednesses, crookedness of the body, speech, and mind;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trayaḥ kaṣāyāḥ / kāyakaṣāyo vākkaṣāyo manaḥ kaṣāyaḥ iti / tatra yathākramaṃ veditavyāḥ /
column2: and thus three corruptions and three stains.
What is termed crookedness, corruption, stains, is action arisen from hypocrisy, hatred, and attachment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śaṭhyajaṃ kāyakarma kāyavaṅka ityuktam / kuṭilānvayatvāt / evaṃ vāṅmanovaṅkau /
column2: Action of the body, speech, and mind which arises from hypocrisy, proceeds from crookedness, and is called crookedness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dveṣajaṃ kāyakarma kāyadoṣa ityuktam / cittapradoṣānvayatvāt / evaṃ vāṅmanodoṣau /
column2: action which arises from hatred, proceeds from hatred, and is called.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rāgajaṃ kāyakarma kāyakaṣāya ityuktam / rāñjanānvayatvāt / evaṃ vāṅmanaḥkaṣāyau /
column2: Action arises from attachment and proceeds from stain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṛṣṇaśuklādibhedena punaḥḥ karma caturvidham // “asti karma kṛṣṇaṃ kṛṣṇavipākam / asti karma śuklaṃ śuklavipākam / asti karma kṛṣṇaśuklaṃ kṛṣṇaśuklavipākam / asti karmākṛṣṇamaśuklamavipākam /
column2: Action is of four types: black, white, black-white, and neither black nor white.
The Sūtra teaches that action can destroy other actions.
Bad actions are black, good actions of Rūpa are white, and good actions of Kāma are black-white.
Action that destroys other actions is pure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aśubhaṃ karma ekāntena kṛṣṇaṃ kliṣṭatvāt kṛṣṇavipākaṃ cāmanojñavipākatvāt /
column2: Bad action is absolutely black and its retribution is painful.
Good action of the sphere of Rūpadhātu is absolutely white and its retribution is agreeable.
The qualification "white" applies only to action with two retributions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārupyāptaṃ kasmānnocyate / yatra kila dvividho 'sti vipāka āntarābhavika aupapattibhavikaśca /
column2: Now action of the sphere of Ārūpyadhātu does not present these characteristics.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trividhasya kāyavāṅmanaskarmaṇo yatraiva saṃbhavastatraivoktamiti / tadapi tūktaṃ sūtrāntare /
column2: But the Sūtra describes action of the sphere of Ārūpyadhātu as white and of white retribution.
Good action of the sphere of Kāmadhātu, being mixed with the bad, is black-white; its retribution is mixed, so it is thus black-white.
This definition is to be understood as applying, not to the nature of the action itself, but to the “series” or the person; in one and the same mental series, good action is mixed with bad action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hyevañjātīyakamekaṃ karmāsti vipāko vā yat kṛṣṇaṃ ca syāt śuklaṃ cānyonyavirodhāt /
column2: There is no action which is black-white, nor any retribution which is black-white, which would be a contradiction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu caivamakuśalasyāpi karmaṇaḥ kuśalavyavakīrṇatvāt kṛṣṇaśuklatvaṃ prāpnoti /
column2: Objection: But bad action is also mixed with white action, hence bad action should be defined as black-white.
Bad action is not necessarily mixed with good action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātau tasya balavattvāt / kukśalaṃ tu vyavakīryate / durbalatvāditi /
column2: whereas, in Kāmadhātu, good action is necessarily mixed with bad, because, in this sphere, the bad is stronger than the good.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anasravaṃ karmaiṣāṃ trayāṇāṃ karmaṇāṃ kṣayāya prahāṇāya saṃvartate /
column2: Pure action destroys the other three types of action. Not being. It is not black;
not being retribution, it is not white.
It is “non-white”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ tu bhagavatā mahatyāṃ śunyatāyā maśaikṣān dharmānārabhya “ime te ānanda dharmā ekāntakuśalā ekāntānavadyā” iti /
column2: This expression of the Sūtra, «fwkla, is “intentional:” the Blessed One wishes to oppose pure action to white action; but, speaking in the Mahāśūnyatāsūśra of the dharmas proper to the Arhat, he expresses himself thus, “The dbarmas of the Arhat, Oh Ānanda, are absolutely white, absolutely good, absolutely irreprochable.”
And one reads in the Treatise, “What are the white dharmas?
The good dharmas and the neutral dharmas?” Pure action does not have any retribution, for it is not of the domain of the spheres of existence;
in fact, it arrests the process of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ sarvamanāsravaṃ karma sarvasyāsya trividhasya karmaṇaḥ kṣayāya saṃvartate / netyucyate / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: Does any pure action destroy all the actions of the first three categories, black, white, or black-white?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dharmakṣāntiṣu vairāgye cānantaryapathāṣṭake / yā cetanā dvādaśadhā karma kṛṣṇakṣayāya tat //
column2: A volition may be of twelve types, namely the volition of the dharmakṣāṇtis and of the first eight paths of abandoning in the detachment of Kāmadhātu: such is the action which destroys black action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanamārge catasṛṣu dharmajñānakṣāntiṣu kāmavairāgye cāṣṭāsvānantaryamārgeṣu yā cetanā seyaṃ dvādaśavidhā cetanā kṛṣṇasya karmaṇaḥ prahāṇāya karma /
column2: Four volitions correspond to the four dharmakṣāntis of the Path ofSeeing the Truths; all pure actions which destroy bad actions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: navame cetanā yā sā kṛṣṇaśuklakṣayāya ca /
column2: The volition of the ninth is the action which destroys black-white action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: navame kāmavairāgyānantaryamārge yā cetanā sā kṛṣṇaśuklasya kuśalasya karmaṇaḥ kṛṣṇasya cākuśalasya navamasya prakārasya prahāṇāya /
column2: The volition which corresponds to the ninth path of abandoning in the detachment of Kāmadhātu is the pure action which causes the abandoning of black-white action and black action, for at this moment one abandons, in its entirety, good action of Kāmadhātu and the ninth and last category of bad action.
Volition which arises in the last paths of abandoning of the detachment of the dhyānas destroys good action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānādvyānādvairāgyaṃ kurvato yo 'ntyo navama ānantaryamārgastatra yā cetanā iyaṃ caturvidhā cetanā śuklasya karmaṇaḥ prahāṇāya /
column2: The volition of the ninth and last path of abandoning which produces detachment of Kāmadhātu with regard to each dhyāna is fourfold volition which destroys white action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇamantyenaivānantaryamārgeṇa kuśalasya karmaṇaḥ prahāṇaṃ nānyena /
column2: Objection: The first eight paths of abandoning in the detachment of Kāmadhātu destroy black action.
But you attribute the power to destroy. White-black and white action solely to the ninth path of abandoning.
Why is this? There is not, properly speaking, abandonment of any good dharmas, for even if they are abandoned, the good dharmas can reappear;
but when the defilement which has this dharma for its object is destroyed this dharma is said to be abandoned.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato yāvadeko 'pi tadālambanakleśaprakāra āste tāvadasya prahāṇaṃ nopapadyate /
column2: Therefore as long as the last category of defilement which can grasp it as its object is not destroyed, this good dharma is not considered abandoned. Now it is the ninth path of abandoning which breaks the prāpti of the ninth category of defilement relative to each sphere and, as a consequence, allows one to obtain disconnection from this defilement.
According to others, the first two actions are retributed in hell and retributed moreover in Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye punarācāryāḥ paśyanti narakavedanīyaṃ narakāccānyakāmadhātuvedanīyaṃ karma yathākrama kṛṣṇaṃ kṛṣṇaśuklaṃ ceti /
column2: According to other masters action which should be experienced in hell is black action; action which should be experienced elsewhere in Kāmadhātu, in addition to hell, is blackwhite action. Infernal retribution is produced exclusively through bad.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: narake hyakuśalasyaiva karmaṇo vipākastena tadvedanīyaṃ kṛṣṇamityucyate ato 'nya kāmadhātau kuśalākuśalasya karmaṇo vipākastena tadvedanīyaṃ kṛṣṇaśuklamityuktam /
column2: As a consequence, action which should be experienced in hell is black action. Retribution in Kāmadhātu, with the exception of hell, is exclusively produced by good-bad action (that is, by good action mixed with bad action). According to others, arisen in Kāma, actions are black when they can be abandoned through Seeing the Truths;
they are black-white in the contrary case.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye punarāhurdarśanaprahātavyaṃ karma kṛṣṇa kuśalenāmiśratvāt / anyatkṛṣṇaśuklaṃ tu kāmajam //
column2: According to other masters action which is abandoned through Seeing the Truths, not being mixed with the good, is black.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyattu kāmāvacaraṃ karma kṛṣṇaśuklam / kiṃ tadanyat / bhāvanāprahātavyam / taddhi kuśalaṃ cākuśalaṃ ceti /
column2: AIl other actions of Kāmadhātu, namely action which is abandoned through Meditation, is black-white, that is, good mixed with bad.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra uktaṃ trīṇi mauneyāni kāyamauneyaṃ vāṅmauneyaṃ manomauneyaṃ ca / tatra
column2: ‘The Sūtra says, “There are three silences, silence of the body, voice, and of the mind.”
Afaikṣa, that is, an Arhat's, actions of the body, voice and mind, are, in this order, the three silences.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aśaikṣe kāyavākkarmaṇī kāyavāṅmauneye / aśaikṣaṃ tu mana eva manomauneyaṃ na manaskarmeti / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: Silence of the body and silence of the voice is bodily and vocal action which belongs to the Arhat.
Silence of the mind is the mind orBecause the mind is the true Silent One, the true Muni.
The Vahāṣikas say that one knows through inference by reason of the actions of the body and voice that the mind is afaikṣa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: api khalu kāyavākkarmaṇī viratisvabhāvena na manaskarma / cittā vijñaptyabhāvāt /
column2: But an Arhat's bodily and vocal action is, in its nature, abstention, whereas the action of the mind is not, by nature, abstention, because there is no avjñapti of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: viramārthena ca maunam / ato mana eva virataṃ maunamityucyate /
column2: But "silence" is abstention, thus the mind itself "which abstains" receives the name of silence.
Why does only the mind of the Arhat receive this name?
Because the Arhat is the true Silent One through the cessation of all murmuring of his defilements.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trīṇi śauceyāni uktāni sūtre / kāyaśauceyaṃ vākśauceyaṃ manaḥsauceyaṃ ca / tadetat /
column2: The Sūtra says, "There are three purifications, purification of the body, purification of the voice, and purification of the mind.
The threefold good practice in its entirety is the threefold purification.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvaṃ kāyasucaritaṃ kāyaśaucam / sarvaṃ vāṅmanaḥ sucaritaṃ vāṅmanaḥ śaucam / duścaritamalāpakarṣaṇāttāvatkālamatyantaṃ vā /
column2: All the good practices of the body, pure or impure, are a purification of the body, because, either for a time or in a definitive manner, they.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣā ca deśanā mithyāmauna śaucādhimuktikānāṃ vivecānārtham /
column2: efface the impurity of the defilements and bad practices. The same holds for the voice and mind. This teaching has for its goal the instruction of persons who take a false silence for silence, and a false purification of purification.
The Sūtra says that there are three bad practices.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra aśubhaṃ kāyakarmādi mataṃ duścarita trayam /
column2: The bad actions of the body, speech and mind are regarded as being the three bad practices.
Bad actions of the body are the bad practices of the body and so on.
Even though greed, wickedness, anger and false views are not actions, they constitute a threefold bad practice of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akarmasvabhāvamapyasti trividhaṃ manoduścaritaṃ cetanārthāntarabhūtamabhidhyā vyāpādo mithyādṛṣṭiśca /
column2: Further, there are three bad practices of the mind which, by their nature, are not mental action: greed, wickedness or harm, and false views.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhidhyādaya eva manaskarmeti dārṣṭāntikāḥ / saṃcetanīyasūtre vacanāt /
column2: The Dārṣṭāntikas say that greed, wickedness and false views are, in fact, mental actions, for the Saṁcetanāyasñra considers them as actions.
The Vaibhāṣīkas: In this hypothesis, defilements and actions would be the same thing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kim syādyadi kaścit kleśo 'pi karma syāt / naitadasti /
column2: The Dārṣṭāntikas: What harm do you see in that?
To admit that defilement is action is to contradict the Sūtra and the definition that it gives of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtre tu cetanāyāstanmukhena pravṛttestaistāṃ darśayatīti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: As for the Saṁcetanāyasra to which you allude, it is volition itself that it designates when it says “greed,” because volition comes into play under the influence of greed.
Because these produce a painful retribution, and because they are condemned by good persons, these practices of the body, speech and mind are bad; they are thus termed bad practices.
Good practice is the opposite.
The opposite of bad practice is good practice: good actions of the body, speech, and mind; further, non-greed, non-wickedness and right views.
How can false views or right views by regarded as bad, or good? In fact, the first does not contain an intention to do evil, and the second does not contain an intention to do good to another.
This is true, but they are the root of this twofold intention.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadaudārikasaṃgrahāt / daśa karmapathā uktā yathāyogaṃ śubhāśubhāḥ //
column2: By taking, among these practices, the most evident, one defines the ten coutses of action, good and bad respectively.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāmeva sucaritaduścaritānāṃ caudārikasaṃgraheṇa daśa karmapathāḥ sūtra uktāḥ yathāyogaṃ kuśalāḥ sucaritebhyo 'kuśalā duścaritebhyaḥ /
column2: The Sñtra defines ten courses of action: good courses of action, by taking the most important, which are the easiest to see from among the good practices; and bad courses of action, by taking the gravest from among the bad practices.
What practices, bad or good, are not included in the courses of action?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akukśaleṣu tatkarmapathesu kāyaduścaritasya pradeśo na saṃgṛhītaḥ prayogapṛṣṭhabhūtaḥ kliṣṭaścānyo 'pi bandhānādiḥ / tasya nātyaudārikatvāt /
column2: A part of the bad practices of the body, namely preparatory and consecutive actions of bodily courses of action; and certain defiled actions of the body, for example, drinking alcohol, hitting, binding, etc. , are not included among the courses of action, because these practices are not extremely grave.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaddhi kāyaduścaritaṃ pareṣāṃ jīvitabhogadārebhyaścyāvakaṃ tatkarmapatha uktaṃ tato vivecanārtham /
column2: Among the bad practices of the body are courses of action which deprive another of his life, of his goods, or of his wife: one must absolutely abstain from them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vāgduścaritamapi yadeva praśādaṃ tatkarmapatha uktaṃ tadarthameva /
column2: That which is very grave among bad practices of speech is, for this same reason, declared to be a course of action, not preparatory, consecutive, or minor action.
One part of the bad practice of the mind, volition, is also excluded.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśaleṣvapi kāyasucaritasya pradeśaḥ prayogapṛṣṭhamadyādiviratidānejyādiko vāksucaritasya priyavacanādiko manaḥ sucaritasya cetanā /
column2: The good courses of action do not include either a part of the good practice of the body: preparatory or consecutive; abstention from inebriating drinks, etc. ; alms, worship, etc. or one part of the good practice of speech, affectionate words, etc. or one part of the good practice of the mind, good volition.
Among the courses of action, six bad courses of action can be exclusively gviñapti.
When one has six courses of action—murder, stealing, lying, maliçious speech, harmful speech, or inconsiderate speech—performed by another, then these six courses of action are only avsjñap²ái.
He who had these actions carried out is lacking the principle vijñapti, that is, the act of killing itseif, etc. One bad course of action is always of two types.
Adultery is always viyñapti and vijñapti, for it must be perpetrated in person.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi taṃ pareṇa kārayatastādṛśī prītirbhavatīti / te 'pi kurvataḥ /
column2: When one has it committed by another, he does not procure the same pleasure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te 'pi ṣaṭ karmapathāḥ svayaṃ kurvato dvividhā bhavanti vijñaptiravijñaptiśca tatkālamaraṇe paścāt maraṇe tvavijñaptireva /
column2: Six, when one caṟries them out himself, are of two types. When one executes them himself, the six courses of action specified above are atone and the same time véñaptá andavjñapt; if death takes place at the same moment as the vjñapti (that is, at the moment of the stroke by which one intends to kill); if death takes place later, there is only gvijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalānāṃ punaḥ karmapathānāṃ dvividhāḥ sapta kuśalāḥ
column2: Among the good courses of action, Seven good courses of action are of two types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalāḥ sapta rūpiṇaḥ karmapathā avaśyaṃ dviprakārā vijñaptiravijñaptiśca /
column2: Seven courses of material actions, that is, of the body and the voice, are of two types, viñapá and avijñapti.
In fact, the morality that one undertakes depends on one vrjñapti.
They are only zvrñapti when they have arisen from absorption.
The courses of action which are included in āharmasia, that is, in the discipline of dhyāna and in the pure discipline, are qualified as “arisen from absorption.

” These two disciplines depend on a single thought: the courses of action are thus not vsjñapti. Is this also the case for preparatory and consecutive actions as for the principle action or the course of action proper? The sāmantakas or preliminary actions are actions which prepare for the courses of action of the sphere of Kāmadhātu.
They are always viñapti.
They may or may not be avijñapti.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tīvreṇa paryavasthānena pramādena vā ghanarasena prayogamārabheta syādavijñaptiranyathā na syāt /
column2: When they are accomplished with a great violence of passion, or with an extreme strength of faith, they are avijñapti. If not, then no.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: viparyayeṇa pṛṣṭhāni sāmantakebhyo viparyayeṇa karmapathānāṃ pṛṣṭhāni veditavyāti / tāni avaśyamavijñaptisvabhāvāni / vijñaptistu bhavenna vā /
column2: The opposite concerning consecutive action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi karmapathaṃ kṛṭvā punastasyānudharmaṃ ceṣṭeta tasya syāt vijñaptiranyathā na syāt /
column2: Consecutive actions are, on the contrary, necessarily viñapti: They are viñapti when having accomplished a course of action, one continues to commit actions analogous to the course of action.
What is it that constitutes preparatory action, the course of action proper, and consecutive action?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā tāvadiha kaścit paśuṃ hantukāmo mañcakāduttiṣṭhati mūlyaṃ gṛhlāti gacchatyāmṛśati paśuṃ krīṇātyānayati puṣṇāti praveśayati nihantuṃ śāstramādatte prahāramekaṃ dadāti dvau vā yāvanna jīvitā dvacyaparopayati tāvat prayogaḥ /
column2: A man, desiring to kill an animal, rises from his bed, takes some silver, goes to the market, feels the animal, buys the animal, leads it, pulls it, makes it enter, mistreats it, takes a sword, strikes the head once or twice: as long as he does not kill it, the action preparatory to killing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yena tu prahāreṇa jīvitādvyaparopayati tatra yā vijñaptistatkṣaṇikā vā 'vijñaptirayaṃ maulaḥ karmapathaḥ /
column2: The vġñapts of the moment of killing an animal and the simultaneous aviñapti are the proper course of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvābhyāṃ hi kāraṇābhyāṃ prāṇātipātāvadyena spṛśyate prayogataḥ mṛte sati phalaparipūritaśca / tata ūrdhvamavijñaptikṣaṇāḥ pṛṣṭhaṃ bhavanti /
column2: One is touched by the transgression of murder due to the preparatory action and the achievement of the result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvacca taṃ paśuṃ kuṣṇāti śodhayati vikrīṇīte pacati khādayatyanukīrtayati vā tāvadasya vijñaptikṣaṇā api pṛṣṭhaṃ bhavanti /
column2: The moments following the killing, such as pulling the hide off the animal, washing it, weighing it, selling it, cooking it, eating it, and congratulating oneself on it, are consecutive action.
The series of moments of viñapti also constitute consecutive action. The other six courses of bodily and vocal action can be explained in the same way with necessary changes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhidhyādīnāṃ nāsti prayogo na pṛṣṭhaṃ saṃmukhībhāvamātrātkarmapathaḥ /
column2: There is no reason to distinguish preparatory and consecutive action for greed, wickedness, and false views. By the sole fact of their presence, they are courses.
A question is raised.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tāvat maraṇabhavasthe tasmin prāṇini ye vijñaptyavijñaptī te karmapatha āhosvinmṛte /
column2: Is the course of action made up of vijñaptś aṇd avijñaptś at the moment when the animal is in varapabhava, that is,at the moment when the animal dies?
Or is the vjñapti and the avjjñapti of the moment when the animal is in r¢tabhava, that is, when it is dead?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tāvanmaraṇabhavasthe sahamṛṭasyāpio anturghātayiturvā prāṇātipātāvadyena yogaḥ prāpnoti / na ceṣa siddhāntaḥ / atha mṛte /
column2: If you accept the first hypothesis, a person would be guilty of the transgression of killing when he kills at the very moment when the killed animal dies: but your system does not admit this.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaduktaṃ “yena tu prahāreṇa jīvitādvacyaparopayati tatra yā vijñaptistatkṣaṇikā vā 'vijñaptirayaṃ maulaḥ karmapatha” iti tanā vaktavyam /
column2: And in the second hypothesis, you have rightly said that, “at the stroke by which he deprives the animal of its life, the viñapti of this moment and the svġjñapti simultaneous to this vifñapti, are the course of action proper. ” Further, if you accept the second hypothesis, you contradict the explanation that the Vaibhāṣikas give to the phrase,"while the prayoga has not yet disappeared,” that one reads in the Mṁlasfāstra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaccāpīdaṃ śāstra uktaṃ “syāt prāṇī hataḥ prāṇātipātaścāniruddhaḥ /
column2: This Śāstra says, “Can it be the case that aYes, when the living being has already been deprived of life, but when the prayoga has not yet disappeared.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syādyathā hi tatprāṇī jīvitādvyaparopito bhavati prayogaścāpratiprasragdha” ityatra pṛṣṭhaṃ prayogaśabdenoktamiti vaibhāṣikīyo 'rthavirodho maulasyaiva tadānīmaniruddhatvāt /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas explain this text by saying that the word prayoga here has the meaning of consecutive action. Now you contradict this explanation since, placing the course of principle action at the moment when the animal dies, it is indeed the course of principal action which, according to you, has not disappeared at the moment when the animal dies. You interpret the word prayoga of the Śāstra in the sense of the principal action.
The Vaibhāsikas: One must explain the Śāstra insucha manner that it does not lend itself to criticism.
And how is that?
In the text in question, prayoga signifies principal course of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vijñaptistarhi tadā kathaṃ maulaḥ karmapatho bhavati /
column2: But how could the vñaptá of the moment when the animal is already dead be the principal course of action?
The Vaibhāṣikas: Why would it not be?
Because it is ineffective. The animal is dead: one does not cause it to die again.
The Vaibhāṣikas: But how is avsṝñaptá, which is always ineffecive, a course of action? It is not their efficacy which makes a vjñaptś and an avijñaptá couṟses of action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt prayogaphalaparipūrikāle tadubhayaṃ karmapathaḥ syāt karmatpatho 'pyanyasya prayogaḥ pṛṣṭhaṃ ca bhavati /
column2: it is the fact that they are produced at the moment of the achievement of the result of the preparatory action. Can it be the case that one course of action is either a preparatory action or a consecutive action of another couṟse of action? Yes.
For example the ten courses of action can be a preparatory action for murder.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca śatrorvadhārthaṃ kṛtyaṃ samupasthāpayan paśunā valiṃ kuryāt parakīyaṃ kṛtvā dāreṣu cāsya vipratipadyeta taireva tadghātanārtham anṛtapiśunaparuṣasāntavaiścāsya
column2: A man desires to kill his enemy; in order to assure the success of this enterprise, he takes the goods of another and offers an animal in sacrifice; as a means to this same end, he committs adultery with the wife of his enemy in order to make her an accomplice;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mitrabhedaṃ kuryādyānyasya paritrāṇāya kalperan abhidhyāṃ ca tatsva kuryāttatraiva
column2: throughhe causes a falling out between his enemy and his friends who would be able to defend him; he covets the goods of his enemy; he wishes to do evil to his enemy;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ca vyāpādaṃ tadvadhārthaṃ ca mithyādṛṣṭiṃ vṛṃhayediti /
column2: he nourishes false views with regard to the murder that he wants to commit.
In this same way the ten courses of action can be the consecutive action of murder.
And the same for the other courses of action, stealing, etc. But, greed, wickedness and false views are never preparatory actions, for they are not the beginning of an action;
nor are they preparatory actions, for they are solely a production of the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra uktaṃ “prāṇātipāto bhikṣavastrividho lobhajo dveṣajo mohajo yāvanmithyādṛṣṭi“riti /
column2: The Sutra says, "There are, Oh Bhikshus, three types of killing: killing arisen from desire, killing arisen from hatred, and killing arisen from ignorance," and thus following to, "There are, Oh Bhikshus, three types of false views.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra kīdṛśaḥ prāṇātipāto lobhaja ityevamādi vaktavyam /
column2: What are these different killings, etc. ?
All the courses of action are not indifferently achieved by desire, hatred, or ignorance;
butThe preparatory action of all of the courses of action can indifferently arise from the three roots.

The BlessedOne, by expressing himself as we have seen, refers to the first cause, the cause which gives rise to the course of action. Killing arisen from desire: killing in order to seize a certain part of an animal; killing in order to seize some goods; killing for pleasure;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra lobhajapraṇātipāto yathā taccharīrāvayavārthamarthārthaṃ krītārthaṃ ca prāṇinaṃ jīvitādvyaparopayati ātmasuhṛtparitrāṇāya /
column2: killing in order to defend oneself, or one’s friends.
Killing arisen from hatred, in order to satiate hostility. Killing arisen through ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mohajo yathā yājñikānāṃ dharmabuddhyā rājñāṃ ca dharmapāṭhakaprāmāṇyāddhiṃsatām / duṣṭānāṃ kila nigrahaṃ kurvanto rājānaḥ puṇyabhājo bhavantīti /
column2: To consider the sacrifice as a pious action and so to kill, when a king, according to the authority of the legalists kills through duty, “The first of the meritorious actions of the king is to punish evil-doets”;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pārasīkānāṃ ca / te hyevamāhuḥ / “mātāpitarau jīrṇau vā glānau vā hantavyā“viti /
column2: when the Persians say, “One should kill one’s aged and sick parents”;
when one says, “One should kill serpents, scorpions, and ryambuka flies , etc. , because these creatures are poisonous; one must kill game, cattle. Birds and buffalos in order to nourish oneself.
And finally killing which is provoked by false views: murder committed by a person who denies a future life and whom nothing can stop. Stealing arisen from desire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: lobhajamadattādānaṃ yo yenārthi sa tadvarati anyalābhasatkārayaśo 'rthaṃ vā ātmasukṛtaparitrāṇāya vā /
column2: Either one steals the object desired, or one steals in order to then gain possession of another object, to acquire honor and respect, or in order to defend oneself and one's friends.
Stealing arisen from hatred, in order to satiate hostility. Stealing arisen from ignorance.
A king, upon the authority of the legalists, seizes the goods of evil-doers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duṣṭanigrahārthaṃ yathā brāhmaṇā āhuḥ “sarvamidaṃ brahmaṇā brāhmaṇebhyo dattaṃ brāhmaṇānāṃ daurbalyādvṛṣlāḥ paribhuñjate /
column2: The Brāhmins say, "All things have been given to the Brāhmins by Brahmā; and it is through the weakness of the Brāhmins that the Vrṣalas enjoy it. Consequently, when a Brāhmin steals, he takes that which belongs to him;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādapaharan brāhmaṇaḥ sumādatte svameva brāhmaṇo bhuṅkte svaṃ vaste svaṃ dadāti ce” ti / na caiśāmaparasvasaṃjñā bhavati /
column2: he eats what is his, wears what is his, and gives what is his. " And yet, when Brāhmins take, they indeed have the notion of the goods of another.
Stealing provoked through false views is also stealing from ignorance.

Illicit sexuality arises from desire, such as sexual intercourse with the wife of another, either through love, or in order to obtain honor and respect, or in order to defend oneself and one’s friends.
Illicit sexuality can also arise through hatred, in order to satiate hostility. Illicit sexuality can also arise from ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mohajo yathā pārasīkānāṃ mātrādigamanaṃ gosave ca yajñe / yothoktaṃ “brāhmaṇo gosaveneṣṭyā saṃvatsaragovratī bhavati /
column2: The Persians, etc. , have intercourse with their mothers and other forbidden women.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upahā udakaṃ cūṣati tṛṇāni cchinatti upaiti mātaramupasvasāramupa sagotrā“miti /
column2: In the gosava sacrifice, a Brāhmin drinks water in the manner of an animal, grazes through the grass, has intercourse with his mother, his sister, or a woman of his go$ra; he must copulate with them wherever he finds them: in this manner this bull will triumph over the world.
And such too are those that say, “Women are like rice mortars, flowers, fruits, cooked food, ladders, roads, and ferryboats: they are there to be used.
” Lying and other vocal transgressions can arise from ignorance and from hatred, as above.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mohajo mṛṣāvādo yathāha / “na narmayuktamanṛtaṃ hi nāsti
column2: Lying can also arise from ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na strīṣu rājanna vivāhakāle / prāṇātyaye sarvadhanāpahāre pañcānṛtānyāhurapātakānī“ti /
column2: “Oh King, playful lying, lying to women, in marriage, or in danger of death, does not hurt: one says that.
”This is lying provoked by false views.
Malicious words and other vocal transgressions arisen from ignorance. These are provoked through false views.
Further, the false discourses of the Vedus, etc. ,are frivolous words arisen from ignorance.
How do greed, wickedness and false views arise out of desire, etc. ? Since they are not preparatory action, this creates a difficulty:
Greed and the other two mental courses arise from the three roots because they appear subsequent to these roots.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: lobhādanantaramutpannā lobhajāḥ dveṣādanantaraṃ dveṣajā mohādanantaraṃ mohajāḥ /
column2: When they appear immediately after desire, they arise from desire; We have explained the bad courses of action in their relationship with the roots.
As for the good courses of action,
Good actions, with their preparatory and consecutive actions, arise from non-desire, non-hatred, and non-ignorance.
Good courses of action, with their preparatory and consecutive actions, have a good mind for their originating cause.
This good mind, being necessarily associated with the three roots, arises. The renouncing of a preparation of a bad course of action is a preparation of a good course of action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya ca avaśya malobhādibhiḥ saṃprayogāt tatrākuśala karmapathaprayogādviratiḥ kuśalakarmapathaprayogaḥ / maulādviratiḥ maulaḥ /
column2: the renouncing of the action proper which constitutes a bad coarse of action is itself a good course of action;
the renouncing of a consecative action of a bad course of action is a consecutive action of a good course of action. Let us give as an example: the ordination of a novice.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā śrāmaṇera upasaṃpādyamāno nānāvāsaṃ praviśati bhikṣūnvandate upādhyāyaṃ yācate yāvadekaṃ karmavācanaṃ kriyate dvitīyaṃ ca / ayaṃ prayogaḥ /
column2: From the moment when the novice enters into the nānāvasa, salutes the Saṅgha, addresses his request to the Upādhyāya, uṇntil the first or second karmavācana, this is the preparatory actior.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tṛtīya karmavācane yā vijñaptistatkṣaṇikā cāvijñaptirayaṃ maulaḥ karmapathaḥ /
column2: At the achievement of the third armavācana there takes place a viṝñapti, and an avijñapti simultaneous to this véēupti, which constitute the course of action itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tata ūrdhvaṃ yāvanniśrayā ārocyante tadadhiṣṭhānaṃ ca vijñapayati avijñaptica yāvadatuvartate idaṃ pṛṣṭham /
column2: After this moment, when one notifies the new monk of the nifrayas, when he makes known that he accepts them, aṇd as long as the series of the gvijñapri cteatedby the principalaction continues—that is to say, as long as the monk does not lose the Pṛātimokṣa discipline.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaduktaṃ “na sarveṣāṃ karmapathānāṃ lobhādibhirniṣṭhe“tyatha kasya kena niṣṭhā /
column2: We have seen that bad courses of action were not indifferently “achieved” by the three roots.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vadhavyāpādapāruṣyaniṣṭhā dveṣeṇa eṣāṃ prāṇātipātavyāpādapāruṣpāṇāṃ dveṣeṇa samāptiḥ / parityāgaparuṣacittasaṃmukhī bhāvāt /
column2: Killing, wickedness, and injurious words are achieved through hate.
Solely by hate. They are achieved when one thought of murder, or one thought of violence manifests itself.
Adultery, greed, and stealing are achieved through desire. “Adultery” is illicit sexuality.
False views, through ignorance.
Through an extreme ignorance.
The others, by the three.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mṛṣāvādapaiśunyasaṃbhinnapralāpāḥ / eṣāṃ tribhirapi niṣṭhā lobhena dveṣeṇa mohena vā
column2: The other courses of action, lying, malicious words, and inconsiderate words, are achieved either through desire, hatred, or ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya ete karmapathāścaturbhiḥ kāṇḍairuktāstrayastraya ekastrayaśca eṣāṃ yathākramaṃ sattvabhogāvadhiṣṭhānaṃ nāmarūpaṃ ca nāma ca //
column2: The courses of action, which have just been divided into four sections, three, three, one and three, have respectively for their object: living beings, objects of enjoyment, nāmaripa, and ṉāmam.
Living beings are the objects of killing, wickedness and injurious speech;
the objects of enjoyment are the objects of adultery, greed and stealing;
nāmarūpa, that is, the five skandhas, atre the object of false.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ paraṃ maraṇānniyamayya samaṃ tena pūrvaṃ vā mriyate kimasya maulaḥ karmapatho bhavatyutāho na /
column2: When one has decided to kill someone, and if the murderer dies either before the intended victim, or if he dies at precisely the same moment as the victim, is there a principal course of action for the author of the murder?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samaṃ prāk ca mṛtasyāsti na maulaḥ
column2: If one dies before or at the same time, there is no principal course of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evocyate “syāt prayogaṃ kuryāt phalaṃ ca paripūrayenna ca prāṇātipātāvadyena spṛśyate /
column2: 'This is why the Vbhāṣā says, “Question: When a person has made the preparation for killing, can it be that, at the moment when the result of this preparation is achieved, this person is not touched by the transgression of killing?
Answer: Yes, when the murderer dies before or at the same time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syāt yathāpi tadvyaparopavaḥ pūrvaṃ saha vā kālaṃ kuryā“diti kiṃ punastatkāraṇam nahi vadhye jīvati hantuḥ prāṇātipātāvadyenāsti yogo nāpi sahamṛtasya hantuḥ /
column2: ” The reason is clear: as long as the victim is living, the murderer is not touched by the transgression of murder; and when the victim dies, he no longer exists if he died at the same time or before.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyāśrayodayāt / thenāśrayeṇa tatprayogaḥ kṛtaḥ sa ucchinno 'nya evāśrayo nikāyasabhāgabhinna utpannaḥ / tasya prayoktṛtvāt karmapathena yogo na yuktaḥ /
column2: Because a new body has come into existence. The body—the personality—by whom the preparation had been.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatsenāpātamṛgayāvaskandheṣu pareṣāṃ vadhārthaṃ bahavaḥ samagrāḥ patantyekaśca prāṇātipātaṃ karoti kastena samanvāgato bhavati /
column2: When many persons are united with the intention to kill, either in war, or in the hunt, or in banditry, who is guilty of murder, if only one of them kills?
As soldiers, etc. , concur in the realization of the same effect, all are as guilty as the one who kills.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathaiva hi karttā tathā sarve samanvāgatā bhavantyekakāryatvāt / arthato hi te 'yonyaṃ payoktāro bhavanti /
column2: Having a common goal, all are guilty exactly as he who among them kills, for all mutually incite one another, not through speech, but by the very fact that they are united together in order to kill. But is the person who has been constrained through force to join the army also guilty?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastarhi balānnīyate so'pi samanvāgato bhavatyanyatra ya evaṃ naścitya yāyāt yāvajjīvitahetorapi prāṇinaṃ na haniṣyāmīti /
column2: Evidently so, unless he has formed the resolution, "Even in order to save my life, I shall not kill a living being.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiyatā punaḥ prāṇātipātaṃ svayaṃ kurvataḥ karmapatho bhavati kiyatā yāvanmithyādṛṣṭiḥ karmapathaḥ iti lakṣaṇaṃ vaktavyaṃ taducyate /
column2:
What does he do in order that he who kills should commit the course of action? Same question for the other transgressions up to and.
prāṇātipātaḥ saṃcintya parasyābhrāntimāraṇam /	Murder is to kill another, consciously, without making an error.
yadi mārayiṣyāmyenamiti saṃjñāya paraṃ mārayati tameva ca mārayati nānyaṃ bhramitvā / iyatā prāṇātipāto bhavati /	When a person kills by thinking, “I am killing such a one,” and kills this same person, and not another through error, then there is murder.
yastarhi saṃdigdho mārayati kimayaṃ prāṇī na prāṇīti sa evānyo veti so 'pyavaśyametaṃ niścayaṃ labdhvā tatra praharati /	But is there murder when a person kills, doubting if he hits a living being or a thing, or if he hits another? This person possesses the certitude, “This is certainly him”; he hits him;
yo 'stu so 'stviti kṛtamevānena tyāgacittaṃ bhavati /	and as a consequence, there is the thought of parityāga.
kathaṃ kṣaṇikeṣu skandheṣu prāṇātipāto bhavati /	How can there be murder, or destruction of the prāṇa, since the skandhas are momentary?
prāṇo nāma vāyuḥ kāyacittasaṃniśrito vartate / tamabhipātayati /	Prāna, the “vital breath”, is a wind whose existence depends on the body and the mind.
yathā pradīpaṃ nirodhayati ghaṇṭāsvanaṃ vā /	This prṇa is annihilated by a murderer in the same way in which one annihilates a flame or a sound of a bell, that is to say, by obstructing the continuation of its reproducing itself.
jīvitendriyaṃ vā prāṇāstannirodhayati / yadyekasyāpi jīvitakṣaṇasyotpadyamānasyāntarāyaṃ karoti prāṇātipātāvadyena spṛśyate nānyathā / kasya tajjīvitaṃ yastadabhāvānmṛto bhavati /	Or rather, prūṉa is the vital organ: when a person creates an obstacle to the arising of a new moment of the vital organ, he annihilates it, and is touched by the transgression of killing.
kasyeti ṣaṣṭhīṃ pudgalavāde vicārayiṣyāmaḥ /	The true value of the pronoun “to whom” or “of whom” will be examined in the chapter on the Refutation of the Pudgala Chapter ĪX.
uktaṃ tu bhagavatā “āyuruṣmā 'tha vijñānaṃ yadā kāyaṃ jahatyamī / apaviddhastadā śete yathā kāṣṭhamacetana” // iti /	Let us observe that the Blessed One said, “When life, heat and consciousness leave the body, it lies abandoned, like a piece of wood, deprived of feeling One says that the body lives when it is endowed with the organs;
tasmātsendriyaḥ kāyo jīvatītyucyate anindriyo mṛta iti /	and that the body is dead when it is devoid of them.
abuddhipūrvādapi prāṇivadhāt karturadharmo yathā 'gnisaṃyogāddāha iti nirgranthāḥ /	According to the Nirgranthas, transgression results for the doer from killing, even committed without knowing it, or without desiring it, in the way that contact with fire results in burning.
teṣāṃ paradāradarśane 'pyeṣa prasaṅgaḥ /	But if this is the case, then one is guilty when one sees, or touches, without wanting to, the wife of another; he who trims the hair of the Nigranthas is guilty;
nirgranthaśiroluñcane ca kaṣṭatapodeśane ca śāstuḥ tadvisūcikāmaraṇe ca dāturvaidyānāṃ cāturapīḍane maraṇe ca mātṛgabhasthayoścānyonyaṃ duḥkhanimittatvāt	the master of the Nirgranthas is guilty since he preaches terrible austerities; he who gives the Nirgranthas food which provokes cholera and death is also guilty. The mother and the embryo. which are both the cause of suffering, are guilty;
vadhyasyāpi ca tatkriyāsaṃbandhādagnisvāśrayadāhavat / kāryataścāprasaṅgastadasambandhāt /	guilty also is the person killed, for he is bound to the action of killing as the object killed: and fire burns its own support.
pareṇāgnim sparśayatastenādāhavat /	But on the other hand, he who has murder committed by another is not guilty, for one is not himself burned when one has another person touch the fire.
acetanānāṃ ca kāṣṭhādīnāṃ gṛhapāte prāṇivadhāt pāpaprasaṅgo na vā dṛṣṭāntamātrātsiddhiriti / uktaḥ prāṇātipātaḥ /	Since you do not take intention into consideration, wood and other materials, even though lacking consciousness, are guilty of murder when a house collapses and living beings perish. If you would avoid these consequences, recognize that but one example—the example of the fire—and it alone, not accompanied by any argument, cannot prove your thesis.
adattādānamanyasvasvīkriyā balacauryataḥ //	Stealing—taking what is not given—is to appropriate to oneself the goods of another through force or in secret.
abhrāntyeti vartate /	The reservation above holds: “with the condition that there has been no error.
yadi balādvā cauryeṇa vā parasvaṃ svīkaroti yatraiva ca balacauryābhiprāyeṇānyatra saṃjñāvibhramāt iyatā 'dattādānaṃ bhavati /	” “To appropriate to oneself, through force or in secret, that which is possessed by another, when one does not confuse the person from”whom one wants to steal with another person, constitutes stealing.
stūpādapaharato buddhāda dattādānam / sarvaṃ hi tadbhagavatā parinirvāṇakāle parigṛthītamiti / yeṣāṃ samrakṣyamityapare /	The plunder of a Stupa is to take a thing that has not been given by the Buddha: for, at the moment of Nirvana, the Blessed One accepted, appropriated to himself all the gifts made to Stupas. According to others, this is to take a thing which has not been given by the guardians of the Stupa. To take a thing that does not have an owner is to take what is not given by the ruler of the country. To take the goods, the robes, etc. , of a deceased monk, is to take what is not given by the Sangha of the parish, in the case when an ecclesiastical action has not been done;
asvāmikaṃ ca nidhimuddharato viṣayasvāmikāt parivartakaṃ harataḥ kṛte karmaṇi sīmāprāptebhyaḥ akṛte sarvabuddhaśaikṣyebhyaḥ /	in the opposite case, this is to take what is not given by all the disciples of the Buddha.
agamyagamanaṃ kāmamithyācāraścaturvidhaḥ / catuṣprakāramagamyagamanaṃ kāmamithyācāraḥ /	Illicit sexuality, fourfold, is intercourse with a woman with whom one should not have intercourse.
agamyāṃ gacchati paraparigṛhītāṃ vā mātaraṃ duhitaraṃ vā mātṛpitṛsaṃbandhinīṃ vā /	Intercourse with a forbidden woman, that is, the wife of another, one's mother, one's daughter, or one's paternal or maternal relations;
anaṅge vā gacchati svāmapi bhāryām apāne mukhe vā / adeśe vā gacchati prakāśe caitye vihāre vā / akāle vā gacchati / kaḥ punaḥ akālaḥ / garbhiṇīṃ vā gacchati pāyayantīṃ vā saniyamāṃ vā /	Intercourse with one’s own wife through a forbidden way;
yadi bharturanujñayā saniyamā bhavatītyeke / abhrāntyeti vartate /	in anSome say: when she has taken a vow only with the consent of her husband. The reservation relative to killing, with the condition that there has been no error," also extends to illicit sexuality, and there is no course of action when one has intercourse with the wife of another if one thought that he was with his own wife.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi svasaṃjñī parastriyaṃ yāyāt na syāt karmapathaḥ /
column2: Opinions differ on whether there is a course of action when one takes the wife of a certain one for the wife of another one.
For some, yes, for it is the wife of another who was the object of the preparatory action; it is also the wife of another that one enjoys.
For others, no, as in the case of killing with an error of person: the object of the preparatory action is not the object of the enjoyment.
With regard to whom is intercourse with Bhikṣuṇis illicit sexuality?
With regard to the master of the land, who is not disposed to.
tolerate it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyāpi saniyamā svabhāryeva tu sā na gamyā /
column2: As for the master of the country himself, if his spouse, when she has undertaken a vow, is forbidden to him, all the more reason are nuns so forbidden. Intercourse with a young girl is illicit with regard to the man to whom she is engaged, and, if she is not engaged, with regard to her guardian;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kumārīṃ gacchato yasya nisṛṣṭā no cedyasya rakṣā 'ntato rājñaḥ /
column2: if he has no guardian, then with regard to the king. Lying is discourse held, with differing thoughts, with a person who understands the meaning.
Lying is discourse held, with thoughts different from the sense expressed, with a person who understands the meaning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi yamarthaṃ bravīti tasminnanyathāsamjñī bhavati yaṃ cādhikṛtya bravīti sa tasya vākyasyārthābhijño bhavati tadvākyaṃ mṛṣāvādaḥ / anabhijñe kiṃ syāt / saṃbhinnapralāpaḥ syāt / vākyamityucyate /
column2: When the person addressed does not understand, such discourse is only frivolous words.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kadācicca bahavo varṇā vākyaṃ bhavantīti katamaḥ tatra karmapathaḥ /
column2: Discourse is sometimes made up of numerous syllables. Which will be the course of action? Which will be lies?
The last syllable, which is viñap#á and which is accompanied by avijñapti. Or rather, the syllable whose hearing causes the meaning to be understood.
The preceding syllables are a preparation for the lie.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: arthābhijña ityucyate / ki tāvadabhijñātārthe śrotari āhosvit abhijñātuṃ samarthe /
column2: How should one interpret the expression arthābhijña, “a person who understands the meaning? Does this refer to the moment when the person addressed understands the meaning?
Does it refer to a person addressed capable of understanding the meaning?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyabhijñātārthe manovijñānaviṣayatvādvākyārthasya śrotravijñānena saha nirodhācca vāgvijñapteravijñaptireva syāt karmapathaḥ /
column2: In the first hypothesis, you admit that the course of action takes place when the person addressed has understood the meaning; it follows then that the course of action is solely for the person addressed understood the meaning through mental consciousness, which is consecative to auditory consciousness; and the véjñapt, oṟ vocal action, peṟishes at the same time as the auditory consciousness.
There is no longer any viṝñapti at the moment when the person addressed understands.
In the second hypothesis, this difficulty is not present.

But what must one do in order that the person addressed is “capable of understanding the meaning? The person who knows the language and in whom auditory consciousness has arisen is “capable of understanding the meaning.
”One must interpret the text in a manner in which it will not give rise to criticism.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣodaśa vyavahārāḥ sūtra uktāḥ / “adṛṣṭe dṛṣṭavāditā aśrute 'mate 'vijñāte vijñātavāditā dṛṣṭe adṛṣṭavāditā yāvad vijñāte 'vijñātavāditā itīme 'nāryā aṣṭau vyavahārāḥ /
column2: The Sūtra teaches that there are sixteen “yocal actions,” eight of which are bad: to say that one has seen what one has not seen, to say that one has heard, cognized, or known what one has not heard, cognized, or known,;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭe dṛṣṭavāditā yāvadvijñāte vijñātavāditā adṛṣṭ 'dṛṣṭavāditā yāvadavijñāte avijñātavāditā itīme āryā aṣṭau vyavahārāḥ /
column2: to say that one has not seen when one has seen; and to say that one has not heard, cognized, or known when one has heard, cognized, or known; and eight are good: to say that one has not seen when one has not seen.
What is the meaning of the words seen, heard, cognized, and known?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣuḥ śrotramanaścittairanubhūtaṃ tribhiśca yat / taddṛṣṭaśrutavijñātaṃ mataṃ coktaṃ yathākramam // yaccakṣurvijñānenānubhūtaṃ taddṛṣṭamityuktam /
column2: What is perceived through the visual consciousness, through the auditory consciousness, through the mental consciousness, and through three consciousnesses, is called, in order, seen, heard, cognized, and known.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yacchrotravijñānena tacchrutam / yanmano vijñānena tat vijñātam / yat ghrāṇajihvākāyavijñānaistanmatam /
column2: What is perceived through the visual consciousness receives the name of seen, what is perceived through the consciousness of smell, taste, and touch, receives the name of known.
How do you justify this last interpretation?
The Vaibhāṣikas say that odors, tastes and tangible things, being morally neutral, are as dead;
this is why they are called mmākā.

The Sautrāntikas: According to what authority do you maintain that the expression ṁata refers to what is smelled, tasted, and touched? ‘The Vaibhāṣikas: According to the ūtra, and by virtue of reasoning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtraṃ yuktiśca / sūtraṃ tāvat “tatkiṃ manyase māhakīmātaḥ yāni tvayā cakṣuṣā rūpāṇi na dṛṣṭāni na dṛṣṭapūrvāṇi na paśyasi nāpi te evaṃ bhavati paśyeyamiti / api nu te tannidānamutpannaśchando vā rāgo vā sneho vā yena vā ālayo vā nīyatiradhyavasānaṃ vā /
column2: The Sūtra says, “What do you think,Oh Mālakīmātar, the visible objects that you have not seen, that you have not seen formerly, that you do not see, about which you do not think “Would that I could see them, do you have, by reason of them, any longing, lust, desire, affection, attachment, appetite, or searching out?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: no bhadanta / ye tvayā śrotreṇa śabdā na śrutā na śrutapūrvā vistareṇa yāvanmanasā dharmā na vijñātā vistareṇa yāvanno bhadanta /
column2: No, Lord.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atra ca te māhakīmātardṛṣṭe dṛṣṭamātraṃ bhaviṣyati śrute mate vijñāte vijñātapātramityu“ktam /
column2: Oh Mālakīmāta:, with regard to the subject seen, you will only think, Śit is seen,’ with regard to the subject heatd, cognized, and known, you will only think, ‘it is heard, cognized, known .
The words “seen,”“heard,” and “cognized,” certainly refer to visible things, to sounds, and to the dharmas: hence the word ata refers to smells, tastes, and tangible things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evaṃ cāniṣyamāṇe dṛṣṭādibhāvabāhyatvāt gandhādiṣu vyavahāro na syādityeṣā yuktiḥ / sūtraṃ tāvajjñāpakamanyārthatvāt /
column2: If it were otherwise, the experience relative to smells,This Śūtra does not have the meaning that you believe it does, and it does not confirm your interpretation of the word maia.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hyatra sūtre bhagavān vyavahārānāṃ lakṣāṇaṃ śāsti sma / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: The Blessed One does not aim to define the characteristics of the four experiences, having seen, having heard, having cognized, having mata.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atra ca te ṣaḍvidhe viṣaye caturṣu vyavahāreṣu dṛṣṭādivyavahāramātraṃ bhaviṣyati na priyāpriyanimittādhyāropa ityayamatra sūtrārtho dṛśyate
column2: His mind is evidently, “In the fourfold experience, seeing, etc. ,— each of which beats on the sixfold objects, visible things, sounds, smells, tasṣtes, tangible things and dharmas,—you maintain only that this experience takes place, that you see, etc. , without attributing to the object the characteristic of disagreeable or agreeable.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punarḍṛṣṭaṃ kiṃ ca yāvadvijñātam / kecittāvadāhuḥ /
column2: ” Then what should one thus understand by seen, heard, mata and cognized?
According to the Śautrāntikas, that which is immediately perceived by the five material organs, is seen, dṛṣṭ;
that the consciousness of which is transmitted to us by another, is heard, fru;
what is admitted by reason of correct reasoning, is zaśa, known;
and what is perceived by.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ete ca pañca viṣayāḥ pratyekaṃ dṛṣṭā iti vā kṛtvā vyavahrilyante / śrutā matā vijñātā iti vā /
column2: Thus five categories of objects—visible matter, sounds, odors, tastes, and tangible things—are seen, heard, known, and cognized;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣaṣṭho 'nyatra dṛṣṭāditi nāsti gandhādiṣu vyavahārābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tasmādyuktiṃrapyeṣā yuktirna bhavati /
column2: the sixth category—dharmas--is not seen: such is the fourfold experience that the Sūtra refers to. It is thus false that, in the hypothesis where a does not designate odors, tastes, and tangible matter, the experience relative to these objects would be omitted in the Sūtra: thus the argument of the Vaibhāṣikas does not hold.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvācāryā evamāhuḥ / yad dṛṣṭaṃ yat pratyakṣīkṛtaṃ cakṣuṣā /
column2: According to former masters, “seen” is what is perceived by the organ of seeing;
