prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kimānantarye prayogaṃ kṛtvā tasminnavyāvartite vairāgyaṃ phalaṃ vā na prāpnuyāt /
column2: Can a person who made preparation for a mortal transgression, obtain detachment and its result by arresting it?
Detachment and its results are impossible for one who has made preparation for a mortal transgression.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyakarmaphalapathaprayogaṃ tu kṛtvāryamārgotpattau na punaḥ karmapathotpattirāśrayasyātyantaṃ tadviruddhatvāt /
column2: Why? Because there is an absolute contradiction between the intention of a mortal transgression and the acquisition of detachment or a result. A person who enters the Pathafter havingdone the preparation for any other evil deed, will not produce this deed, by reason of the absolute.
What is the gravest of the mortal transgressions?
Lying with a view to schism is considered the gravest transgression.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ saṃghabhedanimittaṃ mṛṣāvādo dharmādharmajñasya viparyayadyotanāt sa sarveṣāṃ duścaritānāṃ mahāvadyatamaḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: A person who, knowing what is Dharma and non-Dharma, lies with a view to dividing the Saṅgha and teaching falsely, by this makes himself guilty of the gravest transgression among all misdeeds.
In fact, he wounds the Dharma body of the Tathāgatas, he creates an obstacle to temporal well-being and to the deliverance of creatures.

As long as concord is not established in the Saṅgha, there is hindrance to entry into the Path, to the acquisition of results, to the acquisition of detachment, and to the destruction of the defilements: all actions relative to dhyāna, study and reflection are also arrested;
the worlds of gods, Nāgas and humans are troubled and saddened, they are not masters of themselves, and misguided.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vimanaskaṃ vartate yāvat punarna pratisaṃdhito bhavatiyasmāccāvicau kalpaṃ vipākaḥ /
column2: This is why the retribution for this crime lasts a cosmic age and takes place in Avīci.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣāṇāmānantaryāṇāṃ yathākramaṃ pañcamatṛtīyaprathamāni gurutarāṇi sarvalaghuḥ pitṛvadhaḥ /
column2: Among the other mortal transgressions, the fifth, the third and the first are, in descending order, the heaviest. Patricide is the lightest.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi bhagavatā trayāṇāṃ daṇḍānāṃ manodaṇḍo mahāsāvadya uktaḥ punarmithyādṛṣṭiḥ paramavadyānāmityuktam ānantaryāṇi niyamasya saṃghabhedo mahāsāvadya uktaḥ /
column2: Objection: The Blessed One said that mental danda is the most culpable of the threedaṇḍḍus; he said also that false view is the gravest among all the transgressions. One must understand that, among the mortal transgressions, schism is the gravest transgression;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trīṇi karmāṇi niyamayya manodaṇdaḥ dṛṣṭīrniyamayya mithyādṛṣṭiḥ /
column2: that mental danda is the gravest among the three actions; and that false view is the gravest among the bad views.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athavā vipākavistaraṃ mahājanavyāpādanaṃ kuśalamūlasamucchedaṃ cādhikṛtya yathākramam /
column2: Or rather schism is the gravest transgression if one considers the extent of its retribution; vanodanda, if one considers the number of persons destroyed by it; and false view, if one considers the roots of good which false view alone cuts off.
Among the good actions, which bears the greatest result?
Among the good worldly dharmmas, a volition for Bhavagra bears the greatest result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśale punaḥ karmaṇi bhavāgracetanā sarveṣāṃ mahāphalatamā /
column2: Volition for Bhavagra means the mental action through which one is reborn in the highest stage of Arupyadhatu.
This action is the. most fruitful of good worldly actions, for its retribution is a perfect tranquility for twenty-four thousand cosmic periods.
This is understood from the point of view of its retributive results.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: visaṃyogaphalaṃ tvadhikṛtya vajropamasamādhicetanā sarveṣāṃ mahāphalā sarvasamyojanaparyādānaphalatvāt /
column2: From the point of view of its disconnective result the most fruitful action is volition associated with Vajropamasamādhi, for this volition has for its result the cutting off of all the bonds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva loka ityuktam / kimānantaryairevāvaśyaṃ narakeṣūpapadyate /
column2: This is why the Kārikā says, “Among the good worldly dharmas, is it only through a mortal transgression that a person is necessarily reborn in hell?
A person is also necessarily reborn in hell through transgressions similar to mortal transgressions.
Others add: but not immediately so.
To defile one's mother, to defile an Arhantī;
to kill a predestined Bodhisattva; to kill a Saikṣa; and to steal the goods of the Saṅgha are transgressions similar to mortal transgressions;
the fifth is the destruction of a Stūpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etāni pañca pañcānāmānatnaryāṇāṃ yathākramam sabhāgāni / yadi mātaramarhantīṃ dūṣayatyabrahmacaryakaraṇāt niyatipatītaṃ bodhisattvaṃ mārayati śaikṣaṃ mārayati saṃghasya sukhāyadvārikaṃ harati stūpabhedaṃ karoti /
column2: These five transgressions, in this order, are similar to mortal.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyadapi tu karma savipākaṃ triṣu kāleṣvatyarthaṃ vighnayati / katameṣu trisu /
column2: Other actions embracing retribution are impeded in three circumstances.
He absolutely impedes actions by the acquisition of Kṣānti, the quality of Anāgāāmin, and the quality of Arhat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mūrdhabhyaḥ kṣāntimākirata āpāyikāni karmāṇi vighnāyopatiṣṭhante / tadvipākabhūmyatikramāt /
column2: When, upon leaving the stage of mṁrdhānas, he obtains the stage called patience, the actions which should be retributed in painful realms of rebirth, being impeded, remain below, because he passes beyond the state of retribution of these actions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā puruṣasya deśatyāgaṃ kurvato dhanikā upatiṣṭhante /
column2: In the same way the creditors of the man who is about to emigrate from his country rise up.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgāmiphalaṃ prāpnuvataḥ kāmāvacarāṇi vighnāyopatiṣṭhante tathaiva sthāpayitvā dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ karma /
column2: When he obtains the quality of Anāgāmin, the actions which should be retributed in Kāmadhātu, being impeded, remain below, with the exception of those which should be retributed in the present existence.
The same for the actions which should be retributed in Rūpadhātu.
We have seen that the killing of a Bodhisattva is a quasi-mortal transgression.
Since when is one a Bodhisattva?
From what moment on does one receive the name of Bodhisattva?
When he begins to cultivate actions which produce the marks, he is "predestined.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yataḥ prabhṛti lakṣaṇavipākāni karmāṇyārabhate kartuṃ sa hi tadānīṃ niyatipatito bhavati /
column2: Starting from the moment when he begins to cultivate actions which have for their retribution the thirty-two marks, he is "predestined.
How is this?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa hi tasmāt kālāt prabhṛti nityaṃ bhavati /
column2: From this moment onward, he always has good realms of rebirth;
he is born into noble families; he possesses all the organs; he is a male; he remembers his past lives; and he does not desist.
One says that he is srgati, because his rebirth realms are excellent, for he is born among gods and humans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyāṃ ca sugatau kṣatriyabrāhmaṇagṛhapatimahāśālakulajo bhavati nānyaḥ kulīnaḥ / vikalānyakṣāṇyasyeti vyakṣaḥ /
column2: He is born in the wealthy families of Kṣatriyas, Brāhmaṇas, and Gr̥hapatis, not in humble families.
The man whose organs are not complete is vṝkalendriya; if his organs are complete, he is an zvyaéṣa, a synonym for avikalendriya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: puruṣa eva na strī kuta eva śaṇḍhādiḥ / jātismaraśca bhavati /
column2: He is always male, never female, and, even more so, never nonsexual.
In all of his existences, he remembers his past births. One desists by giving in;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na nivṛdanivṛt / anivartaka ityarthaḥ / sattvahitārthaṃ sarvaduḥkhaprakāraiḥ sarvasattvavipratipattibhiścākheditatvāt /
column2: as he does not give in, he is avôvṛt, a synonym for an avaivartika, one who does not desist or regress: in fact, with an end to being useful to all creatures, he is not cast down by all sorts of sufferings, or by any outrages.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattalloka ucyate “apaṇakrīto dāsa” iti / bodhisattvāste te hi mahātmānaḥ sarvasaṃpatprakarṣaviśeṣaprāptā api santo niṣkāraṇakaruṇāpāratantryātsarvasattveṣu
column2: He is called the slave not purchased by the world, indeed the Bodhisattva: this great-souled one, who yet possesses the most sublime perfections, acts through pure compassion;
he acts without egoism, like a dog, in the presence of all creatures; he bears, on the part of all creatures, outrages and bad treatment;
he assumes all fatiguing and painful tasks.
He cultivates actions which have the marks for their retribution.
In Jambudvīpa, being a male; in the presence of the Buddhas, thinking of the Buddhas; having their origin in reflection;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cintāmayaṃ kalpaśate śeṣa ākṣipate hi tat //
column2: in the course of one hundred supplementary cosmic ages.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jambūdvīpa eva bodhisattvo lakṣaṇavipākaṃ karmākṣipati / nānyatra / jāmbūdvīpakānāṃ tīkṣṇabuddhitvāt /
column2: The Bodhisattva cultivates actions which ripen in the marks solely in Jambudvīpa, not elsewhere, for the inhabitants of Jambudvīpa are of lively intelligence;
he is a male and not a female, for he has already gone beyond the state of female;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃmukhībhūta eva śāstari buddhālambanayaiva cetanayā cintāmayaṃ tatkarma na śrutamayaṃ na bhāvanāmayam /
column2: and he is only in the presence of Masters, for his volition has the Buddhas for its object. These actions have their origin in reflection, not in hearing or in the absorptions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kalpaśate ca śeṣa ākṣipati na bahubhavesu /
column2: The Bodhisattva accomplishes these actions in the course of one hundred supplementary cosmic ages, and not during a longer time.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhagavatā tu śākyamuninottaptavīryatayā nava kalpā apāvartitā ekanavatyā kalpairākṣiptam /
column2: Nevertheless the Blessed Śākyamuni, through the purification of his energy, leaped over nine of these cosmic ages and carried out the actions ripening in marks in the course of ninety-nine cosmic ages so that, in this way, one hundred were completed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva cokta “mito 'haṃ grāmaṇīrekanavataṃ kalpamupādāya na samanusmarāmi nābhijānāmi yadekakulamapi pakṣabhikṣāpradānahetoḥ kṣataṃ vā syādupahataṃ ve“ti /
column2: This is why, speaking to Aśibandhaka, he said, “Oh village chief, remembering ninety-one cosmic ages from now, I do not see any family that has been impoverished or inconvenienced by the giving of cooked foods. ”Blessed One expressed himself in this way because his natural memory bore on this number of cosmic periods.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ prabhṛti prakṛtijātismaratvāt prathamakalpāsaṃkhyeyaniryāta eva bodhisattva etāṃścaturo doṣān vyāvartayati dvau ca guṇo pratilabhata iti pūrvācāryāḥ /
column2: Former masters say It is when he finished the first cosmic age that the Bodhisattva abandoned the four defects and obtained the two qualities.
Of the marks.
Each arises from one hundred merits.
What is the measure of each of these one hundred merits?

According to some, it is equal to the merit which has for its result the pleasure of all beings, with the exception of the Bodhisattva close to Bodhi—that is to say, accomplishing actions which ripen in marks.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvat sarvasattvānāṃ karmādhipatyena trisāhasramahāsāhasrako loko 'bhinivartata ityapare /
column2: According to others, it is equal to the collective action of all beings, which, through its predominating result, produces the creation of the world.
According to others, only the Buddhas know the measure of this merit.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha bodhisattvabhūto bhagavān kiyato buddhān paryupāsayāmāsa /
column2: How many Buddhas did the Blessed One venerate when he was a Bodhisattva?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratheme kalpāsaṃkhyeye pañcasaptatisahasrāṇi dvitīye ṣaṭsaptatiṃ tṛtīye saptasaptatim /
column2: In the course of the first asamkhyeya kalpa, he venerated seventy-five thousand Buddhas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kasya kalpāsaṃkhyeyasyānte katamo buddha āsīt /
column2: seventy-six thousand in the course of theWho were the Buddhas at the end of each sakhyeya kalpa?
In the reverse order of their enumeration.
At the end of the three asarṁkhyeyas, Paśyin, Dīpa, and Ratṇaśikhin.
In the period of the perfect and complete Buddha Ratnaśikhin, he completed the first ase/khyeya kalpa;
in the period of the Blessed Dīpaṁkara he completed the second;
and in the period of the Tathāgatha Vipaśyin he completed the third.
Of all the Buddhas that he venerated.
The first was Śākyarnuṇi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śākyamunirnāma samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ pūrvaṃ vabhūva / yatra bhagavatā bodhisattvabhūtenādyaṃ praṇidhānaṃ kṛtam evaṃprakāra evāhaṃ buddho
column2: It was an ancient Śākyamuni, a perfect Buddha, under whom the Blessed One, the then Bodhisattva, formulated for the first time the vow of Bodhi by saying, “May I too become a Buddha in all ways similar to yon!”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhaveyamiti no 'pyevaṃ kaliyuga evotpannavānāryavattasyāpyevaṃ varṣa sahasrāntaṃ śāsanaṃ babhūva /
column2: This Śākyamuni, as ours, appeared during a bad age of the world; also his Law lasted only one thousand years.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kasyāmavasthāvāṃ bodhisattvaḥ kāṃ pāramitāṃ paripūrayate /
column2: How did the Bodhisattva complete each Pāramitā?
He completed Giving by giving everything to everyone, out of compassion.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā sarvasmai sarvaṃ dadāti ā akṣṇaḥ ā majjāyāḥ kāruṇyānnābhyudayaviśeṣaṃ lipsamānaḥ iyatā dānapāramitā paripūrṇā bhavati /
column2: When he gave everything to everyone, even to his eyes and the marrow of his bones, out of compassion, without desiring any happiness for himself, he completed the virtue of Giving.
Morality and Patience were completed by his not being irritated, even when his limbs were broken, although he was still ' tied to desire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā 'yamavītarāgo 'pi cchidyamāneṣvaṅgeṣu nālpamapi kupyati tadā 'sya kṣāntiśīlapāramite paripūrṇe bhavataḥ /
column2: When, even though he was not detached, he was not at all irritated when his limbs were broken,he then completed the virtues of Morality and Patience.
Energy, by praising Puṣya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tiṣyaṃ tathāgataratnaguhāyāṃ tejodhātusamāpannadṛṣṭyā bhagavān bodhisattvabhūta ekena pādena sthitvā sapta divasān stutavānekagāthayā
column2: The Blessed One, when he was a Bodhisattva, saw the Tathāgata Puṣya who had become incandescent in the interior of a cave in a mountain.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “na divi bhuvi vā nāsmin loke na vaiśravaṇālaye / na marubhavane divye sthāne na dikṣu vidikṣu vā // caratu vasudhāṃ sphītāṃ kṛtsnāṃ saparvatakānanām / puruṣavṛṣabhastvattulyo 'nyo mahāśramaṇaḥ kuta” iti //
column2: He praised him for seven days and seven nights, standing, repeating the stanza, "Neither in heaven nor on earth, nor in this world, nor in the abode of Vaiśravaṇa, nor in the palace of the Marus, nor in other celestial abodes, nor in any of the ten directions, would one find, Oh Chief of Men, an ascetic who is your equal, even if one were to".

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadā kila vīryapāramitā paripūrṇā nava ca kalpāḥ pratyudāvartitāḥ /
column2: Then, according to this School, he was found to have fulfilled the virtue of Energy and nine cosmic ages were passed over.
Absoṟption and Intelligence, immediately before.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bodheḥ pūrvasamanantaraṃ dhyānaprajñāpāramitayoḥ paripūrirvajropamasamādhau svasyāḥ saṃpadaḥ pāragamanāt pāramitāḥ /
column2: At the moment of Vajropamasamādhi, immediately before Bodhi, he accomplished the virtues of dhyāna and prajñā. The Pāramitās receive the name of pāramitā because they have arrived at the other shore of the other shore of the totality of the perfectons proper to each of them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtra uktaṃ “trīṇi puṇyakriyāvastūni / dānamayaṃ puṇyakriyāvastu śīlamayaṃ bhāvanāmayami“ti /
column2: The Sūtra teaches that there are three items of meritorious work, which consist of Giving, Morality, and Meditation.
How are Giving, Morality, and Meditation items of meritorious work?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: puṇyaṃ kriyā 'tha tadvastu trayaṃ karmapathā yathā // puṇyamapyetattrayaṃ kriyā 'pi vastvapi yathāyogamiti puṇyakriyāvastu / tadyathā karma ca te panthānaśca panthāna eva ca karmaṇa iti karmaṃpathā uktāḥ /
column2: Three are merit, action, occasions of the exercise of action, as in the case of deeds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra dānamaye tāvat puṇyakriyāvastuni kāyavākkarma tridhā bhavati /
column2: ‘These three,—Giving, Morality, and Meditation,:—each according to its nature, are merit, action, or occasion of exercise, either inTo consider first the item of meritorious work which consists of Giving, one must distinguish: 1. bodily and vocal action which is an item of meritorious work on three grounds: merit, because its retribution is agreeable; action, because it is action by nature; and an occasion for the exercise or an object of the volition of giving which provokes it;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatsamutthāpikā cetanā puṇyaṃ ca kriyā ca /
column2: the volition of giving, which is merit and action;
and the dharmas which accompany bodily and vocal action, and which are solely merit.
The item of meritorious work which consists of Morality is exclusively bodily and vocal action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhāvanāmayo maitrī puṇyaṃ ca puṇyakriyāyāśca vastu /
column2: it is necessarily merit, action and occasion of exercise of action. For the item of meritorious work which consists of Meditation, let us consider the Meditation of Compassion: 1. this meditation is merit;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatsaṃprayuktāyāścetanāyā maitrīmukhenābhisaṃskaraṇāt tatsahabhuvaścetanā śīlaṃ ca puṇyaṃ ca kriyā ca /
column2: it is also an occasion for the exercise of a meritorious action, namely that of a volition associated with compassion; the. The volition in question pertains to merit and action. The same is true for the Morality that constitutes dhyānasaṁvara, the discipline of dhyāna, which a person who practices the Meditation of Compassion possesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye tatsahabhuvaḥ puṇyameva puṇyasya vā kāraṇaṃ puṇyakriyā puṇyaprayogastasyā etāni trīṇi vastūni /
column2: The other dharmas concomitant to this Meditation are solely merit. Or rather, the expression puṇyakrśyā signifies puṇyakāraṇa, or puṇyaprayoga.
Giving, Morality, and Meditation are vastus of puṇyakriya because, with a view to realizing them, one undertakes the preparation of merit.
According to another opinion, puṇyaukriyā is, to speak precisely, good volition. Giving, Morality, and Meditation are its vasÉx, an occasion for the exercise of this volition.
What is Giving, dāna?

Without doubt, dāna in general is what is given, but here Giving is what gives. But one gives through fear, or with the hope of reciprocity, or through attachment, etc. Now this does not refer to this type of giving.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dīyate yena daddānaṃ bhavati sma / rāgādibhirapi dīyate / na cātra tadiṣṭam / ato viśeṣaṇārthamāha
column2: Consequently, in order to specify, the author says, “Giving is what gives.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūjānugrahakāmyayā / pareṣāṃ pūjānugrahakāmatābhyāṃ yena dīyate / kiṃ punastatsyādyena dīyate /
column2: ” Through the desire to render homage or service.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyavākkarma sotthānaṃ kiṃ punastadutthānam / yena kalāpena tadutthāpyate /
column2: A collection of mind-and-mental states gives rise to a bodily or vocal action: this collection and this action give.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āha cātra śubhena manasā dravyaṃ svaṃ dadāti yadā pumān / tat kṣaṇaṃ kuśalāḥ skandhāḥ dānamityabhidhīyate //” iti /
column2: As the stanza says, “When a person, with a good mind gives what belongs to him, then one says that the good skandhas give.”
It has for its results great joys.
The puṇyakriyāvastu which consists of Giving has great joys as its result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svabhāve caiṣa mayaḍveditavyaḥ / tadyathā tṛṇamayaṃ gṛhaṃ parṇamayaṃ bhājanamiti / tat khalvetaddānaṃ
column2: The suffix aya, which we translate “which consists of,” should be understood as “having as its nature,” the same way that one says, “a house made of grass”, or `a vase made of leaves.”
Giving is beneficial to oneself, to others, to both or neither. A gift made to a Caitya is not useful to another;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra yadavītarāgaḥ āryaḥ pṛthagjano vā vītarāgaścaitye dānaṃ dadāti tadasyātmana evārthāya / pareṣāṃ tenānugrahābhāvāt /
column2: but it is useful to him who gives when he is an Āryan not detached from desire, or a Pr̥thagjana detached or not detached.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadāryo vītarāgaḥ parasattvebhyo dānaṃ dadāti sthāpayitvā dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ tatra dānaṃ pareṣāmarthāya / tena teṣāmanugrahāt /
column2: The gift that a detached Āryan makes to another—with the exception of the case when this gift ripens in the present existence—is. pot useful to this Āryan, for the Āryan who is detached has definitively passed beyond the sphere where the retribution of the gift could have taken place in a later existence.
This gift is only useful to another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadavītarāgaḥ pṛthagjano vā vītarāgaḥ parasattvebhyo dadāti taddānamubhayeṣāmarthāya /
column2: The gift thata non-detached Āryan makes to another, to a detached or non-detached Pṛthagjana, is useful both to himself and to another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadāryo vītarāgaścaitye dadāti sthāpayitvā dṛṣṭadharmavedanīyaṃ taddānamubhayeṣāṃ nārthāya /
column2: The gift that a detached Āryan makes to a Caitya—with the exception of the case when this gift willripen in the present existence-— is not useful either to himself, or to another.
This gift has for its effect only the expression of homage and recognition.
We have said, ina general manner, that giving produces great joys.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadviśeṣaḥ punardātṛvastukṣetraviśeṣataḥ // tatra tāvat dātā viśiṣṭaḥ śraddhādyaiḥ
column2: Giving is excellent by the excellence of the giver, of the object given, and of the field.

The giver is excellent through his faith, etc. The giver is excellentwhen he isendowed with faith, with morality, with learning, with generosity, with wisdon, with few desires, etc. When the giver is excellent, the gift is excellent;
when the gift isits result is excellent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa ca tādṛśo dātā satkṛtyādi dadāti satkṛtya svahastaṃ kāle parānupahatya dadāti / ataḥ /
column2: He gives with respect, etc. Such a giver gives with respect, by his hand, at the right time, without doing evil to anyone.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satkārodārarucitā kālānācchedyalābhitā // ato 'sya dātustattādṛśaṃ dānaṃ dattvā yathākramaṃ catvāro viśeṣā bhavanti /
column2: From whence he obtains honors, superior joys, at the right time, sheltered from all loss.
The giver who gives with respect obtains honors;
giving by his hand, he will find satisfaction in superior joys;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kālelna ca bhogān labhate nātikrāntikālena / anācchedyāṃśca bhogān labhate / nāsya bhogāḥ parairācchādyante nāpyagnyādibhirvināśyante /
column2: giving at the right time, he will obtain these joys at a suitable time and not when he cannot enjoy them;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ yathā dātā viśiṣyate tadviśeṣācca dānaviśeṣaḥ /
column2: giving without doing any evil, these joys will be indestructible: they will not be stolen, annihilated through fire, etc. We have explained in what the excellence of the giver consists and how the gift is excellent through the excellence of the giver.
How is the object given excellent?
The object perfect in color, etc. Add: "is excellent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi yaddīyate dadvarṇagandharasasparśānāmanyatamenāpi saṃpannaṃ bhavati / evaṃ vastu viśiṣyate /
column2: The object is excellent when that which one gives is perfect in color, in odor, in taste, in contact.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tādṛśaṃ vastu dattvā kiṃ bhavati / yathākramam surūptvaṃ yaśasvi vā / priyatā sukumārartusukhasparśāṅtā tataḥ //
column2: What will one obtain through the giving of such an object?
He who gives an object perfect in color will be beautiful.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gandhasaṃpannaṃ dattvā yaśasvī bhavati / gandhavadyaśaso dikṣu vidhāraṇāt /
column2: He who gives an object perfect in odor will have his reputation extend to all directions, in the same way that an odor spreads.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rasasaṃpannaṃ dattvā priyo bhavati / rasa iva svāduḥ /
column2: He who gives an object perfect in taste will be happy, like a sweet taste.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sparśasaṃpannaṃ dattvā sukumārāṅgāśca bhavati ṛtusukhasparśāni cāsyāṅgāni bhavanti yathā strīratnasya /
column2: The body of him who gives an object perfect to the touch, will be very delicate, like the jewel-like wife of a Cakravartinking, and his limbs will have only agreeable contacts, hot or cold according to the season.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kṣetraṃ kathaṃ viśipyate / gatiduḥkhopakāritvaguṇaiḥ kṣetraṃ viśiṣyate /
column2: How is the field excellent?
A field is excellent through the realm of rebirth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā hyuktaṃ bhagavatā “tiryagyonigatāya dānaṃ dattvā śataguṇo vipākaḥ pratikāṅkṣitavyaḥ / duḥśīlāya manuṣyabhūtāya dānaṃ dattvā sahasraguṇa” iti /
column2: The Blessed One said, “If a person gives to an animal, the giver will receive a retribution one hundred times greater than the gift made to the animal, but if this person gives even to a human who has transgressed the precepts, he will receive a retribution one thousand times greater than the gift made.
A field is excellent through suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā hyaupadhikeṣu puṇyakriyāvastuṣu / glāne dānaṃ glānopasthāpake dānam / śītalikādiṣu ca dānamuktvoktame” bhiḥ saptabhiḥ auṣadhikaiḥ puṇyakriyāvastubhiḥsamanvāgatasya śrāddhasya kulaputrasya vā kuladuhiturvā na labhyaṃ puṇyānāṃ pramāṇamudgrahītumi“ti /
column2: The Blessed One, among the seven aupadhikapuṇyakriyāvastus, enumerated giving to a sick person, giving to a hospital attendant, giving during cold seasons, etc. , and he continued: “One cannot enumerate the measure of the merits of a son or daughter of good family who is endowed with these seven material meritorious works.” A field is excellent through benefactors.
This is giving to one’s father, to one's mother, to one's master, or to other benefactors.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: guṇaviśeṣādyathā” śīlavate dattvā śatasahasraguṇo vipāka” ityevamādi /
column2: Example: the Jtakas of the bear, of the antelope, etc. A field is excellent through its qualities. The Blessed One said, “A retribution one hundred thousand times greater than a gift made to a person who upholds the necessities. ¹ and so on.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarveṣāṃ tu dānānām agraṃ muktasya muktāya
column2: Among all the gifts, the best is the gift from a delivered person to a delivered person.
The Blessed One said that a gift given by a detached person to another detached person is the best of material gifts.
Or a gift from the Bodhisattva.

Or rather, the gift that a Bodhisattva gives for the welfare of all beings; this gift, although given by a non-detached person to other non-detached persons, is the best gift. With the exception of the gift from the Bodhisattva.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat sthāpayitvā yāni bhagavato 'nyānyaṣṭau dānānyuktāni teṣām aṣṭamam // agramiti vartate /
column2: The eighth among the eight gifts that the Blessed One taught.
'What are the eight gifts?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āsādya dānaṃ bhayadānam adānme dānaṃ dāsyati me dānaṃ dattpūrvaṃ me dānaṃ pitṛbhiśca
column2: An āsadya gift; a gift through fear; a gift made "because he gave to me”; a gift made “because he gives to me”;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pitāmahaiśceti dānaṃ dadāti svargārthaṃ dānaṃ kīrtyarthaṃ dānaṃ cittālaṅkārārthaṃ
column2: a gift made “because my fathers and my grandfathers gave ceti dāṇam, compare Jāpaka, vol. a gift made in order to obtain heaven; a gift made with an eye to one’s reputation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dānaṃ cittapariṣkārārthaṃ yiogasaṃbhārārthamuttamārthasya prāptaye dānaṃ dadāti /
column2: a gift made in order to adorn one’s mind; in order to fillthe mind; in order to equip it with a view to yoga; and in order to acquire the supreme goal.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāsādya dānaṃ yat āsannebhya upagatebhyo dānaṃ dadātīti paurāṇāḥ /
column2: What is an āsadya gift? Some ancient masters explDain this as an immediate gift to those who are near, who approach one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhayadānaṃ yadvināśābhimukhaṃ dṛṣṭvā varaṃ dadāmīti dadāti / śeṣaṃ sugamatvānna vibhaktam /
column2: A gift through fear is a gift that a person makes who sees that theThe Sūtra says, "An incalculable retribution proceeds from a gift made to a srotaāpannaphalapratspannaka;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: srota āpattiphalapratipannakāya dānaṃ dattvā 'prameyavipākaḥ / tato 'prameyataraḥ srota āpannāyeti vistareṇoktaṃ sūtre /
column2: an even more incalculable retribution proceeds from a gift made to a ṛrotaāpanna. " But there are also five persons who, even though Prthagjanas, confer an incalculable retribution on the offering that is made to them: 118.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apitu mātṛpitṛglānadhārmakathikebhyo 'ntyajanmane / bodhisattvāya cāmeyā anāryebhyo 'pi dakṣiṇā //
column2: Even though they are not Āryams, offerings made to one's father and mother, to a sick person, to a preacher, to the Bodhisattva in his last birth are without measure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ebhyaḥ pañcabhyaḥ pṛthagjanabhūtebhyo 'pyaprameyā phalato dakṣiṇā bhavati /
column2: These offerings are without measure from the point of view of their retribution.
A "Bodhisattva in his last birth" means a "Bodhisattva in his last existence. " (To what category does a preacher belong?
Among what field should he be placed?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upakāripakṣe / sa hi mahākalyāṇamitram avidyāndhāyāṃ prajāyāṃ prajñācakṣuṣo dātā samaviṣamasya prakāśayitā anāsravasya dharmakāyasyātinivartayitā samāsato buddhakṛtyasya kartā / karmaṇāṃ tu gurulaghutvaṃ jñātukāmena samāsataḥ ṣaṭ kāraṇāni jñeyāni / tadyathā pṛṣṭhaṃ kṣetramadhiṣṭhānaṃ prayiogaścetanāśayaḥ /
column2: He forms part of the category of benefactors: he gives the eye of wisdom to multitudes blinded by ignorance; he proclaims what is good and bad; he erects the pure body of the Law;

in a word, he accomplishes all the work of a Buddha: )In order to appreciate the lightness and the gravity of actions, one should, in short, take into consideration six causes: Accordingly as these causes--consecutive, field, adhisṭhāṇa, preparation, volition, or intention—are small or large, action also is small or large.
Consecutive: after having done the action, that is, consequential action.
Field: the person to whom one does good or evil.
Aāhiṣṭhāna: the deed itself.
Preparation: bodily or vocal action with a view to the preceding.
Volition: that through which the deed is achieved. Intention: to project the thought, “I shall do this or that to them;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āśayastadabhiprāya evaṃ caivaṃ ca kuryāmevaṃ caivaṃ ca na kariṣyāmīti /
column2: then I shall do this or that.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasyacit pṛṣṭhaparigraheṇaiva tatkarma guru saṃpadyate / vipākanaiyamyenāvasthānāt / kasyacit kṣetravaśenaiva /
column2: ” It happens that an action can be grave only by reason of its consecutive action, for example, when this confers on the retribution the character of necessity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatraiva kṣetre punaradhiṣṭhānavaśāt guru saṃpadyate nānyathā /
column2: It happens that an action can be grave by reason that, if the field is the same, a certain adhiṣṭhāna rendets an action grave while another adhiṣṭhāna makes it light: for example, tokill one’s father and mother is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā mātāitroḥ prāṇātipātāt na tvevamadattādānādikāt / evamanyadapi yojyam /
column2: A grave action but to steal from one’s father and mother, to lie to them, etc. , is not grave by comparison.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya tu sarvāṇyadhimātrāṇi bhavanti tasyātyarthamadhimātraṃ guru karma veditavyam /
column2: One can explain in this same way the gravity resulting from the preparation, etc. When all these causes are great, the action is very grave;
when they are small, the action is very light.
Action “done” is distinguished from “accumulated” action.
What are the characteristics and conditions of accumulated action?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃcetanasamāptibhyāṃ niṣkaukṛtya vipakṣataḥ / parivārādvipākācca karmopacitamucyate // kathaṃ saṃcenataḥ /
column2: Action is termed “accumulated” by reason of its intentional character, by its completion, by the absence of regret and opposition, by its accompaniments, and by its retribution. By reason of its intentional character: Action done voluntarily or intentionally is accumulated action;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃcintya kṛtaṃ bhavati nābuddhipūrvaṃ na sahasā kṛtam / kathaṃ samāpattitaḥ /
column2: action done involuntarily or unconsciously, and action not done in haste, even if it is voluntary, is action that is “done.”
“By reason of its completion:” Some go to painful realms of rebirth through misdeeds; some by two; some by three (bodily, vocal, and mental misdeeds),;
some through one deed, through two, through three.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra yo yāvatā gacchati tasminnasamāpte kṛtaṃ tatkarma nopacitam samāpte tūpacitam / kathaṃ niṣkaukṛtyavipakṣataḥ /
column2: Since it's a rule that a person goes to a painful realm of rebirth through a certain quantity of actions, if this measure is not completed, the action is done, but not accumulated;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirvipratisāraṃ ca tat karma bhavati niṣpratipakṣaṃ ca / kathaṃ parivārataḥ /
column2: but when this measure is completed, it is accumulated, "By reason of the absence of regret and opposition" When remorse is absent, or when opposition,--confession, etc,—is absent, action is then termed "accumulated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akuśalaṃ cākuśalaparivāraṃ ca bhavati / kathaṃ vipākataḥ / vipākadāna niyataṃ bhavati /
column2: By reason of its accompaniments:" When an action is bad and has a bad escort: it is "By reason of its retribution:" Action is accumulated which necessarily gives forth retribution.
The same for good action.
Action which does not present these characteristics is done, but is not accumulated.
We have seen that a gift made to a Caitya by a person not detached from desire is a gift of benefit for him who made it.
But no one enjoys the thing given: how can this gift be meritorious?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvividhaṃ hi puṇyaṃ tyāgānvayaṃ tyāgādeva yadupapadyate paribhogānvayaṃ ca deyadharmaparibhogādyadutpadyate /
column2: The merits of the gift are of two types: 1. merit produced by abandoning, that is, the merit which results from the sole fact of. the merit produced by enjoying an object is the merit that results in joy for the person who receives it.
The merit of a gift to a Caitya is produced by abandoning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paribhogānvyaṃ puṇyaṃ nāsti / kathaṃ tatrāpratigṛhṇati kasmiṃścit puṇyam /
column2: How can a gift produce merit when no one receives it?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ sati pratigrahītari bhavitavyaṃ nāsatīti /
column2: We would answer this objection by asking why the gift would produce merit when someone receives it, and why it would not produce merit when no one receives it.
Because, in the second case, no one is satisfied or favored by the gift.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi hi puṇyaṃ parānugrahādeva syāt maitryādyapramāṇasamyagdṛṣṭibhāvanāyāṃ na syāt / tasmādeṣṭavyaṃ caityai 'pi puṇyam / maitryādivadagṛhṇati /
column2: If the satisfaction of a person who receives is a condition for merit, then you deny that the Immeasurable Meditations and the Meditation of Right View are meritorious.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā maitryādiṣvantareṇāpi pratigrāhakaṃ parānugrahaṃ vā puṇyaṃ bhavati svacittaprabhavaṃ tathābhyatīte 'pi guṇavati tadbhaktikṛtaṃ svacittāt puṇyaṃ bhavati /
column2: The gift to a Caitya thus produces merit, even though no one receives it, as is the case with compassion, etc. In the case of the Meditation on Compassion, no one receives, no one is satisfied, and yet merit arises for the compassionate person, through the very force of his thoughts of compassion. In the same way. Even though the Excellent Being has passed away, a gift to a Caitya made with devotion to him is meritorious by reason of the thought of the believer himself.
Should we conclude then that material offerings and worship are superfluous?
No, for the devotion which produces these actions very much outweighs the devotion of a person who worships and who gives in mind only.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā hi śatruvadhābhiprāyasya tatsamutthāpitaṃ kāyavākkarma / śatrusaṃjñayā tasminmṛte 'pi kurvato bahutaramapuṇyaṃ jāyate / nābhiprāyamātreṇa /
column2: When a person who has the intention of killing his enemy, contintes his bodily and vocal actions on the dead body of his enemy which this intention provokes, thinking, "This is my enemy," that is to say, he thinks, "This enemy is not yet dead," he obtains dermerit very much greater than he would have through merely the intention.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathābhyatīte śāstari tadbhaktisamutthāṃ dānamānakriyāṃ kurvato bahutaraṃ puṇyaṃ jāyate / na bhaktimātreṇa /
column2: In the same way, even though the Master has passed away, the person who does actions of giving and worship inspired through devotion obtains a much greater merit than he would have only through devotion.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi svakṣetre dānakriyāvījamiṣṭaphalaṃ bhavati tatkṣetre tarhyaniṣṭaphalaṃ bhaviṣyati /
column2: If a seed given to a good field bears an agreeable result, should we think that it bears a disagreeable result if given to a bad field?
Even seeded into a bad field, the gift bears agreeable results, for there is never opposition between the result and the seed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kukṣetre 'pi phalasya bījādaviparyayo dṛṣṭo mṛdvīkābījānmṛdvīkāphalamevotpadyate madhuraṃ nimbavījānnimbameva tiktam /
column2: From the seed of the vine, there arises solely the sweet fruit of the vine; from the seed of the vômba there arises only the sour fruit of the vôwba: even seeded into a bad field, the seed bears the result which is appropriate to it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ kukṣetre 'pi parahitādhyāśayapravṛttasya dānabījasyeṣṭameva phalaṃ nirvartate nāniṣṭam /
column2: In the same way, this seed which is the gift of a person who has the intention of being useful to another, even if placed into a bad field, can only produce an agreeable result.
Bat, through the evil of the field, the result will be small or almost nil.
We have explained meritorious work which consists of Giving, together with its related questions.
We must now explain meritorious work which consists of the Precepts.
Immorality is bad r%pa. Morality is the renouncing of immorality.
Bad rūpa is called immorality.
The renouncing of immorality, which is morality, is Ōf two types.

column2: Renouncing is vijñapti, the action by which one renounces.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca kevalaṃ dauḥśīlyādviratiḥ śīlam / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: Morality is not solely the renouncing of immorality.
It is farther, the renouncing of that which is prohibited by the Buddha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadapi na prakṛtyā dauḥśīlayaṃ bhagavatā ca buddhena pratikṣiptamakālabhojanādikaṃ tasmādapi dvidhā viratiḥ śīlam /
column2: To renounce that which is prohibited by the Buddha, the Blessed One—without being in and of itself immoral, for example renouncing meals at forbidden times—is also morality. This renouncing is also vijñapti and aviñapti.
He who has undertaken to observe the rules and who then violates them, commits immorality.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ tamāsena śīlam // viśuddhaṃ tu caturguṇam //
column2: The morality that we have just described, in short, is Pure, when it is endowed with the four qualities.
Morality endowed with the four qualities is pure;
it is impure in the contrary case. Not troubled by immorality, by the causes of immorality;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dauḥśīlyataddhetvahataṃ tadvipakṣaśamāśritam / dauḥśītyena tāvadanupahataṃ bhavati yathoktena dauḥśīlyena / hetunā 'pyanupahataṃ bhavati /
column2: it takes as its support the opposite of immorality and “Not troubled by immorality” we have described;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: lobhādibhiḥ kleśopakleśaiḥ dauḥśīlyavipakṣāśritaṃ ca bhavati / smṛtyupasthānasaṃniśritatvāt samāśritaṃ ca bhavati / nopapattiviśeṣāśritam / nirvāṇapariṇāmitavāt /
column2: “not troubled by the causes of immorality,” that is, by the éeśar and upaklefas, “it takes as its support the opposites of immorality, because jt relies oa the four smrṛtyupasthānas;

column2: and it relies on “peace,” not on rebirth inAccording to one opinion, morality is made pure by five causes: the purity of the deed itself, the purity of their attendants, the absence of disturbance from the viruses, its supervision through mindfulness, and its application to Nirvana.
According to another opinion, morality is of four types: the morality of fear, mercenary morality, a morality suitable to the parts of Bodhi, and pure morality.
We have explained morality.
Good absorption or good in absorption, is bhāvanā, meditation, soaking in, or impregnation.
What do we understand by samāhita, absorbed?
That which is absorption by its nature, and that which coexists with what is absorption by nature.
Why does "good absorption" receive the name of bhāvanā?
Because it perfumes, impregnates the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taddhi samāhitaṃ kuśalamatyarthaṃ cittaṃ vāsayati / guṇaistanmayīkaraṇātsaṃtateḥ / puṣpaistilabhāvanāvat /
column2: Good absorption impregnates the mind to an extreme degree, because it grasps the qualities of this good, in the same way as sesame seeds are impregnated by flowers in their grasping the odor of these flowers.
We have said that the result of giving consists of joys.
What result does one obtain from the precepts and from meditation?
Essentially, the precepts have heaven for their result;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dānamapi svargāya śīlaṃ prādhānyāt / śīlamapi visaṃyogāya /
column2: meditation has disconnection for its result, Giving also has heaven for its result, but the precepts are the principle, normative cause of it. Disconnection, or Nirvāṇa. has meditation for its cause, which, in the path of abandoning immediately produces disconnection from the defilements;
but the precepts contribute to it, since stilling and insight presuppose the precepts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sutra uktaṃ “catvāraḥ pudgalā brāhmaṇyaṃ puṇyaṃ prasavantī“ti /
column2: The Sūtra says that four persons produce “Brahmin” merit, brāhmapnṇya.
What is this merit?
According to the Vaibhāṣikas, this is the merit which has been defined above in order that we might know the measure of the action which has the marks of the Bodhisattva for its result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pūrvācāryās tu vyācakṣate / caturṇāṃ brāhmapuṇyatvaṃ kalpaṃ svargeṣu modanāt //
column2: The ancient masters said: Four possess Brahmin merit, because they are happy in the heavens for a kalpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvatā puṇyena kalpaṃ svargeṣu modate idaṃ brāhmaṃ puṇyam / brahmapurohitānāṃ kalpāyuṣkatvāt /
column2: The merit of such a measure that one is happy in heaven for a kalpa is the Brahmin merit, for the lifespan of the Brahmapurohitas is a kalpa.

We have studied material giving.

column2: The gift of the Dharmas is the correct teaching, not defiled, of the Sūtras etc. The gift of the Dharma is to teach, correctly and with a mind not defiled, the Śūtra and the other parts of Scripture.

It is recognized that whoever, understanding the sermons concerning the defects of Saṁsāra, the non-self, and the qunalities of Nirvāṇa, has his hairs stand on end and who pours forth tears, possesses the mokṣgabhāgīya rtoot of good; in this same way, one knows that there was a seed in the khalabila. when, in the rain, one sees a plant put forth shoots.

“Threefold action” is bodily, vocal, and mental action.
“Writing and carving” are bodily actions, industrious, together with what gives rise to this action, namely the collection of the mind and its mental states.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gaṇanā kāvyaṃ ca vākkarma / ityetāni pañcaskandhasvabhāvāni /

this refers to the mental enumeration of the dharmas.

teṣāṃ nityaṃ saṃnihitatvāt /	No, for if the anufayas were disassociated from the mind, they would always be present; and, consequently, if we suppose that they have a similar effect, then good would never be able to arise.
upalabhyate ca /	Now it is a fact that it does arise.
ataḥ “kuśalasya copalambhādaviprayuktāḥ atha ihānuśayāḥ” iti / tadidamajñāpakaṃ yasmādyo viprayuktamanuśayamicchati sa etatsarvamanuśayakṛtaṃ necchati /	Thus the anuśayas are not disassociated from the mind.
kleśakṛtamevecchati /	But again, the masters who consider the zvuś4yas as disassociated from the mind do not attribute this threefold activity to the aṉxśayas, but to the kleśa itself (that is, to the paryavasthāna, the active defilement; and this is not always present).
evaṃ tu sādhu yathā sautrāntikānām / kathaṃ ca sautrāntikānām /	The Sautrāntika theory is best.
kāmarāgasyānuśayaḥ kāmarāgānuśaya iti /	Kāmarāgānuśfaya means “anuśaya of kāmarāga’'.
na cānuśayaḥ saṃprayukto na viprayuktastasyādravyāntaratvāt /	But the anuśaya is neither associated with the mind, nor disassociated from it: foṟ it is not a separate thing.
prasupto hi kleśo 'nuśaya ucyate /	What is called aenuśaya is the kleśa itself in a state of sleep, whereas the paryavasthāna is the.
prabuddhaḥ paryavasthānam / kā ca tasya prasuptiḥ /	klefa in an awakened state.
asaṃmukhībhūtasya bījabhāvānubandhaḥ / kaḥ prabodhaḥ / saṃmukhībhāvaḥ / ko 'yaṃ vījabhāvo nāma /	The sleeping keśa is the non-manifested klefa, in the state of being a seed; the awakened kleśz is the manifested kesa, the kleśa in action.
ātmabhāvasya kleśajā kleśotpādanaśaktiḥ /	And by “'seed” one should understand a certain capacity to produce the é/eśz, a power belonging to the person engendered by the previous kleśa.
yathānubhavajñānajā smṛtyutpādanaśaktiryathā cāṅkurādīnāṃ śāliphalajā śāliphalotpādanaśaktiriti /	In this same way there exists in a certain person the capacity of producing a consciousness of memory, a capacity engendered by a consciousness of preception; in this same way the capacity to produce rice, which belongs to the plant, the shoot, the stalk, etc. , is engendered by the rice seed.
yastu kleśānāṃ bījārthamarthāntaraṃ vīprayuktamanuśayaṃ kalpayati tena smṛtibījamapyarthāntaraṃ kalpayitavyaṃ jāyate /	The masters for whom the seed of the k/eśa is a certain dharma distinct from the éleśu itself, disassocated from the mind and called an enusśuya, must admit a ḍharma existing in and of itself, disassociated from the mind and the cause of memory. And the same would hold for the plant. You do not have the right to explain “anuśaya of kāmarāga,” for the Sūtra clearly teaches that anuśaya is kāmarāga itself. The Sasatkasutra says, This person has agreeable sensation, and raganusaya.
yattarhi sūtre kleśa evānuśaya uktaḥ ṣaṭṣaṭke “so 'sya bhavati sukhāyāṃ vedanāyāṃ rāgānuśaya” iti /	But the Sutra says, “He has raganusaya;
bhavatīti vacanānnāsau tadaivānuśayaḥ / kadā tarhi bhavati /	” it does not say, “He then has raganusaya.
yadā prasupto bhavati /	” When this sensation ends, desire becomes dormant: then there is only the anusaya of desire, dormant desire, the seed of future awakened desire. Or rather, we would say, when the Sutra says raganusaya, it means raga: the first is the effect of the second, and the cause can be designated by the name of its effect.
hetau vā tadupacāra eṣa draṣṭavyaḥ /	The examination of this chance problem is finished.
tiṣṭhatu prasaṅgaḥ / śāstraṃ pravarttatām /	Let us return to our subject.
ya eṣa sūtre rāgasya bhedaḥ kṛtaḥ kāmarāgo bhavarāga iti /	What is this division that the Sutra sets up, attachment to? Agreeable objects and attachment to existence?
ko 'yaṃ bhavarāgaḥ /	What is attachment to existence?
bhavarāgo dvidhātujaḥ /	Attachment to existence arises from the two Dhātus.
rūpārūpyadhātujo rāgo bhavarāgaḥ kṛṭaḥ /	Attachment to Rūpadhātu and to Ārūpyadhātṭu is called bhavarāga, attachment to existence.
kiṃ kāraṇamevaṃ kṛtaḥ /	Why is the name of attachment to existence reserved for attachment to the two higher Dhātus?
antarmukhatvāttanmokṣasaṃjñāvyāvṛttaye kṛtaḥ //	It is so called because it is turned within, and in order to avoid the idea that these two Dhātus are deliverance.
samāpattirāgo hi teṣāṃ prāyeṇa /	The School explains: In general, the attachment of the beings in these two Dhātus is with regard to absorption. One says in general" because these beings also have attachments with regard to their palaces, vômānas, etc. This attachment, being an absorption, is turned within.
This is why it alone receives the name of attachment to existence.
existence means the person. Beings in absorption enjoy both the absorption itself and their own persons.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te ca sattvāḥ samāpattiṃ sāśrayā māsvādayanta ātmabhāvamevāsvādayanti kāmavītarāgatvāt /
column2: Being freed from attachment to pleasures, they only enjoy their own persons and not external objects.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ataḥ sa rāgo bhavarāga ityuktaḥ / punarete ṣaḍanuśayā abhidharme daśa kriyante /
column2: This is why attachment to the two higher Dhātus is called attachment to existence.
How is this?
There are five views: a belief in a self, false views, a belief in the extremes, the esteeming of views, and the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices: thus there are ten anmuayas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣaṇṇāmanuśayānāṃ dṛṣṭiṃ pañcadhā kṛtvā daśa bhavanti /
column2: By dividing views into five, there are six eṉuśayas, for a total of ten «nusfayas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañca dṛṣṭisvabhāvāḥ satkāyadṛṣṭirantagrahadṛṣṭirmithyādṛṣṭirdṛṣṭiparāmarśaḥ śīlavṛtaparāmarśaśca / yathā dṛṣṭisvabhāvāḥ rāgahpratidhho māno 'vidyā vicikitsā /
column2: five which are not views by nature, namely desire, anger, ptide, ignorance and doubt; and five which are views.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ete punarete daśānuśayā abhidharme 'ṣṭānavatiḥ kriyante / kāmāvacarāḥ ṣaṭtriṃśad rūpāvacarā ekatriṃśat ārūpyāvacarā ekatriṃśat / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: In addition the Abhidharma teaches that these ten anśayas make up thirty-six anuśayas in Kāmadhātu, thirty-one śayas in Rūpadhātu, and thirty-one anusayas in Ārāpyadhātu: in all ninety-eight anuśayas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāsato hyete 'nuśayāstraidhātukā darśanaprahātavyā bhāvanāprahātavyāśca / tatra tāvat kāmāvacarā darśanaprahātavyā dvātriṃśat / katame ta ityāha
column2: Thirty-two of the thirty-six anufayas of Kāmadhātu are abandoned by Seeing the Truths.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśaite saptasaptāṣṭau tridvidṛṣṭivivarjitāḥ / yathākramaṃ prahīyante kāme duḥkhādidarśanaiḥ //
column2: With the exception of three or two views, ten, seven, seven, eight anussayas are abandoned in Kāmadhātu by the Seeing of Suffering and the three other Truths respectively.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya ete daśānuśayā uktā ete kāmadhātau daśāpi duḥkhadarśanaheyāḥ santi /
column2: All of the above mentioned śayas are, in Kāmadhātu, abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ebhya eva sapta samudayadarśanapraheyāḥ / sapta nirodhadarśanaheyāḥ satkāyadṛṣṭimantagrāhadṛṣṭiṃ śīlavrataparāmarśaṃ ca varjayitvā /
column2: Seven are abandoned through the Seeing of Arising and through the Seeing of Extinction, with the exception of a belief in a self, a belief in the extremes, and the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices.
Eight are abandoned through the Seeing of the Path, with the exception of satkāyadr̥ṣṭi and antagrahadr̥ṭi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ityete kāmāvacarā dvātriṃśadanuśayā darśanaprahātavyāḥ / satyānāṃ darśanamātreṇa prahāṇāt / catvāro bhāvanāheyāḥ
column2: This makes thirty-two anśayas abandoned through Seeing, because the mere Seeing of the Truths suffices to abandon them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā rāgaḥ pratigho māno 'vidyā ca / dṛṣṭasatyasya paścāt mārgābhyāsena prahāṇāt /
column2: Namely desire, anger, ignorance and pride because one who has seen the Truths then abandons them through Meditation on the Path.
In this way sakāyadṛṣṭi, the view of self and of things pertaining to a self, is unique, being susceptible of being abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering;
and the same for antagrāhadr̥ṣṭi, the belief in extremes.
False views is of four types, abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering, Arising, Extinction, and the Path;
the same for the esteeming of bad views and doubt.
The esteeming of morality and ascetic practices is of two types, being susceptible of being abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and the Path.
Desire, anger, pride, and ignorance are of five types, being abandoned through the Seeing of each of the Truths, and through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kīdṛśā ete duḥkhadarśanaheyāḥ kīdṛśā yāvad bhāvanāheyāḥ /
column2: What is the characteristic or definition of the aenuśayas susceptible of being abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering? What is the definition of the aznuśayas susceptible of being?

When it is possible to abandon the object of an anuśaya through the Seeing of a certain Truth, it is said that this anuśaya can be abandoned through the Śeeing of this Truth. The others are abandoned through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tā eva dvādaśa dṛṣṭayo bhavanti catasro vicikitsāḥ pañca rāgāḥ pañca pratighāḥ pañca mānāṃ pañcāvidyā ityete kāmāvacarāḥ ṣaṭtriṃśadanuśayā bhavanti ta evāpratighāḥ punaḥ /
column2: There are thus twelve views, four doubts, five desires, five ignoṟances, and five prides: in all thirty-six anuśayas in Kāmadhātu.
The same, with the exception of the angers, for Rūpadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcaprakāraṃ pratighamapahāya ta eva rūpāvacarā ekatriṃśadanuśayā bhavanti /
column2: The same sorts of anuśayas, with the exception of the five angers, make up the thirty-one gnufayas of Rūpadhātu.
The same in Ārūpyadhātu.
The same thirty-one.
In this way, there are ninety-eight.
The Ābhidhārmikas say that the six enuṝayas make ninety-eight through the differences of their aspect, their mode of expulsion, and their sphere of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya ime darśanaprahātavyānuśayā uktāḥ kimete niyataṃ darśanenaiva prahīyante / netyāha / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: Among the ninety-eight enuśayas, eighty-eight are abandoned through Seeing because they are struck, destroyed through the “patiences””, and ten are abandoned through.

When they arise in Bhavāgra, the anuśayas which are struck by the kṣāntis are abandoned through Seeing and through Meditation. The word "kṣāntis" refers to the dharmajñānakṣāṇtis and the anvayajñānakṣāṇtis.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye bhavāgrabhūmijā anvayajñānakṣāntiheyā anuśayāste darśanaheyā eva na bhāvanāheyāḥ / śeṣajāḥ / dṛgbhāvanābhyām kṣāntivadhyā iti vartate /
column2: Among the anuśayas which are struck by the kṣāntis, those which are in Bhavāgra are abandoned only by Seeing, for only anvayajñānakṣāntis causes them to be abandoned.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣāsu bhūmiṣu yathāyogaṃ dharmānvayajñānakṣāntiheyā anuśayā āryāṇāṃ darśanaheyāḥ pṛthagjanānāṃ bhāvanāheyāḥ /
column2: Those in the eight bhāmis are abandoned either through Seeing or through Meditation: Āryans abandon them solely through Seeing, and not through Meditation, by means of the dharmajñānakṣāntis or the anvayajñānakṣāntis accordingly as they belong to the śayas of Kāmadhātu or of the higher spheres, whereas Pr̥thagjanas abandon them only through.
Meditation, and not though Seeing, for these can be abandoned through a worldly knowledge. The anuśayas which are not struck by the kṣgāntis are only abandoned through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvāsu bhūmiṣu ye 'nuśayā jñānavadhyāste ubhayeṣāṃ nityaṃ bhāvanāheyāḥ /
column2: The anṇfayas which are struck by the “knowledges”, at whichever stage they belong, are only abandoned through Meditation, whether they belong to an Āryan or to a Pṛthagjana. In fact, an Āryan abandons them through aenāsrava jñāna meditation, or pure knowledge, whereas a Pr̥thagjana abandons them through a worldly knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva hi bāhyakānāṃ darśanaprahātavyāḥ prahīyanta ityapare /
column2: Some other masters maintain that non-Buddhists cannot abandon the an#u&yas abandoned through Seeing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathāhi mahākarmavibhāgasūtre pūrvāntakalpakānāṃ ca śāśvatavādināmekatyaśāśvatikānām ahetusamutpattikānāṃ ca vītarāgāṇāṃ ca kāmadhātvālambanānāṃ dṛṣṭīnāṃ samudācāra uktaḥ /
column2: For the Mahākarmavibhāgasñtra teaches that erroneous views are active among the non-Buddhists in Kāmadhātu, although they may be “detached” (vitarāga, that is, having abandoned the attachments of Kāmadhātu, attachments that one abandons through Meditation. ) And the Brahmajālasṁtra says that some non-Buddhists are entirely detached from all sorts of views of Kāmadhātu: there are among them some persons who conjure up systems.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca rūpāvacarāṇāṃ kleśānāṃ kāmadhāturālambanaṃ vītarāgatvāt / tasmāt kāmapratisaṃyuktā eva tā aprahīṇā iti /
column2: Kāmadhātu cannot be, with regard to that which concerns it, the object of defilements of Rūpadhātu, because such persons are detached from Kāmadhātu. But they have not abandoned the views of Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭyutpādasamakālaṃ te parihīṇā devadatta iveti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas explain this difficulty by saying that those who are detached lose when they produce a view, in the manner that Devadatta lost his rddhi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭayaḥ paṇca nāmato nirdiṣṭā na tu svabhāvatastat kastāsāṃ svabhāvaḥ /
column2: We have seen that view is divided into five categories by reason of its aspect. What are the five views?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmātmīyadruvocchedanāstihīnā gradṛṣṭayaḥ / ahetvamārge taddṛṣṭiretāstāḥ pañca dṛṣṭayaḥ // ātmadṛṣṭirātmīyadṛṣṭirvā satkāyadṛṣṭiḥ /
column2: The view of self and things pertaining to self, the view of eternity and annihilation, the view of negation, the view that holds as high that which is low, and that which holds for cause and Path that which is not cause and Path: these are the five views.
To believe in a self and in things pertaining to self is satkāyadr̥ṣṭi it is termed sat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cayaḥ kāyaḥ saṃghātaḥ skandha ityarthaḥ / saccāyaṃ kāyaśceti satkāyaḥ pañcopādānaskandhāḥ /
column2: Sa$⁸āya means “an accumulation of perishing things,” that is, the five wpādānaskandhas. The expression satkāya is put forth in order to discard the idea of permanence—this is why one says snx⁴—and in order to discard the notion of a unity—this is why one says kāya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nityasaṃjñāṃ piṇḍasaṃjñāṃ ca tyājayitumevaṃ dyotitā / etatpūrvako hi teṣvātmagrahaḥ /
column2: In fact, if one believes that the skandhas are a self, this is because one first and foremost attributes a permanence and unity to them.
Satkāyadr̥ṣṭi means, then, “a view with regard to the satéāya.
” By this, all the views whose object is an impure belief in extremes, etc. , are views of the satkāya, that is, of the five rkandhas.
But even though they are views of the sa? kāya, they are not “views of the self or of things pertaining to self.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā gamyeta satkāyadṛṣṭiriyaṃ nātmani nātmīye veti / yathoktaṃ “ye kecid bhikṣavaḥ śramaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ātmeti samanupaśyantaḥ samanupaśyanti sarve ta imāneva pañcopādānaskandhāni“ti /
column2: ” Also, it is only the belief in a self or in things pertaining to a self that receives the name of sa$kāyadrṛṣṭi, for according to a declaration of the Blessed One, “Oh monk, any monk or Brahmin who in this world believes in a self, what he considers to be a self is.

”To believe in the eternity or in the annihilation of what one believes to be a self, is antagrāhadṛ̥ṣṭi, 'a view that grasps extremes,' for this is to falsely believe in the extreme thesis of eternity or annihilation.
The view that consists of negating that which really exists, the Truth of Suffering, etc. and which consists of saying nāsti, 'that is not,' is mithyādrṟṣṭi or false view.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvaiva hi viparītasvabhāvapravṛṭtā dṛṣṭirmithyādṛṣṭiḥ ekaiva tūktā / atiśayavattvāt durgandhakṣatavat /
column2: All falsely conceived views are 'false views', but only máhyādṛṣṭi receives this name because it is the most false of all, as the worst odor is called the bad odor.
It is a negation, whereas the other views are an affirmation or erroneous attribution.
The view which considers that which is bad, low, abandoned as good, or 'high,' is called dṛjṭiparāmarśa, 'the esteeming of bad views.
What does hna mean?
It refers to everything that is impure, because the Śaints abandon it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyāgrato grahaṇaṃ dṛṣṭiparāmarśaḥ / dṛṣṭyādiparāmarśa iti vaktavye ādiśabdalopaḥ kṛtaḥ /
column2: And the view that consists of esteeming this is called simply 'consideration.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ahetau hetudṛṣṭiramārge mārgadṛṣṭiḥ śīlavṛtaparāmarśaḥ / tadyathā maheśvaro na heturlokānām / taṃ ca hetuṃ paśyati prajāpatimanyaṃ vā /
column2: 'The view which considers as cause that which is not cause, ot as the path that which is not the Path, is called sīavrataparāmarśa: namely, to consider Maheśvara, Prajāpati, or any other entity which is not a cause of the world as a cause of the world;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: agnijalapraveśādayaśca na hetuḥ svargasya tāṃśca hetuṃ paśyati /
column2: to consider the rituals of suicide, entering into fire or drowning as a cause of a heavenly rebirth when they do not in fact procure heaven;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śīlavratamātrakaṃ sāṃkhyayogajñānādayaśca na mārgo mokṣāsya tāṃśca mārgaṃ paśyati /
column2: or to consider morality and ascetic practices as the only path to deliverance when they are themselves not the only path to deliverance, nor the “knowledges” of the Sāṁtṅkhyas and the Yogins which are not a path to deliverance;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atrāpi kilādiśabdalopaḥ kṛta ityetāstāḥ pañca dṛṣṭayo veditavyāḥ /
column2: and so too the rest. These are the five erroneous views. You have said that the erroneous view that regards as a cause of the world that which is not a cause of the world is the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices. In this hypothesis, the esteeming of morality and.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satyakāraṇe kāraṇadṛṣṭiḥ śilavrataparāmarśaḥ / kasmādayaṃ na samudayadarśanaprahātavyaḥ /
column2: ascetic practices is abandoned through the Seeing of the Truth of Arising, since it admits of error with regard to cause.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo hi kaścidīśvaraḥ prajāpatimanyaṃ vā kāraṇaṃ paśyati sa tannityamekaṃ cātmānaṃ kartāramabhiniviśya / tadyasmāt sa īśvarādiṣu nityātmaviparyāsāt pravartate /
column2: We would answer that those who consider the Lord or Prajāpati as a cause of the world regard the Lord and Prajāpati as eternal beings, one, personal, and active. It then follows that: If one clings to the idea that the Lord, etc. , is the cause of the world, this is by reason of false conceptions of permanence and personality.
Thus this clinging is to be abandoned through Seeing of Suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhadarśanādeva hi teṣu tau nityātmagrāhau prahīyete /
column2: The belief in the eternity or in the personality of the Lord or Prajāpati is abandoned through Seeing the single Truth of Suffering;
as a consequence the belief in their causality, which results from this first belief, is abandoned in the same way as this same first belief is abandoned.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastarhi jalāgnipraveśādibhiḥ svargopapattiṃ paśyati śīlavṛtena vā śuddhiṃ so 'pi duḥkhadarśanaprahātavya eva /
column2: The erroneous view that suicide through fire or drowning produces a heavenly rebirth, and the erroneous view that morality and ascetic practices produce by themselves purity, have nothing to do with the false conceptions of permanence and. It is through the Seeing of the Truth of Arising that one should abandon them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa hi śāstrapāṭhaḥ / “ye caivaṃ dṛṣṭaya evaṃvādino yadayaṃ puruṣapudgalo gośīlaṃ samādāya vartate mṛgaśīlaṃ kukkuraśīlaṃ,
column2: The Mūlaśāstra says, “There are some non-Buddhists who give rise to this view, who posit this theory: a person who adopts the habits of bulls, the habits of deer, or the habits of dogs, shall obtain purity, deliverance, and escape;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa tena śudhyati mucyate sukhaduḥkhaṃ vyatikrāmati sukhaduḥkhavyatikramaṃ cānuprāpnoti /
column2: he shall obtain the absolute going beyond of the happiness and suffering, and he shall reach the place beyond happiness and suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akāraṇaṃ kāraṇataḥ pratyeti śīlavrataparāmarśo duḥkhadarśanaprahātavyaḥ” iti vistaraḥ / kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇamasau duḥkhadarśanaprahātavyaḥ /
column2: One should know that all these types of considering as cause that which is not truly cause is the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices, which is abandoned through Seeing the Truth of Suffering.”

The doctrine of the Vaibhāṣikas is thus that these two opinions are to be abandoned through the Seeing the Truth of Suffering, because they allow error with regard to suffering. But his argument is carried too far!
All the defilements which have the impure for their object embrace error with regard.
Furthermore, we would ask what is the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices which is abandoned through Seeing the Truth of the Path?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo mārgadarśanaprahātavyālambanaḥ / so 'pi hi nāma duḥkhe vipratipannaḥ /
column2: If the Vaibhāṣikas answer, “The esteeming of morality and ascetic practices relative to the ḍharma which is abandoned through Seeing the Path, namely relative to one of the eight anuśfayas the first of which is wrong views,” we would then answer that this esteeming of morality and ascetic practices also supposes error relative to suffering. Moreover we do not see how the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices could be relative to a dharma to be abandoned through the Truth of the Path:

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya ca mārgālambanā mithyādṛṣṭirvicikitsā vā 'sti sa nāsti mokṣamārga iti paśyan vicikitsan vā kathaṃ tayā śuddhiṃ pratyeṣyati /
column2: How could a person who entertains wrong views or doubt relative to the Path, thinking “There is no Path,” or “Is there, or is there not, a Path? ,” imagine to obtain purification through this wrong view or through this doubt? If this person, taking up the path of deliverance imagined by the Sāṁkhyas, etc. , says, “This is the path;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athānyaṃ mokṣamārgaṃ parāmṛśya eṣa mokṣamārgo nāstītyāha / so 'pi tenaivānyena śuddhiṃ pratyeti na tayā mithyādṛṣṭyeti / tasyāpyasau mārgadarśanaprahātavyālambano na sidhyati /
column2: the Buddhist Path isnot the path, then this non-Buddhist imagines that he obtains purification through the path of the Sāṁkhyas, and not through wrong views relative to the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaścāpi samudayanirodhadarśanaprahātavyālambanayā mithyādṛṣṭyā śuddhiṃ pratyeti sa kasmānna taddarśanaheyaḥ /
column2: Furthermore, when a person imagines that he obtains purification through a wrong view abandoned through the Seeing of Arising or Extinction, why is his esteeming of morality and ascetic practices not abandoned through the Seeing of these same two Truths?
This point remains to be examined.
We have spoken of the two erroneous views of permanence and personality.
Are there only two errors?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catvāro viparyāsāḥ / anitye nityamiti / duḥkhe sukhamiti / aśucau śucīti /
column2: There are four errors: to hold that which is impermanent to be permanent, that which is suffering to be happiness, that which is impure to be pure, and that which is not a “soul” to be a soul or self.
What is the nature of these four errors?
One distinguishes four errors within the three views.
That part of the belief in extremes which is a view of permanence constitutes one error;
two parts of the esteeming of bad views constitute the errors of happiness and purity;

and thatSome other masters maintain that all satkāyadr̥ṣṭi, that is, not simply the idea of self but also the idea of things pertaining to self, constitutes āśmaviṣparyāsa, 'error with regard to the self.
How could the idea of things pertaining to a self be part of error with regard to the self?

In fact the Sūtra of the Viparyāsas does not indicate this. (It says simply, “It is an error to say that anātman is ātman”) and the following: “He who sees a self prevailing within the five skandhas sees ‘mine'”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmānameva tatra vaśinaṃ paśyennātmīyaṃ paśyatītyātmadṛṣṭirevāsau dvimukhī athāhamityetasmāt mameti dṛṣṭyantaraṃ syāt /
column2: [Thus the view of “mine” differs from the view of 'self,” a view from whence it derives. But we think that the view of self has two parts: to say '"I” and to say “mine.”

If the idea of “mine” were a view different from the idea of “I,” then the ideas expressed by other grammatical cases, such as maya or mahyam would thus constitute so many new views. Thus all belief in a self and in things pertaining.
Are not the other defilements errors because, in order for there to be error, a combination of three characteristics is indispensable?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmāt tribhiḥ kāraṇairviparyāsānāṃ vyavasthānam katamaistribhiḥ / vīparītataḥ /
column2: What are these three characteristics?
Reflective judgment and affirmation because they allow complete error.
The view of annihilation, a part of the belief in extremes, and false views are not affirmations or erroneous attributions, since they are directed towards the absence of existence.

The esteeming of morality and ascetic practices affirms that morality and practices suffice for purification: there is no total error in this, since morality and practices do contribute to purification.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye kleśā na santīrakā ato na viparyāsāḥ /
column2: The other defilements do not admit of reflective judgment, and as a consequence are not complete errors.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi sūtre ukta “manitye nityamiti saṃjñāviparyāsaḥ cittaviparyāso dṛṣṭiviparyāsa” iti /
column2: But the Blessed One said, "To consider the impermanent as permanent is an error of idea, an error of thought, and an error of view," and thus following for happiness, purity, and the self. Neither ideas nor thoughts admit of reflective judgment. Thus the definition proposed for error is inexact.
Thought and idea are termed "error" by reason of view.
Only view is error, but by virtue of the esteeming of bad views, ideas and thoughts associated with view and having its same aspect are also termed "errors.
Why does not the same hold for sensation and the other mental states associated with view?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: loke hi viparyastasaṃjño viparyastacitta iti prasiddhaṃ na punarviparyastavedana iti /
column2: Because one says in worldly language "error of idea," and "error of thought," but not "error of sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta ete viparyāsāḥ sarve 'pi srota āpannasya prahīṇā bhavanti / darśanapraheyatvāt dṛṣṭīnāṃ sasaṃprayogāṇām / dvādaśa viparyāsāḥ /
column2: A Srotaāpaṇṇa abandons all these errors for the Seeing of the Truths which brings about the abandonment of views also brings about the abandoning of the ideas and thoughts associated with these views.
Another School says: The error which consists of holding as permanent that which is impermanent contains three errors: error of idea, of thought and of view;
and the rest. We then have twelve errors instead of four errors.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāṣṭau darśanaprahātavyāścatvāro bhāvanāprahātavyāḥ / duḥkhe ca saṃjñā cittaviparyāsāvaśucau ceti nikāyāntarīyāḥ /
column2: Among these twelve, eight are abandoned through the Seeing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itarathā hi kathamantareṇa sukhaśucisaṃjñāmavītarāgasyāryasya kāmarāgaḥ saṃbhavediti /
column2: In fact the Āryans, who by definition have abandoned all the anuśayas that one abandons through Seeing the Truths, certainly possess ideas of happiness and purity, since, when they are not detached, they produce an attachment to pleasure.
The Vaibhāṣikas do not consider this reasoning as conclusive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi hi sukhaśucisaṃjñācittasamudācārādāryasya tadviparyāsāvīkṣyete / sattvasaṃjñācittasamudācārāttadviparyāsāvapi kiṃ neṣyete /
column2: From the fact that these Āryans have ideas of happiness and purity, you conclude that they have error relative to happiness and purity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi striyāmātmani ca vinā sattvasaṃjñāyā kāmarāgo yukta iti /
column2: You should say that they also have the error relative to self, since they certainly have the idea and thought of a living being: attachment to pleasure relative to a woman or relative to themselves evidently presupposses the idea and the thought of a being.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtre 'pi coktaṃ “yataśca śrutavānāryaśrāvaka idaṃ duḥkhamāryasatyamiti yathābhūtaṃ prajānāti / yāvat tasya tasmin samaye yo 'nitye nityamiti saṃjñāviparyāsaḥ cittaviparyāso dṛṣṭivīparyāsaḥ sa prahīyata” iti vistaraḥ /
column2: Moreover one reads in the Sūtras, “The Āryan Śrāvaka teaches true seeing and knowing: this is the Truth of Suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmād dṛṣṭisamutye eva saṃjñācitte viparyāsau nānye tatkāla bhrāntimātratvādalātacakracitra yakṣabhrāntivat / yattarhi sthavirānandenārthaṃ vāgīśamadhikṛtyoktaṃ
column2: At this moment the errors of idea, of thought and of view relative to theAs a consequence, only the ideas and thoughts provoked by erroneous views, or associated with erroneous views, are errors, and not the others, which are abandoned through Meditation. In fact, it happens that the Āryan, through an illusion which lasts only as long as he first sees an object, produces attachment to pleasure, such as the illusion caused by the circle of a fire-brand or by a painted Yakṣa. There is no error in the Āryan, but only a mistaken idea and thought.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “viparyāse ca saṃjñānāṃ cittaṃ te paridahyate” / nimittaṃ varjyatāṃ tasmācchubhaṃ rāgopasaṃhitam //
column2: But the Sthavira Ānanda said to the Āryan Vāgīśa, ““Your mind is burned by the error of your ideas.” How do we explain these words if one admits the thesis of the Vaibhāsikas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt sarva evāṣṭau saṃjñācittaviparyāsāḥ śaikṣasyāprahīṇā ityapare /
column2: As a consequence the Śaikṣa has not completely abandoned the eight errors of idea and thought.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te 'pi cāryasatyānāṃ yathābhūtaparijñānāt prahīyante / na vinā tenetyupāyasamā khyānānnāsti sūtravirodhaḥ /
column2: It is true that these errors are abandoned by means of correct knowledge of the Truths, and not without this knowledge. The Sūtra that the Vaibhāṣikas quote thus indicates the means of abandoning these said errors; there.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kiṃ dṛṣṭyanuśayasya eva bhedo nānyasya /
column2: The anuśaya of erroneous view is subdivided in this manner. Is it the same for the other enuiśayas?
It is the same for pride.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamityāha sapta mānāḥ māno 'timāno mānātimāno 'smimāno 'bhimāna ūnamāno mithyāmānaśca /
column2: There are seven types of pride: These are māna, adhimāna, mānātmāna, asmimāna, abhimāna, ūnamāna, and miūhyāmána.
In general, arrogance of the mind is called weāṉa.
Māṇa is subdivided on the basis of its different modes: 1.
Māṇa: when the mind makes itself lofty or develops pride by thinking, “I am superior” or “I am equal’'relative to an inferior or to an equal.
Adhimāṇa: to think, “I am superior,” “I am equal,” relative to an equal, or to a superior.
Mānātimānṇa: to think, “I am superior” relative to a superior.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañcopādānaskandhānātmata ātmīyato vā manyamānasyāsmimānaḥ / aprāpte viśeṣādhigame prāpto mayetyabhimānaḥ /
column2: Armimāṇna: when the mind prides itself by taking the five xpādānaskaṇdhas for its ''self'' and “'mine. Abhimāṇa to think that one possessess distinctions, that is, some dharmas, pure or impure, which abide in absoxrption, when one does not possess them.
Ūṇamāna: to think, “I am >Abhimāna has a substantial basis: it is revas$uka;

this is the pride of someone who has some qualities resembling the vifeṣas. Mithyāmāna has no substantial basis: this is the pride of someone who has no qualities whatsoever but who believes that he has some.
Yet the Śāstra teaches nine types of pride, mānavidhā, or sinraply vidhā, namely, 1.
“T am superior;
“I am equal;
“I am less good; ““Another is better than I;
