prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti me śreyānasti me sadṛśo 'sti me hīnaḥ /
column2: “He is equal to me; "He is worse than I; “Another is not better than I;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāsti me śreyānnāsti me sadṛśo nāsti me hīna” iti /
column2: “He is not my equal; ”” and 9. “"He is not worse than 1.”
Which of the seven types of pride make up these nine types?
Three make nine types.
These nine types come from three māṇas, namely māna, adhimāna and ūnṉamāna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra prathamaṃ trayaṃ dṛṣṭisaṃniśritāstrayo mānāḥ / atimānamānonamānāḥ /
column2: The first three are the three mānas which reside in the eṟṟoneous view of self. One first thinks “me.” Then there arises inOne has a type of māna which consists of saying, “I am better,” adhśmāna which resides in erroneous views, and the rest.
The second three are, in their order, ūnamāṉa, māna, aṅḍd aḍhimāna.
The third three are, in their order, māna, adhimāṇna, and ānamána.
We see that although we think “I am a bit inferior” relative to some one greatly superior, this is indeed ṉamāna, for the mind prides itself in this thought;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāsti me hīna ityatra kimunnati sthānam /
column2: but how can this type of zāṉa “He is not worse that I” be a locus of pride?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti sadṛśo yo 'bhiprete vare sattvarāśau nihīnamapyātmānaṃ bahu manyate / api cāstyeva jñānaprasthānavihito vidhiḥ / prākaraṇaṃ tu nirdeśaṃ parigṛhya śreyānasmītyekeṣu māno 'pi syādati māno 'pi mānātimāno 'pi hīnasamaviśiṣṭāpekṣayā /
column2: This is indeed a locus of pride, since one esteems oneself relative to a group of excellent persons which one regards as superior, even though one is really vastly inferior to them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athaite sapta mānāḥ kiṃprahātavyā ityāha dṛgbhāvanākṣyāḥ /
column2: How are the seven types of pride abandoned?
They perish through Seeing and Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etaduktaṃ bhavati sarve darśanabhāvanāprahātavyā iti yadbhāvanāheyamaprahīṇaṃ kimavaśyaṃ tadāryāṇāṃ samudācarati /
column2: All, including asmimána, perish, that is, are abandoned, through Seeing and Meditation. Must we believe that, among the Āryans, the an#śayas which are abandoned though Meditation and which have not yet been abandoned, are presently active?
Not necessarily.
The paryavasthāna of killing, etc. , is abandoned through Meditation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yena kleśaparyavasthānena saṃcintya prāṇivadhaṃ kuryādyāvanmṛṣāvādaṃ tad bhāvanāheyaṃ bhāvanāheyadharmālambanatvāt /
column2: The paryavasthāna of killing, refets to the defilement, kleśa, by which one voluntarily commits murder.
“Of killing, etc. ,” refers to killing, stealing, adultry, and lying. These paryavasthānas have the dharmas abandoned through Meditation for their object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vibhavecchā vibhavatṛṣṇā 'pi bhāvanāheyā / vibhavo nāma ka eṣa dharmaḥ /
column2: The thirst for non-existence, etc. Vibhavatṛṣṇā, “the thirst for non-existence,” is also abandoṅned through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: traidhātukī anityatā / tatra prarthanā vibhavatṛṣṇā / tathāśabdena bhavatṛṣṇāyāḥ pradeśo gṛhyate / “aho vatāhamairāvaṇaḥ syāṃ nāgarāja” ityevamādi /
column2: By viôbhava we mean the impermance of the three Dhātus, Kāmadhātu, etc. Desire which is directed to impermanence is called vibhavatrṛṣṇā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mānavidhā api bhāvanāprahātavyāḥ santītyuktamasmimamānaśca / na cāryasya saṃbhavanti vidhādayaḥ /
column2: Among the Āryans the various types of pride, etc. , and egotism, and bad regret, are impossible.
The types of pride, etc. are not produced, and do not become active among the Āryans, nor is there any longer “egotism” among them.
“Et cetera” signifies the en#uśayas enumerated above, the paryavasthānas of killing, the desire for non-existence and part of the desire for existence.
Why is this?
Because they are nourished by views. Because all these anuśayas are nourished by erroneous views: when their nourishment is burned up, they no longer have the power to arise.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satkāyadṛṣṭipuṣṭā hi mānavidhā asmimānaśca / ato bhagnapṛṣṭhatvāt notthātum punarutsahante / vadhādiparyavasthānaṃ mithyādṛṣṭipuṣṭatvāt /
column2: Māṇna and armitā,‘egotism,”’ are nourished through wrong views;
the desire for non-existence is nourished through the view of annihilation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavatṛṣṇāyāḥ pradeśaḥ śāśvatadṛṣṭipuṣṭatvāt / kaukṛtyaṃ nāpi cāśubham // akukśalaṃ cāpi kaukṛtyaṃ bhāvanāprahātavyam /
column2: and a part of the desire for existence is nourished.
Even though "bad regret" is abandoned through Meditation, it does not become active among the Āryans, because it is nourished by doubt.
Among the ninety-eight guuśayas, how many are universal? How many are not univeṟsal?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvatragā duḥkhahetudṛggheyā dṛṣṭayastathā / vimatiḥ saha tābhiśca yā 'vidyā 'veṇikī ca yā //
column2: Universal ṉufayas are the erroneous views and doubts which are abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and Arising, the ignorance which is associated with them, and independent ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhasamudayadarśanaprahātavyā dṛṣṭayo vicikitsā ca tābhiśca saṃprayuktā avidyā āveṇikī ca duḥkhasamudayaprahātavye cāvidyā / itīme ekādaśānuśayāḥ sabhāgadhātusarvatragāḥ /
column2: This makes eleven gnufśayas: the five erroneous views which are abandoned by the Seeing of Suffering; wrong views and the esteeming of views abandoned through Seeing of Arising;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sapta dṛṣṭayo dve vicikitse dve avidye sakalasvadhātvālambanatvāt /
column2: and two doubts and two ignorances abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and the Seeing of Arising. These eleven anxfayas are called "universal," "going everywhere," because they grasp the entire Dhātu as their object.
Objection: Do these universals grasp their entire Dhātu successively or all at once?
In the first hypothesis, the definition would apply to the other. anufayas as well;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha yugapat kaḥ sakalena kāmadhātunā śuddhiṃ pratyetyakāraṇaṃ vā kāraṇataḥ /
column2: and the second hypothesis is inadmissible: in fact no one considers the totality of the Dhātu as a means of purification; it is only certain practices which are the object of the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sakalaṃ nocyate sakalaṃ yugapadālambanta iti / api tu pañcaprakāramapi sarvaṃ yugapat /
column2: In the same way, no one considers the totality of the Dhātus as he cause of the world, but only Īévara, Prajāpati, etc. We do not say that the universals have the entire Dhātu for their object all at once, but rather they have the Dhātu in its five categories for their object: “entire” refers to the totality of types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamapi yatrātmadṛṣṭistatrātmatṛṣṇā yatrāgraśuddhidṛṣṭī tatra tatprārthanā tena ca māna iti tṛṣṇāmānayorapi sarvatragatvaṃ prāpnoti /
column2: But, if we understand universality in this way, desire and pride would also be univeṟsals. There is ātmadrṣṭi, 'a view that there is the self,” relative to the five upādānaskandhas: there will be ātmatṛṣṇā, 'desire for a self” relative to the same skandhas. There is agradrṣṭi, "“opinion that this is better” , and śuddhidṛṣṭi, 'opinion that this is a means of purification” relative to a certain object: and there will be desire relative to this same object.
And there will aisoLike a belief in a self, their object is abandoned through Seeing and Meditation. Or should we think that they are to be abandoned through Seeing or through Meditation.
The author answers: As their object is mixed, they are abandoned through Meditation.
Or rather, they are abandoned through Seeing, for they exist through the efficacy of the view.
Thirst and pride are special defilements and not general defilements.
This is why they are not universal.
We have seen that eleven e#»u7fśayas are universal in their Dhāṭu, in the sphere of existence wherein the person is born in whom they are found.
Among them, nine, with the exception of the two views, bear on the superior.
With the exception of a belief in a self and a belief in extremes, the nine other universals are also universals in a different Dhātu;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kadācittu visabhāgamekaṃ dhātumālambante kadācit dvau / “ye 'nuśayāḥ kāmapratisaṃyuktā rūpapratisaṃyuktālambanāḥ /
column2: they sometimes bear on a different Dhātu, sometimes on two, for it is said, “There are some anuśayas of the realm of Kāmadhātu which bear on the dharmas of the realm of Rūpadbātu, on the dharmas of the realm of Ārūpyadhātu, or on the dharmas of both the realms of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmapratisaṃyuktā ārūpyapratisaṃyuktālambanāḥ kāmapratisaṃyuktā rūpārūpyapratisaṃyuktālambanā” iti vacanāt /
column2: (And there are some anuśayas of the realm of Rūpadhātu which bear on the dharmas of the realm of Ārāpyadhātu).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā kāmadhātau sthito brahmaṇi sattvadṛṣṭiṃ nityadṛṣṭiṃ cojtpādayati tadā kathaṃ satkāyānta grāhadṛṣṭī visabhāgadhātvālambane na bhavataḥ /
column2: ” When some beings in Kāmadhātu produce the opinion that Brahmā is a being, the opinion that he is permanent, they then entertain a belief in a self and a belief in extremes with regard to a thing belonging to a different, superior Dhātu. Thus you are wrong to exclude these two erroneous views from the list of the universal anuśayas in a different Dhātu. But one does not have the idea of a self and of things pertaining to a self with regard to Brahmā: thus the idea that he is. A being is not a belief in a self.
And a belief in extremes is created by a belief in a self; thus the idea of the permanence of Brahmā is not a belief in extremes.
What sort of views would a belief in a living being and a belief in permanence be with respect to Brahmā?
The Ābhidhārmikas say that there are no erroneous views here, but only “false knowledge.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuto nu khalvetadanyā tadālambanā dṛṣṭireṣā na dṛṣṭiriti siddhāntastu pramāṇayitayaḥ /
column2: But why are the other false opinions which have Brahmā for their object considered as erroneous views, and not the two opinions of being and permanence? The Siddhānta serves as authority.
Are only the anṉuśayas universals?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prāptivarjyāḥ sahabhuvo ye'pyebhiste 'pi sarvagāḥ // sarvatragairanuśayaiḥ sahabhuvo ye 'pyanye dharmāste 'pi sarvatragāḥ prāptayastu naivam /
column2: With the exception of the prāptis, dharmas coexistant with the universal anuśfuyas are also universals.
“Coexistant ḍbarmas” refer to sensation, etc. Not the prāptis, because the prāpii and the prāpya (the thing adhered to) do not have the same result. Are universal anuśayas universal causes?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva syuḥ sarvatragānuśayā na sarvatrahetunā heturiti catuṣkoṭikaṃ kriyate /
column2: Future universal aenṉuśayas are not universal causes.
Coexistents of past and present universal z»wŚayas are universal causes, but not universal anṉuśayas.
Past and present universal anufayas are universal causes. Future coexistents of universal anuśayas are neither universal anuśayas nor universal causes.
Among the ninety-eight zṉ%5ayas, how many have a pure dharma for their object, that is, the Third and Fourth Truth, the Truth of Extinction and the Path? How many have an impure dharma?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mithyādṛgvimatī tābhyāṃ yuktā 'vidyā 'tha kevalā / nirodhamārgadṛggheyāḥ ṣaḍanāsravagocarāḥ //
column2: Wrong views, doubt, and the ignorance which is bound to them, and independent ignorance, abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction and the Path, make six anuśayas whose object is pure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirodhadarśanaprahātavyāstrayo 'nuśayā mithyādṛṣṭirvicikitsā 'vidyā ca tābhyāṃ saṃprayuktā '; 'veṇikī ca / mārgadarśanaprahātavyā apyeta eva trayaḥ / ityete ṣaḍanāsravālambanāḥ /
column2: Except for the six,—that is, the three @4#754yas abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction, namely wrong views, doubt, and the ignorance associated with them or independent of them, and these same three gzṉuśayas abandoned through Seeing the Path,—all the other ehuśayas have impure dḍharmas for their object.
The extinction of their own bhā%mi is the object of theAnuśayas which have extinction for their sphere;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra punaḥ svabhūmyuparamo mārgaḥ ṣaḍbhūminavabhūmikaḥ / tadgocarāṇāṃ viṣayo mārgo hyanyo 'nyahetukaḥ //
column2: the Path with its six or nine bhūmis, is the object of the aenuśfayas which have the Path for their sphere, for the Paths depend on one another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirodhālambanānāṃ mithyādṛṣṭyādīnāṃ svabhūminirodha evālambanaṃ kāmāvacarāṇāṃ kāmadhātoreva yāvat bhavāgrabhūmikānāṃ bhavāgrasyaiva /
column2: The three anuśayas which are abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction and which have Extinction for their objecr, do not have Extinction for their total object: when they belong to Kāmadhātu, they bear on Extinction in Kāmadhātu, and so on from bhāmi to bhāmi, until: when they belong to Bhavāgra they bear on Extinction in Bhavāgra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mārgālambanānāṃ kāmāvacarāṇāṃ ṣaḍbhūmiko dharmajñānapakṣo mārgaḥ sarva evālambanam /
column2: When they are in the realm of Kāmadhātu, the three anuśayas which have the Path for their object bear on the totality of the Path as well as on a portion of the dharmajñāna, with its six bhūmis (namely anāgamya, dhyānāntara, and the four Dhyānas).

When they are of the realm of Rūpadhātu or Ārūpyadhātu, these same anuśayas bear on the totality of the Path, and on a part of the enṉvayajñāna, with its nine bhūmis (namely the preceeding six and the first three Ārūpyas).
In fact the Paths are mutually dependent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyapi dharmajñānānvayajñāne apyanyonyahetuke natvanvayajñānaṃ kāmadhātupratipakṣa iti / na kāmāvacarā mārgālambanā anvayajñānapakṣānālambante /
column2: Although Zharmajñāna and anvayajñāna are mutually dependent, because guvayajñāna is not opposed to Kāmadhātu, the three anuśayas of the realm of Kāmadhātu which have the Path for their object do not have the Path which forms part of the envayajñāna for their object.

But the dharmajñāna which is opposed to Kāmadhātu is also opposed to Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu: consequently it will also be the object of the three anusuyas of these two Dhātus which have the Path for their object.

Dharmajñāná in its entirety is not opposed to Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu, for the dharmajñāṇṉa of suffering and arising are not opposed to these two Dhātus. [Thus it is not the object of the three anuśayas of these two Dhātus.
And dharmajñāna is not opposed to Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu in their entirety [for it is not opposed to the dharmas abandoned through seeing.

Thus it is not the object of the three anuśayas of these two Dhātus], because the first two dharmajñānas are not opposed to these Dhātus, and because the first category of. Why do not lust, anger, egotism, the esteeming of bad views, and the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices bear on pure dharmas, on the Extinction of Suffering or on the Path?
Lust does not bear on pure dharmas, because lust should be rejected.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: varjanīyo hi rāgaḥ yadi cānāsravālambanaḥ syānna varjanīyaḥ syātkuśaladharmacchandavat /
column2: The latent defilement of lust should be abandoned; but if it has pure dharmas for its object, it will not be rejected; in the same manner, the aspiration after good dharmas should not be rejected.
Anger does not, because pure dharmas do not do evil.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apakāravastuni hi pratigha utpadyate / na caivaṃ nirodhamāgauṃ /
column2: Anger arises with regard to a thing which does evil, and pure dharmas, the Extinction of Suffering or the Path, do not do evil.
Egotism and the two esteemings do not, because pure dharmas are calm, pure, and excellent.
One cannot pride oneself on Extinction or the Path, for they are calm.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhūtārthaśuddhitvānna tayoḥ śuddhigrāhaḥ śīlavrataparāmarśaḥ / agrau ca tau /
column2: The esteeming of morality and ascetic practices is to hold as athat which is not such: the pure dharmas are really purification, so one cannot have a false conception of purity, with regard to them.

The esteeming of bad views is to hold as excellent that which is vile: now the pure dharmas are what are best, so one cannot have a false conception of excellence, with regard to them. Among the ninety-eight anṉuśayas, how many become anuśaya from the fact of being an object?
How many become eznuśayana solely through association, solely by reason of being dharmas associated with the mind, sensation, etc. ?
Universal aṉuśayas, relative to the object, become anuśayaṉa in all their spheres;
the noṉ-universals, in their one category.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye sarvatragā anuśayāste sakalāṃ pañcaprakārāmapi svāṃ bhūmimālambanato 'nuśerate / asarvatragāstu svasyāṃ bhūmau svameva nikāyamālambanato 'nuśerate nānyam /
column2: From the point of view of the object, the universal anuśayas become anuśayana, that is, '“become lodged in”” the five categories of their sphere;
the other in one category: the enuśayas that one abandons through the Seeing of Suffering become anuśayana in the dharmas that one abandons through the Seeing of. Suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yāvadbhāvanāprahātavyā bhāvanāprahātavyameva nānyam / utsargaṃ kṛtvā 'pavādaṃ karoti
column2: The anuśayas that one abandons through Meditation become anuruśayana in the dharmas that one abandons through Meditation. This general rule calls for more precision.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nānāsravordhvaviṣayāḥ anāsravālambanā anuśayā naivālambanato 'nuśerate / nāpyūrdhvabhūmyālambanāḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam / tadālambanasya vastunaḥ asvīkārādvipakṣataḥ /
column2: Not the ṉśyas that bear on the pure ḍharmas or a higher sphere, because their object is not “made one’s own” and opposes the anuśayas. The six anuśayas which have the pure dharmas—Nirvāṇa or the Path—for their object, and the nine enuayas which have a higher sphere for their object do not become anuśayana in the object, because one does not do this thing by oneself either through the “view of self” or through desire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaddhi vastvātmadṛṣṭitṛṣṇābhyāṃ svīkṛtaṃ bhavati tatrānye 'pyanuśayā anugamayitumutsahante / ārdra iva paṭe rajāṃsi saṃsthātum /
column2: Other anuśayas would apply to the thing which one considers as the self, or which one makes one’s own through desire, and they become aenruśayana, as dust is applied to a wet piece of cloth.
But the pure dharmas and the higher bhāmis are not susceptible of being considered as 'self' or as 'pertaining to self': thus the anuśayas which have them for their object do not become.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato na tadālambanāsteṣvanuśerate / yastvihasthastāṃ bhūmiṃ prārthayate /
column2: We would remark in fact that the desire that seeks either the pure dharmas or a higher sphere is not the enuśaya called “desire,” but rather “an aspiration for good dharmas”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalo 'sau dharmmacchandaḥ vipakṣabhūtau ca nirvāṇamārgau tadālambanānāṃ kleśānāmūrdhvā ca bhūmiradharāṇām /
column2: Further, the pure dharmas, Nirvāṇa or the Path, are opposed to the kleśfas which take them as their object;
the dharmas of a higher bhūmi are opposed to the kleśas of a lower bhūmi: as a consequence the k/eśas cannot become anuśayana there, that is, install themselves there;

in the same way that the sole of the foot cannot install itself on a rock which is red hot with fire. We have up to now understood the word enusśfayana, anuśete, as “ṭo become anuśayana,” in the sense of “to install,” or ““to become lodged in.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ānuguṇyārtho 'trānuśayārthaḥ / na ca te tadanuguṇā ityapare /
column2: According to some other masters, an#uśayana should be understood as ānuguṇya. Nirvāṇa, etc. , is not favorable to the arising and development of wrong views: in the same way that one says that if a person who has a cold takes a bitter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vātikasya rukṣānanuśayanavat / ata uktā ālambanato 'nuśerate / yena yaḥ saṃprayuktastu sa tasmin saṃprayogataḥ //
column2: In medicine, there is no increase in the cold due to the medicine.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anuśareta iti vartate / yo 'nuśayo yena dharmeṇa saṃprayuktastasmin saṃprayogato 'nuśete /
column2: Any anushayana which is associated with a certain dharma becomes anushayana through association with this dharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvadaprahīṇa iti viśeṣaṇārthastuśabdaḥ / syuranuśayā nānāsravālambanā na visabhāgadhātusarvatragāḥ /
column2: With a certain dharma, that is, with sensation, etc. The word eva indicates reservation: "'as long as the anushaya is not abandoned. Are there any anushayas which do not have the pure dharmas for their object, which do not have a superior Dhātu for their object yet which become anushayana solely through association with and not from the fact of the object?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te cānuśayāḥ saṃprayogato 'nuśayīrannālambanataḥ na syurvisabhāgabhūmisarvatragā anuśayāḥ / eṣāmaṣṭānavateranuśayānāṃ katyakuśalāḥ katyavyākṛtāḥ /
column2: Yes, universal anushayas which have a superior bhumi for their object (namely the universal anushayas of the First Dhyana which have the three higher Dhyanas for their object). Among the ninety-eight dhyānas, how many are bad, and how many are morally neutral, that is, without retribution?
All the "higher" dhyānas are morally neutral.
[The belief in a self, a belief in extremes, and ignorance are neutral in Káāmadhātu. The other anushayas, here, are bad. ]All the nuśayas beloṉging to Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu are neutral.
In fact, all defiled dharmas, when they bear retribution; bear painful retribution.
Now suffering does exist in these two spheres, for no causes for doing evil to others are present there.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāme satkāyadarśanam / antagrāhaḥ sahābhyāṃ ca mohaḥ
column2: The belief in a self, a belief in extremes, and ignorance are neutral in Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātau satkāyāntagrāhadṛṣṭī tatsaṃprayuktā cāvidyā avyākṛtāḥ / kiṃ kāraṇam /
column2: In Kāmadhātu, a belief in a self, a belief in the extreres, and the ignorance which is associated with them, are neutral.
In fact, these anuśayas are not in contradiction to giving and other good deeds.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ahaṃ pretya sukhī bhaviṣyāmīti dānaṃ dadāti śīlaṃ rakṣati /
column2: One thinks, “May I be happy in the future! ,” and one give gifts and observes the precepts.

The erroneous view of annihilation is favorable to deliverance. This is why the Bleesed One said, “Among the doctrines of the Tīrthikas, the best is that which says, I do not exist, things of mine do not exist;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evoktaṃ bhagavatā “etadagraṃ bāhyakānāṃ dṛṣṭigatānāṃ yaduta no ca syāṃ no ca me syāt na bhaviṣyāmi na me bhaviṣyatī“ti /
column2: I shall not exist, things pertaining to me shall not exist.”

These two views—a belief in a self and a belief in the extremes—are only aberrations relative to things which constituteThe pseudoperson; they do not being about harm to another: thus they are morally neutral.

But these different reasons—because they are not in contradiction to giving, etc—could be applied to the “desire for heaven” and to egotism, which should thus also be neutral; but the School does not admit this. Some ancient masters also say, “An innate belief in a self, which is to be found among the savage animals and birds, is neutral. But a cogitated belief in a self is bad.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yā mṛgapakṣiṇāmapi varttate / vikalpitā tvakuśaleti pūrvācāryāḥ /
column2: (The same bolds for an innate and cogitated belief in the extremes).
The other anṉuśayas, here, are bad.
The other nuśayas of Kāmadhātu are impure, that is, bad.
Among the ninety-eight ś4yas, how many are roots of evil? How many are not?
Lust, anger and māḍi, in Kāmadhātu, are roots of evil.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātau sarvarāgaḥ sarvapratighaḥ sarvo moho 'nyatra satkāyāntagrāhadṛṣṭisaṃprayuktādyathākramam / trīṇyakuśalamūlāni lobho 'kuśalamūlaṃ dveṣo moho 'kuśalamūlam /
column2: All lust, all anger, and all māḍi (that is, all delusion or n0ba) belonging to Kāmadhātu—with the exception of the delusion which is a belief in a self and the belief in the extremes—are, in this order, the three roots of evil, greed.
A belief in a self and a belief in the extremes are not roots of evil, for a root of evil is only that which is bad and is only a root of evil.
The other anuśayas are not roots of evil.
How many dharmas are neutral roots?
How many are not?
Three roots, desire, ignorance, and mat are neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: setyavyākṛtatāṃ darśayati yā kācidavyākṛtā tṛṣṇā avidyā prajñā cāntato vipākajā api sarvā 'sāvavyākṛtamūlamiti kāśmīrāḥ /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas of Kāśmīr hold that desire, ignorance, and prajñā which are neutral, of whatever type they are up to and including the prajñā which arises from retribution, are neutral roots.
The others are not roots, because their modality is of duality and elevation.
Doubt cannot be regarded as a root, being twofold and mobile by nature.
Egotism, being "an elevation" of the mind, is not a root, since it consists of elevation, the opposite of a root.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vividhasmṛtimūlāni hi sthirāṇyadhovṛttīni ca loke dṛṣṭānnīti / catvāryeveti bāhyakāḥ / bāhyakā ścatvāryavyākṛtamūlānīcchanti / tṛṣṇādṛṅ mānamohāste sa ityavyākṛtā iti darśayati /
column2: For in this world roots are firm and reach downward.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avyākṛtā tṛṣṇā dṛṣṭirmāno 'vidyā ca / kiṃ kāraṇametānyavyākṛtamūlānīcchanti / dhyāyitritvādavidyayā //
column2: Four: desire, views, egotism, and delusion which are neutral;
in fact there are three contemplations based on ignorance. One can distinguish "absorption of desire".
Now these contemplations are such by reason of delusion or ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te cāvidyāvaśādbhavantīti / yāni sūtre caturdaśāvyākṛtavastūni kiṃ tāni avyākṛtatvāt / netyāha / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: Are the fourteen "undefined points" of which Scripture speaks so called because they are neutral in the sense that we have just studied? In the Sūtra a neutral question is a question which should be set aside: that is, this type of question is called neutral, not answered, because it should be set aside, or rejected.
The object of such a question is termed "an undefined point.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ sarve janiṣyanta iti vibhajya vyākarttavyaṃ saṃkleśā janiṣyante na niḥkleśā iti /
column2: If one asks, "Will all being be reborn? " one should answer by distinguishing, "Beings endowed with defilements will be reborn; being freed from defilements will not be reborn.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ manuṣyo viśiṣṭo hīna iti paripṛcchayya vyākattevyam /
column2: If one asks, "Is a person superior or inferior?
," one should answer by the question, "In comparison with whom?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi brūyād devāniti / hīna iti vyākarttavyam / atha brūyādapāyāniti /
column2: If he answers, In comparison with the gods," one should answer, "He is inferior.
If one answers, In comparison with beings in the painful realms of rebirth,"one should answer, "He is superior.
If one asks, "Are the skandhas the same thing as a satva or living being, or are they different? ," this is a question that is to be rejected because the thing called a "living being" does not exist.
In the same way one would reject the question, 'Is the child of a sterile woman white or black?
How can you say that one has responded to this fourth question, since one did not answer whether the skandhas are, yes or no, identical to a living being?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ vyākaraṇāt / apara āha / idamapyekāṃśavyākaraṇaṃ yanna sarve janiṣyanta iti / yastu pṛcchedye mariṣyanti kiṃ te janiṣyanta ityetadvibhajyavyākaraṇīyaṃ syāt /
column2: This question is answered by saying, "This question is to be.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: manuṣyeṣu cobhayamasti hīnatvaṃ viśiṣṭatvaṃ cāpekṣikamityubhayamekāṃśena vyākarttavyam /
column2:
A human being in fact is at one and the same time superior and inferior according to the point of comparison.
tadyathā vijñānaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇaṃ ceti ekāntena tu pṛcchato naikāntavyākaraṇāt vibhajyavyākaraṇaṃ yujyate / skandhebhyo 'nyaḥ sattva ityetadavyākṛtameva /	In the same manner as if one were to ask, “Is consciousness a cause, or is it a result? ,” one should answer, “It is a cause with respect to its result, and it is a result with respect to its cause.” But, says the author, to someone who asks in a categorical manner “Is a person superior or inferior?
na cāvyākaraṇameva vyākaraṇaṃ yujyata iti /	,” it is not suitable to respond.
yastu sthāpanīyaḥ praśnaḥ sthāpanīyatvena vyākriyate /	Categorically, one must first be assured of the intention of the questioner. The Abhidharmikas say: A categorical response: If someone asks, Is the Blessed One the Arhat Samyakṣaṁbuddha? Is the Dharma that he speaks well spoken? Is the Saṁgha of the Śṛāvakas well instructed? Is physical matter impermanent? Is consciousness impermanent?
Can Suffering be known?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ābhidharmikā āhuḥ / “tathāgato bhagavānarhan samyaksaṃbuddhaḥ svākhyāto 'sya dharmaḥ supratipannaḥ śrāvakasaṃghaḥ rūpamanityaṃ yāvadvijñāna duḥkhaprajñaptiryāvanmārgaprajñaptirekāṃśena vyākarttavyamarthopasaṃhitatvāt /
column2: Can the Path be known? ," then to these questions one should answer in a categorical manner, by reason of the superior benefit.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vibhajjavyākaraṇaṃ nāma yadi kaścid brūyāddharmān vadeti sa vaktavyo bahavo dharmā atītā anāgatāḥ pratyutpannāḥ katamān vadāmīti / yadi brū yādatītāniti /
column2: An answer by distinguishing: If a person asks, "I desire that the Venerable One teaches me the dharmas," one should distinguish, "The dharmas are numerous, past, present, and future: which do you desire that I should teach you?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa vyaktavyo 'tītā api bahavo rūpaṃ yāvadvijñānamiti /
column2: If he answers, Teach me the past dharmas," one should distinguish, "The past dharmas are numerous: rāpa, vedanā, saṁjñā, saṁskāras, and vijñāna.
If he asks, Teach me concerning r%pa," one should.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa vaktavyo rūpamapi trividhaṃ kuśalamakuśalamavyākṛtaṃ ca / yadyāha kuśalamiti / tadapi saptaprakāraṃ prāṇātipātādviratiryāvatsaṃbhinnapralāpāditi / yadyāha prāṇātipātādviratimiti /
column2: If one asks, "Teach me concerning the good," one should distinguish, "There are seven types of good rāpa: abstention from killing and abstention from idle words.
If one asks, "Teach me abstention from killing," one should distinguish, "It is of three types, arisen from the three roots of good, non-greed, non-anger, and non-ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyāhālobhajāmiti / alobhajā 'pi dvividhā vijñāptyavijñaptibhedādityevaṃ vibhajya vaktavyamiti /
column2: If one asks, "Teach me the abstention from killing arisen from non-greed," one should distinguish, "It is twofold, vijñap#i and avijñapt; Which do you desire that I teach you?
A response by a question: The same question, put by a false-hearted person, is a question to which one should respond by another question.

If such a person asks, "I desire that the Venerable One teach me the dbarmas," one should counter-interrogate him, "The dharmas are numerous: which do you desire that I teach you? But one need not establish the distinctions (past, present, and future dharmas); one should continue to counter-interrogate.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tu vibhaktavyā yāvattūṣṇim vā tiṣṭhati svayaṃ vā vyākarotīti /
column2: him until the questioner remains silent or he himself explains. But if a good-hearted person and a false-hearted person do not question you, but content themselves with expressing a desire, “Teach me the dharmas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā tau na kiñcit pṛcchataḥ kevalamadhyeṣayataḥ tayośca na kiñcit vyākriyate kevalaṃ paripraśnyete tat kathamanayoḥ praśno bhavati kathaṃ vā vyākaraṇam /
column2: ” and if, on the other hand, one does not answer them, if one does not explain to them, and if one is content to interrogate them, “Which dharmas shallI teach you? ,” how can you say that there is a question and a response?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo hhi panthānaṃ brūhītyāha kim tena panthā na pṛṣṭo bhavati /
column2: The author answers: He who says, “Teach me the Path,” asks concerning the Path, exactly as if he has said, “Which is the Path? ” One the other hand, through this counter-interrogation, one explains to the questioner concerning his questions: is the Path then not explained ?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paripṛcchayaiva vyākaraṇāt kathaṃ na paripṛcchāvyākaraṇaṃ bhavati /
column2: If this is the case, then is there an answer by means of a question in the second and third type of question? No, the responses differ, for sometimes there is distinction, and sometimes there is no distinction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sthāpanīyastu yathā antavān loko 'nantavānityevamādi sūtrāntādeva tu praśnavyākaraṇānāṃ lakṣaṇaṃ draṣṭavyam / bhadantamahāsāṅghikāḥ sūtraṃ paṭhanti /
column2: A question to be rejected: If one asks “Are the number of persons finite or infinite, etc. ? ,” then this question should be.
One may find in the Sūtra itself the definition of these four questions and answers: the venerable Mahāsāṁghikas read a Sūtra which says, “Bhikṣus, there are four responses to questions.
What are these four?
There are some questions which one should reply categorically.
there are some questions which one should reject.
What is the question to which one should respoṇd categorically?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarve saṃskārā anityā ityayaṃ bhikṣava ekāṃśavyākaraṇīyaḥ praśnaḥ /
column2: When one asks if all the rkandhas are impermanent.
What is the. question to which one should respond by distinguishing?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃcetanīyaṃ karma kṛtvā kiṃ prativedayata ityayam vibhajyavyākaraṇīyaḥ praśnaḥ /
column2: When someone asks what retribution in sensation a voḻuntary action requires.
What is the question to which one should repsond by a question?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃjñāsu puruṣasyātmā utāho 'nyāsaṃjñā anya ātmeti pṛṣṭena satā paripraṣṭavyaḥ katamaṃ punarāyuṣmānātmānaṃ pratyeti /
column2: When someone asks if re is the soul of a person, one should counter-interrogate, “My friend, what do you think of the soul?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa cedevaṃ vadedau dārikaṃ khalvahayāyuṣmannātmānaṃ pratyemi / evaṃ satyanyā saṃjñā anya ātmetyevaṃ vacanīyaḥ / ayaṃ hi paripṛcchya vyākaraṇīyaḥ praśnaḥ /
column2: ,” and if he answers, “My friend, I think that the soul is coarse,” one should respond that the ra is other than the soul. (Dīgha, i.
What is the question to be rejected?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā śāśvato loko 'śāśvataḥ / śāśvataścāśāśvataśca / naiva śāśvato nāśāśvataḥ / antavānantataḥ / antavāṃścānantaśca / naivāntavānnānantavān / bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇānna bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maraṇāt yāvadanyo jīvo 'nyaccharīramityayaṃ bhikṣavaḥ sthāpanīyaḥ praśna” iti /
column2: When someone asks if the world is eternal, non-eternal, eternal and non-eternal, neitherWithin a certain person, aṅ zṉuśaya or latent defilement attaches itself to a certain object;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya pudgalasya yo 'nuśayo yasminnālambane 'nuśete sa tena tasmin saṃprayuktaḥ /
column2: this person is bound to this object by this anuśaya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idaṃ tu vaktavyamatīte na kasmin yāvat pratyupanne na kasminniti /
column2: We must examine to what object a person is bound by a past, present, or future grufaya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāsata ime dvividhāḥ kleśāḥ / svalakṣaṇakleśāśca rāgaprativamānāḥ /
column2: From this point of view the anuśayas ot kleśas are of two types: specific kleśar, namely lust, anger, egotism;
and general kleŚśas, namely views, doubt, and ignorance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rāgapratighamānaiḥ syādatītapratyupasthitaiḥ / yatrotpannā 'prahīṇāste tasmin vastuni saṃyutaḥ //
column2: One is bound by lust, anger, and egotism, past and present, to the object from whence they have been produced without their having been abandoned.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atītāḥ pratyutpannāśca rāgapratighamānā yasmin vastunyutpannā na ca prahīṇāstasmin vastuni taiḥ saṃyuktaḥ /
column2: When the specific klefas have arisen with respect to a certain object—an object past, present or future, an object abandoned through Śeeing, etc. —and is thus found in the past or in thepresent, when they have not been abandoned, the person in whom they are produced is bound to this object by these specific.
For, being specific, they are not necessarily produced within all persons with respect to all things, but rather within a certain person with respect to a certain thing.
One is bound to all objects by the same future, since they are mental states.
One is bound to any and all objects, past, present, and future, by these same specific future, since they belong to the manovijñána.
For the sphere of the māṇas is tritemporal. One is bound to the object of their time period by the same future, since they are not mental states.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyai rāgapratighairanāgatairanāgata eva vastuni saṃyuktaḥ / ke punaranye /
column2: One is bound to future objects through future lust and anger which differ from the preceding—that is, non-mental states in a relationship with the five sense consciousnesses.
The five consciousnesses, in fact, cognize only objects contemporaneous to.
Sometimes this rule concerns only future lust and anger of the nutpattidharmin or “destined to arise” category.
It is otherwise when they are not destined to arise.
Not destined to arise, one is bound everywhere by the same.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anutpattidharmabhiḥ pañcavijñānakāyikairapi sarvatra vastuni saṃyuktaḥ / traiyadhvike 'pi
column2: “Everywhere,” this is, to all objects, past, present, and future.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣaistu sarvaiḥ sarvatra saṃyutaḥ // ke punaḥ śeṣāḥ / dṛṣṭivicikitsā 'vidyāstraiyadhvikāḥ /
column2: One is bound everywhere by the others, whatever they are.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taiḥ sarvairapi sarvasminvastuni saṃyuktaḥ / sāmānyakleśatvāt / yāvadaprahīṇā ityadhikāro 'nuvarttata eva /
column2: One is bound to all the objects of the three time periods and the five categories, according to the case, by the other, general kleśas—which, having for their object the five xpādānaskandhas, are produced within all and relative to all—in whatever period the said kleśas belong.
Do the kleśas, and past and future objects, really exist?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyasti sarvakālāstitvātsaṃskārāṇāṃ śāśvatatvaṃ prāpnoti / atha nāsti /
column2: If one says that they really exist, one admits that conditioned things always exist and are thus eternal;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ tatra tena vā saṃyukto bhavati visaṃyukto vā /
column2: if they do not exist, how is it possible to say that a person is bound to these objects by the kleśas, or that he is liberated from them?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na saṃskārāṇāṃ śāśvatatvaṃ pratijñāyate vaibhāṣikaiḥ saṃskṛtalakṣaṇayogāt / pratijñāyate tu viśadaṃ sarvakālāstitā
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas maintain that past and future dharmas really exist. Exist conditioned things nevertheless are not eternal for they are endowed with the characteristics of conditioned things. In order to better illustrate their position we present, in summary fashion, their doctrine: The dharmas exist in the three time periods.
Why is this?
Because the Blessed One has said it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ hi bhagavatā '“tītaṃ ced bhikṣavo rūpaṃ nābhaviṣyanna śrutavānāryaśrāvako 'tīte rūpe 'napekṣo 'bhaviṣyat / yasmāttarhyastyatītaṃ rūpaṃ tasmācchrutavānāryaśrāvako 'tīte rūpe 'napekṣo bhavati /
column2: The Blessed One taught in his own words the existence of the past and the future, “Monks, if past did not exist, the learned holy Śrāvakas would ‘not take into consideration’ past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgataṃ cedrūpaṃ nābhaviṣyat na śrutavānāryaśrāvako 'nāgataṃ rūpaṃ nābhyanandiṣyat / yasmāttarhyastyanāgataṃ rūpamiti” vistaraḥ /
column2: If future rūpa did not exist, the learned holy Śrāvakas would ‘ʻnot delight inʼ future. It is because future exists that the learned holy Śrāvakas.
Because mental consciousness preceeds from two.
The Blessed One implicitly teaches the same doctrine when he says, “Consciousness is produced by reason of two.
What are these two?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣū rūpāṇi yāvat mano dharmā iti /
column2: The organ of sight and a visible thing. the anṇas and the dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asati vā 'tītānāgate tadālambanaṃ vijñānaṃ dvayaṃ pratītya na syāt / evaṃ tāvadāgamato 'styatītānāgataṃ yuktito 'pi /
column2: Now if the past and futute dharmas do not exist, mental coṅsciousness which has them for its object would not arise.
Because it has an object.
A consciousness can arise given an object, but not if an object is not present.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cātītānāgataṃ na syādasadālambanaṃ vijñānaṃ syāt /
column2: If past and future things do not exist, there would be consciousness without an object;
thus there is no consciousness without an object.
And because the past bears a result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cātītaṃ na syāt śubhāśubhasya karmaṇaḥ phalamāyatyāṃ kathaṃ syāt /
column2: If the past does not exist, how can good and bad action give forth a result?
In fact, at the moment when the result is produced, the retributive cause is past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādastyevātītānāgatamiti vaibhāṣikāḥ / avaśyaṃ ca kilaitatsarvāstivādena satā 'bhyupagantavyam / yasmāt
column2: Therefore, because of the proofs from Scripture and reasoning quoted above, the Vaibhāṣikas affirm the existence of both the past and the future.

The masters who call themselves Sarvāstivādins, “believers in the existence of all,ʼ maintain that the past and the future exist. He who affirms the existence of the dharmas of the three time periods is held to be a Sarvāstivādin.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye he sarvamastīti vadanti atītamanāmataṃ pratyutpannaṃ ca te sarvāstivādāḥ /
column2: The masters who affirm the existence of all things, past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye tu kecidasti yat pratyutpannamadattaphalaṃ cātītaṃ karma kiñcinnāsti yaddattaphalamatītamanāgataṃ ceti vibhajya vadanti te vibhajyavādinaḥ kati caite sarvāstivādā ityāha
column2: Those who affirm the existence of the present and a part of the past, namely the existence of action which has not given forth its result; and the non-existence of the future and a part of the past, namely the non-existence of action which has given forth its result, are regarded as Vibhajyavādins.
There are four types of Sarvāstivādins accordingly as they teach a difference in existence, a difference in characteristic, a difference in condition, and mutual difference.
The Bhadanta Dharmatrāta defends bhāvānyathātva, that is, he affirms that the three time periods, past, present, and future, are differentiated by their non-identity of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dharmasyādhvasu, pravartamānasya bhāvānyathātvaṃ bhavati na dravyānyathātvam /
column2: When a dharma goes from one time period to another its nature is not modified, but its existence is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā suvarṇabhājanasya bhittvā 'nyathā kriyamāṇasya saṃsthānānyathātvaṃ bhavati na varṇānyathātvam /
column2: A gold vase which one breaks is an example which shows the difference of figure: its.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca kṣīraṃ dadhitvena pariṇamadrasavīryavipākān parityajati na varṇam /
column2: An example which shows difference in qualities: milk becomes whey; its taste, force, and digestibility change, but not its color.
In the same way, when a future dharma passes from the future into the present, its future existence is abandoned, and its present existence is acquired, but its nature remains the same.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ pratyutpannādatītamadhvānaṃ gacchan pratyutpannabhāvaṃ jahāti na dravyabhāvamiti /
column2: When it passes from the present into the past, its present existence is abandoned, and its past existence is acquired, but its nature remains the same.
The Bhadanta Ghoshaka defends Zakshananyathatva, that is, the time periods differ through the difference in their characteristics.
A dharma goes through the time periods. When it is past, it is endowed with past characteristics, but it is not deprived of its present and future characteristics;
when it is future, it is endowed with its future characteristics, but it is not deprived of its present and past characteristics;
and when it is present, it is endowed with its present characteristics, but it is not deprived of its past and future characteristics.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā puruṣa ekasyāṃ striyāṃ raktaḥ śeṣāsvavirakta iti /
column2: Example: a man attached to one woman is not detached with respect to other women.
The Bhadanta Vasumitra defends gvasthānyathātva, that is, the time periods differ through the difference of condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dharmo 'dhvasu pravartamāno 'vasthāmavasthāṃ prāpyānyo 'nyo nidiśyate avasthāntarato na dravyāntarataḥ /
column2: A dharma, going through the time periods, having taken up a certain condition, becomes different through the difference of its condition, not through a difference in its substance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathaikā vartikā ekāṅke nikṣiptā ekamityucyate śatāṅke śataṃ sahasrāṅke sahasramiti /
column2: Example: a token placed on the square of ones, is called one; placed on the square of tens, teṉ; and placed on the square of hundreds, one hundred.
The Bhadanta Buddhadeva defends anyonyathātva, that is, the time periods are established through their mutual relationships.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dharmo 'dhvasu pravartamānaḥ pūrvāparamapekṣyānyo 'nya ucyate avasthāntarato na dravyāntarataḥ /
column2: A dharma, going throughout the time periods, takes different names through different relationships, that is, it is called past, future, or present, through a relationship with what preceeds and with what follows.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathaikā strī mātā vocyate duhitā veti / ityete catvāraḥ sarvāstivādāḥ /
column2: For example, the same woman is both a daughter and a mother.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣāṃ tu prathamaḥ pariṇāmavāditvāt sāṃkhyapakṣe nikṣeptavyaḥ / dvitīyasyādhvasaṃkaraḥ prāpnoti /
column2: The first, professing "transformation" may be refuted along with the Sāṁkhyas.
In the thesis of the second master, the time periods, past, present, and future, are confounded, since the three characteristics are found everywhere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: puruṣasya tu kasyāñcit striyāṃ rāgaḥ samudācarati kasyāñcit kevalaṃ samanvāgama iti kimatra sāmyam /
column2: The example moreover is lacking any similarity to the problem, for, within the man in question, there is active lust with respect to one woman, but there is only the "possession of lust" with respect to other women.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturthasyāpyekasminnevādhvani trayo 'dhvānaḥ prāpnuvanti / atīte 'dhvani pūrvapaścimau kṣaṇāvatītānāgatau madhyamaḥ kṣaṇaḥ pratyutpanna iti / evamanāgate 'pi / ata eṣāṃ sarveṣāṃ
column2: In the thesis of the fourth master, the three time periods exist at the same time: a past ḍharma, for example, is past in relation to that which precedes it, future in relation to that which follows, and present in relation to what precedes and what follows.
The third is the best.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'yamavasthā 'nyathikaḥ / tasya kila adhvānaḥ kāritreṇa vyavasthitāḥ //
column2: Consequently the best system is that of Vasumitra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā sa dharmaḥ kāritraṃ na karoti tadā 'nāgataḥ /
column2: The three time periods are proven by reason of their activity, According to which the time periods and the conditions are established through the operation of the activity of a dharma: when a dharma does not accomplish its operation, it is future.
When it is accomplishing it, it is present;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā kṛtvā niruddhastadā 'tīta iti / parigatametatsarvam / idaṃ tu vaktavyam /
column2: and when its operation has come to an end, it is past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyatītamapi dravyato 'styanāgatamiti / kasmāttadatītamityucyate 'nāgatamiti vā / nanu coktamadhvānaḥ kāritreṇa vyavasthitā iti /
column2: If the past and the future exist as things, they are present: why are they thus qualified as past and future? It is action not yet completed, in the act of being completed, or already completed, which determine the time period of a dharma. Good enough.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyevaṃ pratyutpannasya tatsabhāgasya cakṣuṣaḥ kiṃ kāritram /
column2: But what action would you assign to a $atsabhāga eye? The action of an eye is to see, and a ta; sabhāga eye does not now see.
Would you say that its action is to project and to give forth a result?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atītānāmapi tarhi sabhāgahetvādīnāṃ phaladānāt kāritraprasaṅgo 'rdhakāritrasya veti lakṣaṇasaṃkaraḥ /
column2: But then if giving forth a result is an “action,” then sabhāgahetu causes, etc. give forth their result when they are past, and so one arrives at the conclusion that they accomplish their action in the past and so would be as a consequence in the present. Or if an action, in order to be complete, calls for a projection and a giving forth of a result, these past causes would be at least semi-present. Thus the time periods are confounded.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idaṃ ca vaktavyam / tenaivātmanā sato dharmasya nityaṃ kāritrakaraṇe
column2: But, if it always exists, why doesn't a dharma always exercise its activity?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ vighnaṃ yena kadācit kāritraṃ karoti kadācinneti /
column2: What obstacle causes it to sometimes produce and sometimes not to produce its action?

One cannot say that its inaction results from the non-presence of certain causes, since these causes also always exist. How can activity be past, etc. ? And how can activity itself be past, etc. P Would you imagine a second activity of activity? That would be absurd. But if the activity, in and of itself, is past, etc. , why not admit that the same holds for the dharma?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yacca tat kāritramatītānāgataṃ pratyutpannaṃ cocyate tatkathaṃ kiṃ kāritrasyāpyanyadasti kāritram /
column2: And who says that the time periods depend on past activity, etc. ?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha tannaivātītaṃ nāpyanāgataṃ na pratyutpannamasti ca /
column2: Would you say that activity is neither past, present, nor future, but that, nevertheless, it exists?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tenāsaṃskṛtatvānnityamastīti prāptam / ato na vaktavyaṃ yadā karitraṃ na karoti dharmastadā 'nāgata iti /
column2: Then, being unconditioned, it is eternal, and how can you then say that a dharma is future when it does not exercise its activity, or past when it no longer exercises it?
These objections would hold, if activity were other than the dharma itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tattu khalu nānyat ato na bhavatyeṣa doṣaḥ / evaṃ tahi sa eva adhvāyogaḥ
column2: But it is not other than the dharma.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi dharma eva kāritraṃ kasmātsa eva dharmastenaivātmanā vidyamānaḥ kadācidatīta ityucyate kadācidanāgata ityadhvanāṃ vyavasthā na sidhyati
column2: If activity is the same as the dharma, and if the dharma always exists, its activity would also always exist. Why and how does one say that sometimes it is past, sometimes future? The distinction of the time periods is not justified.
How is it not justified?
In fact, a conditioned dharma which has not arisen is called future;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo jāto bhavati na ca vinaṣṭaḥ sa varttamānaḥ /
column2: that which, having arisen, is not destroyed, is called present;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo vinaṣṭaḥ so 'tītaḥ iti / etadevātra vaktavyam /
column2: and that which is destroyed is called past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi yathā varttamānaṃ dravyato 'sti tathā 'tītamanāgataṃ cāsti /
column2: If, in the past and future, a dharma exists with the same nature as when it is present,
Existing in the same manner, how can it be non-arisen or destroyed?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tenaiva svabhāvena sato dharmasya kathamidaṃ sidhyatyajāta iti yo vinaṣṭaḥ iti veti /
column2: If the unique self-nature of a dharma continues to exist, how can this dharma be non-arisen or destroyed?
What is it that it is lacking now, through the absence of which it is qualified as non-arisen?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ ca paścānnāsti yasyābhāvā dvinaṣṭa ityucyate / tasmānna sidhyati sarvathā 'pyatrādhvatrayam / yadyabhutvā bhavatīti neṣyate bhūtvā ca punarna bhavatīti /
column2: What is it that it is lacking later, through the absence of which it is qualified as destroyed?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadapyuktaṃ “saṃskṛtalakṣaṇayogānna śāśvatatvaprasaṅga” iti / tadidaṃ kevalaṃ vāṅmātramutpādavināśayorayogāt /
column2: Consequently, if one does notThe argument that, possessing the characteristics of conditioned things, conditioned things are not eternal even though they exist both in the past and in the future, is pure verbiage, for, if it always exists, a dharma is not susceptible either of arising or of perishing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nityaṃ ca nāmāsti sa dharmo na ca nitya ityapūrvaiṣā vāco yuktiḥ / āha khalvapi
column2: “A dharma is eternal, and it is not eternal:” to speak in this manner is to contradict oneself through one’s own words.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “svabhāvaḥ sarvadā cāsti bhāvo nityaśca neṣyate / na ca svabhāvād bhāvo 'nyo vyaktamīśvaraceṣṭitam /“ yattūktamuktatvāditi /
column2: This is what the stanza explains when it says, “Self nature always exists, but this does not mean that being is eternal, nor that being is different from its self nature: this is clearly stated by the Lord.”

With regard to the argument that the Blessed One taught the existence of the past and the future since he said “Past action exists, and future results exist”, we would also say that the past exists, and that the future exists.
Past is that which was existent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgataṃ yatsati hetau bhaviṣyati / evaṃ ca kṛtvā 'stītyucyate na tu punardravyataḥ /
column2: The future is that which, given its cause, will exist; it is in this sense that we say that the past and the future exists. But they do not exist as substantial entities as does the present.
Who says that they exist like the present?
If they don't exist like the present, how do they exist?
The Sarvāstivādins answer: They exist with the nature of the past and the future.
But, if they now exist, how can one attribute the nature of past and future to them?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt bhūtapūrvasya ca hetorbhāvinaśca phalasya bhūtapūratāṃ bhāvitāṃ ca jñāpayituṃ hetuphalāpavādadṛṣṭipratiṣedhārthamuktaṃ bhagavatā “astyatītamastyanāgatami“ti
column2: In fact, the Blessed One, in a text quoted by the Sarvāstivādins, had the intention of condemning the view that negates cause and effect. He said "the past exists" in the sense of "the past was; " he said "the future exists" in the sense of "the future will be.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: astiśabdasya nipātatvāt / yathā 'sti dīpasya prāgabhāvo 'sti paścādabhāva iti vaktāro bhavanti yathā cāsti niruddhaḥ sa dīpo na tu mayā nirodhita iti /
column2: The word is" is a nipāka in the same sense as the expressions, "There is previous non-existence of the lamp," "there is later non-existence of the lamp," and again, "This lamp is extinguished, but it was not extinguished by me.
It is in this same way that the text says the past exists, and the future exists.

To understand otherwise, being in the past, the past would not now be the past.
yattarhi laguḍaśikhīyakānparivrājakānadhikṛṭyoktaṃ bhagavatā “yatkarmābhyatītaṃ kṣīṇaṃ niruddhaṃ vigataṃ vipariṇataṃ tadastī“ti /	We see that the Blessed One, addressing the Lāguḍaśikhīyaka ascetics, expressed himself in this way, “Past action, which has been destroyed, which has perished, and which has ceased, does exist.” According to the proposed explanation, the sense would be, “This action was.”
kiṃ te tasya tasya karmaṇo bhūtapūrvatvaṃ necchanti sma /	Now can we suppose that the ascetics would not admit that past action has already passed away?
tatra punastadāhitaṃ tasyāṃ saṃtatau phaladānasāmarthyaṃ saṃdhāyoktam /	When the Blessed One says that past action exists, he had in view its power of giving forth a result, a power which was placed in the series of the agent through action which has now passed away.
anyathā hi svena bhāvena vidyamānamatītaṃ na sidhyet /	To understand otherwise, that is, if past action actually exists now in and of itself, how can it be considered as past?
itthaṃ caitadevaṃ yat paramārthaśūnyatayāmuktaṃ bhagavatā “cakṣurutpadyamānaṃ na kutaścidāgacchati nirudhyamānaṃ na kvacitsaṃnicayaṃ gacchati	Of the rest, Scripture contains a formal declaration. The Blessed One said in the Paramārthaśūnyatāsñt¢ra,'The eye, Oh Bhikṣus, arising, does not come from any place; perishing, it does ṇot remain in any place.
iti hi bhikṣavaścakṣurabhūtvā bhavati bhūtvā ca pratigacchatī“ti	In this way, Oh Bhikṣus, the eye exists.
yadi cānāgataṃ cakṣuḥ syānnoktaṃ syād bhūtvā na bhavatīti /	If a future eye existed, the Blessed One would not have said that the eye exists only after having been non-existent.
varttamāne 'dhvanyabhūtvā bhavatīti cet na / adhvano bhāvādanarthāntaratvāt /	The expression, “It exists after having been non-existent” signifies “after having been non-existent in the present”, that is, “after having been non-existent as present”. This is inadmissible, for the time periods do not differ from the eye.
atha svātmanyabhūtvā bhavati /	Does this mean that one should understand this as, “After having been non-existent in its own nature?”
siddhamidamanāgataṃ cakṣurnāstīti /	But this is to explicitly acknowledge that a future eye does not now exist.
yadapyuktaṃ “dvayaṃ pratītya vijñānasyotpādāditi idaṃ tāvadiha saṃpradhāryam / yanmanaḥ pratītya dharmaścotpadyate manovijñānaṃ kiṃ tasya yathā manojanakaḥ pratyaya evaṃ dharmā āhosvidālambanamātraṃ dharmā iti /	As for the argument that “the past and the future exist, since the consciousness arises by reason of two things,” should one understand that since the mental consciousness arises by reason of a mental organ and past, present, or future dharmas, these dharmas are a necessary condition for the mental consciousness to arise to the same extent as is the mental organ, that is, in the.
yadi tāvat janakaḥ pratyayo dharmāḥ kathaṃ yadanāgataṃ kalpasahasreṇa bhaviṣyati vā na vā tadidānīṃ vijñānaṃ janayiṣyati /	Evidently futare dharmas, which will be produced after thousands of yeats or which will never be produced, are not the generating causes of a present mental consciousness.
nirvāṇaṃ ca sarvapravṛttinirodhājjanakaṃ nopapadyate /	Evidently Nirvāṇa, which is contradictory to all arising, cannot be a generating cause.
athālambanamātraṃ dharmā bhavanti / atītānāgatamapyālambanaṃ bhavatīti brūmaḥ /	It is enough that the dharmas are a condition for the arising of a consciousness in their qualtiy of being an object: let us admit that it is thus for future and past dharmas.
yadi nāsti kathamālambanam / atredānīṃ brūmaḥ /	If the past and future dharmas do not exist, how can they be the objects of consciousness? They exist in the manner in which they are taken as objects.
yadā tadālambanaṃ tathāsti kathaṃ tadālambanam abhūt bhaviṣyati ceti /	And in what manner are they taken as objects? They are taken as objects with the mark of the past and the future, as having existed or as coming into existence.
na hi kaścidatītaṃ rūpaṃ vedanāṃ vā smarannastīti paśyati / kiṃ tarhi /	In fact, a person who remembers a past visible object of a past sensation, does not see “this is;
abhūditi /	” but he remembers “this was; ” the man who foresees the future does not see the future as existing, but he.
yathā khalvapi varttamānaṃ rūpamanubhūtaṃ tathā tadatītaṃ smaryate / yathā cānāgataṃ varttamānaṃ bhaviṣyati tathā buddhyā gṛhyate /	Memory grasps a visible thing that has been seen, a sensation that has been felt, that is, a visible object and a sensation in a present state of being.
yadi ca tattathaivāsti vartamānaṃ prāpnoti /	If a dharma which one remembers is, in fact, the one grasped by the memory, it is presently manifested;
atha nāsti / asadapyālambanaṃ bhavatīti siddham / tadeva tadvikīrṇamiti cet /	if it is not one that one grasps through the memory, then the memory consciousness certainly has a non-existent object.
na / vikīrṇasyāgrahaṇāt / yadi ca tattadeva rūpaṃ kevalaṃ paramāṇuśo vibhaktam /	Would one say that past and future visible objects exist without being present, because past or future visible objects are nothing other than atoms in a state of dispersion? But we would say: when the consciousness takes as its object, through memory or prevision, a past or future visible object, it does not take it as an object in a state of dispersion, but on the contrary, as an assembled collection of atoms;
evaṃ sati paramāṇavo nityāḥ prāpnuvanti / paramāṇusaṃcaryāvabhāgamātraṃ caivaṃ sati prāpnoti /	if a past or future visible object is the visible object of the present with this small difference that the atoms are dispersed, then the atoms are thus eternal;
na tu kiñcidutpadyate nāpi nirudhyata ityājīvikavāda ālambito bhavati /	there is never either production nor.
sūtraṃ cāpaviddhaṃ bhavati “cakṣurutpadyamānaṃ na kutaścidāgacchatī“ti vistaraḥ /	To maintain such a thesis is to adopt the doctrine of the Ājīvikas and to reject the Sūtras of the Sugata: “The eye, Oh Bhikṣus, arising, does not come from any place.
aparamāṇusaṃcitānāṃ vedanādīnāṃ kathaṃ vikīrṇatvam /	” The argument does not hold for sensation and other “non-solid” dharmas: not being combinations of atoms, we do not see how they can be, in the past or in the future, atoms in a state of dispersion.
te 'pi ca yathotpannānubhūtāḥ smaryante /	In fact, moreover, one remembers the sensation as it was experienced when it was present; one foresees it as it will be experienced when it will be present.
yadi ca te tathaiva santi nityāḥ prāpnuvanti / atha na santi / asadapyālambanamiti siddham /	If, past and future, it is such that one grasps it through memory or prevision, it would be eternal. Thus the mental consciousness termed “memory” has a non-existent object, namely a sensation that does not now presently exist.
yadyasadapyālambanaṃ syāt trayodaśamapyāyatanaṃ syāt /	If that which does not absolutely exist can be the object of consciousness, then a thirteenth āya$tana could be the object of consciousness.
atha trayodaśamāyatanaṃ nāstītyasya vijñānasya kimālambanam /	Then what is, according to you, theIt is its name, “thirteenth āyatana.”
etadeva nāmalambanam / evaṃ tarhi nāma eva nāstīti pratīyeta /	Then this object is only a name; the thing designated, the object, does not exist.
yaśca śabdasya prāgabhāvamālambate kiṃ tasyālambanam /	Furthermore, what will be the presently existing object upon which the consciousness of the previous non-existence of sound bears?
śabda eva /	The object of this consciousness is the sound itself.
evaṃ tarhi yaḥ śabdābhāvaṃ prārthayate tasya śabda eva kartavyaḥ syāt /	Then, anyone who is in quest of the non-existence of sound should make a noise! No, for the sound of which there is previous non-existence, exists in a future state, and it is this sound in its futuṟe state which is the object of the previously non-existent conṅsciousness.
anāgatāvasya iti cet / sati kathaṃ nāstibuddhiḥ /	But if future sound, of which there is previous non-existence, exists in fact, how can there be the idea that it does not now exist?
vartamāno nāstīti cet / na / ekatvāt / yāvatā tasya viśeṣastasyābhūtvābhāvasiddhiḥ /	It does not presently exist; from whence there is the idea, ''it does not now exist.” You do not have the right to speak in this manner, for it is the same dharma which is past, present, and future. Or, if there is aIf you recognize the distinctive characteristic of the present exists after not having existed, then you understand the difference between future and present sound and the idea it does not now exist.

We must prove that existence and non-existence can be objects of consciousness.
yattarhi bodhisattvenoktam “yattat loke nāstitadahaṃ jñāsyāmi vā drakṣyāmi vā nedaṃ sthānaṃ vidyata” iti /	If a non-existent thing can be an object of consciousness, how could the Bodhisattva in his last existence say, It is impossible that I know, that I see that which does not exist in this world?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apare ābhimānikā bhavantyasantamapyavabhāsaṃ santaṃ paśyanti / ahaṃ tu santamevārstīti paśyāmītyayaṃ tatrābhiprāyaḥ /
column2: The meaning of this text is clear: I am not like other prideful ascetics who attribute to themselves a non-existent 'Illumination': as for me, I only see as existing that which is. " Moreover, to admit your thesis, the object of any idea would be real;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itarathā hi sarvabuddhīnāṃ sadālambanatve kuto 'sya vimarśaḥ syāt ko vā viśeṣaḥ /
column2: if all that one thinks is real, there is no longer any place for doubt or examination; there would be no difference between the Bodhisattva and others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itthaṃ caitadevam / yadanyatra bhagavatoktam “etat bhikṣurmama śrāvako yāvatsa mayā kalpamavoditaḥ sāyaṃ viśeṣāya paraiṣyati / sāyamavoditaḥ kalpaṃ viśeṣāya paraiṣyati /
column2: Let us add moreover that ideas certainly have existent and non-existent things for their object, for the Blessed One explicitly.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sacca sato jñāsyati asaccāsataḥ sottarañca sottarataḥ anuttaraṃ cānurattarata” iti / tasmādayamapyahetuḥ /
column2: my Śrāvaka is instructed from evening until morning: he will know that which is as is and that which is not as not, that which is not the highest as not the highest, and that which is the highest as the highest.
Consequently the reason that the Sarvāstivādins gave in favor of the existence of the past and the future, that is, “because the object of the consciousness is existent” does not hold.
The Sarvāstivādins also deduce an argument from the result of action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva hi sautrāntikā atītāt karmaṇaḥ phalotpatti varṇayanti / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: But the Sautrāntikas do not admit that a result arises directly from a past action.
A result arises from a special state of the series , a state which proceeds from the action, as one shall see at the end of this work wherein we refute the doctrine of the Vātsīputrīyas .

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya tvatītānāgataṃ dravyato 'sti tasya phalaṃ nityamevāstīti kiṃ tatra karmaṇaḥ sāmarthyam /
column2: But the masters who affirm the real existence of the past and the future should also admit the eternity of the result: what efficacy can they attribute to the action?
An efficacy with regard to production ?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: utpādastarhyabhūtvā bhavatīti siddham / atha sarvameva cāsti /
column2: An efficacy withThis is to admit that arising exists after having been non-existent.
If you say that arising itself pre-exists, how can you attribute the efficacy of a thing to that same thing?
You cannot but join the School of the Vārṣagaṇyas, “That which is, solely is;
that which is not, solely is not;
that which is not, does not arise;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sato nāsti vināśa” iti / vartamānīkaraṇe tarhi sāmarthyam /
column2: and that which is, is not destroyed.”
What should we understand by “the action of making something present?”
Will this be the fact of drawing something to another place?
We see three difficulties in this: the result will thus be eternal;
how could the result, when it is non-material, be achieved?
and movement would exist after having been non-existent.
Would this be the fact of modifying the unique or self nature of a pre-existent result? But is there not, in this thesis, the appearance of a modification previously non-existent?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmānnaivaṃ sarvāstivādaḥ śāsane sādhurbhavati / yadatītānāgataṃ dravyato 'stīti vadati / evaṃ tu sādhurbhavati /
column2: Consequently, the sarvāstivāda, “the doctrine of the existence of all,” of the Sarvāstivādins who affirm the real existence of the.
Good sarvastivada consists in affirming the existence of "all" by understanding the word "all" as Scripture understands it.
How do the Sutras affirm that all exists?

When one says, 'all exists,' Oh Brahmins, this refers to the twelve ayatanas: these are equivalent terms. Or rather, the all" that exists is the three time periods. And it has been said how they exist: "That which has previously been, is the past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tu tadasti tathoktaṃ athāsatyatītātānāgate kathaṃ tena tasminvā saṃyukto bhavati /
column2: But if the past and future do not exist, how can one be bound by a past or future klesa to a thing which is past or future? One is bound by a past klesa by reason of the existence, in the series, of an anusaya which has arisen from a past klesa;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tajjataddhetvanuśayabhāvāt kleśena tadālambane kleśānuśayabhāvādvastuni saṃyukto bhavati /
column2: one is bound by a future klesa by reason of the existence of an anusaya which is the cause of the future anusaya of a klesa which has had or will have this thing for its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: astyeva tvatītānāgatamiti vaibhāṣikāḥ / yatra netum śakyate tatrātmakātmanaivaṃ veditavyam /
column2: The Vaibhashikas say: "The past and the future truly exist.
As"The nature of things is indeed profound;
certainly, it cannot be proven through reasoning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti paryāyo yadutpadyate tannirudhyate / rūpamutpadyate rūpaṃ nirudhyate /
column2: One can say that that which arises perishes: for example a visible.
One can say that that which arises differes from that which perishes: in fact, that which arises is the future;
that which perishes is the present.
Time also arises, for that which is arising is embraced within time, it has time for its nature;
and a dharma arises from time, by reason of the multiplicity of the moments of future time.
We have thus finished with the problem presented to us by the theory of the anuśayas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadvastu prahīṇaṃ visaṃyuktaḥ sa tasminvastuni / yatra vā visaṃ yuktaḥ prahīṇaṃ tasya tadvastviti /
column2: When a person abandons an object through the disappearance of the possession that he had of this object, is there for him “disconnection” from this object through the cutting off of the possession of the defilements which bears on this object?
And inversely, when there is disconnection, is there abandoning?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: syātu prahīṇaṃ na ca tatra visaṃyuktastadyathā
column2: When there is disconnection from an object, there is always an.
When that which is to be abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering is abandoned, the ascetic remains in connection with it from the fact of the other universal defilements;

when the first category is abandoned, he remains in connection with it from the fact of the other defilements which have it as their object. Let us suppose a person enters on to the path of the Seeing of Truths;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhajñāne samutpanne samudayajñāne 'nutpanne duḥkhadarśanaprahātavyo nikāyaḥ prahīṇo bhavati /
column2: the Seeing of Suffering has arisen in him, but not yet the Seeing of Arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmin prahīṇe tadālambanaiḥ samudayadarśanaprahātavyaiḥ sarvatragaiḥ saṃyuktaḥ /
column2: He has abandoned the things which are abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering, but he is not yet disjoined from these things by this: for he continues to be bound to these first things through the universal defilements whose abandoning depends on the Seeing of Arising and which are relative to these first things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhāvanāprahātavye 'pi nikāye navānāṃ prakārāṇāṃ yaḥ prakāraḥ prāk prahīṇastasmin prahīṇe 'pi śeṣaistadālambanaiḥ kleśaiḥ saṃyukto veditavyaḥ
column2: In the Path of Meditation wherein one successively expels nine categories of defilements, when the first category is abandoned and not the others, these other categories of. How many anrśayas attach themselves to each object?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasminvastuni katyanuśayā anuśerata iti etatpratipadamabhidhīyamānaṃ bahutaraṃ vaktavyaṃ jāyate /
column2: We would never finish were we to examine this problem in detail.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt piṇḍavibhāṣāṃ kurvanti / kathamalpenālpena yatnena mahato mahataḥ praśnaughān pratipādyemahīti /
column2: The Vaibhāṣikas give a summary exposition of this.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāsata ime ṣoḍaśa dharmāḥ kāmarūpārupyāvacarāḥ pañcaprakārāḥ anāsravāśca /
column2: In general one can say that there are sixteen types of dharmas, objects to which the anuśayas attach themselves: for each sphere there are five categories (categories to be abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering, etc. ); plus the pure dharmas.
The consciousnesses are of the same sixteen types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra katamo dharmaḥ kasya cittasyālambanamiti jñātvā amuṣminniyanto 'nuśayā anuśerata ityetadabhyūhitavyam /
column2: When we know which dharmas are the objects of which consciousness, we are then able to calculate how many anuśayas attach themselves to these dharmas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra tāvat duḥkhahetudṛgabhyāsapraheyāḥ kāmadhātujāḥ / svakatrayaikarūpāptāmalavijñānagocarāḥ // svakaṃ ca tattrayaṃ ca svakatrayam / ekaṃ ca tadrūprāptaṃ ca ekarūpāptam / eṣā vigrahajātiḥ /
column2: Abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and Arising, abandoned through Meditation, the dharmas in Kāmadhātu are the sphere of three consciousnesses of this sphere, of one consciousness of Rūpadhātu and the pure consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacarāstāvad duḥkhasamudayadarśanaheyā bhāvanāheyāśca dharmāḥ pañcānāṃ cittānāmālambanam /
column2: In all, these dharmas are the object of five consciousnesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svadhātukānāṃ trayāṇāṃ teṣāmeva ūrdhvadhātukasyaikasya bhāvanāheyasyaiva anāsravasya ceti /
column2: The three consciousnesses of Kāmadhātu are abandoned through theOne consciousness of Rūpadhātu is abandoned through Meditation.
The same three categories of dharmas in Rūpadhātu are the object of three consciousnesses of Rūpadhātu, three of Kāmadhātu, one of Ārūpyadhātu and the pure consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāvacarāsta eva triprakārā dharmā aṣṭānāṃ cittānāmālambanam / svadhātukānāṃ trayāṇāṃ teṣāmeva / adharadhātukānāṃ trayāṇāṃ teṣāmeva /
column2: The three consciousnesses of Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu are the same as above: they are abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and its Arising, and through Meditation.
Consciousness in Ārūpyadhātu is abandoned through Meditation. In all, these dharmas are the objects of eight consciousnesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārupyajāstridhātvāptatrayānāsravagocarāḥ // ārūpyāvacarāsta eva triprakārā dharmā daśānāṃ cittānāmālambanam /
column2: The same categories of dharmas in Ārūpyadhātu are the objects of three consciousnesses of the three spheres and pure consciousness.
The same three consciousnesses.
In all, these dharmas are the object of ten consciousnesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirodhamārgadṛggheyāḥ sarve svādhikagocarāḥ / nirodhamārgadarśanaheyānāṃ svaṃ cittaṃ nirodhamārgadarśanaheyameva / tasyādhikasya te dharmā ālambanaṃ jñeyāḥ / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: The dharmas abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction and the Path are all the objects of the same consciousnesses with the addition of the consciousness of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacarā hi nirodhadarśanaheyā dharmāḥ ṣaṇṇāṃ vijñānānāmālambanam / pūrvoktānāṃ pañcānāṃ tasyaiva ca nirodhadarśanaprahātavyasyādhikasya / mārgadarśanaheyā apyevam /
column2: The dharmas of Kāmadhātu abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction are objects of the five consciousnesses as above, plus the consciousness abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction: in all six consciousnesses.

The dharmas of Kāmadhātu abandoned through the Seeing of the Path are objects of the five consciousnesses as above, plus the consciousness abandoned through Seeing the Path: in all six consciousnesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ rūpārūpyāvacarāṇi / nirodhamārgadarśanaprahātavyāstasyaiva nirodhamārgadarśanaprahātavyasyādhikasya cittasyālambanamiti navānāmekādaśānāṃ ca cittānāmālambanaṃ bhavanti uktāstraidhātukāḥ pañcaprakārāḥ dharmāḥ / anāsravāstridhātvantyatrayānāsravagocarāḥ // anāsravā dharmā daśānāṃ cittānāmālambanam /
column2: The dharmas of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu are abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction and the Path: they are the objects, respectively, of nine and eleven consciousnesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: traidhātukānāmantyānāṃ triprakārāṇāṃ nirodhamārgadarśanabhāvanāheyānāmanāsravasyeti / punarasyaivārthasyādhyardhena ślokena saṃgraho bhavati / “duḥkhahetudṛgabhyāsaheyā dhātutraye 'malāḥ
column2: The pure dharmas are the object of the last three consciousnesses of the three spheres and of pure consciousness.
They are the objects of ten consciousnesses, the consciousnesses of the three spheres abandoned through the Seeing of Extinction and the Path, through Meditation, and the pure consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evameṣāṃ ṣoḍaśānāṃ cittānāṃ ṣoḍaśadharmālambanavyavasthāṃ viditvā kathamanuśayakāryāṃ yojayitavyam /
