column2: Here are two summarizing ŚYoéas: “The dharmas of the three spheres abandoned through the Śeeing of Suffering and theSuch are the sixteen types of dharmas, objects of sixteen types of consciousness. We shall now examine what anusfaya attaches itself to what dharma.
A complete analysis would take us too far afield; we will content ourselves with studying a typical case.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukhendriyālambane vijñāne katyanuśayāḥ anuśerata iti praśna āgate vicārayitavyam /
column2: Let us choose, among the objects of attachment, agreeable sensation, and let us see how many anuśayas attach themselves to it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukhendriyaṃ saptavidhaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ bhāvanāprahātavyaṃ rūpāvacaraṃ ca pañcaprakāramanāsravaṃ ceti /
column2: Agreeable sensation is of seven types: belonging to Kāmadhātu, to be abandoned through Meditation; belonging to Rūpadhātu, of five categories; and pure. When it is pure, the anufayas do not attach themselves to it, as we have shown. When they belong to Kāmadhātu, the ¢ṉ%2yas abandoned through Meditation and all the universal anrśayas attach themselves to it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadetatsamāsato dvādaśadharmasya vijñānasyālambanaṃ bhavati / kāmāvacarasya catuṣprakārasyānyatra nirodhadarśanaheyāt /
column2: The consciousness which has agreeable sensation for its object is of twelve types: belong to Kāmadhātu, for categories of consciousness;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāvacarasya pañcaprakārasyārūpyāvacarasya dviprakārasya mārgadarśanabhāvanāheyasyānāsravasya ca / idaṃ dvādaśavidhaṃ sukhendriyālambanaṃ vijñānam / tatra yathāsaṃbhavaṃ kāmāvacarāścatvāro nikāyā rūpāvacarāśca saṃskṛtālambanā ārūpyāvacarau ca dvau nikāyau sarvatragāścānuśayā anuśerata iti jñātavyam /
column2: belong to Rūpadhātu, five categories; belong to Ārūpyadhātu, the consciousness abandoned through Seeing the Path and the one abandoned through Meditation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukhendriyālambanālambane vijñāne katyanuśayā anuśerate / tat punaḥ sukhendriyālambanālambanaṃ dvādaśavidhaṃ vijñānaṃ katamasya vijñānasyālambanam /
column2: and the pure consciousness. Attaching themselves to it are, according to their types.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyaiva dvādaśavidhāsyārūpyāvacarasya ca bhūyo dviprakārasya duḥkhasamudayadarśanaprahātavyasya / idaṃ caturdaśavidhaṃ sukhendriyālambanālambanaṃ vijñānaṃ tatrārūpyāvacarau dvau duḥkhasamudayadarśanaheyau
column2: The consciousness which has an agreeable sensation for its object, and which is of twelve types, is itself the object of a consciousness which can be of fourteen types, namely the twelve aforementioned types with the addition of the consciousnesses of the sphere of Ārūpyadhātu abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and the Seeing of the Arising of Suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vardhayitvā kāmāvacarā ārūpyāvacarāścatvāro nikāyā rūpāvacarāḥ saṃskṛtālambanā anuśayā anuśerata iti jñātavyam /
column2: Attaching themselves to this consciousness are, according to their types, the anṉuśayas described above in the first two spheres, plus four categories in Ārūpyadhātu (by excluding the anzśaya abandoned through the Seeing of the Extinctioôn of Suffering).
The other dharmas will be examined on the basis of this example.
The mind is termed sānuśaya, “having anuśaya,” from the fact of the anuśayas. Should we think that, necessarily, the anaśayas nourish themselves, and lodge in the sānuśaya mind?
Those which lodge in it are the non-abandoned an#uśayas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye 'nuśayāstena cittena saṃprayuktāḥ prahīṇāstadālambanāśca / tadevaṃ kṛtvā bhavati /
column2: Those which do not lodge in it are the abandoned anusayas which are associated with the mind in question.
The defiled mind is sá⁴ṇuśaya in two ways;

the non-defiled mind solely from the fact of the gṉayas which lodge therein. The defiled mind is sānufaya from the fact of the annśayas which lodge therein: the enuśayas with which īt is associated, whose object is not abandoned, which takes an object; and from the fact of the exśayas which are not therein: the abandoned anuśayas and that to which it is associated: for this mind continues to have them as companions.
The non-defiled mind is sānefaya from the fact of the anusśayar which lodge therein: the non-abandoned gnśayas which are associated with the mind.
In what order are the ten nṉuśuyas produced (Vibhāṣā, TD , p. b and following)? Any one can arise after any one: there is thus no rule which applies to all of them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ādita eva tāvadavidyāyyogātsatyeṣu sa muhyati / duḥkhamasmai na rocate yāvat mārgastataḥ mohākāṅkṣā
column2: Nevertheless, for the order of theirAt first, bound by ignorance, a person is in confusion with respect to the Truths: he does not take pleasure in the Truth of Suffering; he does not admit it.
From this state of confusion, there arises doubt; he undertands the two thesis;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhaṃ nvidaṃ natvidaṃ duḥkhamityevamādi / tato mithyādṛṣṭiḥ
column2: he doubts whether suffering is true, or if non-suffering is true.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vicikitsāyā mithyādṛṣṭiḥ pravartate / saṃśayitasya mithyāśramaṇacittānāṃ mithyāniścayotpatteḥ / nāsti duḥkhamityevmādi /
column2: From doubt there arises false views: by reason of false teaching and false reflection, he comes to the judgement "This is not suffering.
From false view there arises the view of personality;
for, not recognizing the skandhas as suffering, he considers these skandhas as constituting a "self.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato 'ntagrahaṇaṃ satkāyadṛṣṭerantagrāhadṛṣṭiḥ pravartate / ātmanaḥ śāśvatocchedāntagrahaṇāt / tasmācchhīlāmarśaḥ antagrahācchīlavrataparāmarśaḥ / yamevāntaṃ gṛhṇāti tena śuddhipratyāgamanāt / tato dṛśaḥ / āmarśa iti vartate /
column2: From whence there is the view of the two extremes, for a person, believing in a self, becomes attached to the idea of the eternity or the annihilation of the self.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śīlavrataparāmarśāddṛṣṭiparāmarśaḥ pravartate / yena śuddhiṃ pratyeti tasyāgrato grahaṇāt /
column2: From this there is an esteeming of morality and practices.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato / rāgaḥ svadṛṣṭau mānaśca tasyāmabhiṣvaṅgāt tayā connatigamanāt /
column2: From this there is attachment to one's own views, and pride and pleasure in these views.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dveṣo 'nyatra svadṛṣṭyadhyavasitasya tatpratyanīkabhūtāyāṃ paradṛṣṭau dveṣaḥ pravartate /
column2: And hatred with respect to another: From this there is dislike: for, quite full of his own views, he detests the views of others which are contrary to his own.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apare svadṛṣṭāvevānyatra gṛhīte tyaktāyāṃ dveṣamicchanti darśanaheyānāṃ rāgādīnāṃ svāsāntānikadṛṣṭyālambanatvāt /
column2: According to other masters, there is hatred for one's own opinions when one changes them; for lust and the other anṇuśayar which are abandoned through the Seeing of the Truths are those which have for their object the person himself and his own views.
Such is the order.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa eṣāṃ daśānāṃ kleśānāṃ pravṛttikramaḥ / utpadyamānastu tribhiḥ kāraṇairutpadyate /
column2: This is the order of the arising of the ten klesas.
Kleśas arise from the non-abandoning of the znazśaya, from the presence of their object, and from erroneous judgment.
For example, lust arises when the anuśaya of lust is non-abandoṉed—not-completely-known—its opposition not having arisen;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā rāgānuśayo 'prahīṇo bhavatyaparijñātaḥ kāmarāgaparyavasthānīyāśca dharmā ābhāsagatā bhavanti tatra cāyoniśo manaskāra evaṃ kāmarāga utpadyate /
column2: when the dharmas which provoke the manifestation of lust, namely visible things, etc. , are found in the field of experience, and when there is erroneous judgmenṇt.
The anzjśaya is cause; the dharmas are its object; and incorrect judgmeṇnt is its immediate preparation: three distinct forces.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamanyo 'pi kleśa utpadyata iti veditavyo yaḥ saṃpūrṇakāraṇaḥ // kadācitkial viṣayabalenaivotpadyante /
column2: The same holds for the other kleśas.
With complete causes. This is the case for the kÉeśfas which proceed frorm all causes. For, according to the School, a kleśz can arise through the mere force of its object;
as in the case of the Arhat who is subject to falling away.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eta evānuśayāḥ sūtre bhagavatā traya āsravā uktāḥ kāmasravo bhavāsravo 'vidyāsrava iti /
column2: In a Sūtra, the Blessed One said that the ninety-eight aṉuśayas, with the ten wrappings of attachment, are made up of three cankerous influences, the cankerous influence of objects of pleasure, the cankerous influence of existence, and the cankerous influence of ignorance;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catvāra oghāḥ kāmaugho bhavaugho dṛṣṭyobho 'vidyaughaśca / catvāro yogā eta eva /
column2: four floods, the flood of the. objects of pleasure, existence, views, and ignorance are four yokes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catvāryupādānāni kāmopādānaṃ dṛṣṭyupādānaṃ śīlavṛtopādānamātmavādopādānamiti / tatra tāvat
column2: There are also four clingings: clinging to objects of pleasure, clinging to views, clinging to morality and ascetic practices, and clinging to a belief in a self. What is the definition of the cankerous influences?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāme saparyavasthānāḥ kleśāḥ kāmāsravo vinā / mohena
column2: In Kāmadhātu, the defilements, with the exception of ignorance, but with the wrappings of attachment, constitute āśravaś.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avidyāṃ varjayitvā 'nye kāmāvacarāḥ kleśāḥ saha paryavasthānaiḥ kāmāsravo veditavya ekacatvāriṃśaddravyāṇi / ekatriṃśadanuśayāḥ pañcaprakārāmavidyāṃ hitvā daśa paryavasthānāni /
column2: The kleśas of Kāmadhātu, with the exception of the five ignorances, plus the ten wrappings make up forty-one things: this is the cankerous influence of the objects of pleasure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anuśayā eva rūpārūpye bhavāsravaḥ // vinā moheneti vartate / rūpārūpyāvacarā avidyāvarjyā anuśayā bhavāsravo dvāpañcāśaddravyāṇi / rūpāvacarāḥ ṣaḍviṃśatiranuśayāḥ pañcaprakārāmavidyāṃ hitvā / ārūpyāvacarāḥ ṣaḍviṃśatiḥ /
column2: In Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu, only the aṉuśayas themselves constitute the cankerous influence of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca tatrāpyasti paryavasthānadvayaṃ styānamauddhatyaṃ ca /
column2: But there are, in the two higher spheres, two wrappings, namely torpor and dissipation.
The Prakaraṇa says, “What is the cankerous influence of existence? With the.

”exception of ignorance, it is the other connections, bonds, anuśayas, upakleśas and wrappings of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu. The Vaibhāsṣikas of Kāśmīr say that the wrappings of attachment are not mentioned as forming part of the cankerous influence of existence because, in the two higher spheres, they are not independent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasmā diha tasyāgrahaṇam / asvātantryāditi kāśmīrāḥ / kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ rūpārūpyāvacarā anuśayāḥ samasyaiko bhavāgra uktaḥ /
column2: Why are the gnuśayas of the two higher spheres placed together in order to make one single cankerous influence of existence?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avyākṛtāntarmukhā hi te samāhitabhūmikāḥ / ata ekīkṛtāḥ /
column2: They are morally neutral, proceed inwards, and belong to the stage of absorption: this is why they are put together.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te hyūbhaye 'pyavyākṛtā antarmukhapravṛttāḥ samāhitabhūmikāśceti trividhena sādhamyerṇaikatāḥ /
column2: They both present the threefold common characteristics of being morally neutral, of being turned inward (that is, of not depending on objects), and of belonging to the spheres of absorption: they are thus united into a single cankerous influence. And again they are called the cankerous influence of existence for the same reason that one distinguishes the cankerous influence of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yenaiva ca kāraṇena bhavarāga uktastenaiva bhavāsravaḥ ityavidyedānīṃ traidhātukyavidyāsrava iti siddham / tāni pañcadaśa dravyāṇi /
column2: From the above, it results that the gvidyās, "the ignorances," of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ kāraṇamasau pṛthagvyavasthāpyate / sarveṣāṃ hi teṣāṃ
column2: Why do the ignorances constitute a separate cankerous influence?
Ignoraṇce is the root: it is thus said to constitute a separate cankerous influence.
In the manner in which the cankerous influences are explained, So too for the floods and the yokes.
But views constitute a separate flood and a separate yoke by reason of their acuteness. The “floods” and the “'yokes” are explained in the same manner.
The cankerous influence of the objects of sensual pleasure without views, is both the flood of the objects of sensual pleasure and the yoke of the objects of sensual pleasure;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ bhavāsrava eva bhavaugho bhavayogaścānyatra dṛṣṭibhyaḥ /
column2: so too the cankerous influence of existence, without views, is both the flood of existence and the yoke of existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāḥ kila paṭutvādoghayogeṣu pṛthak sthāpitāḥ / nāsraveṣvasahāyānāṃ na kilāsyānukūlatā // āsayantītyāsravāṇāṃ nirvacanaṃ paścādvakṣyate /
column2: According to the School, it is by reason of their characteristic of sharpness that views constitute a separate flood and a separate yoke.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca kila kevalā dṛṣṭya āsyānukūlāḥ paṭutvāt /
column2: They are not a separate cankerous influence, because. Isolated views are not favorable to installation, being acute.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata āsraveṣu na pṛṭhak sthāpitāḥ / miśrīkṛtya sthāpitā iti tadevaṃ kāmaugha ekānnatriṃśaddravyāṇi /
column2: Thus one does not make a separate place among the cankerous influences for them;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rāgapratighamānāḥ pañcadaśa vicikitsāścatasro daśa paryavasthānānīti / bhavaugho 'ṣṭāviṃsatidravyāṇi /
column2: they figure in the category of the cankerous influences but are not mixed with the other enexśayas. Therefore we have: The flood of the objects of sensual pleasure is made up of five lusts, five hatreds, five egotisms, four doubts, and ten wrappings: in all twenty-nine things.
The flood of existence is made up of ten lusts, ten egotisms, eight doubts: in all twenty-eight things.
The flood of views is made up of the twelve views of the three Dhātus: in all thirty-six things.
The flood of ignorance is made up of the five ignorances of the three Dhātus: in all fifteen things.
The same for the yokes.
So too the zpādānas, by placing ignorance and by dividing the drṛṣgis into two.
We have five clingings: a.

Clinging to the objects of sensual pleasure is made up of the yoke of the objects of sensual pleasure plus the ignorances of Kāmadhātu, that is, five lusts, five hatreds, five egotisms, five ignorances, four doubts, and ten wrappings: in all thiṟty-four things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rāgapratighamānā 'vidyāviṃśatirvicikitsāścatasro daśa paryavasthānāni / bhavayoga eva sahāvidyayā ātmavādopādānamaṣṭatriṃśaddravyāṇi / rāgamānāvidyāstriṃśadvicikitsā aṣṭau /
column2: Clinging to the belief in a soul is made up of the yoke of existence plus the ignorances of the two higher spheres, that is, ten lusts, ten egotisms, ten ignorances, and eight doubts: in all thirty-eight things.
The clinging to views is made up of the yoke of views without the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices: in all thirty things.

Clinging to morality and ascetic practices is made up of the six remaining things. Why distinguish "the presumption of morality and of ascetic practices" from the other views and make it a separate clinging?
Because it is in opposition to the Path and deludes the two.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gṛhiṇo 'pyanena vipralabdhā anaśanādibhiḥ svargamārgasaṃjñayā pravrajitā apīṣṭaviṣayaparivarjanena śuddhipratyāgamanāditi /
column2: The laity are deluded with expectations of obtaining heaven through abstinence, etc. and clerics are deluded with expectations of obtaining purity through the renouncing of agreeable things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ kāraṇamavidyāṃ miśrayitvopādānamuktaṃ na pṛthak / bhavagrahaṇādupādānāni /
column2: But why doesn't ignorance constitute a separate clinging?
Ignorance is not the grasper; like clinging, it is mixed with the other anuśayas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaṃprakhyānalakṣaṇatayā 'paṭutvādavidyā na grāhikā bhavatyataḥ kila miśritā /
column2: Ignorance has non-intellection for its characteristic; it is not at all sharp; thus it does not grasp; therefore, say the School, it is only mixed with the other defilements as is clinging.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtre tu bhagavatoktaṃ “kāmayogaḥ katamaḥ / vistareṇa yāvadyo 'sya bhavati kāmeṣu kāmarāgaḥ kāmacchandaḥ kāmasnehaḥ kāmaprema
column2: But, we would say, the Blessed One said in the Sūtra, ““What is the yoke of the object of sensual pleasure?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmecchā kāmamūrcchā kāmagṛddhaḥ kāmaparigarddhaḥ kāmanandī kāmaniyantiḥ kāmādhyavasānaṃ tadanyacittam paryādāya tiṣṭhati / ayamucyate kāmayogaḥ /
column2: With regard to the objects of pleasure, within the person who does not know the origin of the object of pleasure, it is éāxarāga, kāmaprema, kāmecchā, kāmamūrchā, kāmagṛddha, kāmaparigardḍha, kāmanandī, kāmaniyanti, and kāmādhyavasāna which overpowers the mind: these are the yokes of the objects of sensual.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yāvadbhavayogaḥ” / cchandarāgaścopādānamuktaṃ sutrāntareṣvato vijñāyate kāma hyupādānamapi kāmādiṣu cchandarāga iti /
column2: The Blessed One defines the other yokes in the same way.
In another Sutra, he says that chandarāga is a clinging.

Thus chandarāga with respect to the objects of pleasure, views, etc. , is what is called clinging to the objects of pleasure, etc. What is the meaning of the words anufaya, āsrava, ogha, yoga and upādāna?
They are atomic; they adhere; they nourish themselves in two ways;
they continually bind: this is why they are termed anuśayas.
They are atomic, for their mode of existences is subtle, being difficult to know.
They adhere through the adhesion of their prāptis;
they nourish themselves in two ways, both from the object and from the dharmar with which they are associated;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anubadhnantyaprayogeṇa prativārayato 'pi punaḥ punaḥ saṃmukhībhāvāt / ebhiḥ kāraṇairanuśayā ucyante /
column2: and they continually bind, for, unless one makes an effort, and even when one creates an obstacle to them, they will appear and reappear.
They fix and they flow, they carry away, they attach, they seize: such is the etymology of the words āsravas, etc. The anuśayas fix, “seat” beings in transmigration.
They flow from the highest heaven to Avīci;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āsayanti saṃsāre āsravanti bhavāgrādyāvadavīciṃ ṣaṅbhirāyatanavraṇair ityāsravāḥ /
column2: they flow out by the six organs which are as wounds. They are thus called cankerous influences, or āsravas.
The anuśayas carry away; they are thus called oghas or floods. “The anuśayas cause beings to be attached;
they are thus called yogas or yokes.
The anuśayas seize; they are thus called uwpādānas or clingings.
The best explanation is the following. By means of the auśayas, the mental series flows into the objects;
the an#fayas are thus āsravas or cankerous influences.

In conformity with the comparison of the Śūtra “In the same way that one makes great efforts in order to steer a boat against the current but when these efforts begin to weaken, the boat is carried with the stream;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sā teṣāmeva saṃskārāṇāṃ gratiprasravdhyā 'lpakṛcchreṇānusrota uhyata''; iti sūtravādānusārāt /
column2: [so too, it is with great pains that the mental series is freed from its objects through the good dharmas].
When they are very violent, the @nuśayas are called oghas; in fact they carry away, as in a flood, those who are bound to them.
When they do not enter into activity with an extreme violence, the anufayas are called yogas, because they yoke one to the very many sufferings of transmigration;
or rather because they adhere with obstinance.

The anuxśayas are called upādānas, because, through their action, one clings to things of the senses, etc. These same anuśayas or latent defilements which make up four categories—cankerous influences, floods, yokes, and clingings,— also make up five categories: saṁyojanas or connections , bandhanas or bonds , anuśayas, upakleśas , and paryavasthāṇnas oṛ wrappings.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta evānuśayāḥ punaḥ saṃyojanabandhanānuśayopakleśaparyavasthānabhedena pañcadhā bhittvoktāḥ / tatra nava saṃyojanānyanunvayapratighamānāvidyādṛṣṭiparāmarśavicikitserṣyā mātsaryasaṃyojanāni /
column2: There are said to be five types by reason of their division into connections, etc. The nine raṁyojanas or connections are: 1) affection, 2) aversion, 3) pride, 4) ignorance, 5) view, 6) uṇjustified estimation, 7) doubt, 8) envy, and 9) avarice.
Anunaya-saṁyojana or the attachment of affection is lust of the three Dhātus.
One should understand the other connections in. The second, the eighth, and ninth belong exclusively to Kāmadhātu.
Dr̥ṣṭi-samyojana or the attachment to views is made up of the first three views.
Parāmarśa-saṁyojana, the attachment to esteeming, is made up of the last two.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evocyate syāt dṣṭisaṃprayukteṣu dharmeṣvanunayasaṃyojanena saṃyukto na dṛṣṭisaṃyojanena na ca tatra dṛṣṭyanuśayo nānuśayīta /
column2: The question is thus posed: Does it happen that a person is attached through the connection of affection, and not through the connection of views, to the dharmas associated with views, while dṛṣ¢yanuśaya, the latent defilement of views, is not active with respect to these dharmas? Yes.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āha syāt samudayajñāne utpanne nirodhajñāne 'nutpanne nirodhamārgadarśānaprahātavyeṣu dṛṣṭiśīlavrataparāmarśasaṃprayukteṣu dharmeṣu /
column2: Let us consider a person who has produced the knowledge of the Arising of Suffering but not the knowledge of the Extinction of Suffering. Within him arises a connection of affection with respect to the dharmas associated with the views of esteeming.
This person will be attached to these dharmas through the connection of affection, but not through the connection of views;

for he has abandoned the universal connection of views which is abandoned through the Truths of Suffering and the Arising of Suffering, and there does not exist in him any non-universal connection of views which bears on these dbarmas or which is associated with them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭyanuśayaśca teṣvanuśete / te eva parāmarśaḍṛṣṭī saṃprayogataḥ /
column2: Nevertheless latent defilement of views is active with respect to these dharmas, for the two drṣṭis which are esteeming and which have not yet been abandoned, are active through association.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ saṃyojaneṣu tisro dṛṣṭayo dṛṣṭisaṃprayojanaṃ pṛthaguktaṃ dve punardṛṣṭī parāmarśāsaṃyojanaṃ pṛthak /
column2: Why does one makes one connection—the connection of views—out of the first three views, and another connection,. —the connection of esteeming—out of the last two?
Two views constitute separate coṇnection by treason of their equal number of things, and by reason of their.
The first three views make up eighteen distinct things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭādaśaiva dve parāmarśadṛṣṭī / ataḥ kila dravya sāmānyādete saṃyojanāntaram kṛte /
column2: The same goes for the last two, twelve esteeming of views and six esteeming of morality and ascetic practices.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ete ca dve parāmarśasvabhāvena śeṣāiti parāmarśanasāmānyādapyete pṛthagvihite grāhyagrāhakabhedāt /
column2: The last two views are, by their nature, esteeming, but not the first three. They take the first ones as their object, but the opposite is not true.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kasmādīṣryāmātsarye saṃyojane pṛthaksaṃyojanadvayamuktaṃ nānyat paryavasthānam /
column2: Why do envy and avarice make up two connections, while the other wrappings are not distinct connections?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekāntākuśalaṃ yasmāt svatantraṃ cobhayaṃ yataḥ / īṣryāmātsaryameṣūktaṃ pṛthak saṃyojanadvayam // nahyanyatparyavasthānamevañjātīyakamasti yatraitadubhayaṃ syādekāntākuśalatvaṃ svatantratvaṃ ceti /
column2: Envy and avarice are each a connection because, among the wrappings, they are at one and the same time completely bad and independent. These two characteristics are not encountered in the other wrappings.
According to another opinion, this reason is good for the master who admits only eight wrappings;
but for the master who admits ten wrappings, the reason proposed raises no difficulties, for anger and.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmānna bhavatyayaṃ parihāra ityapare / punaranyatra bhagavatā saṃyojanamuktam pañcadhā 'varabhāgīyaṃ
column2: The Blessed One said moreover, that, among the connections, Five are inferior.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadyathā satkāyadṛṣṭiḥ śīlavrataparāmarśo vicikitsā kāmacchando vyāpāda iti / kasmādetānvavarabhāgīyānyucyante / avarabhāgahitatvāt /
column2: Namely a belief in a self, the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices, doubt, desire for the objects of sensual pleasure and anger.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avaro hi bhāgaḥ kāmadhāturetāni ca tasyānuguṇāni /
column2: “Inferior” means that which is in relation to, that which is favorable to the “‘inferior part” , that is, to Kāmadhātu.
Now, among these five connections: Two cause one not to get out of Kāmadhātu;
three cause one to return there.
Desire for the objects of sensual pleasure and anger obstruct leaving Kāmadhātu;
a belief in a self and the two remaining connections cause one, once he has left Kāmadhātu, to return there: as the jailor of a prison and his helpers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tribhiḥ sattvāvaratāṃ nātikrāmati pṛthagjanatvaṃ dvābhyāṃ dhātvavaratāṃ kāmadhātum / ata eva tānyavarabhāgīyānītyapare /
column2: According to another opinion, it is by reason of the three that one does not leave the state of being inferior, namely a Pr̥thagjana; and it is by reason of the two that one does not get out. The Blessed One said, in fact, that one becomes a Srotaāpannṇa by the complete abandoning of the three connections in question.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā srota āpannasya paryādāya trisaṃyojanaprahāṇāt ṣaṭkleśāḥ prahīṇāḥ kimarthaṃ tisro dṛṣṭīrapahāya trayamevāha satkāyadṛṣṭiṃ śīlavrataparāmarśaṃ vicikitsāṃ ca / sarvametadvaktavyaṃ syāt / kiṃ tūktaṃ
column2: But, on the other hand, the Srotaāpanna has also abandoned three desires: a belief in the extremes, false views, and the esteeming of views. It appears that the Blessed One should term these views connections favorable to the quality of Prthagjana.
Three, because they make up the gate and the root.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: triprakārāḥ kila kleśā ekaprakārā dviprakārākścatuprakārākśca / teṣāmebhistribhirmukhaṃ gṛhītamiti /
column2: There are three categories of klefa: 1.

simple, to be abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering, namely a belief in a self and a belief in the extremes; twofold, to be abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and the Path, namely the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices; and 3. fourfold, to be abandoned through Seeing the Four Noble Truths, namely doubt, false views, and the esteeming of views. By indicating the first three as connections, the Blessed One indicates the gate to the.
He also indicates the root, for a belief in the extremes is set into motion by a belief in a self, the esteeming of views by the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices, and false views by doubt.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: apare punarāhuḥ / agantukāmatāmārgavibhramo mārgasaṃśayaḥ / ityantarāyā mokṣasya gamane 'tastrideśanā // trayo 'ntarāyā deśāntaragamane bhavanti / agantukāmatā mārgavibhramo 'nyamārgasaṃśrayaṇāt mārgasaṃśayaśca /
column2: Others say: Three are indicated because three things create an obstacle to arriving at deliverance: a non-desire to go, error with respect to the Path, and doubt with respect to the Path.
In the same way that, in the world, these three things form an obstacle to progress to another place, in this same way they form an obstacle to progress towards deliverance: a.
a belief in a self, which inspires a fear of deliverance and causes one not to desire to arrive at it;
the esteeming of morality and ascetic practices through which, having recourse to another path, one becomes deluded about the Path;
and c. doubts, doubt about the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣāṃ mokṣagamanāntarāyāṇāṃ prahāṇaṃ dyotayan bhagavān kleśatrayasyaiva prahāṇaṃ deśitavān /
column2: The Blessed One, wishing to teach that the Śrotaāpanna has completely abandoned these three obstacles, says that he has abandoned three.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā bhagavatā pañcavidhamavarabhāgīyaṃ saṃyojanamuktam / evaṃ punaḥ pañcadhaivordhvabhāgīyaṃ kathamityāha dvau rāgau rūpyarūpijau tau auddhatyamānamohāśca ityetāni pañcordhvabhāgīyāni saṃyojanāni / tadyathā rūparāga ārūpyarāga auddhatyaṃ māno 'vidyā ca /
column2: In the same way that the Blessed One characterized five connections as “inferior,” in this same way Five are “superior,” namely two lusts, those which arise from Rūpadhātu and from Ārūpyadhātu, namely dissipation, pride and ignorance.
’They are “superiot,” which means that one cannot pass beyond the higher spheres when one has not abandoned them.
This exposition of the connections is finished.
How many bandhanas or bonds are there?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trīṇi bandhanāni / rāgo bandhanaṃ sarvaḥ dveṣo bandhanaṃ sarvaḥ moho bandhanaṃ sarvaḥ /
column2: Three, namely all lust, all batred, and all ignorance.
Why are only these three called bonds?
There are three bonds by reason of sensation.
There are three bonds by reason of the three sensations.
Lust creates aṉuśayana, that is, “becomes lodged in and grows” in agreeable sensation, both by taking it as its object and by associatioṇ;
hatred in disagreeable sensation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aduḥkhāsukhāyāṃ moho na tathā rāgadveṣau / svāsāṃtanikālambanato vā niyamaḥ /
column2: and ignorance, and—but not in the same manner—lust and hatred, in the sensation of indifference.
Or rather the preceeding rule refers to the sensation of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra ye yāvat kleśā upakleśā api te / cittopakleśanāt /
column2: The kleśas are upakleśas because they defile the mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye 'pyanye caitasāḥ kliṣṭāḥ saṃskāraskandhasaṃjñitāḥ / kleśebhyaste 'pyupakleśāste tu na kleśasaṃjñitāḥ //
column2: Defiled mental states, forming part of the sa/ṁskāraskandha, but different from the kleśas, are also upakleśas without being kleśas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye 'pyanye kleśebhyaḥ kliṣṭā dharmāḥ saṃskāraskandhasaṃgṛhītāścaitasikāsta upakleśāste punarye kṣudravastuke paṭhitāḥ /
column2: Dbarmas different from the kleśas, defiled mental states, included within the semskāraskandha, are solely xpakleśas. Upakleśas means that which is found near the kleśa, or close to which the élesa is found, (i. , which is produced following the klefa). Not being roots, they are not kleś5,:¹⁶⁶ the npakleśas are enumerated in the Kṣudravastuka.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: iha tu paryasthānakleśamalasaṃgṛhītāneva nirdekṣyāmaḥ / kāni punaḥ paryavasthānānītyāha /
column2: Let us now explain the relationship of the kleśas with the wrappings and the kleśamalas.
A klefa is also a wrapping, as we can see from the text: “One experiences a suffering which proceeds from the wrapping which is luṣt.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prakaraṇaśāstre tu āhlīkyamanapatrāpyamīrṣyāmātsaryamuddhavaḥ / kaukṛtyaṃ styānamiddhaṃ ca paryavasthānamaṣṭadhā //
column2: The Prakaraṇapādaśāstra teaches that there are eight wrappings.
The system of the Vaibhashikas admits ten, by adding.
Also anger and hypocrisy. Disrespect and absence of fear.
Envy or mental dissatisfaction concerns the prosperity of another.
Avarice is tenacity of the mind, which is opposed to either spiritual or material giving.
Dissipation. Regret.
Regret is good or bad, but only defiled regret is a wrapping. Torpor.
Languor is a compression of the mind which rends it incapable of commanding the body.
Languor can be good, bad, or neutral, but only defiled languor is a wrapping.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaukṛtyaṃ ca vyāpāda vihiṃsāvarjitaḥ sattvāsattvayorāghātaḥ krodhaḥ /
column2: Anger is irritation of the mind with respect to living beings and to things, an irritation distinct from that of regret, anger or hostility.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avadyapracchādanaṃ bhrakṣaḥ / eṣāṃ ca daśānāṃ paryavasthānānāṃ
column2: Hypocrisy is hiding one's faults. What is the origin of the wrappings?
From out of lust there proceeds disrespect, dissipation, and avarice.
These three paklesas proceed from lust.
There is no agreement with regard to hypocrisy.
There is no agreement with regard to hypocrisy according to some, it proceeds from out of desire;
according to others, from out of ignorance;
according to others, from out of one or the other accordingly as it refers to persons who are knowledgeable or who are ignorant.
From out of ignorance there proceeds torpor, languor, and absence of fear.
These three proceed from ignorance.
From out of doubt there proceeds regret and anger; from out of hatred there proceeds envy.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratighasamutthe ityete ca daśa kleśaniḥṣyandā upakleśāḥ /
column2: It is thus that these ten wpaklefas are an outflowing of the klesas. (In the same way that foul things, wala, leave the body, so too the klesamalas, "tilth of the klesas," come out of the klesas).
What are the klesamalas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: māyā śāṭhyaṃ madastathā // pradāśa upanāhaśca vihiṃsā ceti tatra paravañcanā māyā /
column2: Cheating is the dharma that causes one to delude another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cittakauṭilyaṃ śāṭhyaṃ yena yathābhūtaṃ nāviṣkaroti vikṣipatya parisphuṭaṃ vā pratipadyate /
column2: Double-dealing or crookedness of mind causes one not to say. Things as one should, not to deny when one should, or to explain something in a confused manner.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: madaḥ pūrvoktaḥ / sāvadyavastudṛḍhagrāhitā pradāśo yena nyāyasaṃjñaptiṃ na gṛhṇāti /
column2: The drunkenness of pride, as.
Esteeming evil is what which causes one not to accept remonstrances. Enmity is aversion.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: viheṭhnaṃ vihiṃsā yena prahārapāruṣyādibhiḥ parān viheṭhyate / eṣāṃ punaḥ ṣaṇṇāṃ kleśamalānāṃ
column2: Hostility is what is translated into deeds and words harmful to another.
From out of lust there proceeds cheating and the drunkenness of pride; from anger enmity and hostility;
esteeming evil from out of the esteeming of views; and crookedness from out of view.
Crookedness is an outflowing of view, for it is said in a stanza, “What is crookedness?
It is transgressing views.” The wrappings and the malas arise from the kleśar; they are thus upakleśas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ka eṣāṃ kiṃprahātavyaḥ / yāni tāvat daśa paryavasthānānyuktāni
column2: How are they abandoned? Disrespect, absence of fear, torpor, languor, and dissipation are abandoned through Seeing and Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāhlīkyānapatrāpyastyānamiddhoddhavā dvidhā // ete pañca dharmā dvividhā darśanabhāvanāprahātavyā ubhayaprakārakleśasaṃprayogāt / yaśca yaddarśanaheyasaṃprayuktaḥ sa taddarśanaprahātavyaḥ /
column2: Five wrappings—namely the five the first of which is disrespect—being associated with two kleśas, are twofold: abandoned through Seeing and Meditation. They are abandoned.
The other wrappings are solely abandoned through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tebhyo 'nye paryavasthānasaṃgṛhītā upakleśā bhāvanāheyā eva / irṣyāmātsaryakaukṛtyakrodhabhrakṣāḥ svatantrāśca / svatantrāścaite pañcopakleśā adhimātrasaṃprayogitvāt / yathaite īrṣyādayaḥ pañcopakleśā bhāvanāheyāḥ
column2: The other wrappings, envy and the rest, are abandoned only by Meditation: in fact they are of the so-called “autonomous” category, being associated with a single ignorance which is abandoned through Meditation.
And so too the ṁalas, being autonomous.
The same holds for the kleśfamalas.
In Kāmadhātu, they are of two types; the others are bad;
Torpor, dissipation, and languor are both bad and neutral.
Above, the #wpakleśas are neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmadhātorurdhvamavyākṛtāḥ upakleśā yathāsaṃbhavam / kati punareṣāṃ kutastyā veditavyāḥ /
column2: Above Kāmadhātu, the #pakleias—to the extent that they exist there—are neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: māyā śāṭhyaṃ ca kāmādyadhyānayoḥ etau dvau kāmadhātau prathame ca dhyāne /
column2: Cheating and crookedness exist in Kāmadhātu and in the First Dhyāṇna. These two upakleśas exist in two spheres, Kāmadhātu and Ṛūpadhātu.
Since Brahmā tried to deceive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: brahmavañcanāt / sa hi tatra mahābrahmā vitathātmasaṃdarśanatayā āyuṣmantamaśvajitaṃ vañcayituṃ pravṛttaḥ / uktamapi śāṭhyaṃ prasaṅgāgataṃ punarevoktam / styānauddhatyamadā dhātutraye ete trayastraidhātukāḥ / anye kāmadhātujāḥ //
column2: We cannot doubt this, for Mahābrahmā attempted to deceive the Āyuṣman Aśvajit by giving him an inexact definition of himself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣoḍaśabhyaḥ pañcāpanīyānya ekādaśopakleśāḥ kāmāvacarā eva / uktā kleśāḥ upakleśāśca / athaiṣāmanuśayānāṃ kati manobhūmikāḥ kati ṣaḍvijñānakāyikāḥ /
column2: Of the sixteen pakleshas, ten wrappings and six alas, eleven exist only in Kāmadhātu, with the exception of cheating, crookedness, torpor, dissipation, and pridefulness.
Those that are abandoned through Seeing the Truths are of the spheres of the manovijñāna, plus pride and languor.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanaprahātavyāḥ sarve manobhūmikāḥ saha mānasiddhābhyāṃ bhāvanāheyābhyāmapi /
column2: Kleśas and upakleśas which are abandoned through Seeing are supported by the manovijñāna alone; so too pride and languor which are abandoned through Meditation;
for these two, in their totality, are of the sphere of the manas.
Plus the autonomous pakleshas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye ca kecidupakleśāḥ svatantrāste bhāvanāheyā api santo manobhūmikā eva draṣṭavyāḥ /
column2: In the same way, the antonomous pakleshas are abandoned through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣaḍvijñānāśrayāḥ pare // anye kleśopakleśāḥ ṣaḍvijñānabhūmikāḥ veditavyāḥ / ke punaranye /
column2: The others have the six consciousnesses for their support.

The others are supported by the six consciousnesses: lust is abandoned through Meditation, as are hatred and ignorance, as well as the pakleshar which are associated with them, disrespect, absence of fear, torpor, and dissipation, and those which are.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye ca kleśamahābhūmikeṣūktāḥ / yānīmāni sukhādīni pañcendriyāṇi eṣāṃ katamenendriyeṇa katamaḥ kleśa upakleśo vā saṃprayuktaḥ /
column2: With which sense organs are the kleśas and the wpakleśar associated?
First, with respect to the kleśas of Kāmadhātu: Lust is associated with two agreeable sensations.
Lust is associated with pleasure and satisfaction.
Hatred with the contrary.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhābhyāmityarthaḥ / duḥkhena daurmanasyena ca / harṣadainyākāravartitvāt ṣaṅvijñānabhūmikatvācca rāgadveṣayoḥ /
column2: Hatred is associated with displeasure and dissatisfaction, for lust and hatred have respectively happiness and dejection for their aspect, for both of them belong to the six consciousnesses.
Moha with all.
Being associated with all the kJefas, ignorance is associated with the five sensations.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaddṛṣṭirmanoduḥkhasukhena tu // manoduḥkhaṃ daurmanasyaṃ manaḥsukhaṃ saumanasyaṃ ca /
column2: The view of negation with dissatisfaction and sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tābhyaṃ mithyādṛṣṭiḥ saṃprayuktā puṇyakarmaṇāṃ pāpakarmaṇāṃ ca yathākramam /
column2: False view is associated with dissatisfaction among those persons who have done meritorious actions and who regret that their actions are without result; it is associated with satisfaction among transgressors.
Doubt with dissatisfaction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃśayito hi niścayenārthī durmanāyate / anye saumanasyena
column2: If one who aspires to certitude doubts, then he is dissatisfied.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anye 'nuśayāḥ saumanasyenaiva saṃprayuktāḥ / ke punaranye / catasro dṛṣṭano mānaśca / harṣākāravartitvāt /
column2: The others, that is, the views with the exception of false views and egotism—are associated with satisfaction, for they have the aspect of happiness.
Which anuśayas have we considered up to now?
Those arisen in Kāmadhātu.
Having indicates the difference of these gnuśayas, the author notes a common characteristic: All are associated with indifference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarve 'pyete 'nuśayā upekṣendriyeṇa saṃprayuktāḥ / pravāhacchedakāle kila kleśānāmavaśyamupekṣā saṃtiṣṭhate /
column2: All these anuśayas are associated with the indriya of indifference, for, says the School, there is necessarily indifference when the series of the £/efa is going to be broken.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: adhobhūmikāḥ kathamityāha svaiḥ svairyathābhumyūrdhvabhūmikāḥ // svaiḥ svairindriyairurdhvabhūmikā anuśayāḥ saṃprayujyante /
column2: With respect to the kesas of the higher spheres: In the higher stages, they are associated with their own seṇsations, to be determined according to the stage.

In the higher stages, the aṉuśayas are associated with the sensation which are proper to them, to the extent that these sensations exist there. In the stage—the First Dhyāna—where there are four consciousnesses, seeing, hearing, touch, and mental consciousness. The anufayas which are produced with each of these consciousnesses are associated with the sensations proper to this consciousness: there one finds the sensation of pleasure corresponding to the consciousnesses of seeing, hearing, and touch;

the sensation of satisfaction corresponding to the mental consciousness; and the sensation of indifference corresponding to the four consciousnesses. In the stages—the Second Dhyāna, etc. —where only the mental consciousness is found, the anuśayas which are produced with this consciousness are associated with the sensations proper to this consciousness in the state in question: Second Dhyāna, satisfaction end indifference: Third Dhyāna, pleasure and indifference; Fourth Dhyāna and Ārūpyas, indifference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upakleśānāṃ punaḥ daurmanasyena kaukṛtyamīrṣyā krodho vihiṃsanam / upanāhaṃ pradāśaśca saṃprayuktānīti vartate / dainyākāravartitvādeṣāṃ manobhūmikatvācca / mātsaryaṃ tu viparyayāt //
column2: With respect to the pakÉeśas: Regret, envy, anger, hostility, aversion, and the esteeming of evil are associated with dissatisfaction. These wpakleśas are associated with the indriya of dissatisfaction because they have dejection for their mode and they belong to.
Avarice is associated with the śndriya of satisfaction;
it has happiness for its mode, for it proceeds greed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: māyā śāṭhyamathī bhrakṣo middhaṃ cobhayathā saumanasyadaurmanasyābhyāṃ saṃprayujyante / kadāciddhi sumanāḥ paraṃ vañcayate / kadāciddurmanāḥ / evaṃ yāvat svapiti /
column2: Crookedness, cheating, hypocrisy, and languor are associated with one and the other. ““Associated with the ⁴ndriya of satisfaction and with the indriya of dissatisfaction:” it happens that one deceives another with satisfaction, and one deceives with dissatisfaction.
Pridefulness is associated with the two agreeable sensations.
In the Third Dhyāna, pridefulness is associated with the indriya of pleasure; below, with the ôndriya of satisfaction;
above, with the ⁴ndriya of indifference.
Indifference is everywhere.
All are associated with indifference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi tasyāḥ kvacit pratiṣedho yathā 'vidyāyāḥ /
column2: In the way that there is no restriction in the association of the kleśfa and the wpakleśas with ignorance, so too with indifference.
The four others with five.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āhlīkyamanapatrāpyaṃ styānamauddhatyaṃ caitānicatvāri paryavasthānāni pañcabhirapīndriyaiḥ saṃprayujyante /
column2: FPour wrappings—namely disrespect, absence of fear, torpor, and dissipation—are associated with the five sensations, because.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akuśalamahābhūmikatvāt kleśamahābhūmikatvācca / yāni sūtre pañca nivaraṇāni uktāni kāmacchando vyāpādaḥ styānamiddhamauddhatyakaukṛtyaṃ vicikitsā ca /
column2: From another point of view, the Sutra declares that there are five hindrances or obstacles, among the kleśas and upakleśas: kāmacchaṇda, anger, torpor-languor, dissipation-regret, and doubt.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra kiṃ traidhātukyaḥ styānauddhatyavicikitsā gṛhyante / atha kāmapratisaṃyuktā eva / “kevalo 'yaṃ paripūrṇo'kuśala rāśiryaduta pañca nivaraṇānī“tyekāntākuśalatvavacanātsūtre /
column2: Does this refer to the torpor, dissipation, and doubt of all the three Dhātus, or only of Kāmadhātu? The Sutra says that the hindrances are exclusively bad;
consequently, the hindrances exist in Kāmadhātu.
But in none of the other Dhātus.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ dve styānamiddhe ekaṃ nivaraṇamuktaṃ dve cauddhatyakaukṛtye ekam /
column2: Why do torpor-and-languor and dissipation-and-regret constitute, as groups, two hindrances?
Two make up a single hindrance because they have the same opposites, the same nourishment, and the same result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vipakṣaḥ pratipakṣo 'nāhāra ityeko 'rthaḥ / styānamiddhayoreka āhāraḥ sūtre 'nāhāraśca /
column2: The Sutra teaches that torpor and languor have the same nourishment and the same counter-nourishment.
What is the nourishment of torpor-languor?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañca dharmāḥ / tandrā aratirvijṛmbhikā bhakte 'samatā cetaso līnatvamiti / atha styānamiddhanivaraṇasyānāhāraḥ ālokasaṃjñeti /
column2: Five dharmas, namely ¢andrī. arati, vijṛmbhikā and bhakte’ṣamatā, and cetaso līnatva. What is the counter-nourishment?
Ālokasaṁjñā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhe api hyete cittaṃ layaṃ codayataḥ /
column2: Toṟpor and languor have the same action or task of rendering the mind languid.
In this same way dissipation and regret have the same nourishment, the same counter-nourishment, and the same effect.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: catvāro dharmāḥ / jñātivitarko janapadavitarko 'maravitarkaḥ paurāṇasya ca hasitakriḍitaramitaparibhāvitasyānusmartā bhavatīti / kaścauddhatyakaukṛtyanivaraṇasyānāhāraḥ /
column2: Its nourishment is four dharmas: preoccupation relative to one’s relatives, preoccupation relative to one’'s land, preoccupation relative to the deathless ones, and remembrance of one’s former merry-making and companions.
Its counter-nourishment is calmness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ubhe api hyete cittamavyupaśāntaṃ vartayataḥ / ata ekavipakṣāhārakṛtyatvāt dvayorapyekatvamuktam /
column2: Its effect is to agitate the mind.
But all the ēleśas are a “hindrance.” Why does the Sūtra distinguish five hindrances?
Only five, be reason of the destruction of a rkandha, by reason of doubt.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmacchandavyāpādābhyāṃ śīlaskandhavidhātaḥ / styānamiddhena prajñāskandhasyauddhatyakaukṛtyena samādhiskandhasya samādhiprajñayorabhāve satyeṣu vicikitsako bhavatītyataḥ pañcoktāni /
column2: Kāmacchanda and anger destroy the element of morality, torpor-languor destroy the element of discrimination, and dissipation-regret destroy the element of absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etasyāṃ tu kalpanāyāṃ samādhiskandhavirodhina auddhatyakaukṛtyanivaraṇasya pūrva grahaṇaṃ prāpnoti /
column2: And in theBut, one would say, if this explanation is correct, dissipation regret, which hinders absorption, should be listed, in the list of the hindrances, before torpor-languor.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato yathāsaṃkhyametābhyāṃ samādhiprajñāskandhopaghāta ityapare / samādhiprayuktasya hi styānamiddhādbhayam / dharmapravicayaprayuktasyauddhatyakaukṛtyāditi /
column2: Thus these two hindrances destroy, in the order in which they are named, the two elements of absorption and discrimination: the danger to the person who applies himself to absorption is in torpor-languor; the danger to him who applies himself to discrimination of the dharmas is in dissipation-regret.
Other masters give another explanation.
How do they explain this? The monk on his rounds perceives an agreeable or disagreeable object, and considers it as such;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cāragatasya priyāpriyarūpeṣu viṣayeṣu nimittagrāhādvihāragatasya tatpūrvakau kāmacchandavyāpādau samādhipraveśasyādito 'ntarāyaṃ kurutaḥ /
column2: when he returns to the monastery the enjoyment and the aversion which proceed from this agreeable-disagreeable impression, first hinder his entry into absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ samādhipraviṣṭasyāprayogeṇa śamathavipaśyanā sevanāt styānamiddhamauddhatyakaukṛtyaṃ vicikitsā ca yathākramaṃ śamathavipaśyanayorantarāyaṃ kurutaḥ /
column2: Then, when the monk has entered into absorption, as he does not correctly cultivate calm and insight, there is then produced torpor-languor.
Finally, when he has left the absorption, doubt hinders his reflection on the dharmas.
It is in this way that there are the five hinderances.

There is one point to be examined. Let us consider the esas “universal in a different sphere” —that is, those that form the group of false views, etc. , and are abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and of the Arising of Suffering—which have for their object the two higher spheres. This object is “completely known” by the anvayajñānas of Suffering and the Arising of Suffering which bear on the higher spheres : but it is not at the moment when these envayajñānas are produced that the kleśas in question are abandoned, for, also having Kāmadhātu for their sphere, these kleśas have been formerly destroyed by the dharmajñānas of Suffering and the Arising of Suffering the production of which is before that of the anvayajñānas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: visabhāgadhātusarvatragāṇāṃ nirodhamārgadarśanaprahātavyānāṃ ca sāsravālambanānāṃ yadālambanaṃ parijñāyate tadā na prahīyante /
column2: Conversely, with respect to the kleśas having an impure objectIt is not when their object is completely known that the group of false views to be abandoned through the Seeing of the Extinction of Suffering and of the Path are abandoned. Rather, they are abandoned only later by the Seeing of the Extinction of Suffering and by the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā prahīyante tadālambanaṃ na parijñāyate iti kathameṣāṃ prahāṇam /
column2: Thus, how can one say that these two categories of kleśas are abandoned by a knowledge of their object?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāvaśyamālambanaparijñānāt kleśānāṃ kṣayo bhavati / kim tarhi /
column2: It is not an absolute principle that the kleśas are abandoned by a knowledge of their object.
They are abandoned in four ways.
With respect to the kleśas abandoned through Seeing: 60a-c.
Destruction by a knowledge of the object, by the destruction of the kleśas of which they are the object, and by the abandoning of the object.
Suffering, or having a pure object, abandoned through the Seeing of the Extinction of Suffering and the Path, are abandoned through a knowledge of their object.
The universal kleśas in another sphere, abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and the Arising of Suffering, are abandoned through the destruction of the kef of which they are the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadālambanā hi sabhāgadhātusarvatragāḥ / teṣu prahīṇeṣu te 'pi prahīṇā bhavanti /
column2: These klesas are of the object of a universal kleśa in its own sphere: by the destruction of those, these are also destroyed.
The kleśas having an impure object, abandoned through the Seeing of the Extinction of Suffering and the Path are abandoned through the abandoning of their object.
These keś25 have for their object the k/esśa which has a pure object.
By the destruction of those, these are also destroyed.
With respect to the k/eśas abandoned through Meditation, 60d.
There is destruction through the arising of the opposition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasya hi kleśaprakārasya pratipakṣo mārga utpadyate sa prahīyate /
column2: When a path is opposed to one category of kleśa, this path, by arising, causes this category of defilement to be abandoned. This will be taught in detail: "The weak-weak path is opposed to the strong-strong category. The strong-strong path is opposed to the weak-weak category.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasya punaḥ kaḥ pratipakṣaḥ / adhimātrādhimātrasya mṛdumṛduriti vistāreṇa paścāt pravedayiṣyāmaḥ / katividhaśca pratipakṣa ityāha
column2: How many types of oppositions are there?
Opposition is fourfold: abandoning, maintaining, removal, and disgust.
The Uninterrupted Path is a prahāṇa-prasipakṣa, 'an opposition which results in abandoning.
The next path, the Path of Deliverance, is an adhāra-pratipakṣa, 'opposition through which the abandoning obtained by the proceeding path, is found to be maintained, affirmed.
The next path, viśeṣamārga is the dGrībhāva-pratipakṣa, "opposition by which the possession of the klefa previously cut off, is found to be removed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vimuktimārgo 'pītyapare / so 'pi hi tāṃ prāpti dūrīkaroti /
column2: According to others, the Path of Deliverance is itself the opposition of removal, for the possession of the klesa is also removed from it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vidūṣaṇāpratipakṣo yena mārgeṇa taṃ dhātum doṣato darśanādvidūṣayati / api tveṣāmiyamātupūrvīṃ sādhvī bhavet /
column2: The path which consists of considering a sphere of existence as bad and which finds disgust in it is the path.
But we say, here is the correct order: opposition through disgust is the Preparatory Path;
opposition through abandoning is the whole of the Uninterrupted Path;
opposition through which the proceeding path is maintained is the Path of Deliverance;
and opposition by which the possession of the kleśa previously cut off, is removed is the Distinguished Path.
When one abandons the klesas, through separation from what are they abandoned?
The klesa is supposed to become abandoned through separation from its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi saṃprayogāt kleśo vivecayituṃ śakyate ālambanācca śakyate / yasmānna punastadālambyotpadyate /
column2: The klesa, in fact, cannot be separated from its samṁprayoga, but it can be separated from its object in such a manner that it no longer re-arises bearing on this object.
A future klesa can be separated from its object, but how can a past kleśa be? The thing that it has taken as its object remains having been taken as object.
Would you say that theBut the rule that the Īśa is abandoned through knowledge of the object is not absolute;
consequently, there is a difficulty to be resolved here.
What does one do in order that the kleśas may be termed prahīṇa, or "abandoned?

A personal kleśa is abandoned through the cutting off of prāpti or the possession of this kleśa which exists in the personal series.
pārasāṃtānikastu kleśaḥ sarvaṃ ca rūpamakliṣṭaśca dharmastadālambanasvāsāṃtānikakleśaprahāṇāt / dūrībhāva ityucyate /	As for the kleśa of another, or for rāpa in its totality (kz. ala, etc. ), or for the undefiled dharmas, these diverse things are abandoned through the abandoning of the personal élefa which takes them as its object.
katividhho dūrībhāvaḥ /	How many types of separation are there?
caturvidhā kila dūratā /	There are four, say the School: 62.
vailakṣaṇyādvipakṣatvāddeśavicchedakālataḥ / bhūtaśīlapradeśādhvadvayānāmiva dūratā //	Separation through difference of nature, through opposition, through separation of place, and through time;
vilakṣaṇadūratā yathā mahābhūtānām /	as, for example, the primary elements, the precepts, places, and the two time periods.
vailakṣaṇyātsahajānāmapi dūratā /	Separation through difference of nature: although thePrimary elements arise together, they are separated one from the other by the fact of their different natures.
vipakṣadūratā yathā śīlasya dauḥśīlyam /	Separation by opposition: one is separated from immorality by the precepts.
deśavicchedadūratā yathā viprakṛṣṭadeśānāṃ deśavicchedāt pūrvapaścimasamudravat /	Separation of place by difference of place: the oceans of the East and the West.
kāladūratā yathā atītānāgatadūramucyate /	Separation by time: as the past and the future.
dutastaddūram /	One says that the past and the future are separated: from what are they separated?
vartamānāt /	They are separated from the present.
yadanantarātamutpadyamānaṃ vā tat kathaṃ dūram /	How can the past which has just perished and the future which is about to arise be separated from the present? It is by reason of the difference of time period that, according to us, the past and the future are separated;
adhvanānātvena taddūraṃ na cirabhūtabhāvitvena /	not by reason of the fact that they will be distant in the past or in the future.
vartamānamapyevaṃ dūraṃ prāpnoti /	For if this were the case, the present would also be separate, for it constitutes a different time period. We say that the past and the future are separated through their activity.
akāritrā ttarhi taddūram / asaṃskṛtasya kathamantikatvaṃ sidhyati /	But how can an unconditioned thing, which is always inactive, be considered as near?
sarvatra tatprāpteḥ /	Because, universally, they possess the two extinctions.
atītānāgate 'pi tatprasaṅgaḥ /	This argument would hold for the past and the future (one possesses past and future good dharmas, etc. );
ākāśaṃ ca katham /	but how can space, which one cannot possess, be near?
evaṃ tarhyatītānāgatamanyo 'nyaṃ varttamānavyavahitatvād dūram /	We say that the past and the future are separated from one another because they are separated by the present;
varttamānamubhayo rāsannatvādantikam /	the present is near because it is near to the past and future;
asaṃskṛtaṃ cāpyavyavahitatvāditi /	an unconditioned thing is near because it is not separated or hindered by anything.
evamapyatītānāgataṃ varttamānasyāntikatvādubhayaṃ prāpnoti /	But then the past and the future will be at one and the same time far and near, being far from each other and near to the present.
evaṃ tu yuktaṃ syāt /	Here is the correct explanation.
dharmasvalakṣaṇādanāgataṃ dūramasaṃprāptatvāt /	The future is separated from the unique, self characteristics of the dharmas, because it has not attained them;
atītaṃ ca pracyutatvāditi /	the past is separated from them because it has fallen away from them. It has been said that the keshas are not destroyed through the arising of their opposition or opposites.
kim mārgaviśeṣagamanāt kleśānāṃ punaḥ prahāṇaviśeṣo bhavati / naitadasti / sarveṣāṃ hi kleśānāṃ sakṛt kṣayaḥ	We would ask if, through the Distinguished Path, there is a progressive abandoning" of the kleshas?
The kleśa is destroyed through the Path which is its “path of abandoning.”
But the acquisition of disconnection from the keśas takes place many times.
In how many moments? In six moments: there is arising of the opposition, the acquisition of results, and the perfection of the faculties.
“Opposition” here means the “Path of Deliverance.”
“Results” means the four results of the religious life, the result of Srotaāpaṇṇna, etc. “Perfection of the faculties” refers to £ndriyasaṁeāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eteṣu kāleṣu kleśasya visaṃyogalābhaḥ / sa punareṣa yathāyogaṃ draṣṭavyaḥ / keṣāñcit ṣaṭsu kāleṣu keṣāñcid yāvaddvayoḥ /
column2: Disconnection from the klesas is acquired in these moments: for certain kleśas, according to the case, in six moments; but in decreasing number down to two for others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa eva visaṃyogastāsu tāsvavasthāsu parijñāsaṃjñāṃ labhate /
column2: Under certain conditions, disconnection receives the name of parijñā, 'perfect knowledge” (Vibhāṣa, TD 27, p.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dve hi parijñe jñānaparijñā prahāṇaparijñā ca / tatra jñānaparijñā sāsravaṃ jñānam / prahāṇaparijñā tu prahāṇameva / phale hetūpacārāt /
column2: There are two types of perfect knowledge: jñānaparijñā, “perfect knowledge consisting of knowledge,”’ which is pure knowledge;
and prahāṉaparijñā, `perfect knowledge whichDoes all abandoning constitute one perfect knowledge?
Why is this?
There are nine perfect knowledges.
That is, the destruction of the first two types of Kāma consititute one perfect knowledge.
That is, the destruction of the first two types of klesa of Kāmadhātu, the é/eśas abandoned through the Seeing of Suffering and the Arising of Suffering.

The abandoning of the avarabhāgīya caṇkerous influences, that is, the cankerous influences of Kāmadhātu, constitutes one perfect knowledge.

The abandoning of the cankerous influences of Rūpadhātu, which is called "perfect knowledge consisting of the destruction of attachment to Rūpadhātu", is another perfect knowledge. These perfect knowledges are achieved through the Seeing of Suffering, the Arising of Suffering, the Extinction of Suffering, and the Path.
Rūpadhātu is distinguished from Ārūpyadhātu with respect to the abandoning of the kleśas abandoned through Meditation;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasmādrūpārūpyāvacarāṇāṃ bhāvanāheyānāṃ prahāṇaṃ pṛthak parijñā na darśanaheyānām / bhāvanāheyānāmatulyapratipakṣatvāt /

The others, the results of the knowledges. Knowledge which consists of the abandoning of Kāmadhātu are obtained through the Path of Meditation;
thus they are the result of the "knowledges. " How can a perfect knowledge be the result of patience?

Because the patiences are the associates of the jñānas or knowledges: in the manner in which the associates of a king improperly receive the name of king; or rather, because a patience and a knowledge have the same result.
All are the result of aṉāgamya;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāgamyaphalaṃ sarvā dhyānānāṃ pañca vāthavā / aṣṭau

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vaibhāṣikamatena mauladhyānaphalaṃ pañca parijñā yā rūpārūpyāvacarakleśaprahāṇa svabhāvāḥ /
column2: According to the Vaibhāṣikas, five are the result of the ṁmauladhyānas or the "principal absorptions," namely, those which consist of the abandoning of the kleśas of the sphere of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu (perfect knowledges four, five, six, eight and nine). prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa hi vītarāgasyāpi kāmāvacarāṇāṃ darśanaheyānāṃ prahāṇaṃ darśanamārgaphalamicchanti / anāsravavisaṃyogaprāptilābhāt /

The single perfect knowledge which consists of the abandoning of the cankerous influence of Kāmadhātu is solely the result of anāgamya.
This holds as well for dhyānāntara as for the principle Dhyāṇas. One is the result of a sámantaka.

Two of the worldly path.

The last three are the result of dharmajñāna included in the Path of Meditation, for this knowledge is opposed to the keśas of the three spheres abandoned through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣaṭ tatpakṣasya pañca ca // dharmajñānapakṣasya ṣaṭ parijñāḥ phalaṃ yā eva dharmajñāna kṣantijñānānām /

column2: With regard to abandoning, the result of the patiences (Path of Seeing the Truths): There is perfect knowledge by reason of the pure acquisition of disconnection, the partial abandoning of Bhavāgra, and the destruction of two causes.

column2: In the fourth moment, Bhavāgra is “mutilated,” and so too in the fifth: but the two causes are not destroyed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jñānaphalaṃ tu prahāṇam / ataśca kāraṇatrayāt parijñākhyāṃ labhate / caturthācca
column2: With respect to the three perfect knowledges which consist of the abandonings, the results of knowledge (Path of Meditation on the Truths), they are thus called by reason of these three characteristics and by reason of a fourth: 68d.
By the reason of the fact that one passes over a sphere.
That is, because the ascetic detaches himself from a sphere in its totality.
Other masters formulate a fifth cause: the fact of being disjoined from a twofold bond.

How many perfect knowledges can one possess?
One who is to be found in the Path of Seeing of the Truths is either not endowed with perfect knowledge, or is endowed with from one to five perfect knowledges.
A Prthagjana has no perfect knowledges.
In the Path of Seeing, the Āryan is not endowed with any perfect knowledge until samnṇdaye dharmajñānakṣānti (vi. 25c and foll.

column2: When one has obtained this detachment, either before or after the comprehension of the Truths, one is endowed with a single perfect knowledge of the abandoning of the cankerous influences of Kamadhatu.
The Arhat who obtains the quality of Arhat is endowed with a single perfect knowledge of the annihilation of all the bonds.

The Arhat who falls away from the quality of Arhat through a wrapping of Rupadhatu finds himself again in the condition of an Aryan who is detached from Kamadhatu: one is thus endowed with a single perfect knowledge of the abandoning of the cankerous influences of Kamadhatu. Falling away through one defilement of Kamadhatu, he finds himself again in the condition of an Aryan not detached from this sphere: six perfect knowledges. column2: 9 par hāna is used toWe have said how the abandoning of the defilements receives the name of “perfect knowledge”. As for abandoning, la-b.
It has been said that the defilements are abandoned through Seeing the Truths and through Meditation.
We have explained in detail that some of the defilements are to be abandoned through Seeing, and others through Meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāvidānīṃ darśanabhāvanāmārgau kimanāsravau sāsravāviti vaktavyam / ata idamucyate
column2: Is the Path of Seeing and the Path of Meditation pure or impure?
The Path of Meditation is of two types; the Path of Seeing is pure.
The Path of Meditation is worldly or impure as well as transworldly or pure.
The Path of Seeing is opposed to the defilements of the Three Dhātus;
it eliminates in one single stroke the nine categories of the defilements to be abandoned through Seeing; it is thus exclusively transworldly;
now such a power does not belong to a woṟldly path.
We have said, “through Seeing the Truths.”
What are the Truths?
The Four Truths have been mentioned.
By saying "The pure dharmas are the Truth of the Path," we have designated the Truth of the Path by its name.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “anāsravā mārgasatyami“ti svaśabdena “pratisaṃkhyānirodho yo visaṃyoga” iti nirodhasatyaṃ “duḥkhaṃ samudayo loka” ityatra duḥkhasamudayasatye
column2: By saying "Pratásaṁkhyānirodha is disconnection," we have designated the Truth of Extinction. By saying "Suffering, origin, world," we have designated the Truths of Suffering and Origin.
Is that the order of the Truths?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tarhi / duḥkhaṃ samudayastathā / nirodhamārga iti eṣa eṣāmanukramaḥ /
column2: Rather: Namely suffering, origin, extinction, and path.
The word "namely" indicates that the nature of the Truths is indeed as has been mentioned in the First Chapter.
Their order is that in which they are understood.
The Truth that is understood first is mentioned first.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: itarathā hi pūrvaṃ hetunirdeśo 'bhaviṣyat paścāt phalanirdeśaḥ /
column2: Otherwise there would be the occurrence of first mentioning the cause and then the result.
Sometimes dharmas are arranged in the order in which they arise;
this is the case for the applications of mindfulness, the smrṛtyupasthānas and for the Dhyāṇnas. Sometimes they are arranged in an order favorable for teaching;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: deṣāñcitprarūpaṇānukūlā deśanā yathā samyak prahāṇānām / na hyeṣa niyamo yat pūrvamutpannānāṃ prahāṇāya cchandaṃ janayati / paścādanutpannānāmanutpādāyeti /
column2: this is the case for the right abandonings, the sayakprahāṇas, existent dharmas and the black āharmas are easier to.
The Truths are mentioned in the order in which they are comprehended.
Why are they comprehended in this order?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatra hi satto yena ca vādhyate yataśca mokṣaṃ prarthayate tadevādau vyavacāraṇāvasthāyāṃ duḥkhasatyaṃ parīkṣyate /
column2: Because, in the period preparatory to the Path proper, that is, the period of examination, the ascetic first creates an idea of that to which he is attached, of that by which he is totmented, of that from which he seeks to be delivered, namely, suffering.

column2: Then he asks what is its cause, and he creates an idea of its origin. Then he asks what does extinction consist of, and he creates an idea of extinction. Then he asks what is the Path to extinction, and he creates an idea of the path.
So too, having seen a disease, one searches out its origin, its disappearance, and its remedy.
This illustration of the Truths is also given in the Sūtra.
In which Sūtra?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā ca vyavacāraṇāvasthāyāṃ satyaparīkṣā tathābhisamayāvasthāyāṃ satyābhisamayaḥ / pūrvavedhāt / dṛṣṭabhūminiḥsaṃgāśvadhāvanavat /
column2: In the Sūtra which says, “Endowed with theIn the order in which, in the course of the period of examination, he creates an idea of the Truths, in this same order, having reached the period of comprehension, he understands the Truths, because comprehension is projected by the preparatory exercises, the same way that a horse gallops without obstacie over familiar teṟrain.
What is the meaning of the word abhisamaya? This word signifies abhisaṁbodha, understanding, comprehension.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: abhisaṃbodha iṇo bodhanārthatvāt / karamādanāsrava eva na sāsravaḥ /
column2: The root signifies “to understand.” Why is comprehension only pure?
Because it is a knowledge tuṟned towards Nirvāṇa and the true.
Samyak means confoṟming to reality.
To the extent that they are a result, the five zpādānaskandhas are the Truth of Suffering, that which one should see in truth as being suffering.
To the extent that they are a cause they are the Truth of Origin or arising, because suffering arises from them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva tayoḥ phalahetubhāvānnāmato bhedo na dravyataḥ / nirodhamārgayostu dravyato 'pi /
column2: Consequently suffering and arising differ in name, but do not differ in fact, since they are the same upādānaskandhas.
The Sūtra gives the name of āryasatya, truth of the Āryans, to the Truths.
What is the meaning of this expression?
They are truth for the Āryans, truths of the Āryans: this is why they are called āryasatya.
Does this mean that they are false for the non-Āryans?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarveṣāmetāni satyānyaviparītatvāt / āryaistu yathaitāni tathā dṛṣṭāni nānyaiḥ / ata āryāṇāmetāni satyānyucyante na tvanāryāṇāṃ vīparītadarśanāt /
column2: Not being erroneous, they are true for everyone.
As the stanza says, “What the Āryans call happy others call painful;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatpare sukhatḥ prāhustadāryā duḥkhato biduḥ //“ iti gāthā /
column2: what others call happy, the Āryans call painful.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dve āryāṇāṃ satye dve ārye cāryāṇāṃ ca satye ityapare /
column2: According to other masters, two are Āryan truths, and two are truths of both Āryans and others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā vedanaikadeśo duḥkhasvabhāvaḥ / kathaṃ sarve sāsravāḥ saṃskārā duḥkhamityucyante /
column2: Since only a part of sensation is painful by its nature, how can one say that all impure, conditioned things are suffering?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhāstriduḥkhatāyogādyathāyogamaśeṣataḥ / manāṣā amanāpāśca tadanye caiva sāsravāḥ //
column2: Impure dharmas, whether they are agreeable, disagreeable, or otherwise, are, without exception, suffering, by reason of the three types of suffering, each according to its type.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tisro hi duḥkhatā duḥkhaduḥkhatā saṃskāraduḥkhatā vipariṇāmaduḥkhatā ca /
column2: There are three types of suffering: suffering which is suffering in and of itself, suffering through the fact of being conditioned, and suffering which is change or transformation.
By reason of these three, all impure conditioned things, without exception, are suffering: agreeable things are suffering because they are subject to transformation;
disagreeable things are suffering in and of themselves;
and neither-disagreeable-nor-agreeable things are suffering because they are conditioned.
What are the agreeable, disagreeable, and neither-disagreeable-nor-agreeable dharmas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tisro vedanā yathākramaṃ tadvaśena sukhavedanīyādayo 'pi saṃskārā manāpādisaṃjñāṃ labhante /
column2: The three sensations, in this order; and, by reason of the three sensations, all the se/skāras which result in agreeable sensation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukhāyā hi vedanāyā vipariṇāmena duḥkhatā / sūtra uktaṃ “sukhā vedanā utpādamukhā sthitisukhā vipariṇāmaduḥkh“ti /
column2: Agreeable sensation is suffering through transformation, as the Sūtra says, “Āgreeable sensation is agreeable when it arises, agreeable while it lasts, but suffering in its change.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhāyāḥ duḥkhasvabhāvenaiva duḥkhatā / “duḥkhā vedanā utpādaduḥkhā sthitiduḥkhā” iti sūtre / aduḥkhāsukhāvedanāyāḥ saṃskāreṇaiva duḥkhatā /
column2: Disagreeable sensation is suffering by nature, as the Sūtra says, “Suffering sensation is suffering when it arises, and suffering while it lasts.”
Neither-disagreeable-nor-agreeable sensation is suffering because it is so decreed by its causes, as the Sūtra says, “That which is impermanent is suffering.”
The same holds true for the samskaras which result in these sensations as for these sensations themselves.

According to other masters, the expressions should be analysed: duhkham eva duhkhatā (''suffering is itself suffering”), viparinama eva duhkhatā (''transformation is itself suffering”), and samskara eva duhkhatā (''conditioned things are themselves suffering”). The meaning is the same.
Agreeable dharmas do not participate in suffering which is.

Suffering in and of itself, nor do the disagreeable dharmas participate in suffering which is transformation: the second state of suffering belongs to the first ones, and the first to the second ones.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarve tusaṃskārāḥ saṃskāraduḥkhatayā duḥkhāḥ / tāṃstvāryā eva paśyanti // āha cātra /
column2: But all conditioned things are suffering from the fact of suffering through the fact of being conditioned, and they are seen under this aspect only by the Āryans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “ūrṇāpakṣma yathaiva hi karatalasaṃsthaṃ na vedyate pumbhiḥ akṣigataṃ tu tathaiva hi janayatyaratiṃ ca pīḍaṃ ca /
column2: Therefore it is said, “One does not feel a hair placed on the palm of the hand; but the same hair, in the eye, causes suffering and injury.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: karatalasadṛśo bālo na vetti saṃskāraduḥkhatāpakṣma akṣisadṛśastu vidvāṃstenaivodvijyate gāḍhami“ti //
column2: So too the ignorant, resembling the hand, do not feel the hair which is suffering through the fact of being conditioned: but the Āryans, resembling the eye, are tortured by it.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi bālānāmāvīcikeṣvapi skandheṣu tathā duḥkhabuddhiḥ pravartate yathāryāṇāṃ bhāvāgrikeṣvapīti /
column2: The Āryans make of existence in the most sublime heaven an idea more painful than do fools make of existence in the most dreadful hell.
But, one would say, the Path is conditioned;
it should thus be suffering from the fact of suffering through the fact of being conditioned.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratikūlaṃ hi duḥkhamiti lakṣaṇānna mārgo duḥkham / na hi tasyotpāda āryāṇāṃ pratikūlaḥ sarvaduḥkhakṣayāvāhanāt /
column2: The Path is not suffering, because the definition of suffering is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadāpi te nirvāṇaṃ śāntataḥ paśyanti tadāpi yadeva duḥkhato dṛṣṭaṃ tasyaiva nirodhaṃ śāntataḥ paśyantina mārgasya /
column2: When they consider Nirvāṇa as peaceful, what they consider as peaceful is the extinction of what they consider as suffering namely impure conditioned things, and not the extinction of the Path.
But, since the agreeable or happiness does exist, why is only suffering, and not the agreeable, a truth of the Āryans?
According to one explanation, it is because of the slightness of happiness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ko hi vidvān pariṣekasukhāṇukena gaṇḍasukhamiti vyavasyet /
column2: In the same way that one calls a pile in which some peas are to be found a pile of beans, so too no one with any intelligence would consider a wound as agreeable because one experiences a very small agreeable sensation when one washes this wound.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āha khalvapi “duḥkhasya ca hetutvāt duḥkhaiścānalpakaiḥ samuditatvāt / duḥkhe ca sati tadiṣṭerduḥkhaṃ sukhamiti vyavasyanti” iti //
column2: And further, Because it is a cause of suffering, because it is produced by many sufferings, because one desires it when one suffers, the agreeable, they conclude, is suffering.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sahaiva tu sukhena sarvaṃ bhavamāryā duḥkhataḥ paśyanti /
column2: But, even if accompanied by happiness, existence in itsTotality has the same flavor of suffering through the fact of being conditioned.
Āryans thus consider it as suffering.
This is why suffering and not happiness is an Āryan Truth.
But how can Āryans regard sensations which are agreeable by nature as suffering?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anityatayā pratikūlatvāt / yathā rūpasaṃjñādīnyapi duḥkhataḥ paśyanti / na catānyevaṃ duḥkhāni yathā duḥkhavedaneti /
column2: They are hateful by reason of their impermanence in the same way that they consider the rāēpas, saṁjñās, etc. , as suffering, even though the rāēpas, saṁjñās, etc. , are not suffering in the same way as is disagreeable sensation.
With regard to the proposed argument “The agreeable is suffering because it is a cause of suffering”: to be a cause of suffering is its aspect or origin;
to see things as a cause of suffering is not to see them as suffering;
how could the Āryans born in Rūpadhātu and in Ārūpyadhātu have an idea of suffering?
