laukikenāryavairāgye visaṃyogāptayo dvidhā /	For the Āryan who detaches himself through the worldly path, his acquisitions of the disconnections are of two types.
laukikena mārgeṇāryavairāgyaṃ gacchato dvividhā visaṃyogaprāptaya utpadyante laukikyo lokottarāśca / lokottareṇa cetyeke	The Āryan who detaches himself from the first eight spheres obtains disconnection from the defilements of these spheres through the worldly path; in other words, he acquires the prāpri or possession of the pratisaṁkhyānirodha of these defilements.
lokottareṇāpyevamityapare / kiṃ kāraṇam /	This possession is worldly and transworldly. According to other masters, he becomes detached through the transworldly path, in the same way. Some other masters say that in the case also where the Āryan becomes detached through the transworldly path, his acquisition of disconṉnection is twofold.
tyavate kleśāsamanvayāt //	For even when pure disconnection is lost, the Aryan is not filled with the defilements.
yadi hyāryamārgeṇa vairāgyaṃ prāpnuvato laukikī visaṃyogaprāpotirnotpadyate evaṃ	Let us admit an instance, when the Aryan becomes detached through the transworldly or Aryan Path, he then does not have worldly possession of disconnection.
sati ya āryamārgeṇākiñcanyāyatanādvītarāgo dhyānaṃ niśrityendriyāṇi saṃcarati sakṛtsnapūrvamārgatyāgātkevalaphalamārgalābhāccordhvabhūmikleśavisaṃyogenāsamanvāgataḥ syāt /	In this hypothesis, there may be an Aryan who, through the Aryan Path, becomes detached from Akinchanyayatana; who then, in a Dhyana, transforms, that is, sharpens his faculties. This Aryan by the fact that he abandons the paths previously acquired, by the fact that he only possesses the path of the state of Anagamin, in relation to his sharp faculties will no longer be in possession of disconnection from the defilements of Arupyadhatu and having lost this disconnection, he will be filled with these defilements.
tyakte ca tasmin taiḥ kleśaiḥ samanvāgataḥ syāditi / bhavāgrādhavimuktordhvajātavattvasamanvayaḥ /	But if he is not filled with these defilements, he is like a saint half delivered from Bhavagra, like a person who is reborn above.
asatyāmapi tu tasyāṃ laukikyāṃ visaṃyogaprāptau na taiḥ samanvāgamaḥ syāt /	This Aryan does not have worldly acquisition of disconnection. Nevertheless this Āryan is not filled with the said defilements.
tadyathā bhavāgrādardha prakāravimuktasyāsatyāmapi tu laukikyāṃ tadvisaṃyogaprāptau tyaktāyāmapi cendriyasaṃcāreṇa lokottarāyāṃ na punastaiḥ kleśaiḥ samanvāgamo bhavati /	So too, the saint who is delivered from half of the categories of defilements of Bhavāgra, certainly does not possess a worldly acquisition of disconnection from these categories, since only the transworldly or Āryan Path destroys the defilements of Bhavāgra. Let us suppose that this saint, sharpening his faculties in a Dhyāna, abandons the transworldly acquisition of disconnection from these defilements of Bhavāgra: you yourself recognize, nevertheless, that he is not filled with these defilements.
yathā ca pṛthagjanasya prathamadhyānabhūmerurdhvaṃ jātasya kāmāvacarakleśavisaṃyogaprāptityāgānna punastaiḥ samanvāgamo bhavatītyajñāpakametat	So too, a Prṛthagjana is born above the First Dhyāna, in the Second Dhyāṇa, etc. By the fact that he passes into the Second Dhyāṇna, he loses the acquisition of disconnection from the defilements of Kāmadhātu; nevertheless you admit that he is not filled with these defilements.
katapayā punarbhūmyā kuto vairāgyaṃ bhavati /	By means of what spheres does one obtain detachment from the different spheres?
anāsraveṇa vairāgyamanāgāmyena sarvataḥ // ābhavāgrāt /	One becomes detached from all the spheres by means.
atha yaḥ sāmantakaṃ niśrityādharabhūmivairāgyaṃ prāpnoti kimasyānantaryamāgavatsarve vimuktimārgāḥ sāmantakādbhavanti / netyāha /	When the ascetic becomes detached from a lower sphere in a sāmauntaka, should one admit that all of the Paths of Deliverance arise from the sāmantaka, as is the case for the Irresistible Paths?
kiṃ tarhi /	Why is this?
dhyānātsāmantakādvā 'ntyo mukti mārgastribhūjaye /	At the detachment from the Three Dhātus, the last Path of Deliverance arises either from the Dhyāṇa, or from a sāmanmtaka.
nava hyapapattibhūmayaḥ / sarvakāmadhāturaṣṭau ca dhyānārupyāḥ /	There are nine spheres of arising: Kāmadhātu, the Four Dhyānas and the Four Ārūpyas.
tatra yāvat dvitīyadhyānavairāgyaṃ tribhūmijayaḥ / tasmin paścimo vimuktimārgaḥ sāmantakādbhavati dhyānādvā maulāt /	When one triumphs over the Three Dhātus, that is, when one becomes detached from Kāmadhātu, from the First Dhyāṇna, or from the Second Dhyāṇna, it is with a ninth Path of Deliverance which arises either from a sāmantaka or from the Dhyāṇna itself.
nordhvaṃ sāmantakāt	Above, it does not arise from a sāmantaka.
tribhūmijayādūrdhvaṃ maulādeva na punaḥ sāmantakādupekṣendriyasāmānyāt /	With respect to the higher spheres, the last Path of Deliverance always arises from the fundamental absorption, never from the preliminary stage or threshold of this absorption.
triṣu hi dhyāneṣu sāmantakamaulayorindriyabhedāt kaścinna śaknoti maulaṃ dhyānaṃ praveṣṭum /	In fact, after the Fourth Dhyāṇna, the fundamental absorption. The preliminary absorption has the same sensation, the sensation of indifference.
indriyasaṃcārasya duṣkaratvāt /	In the spheres of the first Dhyānas, the two sensations differ: ascetics with weak faculties are not capable of entering, in the ninth Path of Deliverance, the fundamental absorption, for the transformation of their sensation is difficult.
atastribhūmivairāgye dhyānasāmantakādapyanyo vimuktimārgo bhavati /	Therefore the ninth Path of Deliverance of detachment from the first three spheres arises from preliminary absorption.
“anāsraveṇa vairāgyamanāgamyena sarvata” ityuktamanyaistu noktam / ata ucyate	We have seen that the ascetic can detach himself from all the spheres through the pure paths practiced in enāgamya. It is not said that the same power belongs to the pure paths cultivated in spheres other than anāgamya.
āryairaṣṭābhiḥ svordhvabhūjayaḥ //	Through the eight pure paths, he triumphs over his sphere, and over a higher sphere.
anāsravairaṣṭābhirdhyānadhyānāntarārupyaiḥ svasyā ūrdhvāyāśca bhūmervairāgyaṃ nādharāyā vītarāgatvāt /	Through the pure path cultivated in eight spheres, the Dhyānas, dhyānāntara, and three Ārūpyas, the ascetic detaches himself from the sphere in which he finds himself and from higher spheres; but not from a lower sphere because he is already.
tatra lokottarā ānantaryavimuktimārgāḥ satyālambanatvātsatyākārapravṛttā iti siddham / vimuktyānantaryapathā laukikāstu yathākramam / śāntādyudārādyākārāḥ	It is established that the transworldly paths, the Irresistible Path as well as the Path of Deliverance, proceed from aspects of the Truths, that is to say, from seeing the dharmas as impermanent, suffering, etc. The worldly paths, paths of deliverance and paths of abandoning, have respectively the aspects of calm, etc. ;
vimuktimārgāḥ śāntādyākārā ānantaryamārgā audārikādyākārāḥ / te punaryathākramam uktarādharagocarāḥ //	coarse, etc. The worldly paths of deliverance have the aspects of calm, etc. , that is, seeing their objects as calm, etc. The worldly paths of abandoning have the aspect of coarse, etc. Respectively.
vimuktimārgā uttarāṃ bhūmiṃ śāntataḥ praṇītato niḥsarṇataścākārayanti saṃbhavataḥ /	They have for their objects the higher sphere, and the lower sphere. The paths of deliverance can see the higher spheres as calm, excellent, and as definitive liberation.
ānantaryamārgā adharāṃ bhūmimaudārikato duḥkhilataḥ sthūlabhittikataśca / aśāntatvādaudarikato mahābhisaṃskārataratvāt /	The paths of abandoning see the lower spheres as coarse, bad, as a thick wall: as coarse, because it is not calm, entailing a great effort;
apraṇītatvāt duḥkhilato bahudauṣṭhulyataratvena pratikūlabhāvāt / sthūlabhittikatastayaiva tadbhūmyaniḥsaraṇāt bhittyaniḥsaraṇavat /	as bad, because it is not excellent, because it is odious as well as presenting the greatest incapacity to.
eṣāṃ viparyayeṇa śāntapraṇītaniḥsaraṇākārāḥ / gata mānuṣaṅgikam /	The aspects of calm, excellent, definitive liberation, are the opposite.
idaṃ tu vaktavyam /	Having terminated this accessory question, let us return to our subject.
atha kṣayajñānākanantaraṃ kimutpadyate	What arises immediately after the Knowledge of Destruction?
yadyakopyaḥ kṣayajñānādanutpādamatiḥ	When he is Immovable, after his Knowledge of Destruction, there is the consciousness of non-arising.
akopyadharmā cedarhanbhavati kṣayajñānātsamanantaramanutpādajñānamasyotpadyate /	If the Arhat is of the class of the Immovable Ones, immediately after his Knowledge of Destruction there arises the consciousness of the future non-arising of the vices or āsravas.
na cet / kṣayajñānamaśaikṣī vā dṛṣṭiḥ	In the contrary case, there is either the Knowledge of Destruction or the “seeing of the Aśaikṣas.
na cedakopyadharmā bhavati kṣayajñānāt kṣavajñānamevotpadyate aśaikṣī vā samyagdṛṣṭiḥ /	If the Arhat is not of this class, then after his Knowledge of Destruction there arises either the same Knowledge of Destruction, or the Right Views of the Aśaikṣas;
na tvanutpādajñānaṃ parihāṇisaṃbhavāt /	but not the Knowledge of Non-Arising.
kiṃ punarakopoyadharmaṇaḥ sā naivotpadyate /	Is this to say that the Immovable Arhat does not possess the Views of the Aśaikṣa?
sarvasya sā 'rhataḥ //	These Views belong to all the Arhats.
akopyadharmaṇo 'pyanutpādajñānātkadācidanutpādajñānamevotpadyate kadācidaśaikṣī samyagdṛṣṭiḥ /	In the Immovable Arhat, sometimes the Knowledge of Non-Arising succeeds Knowledge of Non-Arising, sometimes the Right Views of the Aśaikṣa.
yānyetāni catvāri phalānyuktāni kasyaitāni phalāni /	We have spoken of the four states or results. Of what are they the results?
śramaṇyaphalāni /	They are the results of śrāmaṇya or “the religious life.”
kimidaṃ śrāmaṇyaṃ nāma /	What is śrāmaṇya?
śrāvaṇyamamalo mārgaṃḥ	Śrāmaṇya is the immaculate path.
anāsravo mārgaḥ śramaṇyam /	Śrāmaṇya is the pure path.
tena hhi śramaṇo bhavati / kleśasaṃśamanāt /	By this path, by śrāmaṇya, one becomes a Śramaṇa, that is to say a person who calms or who makes cease the defilements.
“śamitā anena bhavanti anekavidhāḥ ṣāpakā akuśalā dharmā vistareṇa yāvajjarāmaraṇīyāstasmācchramaṇa ityucyata” iti sūtre vacanāt /	Therefore it is said in the Sūtra, “He is called a Śramaṇa because he calms all of the types of dhatrmas of transgression, bad, favorable to transmigration, producing rebirth, old age and death.”
anatyantaśamanānna pṛthagjanaḥ paramārthaśramaṇaḥ / tasya punaḥ śrāmaṇyasya /	The Prthagjana is not a true Śramaṇa because he does not calm the defilements in an absolute manner.
saṃskṛtāsaṃskṛtaṃ phalam /	His result is both conditioned and unconditioned.
saṃskṛtāsaṃskṛtāni hi śrāmaṇyaphalāni punaścatvāryuktāni sūtre / api tu	The results of frāmaṇya are conditioned and unconditioned dharmas. The Sūtra says that these results are four in number.
ekānnanavatistāni	On the other hand, there are eighty-nine.
kāni punastāni	What are these eighty-nine?
muktimārgāḥ saha kṣayaiḥ //	The paths of deliverance with their destructions.
darśanaheyaprahāṇāyāṣṭāvānantryamārgā aṣṭau vimuktimārgā bhāvanāheyaprahāṇāya navasu bhūmiṣu pratyekaṃ nava prakārāṇāṃ kleśānāṃ prahāṇāya tāvanta evānantaryamārgā vimuktimārgāśca /	We have eight Irresistible Paths, followed by eight Paths of Deliverance, for the abandoning of the defilement to be abandoned through seeing. We have eighty-one Irresistible Paths for the abandoning of the defilements abandoned through meditation, namely nine paths through which one abandons the nine categories of defilements of each of the nine spheres, and also as many for the Paths of Deliverance. The eighty-nine Irresistible Paths constitute frāmaṇya.
tatrānantaryamārgāḥ śrāmaṇyaṃ vimuktimārgāḥ saṃskṛtāni śrāmaṇyaphalāni / tanniṣyandapuruṣakāraphalatvāt /	The eighty-nine Paths of Deliverance are the conditioned results of frāmaṇya, being outflowing results and virile results of śrāmaṇya.
teṣāṃ kleśānāṃ prahāṇānyasaṃskṛtāni śrāmaṇyaphalāni /	The abandoning or pratisaṁkhyanirodha of the eighty-nine categories of defilements is the unconditioned result of frāmaṇya.
evamekānnanavatirbhavanti /	We have therefore eighty-nine results of frāmaṇya.
evaṃ tarhi buddhasyopasaṃkhyānaṃ kartavyaṃ jāyate / na kartavyam /	But, if this theory is correct, is there not reason to complete the teaching of the Buddha?
yadyapi bhūyāṃsi phalāni	The results are indeed eighty-nine in number.
catuṣphalavyavasthā tu pañakāraṇasaṃbhavāt /	But four results are established for five reasons which are encountered therein.
yasyāṃ hi prahāṇamārgāvasthāyāṃ pañca kāraṇāni saṃbhavanti tasyāṃ kia bhagavatā phalaṃ vyavasthāpitam /	The Blessed One defined as results the stages of the path of abandoning in which some five causes are encountered. Such is the opinion of the School.
katamāni pañca /	What are these five causes?
pūrvatyāgo 'nyamārgāptiḥ kṣayasaṃkalanaṃ phale // jñānāṣṭakasya lābho 'tha ṣoḍaśākārabhāvanā /	In a result, there is the abandoning of a previous path, the acquisition of another path, the addition of destructions, the acquisition of a group of eight knowledges, and the acquisition of sixteen aspects.
pūrvamārgatyāgo 'pūrvamārgāptiḥ pratipannakaphalamārgatyāgalābhāt /	That is to say: there is the abandoning of the path of the candidate, and the acquisition of the path of the result;
prahāṇasaṃkalanaṃ sarvasyaikaprāptilābhāt /	the acquisition of a single possession of abandoning in its entirety;
yugapadaṣṭajñānalābhaścaturvidhanāṃ dharmānvayajñānānām /	the acquisition at one and the same time of eight Knowledges, the fourfold Dharma Knowledge, and the fourfold.
ṣoḍaśākārabhāvanā anityādyākārāṇām / imāni hi pañca kāraṇāni phale phale bhavanti /	Consecutive Knowledge and the acquisition of the sixteen aspects, impermanence, etc. These characteristics exist in each of the four results.
yadyanāsravo mārgaḥ śrāmaṇyaṃ kathaṃ laukikamārgaprāptaṃ phaladvayaṃ śrāmaṇyaphalaṃ yujyate /	But if only the pure path receives the name of frāmaṃya, how can the two states, those of Śakr̥dāgāmin and Anāgāmin, when they are obtained by a worldly path, be the results of frāmaṇya?
laukikāoptaṃ tu miśratvānāsravāptiḥ dhṛteḥ phalalm //	obtained by a worldly path is a result, because it is combined, and because it is supported by pure possession.
na hi tatra laukikamārgaphalamev prahāṇaṃ sakṛdāgāmiphalaṃ vā bhavatyanāgāmiphalaṃ vā /	The state of Sakr̥dāgāmin and the state of Anāgāmin, even if they were acquired by a worldly path, are not only abandonings resulting from a worldly Path of Meditation: in fact, they also include an abandoning result of the Path of Seeing; this second abandoning is not separable from the first abandoning;
kiṃ tarhi / darśanamārgaphalamapi prahāṇaṃ tatra miśrīkriyate / sarvasya tatphalasaṃgṛhītaikavisaṃyogaprāptilābhāt /	for there is inherent in the results of Sakr̥dāgāmin and Anāgāmin the single possession of abandoning in its entirety, on the one hand, of defilements abandoned by Seeing, and on the other hand, of defilements abandoned by the worldly Path of Meditation.
ata eva hi sūtra uktaṃ “sakṛdāgāmiphalaṃ katamat /	This is why the Sutra says, What is the result of Sakrdāgāmin?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattrayāṇāṃ saṃyojanānāṃ prahāṇaṃ rāgadveṣamohānāṃ ca tatutvamiti /
column2: The abandoning of the three bonds--which are abandoned through Seeing--and the reduction of lust, anger, and delusion.
What is the result of Anāgāmin?
The abandoning of the five bonds here below.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravayā ca visaṃyogāprāptyā tatprahāṇaṃ sadhāryate / tadvalena parihīṇāmaraṇāt / ato 'pyasya maraṇaṃ yuktaṃ śrāmaṇyaphalam /

column2: So too "the teaching of two things" is the teaching of a great number of things which go by twos; in the same way a person "skillful in seven things," is skillful in a great number of seven things.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ebhiśca parivartairdarśanabhāvanāśaikṣamārgā yathāsaṃkhyaṃ darśatā iti vaibhāṣikāḥ /
column2: The three revolutions correspond, in this order, to the Path of Seeing, the Path of Meditation, and the Path of the Arhat or Aśaikṣa. Such is the explanation of the Vaibhāṣīkas (Vibhāṣa, TD 27, p.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyevaṃ na tarhi darśanamārga eva triparivartto dvādaśākāra iti kathamasau dharmacakraṃ vyavasthāpyate /
column2: But if this is the case, then the Path of Seeing would not have three revolutions and twelve aspects. Therefore how would the Wheel of the Dharma be the Path of Seeing? Consequently one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmātsa eva dharmaparyāyo dharmacakraṃ triparirtaṃ dvādaśākāraṃ ca yujyate / kathaṃ ca punastriparivartam /
column2: should understand that the Wheel of the Dharma is this sermon itself, the Sermon of Benares, which sets into motion the Wheel of the Dharma, which includes three revolutions and twelve aspects: three revolutions, because it causes the Truths to be turned some three times;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satyānāṃ triḥ parivarttanāt / kathaṃ dvādaśākāram / caturṇāṃ satyānāṃ tridhākaraṇāt / duḥkhaṃ samudayo nirodho mārga iti /
column2: and twelve aspects, because it considers each Truth under a threefold aspect.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: parijñeyaṃ praheyaṃ sākṣātkartavyaṃ bhāvayitavyamiti / parijñātaṃ prahīṇaṃ sākṣātkṛtaṃ bhāvitamiti /
column2: Through the setting into motion of this sermon, one should understand that it goes, that it is cast into the intelligence of another;
it goes towards the intelligence of another, in that it comes to be known by another.

Or rather, the entirety of the Noble Path, the Path of Seeing, the Path of Meditation, and the Path of the Aśaikṣa, is the Wheel of the Dharma, because it penetrates into the intelligence of those to be disciplined.

If the Sūtra says that the Wheel was set into motion when Kauṇḍinya realized the Path of Seeing, this is because the prefix pr+ indicates the beginning of action: pravartiṭa signifies what begins to be vartia.
When theHow can one obtain the results within each sphere?
Three are acquired in Kāmadhātu.
Three can only be acquired in Kāmadhātu, not elsewhere.
The last, in the three Dhātus.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: antyaṃ śrāmaṇyaphalamarhatvaṃ tasya triṣu dhātuṣu prāptiḥ /
column2: The last state of srāmaṇya, or the quality of Arhat, can be acquired in the Three Dhātus.
We can understand why the first two states, which suppose that the ascetic is not detached from Kāmadhātu, cannot be acquired in the higher spheres;
but why does the same hold for the third?
Higher, the Path of the Seeing of the Truths is absent.
Above Kāmadhātu, the Path of Seeing is absent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca tena vinā 'sti vītarāgasyānāgāmi phalaprāptirityetat kāraṇam /
column2: In its absence, a person detached from Kāmadhātu and reborn in a higher heaven cannot obtain the state of Anāgāmin.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ tatra darśanamārgo nāsti /
column2: Why is the Path of Seeing absent there?
With respect to Ārūpyadhātu, because hearing is absent.
Disgust is absent there, because the Sūtṛa says, "Here one undertakes, and there one achieves.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpāvacarā hi pṛthagjanāḥ samāpattimukhasaṅgā duḥkhavedanābhāvācca na saṃvijante /
column2:
Pṛthagjanas, reborn in Rūpadhātu, are totally given over to the bliss of absorption: all suffering sensation is absent in them;
na ca vinā saṃgenāryamārgaḥ śakto labdhum /	therefore disgust is impossible there, and one cannot enter the Noble Path except through disgust.
iyaṃ tāvadyuktiḥ / āgamo 'pyayaṃ “pañcānāṃ pudgalānāmiha vidhā tatra niṣṭhā antarāparinirvāyiṇo yāvadūrdhvaṃsrotasa” iti /	Furthermore, the Sūtra says, “Five persons, the Antarāparinirvāyin being the first and the Ūrdhvasrotas being the fifth, undertake here and achieve there.
vidhā hi mārgarambho nirvāṇopāyatvāt /	” “Undertake”, vidhā, means to establish the Path, because it is the means to Nirvāṇa.
idamuktaṃ “yadyakopyaḥ kṣayajñānādanutpādamati” riti /	We have seen that: If the Arhat is Immovable, then after his Knowledge of Destruction there arises the Knowledge of Non-Arising”;
tatra kimarhatamapyasti bhedaḥ /	is this to say that there are differences among the Arhats?
astītyucyate / ṣaḍarhanto matāḥ	Śix types of Arhat are known.
sūtra uktaṃ ṣaḍarhantaḥ parihāṇadharmā cetanādharmā anurakṣaṇā dharmā sthitākampoyaḥ prativedhanābhavyo 'kopyadharmā ceti /	The Sūtra says that there are six types of Arhats: Parihāṇadharmans, Cetanādharmans (those who can at will put an end to their existences), Anurakṣaṇādharmans. They will be defined on p. Sthitākampyas, Prativedhanādharmaṇs, and Akopyadharmans.
teṣāṃ pañca śraddhādhhimuktijāḥ /	Five arise from the Śraddhādhimuktas.
akokpyadharmāṇaṃ varjayitvā 'nye pañca śraddhādhimukti pūrvakāḥ /	Five, with the exception of the Immovable Ones have been Śraddhādhimuktas.
vimuktiḥ sāmayikyeṣām /	Their deliverance is occasional.
eṣāṃ ca pañcānāṃ sāmayikī kānta cetovimuktirveditavyā / nityānurakṣyatvāt /	It should be known that the deliverance of mind of these five types of Arhats is occasional and dear, for it should be constantly guarded.
ata evaite samayavimuktā ucyante /	Consequently these Ārhats are called ramayavimukta.
samayāpekṣāścaite 'dhimuktāśceti samayavimuktā madhyapadalopāt dhṛtaghaṭavat /	Depending on the occasion, they are delivered: this compound is made by omitting the middle term. We have thus samayavimukta, delivered by reason of the occasion, like ghṛ̥taghata, a pot full of butter, a pot for butter.
eṣāṃ hi samayāpekṣāsamādhisaṃmukhībhāva upakaraṇārogyadeśaviśeṣāpekṣatvāt / akopyākopyadharmaṇaḥ //	For them, the realization of absorption depends on saaya, on circumstances: possession of a number of material goods, the absence of illness, a ceṟtain place.
akopyadharmaṇastvakopyā vimuktiḥ / kopayitumaśakyatvādaparihāṇitaḥ /	The deliverance of an Immovable One cannot be moved because he cannot fall away from this deliverance;
ato 'samayamukto 'sau	consequently it is immovable.
ata evāsamayavimukti ucyate /	Thus he is not occasionally delivered.
sa hyasamayāpekṣāvimuktiśca / icchātaḥ samādhisaṃmukhībhāvāt /	It follows that an Immovable One is not occasionally delivered.
kālāntarātyantavimuktito vā kopyākopyadharmaṇoḥ samayāsamaye vimuktatvaṃ parihāṇisaṃbhavāsaṃbhavataḥ /	As he realizes absorption of his own accord, he is delivered independently or circumstances. Or rather samaya signifies “time”: the first five Arhats are susceptible of falling away from their deliverance, they are thus delivered for a time, and so are samayavimukta; the sixth Arhat is not susceptible of falling away from his deliverance, he is. thus definitively delivered, and so he is an asamayavimukta.
dṛṣṭipraptānvayaśca saḥ /	He proceeds from Drṣṛiprāpta.
sa cākopyadharmā dṛṣṭiprāptapūrvako veditavyaḥ /	The Immovable One has been a Drṣṭiprāpta.
kiṃ punarete ṣaḍarhanta ādita eva tadgotrā bhavantyatha paścāt /	Do these six Arhats belong, from the beginning of their teligious careers, to the family to which. As Arhats, they belong? Or rather have they acquired this family later?
tadgotrā āditaḥ kecitkeciduttāpanāgatāḥ //	Some Arhats are of their present families from the very beginning; some become part of their present families through purification or perfecting.
kaścitprathamata eva cetanādharmagotrako bhavati /	Certain Arhats are, from the very beginning, Cetanadharmans;
kaścitpunaḥ parihāṇadharmā bhūtvendriyāṇāmuttāpanayā cetanādharmatāṃ gataḥ / evaṃ yāvadakoopyadharmatāṃ gato veditavyaḥ /	other Arhats, after having been Parihāṇadharmans, become Cetanadharmans through the purification of their faculties and so on.
tatra parihāṇadharmā yaḥ parihātuṃ bhavyo na cetanādidharmā / cetanādharmā yaścetayituṃ bhavyaḥ / anurakṣaṇādharmā yo 'nurakṣituṃ bhavyaḥ /	A Parihāṇadharman is an Arhat who is susceptible of falling away and who is not a Cetanādharman nor a Prativedhanādharman.
sthitākampyo yaḥ parihāṇipratyayaṃ balavantamantareṇānurakṣannapi sthātuṃ bhavyo na hātuṃ nāpi vardhayituṃ vinābhiyogena /	A Cetanādharman is an Arhat who is capable of putting an end to his existence at will, without being an Anurakṣaṇādharman, etc. An Anurakṣaṇādharman is an Arhat who is capable of preserving himself from falling away. A Sthitākampya is an Arhat who when strong causes of falling away are absent, even without preserving himself, is not capable of being budged, that is to say, who dwells in his result; but, not falling away, in the absence of any effort, he is not.
prativedhanābhavyo yo 'kopyaḥ prativeddhaṃ bhavyaḥ /	A Prativedhanādharman is an Arhat who is capable of penetrating without effort the Immovable Oṇnes.
akopyadharmā yo naiva parihātuṃ bhavyaḥ /	An Akopyadharman or an Immovable One is an Arhat who is not capable of falling away.
prathamau dvau pūrvameva śaikṣāvasthāyāṃ sātatyasatkṛtyaprayogavikalau /	When they were Śaikṣas, the first two lacked continual cultivation and intensive cultivation;
tṛtīyaḥ sātatyaprayogī /	the third only cultivated continual practices;
caturthaḥ satkṛtyaprayogī /	the fourth cultivated only intensive practices;
pañcama ubhayathāprayogī mṛdvindriyastu /	the fifth cultivated these two practices, but with weak faculties;
ṣaṣṭha ubhayathāprayogī tīkṣṇendriyaśca /	and the sixth cultivated these two practices with sharp faculties.
nacāvaśyaṃ varihāṇadharmā parihīyate nāpi yāvat prativedhanābhavyaḥ pratividhyati / saṃbhavaṃ tu pratyevamucyate /	The Parihāṇadharman does not necessarily fall away; and so on: the Prativedhanādharman does not necessarily penetrate.
evaṃ kṛtvā dhātutraye 'piṣaḍarhanto yujyante / yeṣāṃ tvavaśyaṃ parihīyate yāvat pratividhyati teṣāṃ kāmadhātau ṣaṭ rūpārupyadhātvoḥ sthitākampyo 'kopyadharmā ca / tayoḥparihāṇicetanendriyasaṃcārābhāvāt /	These persons receive their different names because it can happen that they fall away, etc. Having admitted this principle, one then concludes that the six types of Arhats can exist within the Three Dhātus. But, in the hypothesis where the Parihāṇadharman necessarily falls away, where the Prativedhanādharmaṉn necessarily.
kaḥ punareṣāṃ kutaḥ parihīyate / phalāt gotrādvā / gotrāccaturṇāṃ pañcānāṃ phalāddhāniḥ	Among the first five Arhats, how many can fall away from their families, and how many can fall away from their results? Four fall from their families, and five fall from their states.
cetanādharmādīnāṃ caturṇāṃ gotrātparihāṇiḥ /	Four, the Cetanādharman, etc. , can fall away from their families;
na hi parihāṇadharmā punaḥ svagotrāt parihīyate /	the Parihāṇadharman cannot fall away from his family.
parihāṇadharmādīnāṃ pañcānāṃ phalāt parihāṇiḥ / teṣāmapi tu	Five, the Parihāṇadharman, etc. , can also fall away from their.
na pūrvakāt / yasya yat prathamagotraṃ sa tasmānna parihīyate / śaikṣāśaikṣamārgābhyāṃ dṛḍhīkutatvāt /	The Arhat does not fall away from his first family, from the family which he obtained before he became an Arhat, for this family has been made firm by the Path of the Śaikṣa and the Aśaikṣa.
śaikṣastu laukikalokattarābhyāṃ dṛḍhīkṛtatvāt na parihīyate svagotrāt /	The Śaikṣa does not fall away from his first family, for this family has been made firm by the worldly path and the transworldly path.
yattu paścāt pratilabdhamuttāpanayā tasmāt parihīyate / yasya ca yat prathamaṃ phalaṃ sa tasmānā parihīyate /	But one can fall away from the family which one has obtained by the perfecting of his faculties.
śeṣāt parihīyate /	The ascetic does not fall away from the first state which he has obtained, but he can fall away from the others.
ata eva srota āpattiphalānnāsti parihāṇiḥ / evaṃ ca kṛtvā parihāṇadharmaṇastrayaḥ prakārā bhavanti /	Therefore he does not fall away from the state of Srotaāpanṇna.
tadavasthasya parinirvāṇamindriyasaṃcāraḥ / parihāya vā śaikṣatvam /	It results that from these two principles, three cases are possible with respect to the Parihāṇadharman: the Parihāṇadharman either obtains Nirvāṇa by staying in his family, or by pe:fecting his faculties, or by falling away and again becoming a Śaikṣa;
cetanādharmaṇaścatvāraḥ / eta eva trayaḥ parihāṇadharmagotrapratyāgamanaṃ ca / evamanyeṣāṃ trayāṇāmekaikaprakāravṛddhacyā yathākramaṃ pañca ṣaṭ sapta prakārā veditavyāḥ /	four cases are possible with respect to the Cetanādharman: three as above, plus: or by falling away and becoming a.
yasya ca yat prathamaṃ gotraṃ sa parihāya śaikṣobhūtastatraivāvatiṣṭhate nānyasmin /	When an Arhat again becomes a Śaikṣa, he dwells in the same family that was his first family.
anyathā hi tadgotraviśeṣa labhād vṛddhirevāsya syānna parihāṇiḥ /	Otherwise, in the hypothesis that he would obtain a better family, he would progress, and he would not fall away.
kiṃ punaḥ kāraṇaṃ prathamānām nāsti parihāṇiḥ / darśanaheyānāmavastukatvāt / ātmādhiṣṭhānapravṛttā hyete /	Why does one not fall away from the first state?
satkāyadṛṣṭimūlakatvāt /	Because the defilements abandoned through Seeing have no support in fact, having satkāyadr̥ṣṭi for their root, they exist with the ā$rnan for their support;
sa cātmā nāstīti /	now there is no ātman.
asadālambanāstarhi prāpnuvanti / nāsadālambanāḥ /	Do you pretend that these defilements have for their object a thing that does not exist?
satyālambanatvāt / vitathālambanāstu /	They have the Truths for their object, they consist of considering the pādānaskandhas as permanent, etc. Therefore they do not have a thing that does not exist for their object, but they are mistaken with respect to this object.
katamaśca kleśo naivamasti viśeṣaḥ /	How do the defilements which are abandoned through Seeing differ from those which are abandoned through Meditation? TheseDefilements are also mistaken with respect to their objects. They differ from those which are abandoned through Seeing.
ātmadṛṣṭihi rūpādike vastuni kārakavedakavaśavartitvenātmatvamabhūtamadhyāropayati tadadhiṣṭhānānuvṛttāścāntagrāhadṛṣṭacyādaya ityavastukā ucyante	One indeed sees that the idea of self falsely attributes to real things, physical matter, etc. , which are not self" the quality of "self" under the aspect of a being which acts, a being which feels, or of Īśvara. And the other views, the view of clinging to extremes exist having as their support this same "quality of self"; as a consequence their support is non-existent, they have no support.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhāvanāheyāstu rāgapratighamānāvidyā rūpādike vastuni kevalaṃ saktyāghātonnatyasaṃprakhyānabhāvena vartanta iti savastukā ucyante / asti ca tacdhrātādimātraṃ yatra teṣāṃ pravṛttayaḥ na tvātmādileśo 'pi /
column2: But the defilements which are abandoned through Meditation, namely desire, hatred, pride, and ignorance, have for their nature attachment, antipathy, satisfaction, and confusion with respect to physical matter, etc. : they are therefore, speaking absolutely, a support and in this respect differ from the defilements which are abandoned through Seeing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā hi bhāvanāheyānāmasti pratiniyataṃ vastumanāpāmanāpalakṣaṇaṃ na tu darśanaheyānāmātmādilakṣaṇam /
column2: For the agreeable, the painful, etc. , is real with respect to what exists, whereas there is not a trace of self, of things pertaining to self, of Īśvara, etc. Another explanation: The defilements which are abandoned through Meditation have a determined support, characterized as agreeable, painful, etc. But, for the defilements which are abandoned through Seeing, there is no determined support which is characterized as self or as a thing pertaining to self;
consequently they do not have a support.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: api khalvāryasyānupanidhyāyataḥ smṛtisaṃpramoṣāt kleśa utpadyate nopanidhyāyato rajjvāmiva sarpasaṃjñā /
column2: Another point: Among the Āryans who do not reflect, the defilements which are abandoned by Meditation can arise by reason of the weakness of mindfulness; these defilements do not arise among the Āryans who reflect. In the same way that one thinks a rope is a snake if one does not observe it carefully;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cānupanidhyāyata ātmadṛṣṭacyādīnāmupapattiryujyate santīrakatvāditi nāsti darśanaheyakleśa prahāṇātparihāṇiḥ /
column2: so too when one’s attention is lacking, one forgets its metaphysical characteristics, the impermanence of the pleasant, etc. but the error of personalism cannot arise among Āryans who do not reflect, because this error is a product of reflection. Consequently, the saint cannot fall away from the abandoning of the defilements which have been abandoned through Seeing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: arhatvādapi nāsti parihāṇiriti sautrāntikāḥ / eṣa eva canyāyaḥ / kathamidaṃ gamyate /
column2: The Sautrāntikas say that one can no longer fall away from the quality of Arhat. And their opinion is correct, as one can demonstrate by scripture and by reasoning.
Scripturaḻ arguments.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathamāgamāt / “taddhi bhikṣavaḥ prahīṇaṃ yadāryayā prajñayā prahīṇami“tyuktam / ādyantayośca phalayorāryayaiva prajñayā 'dhigamaḥ /
column2: It is said, “What, Oh Bhikṣus, is abandoned is abandoned by āryā prajñā.
” It is said, “I declare that the Śaikṣa should cultivate vigilance. ” The Blessed One did not proscribe vigilance to the Arhat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “arhato 'pyahamānanda lābhasatkāramantrāyakaraṃ vadāmī“tyatra sūtre dṛṣṭadhamesukhavihāramātrādeva parihāṇiruktā / “yā tvanenākopyacetovimuktiḥ kāyena sākṣātkṛtā /
column2: Without doubt, the Blessed One said, “Ānanda, I declare that, even for the Arhat, property and honors are a cause of obstacle.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato 'haṃ na kenacit paryāyeṇa parihāṇaṃ vadāmī“ti coktam /
column2: ” Yet the Sūtra specifies that, if the Arhat can fall away, it is only from the “blisses”: “With respect to immovable deliverance of mind, which is actualized physically, I declare that one absolutely cannot fall away from it. ' But the Vaibhāṣikas answer: The Blessed One specifies that one cannot fall away from deliverance of the mind when it is immovable; therefore one can fall away from it when it is occasional.
We are indeed in agreement: One can fall away from the.
But what is this deliverance?
Is it, as you think, the quality of Arhat? Should one not believe rather that the Blessed One designates the worldly Dhyānas by “occasional deliverance”?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: maulo hi dhyānasamādhiḥ samaye saṃmukhībhāvātsāmayikī cimuktirityucyate /
column2: Since the absorption which consists of the fundamental Dhyānas is realized under certain circumstances--for example in a place free from noise, etc. --it is termed "occasional deliverance";

it is also called "cherished deliverance," because, each time that it is lost, one desires it anew with a view to enjoying the "blisses. " According to another master, this absorption is called "cherished deliverance" because, being impure, it is "delectable.
But the deliverance which constitutes the quality of Arhat is not occasional" since it is possessed in a permanent manner;
it is no longer "cherished," because one does not have to search it out anew.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cārhattvāt parihaṇisaṃbhavo 'bhaviṣyat kimarthaṃ bhagavānādhicetasikebhya eva dṛṣṭadharmasukhavihārebhyaḥ parihāṇimavakṣyat /
column2: If it were possible for one to fall away from the quality of Arhat, why did the Blessed One say that the Arhat could only fall?
Consequently immovable deliverance of the mind belongs to all the Arhats.
As for the “blisses,” a certain Arhat can fall away from them, when, being distracted by property and honors, he loses his mastery in absorption: this is an Arhat whose faculties are weak.
A certain Arhat does not fall away from them: this is an Arhat whose faculties are sharp.
The Arhat who falls away from the “blisses” is a Parihāṇadharmaṇ;
one who does not fall away is an Aparihāṇadharman.
One should explain the Cetanādharmaṇ, etc. , in the same way.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aparihāṇadharmasthitākampyākopyadharmaṇāṃ ko viśeṣaḥ / aparihāṇadharmā 'nuttāpanāgataḥ / akopyadharmā tūttāpanāgataḥ /
column2: What difference is there between an Aparihāṇadharman, a Sthitākampya and an Akopyadharmaṇ? The first has not perfected his faculties: they have been sharp from the very beginning;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tau hi yaṃ yameva samāpattiviśeṣamutpādayatastasmānna parihīyete /
column2: the third has perfected his faculties: neither of them fall away from the absorptions that they are able to produce.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sthitākampyastu yasminneva guṇe sthitastasmātkevalaṃ na parihīyate na tvanyamutpādayati / utpādayati vā tasmāttu kampata ityeva viśeṣo lakṣyate /
column2: The second does not fall away from the qualities in which he is found: rather, he does not produce any other qualities. Such is the difference between these three saints. But did not the Venerable Godhika fall away from the quality of Arhat?

The Venerable Godhika, being a Śaikṣa, by reason of the excess of his enjoyment and the weak character of his faculties, fell away many times from “occasional deliverance”: in his disgust, he struck himself with a dagger.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: parihīyamāṇo nirviṇnaḥ śastramādhārayan kāyajīvitanirapekṣatvānmaraṇakāla evārhattvaprāptaḥ parinirvṛttaśca /
column2: By reason of his indifference with respect to his body and life, he obtained the quality of Arhat at the very moment of his death, and Nirvāṇa.
Therefore he did not fall away from the quality of Arhat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśottare coktam / “eko dharma utpādayitavyaḥ sāmayikī kāntā cetovimuktiḥ /
column2: The Daśottara teaches, “There is a āharma which one should produce, namely occasional, cherished deliverance.
There is a dḍharma that one should actualize, namely the immovable deliverance of the mind.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cārhattvaṃ sāmayikī kāntā cetovimuktirabhaviṣyat kimarthaṃ tatraiva daśake 'rhattvasya dvigrahaṇamakariṣyāt /
column2: If occasional and cherished deliverance were the quality of an Arhat, and so if the quality of Arhat were of two types, why does the Daśottara, alone among the Sūtras, speak twice, under twoMoreover, no part of the Scripture employs the expression 'to produce the quality of Arhat';
it always says that one should actualize this quality.
Would you say that the quality of Arhat, to the extent that it is associated with weak faculties, is to be produced?
What do you mean by that?
That it can be 'produced'? But then the quality of Arhat associated with sharp faculties, itself, can be produced. That it merits being produced?
All the more reason the second quality of Arhat merits being produced.
Therefore occasional deliverance is not a quality of Arhat.
But, if this is the case, why does the Scripture speak of the 'occasionally delivered' Arhat?
Such is an Arhat who, because of the weakness of his faculties depends on certain circumstances in order to actualize the absorption.
An Arhat who is opposed to this is one who is 'not occasionally delivered'.
According to the Abhidharma, it is by reason of three causes that sensual desire arises: 1. the latent defilement.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmarāgānuśayio 'prahīṇo bhavatyaparijñātaḥ kāmarāgaparyavasthānīyāśca dharmā ābhāsagatā bhavanti tatra cāyoniśo manaskāra” iti / paripūrṇotpattirevamiti cet /
column2: of sensual desire has not been completely known, has not been abandoned. some dharmas present themselves as favorable to the increase of sensual desire. and there is erroneous judgment. Would one say that the Abhidharma speaks of sensual desire which is produced by the totality of its causes, but that sensual desire can arise having incomplete causes, by the sole force of the external object, the vṣaya?
But what dharma can arise without its causes being complete?

Let us pass on to arguments from reason. In the Arhat there are arisen dharmas which are opposed to the defilements and which are of such a nature that the defilements are reduced to the condition of absolutely not being able to arise, anṉutpattidharman.
How then could the Arhat fall away?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tāvadarhatastadrūpaḥ pratipakṣa utpanno yena kleśā atyantamanutpattidharmatāmāpannāḥ kathaṃ punaḥ parihīyate / atha notpannaḥ /
column2: Would you say that such dharmas are not arisen in the Arhat, that the defilements exist within him in the state of a seed, that which constitutes the seed of the defilements not having beenIn this hypothesis, how can one say of the Arhat that he is kṣīṇāsrava, a person whose vices are cut off?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ kṣīṇāsravo bhavati / atyantamanayoddhratāyāṃ tadbījadharmatāyāmakṣīṇāsravo vā punaḥ kathamarhanbhavatītyevaṃ yuktiḥ /
column2: And if he is not a kṣṝṇāsrava, how can one say that he is an Arhat?
But, the theory of the non-falling away of the Aṟhat is contradicted by the dṅgārakarṣūpama.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatredamuktaṃ “tasya khalu śrutavata āryaśrāvakasyaivaṃ carata evaṃ viharataḥ kadācitkarhicit smṛtisaṃpramoṣādutpadyante pāpakā akuśalā vitarkā” iti / sa hi tatrārhanneva jñāpitaḥ /
column2: This Sūtra says, 'A wise Āryan Śrāvaka who follows this rule of life, who passes his time in this way (evaṁ carata evaṁ viharatas),--it happens sometimes, through weakness of mindfulness, that he produced bad thoughts.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “dīrgharātra vivekanimnaṃ cittaṃ bhavati yāvannirvāṇaprāgbhārami“ti vacanāt / arhato hyetadbalamanyatroktam /
column2: Now this Āryan Śrāvaka is not a Śaikṣa, but an Arhat, for the Sūtra says later, “For a long period of time his mind is inclined towards distant separation from the defilements. His mind is turned towards Nirvāṇa.”

And we know further that these qualities, “having the mind inclined towards separation,” etc. , are some of the powers of the Arhat, which power is yet determined by the words, ‘his mind is cold, purged with respect to all the dharmas in which the vices have their abode.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yāvattu cāro na supratibaddhastāvadevaṃ carato 'pi śaikṣasyāsti saṃbhavaḥ kleśotpattāviti śaikṣāvasthāmadhikṛtyaivaṃ vacanādadoṣaḥ / pratijñāyate hi laukikamārgapratilabdhātphaladvayātparihāṇiḥ /
column2: ”But the Aṅgārakarṣūpama refers to a Śaikṣa and not to an Aṟrhat. In fact it is only of a Śaikṣa that one can say that “as long as the actions of a Bhikṣu are not 'well understood,’ even when he thus cultivates these actions, the defilements will sometimes arise within him.”
The Vaibhāsṣīkas maintain that one can also fall away from the quality of Arhat.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punarime 'rhanta eva ṣaḍgotrā bhavanti athānye 'pi ṣaḍgotrā bhavanti /
column2: Are the Arhats the only ones who are divided into six families? Is this also the case for others?
The Śaikṣas and the non-Āryans are also of six families.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śaikṣapṛthagjanā apyevaṃ ṣaḍgotrāḥ / tatpūrvakāṇyeva hyarhatāṃ gotrāṇi / api tu
column2: Śaikṣas and Pr̥thagjanas are also of six families: the families of the Arhats have their antecedents in these families.
In the Path of Seeing, there is no perfecting.

One can perfect his faculties outside of the Path of Seeing the Truths, but not while one traverses this Path, for, in view of its rapidity, one cannot accomplish the preparatory practices required for perfecting.
Some perfect their faculties as Pṛthagjanas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaścicchaddhādhimuktāvasthāyām / yadidaṃ sūtra uktaṃ “ye tvanena catvāra ādhicaitasikā dṛṣṭadharmasukhavihārā adhigatāstato
column2: some, asThe Sūtra quoted above says, “I declare that one can fall away from any one of the four blisses of absorption which one has acquired;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: 'hamasyānyatamānyatamasmāt parihāṇiṃ vadāmi yā tvanenaikākinā yāvadakopyā cetovimuktiḥ kāyena sākṣātkṛtā tato 'haṃ na kenacit paryāyeṇa parihāṇiṃ vadāmī“ti /
column2: but, with respect to the immovable deliverance of mind which is physically actualized, I declare that one absolutely cannot fall away from it.”
How can it be that an Immovable Arhat can fall away from the blisses?
There are three types of falling away: from that which is acquired, from that which has not yet been acquired, and from fruition.
Whoever falls away from the possession of a spiritual quality, falls away from what has been acquired.
Whoever does not acquire a spiritual quality that is to be acquired, falls away from that which has not yet been acquired.
Whoever does not actualize a spiritual quality that he possesses, falls away from his fruition.
Among these falling aways, the last, with respect to the Master; the second also, with respect to an Immovable One;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: antyā śāsturakopyasya madhyā cānyasya tu tridhā //
column2: all three, with respect to others.
The Buddha falls away only from fruition: occupied with the good of his followers, he ceases his enjoyment of the blisses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akopyadharmaṇaḥ sā cāprāptaparihāṇiśca / pudgalaviśeṣadharmāprāpaṇāt / anyasyārhataḥ prāptaparihāṇirapyasti /
column2: The Immovable One falls away from both his fruition and from what has not yet been acquired: for he has not necessarily acquired the dbarmas ptoper to very distinguished persons. The Arhats who are not immovable also fall away from what they have acquired.
Consequently the fact that an Immovable One falls away from his fruition is not in contradiction with the above Sūtra.
The masters who deny any falling away say, “The pure deliverance of any Arhat is immovable;
but an Immovable One is to be defined as we have said;
consequently one cannot object: how does an Immovable One fall away from the blisses?
Does the saint who falls away from the state of Arhat take up a new existence?
He does not die having fallen away from his result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva hi kaścitphalāt parihīṇaḥ kālaṃ karoti /
column2: He never dies in the state of having fallen away from his result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “dhandhā bhikṣava āryaśrāvakasya smṛtisaṃpramoṣā atha ca punaḥ kṣipramevāntaṃ parikṣayaṃ sapadi saṃgacchanīti sūtre vacanāt /
column2: In fact the Sūtra says, “Oh Bhikṣus, it happens that the wise Āryan >Śrāvaka experiences weakness of mindfulness, that his mindfulness becomes slow. But he quickly rejects, he makes disappear, destroys, annihilates.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hyanāśvāsikaṃ brahmacaryaṃ syāt / yataśca phalāt parihīyate tatphalasthena yadakāryaṃ
column2: If it were otherwise, if a person, having become an Aṟhat, falls away from the state of Arhat, and could continue to transmigrate, the religious life would not inspire confidence.
A person fallen away from a state does not do that which a person who resides in this state cannot do: He does not do what should not be done.
Even though fallen, he does not do that which is in contradiction with his state.
In the same way a hero can be moved, but he does not fall.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athendriyāṇi saṃcaratāṃ katyānantaryavimuktimārgā bhavanti / vimuktyānantaryapathā navokopye
column2: How many Irresistible Paths and Paths of Deliverance are included in the transformation or perfecting of the faculties?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: akopyagotre pratividhyamāne pritivedhabhāvanābhavyasya navānantaryamārgā vimuktimārgāśca bhavanti /
column2: For the Immovable One, there are nine paths of two types. The Prativedhanādharman who perfects his faculties and penetrates the family of the Inmmovable Ones, should produce nine Irresistible Paths, nine Paths of Deliverance, exactly like the.
Śaikṣa, in order to obtain the quality of Arhat.
Why is this?
By reason of his intense cultivation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasya mṛdvindriyagotraṃ bhavatīti nālpena vyāvarttayituṃ śakyate /
column2: The Prativedhanādharman has intensely cultivated the family of weak faculties; consequently this family cannot be transformed without a great effort;
it has, in fact, been made firm both by the Path of the Śaikṣa and by the Path of the Aśaikṣa. For the Dr̥ṣṭiprāpta, one of each type.
For the transformation of the faculties by which a Śraddhādhimukta becomes a Drṛṣṭiprāpta, there must be an Irresistible Path and a Path of Deliverance.
In the two cases, there is a preparatory path.
These Irresistible Paths and Paths of Deliverance are Pure paths.
For the faculties of Āryans cannot be transformed by impure paths.
Where can the faculties be transformed?
There is transformation among humans.
Only humans can transform their faculties;
there is no transformation elsewhere, for elsewhere falling away is impossible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaḥ punaḥ katamāṃ bhūmi niśrityendriyāṇi saṃcarati /
column2: In what sphere do the Aśaikṣas and the Śaikṣas exist in order to transform their faculties?
The Aśaikṣas in nine spheres.
Namely in anāgamya, dhyānāntara, the Four Dhyānas and three Ārūpyas, for the same state of Arhat can be obtained in these spheres.
The Śaikṣa, in six.
With the exception of the three Ārūpyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ kāraṇam / yataḥ // saviśeṣaṃ phalaṃ tyaktvā phalamāpnoti vardhayan /
column2: Why is this?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: indriyāṇi hi saṃcaran phalaṃ phalaviśiṣṭaṃ ca mṛdvindriyamārgaṃ tyaktvā tīkṣṇendriyagotrakaṃ phalamārgameva pratilabhate /
column2: Because the Śaikṣa who increases his faculties by abandoning his state and his ptogress, obtains the state. When the Śaikṣa perfects his faculties, he loses a state, a state that he had acquired by the path of weak faculties; he loses his vifeṣa, that is, the progress that he had made--preparatory paths, Irresistible Path, Path of Deliverance, and Path of Excellence,--in the detachment of the Dhyāṇnas, a progress realized with his weak faculties.
He obtains only a state belonging to the family of sharp faculties, a state forming part of the detachment of Kāmadhātu, not the state of Anāgāmin which is of Ārūpyadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta ete ṣaḍevārhanto nava bhavanti / indriyabhedāt / kathaṃ kṛtvā /
column2: The Arhats, by reason of their difference of faculties, are nine.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvau buddhau śrāvakāḥ sapta navaite navadhendriyāḥ // katame sapta śrāvakāḥ / parihāṇadharmādayaḥ pañca / akopyadharmā ca dvividha uttāpanāgata āditaśca tadgotraḥ akopyabheda eva /
column2: The Śrāvakas are seven in number, the five the first of which is the Parihāṇadharman, plus the Immovable One which is divided into two, depending on whether he was from his beginnings of the immovable family, or whether he has obtained this family through the perfecting of his faculties.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvau buddhau pratyekabuddho buddhaśca / ityate mṛdumṛdvādinavaprakārendriyabhedānnava pudgalā bhavanti /
column2: The two Buddhas, the Pratyekabuddha and the Buddha, are varieties of Immovable Ones.
These make nine persons whose faculties are respectively weak-weak, etc. In general, the Āryaṇs are seven in number: 1. the Śraddhāṇusarin, 2. the Dharmānusarin, 3.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śraddhānusārī dharmānusārī śraddhādhimukto dṛṣṭioprāptaḥ kāyasākṣī prajñāvimukta ubhayatovimuktaśca /
column2: the Śraddhādhiṃmukta, 4. the Drṛṣṭiprāpta, 5. the Kāyasākṣin, 6.
the Pṛajñāvimukta, and 7. the Ubhayatobhāgavimukta.
Seven pudgalas, by reason of their cultivation, their faculties, absorption, deliverance, of two.
By reason of their cultivation, there exists the Śraddhānusarin and the Dharmānusarin. In the beginning, in the state of Pṛthagjana, it is by reason of faith.

that the first, under the impulse of another applied himself to things, that is, he devoted himself to reflection and meditation. The second applied himself in the same way, but by following the dharmas, that is, the twelvefold Scriptures, and by pursuing the dharmas, that is, the parts of Bodhi by himself.
By reason of their faculties, there exists the Śraddhādhimukta and the Drṣtiprāpta.
Their faculties are respectively weak and sharp by reason of the predominance, among the first, of intention proceeding from faith, and, among the second, of wisdom.
By reason of absorption, there exists the Kāyasākṣin, because he has realized the Absorption of Extinction.
By reason of deliverance, there exists the Prajñāvimukta.
By reason of absorption and deliverance, there exists the Ubhayatobhāgavimukta.
Thus, from the point of view of their enumeration, there are seven.
They are six.
These seven, from the point of view of substantial entities, are.
Two exist in each of the three paths.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanamārge hi dvau pudgalau śraddhādharmānusāriṇau / tāveva bhāvanāmārge dvau bhavataḥ /
column2: In the Path of Seeing, there exists two padgalas or persons, the Śraddhānusarin and the Dharmānusariṇ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śraddhādhimuktadṛṣṭiprāptau / tau punaraśaikṣamārge dvau bhavataḥ / samayāsamayavimuktāviti /
column2: who, in the Path of Meditation, become a Śraddhādhimukta and a Drṛṣṭiprāpta, and, in the Path of the Arhat, a Samayavimukta and an Asamayavimukta.
The Śraddhāṇusariṇ, from the point of view of his faculties, is of three types: his faculties are weak by definition; but they can be either weak-weak, weak-medium, or weak-strong;
from the point of view of his family, of five types: of the family of the Parihāṇadharman, etc. ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mārgataḥ pañcadaśa / aṣṭa kṣāntisaptajñānasthāḥ / vairāgyatastrisaptatiḥ / sakalabandhanaḥ /
column2: from the point of view of the Path, of fifteen types: accordingly as he is in one of the eight Patiences or in one of the seven Knowledges;
from the point of view of detachment, of seventy-three types: bound by all of the bonds of Kāmadhātu, detached from one from nine categories of bonds of Kāmadhātu;

detached from one from nine categories of bonds of the First Dhyāṇa, and so on up to and including Ākiñcanyāyatana. Eight times nine--detachment from Kāmadhātu, from the Four Dhyāṇnas, and fromFrom the point of view of the physical person, of nine types: born in one of the three Dvīpas.
Born in one of the six heavens of Kāmadhātu. Higher, the Path of Seeing is absent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: indriyagotramārgavairāgyāśrayataḥ paṇḍitāḥ śatasahasraṃ saṃpadyante sahasrāṇi ca saptacatvāriṃśacchatāni cāṣṭau pañcaviśatiśca /
column2: By taking into account all of these differences, there are some 147,825 types of Śraddhānusarin.
The calculation relative to other saints is established according to the same elements, with the differences of title.
Who is the saint that is called an Ubhayatobhāgavimukta? Who is the saint that is called a yga Prajñāvimukta?
He who possesses extinction is doubly delivered; the other is delivered through prajñā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo nirodhasamāpattilābhī sa ubhayatobhāgavimuktaḥ / prajñāsamādhibalābhyāṃ kleśavimokṣāvaraṇavimuktatvāt /
column2: One who has entered the Absorption of Extinction, that is to say, one who is endowed with extinction, is called “doubly deliveredʼ', because, by the power of prajñā and absorption, he is delivered from the hindrance of the defilements and from the hindrance that opposes the arising of the eight liberations.
The other is "one who is delivered through prajñā," because, by the power of prajña, he is delivered from the hindrance of the defilements.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaduktaṃ bhagavatā “kleśān prahāyeha hi yastu pañca ahāryadharmā paripūrṇaḥ śaikṣa” iti /
column2: The Blessed One said, "One who has abandoned the five defilements here below and who is not subject to falling away is a complete Śaikṣa.

How is a Śaikṣa completed?
samāpattindriyaphalaiḥ pūrṇaḥ śaikṣo 'bhidhīyate //	It is from the point of view of absorption, of faculties, and of result that a Śaikṣa is said to be complete.
trividhā śaikṣasya parīpūriḥ / phalataḥ indriyataḥ samāpattitaśca /	The complete Śaikṣa is of three types, complete by his result, his faculties, and his absorption.
phalata eva śraddhādhimuktasyākāyasākṣiṇo 'nāgāminaḥ /	The Anāgāmin of the Śraddhādhimukta class who is not a Kāyasākṣin is complete from the point of view of only his result.
indriyata eva dṛṣṭiprāptasyāvītarāgasya /	The saint of the Drṛṣṭiprāpta class who is not detached from Kāmadhātu is complete from the point of view of only his faculties.
phalendriyato dṛṣṭiprāptasya kāyasākṣiṇo 'nāgāminaḥ /	The Anāgāmin of the Drṣṭiprāpta class who is not a Kāyasākṣin is complete from the point of view of his result and his faculties.
phalasamāpattitaḥ śraddhādhimuktasya kāyasākṣiṇaḥ /	The Anāgāmin of the Śraddhādhimukta class who is a Kāyasākṣin is complete from the point of view of his result and his.
phalendriyasamāpattito dṛṣṭiprāptasya kāyasākṣiṇaḥ /	The Anāgāmin of the Drṛṣṭiprāpta class who is a Kāyasākṣin is complete from the point of view of his result, his faculties, and his absorption.
