mārgasatyamabhisamayan buddhe tasya ca śrāvakasaṃghe 'vetyaprasādaṃ pratilabhete /	At the comprehension of the Truth of the Path, dear to the Āryams, there is an acquisition of the avetyaprasāda 1elating to the Buddha and to his Śrāvaka-Saṅgha. The word “also” is there in order to mark that there is also an acquisition of the avetyaprasāda relating to the Dharma and the precepts.
yo hi tayoḥ prasādaḥ so 'śaikṣyeṣu buddhakarakeṣu dharmeṣu śaikṣāyāśaikṣeṣu ca saṃghakarakeṣu prasādaḥ / api śabdācchīladharmāvetyaprasādau ca pratilabhate /	“The prasāda relating to the Buddha is a prasāda 1elating to theAśaikṣa dharmas which make up a Buddha; so too one should understand by Śaṅgha the Śaikṣa and Aśaikṣa dharmas which make up the Saṅgha.
ko 'yamiha dharmo 'bhipretaḥ /	ĪE What is understood by Dharma in the expression “zvetyaprasāda relating to the Dharma”?
dharmaḥ satyatrayaṃ bodhisattvapratyekabuddhayoḥ // mārgaśca	The Dharma is the three Truths and the Path of the Pratyekabuddha and the Bodhisattva.
ataścatvaryapi satyānyabhisamayato dharmāvetyaprasādalābhaḥ /	Consequently, when one understands the Four Noble Truths, one obtains the aveyaprasāda relating to the Dhaṛma.
ta ete śraddhādhiṣṭhānabhedānnāmataścatvāro 'vetyaprasādā ucyante /	Therefore we have seen from the differences of the object of prasāda, four prasādas distinguished from the point of view of their nares.
dravyatastu dve śraddhā śīlaṃ ca	From the point of view of substantial entities, these four are two things, faith and morality.
buddhadharmasaṃghāvetyaprasādāḥ śraddhāsvabhāvāḥ āryakāntāni ca śīlāni śīlamiti dve dravye bhavataḥ /	The avetyaprasāda relating to the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha, are, by their nature, faith. The precepts dear to the Āryans, are, by their nature, morality. Therefore they are two things. Are these two things pure or impure?
kiṃ punarete sāsravānāsravā ekāntenāvetyaprasādāḥ / nirmalā /	The avetyaprasādas are exclusively Immaculate.
avetyaprasādā iti ko 'rthaḥ /	What is the meaning of the term avetyaprasāda?
yathābhūtasatyānyavabudhya saṃpratyayo 'vetyaprasādaḥ /	A faith consecutive to the exact comprehension of the Truths.
yathā ca vyutthitaḥ saṃmukhīkaroti tathaiṣāmānupūrvīm /	The avetyaprasādas are arranged in the order in which, upon leaving the contemplation of the Truths, they are actualized.
kathaṃ vyutthitaḥ saṃmukhī karoti /	How does one actualize them upon leaving this contemplation?
samyaksaṃbuddho vata bhagavān svākhyāto 'sya dharmavinayaḥ supratipanno 'sya śrāvakasaṃgha iti vaidyabhaiṣajyopasthāpakabhūtatvāt /	the Blessed One is a perfect Buddha! Well preached is his Dharma-Vinaya! Well cultivating is his Śrāvaka-Saṅgha! it is thus that one actualizes them, for the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha are, in this order, the doctor, the remedy, and the patient.
cittaprasādakṛtaśca śīlaprasāda ityucyate caturtha uktaḥ / evaṃ prasannasyaiṣā pratipattiriti /	As the prasāda of morality results from the prasāda of the mind, it is placed fourth, at the end: it is when the mind is thus believing that one acquires the precepts dear to the Āryans. Or rather, the prasāda of the precepts is placed at the end, because the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saṅgha are the doctor, the remedy, and the patient, and the prasāda of the precepts corresponds to health. Or rather because the Buddha is the guide, the Dharma is the path, the Saṅgha is one’s travelling. Companions, and the precepts dear to the Āryans are the vehicle.
ārogyabhūtatvādvā deśika mārga sārthikayānavadvā / sūtra ukta“maṣṭābhiraṅgai samanvāgataḥ śaikṣo darśabhiraṅgaiḥ samanvāgato 'śaikṣa” iti /	According to the Sūtra, a Śaikṣa has eight parts, namely the eight parts of the Noble Eightfold Path termed “pertaining to the Śaikṣa”': Farī samyagdrṣṭi. Faikṣa samyaksamādhi; an Aśaikṣa has ten parts, namely the same eight parts of the Noble Eightfold Path termed “'pertaining to the Aśaikṣa”. Plus aśaikṣī samyagviṃukti and afaikṣa samyagjñāna, the perfect deliverance proper to Aṛhats and the knowledge of the acquisition of this deliverance.
kasmācchaikṣasya samyak vimuktiḥ samyagjñānaṃ ca noktam /	Why does not the Sūtra attribute both perfect deliverance and the knowledge of this perfect deliverance to the Śaikṣa?
noktā vimuktiḥ śaikṣāṅga baddhatvāt /	Because he is bound, deliverance is not said to be a part of a Śaikṣa.
baddho hi śaikṣaḥ kleśabandhanairadyāpīti /	A Śaikṣa is bound by the bonds of the defilements.
kathaṃ baddhasyaiva sato vimuktirvyavasthāpyeta / na hi bandhanaikadeśānmukto mukta ityucyate /	How could one consider him delivered? The person who is partially bound is not called released.
binā ca vimuktacyā kathaṃ vimuktijñānam vyavasthāpyate /	Deliverance is absent from him, and he cannot possess the knowledge of the acquisition of deliverance.
aśaikṣastu sarvakleśabandhanātyantanirmokṣādvimuktitatpratyātmajñānābhyāṃ prabhāvita iti tasyaiva tadvacanaṃ nyāyyam /	An Aśaikṣa is completely liberated from all the bonds: he is thus characterized, magnified both by his deliverance from the defilements and by the direct knowledge of his deliverance: therefore it is of the Aśaikṣa alone that one can say that perfect deliverance and the knowledge of this perfect deliverance are his parts.
keyaṃ vimuktirnāma /	What is deliverance?
sā punardvidhā //	Deliverance is twofold.
saṃskṛtā cāsaṃskṛtā ca / tatra /	It is conditioned and unconditioned.
asaṃskṛtā kleśahānamadhimuktastu saṃskṛtā /	Victory over the defilements is unconditioned deliverance; adhimokṣa is conditioned deliverance.
kleśaprahāṇamasaṃskṛtā vimuktiḥ /	The abandoning of the defilements is unconditioned deliverance.
aśaikṣādhimokṣaḥ saṃskṛtā vimuktiḥ /	The intention of the Aśaikṣa is conditioned deliverance.
sāṅgaḥ	This last is a part.
saivāsaṃskṛtā vimuktiraśaikṣāṅgayuktā /	It is conditioned deliverance which is called a “part pertaining to an Aśaikṣa”;
aṅgānāṃ saṃskṛtatvāt /	for the other parts, Right Views, etc. , are conditioned.
saiva vimuktī dve	It is two deliverances.
saiva saṃskṛtā vimuktirdve vimuktī sūtra ukte / ceto vimuktiḥ prajñāvimuktiśca /	This same conditioned deliverance is described, in the Sūtra.
vimuktiskndho 'pi sa eva draṣṭṭavyaḥ /	But, according to another opinion, if the skandha of deliverance is only intention, how do we explain the Sūtra?
yattarhi sūtra uktaṃ “katamacca vyāgrābodhyāyanā vimuktipariśuddhipradhānam /	The Śūtra says, “Oh Vyāghrabodhāyanas! What is the essential factor of the purification of deliveraṅce?
iha bhikṣavo rāgāccittaṃ viraktaṃ bhavati vimuktaṃ dveṣānmohāccittaṃ viraktaṃ bhavati	The mind of a Bhikṣu is detached, delivered from craving; the mind of this Bhikṣu is detached, delivered from hatred and ignorance.
vimuktamityaparipūrṇasya vā vimuktiskandhasya paripūraye paripūrṇasya cānugrahāya	In this way, either with a view to the fullness of the séandha of deliverance which is not complete, or with a view to maintaining the shandha of deliverance which is complete, all desire, all energy . this is the essential factor.
cchandovīryami“ti vistaraḥ / tasmānādhimokṣa eva vimuktiḥ / kiṃ tarhi / tattvajñānāpanīteṣu rāgādiṣu cetaso vaimalyaṃ vimuktirityapare / uktā vimuktiḥ /	” It results from this Sūtra that intention does not constitute deliverance: this is the purity of the mind resulting from thePerfect deliverance has been explained.
samyagjñānaṃ tu samyagdṛṣṭiḥ / vyatiriktaṃ katamat /	What is the perfect or Right Knowledge which is distinct from Right Views?
jñānaṃ bodhiryathoditā // yaiva hi pūrvaṃ bodhiruktā saiveha samyagjñānaṃ veditavyam /	Bodhi, as described above, is knowledge.
yaduta kṣayajñānamanutpādajñānaṃ ca /	Bodhi, as we have described above, is the Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising, and these constitute Right Knowledge, the tenth part of the Aśaikṣa.
katamat punaścittaṃ vimucyate kimatītamanāgataṃ pratyutpannam /	Which mind is delivered?
vimucyate jāyamānasaśaikṣaṃ cittamāvṛteḥ /	The Aśaikṣa mind, arising, is delivered from its obstacles.
“anāgataṃ cittamutpadyamānaṃ visucyate aśaikṣamāvaraṇebhya” iti śāstrapāṭhaḥ /	The Śāstra says, The future Aśaikṣa mind is delivered from its obstacle.
What is this obstacle?
The possession of the defilements, which in fact creates an obstacle to the arising of an Aśaikṣa mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vajropame hi samādho sa ca prahīyate / taccotpadyamānamaśaikṣaṃ cittaṃ vimucyate /
column2: At the moment of Vajropamasamādhi, this possession is abandoned, and an Aśaikṣa mind arises and is delivered.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sā ca prahīṇā bhavati / tacāśaikṣaṃ cittamutpannaṃ vimuktaṃ ca / yattarhi notpadyamānaṃ laukikaṃ ca /
column2: When this possession has been abandoned, the Aśaikṣa mind has arisen and has been delivered. But what would you say of the Ashaiksa mind which has not arisen at the moment of Vajropamasamadhi, or of the worldly mind which is produced within an Ashaiksa?
These two minds are also delivered;
but it is of the future Ashaiksa mind in the process of arising that the Shastra says is delivered.
From what is the worldly mind of an Ashaiksa delivered?
From the same possession of the defilements, an obstacle to its arising. But is not this same worldly mind produced within a Shaiksa, and have you not said that it is delivered?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu cāmuktasyāpi śaikṣasya laukikamutpadyate na tattādṛśam /
column2: The worldly mind of a Shaiksa is not similar to that of an Ashaiksa, for the latter is not accompanied by the possession of the defilements.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kīdṛśaṃ tat / kleśaprāptisahitam / kimavastho mārgastadutpattyāvaraṇaṃ prajahāti /
column2: What is the Path--past, present, or future--by which the obstacle to the arising of the Ashaiksa mind is abandoned?
It is while perishing that the Path causes the abandoning of the obstacle.
Perishing, that is to say, in the present.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yā cāsaṃskṛtā vimuktiruktā ye ca trayodhātava ucyante prahāṇadhāturviṃrāgadhātunirodhadhāturiti /
column2: The Shastra and the present work defined unconditioned deliverance. On the other hand, the Sutra and the Shastra.
What is the relationship between unconditioned deliverance and these three spheres?
Unconditioned deliverance receives the name of dhāru.
This deliverance is the three dhātus.
The destruction of craving is detachment.
The abandoning of craving is virāgadhāsu, the sphere of the absence of craving.
The destruction of the others is abandoning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃkṣaya iti vartate / rāgādanyeṣāṃ kleśānāṃ prahāṇaṃ prahāṇadhātuḥ /
column2: The abandoning of the defilements other than craving is prahāṇadhāsu, the sphere of abandoning.
The destruction of the object is called nirodhadhātu, the sphere of extinction.
The abandoning of the object, impure physical matter, etc. , with the exception of the abandoning of the defilements, is the realm of extinction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yena vastu nirvidyate virajyate 'pi tena vastunā /
column2: Does one become disgusted by means of the same dharmas through which one obtains detachment?
There are four alternatives.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ kṛtvā / nirvidyate duḥkhahetukṣāntijñānaiḥ duḥkhe samudayakṣāntijñānaireva nirvidyate nānyaiḥ /
column2: What are they?
Detachment arises through all the dharmas by means of which there is abandoning.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvairapi duḥkhasamudayanirodhamārga kṣāntijñānairvirajyate / yaiḥ kleśān prajahāti / evaṃ catuṣkoṭikasaṃbhavaḥ // evaṃ catuṣkotikaṃ sidhyati / nirvidyata eva duḥkhasamudayakṣāntijñānaiḥ /
column2: The Patiences and the Knowledges of Suffering, of Origin, of Extinction and of the Path, through which one abandons the defilements, are also the means for acquiring detachment.

If the ascetic does not abandon the defilements through the Patiences and Knowledges of Suffering and Origin, he only acquires disgust: these Patiences and these Knowledges have only the causes of disgust for their sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: virajyata eva nirodhamārgakṣāntijñānaiḥ kleśān prajahat / prāmodyavastvālambanatvāt / ubhayaṃ pūrvaiḥ kleśān prajahat / nobhayamuttaraiḥ kleśānaprajahaditi /
column2: If the ascetic abandons his defilements through the Patience and Knowledges of Extinction and the Path, he only acquires detachment; these Patiences and these Knowledges have only the causes of joy for their sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra vītarāgaḥ satyāni paśyandharmajñānakṣāntibhiḥ kleśānna prajahāti /
column2: If the ascetic abandons the defilements through thePatiences and the Knowledges of Suffering and Origin, he acquires detachment and disgust.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: jñānaistu prayogavimuktiviśeṣamārgasaṃgṛhītairna prajahātīti / abhidharmakośabhāṣye mārgapudgalanirdeśo nāma ṣaṣṭhaṃ kośasthānaṃ samāptamiti //śrī lāmāvākasya yadatra puṇyam // saptamaṃ kośasthānam
column2: If the ascetic does not abandon the defilements through the Patiences and the Knowledges of Extinction and the Path, he acquires neither detachment nor disgust.
The Knowledges O. Homage to the Buddha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣāntayaścocyante jñānāni ca samyagdṛṣṭiḥ samyagjñānaṃ ca /
column2: We have spoken of the ṣāntis or Patiences and of the jñāmas or Knowledges, of samyagāṛṟṣṭi or Right Views and of remyagjñāna or Right Knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kṣāntayo na jñānaṃ samyagjñānaṃ ca na dṛṣṭiḥ /
column2: Are the Patiences actually Knowledges, and isn't Right Knowledge identical to Right Views?

The pure Patiences are not a type of Knowledge. The eight types of pure Patience which form part of the Path of Seeing are not, by their nature, knowledge; for, at the moment of patience, the defilement of doubt, which each Patience abandons, is not already abandoned.
But Knowledge is certain: it is produced when doubt is abandoned. These eight types of Patience are Seeing, because, by their nature, they are examination.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭayastu tā santiraṇātmakattvāt yathā ca kṣāntayo dṛṣṭirna jñānamevaṃ punaḥ kṣayānutpādadhīrna dak /
column2: In opposition to the pure Patiences which are Seeing. The prajñā of destruction and of non-arising is not seeing.

The knowledge of destruction and the knowledge of Non-Arising when they constitute Bodhi are not Seeing, because they do not include examination, and because the intention of inquiry is not in them. All other pure prajñā is both one and the other.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadnyobhayathāryā dhīḥ kṣāntikṣayānutpādajñānebhyo 'nyā 'nāsravā prajñā dṛṣṭiḥ jñānaṃ ca /
column2: Besides the Patiences and the two Knowledges named above, pure prajñā is at one and the same time both seeing and knowledge, for it includes examination, and is therefore seeing; it is free from doubt, and is therefore knowledge. This refers to the eight abhisamaya knowledges and also to all prajñā of the pure Path of Meditation up to the Knowledge of Extinction.
All other prajñā is knowledge.
All other prajñā which is not pure, but worldly or impure i.
, prajñā associated with the five sense consciousnesses, and prajñā associated with the mental consciousness. Six are also seeing. Six impure prajñās are at one and the same time knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pañca dṛṣṭayo laukikī ca samyagdṛṣṭiḥ / eṣā ṣaḍvidhā laukikī prajñādṛṣṭiḥ anyā na dṛṣṭiḥ / jñānaṃ tveṣā cānyā ca /
column2: and seeing, namely the mental prajñā associated with the five defilements which are views by nature and, sixth, good prajñā, which is right worldly views.
How many knowledges are there?
There are ten;
but, in short there are only two: Knowledge is pure or impure. All the Knowledges are subsumed into two types of knowledge, impure or worldly knowledge, and pure or supermundane knowledge.
Of these two knowledges, the first is called conventional.
Impure Knowledge is called "knowledge conforming to worldly conventions. " Why?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prāyeṇa ghaṭapaṭastrīpuruṣādisaṃvṛtigrahāt / ajñānasaṃvṛtatvāt ityapare / anāsravaṃ dvidhā dharmajñānamanvayameva ca // anāsrvaṃ jñānaṃ dvidhā bhidyate /
column2: Because from usage it bears on things which exist conventionally, a jug, clothing, male, female, etc. Pure knowledge is of two types, a knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dharmajñānamanvayajñānaṃ ca / evagete dve jñāne trīṇi bhavanti / saṃvṛtijñānaṃ dharmajñānaṃ ca /
column2: These two knowledges with the preceding make three knowledges: worldly, conventional knowledge, a knowledge of dharmas, and inferential knowledge.
Among these.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃvṛtijñānasya sarvadharmāḥ saṣkṛtāsaṃskṛtā ālambanaṃ saṃbhavataḥ / kāmaduḥkhadigocaram /
column2: All the conditioned and unconditioned dharmas are the object of conventional knowledge. The knowledge of dharmas has for its object the Suffering, etc. , of Kāmadhātu.
The knowledge of dharmas has Suffering, the Arising of Suffering, the Extinction of Suffering, and the Path leading to the Extinction of Suffering of Kāmadhātu for its object.
Inferential knowledge bears on Śuffering, etc. , of the higher spheres.
Inferential knowledge has the Suffering, the Origin of Suffering. of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu for its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: te eva satyabhedena catvāri te eva dharmajñānānvayajñāne satyabhedena punaścatvāri jñānāni bhavanti /
column2: When one takes into consideration the distinction of the Truths, these two knowledges, make up four knowledges.

Namely: the knowledge of Suffering (which includes the knowledge of the dharmas of Suffering and the inferential knowledge of Suffering), the knowledge of Origin, the knowledge of Extinction, and the knowledge of the Path, because these two knowledges have Suffering, its Origin, etc. , for their object.
These two knowledges, fourfold, are termed the knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ete eva dharmajñānānvayajñāne caturvidhe adṛṣṭisvabhāve kṣayajñānamanutpādajñānaṃ cocyate /
column2: The knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledge, which are as we have just seen fourfold by reason of their objects, are, among the Arhats, when they are not of the nature of Seeing, called the Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising.
At the moment when they arise, they are inferential knowledges of Suffering and Origin.

The Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising, at the moment when they first arise are, by their nature, inferential knowledge of Suffering and of its Origin in the higher spheres, because they have for their object the skandhas of Bhavāgra under the aspects of Suffering and Origin. These two knowledges therefore have the same object. The Knowledge of Destruction follows Vajropamasamādhi; and the Knowledge of Non-Arising follows the Knowledge of Destruction.
Does Vajropamasamādhi have the same object as these two?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi duḥkhasamudayālamvano bhavati / atha nirodhamārgālambano naikālambanaḥ /
column2: When it has Suffering and Origin for its object, yes, when it has Extinction and the Path for its object, no.
The knowledge of the mind of another follows from four.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paracittajñānaṃ caturbhyo jñānebhyo draṣṭavyam / dharmānvayajñānamārgaḥ saṃvṛtijñānebhyaḥ / tasya punarayaṃ niyamaḥ bhūmyakṣapudgalotkrāntam naṣṭājātaṃ na veti tat //
column2: The knowledge of the mind of another follows four knowledges, a knowledge of the dharmas, inferential knowledge, a knowledge of the Path, and conventional knowledge.

It does not know a mind in a higher sphere, faculties, personalities, nor the past and future. A mind is superior either from the point of view of its bh%mi, from the point of view of its indriyas, ot from the point of view of its personality.
The knowledge of the mind of another of a lower sphere does not know a mind in a higher sphere.

The knowledge of the mind of another of a saint with weak faculties, namely a Śraddhādhimukta or a Samayavimukta, does not know the mind of a saint of strong faculties, namely a Dṛṣṭiprāpta or a Asamayavimukta.
The knowledge of the mind of another of a lower saint does not know the mind of a higher saiat;
in order, Anāgāmin, Arhat. When the mind of another is either past or future, the knowledge of a mind of another does not know it, for this knowledge has a present mind for its object.
Does the mind of another avoid being in the sphere of the knowledge of the mind of another in other cases as well?
The knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledges do not know one another.
The knowledge of the mind of another, when it is by its nature a knowledge of dharmas, is not capable of knowing the mind of another which is by nature inferential knowledge;
when it is inferential by nature, it is not capable of knowing the mind of another which is by nature a series of dharmas. Why?
Because these two knowledges have for their object the dharmas which are opposed to Kāmadhātu and to the higher spheres respectfully.

There is no knowledge of the mind of another in the Path of Seeing. That is to say, an ascetic, while he cultivates the Path of Seeing, is not endowed with the knowledge of the mind of another. But the mind of another which is found in the Path of Seeing can be the object of the knowledge of the mind of another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra paracittajñānena darjñanamārga jñātukāmaḥ prayogaṃ kṛtvā prathamau
column2: When one desires to know, through the knowledge of the mind of another, the mind of another which is found in the Path of Seeing, one cultivates a preparatory exercise.
The Śrāvaka knows two moment of Seeing;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śrāvako darśanamārgāt paracittajñānena dvau kṣaṇau jānāti / duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣāntiṃ dharmajñānaṃ ca /
column2: the Pratyekabuddha, three; the Buddha, without preparation, all. When a Śrāvaka cultivates the knowledge of the mind of another in the desire to see the mind of an ascetic in the Path of Seeing, he obtains some knowing of the first tvo moments, the Patience of the Knowledge of the dharmas of Suffering end the knowledge of dharmas — but ṉot the following moments (the Patience of the Inferential Knowledge of Suffering.

)—because the knowledge of the inferential part (Suffering in the higher spheres) of the Path of Seeing supposes a different preparatory. Would you say that it is impure, not because it is the object of the craving of another, but because it is the object of a “general defilement” of another? In this hypothesis, do not say that this mind is sarāga, that it “possesses cravingʼ;
say rather that it is semoha, that it “possesses moha,” since it is the object of the or ignorance of another. But, we would say, none of these proposed explanations is valid.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca paracittajñānaṃ prāptyālambanaṃ nāpi taccittālambanaṃ rāgālambanam /
column2: In fact the knowledge of the mind of another does not bear on the “possessions” which can be found in the series of another. Consequently when I know that the mind of another person possesses craving, this mind of another does not possess craving because it is “united with craving” in the sense that it is accompanied by the possession of craving, or in the sense that it is found in the series in which this possession has not been expelled. The knowledge of the mind of another no longer knows the craving which would be the object of the mind of another.
Therefore a mind is not termed rarāga through the fact of rāgasaṁyoga, through the fact of being “united with rāga” in the proposed twofold sense.

If this is the case, what is a serāga mind? One should determine the intention of the Sūtra. A sarāga mind or one “possessing craving” is not a rāgasaṁyukta mind, a mind “united to craving”, but a rāgasaṁprayukta mind, a mind “associated with craving,” a mind in which craving presently exists.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rāgasaṃprayuktaṃ cittaṃ sarāgamasaṃprayuktaṃ vigatarāgamiti sūtrābhigrāyo dṛśyate /
column2: Vigatarāga, “without craving” is a mind which is not associated with craving, even when this mind will be accompanied by the possession of craving.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yat tūktaṃ “vigatarāgamasya taccittaṃ bhavati vigatadveṣaṃ vigatamohamanāvarttikadharmi kāmabhave rūpabhave ārupyabhave” iti / tatra tatpraptivigamaṃ saṃdhāyoktam /
column2: The expression vigatarāga cannot have this meaning; for another Sūtra says that a mind which is without craving, without anger, and without ignorance, does not fall back into threefold existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu coktam anyakleśasaṃprayuktamapi cittaṃ rāgaviprayuktatvādvigatarāgaṃ syādi“ti /
column2: Now if this mind is accompanied by the possession of craving, etc. , it will fall back again. In this other Sūtra, “a mind without craving” signifies “a mind which is not accompanied by the possession of craving”. Have you not refuted your own opinion? We said in fact that if one calls a mind without craving vigatarāga, that is, a mind in which craving is not presently active, then one should terrm all minds associated with another defilement vigatarāga.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tu tadvigatarāgamiti kṛtvā gṛhyate / kiṃ tarhi / sadveṣaṃ samohamityevamādi / alaṃ prasaṅgena siddhānto varṇyatām /

When the knowledge of the mind of another attains its object, namely the mind of another person, does it attain this mind of another as this latter knows it? When one knows the mind of another, one does not see.

column2: One does not see this mind as it itself knows something: one knows only that it is defiled, etc. ; one does not know the object, colot, etc. , by reason of which it is defiled.

column2: If it were otherwise, the knowledge of the mind of another would bear on rpa, etc. ,and would no longer be the knowledge of the mind of another; the knowledge of the mind of another would bear on itself: for the person whose mind I know can at the same moment know my mind.

column2: The knowledge of the mind of another is incompatible with the Path of Seeing and the Uninterrupted Path, with the Samādhi of Emptiness and the Samādhi of No-Marks, and with the Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising.

Other conditions are not excluded: the knowledge of the mind of another is compatible with the Path of Meditation (the Path of Liberation, vimuktimārga, and the Path of Distinction, viśesamārga), with the Uncommitted Samadhi (gpraṇéhitasamādhi, etc. The teaching of the knowledge of the mind of another is ended.
The other has fourteen aspects by excluding the aspect of emptiness and the aspect of non-self. The “‘others” are the Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣayānutpādajñāne śeṣe te caturdaśākāre śūnyānātmakārau varjayitvā /
column2: Both have fourteen aspects, excluding the aspect of emptiness and the aspect of non-self. In fact, these two Knowledges, even though they are of the absolute level of truth, are also included in the conventional level of truth. They are.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pāramārthikayorapi saṃvṛtibhajanāt śīṇā me jātirnāparamasmādbhavaṃ prajānāmīti tadvalānuvyavahārataḥ /
column2: When an ascetic departs from the contemplation in which the knowledges of the absolute truth are realized, through the force of these knowledges, later knowledges are produced which are of the conventional level of truth: “my births are cut off, the religious life has been fully cultivated, I have done what should have been done, and I do not know of any more existences for me. " The two knowledges, the Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising, therefore participate in the conventional level of truth, not in and of themselves or through definition, but through their outflowing.
Are there any pure aspects outside of these sixteen aspects? There are no pure aspects outside of the sixteen.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāśmīrāṇāṃ tāvat nāmalaḥ ṣoḍaśabhyo 'nya ākāraḥ nāstyanāsravākāraḥ ṣoḍaśākāranirmuktaḥ /

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa cecchāstrārtho 'bhaviṣyat / yadidaṃ paṭhacyate “syāddarśanaprahātavyena cittena kāmapratisaṃyuktāndharmānvijānīyāditi / āha / vijānīyāt /

column2: Yes, one can distinguish them, namely, one becomes attached to, one hates, one prides oneself, one errs, one erroneously distinguishes these dharmas as self, mine, as eternal or perishable, as non-cause, non-āction, nonexistent, as supreme, excellent, distinguished, superior, as purification, deliverance, salvation, with anxiety, disagreement, or doubt.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punarime ṣoḍaśākārā nāmata āhosvit dravyataḥ /
column2: How many things constitute the sixteen aspects?
The aspects are sixteen things. Certain masters said that the aspects, sixteen in name, are only seven in fact.

The four aspects of the Truth of Suffering are in fact distinct from one another. The aspects of the other Truths, in their fourfold name, only constitute one thing for each Truth. Ascetics contemplate separately the four aspects of the Truth of Suffering and any one of the aspects, material cause, etc. , of the three other Truths.
But maintain that the sixteen aspects exist in fact.
For the Truth of Suffering: Impermanence, because it arises dependent upon efficient causes.
Suffering, because it is painful by nature.
Empty, as it opposes the belief in the view of things pertaining to self.
No soul, as it opposes the belief in a self.
For the Truth of Origin: Cause, because it has the characteristic of a seed. The hetu is a distant or material cause. The word yoga signifies yāya or truth.
Arising, as it produces. This is the near cause, that from which a dharma immediately arises or originates.
Successive appearance, which constitutes the series: seed.
Efficient conditions, as realizing an effect in joint causation;
for example, the coming together of efficient conditions—earth, stick, wheel, twiṉne, water, etc. —produces a jug.
For the Truth of Extinction: Extinction, by reason of the destruction of the skaṉdhas.
Calm, by reason of the extinction of the three fires, craving, anger, and delusion.
Excellent, by reason of the absence f all pain.
Salvation, because it is disassociated from all causes of pain.
For the Truth of the Path: Path, because one traverses it.
Truth, because it is yogayukta, that is to say, endowed with proofs, endowed with resources of means.
Obtaining, because it brings about correct obtaining, that is to say one obtains.
Definitive release, because it causes one to pass beyond in a definitive manner.
There is a second exegesis: For the Truth of Suffering: Impermanent, because it is not definitive.
Suffering, because it resembles a burden.
Empty, because it is empty of puruṣa.
No-soul, because it does not obey the will.
Cause, because it comes about from that.
Arising, because there is emergence.
Appearance, as it is a procession.
Condition or foundation, that is, the essential element from the action of generation.
Extinction, because of the cessation of the former suffering and of the non-continuation of subsequent suffering.
Calm, because it is delivered from the three conditioned characteristics.
Excellent, because it is absolutely good.
Salvation, because it supremely strengthens.
Path, because it is opposed to the wrong path.
Truth, because it is opposed to non-truth.
Obtaining, because it is not in contradiction with the city of Nirvāṇa.
Definitive release, because it abandons existence in the.
Since ancient explanations differ, we are permitted to present a third explanation: Ã I.

No soul, because this is not an ājman.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svayamanātmatvādanātma / hetusamudayaprabhavapratyayatvaṃ tu yadeva sūtra uktam / “ime pañcopādānaskandhāśchandamūlakāśchandasamudayāśchandajātīyāśchandaprabhavā” iti /
column2: For the Truth of Origin: the four aspects of the Second Truth, cause, arising, appearance, and condition, are explained according to the Stra, “The five xpādānaskandhas are chandamlaka, chandasamudaya, chandajātīya, chandaprabhava,” that is to say they have chanda for their root or hetu, which brings about their arising, for their condition, for their appearance.
The only difference between the Sūtra and the Śāstra is that the latteṛ places the condition aspect in first place, and not the appearance aspect.
What is the difference between these four types of “processions”⁷?
One should distinguish four states of desire.
The affection that one experiences for oneself when one thinks, "I am," without otherwise distinguishing an actual "self," without thinking of a past or future self.
The desire for re-existence without any other specification.
The desire for a certain re-existence.
The desire for reincarnation, a desire which makes one accomplish a certain action.
Twhe first desire is the initial cause of snffering—as the seed is the initial cause of the fruit—;

it is called herx. The second desire is that which brings about re-existence—as the production of the shoot, ṣtalk, etc. , is a casual process or arising which brings about fruit; it is therefore called samudaya, a cause which brings forth.

The third desire is the cause which determines the quality of suffering,—as the field, the water, the fertilizer, etc. , determine the virility, the ripening, the appearance of the fruit; it is therefore called prayaya, or condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣetrādivaśena hi phalasya gandharasavīryavipākaprabhāvabhedā bhavanti caturthaḥ prabhavastataḥ eva tatsaṃbhavāt phalasyeva puṣpāvasānamiti
column2: The fourth desire is the cause from whence the fruit appears. When one thinks I am," general affection for one’s own person without determination is produced, which is fivefold: I am such;
I am the same; I am different; I am something that is; I am something that is not.

column2: may I be such; may I be the same; may”There is produced a desire for reincarnation, which is fourfold;

column2: “It is absolutely necessary that I may be, that I may be such, the same, different. The first desires are the initial cause of suffering; they are therefore the betu. The rest as above.
For the Truth of Extinction: Extinction, because it cuts off transmigration.
Calm, because it is cessationof all suffering;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “iti hi bhikṣavo duḥkhāḥ saṃskārāḥ śāntaṃ nirvāṇami“ti vacanāta /
column2: thus it is said, “AIl the se/skāras, Oh Bhīkṣus, are suffering; only Nirvāṇa aḻone is absolute calmn.
” Excellent, because it is the highest.
Definitive salvation, because it is without returning.
For the Truth of the Path: Path, because it resembles the right path. Truth, because it is true.
Obtaining, because it is determined;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “eṣa mārgo hi nāstyanyo darśanasya viśuddhaya” iti
column2: that is to say one arrives by this path and not by another, as it is said, “This path leads to purity, other systems do not lead to it.
” Definitive release, because it is definitive separation from threefold existence.

Furthermore, it is in order to cure persons who nourish viewsThe cause aspect is opposed to the view, "There is only one cause". The arising aspect is opposed to the view, "There is only one cause"—be it Ilśvara, or pradhāṇa. Cause is a complex. The appearance aspect is opposed to the idea of evolution, the theory that bhāva, or existence, existing initially, transforms itself: rather, bhāva begins.
The condition aspect is opposed to the view that the world is created by an intelligent being: things arise from a multiplicity of causes.
The extinction aspect is opposed to the view that there is no deliverance.
The calm aspect is opposed to the view that deliverance is suffering.
The excellent aspect is opposed to the view that the happiness of the dhyānas and samapāttis is excellent (v. 7, English trans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaḥ punaḥ parihāṇito nātyantiko mokṣa iti dṛṣṭicaritānāṃ niḥsaraṇākāraḥ /
column2: The definitive release aspect is opposed to the view that. Deliverance is subject to falling, that it is not definitive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāsti mārgaḥ kumārgo 'yamanyo mārgaḥ punarāvartī mārga iti dṛṣṭicaritānāṃ mārganyāyapratipannairyāṇikākārā iti /
column2: The Path, truth, cultivation, and definitive release aspects oppose, respectively, the views that there is no path, that a false path is the Path, that there is another path, and that the Path is subject to falling.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ākāro nāma ka eṣa dharmaḥ / prajñākāraḥ
column2: The aspects are prajñā. The aspects are by their nature mental prgjñā oṟ discernment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tarhi prajñā sākārā na bhaviṣyati / prajñāntarāsaṃyogāt / evaṃ tu yuktaṃ syāt / sarveṣāṃ cittacaittānāmālambanagrahaṇaprakāra ākāra iti /
column2: But, we would say, if this is so, then prjñā, the knowledge that discerns the dharmas, will not be endowed with the aspects, for prajñā cannot be associated with prajñā. It is therefore correct to say that “aspect” is a mode of perceiving objects by the mind and mental states.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kiṃ prajñaivākārayati netyāha / kiṃ tarhi / tayā saha /
column2: Is it solely prajñā which perceives the different, unique characteristics of objects?
Everything that has an object perceives.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prajñā cānye ca sarve sālambanā dharmā ākārayanti /
column2: Prajñā and all the other dharmas which have an object perceive. Everything that exists is the object of perception.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvamākāryate tu sat // yatkiñcidasti sarvamākāryate / tadevaṃ kṛtvā siddhaṃ bhavati prajñā ākāraścākārayati cākāryante ca /
column2: Évetything that exists is perceived by the dharmas which have an object. We have therefore three more or less large categories.

Prajna is aspect, subject, and object; the other minds and mental states, which are associated with prajna, are subject and object; and all the other dharmas, conditioned or unconditioned, are only object. We have explained the aspects of the ten knowledges;
we must now explain their natures, the sphere which serves as their support, and the person in whom they arise.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tridhādyaṃ kuśalānyanyāni saṃvṛtijñānaṃ ślokādau bhavatvādādyam / tattrividham /
column2: The first is of three natures;
the others are good. "The first" is worldly, conventional knowledge, because this knowledge is named first in the Karika, and is of three types, good, bad, or neutral.
The nine other knowledges are only good.
The first exists in all spheres.
It exists in all spheres, from Kamadhatu up to Bhavagra.
In six, the knowledge named dharma.
A knowledge of the dharmas is obtained in or through the Four Dhyana, and in Anagamya and Dhyananntara.
In nine, that which is called anvaya. Inferential knowledge is obtained in the six spheres which have been mentioned, and furthermore, in three Arupyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anvayajñānaṃ tāsveva ca ṣaṭsu bhūmiṣvārupyatraye ca / tathaiva ṣaṭ // duḥkhasamudayanirodhamārgakṣayānutpādajñānānyapyetāsveva navasu bhūmiṣvabhedena /
column2: When one considers them together, some six knowledges,— the knowledge of Suffering, Origin, Extinction, the Path, Destruction, and Non-Arising—are obtained in nine spheres;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhedena punrdharmajñānasaṃgṛhītāni ṣaṭsu anvayajñāna saṃgṛhītāni navasu /
column2: when they form part of the knowledge of dhurmas, they are obtained in six spheres; when they form part of inferential knowledge, they are obtained in nine spheres.
The knowledge of the mind of another exists in the Four Dhyāṇnas.
The knowledge of the mind of another is only obtained in the Four Dhyānas, and nowhere else.
It has for its support a person either in Kāmadhātu or Rūpadhātu.
Beings in Kāmadhātu and Rūpadhātu realize the knowledge of the mind of another.
The knowledge of dharmas, a person in Kāmādhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dharmajñānaṃ tu kāmadhātvāśrayameva / na rūpārupyadhātvoḥ saṃmukhīkriyate /
column2: The knowledge of dharmas can only be realized by a person in Kāmadhātu, and notby a person in either Rāpadhātu or Ārūpyadhātu.
Others, in persons of the three spheres.
What are the other knowledges?
They are the eight knowledges with the exception of the knowledge of the mind of another and the knowledge of dharmas.
We have explained the spheres in which one acquires the knowledges, and the sphere to which the persons who can acquire the knowledges belong.
Let us explain the relationship of the knowledges with the four applications of mindfulness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: so 'yamucyate / smṛtyupasthānamekaṃ dhīrnirodhe dhīḥ prajñā jñānamiti paryāyāḥ /
column2: The knowledge of Extinction is an application of mindfulness.
The knowledge of Extinction is an application of mindfulness which relates to a dharma.
The knowledge of the mind of another is threefold.
The knowledge of the mind of another, related to the mind of another, necessarily relates to vedanā, saṅṅjñā, and the saṁskāras.
The others, four.

By excluding the knowledge of Extinction and the knowledge of the mind of another, the other eight knowledges have the four applications of mindfulaness for their nature. The knowledge of Suffering, in fact, sometimes relates to the body. The knowledge of the Path, when it has pure discipline for its object, is an application of mindfulness related to the body.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: katamasya jñānasya kati jñānānyālambanam / dharmadhīgocaro nava //
column2: The different knowledges are the object of how maṅny other.

Nine are the object of inferential knowledge and knowledge of the Path.
Excluding the knowledge of dharmas in inferential knowledge;
by excluding worldly conventional knowledge in the knowledge of the Path, because it does not form part of the Path.
Two are the object of the knowledge of Suffering and Origin.
Worldly conventional knowledge and the part of the knowledge of the mind of another which is impure, are the object of a knowledge of Suffering and of Origin.
Ten knowledges are the object of worldly conventional knowledge, a knowledge of the mind of another, the Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising.
None are the object of one.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekasya nirodhajñānasya naiva jñānamālambanam / yojyā dharmāḥ punardaśa //
column2: No knowledge is the object of the knowledge of Extinction whose only object is Extinction obtained through conscious effort. How many dharmas constitute in their totality the object of the ten knowledges? How many Aharmas constitute the object of each? The totality of their object is ten dharrnas.
What are these ten dharmas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: traidhātu kāmalā dharmā akṛtāśca dvidhā dvidhā /
column2: Dharmas of the Three Dhātus, pure dharmas, unconditioned, each category being twofold.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃkṛtā dharmā aṣṭadhā kriyante / kāmarūpārupyāvacarānāsravāṇāṃ saṃprayuktaviprayuktabhedāt /
column2: The conditioned dharmas are divided into eight classes: dharmas of Kāmadhātu, of Rūpadhātu, of Ārūpyadhātu, plus the pure dharmas, all being either associated with the mind or not.
The unconditioned dharmas are divided into two classes, good and neutral.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ime daśa dharmāḥ kathaṃ yojyāḥ kasya jñānasya katyālambanamiti /
column2: Which of these two classes of dharmas are the object of the ten knowledges?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra saṃvṛtijñānasya sarve daśa dharmā ālambanam /
column2: Worldly conventional knowledge is related to ten dharmas;
a knowledge of dharmas is related to five: two dharmas of Kāmadhātu, associated or not with the mind, and a good unconditioned dharma;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmāvacarānāsravā ścatvāraḥ kuśalaṃ cāsaṃskṛtam / anvayajñānasya sapta / rūpārupyāvacarānāsravāḥ ṣaṭ kuśalaṃ cāsaṃskṛtam /
column2: inferential knowledge is related to seven: two of Rāpadhātu, two of Ārūpyadhātu, and two pure, which make six, and a good unconditioned dharma;
the knowledge of Suffering and of Origin are related to only good unconditioned dharmas;
a knowledge of the Path is related to.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paracittajñānasya trayaḥ / kāmarūpāvacarānāsravāḥ saṃprayuktāḥ / kṣayānutpādajñānayoḥ nava dharmā ālambanamavyākṛtamasaṃskṛtaṃ muktvā / syādekena jñānena sarvadharmān jānīyāt / na syāt /
column2: One conventional knowledge, with the exception of its own complex, knows the rest as non-self.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: api tu sāṃvṛtaṃ svakalāpānyadekaṃ vidyādanātmataḥ // saṃvṛtijñānaṃ svasmātkalāpādanyān sarvadharmānanātvato jānīyāt sarvadharmā anātmāna iti /
column2: When a moment of conventional knowledge knows ail the dharmas as not being a self, this is with the exception, in the totality of the dharmas, of itself, this same moment of conventional knowledge, for the subject of knowledge cannot be its own object; the mental ḍharmas which are associated with it, for they have the same object as it does; and 3.
the dharmas disassociated from the mind but which accompany it, for example, its characteristics, for they are too close.
This conventional knowledge of universal consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tacca kāmāvacaraṃ śrutacintāmayaṃ rūpāvacaraṃ śrutamayam bhāvanāmayam / tasya vyavacchinnabhūmyālambanatvāt /
column2: belongs only to Kāmadhātu, being prajñā of hearing or reflection, not prajñā of absorption, for the conventional knowledge which is of this third type of prajñā always has a determined sphere for its object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hi yugapatsarvato vairāgyaṃ syāt / gatametat / idaṃ tu vaktavyam /
column2: If it were otherwise one could obtain at one and the same time detachment with respect to all of the spheres.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaḥ katibhirjñānaiḥ samanvāgata iti / pṛthagjanastāvadekena samanvāgataḥ /
column2: The different categories of humans are endowed with how many knowledges?
A common person possesses only worldly conventional knowledge;
when he is detached, he also possesses a knowledge of the mind of another.
As for the Āryaṇ, 19a-b.
Not detached, in the first pure moment, he possesses one knowledge.

An Āryaṉ who is not detached through a worldly path before entering the Path, in the moment in which the Patience which is the knowledge of the dharmas related to Suffering arises, possesses a single knowledge, namely worldly conventional knowledge, because this Patience is not a knowledge.
In the second moment, he possesses three knowledges.
At the moment of the knowledge of dharmas related to Suffering, he possesses worldly conventional knowledge, a knowledge of Zharmas, and a knowledge of Suffering.
Beyond, in four moments, each time adding a knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ataḥ paraṃ caturṣu kṣaṇeṣu ekaikajñānavṛddhirasya jñātavyā /
column2: A knowledge is added in each of four subsequent moments;

at the fourth moment there is inferential knowledge; at the sixth moment there is the knowledge of origin; at the tenth moment there is the knowledge of Extinction; and at the fourteenth moment there is the knowledge of the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samudayanirodhamārgadharmajñāneṣu samudayanirodhamārgajñānāni vardhanta iti mārgadharmajñāne saptabhirjñānaiḥ samanvāgato bhavati /
column2: Consequently, having attained the knowledge of the dharmas related to the Path, the ascetic possesses seven knowledges.

For an Āryan who, before entering into the Pure Path, has obtained detachment through a worldly path, we must add the knowledge of the mind of another. A samayavimukta Arhat possesses nine knowledges, by adding the.

How many knowledges does the ascetic cultivate at one and the same time in different stages, the Path of Seeing the Truths, and in the Path of Meditation, etc. ? With respect to the fifteen minds of the Path of Seeing: 20a-c.
In Seeing, future patiences and knowledges exist to the extent to which they are produced.

Those which are produced are acquired or cultivated. For example, when an ascetic produces the Patience of the knowledge of the dharmas related to Suffering, he cultivates future Patience of this same type, and he takes possession of future Patience of this same type. [And so on to the Patience of the inferential knowledge of the Path].

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanamārge yadyadevotpadyate kṣāntirjñānaṃ vā tajjātīyamanāgataṃ bhāvanāṃ gacchati tadākārā eva catvāraḥ /
column2: The four aspects of this Patience (impermanence, etc. ) are also acquired when any one of the aspects is produced.

Why, in the Path of Seeing, is there only acquisition of the knowledge and the aspects of the type of knowledge and theWhen the Patience of the knowledge of the dharmas related to Suffering is produced, the goa,—that is to say, the seed or the cause—of this Patience, and the goras of its four aspects, are grasped, whereas the goiras of the knowledge of dharmas related to Suffering, etc. , are not grasped. As for the aspects, we see that the four aspects of each Truth are of the same type, for they have the same object.
When one of them is produced, the goi7as of the others are grasped.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatraiva darśanamārge saṃvṛtijñānaṃ cāpi bhāvyate triṣu duḥkhasamudayanirodhānvayajñāneṣu /
column2: In the Path of Seeing one also acquires conventional knowledge at the moment of the three inferential knowledges. The ascetic takes possession of future conventional knowledge at the moment of the three inferential knowledges of Suffering, Origin, and Extinction (moments 4, 8, and 12 of the Path of Seeing, vi.
26b): not at the moment of the knowledge of the dharmas, because, in the knowledge of the dharmas, each Truth has not been understood in its totality, but only relating to Kāmadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva tadābhisamayāntikaṃ saṃvṛtijñānamākhyāvate / ekaikasatyābhisamayānte bhāvanāt /
column2: It is termed abhisamayāntika jñānṉa, because it is cultivated at the end of the comprehension of each Truth.
Why does an ascetic not take possession of it at the mornent of inferential knowledge of the Path?
Because the Path has not been understood formerly, through a worldly path, under its aspects of Path, Truth, etc. b.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṛtsnaṃ hi duḥkhaṃ śakyate parijñātuṃ samudayaḥ prahātuṃ nirodhaḥ sākṣātkartu na tu mārgaḥ śakyate kṛtsno bhāvayitum ityabhisamayāntābhāvānna tasminnābhisamayāntikaṃ bhāvyate /
column2: Because the Path is not susceptible of being understood in its entirety. Suffering, its Origin, and its Extinction can be respectively known, abandoned, realized, in their entirety; but the Path caṇnot be practiced in its entirety.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samudayo 'pi na tadā sarvaḥ prahīṇo bhavatīti na syādābhisamayāntikam / na / tatsatyadarśanaheyaḥ sarvaḥ prahīṇno bhavati /
column2: Without doubt one cannot say of a person who is in the Path of Seeing, that, at the end of his comprehension of the Truths of Origin and Extinction, he has complete abandoning of Origin, and complete realization of Extinction: yet a time will come when this abandoning and this realization will be complete.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: mārgastaddarśanaheyapratipakṣo na sarvaḥ śakyate bhāvayituṃ vahugotratvāt ityasti mahānviśeṣaḥ /
column2: But the same does not hold for the Path, given the diversity of families of the Śrāvakas.
Some say Because conventional knowledge accompanies the Path of Seeing.
Now the sixteenth moment of this comprehension forms part of the Path of Meditation. Thus one does not acquire the end of comprehension in the sixteenth moment.
We would say that this argument does not hold, for one should not regard the fact that conventional knowledge does not accompany the Path of Meditation as a proof. It is not destined to arise.

At no moment is there the possibility for it to arise. This knowledge does not arise when the ascetic is in contemplation, nor when the ascetic has left his contemplation. On the one hand this knowledge is incompatible with his contemplation; on the other hand the mind, outside of its contemplation, is too coarse.
If this is so, how can one say that one takes possession of conventional knowledge, and that conventional knowledge is cultivated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: alabdhalābhāt kathamidānīṃ tatpratilabdhaṃ yadi naiva saṃmukhīkartu śakyate /
column2: Formerly it was not acquired, but now it is acquired.
It is termed acquired because it is acquired.
“Acquired because it is acquired,” is an unprecedented manner of speaking.
You do not thus explain how conventional knowledge is cultivated. This point should be understood in the same way as the Former Masters understood it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tu sidhyati yad āhuḥ pūrvācāryāḥ / kathaṃ ca pūrvācāryā āhuḥ /
column2: According to these Masters, one acquires conventional knowledge through the power of the Āryamārga.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: lokottaramārga-sāmarthyāt saṃvṛtijñānaṃ bhāvyate yad vyutthitaḥ satyālambanam viśiṣṭataraṃ laukikaṃ jñānaṃ saṃmukhīkaroti /
column2: After one has left the contemplation of the Āryamārga, a conventional knowledge bearing on the Truths is realized, and it is much more distinguished than that which precedes the obtaining of the Āryamārga itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa eva ca tasya lābho yat-tat-saṃmukhībhāva-samarthāśrayalābhaḥ / gotre hi labdhe labdhaṃ gautrikaṃ bhavati /
column2: When one says that an ascetic acquired this conventional knowledge through the Path of Seeing, one means to speak of the acquisition of a personality capable of realizing of this conventional knowledge, as the acquisition of a mineral containing gold is called the acquisition of gold itself.
The Vaibhāṣikas do not accept this manner of seeing things.
They hold that the so-called agbhiśsamayāntika conventional.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: darśanamārgasya svadhobhūmi yadbhūmiko darśanamārgo bhavati tadbhūmikam cāvarabhūmikaṃ ca saṃvṛtijñānaṃ bhāvyate /
column2: When one realizes the Path of Seeing of a certain sphere, one acquires, in the future, the conventional knowledge of this sphere or of a lower sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ānāgamyabhūmikaścedbhavati dvibhūmikaṃ bāvyate / anāgamyabhūmikaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ ca / evaṃ yāvaccaturthadhyānabhūmike darśanamārge saptabhūmikaṃ saṃvṛtijñānaṃ bhāṣyate / tatra punaḥ kati smṛtyupasthānāni /
column2: This means that if one realizes the Path of Seeing in the state of Anāgamya, one acquires, in the future, the Path of Seeing of a single sphere, and one acquires, in the future, the conventional knowledge of two spheres: and so on until: if one realizes the Path of Śeeing in the Fourth Dhyāṇna, one acquires, in the future, the Path of Seeing of six spheres (Anāgamya, Dhyānāṇtara, and the Four Dhyānas), and one acquires, in the future, the conventional knowledge of seven spheres (the same, plus Kāmadhātu). If one cultivates conventional knowledge at the end of Suffering and Origin, — that is to say in the moments of the inferential knowledge of Suffering and the inferential knowledge of Origin, — conventional knowledge is by nature the four.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirodhe 'ntyaṃ nirodhe 'bhisamite yat saṃvṛtijñānaṃ tadantyaṃ smṛtyupasthānaṃ dharmasmṛtyupasthānam / ekasya parisaṃkhyānātsiddhaṃ bhavati śeṣaṃ catvāri smṛtyupasthānānīti / taccaitadābhisamayāntikaṃ saṃvṛtijñānaṃ
column2: If one cultivates at the end of Extinction, it is only the last foundation of mindfulness, namely the foundation of mindfulness related to dharmas.
It has the aspects of its Truth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatsatyābhisamayāllabhyate tatsatyākārameva / tadākāravacanādālambanasya tadeva satyamityuktaṃ bhavati /
column2: When one cultivates conventional knowledge at the end of the comprehension of a certain truth, the conventional knowledge takes on the aspects of this Truth and has this Truth for its object. It proceeds from effort.

Being acquired through the power of the Path of Seeing, it is exclusively obtained through effort; it does not arise from detachment. The knowledges are so called because knowledge is the major element in them;

if one takes into consideration their followings, they make up four skandhas in Kāmadhātu, and five skandhas in Rūpadhātu. How many knowledges does one cultivate in the different states of the Path of Meditation?
In the sixteenth, six, through non-detachment.
One should add "are cultivated" according to vii.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avītarāgasya ṣoḍaśe mārgānvayajñānakṣaṇe dve jñāne pratyutpanne / mārgajñānamārgānvayajñāne /
column2: In the sixteenth moment, the ascetic who is not detached from Kāmadhātu cultivates two knowledges in the present;
he cultivates six knowledges in the future: namely the knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, and knowledges of the Four Truths.
Through detachment, seven.

With respect to the ascetic already detached from Kāmadhātu, at the moment when he attains inferential knowledge of the Path, one should add the cultivation of the knowledge of the mind of another, the seventh.
Above, in the Path of Meditation associated with sensual desire, there is the cultivation of seven.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣoḍaśāt kṣaṇādurdhvaṃ bhāvanāmārge yāvanna vītarāgo bhavati tāvat sarveṣu prayogāntaryavimuktiviśeṣamārgeṣu sapta jñānāni bhāvyante / dharmānvayaduḥkhasamudayanirodhamārgasaṃvṛtijñānāni /
column2: Beyond the sixteenth moment, that is, in the rest of the Path of Meditation, as long as one has not obtained detachment, in the preparatory paths, the uninterrupted paths, the paths of deliverance, and in the excellent paths,—there is cultivation of seven knowledges, namely a knowledge of the dbarmas, inferential knowledge, the knowledges of the Four Truths, and worldly.
If one cultivates a worldly path, one also, in the present, cultivates worldly conventional knowledge.
If one cultivates a transworldly path, one also, in the present, cultivates one of the four knowledges of the dharmas. One will cultivate the other six knowledges in the future.
In the uninterrupted paths of the victory over seven spheres, of the acquisition of the supernormal knowledges, and of the quality of Immovability, of mixed meditation.
And also in the eight paths of higher deliverance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saptajñānāni bhāvyante iti vartate / sapta bhūmayaḥ catvāri dhyānāni trayaścārupyāḥ /
column2: Based on the preceding, add “there is cultivation of seven knowledges.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāsāṃ jayaḥ vairāgyaṃ tasmin saptabhūmike vairāgye pañcasu cābhijñāsu akopyaprativedhe ca vyavakīrṇabhāvite ca dhyāne śaikṣasya yāvantaḥ ānantaryamārgāsteṣvapi sarveṣu sapta jñānāni bhāvyante tānyeva /
column2: One cultivates seven knowledges, the same as above, in the uninterrupted paths which make up: victory over seven spheres, that is to say detachment from the Four Dhyānas and the three Ārūpyas: these spheres are “vanquished” when one is detached from them; the acquisition of five supernormal knowledges, with the exception of the sixth.
If the ascetic cultivates these paths through a worldly path, he cultivates, in the present, conventional knowledge;
if he follows a transworldly path, he cultivates in the present one of the four inferential knowledges, and one of the two knowledges of dharmas.
In the acquisition of the quality of Immovability, he does not cultivate conventional knowledge;
for this latter is not opposed to Bhavāgra.
Here the Knowledge of the Destruction is the seventh knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saptabhūmivairāgyādapi cordhvaṃbhavāgravairāgye vimuktimārgeṣvaṣṭāsu saptaiva jñānāni bhāvyante / dharmānvayaduḥkhasamudayanirodhamārgaparacittajñānāni /
column2: Above the detachment from the seven spheres, in the first eight paths of deliverance of Bhavāgra, the ascetic cultivates, in the future, seven knowledges, namely the knowledge of dharmas, inferential knowledge, the knowledges of the Four Truths, and the knowledge of the mind of another;
he does not cultivate conventional knowledge, because this knowledge is not opposed to Bhavāgra.
He cultivates, in the present, one of the four inferential knowledges or one of the two knowledges of dharmas.
The Śaikṣa, in the path of deliverance of the perfectioning of the faculties, cultivates six or seven knowledges.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śaikṣasyendriyottāpanāyāṃ vimuktimārge sarāgasya ṣaṇṇāṃ bhāvanā dharmānvayaduḥkhasamudayanirodhamārgajñānānāṃ vitarāgasya saptānāṃ paracittajñānaṃ prakṣipya /
column2: The Śaikṣa in opposition to the Aśaikṣa who enters the state of Immovability in the path of deliverance of the perfectioning of his faculties, cultivates six knowledges when he is not detached. When he is detached, he cultivates seven knowledges, the knowledge of the mind of another being the seventh.
Some other masters say that conventional knowledge is cultivated by one who is not detached as well as by one who is detached.
In the preparatory path, both of them cultivate this knowledge.
In the uninterrupted path, he cultivates six knowledges.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vītarāgasyāvītarāgasya vā śaikṣasyendriyottāpanāyāmānantaryamārge ṣaṇṇāṃ bhāvanā pūrvavat /
column2: Detached or non-detached, he cultivates six knowledges, as above, in the uninterrupted path of the perfectioning of his faculties.
He does not cultivate conventional knowledge, because the perfectioning of the faculties resembles the Path of Seeing;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na paracittajñānasya / sarvānantaryamārga pratipiddhatvāt / kimartha pratipidhyate /
column2: he does not cultivate the knowledge of the mind of another.
because this knowledge is absent from the uninterrupted path: in fact this knowledge does not oppose the defilements.
The same in the victory over Bhavāgra.
In the uninterrupted paths of detachment from Bhavāgra, the Śaikṣa cultivates six knowledges.
At the moment of the knowledge of destruction, nine knowledges.
The ninth path of deliverance of detachment from Bhavāgra is called the Knowledge of Destruction.
The ascetic then cultivates nine knowledges, with the exception of the Knowledge of Non-Arising.
An Immovable One cultivates ten knowledges.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yastvakopyadharmā bhavati tasya daśānāṃ jñānānāṃ bhāvanā / anutpādajñānalābhāt / tatsaṃcare 'ntyamuktau ca
column2: The saint who is from the beginning an Immovable One cultivates ten knowledges at the moment when he produces the Knowledge of Destruction, for at this moment he obtains the Knowledge of Non-Arising.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'pyakopyatāṃ saṃcarati tasyāpyantye vimuktimārge daśānāṃ bhāvanā /
column2: Ten knowledges also in the last deliverance in the passage to the state of Immovability. The ascetic who obtains the state of Immovability through the perfectioning of his faculties also cultivates ten knowledges.
In the cases not mentioned, there is cultivation of eight knowledges.
What are the cases not mentioned?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmavairāgye navamo vimuktimārgaḥ saptabhūmivairāgyābhijñāvyavakīrṇabhāviteṣu vimuktimārgaḥ akopyaprativedho 'ṣṭau vimuktimārgāḥ sarve ca vītarāgasya prayogaviśeṣamārgāḥ /
column2: The paths of deliverence from detachment to the seven spheres, to the five sipernormal knowledges, to mixed meditation of the Śaikṣa. The preparatory path and the excellent path of one who is detached.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣu sarveṣvaṣṭau jñānāni bhāvyante / anāgatabhāvanayā kṣayānutpādajñāne hitvā /
column2: In all these paths, there is cultivation of eight future knowledges, with the exception of the Knowledge of Destruction and the Knowledge of Non-Arising.
This is the case for the Śaikṣa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aśaikṣasya punarabhijñādiprayogavimuktaviśeṣamārgeṣu nava jñānāni daśa vā /
column2: The Aśaikṣa, in the preparatory path, the path of deliverance, and the excellent path of the five supernormal knowledges and of mixed meditation, cultivates nine knowledges (with the exception).

In the uninterrupted paths of the sameʼ, he cultivates either eight or nine knowledges, with the exception of the knowledge of the mind of another in both cases. Nevertheless, in the path of deliverance of the two supernormal knowledges which are neutral, there is no cultivation of any future knowledge.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pṛthagjanasya tu kāmatridhyānavairāgyāntyavimuktimārgeṣu dhyānabhūmikeṣu ca prayogābhijñātrayavimuktimārgāpramāṇādiguṇābhinirhāreṣu saṃvṛtijñānamanāgataṃ bhāvyate paracittajñānaṃ cānyatra nirvedhabhāgīyebhyaḥ / teṣu hi paracittajñānaṃ na bhāvyate /
column2: As for the Prṛthagjana, in the ninth path of deliverance of detachment from Kāmadhātu and the three Dhyānas;
in the preparatory paths; in the paths of deliverance of the three supernormal knowledges;

in the realizations of the spiritual qualities, Apramāṇas, Vimokṣas, etc. : all these paths being cultivated in the Dhyānas, he cultivates, in the future, conventional knowledge and the knowledge of the mind of another; but not in the nirvedhabhāgīāyas.
To which sphere does the knowledge belong which is cultivated in the worldly and transworldly paths?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃvṛtijñānaṃ tāvadyadbhūmiko mārgo yāṃ ca prathamato bhūmi labhate tadbhūmikamanāgataṃ bhāvyate /
column2: A knowledge of the mind of another, a future cultivation, belongs to the sphere which serves as the support of the Path, or rather to the sphere which one obtains through the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravaṃ tu na kevalaṃ yadbhūmiko mārgaḥ / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: It is not a rule that pure knowledge, cultivated in the future, will belong to the sphere which serves as the support for its arising.
The knowledge that one cultivates in the future belongs to the sphere from which one is detached, to the sphere acquired, or to a lower sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadbhūmivairāgyāyāpi hi dvividho 'pi mārgo bhavati prayogamārgādiḥ yāṃ ca bhūmi labhate vairāgyatastdbhūmikānyadhobhūmikāni cānāsravāṇi jñānāni bhāvanāṃ gacchanti /
column2: When, in order to become detached from one sphere an ascetic cultivates the paths of the two classes, pure or impure, he cultivates pure knowledges which are either of the sphere which he obtains for the first time by these paths, of the.
In the knowledge of destruction, the pure is also of all spheres.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣayajñāne tu sarvabhūmikāḥ sāsravā api guṇāḥ kṣayajñānalābhikā bhāvanāṃ gacchanti a4ubhānāpānasmṛtismṛtyupasthānāpramāṇavimokṣādayaḥ rajjucchedāducchvasantīva peḍāsādharmyeṇa /
column2: At the moment when a knowledge of the destruction of the cankers arises, there is cultivated the qualities of all the spheres, including the impure ones, namely the Apramanas, the Vimoksas, etc. In fact, Vajropamasamadhi cuts off these ties which are the possessions of the defilements; all the qualities will be found in a series freed from the defilements; one can thus say that they "breathe", in the manner of a sack when one cuts the ropes that bind it.
The Arhat has obtained rule over his mind: all the good dharmas come towards him, as vassals come to present their homage to a prince who accedes to supreme kingship.
Is everything that has been previously obtained also cultivated?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadapūrva labhyate tat bhāvyate / labdhapūrva na bhāvyate //
column2: That which has been obtained previously is not cultivated. What is cultivated is what has not been obtained.
That which, having been obtained and lost is obtained anew—that is to say, is.
Because this has been acquired and rejected in the past.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ khalu pratilambha eva bhāvanā netyucyate /
column2: Does the term "cultivation" only designate acquisition?
Cultivation is of four types: 1. acquisition, 2.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pratilambhabhāvanā niṣevaṇabhāvanā pratipakṣabhāvanā vinirdhāvanabhāvanā ca / tatra
column2: practice, 3. opposition, and 4. expulsion.
Cultivation of good conditioned dharmas is acquisition and practice;
there is cultivation of opposition and expulsion with respect to impure dharmas.

There is cultivation of acquisition and practice with respect to the good conditioned dharmas, acquisition with respect to the future and acquisition and practice with respect to the present. These two cultivations rest on the first two efforts, effort for the arising of what has not yet arisen, and effort for the growth of what has already arisen.
There is cultivation of opposition and expulsion with respect to impure dharmas; they rest on the last two efforts, effort for the non-arising of what has not arisen, and effort for the.
Thus the good but impure dharmas are susceptible of four types of cultivation;
the pure dharmas are susceptible of the first two; the defiled and neutral dharmas of the last two.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bāhyābhidharmikāṇāṃ ṣaṭ bhāvnāḥ / etāścatasraḥ saṃvarabhāvanā vibhāvana ca /
column2: The Vaibhāsikas of the West say that there are six types of cultivation: four as above, plus the cultivation of constraint, and the cultivation of inspection.
The first is the cultivation of the organs, the eye, etc. ;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “ṣaḍigānīndriyāṇi sudāntāni yāvatsubhāvitāni tathā santyasminkāye kleśā” iti vistaraḥ /
column2: the second is the cultivation of the body, as it says in the Sūtra, “These six organs well subdued, well guarded. ” and, "There is in the body the beard, hair, etc. "
The Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmīr however think that these two cultivations should be included within the cultivation of opposition and expulsion. We have explained the knowledges.

Now we must explain the spiritual qualities, which are made up of the knowledges. Among these qualities, there are first those which are uniquely proper to the Buddha, which the Bodhisattva acquires at the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭādaśāveṇikāstu buddhadharmā balādayaḥ / ye buddhasyaiva bhagavataḥ kṣayajñāne bhāvanāṃ gacchanti nānyasya / katame 'ṣṭādaśa /
column2: These qualities are eighteen in number.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśa balāni catvāri vaiśāradyāni trīṇi smṛtyupasthānāni mahākaruṇā ca /
column2: The dharmas unique to the Buddha are eighteen, the powers, etc. The ten powers, the four absences of fear, the three foundations of mindfulness, and great compassion constitute the eighteen dharmas unique to the Buddha. We shall examine first the nature of the powers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asādhāraṇaṃ hyāveṇikamityucyate / tatra sthānāsthāne daśa jñānāni
column2: There are ten knowledges in sthānāsthāna.
The power which consists of the knowledge of what is possible and what is impossible is made up of ten knowledges.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṣṭau karmaphale kamavipākajñānabalamaṣṭī jñānāni / nirodhamārgajñāne hitvā / nava //
column2: The power which consists of the knowledge of the retribution of actions is made up of eight knowledges.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānādyakṣādhhimokṣeṣu dhātau ca dhyānavimokṣasamādhisamāpattijñānabalaṃ nava jñānāni / nirodha jñānaṃ hitvā /
column2: The power of the knowledge of the Dhyānas, Vimokṣas, Samādhis and Samāpattis;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamindriyaparāparajñāna balaṃ nānādhimuktijñānabalaṃ nānādhātujñānabalaṃ veditavyam / pratipatsu tu / daśa vā
column2: the power of the knowledge of the degree of the moral faculties of beings; the power of the knowledge of the different aspirations of beings;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nava veti matavikalpā 'rtho vāśabdaḥ / yadi saphalā pratipat gṛhyate /
column2: and the power of the knowledge of the different acquired dispositions of beings—these four powers are made up of nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of extinction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvatragāminī pratipajjñānabalaṃ daśa jñānāni / na cennava /
column2: The power of the knowledge of the paths which lead to the different realms of rebirth and to Nirvāṇa, is made up of either nine knowledges or ten knowledges.

If one understands “the Path with its result,” this power then includes the knowledge of extinction; but if one understands “the Path without its result,” then this power is made up of nine knowledges.
The power of the knowledge of former abodes and the power.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ṣaṭ daśa vā kṣaye // āsravakṣayajñānabalaṃ saḍ jñānāni dharmānvayanirodhakṣayānutpādasaṃvṛtijñānāniṃ /
column2: The power of the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is made up of six or ten knowledges.

One can consider the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers in and of itself as the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers which is made up of the knowledge of the dharmas, inferential knowledge, the knowledge of extinction, the Knowledge of Destruction, the Knowledge of Non-Arising, and conventional knowledge;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kṣīṇasravasaṃtāne jñānamāsravakṣayajñānaṃ tato daśa jñānāni / uktaḥ svabhāvo bhūmiridānīmucyate /
column2: or one can understand the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers as the knowledge which is produced in a series where the cankers have been expelled: the ten knowledges exist in such a series.
As for the spheres which serve as the support for the powers:
The power of former abodes and the power of death-rebirth lie in the Dhyānas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣitam / sarvabhūmiṣu śeṣaṃ balaṃ sarvabhūmisaṃgṛhītam / tāḥ punarekādaśa /
column2: the others in all the spheres.
The knowledge of former abodes and the knowledge of the death and rebirth of beings have the Dhyānas for their spheres;
They arise in a male body in Jambudvīpa, that is to say in the Buddha, for Buddhas do not appear outside of Jambudvīpa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyatra duddhānutpādāt / tadetaddaśavidhaṃ jñānamanyasya balaṃ nocyate / buddhasyaiva balamiti /
column2: In others this tenfold knowledge is not called a power: it is only in the series of the Buddha that it is called a power, because, elsewhere, it is shackled. Why?
Because its power does not know any obstacle.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmādasya sarvatra jñeye jñānabhavyāhataṃ vartate tasmādvalam / aneṣāṃ tu vyāhanyate /
column2: The knowledge which knows all the objects of knowledge without any obstacle is called a power. This is why the ten powers exist only in the Buddha, because the Buddha, having expelled all the cankers and all the traces of ignorance, knows all objects of his own accord.
It is not the same for the knowledges of others, and as a consequence these knowledges are not called powers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sthaviraśāriputreṇa pravrajyāpekṣapuruṣapratyākhyānaṃ śyenopadrutasya pakṣiṇa upapattyādīparyantājñānaṃ cātrodāharaṇam /
column2: According to tradition, Śāriputra refused a person who asked for admission to the Order; he was not capable of seeing the number of the previous and subsequent births of a pigeon chased.
The Buddha’s knowledge is exercised without obstacle, the power of his mind is infinite and envelopes all objects. If such is the power of his mind, what is the power of his body?
Nārāyaṇa power in his body. Nārāyaṇa is the name of a power and also the name of one who possesses this power, namely the god Nārāyaṇa: the same for Cāṇūra and Mahānagna.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāye punarbuddhasya nārāyaṇaṃ balaṃ varṇayati saṃdhiṣvanye sandhau sandhau nārāyaṇabalamityapare /
column2: The power of the body of the Buddha is equal to that of Nārāyaṇa. According to others, in his parts; According to others, each part of his body possesses this power.
The Bhadanta says that his physical power is like his mental power, that is, infinite;
for, if it were otherwise, the body of the Blessed One would not be able to support infinite knowledge.
The Buddhas have nzgāgranthi power in their body parts. Pratyekabuddhas have śaṁkalā power, and Cakravartins have śaṅṇku power.

What is the extent of Nārāyaṇa power? This is a power the seventh term of a series which begins with the elephant and in which each term is worth ten times the preceding. There is a series: prākrtahastin, gandhahastin, mahānagna, praskandin, varāṅga, cāṇūra, and nārāyaṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśādhikam / hastyādisaptakabalam yaddaśānāṃ prākṛtahastināṃ balaṃ tadekasya gandhahastinaḥ / evaṃ mahānagnapraskandivarāṅgacānūranārāyaṇānāṃ daśottaravṛddhirvattavyā /
column2: The power of each term is worth ten times the power of the preceding term: ten prākṛtahastins make one gandhahastin and so on. According to others, this is the case for the first six terms;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prākṛtagandhahastimahānagnapraskandināṃ daśāttaravṛddhacyārdhanārāyaṇaṃ balaṃ tat dviguṇaṃ nārāyaṇa mityapare /
column2: but ten cāṇārar are equal to a half-ṉārāyaṇa, and two half-nārāyaṇas are equal to one nārāyaṇa.
According to the author of this book, among the definitions of the physical power of the Buddha, that one is true which makes this power the greatest.
It consists of a tangible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taccatatkāyikaṃ balaṃ sarvasyaiva spraṣṭavyāyatanasvabhāvaṃ mahābhūtaviśeṣa eva / upādāyarūpaṃ saptabhyo 'rthāntaramityapare / uktāni valāni / vaiśāradhyaṃ caturdhā tu
column2: The physical power of the Buddha is, by its nature, a tangible. It consists of primary elements of a special nature. According to others, however, it is a r%pa derived from the.
As for the four assurances, Assurance is fourfold The Buddha possesses four assurances which are explained in the Sūtra.
Resembling the first, the tenth, the second, and the seventh power.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā sthānāsthānajñānabalamevaṃ samyaksaṃbuddhasya vata me sate ityetadvaiśāradyaṃ veditavyam /
column2: The first assurance, the assurance that he has attained supreme comprehension with respect to all the dharmas, resembles the first power (the power of the knowledge of what is possible and what is impossible); it consists of ten knowledges, and can exist in all of the spheres.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathāsravakṣayajñānabalamevaṃ kṣīṇāsravasya vata me sata ityetadvaiśāradyam /
column2: The second assurance, the assurance that he has the knowledge of the destruction of all the defilements, resembles the tenth power, the power of the knowledge of the destruction of the defilements: it consists of ten knowledges, and can exist in six spheres.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā karmasvakajñānavalamevaṃ ye vā punarmayā śrāvakāṇāmantarāyikā dharmā ādhyātā ityetadvaiśāradyam /
column2: The third assurance, the assurance that he can fully explain the dharmas, resembles the second power, the power of the knowledge of the retribution of actions: it consists of eight.
