prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sati hi rupe svaṃ rūpamavaśyaṃ saṃjānīranniti /
column2: Our opponent answers that the Sūtra, in these different passages, intends to speak not of physical matter in general, but of gross physical matter of a lower sphere.
We answer that, in this hypothesis, one should understand in the same sense the text relative to material food, which would exist, albeit subtly, in Rāpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānānāmapi cādhobhūminiḥsaraṇatvādārupya prasaṅgaḥ / vedanādiniḥsaraṇaṃ ca kiṃ noktāḥ / adhobhūmikavedanāniḥsaraṇāt /
column2: One should say that an ascetic leaves the rāpas through the Dhyāṇnas, and that the Dhyāṇnas belong to Ārūpyadhātu, for the Dhyānas are beyond the coarse rāpas of a lower sphere, namely Kāmadhātu.
One should say that, through the Ārūpyas, the ascetic leaves sensation. But the Sutra does not express itself in this way. We then assume that the Arupyas are beyond any and all physical matter.
How can the Arupyas be the 'leaving” of the rupas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavena bhavasyāniḥsaraṇavacanaṃ tu tenaiva tasyāniḥsaraṇādasarvānatyanta niḥsaraṇācca /
column2: The Blessed One, in fact, denies that existence can be the leaving of existence: “I say that one cannot leave bhava through ohava.” The Blessed One expresses himself in this manner with reason, for one cannot leave a certain existence by means of this same existence, and one can neither leave all of the existences nor definitively leave any existence by means of any existence whatsoever.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānesu coktaṃ bhagavatā “yattatra bhavati rūpagataṃ vā yāvadvijñānagataṃ veti / ārupyeṣu tūktaṃ “yattatra bhavati vedanāgataṃ vā yāvadvijñānagataṃ ve“ti /
column2: Finally the Blessed One says that there is rapa, vedana, samrjna, the samskaras, and vijnana in the Dhyanas, and that there is vedana and vijnana in the Arupyas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satyāṃ tesu rūpajātau kasmādrūpagataṃ veti nāvakṣyat /
column2: If there were truly pa in the Arupyas, why did not the Blessed One say that there is repa in them, as he did for the Dhyanas?
Hence, there is no physical matter in Ārūpyadhātu. If this is the case, then when a being obtains an existence in Ārūpyadhātu, his series of physical matter is cut off for numerous cosmic periods.
When this being is finally reborn in a lower sphere, where does his physical matter come from?

Physical matter arises from the mind. A cause was formerly produced—a certain action, etc. ,. —-which should ripen in physical matter; a trace of this cause remains in the mind: its efficacy now matures;
the physical matter that now arises arises from the mind.
But how can a mind in Ārūpyadhātu exist without being supported by physical matter, rāpa?
Why could it not exist without physical matter?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ihaivamadarśanāt / kavaḍīkārāntareṇā 'pi vinā rūpadhātau na vartitavyam /
column2: Because it never happens here below that a mind exists without a body.
But, by virtue of this same reasoning, you should deny that. beings in Rūpadhātu live on material food.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ ca pūrvaṃ yathā vartate / gatametadidaṃ vaktavyam /
column2: Moreover we have already explained how a mind in Ārūpyadhātu has as its support.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kimepāmākāśānantyāyatanādīnāmākāśādaya evālambanaṃ yata evaṃ samākhyāyate / na hi / kathaṃ tarhi /
column2: Do the Ārūpyas receive their different names,—Ākāśānantyāyatana, etc. ,. -from the fact that they have space etc. , for their objects?
The first three, Ākāśānantya, Vijñānānantya, and Ākiṁcanya are named after their preparatory exercises.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anantamākāśamanantaṃ vijñānaṃ nāsti kiñcidityeva manasikurvāṇasteṣu prayujyante yathāsaṃkhyam /
column2: The three lower Ārūpyas receive their names from the fact that, in their preparatory exercises, one considers space, etc. Because of its weakness, the absorption is called Neither-Ideas-Nor-Absence of Ideas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eṣāmetāḥ saṃjñā iti / māndyāktu nasaṃjñanāpyasaṃjñakaḥ // mṛdutvāttu saṃjñāyā naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatanamuktam /
column2: The Fourth Ārūpya receives its name from the fact that saṁjñā, "ideas," is very weak in it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi sā paṭvī saṃjñā na ca punarnaiva saṃjñeti / “yadyapi tatrāpyevaṃ prayujyante saṃjñārogaḥ saṃjñāgaṇdaḥ saṃjñāśalyaḥ āsaṃjñikasaṃmohaḥ etacchāntametatpraṇītaṃ yaduta naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatanamiti
column2: Ideas are not active in it, but neither is it completely without ideas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kasmāttu taistadevaṃ gṛhyata ityavaśyamidaṃ vaktavyaṃ jāyate /
column2: Without doubt, one prepares himself for this Ārūpya by considering, "Ideas are a sickness! Ideas are an ulcer! Ideas are an arrow!

The absence of ideas is stupidity! This is calmness, this is excellent, the Faculty of Neither-Ideas-Nor-Absence of Ideas! But it is not byIt is because of the slightness of the ideas in it. This is the explanation of its name.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ityetānyaṣṭau maulāni samāpattidravyāṇi yaduta catvāri dhyānāni catvāra ārupyā iti /
column2: There are then eight things that are basic absorptions; The Four Dhyānas and the Four Ārūpyas are the eight basic absorptions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ punaḥ tridhā / sapta bhavāgrādanyāni sapta trividhāni /
column2: The first seven of these eight are threefold.
They are associated with enjoyment, are pure, and are free from the defilements.
The eighth is twofold.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavāgramāsvādanāsaṃprayuktaṃ śuddhakaṃ ca / anāsrava nāsti / tatra punaḥ āsvādanāsaṃprayuktaṃ satṛṣṇaṃ
column2: Bhavāgra is associated with enjoyment and is pure, but it is not free from the defilements.
The absorption of enjoyment is associated with thirst;
(a pure absorption is of a worldly order of good; it is the object of enjoyment of the first; the absorption free from the defilements is transworldly. For enjoyment is itself thirst.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: laukikaṃ kuśalaṃ samāpattidravyaṃ śuddhakamuccayate 'lobhādi śuddhadharmayogāt / kiṃ punastenāsvādanāsaṃprayuktenāsvādyate / tattadāsvādyaṃ tacchuddhakaṃ samāpattidravyaṃ tenāsvādyate samanantarātītam /
column2: Worldly good is also termed ‘‘good,” because it arises in conjunction with the pure dharmas, such as non-desire, etc. It is the object of enjoyment. Pure absorption is the object enjoyed by the absorption of enjoyment.
As soon as the pure absorption disappears, the absorption of enjoyment that enjoys it arises.
The absorption free from the defilements is transworldly.
The absorption free from the defilements is transworldly.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣāṃ ca samāpattidravyāṇāṃ dhyānānyeva bhavanti nārupyāḥ /
column2: The Dhyānas are filled with parts or items, but not the Ārūpyas.
How many parts are there in each Dhyāna?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathame bhāge pañcāṅgāni / tarkacārau ca prītisaukhyasamādhayaḥ / vitarko vicāraḥ prītiḥ sukhaṃ cittaikāgratā cetyetāni pañcāṅgāni samādhiḥ kilāṅgaṃ dhyānaṃ ca /
column2: There are five parts in the First: (viśarka, vicāra, joy, happiness, and samādhi; four in the Secoṇd:The teaching of the School is that samādhi or concentration is at one and the same time both Dhyāna and a part of this Dhyāna, whereas the other parts are only parts of Dhyāna, but not Dhyāna itself.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śeṣāṇyaṅgānīti / yathā caturaṅgā senā evaṃ pañcāṅgaṃ dhyānam / prītyādayaḥ prasādaśca dvitīye 'ṅgacatuṣṭayam //
column2: But in our opinion, it is the same for the five-part Dhyāna as for a four-part aṛṟmy, which does not exist apart from its parts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dvitīye dhyāne catvāryaṅgāni / adhyātmasaṃprasādaḥ prītiḥ sukhaṃ cittekāgratā ca / tṛtīye pañca tūpekṣā smṛtiḥ prajñā sukhaṃ sthitiḥ /
column2: The Second Dhyāna contains fout parts: joy, happiness, concentration of the mind on a single object, and internal purity of faith.
The Third Dhyāna possesses five parts: 1) equanimity (not vedanopekṣa, the sensation of indifference, but sa/ṁskāropekṣa). joy which is free from movement towards any object;
2) mindfulness (that is, not losing sight of the motive or reason for this equanimity); 3) samprajnanam (consciousness or awareness relating to this mindfulness); 4) happiness;
and 5) samadhi: sthiti or stability is a synonym for samadhi, as the Sutra says, "What is right samadhi?
It is stability of the mind.

And four in the last: mindfulness, equanimity, the sensation of neither suffering nor happiness, and samadhi.
caturthaṃ dhyānamantyam / tatra catvāryaṅgāni / aduḥkhāsukhā vedanā upekṣāpariśuddhiḥ smṛtipariśuddhiḥ samādhiśca /	The Fourth Dhyana possesses four parts: 1) the sensation of indifference, 2) pure equanimity, 3) pure mindfulness, and 4) samadhi.
tānyetānyaṣṭādaśa dhyānāṅgāni bhavanti / prathamatṛtīyayoḥ pañcāṅgatvāt / dvitīyacaturthayoścaturaṅgatvāt /	These are the eighteen parts of the Dhyanas: the First and the Third Dhyanas have five parts each, and the Second and the Fourth Dhyanas have four parts each.
nāmata evam /	In respect to their names, there are eighteen parts. But how many of these eighteen are distinct things?
dravyato daśa caikaṃ ca	Regarded as things, there are eleven parts.
dravyata etānyekādaśa bhavanti /	Regarded as things or substances, there are eleven.
prāthamadhyānikāni pañca / dvitīye 'dhyātmasaṃprasādo vardhate /	There are five in the First Dhyāṇna, plus internal purity or faith in the Second Dhyāna;
tṛtīye upekṣāsmṛtisaṃprajñānasukhāni /	equanimity, mindfulness, awareness and happiness in the Third Dhyāna;
caturthe 'duḥkhāsukhā vedaneti /	and the sensation of neither suffering nor happiness in the Fourth Dhyāna.
ata evocyate yānyaṅgāni prathame dhyāne dvitīye 'pi tānīti catuṣkoṭikam /	There are then some parts of the First Dhyāṇna that are not parts of the Second Dhyāna.
prathamā koṭirvitarkavicārau /	There are four alternatives: parts of the First Dhyāṇna that are not parts of the Second Dhyāna, namely vikarka aṅd vicāra;
dvitīyā adhyātmasaṃprasādaḥ /	part of the Secoṇd Dhyāna that is not part of the First Dhyāna, namely faith;
tṛtīyā prītiḥ sukhaṃ cittaikāgratā ca / caturthī koṭiruktanirmuktā dharmā iti /	parts common to the First and the Second Dhyāṇas, namely joy, happiness, and concentration of the mind on a single object; and parts that do not belong to either of the First or the Second Dhyāṅas, namely all of the other parts.
evaṃ sarvāṇi dhyānāṅgāni parasparaṃ yojyāni /	The correspondence of the parts of the other Dhyāṇnas is established according to the same principles. Why do you say that the happiness of the Third Dhyāna constitutes a separate thing?
kasmāt / tṛtīye dhyāne sukhaṃ dravyāntaramucyate /	Because the happiness of the Third Dhyāna is agreeable.
yasmāttadvedanāsukhaṃ dhyānayostu	In the first two Dhyānas, happiness signifies well-being.
prasrabdhisukhamādyayoḥ / prathamadvitīyayostu dhyānayoḥ prasrabdhisukhamityuktam /	In the First and Second Dhyāna, prasrabdhi is called happiness: here we have prasrabdhisukha, happiness which consists of prasrabdhi.
iha prasrabdhisukhaṃ tatra vedanāsukhamiti kuta etat /	In the Third Dhyāna, there is only the sensation of happiness.
dvayordhyānasamāpattyoḥ sukhendriyāyogāt /	In fact, in the first two Dhyānas, there can be no faculty of happiness.
na hi tattayoḥ kāyikaṃ yujyate / samāpannasya vijñānakāyābhāvāt /	The reason for this is: the happiness attributed to these Dhyānas cannot be bodily happiness, in light of the fact that the five sense consciousnesses are absent in a person who has entered into contemplation;
nāpi caitasikaṃ prītivacanāt /	the happiness attributed to these Dhyānas cannot be mental happiness because these Dhyānas possess joy.
prītirhi saumanasyam / na ca sukhasaumanasyayoryaugapadyamasti /	Now joy is “satisfaction” and it is inadmissible for joy and happiness, even happiness of sensation, to coexist;
na cāpi tayoḥ paryāyeṇa dhyāne vṛttiryuktā pañcāṅgavacanāditi / apare punarāhuḥ /	they cannot even succeed one another, for the First Dhyūna possesses five parts, and the Second, only four.
nāstyeva caitasikaṃ sukhendriyaṃ triṣvapi hi dhyāneṣu /	In the first three Dhyānas, there is no mental sensation of.
kāyikameva sukhamaṅgaṃ vyavasthāpitamiti /	Happiness, but only a bodily sensation of happiness, which constitutes the part called “happiness” of these Dhyāṇas.
yattarhi sutra uktaṃ “sukhendriyaṃ katamat /	Objection: In this hypothesis you should explain how the Sūtra could say, “What is the faculty of happiness?
yatsukhavedanīyena sparśena spṛṣṭasyotpadyate kāyikaṃ caitasikaṃ sātaṃ veditaṃ vedanāgatamidamucyate sukhendriyami“ti / adhyāropita eṣa pāṭhaḥ /	The bodily and mental sensation of happiness produced by reason of an agreeable contact is what is called the faculty of happiness. ” This reasoning is not authentic, answer the Dūrṣṭāntikas, as the word “mental” has been added.
kenāpi sarvanikāyāntareṣu kāyikamityeva pāṭhāt /	In all the sects the text merely reads “bodily happiness. ” Further, they continue, regarding the part of the Third Dhyāna called happiness, the Sūtra says in its own words that, in this Dhyāna the ascetic “experiences happiness through his body”.
“sukhaṃ ca kāyena pratisaṃvedayata” iti svaśabdena vacanācca / manaskāyeneticet / evamuktvā ko guṇaḥ /	Would one maintain that the word through the body” signifies “through the body of the mind”, and that one should translate, “the ascetic experiences happiness through this complex which is”.
The well-being of the Fourth Dhyāṇna is certainly greater than the well-being of the first two Dhyānas, and the Sūtra does not attribute a happiness part to the Fourth Dhyāna.

The well-being of the first two Dhyānas is called happiness because it is favorable to the sensation of happiness, whereas the well-being of the Fourth Dhyāna does not have this character, "The well-being of the Third Dhyāna, like that of the first two, is favorable to the sensation of happiness;
why do the Vaibhāṣikas not attṛibute prasrabdhisukha, happiness which consists of well-being, to the Third Dhyāna, but rather a happiness consisting of an agreeable mental sensation?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upekṣopahatatvāditi cet / na upekṣayaiva tadvṛddhiḥ / pūrvikābhyastādviśeṣāt /
column2: In the Third Dhyāna, well-being whose character is karmaṇyatā or aptitude is opposed by equanimity, whose character is akarmaṇyatā," for them well-being is accumulated through equanimity, since it results from.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “yasminsamaye āryaśrāvakaḥ pravivekajāṃ prītiṃ kāyena sākṣātkṛtvopasaṃpadya viharatī“tyatra sūtre prasrabdhisukhayoḥ pṛthagvacanānna prasrabdhireva sukham /
column2: Finally, the Śūtra says, "When the Noble Śrāvaka, having realized the joy born of separation, abides in absorption, then five dharmas have been abandoned by him, and he has achieved the cultivation of five dharmas, namely joy, well-being, happiness, prajñā, and samādhi. " In this Sūtra, well-being is listed separately from happiness; it should be distinct from happiness in order for the list of the five dbarmas to be complete. Thus, in the first two Dhyānas, happiness is not well-being.
iii. In order for the happiness of the first two Dhyānas to be agreeable bodily sensation, it is necessaty for the person in absorption to produce a consciousness of touch. Anṇd this is not possible.

In the state of absoṟrption, the body is penetrated by a wind born of excellent mental concentration; this wind is a tangible which is agreeably felt and is called well-being. Hence there is produced a consciousness of touch.
When this consciousness is produced, there is "a distraction of the mind towards an external object": hence the ascetic would fall away from his samādhi.
No, for agreeable or happy bodily sensation which arises from samādhi, being internal, is favorable to samādhi.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyavijñā nakāle vyutthitaḥ syāditi cet /  na / ata eva /
column2: But would the ascetic fall away from the samādhi when he produces the consciousness of touch? No, and for this same reason: this consciousness is favorable to samādhi. Immediately after the appearance of this consciousness, the samādhi is taken up again.
How can the body, which is in Kāmadhātu, give rise to a touch consciousness, which is, according to you, a type of wind in Rūpadhātu?
This criticism does not hold, for this consciousness of touch is produced by reason of well-being. There is a difficulty in regarding well-being as a tangible.
Let us suppose that the ascetic is in possession of transworldly, undefiled Dhyāna: the tangible and the.
consciousness of touch which he has will be undefiled, for some of the parts of defiled Dhyāna cannot be undefiled, while the others are defiled. There is no contradiction here.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyikaprasrabdhivodhyaṅga vacanāt / iṣṭe bodhyaṅgānukūlatvāditi cet / anāsravatvamapyevam / “sāsravā dharmāḥ katame / cakṣuryāvadeva spraṣṭavyami“tyasya sūtrasya virodhāditi cet /  na /
column2: In fact physical well-being is defined as “a part of Bodhi. ” If the Vaibhāṣikas answer, “Even though it is not a part of Bodhi, it is so defined because it is favorable to the part of Bodhi called well-being and which is mental well-being,” we would say that, for the same reason, one can consider bodily well-being as undefiled.

“Bodily well-being cannot be undefiled, for the Sūtra declares that all tangible things are defiled,” we would say that this Sūtra is of intentional meaning and refers to all tangible things with the exception of physical well-being, to the consciousnesses of touch with the exception of the consciousness of touch which cognizes well-being.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cānāsrave kiñcidaṅgaṃ sāsravaṃ kicidanāsravaṃ syāditi cet /
column2: Do you admit that certain parts of undefiled ḍhyāna are undefiled, and that certain parts are not? The undefiled part is not simultaneous to the non-undefiled part; we know indeed that happiness does not exist at the same time as joy.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ayaugapadyātko doṣaḥ sukhaprītyasamavadhānānna pañcāṅgaṃ syāditi cet /
column2: Then the First Dhyāna will not have five parts, and the Second Dhyāna will not have four parts. If Scripture attributes the parts of happpiness and joy to the fitst two Dhyānas, this is because these Dhyānas are susceptible, successively, to happiness and joy; in the same way Scripture attributes v and icāra—which can only exist successively—to the First Dhyāna. We affirm that vitarka and vicāra coexist;
but the example that you cite to prove the non-coexistence of the parts is not proved.
This example is proved;
for vitarka, which is a coarse mental state, and vcāra, which is a subtle mental state, are contradictory and cannot coexist. And you did not say what harm there is in their not coexisting.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmādyānyeva prathamadhyāne pañcāṅgāni teṣāṃ dvitricaturaṅgāpakarṣeṇa dvitīyādidhyānavyavasthānam / ata eva ca prathame dhyāne pañcānāmaṅgatvamuktam /
column2: Let us consider the theory of the “parts”: one determines the specific features of the Second Dhyāna and of those following byIt is for this reason that the First Dhyāna is said to contain five parts, because the other Dhyānas are defined by the elimination, successively and in order, of the first four of these parts.

This is why ideas and the other dharmas of the First Dhyāna are not considered as parts, for they are not cut off in the following Dhyānas. If you do not accept this explanation, then why does the First Dhyāna have only five parts?
But, the five parts are only called parts because they are useful to the Dhyāna.
No, this cannot be the case, since mindfulness and prajñā are more useful to the Dhyāna than are vétarka and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: astyeṣa ekeṣāṃ vādaḥ / naiva tu pūrvācāryā evaṃ nirdiśanti sma yāvantaḥ prajñāntam /
column2: A certain school maintains the system that has been presented, but the ancient masters are not in agreement on this.
Consequently the point should be further examined.
What is the dharma called “internal purity”?
When the agitation of vitarka and vicāra has come to an end, the series flows calmly and clearly: this is what is called internal.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sormikeva hi nadī vitarkavicārakṣobhitā saṃtatir aprasannā vartate iti /
column2: As a river agitated by waves, so too the series, by reason of the agitation of vitarka and vicāra, is not calm or clear.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na tarhi sa dravyāntaram iti kathaṃ dravyata ekādaśāṅgāni bhavanti /
column2: But if we admit this explanation, then internal purity is not a thing in and of itself. Thus there will not be eleven things in the Dhyānas.
Then one must say Purity is faith. Purity is a thing in and of itself, namely faith.
When the ascetic acquires the Second Dhyāna, he produces a profound faith: he admits that the spheres of absorption themselves can be abandoned.

This faith is called internal purity. Faith, having purity for its characteristic, is called purity. Having abandoned externals, it flows equally and so pr@sāda is internal and equal; hence it is termed “internal purity”’ or adhyātmasaṁprasāda.
According to other masters, vitarka, vicāra, samādhi, and internal purity are not separate things.
If these are not separate things, how can one say that they are mental dharmas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avasthāviseso hi nāma cetasaścetasiko bhavati / natveṣa śastrasiddhāntaḥ /
column2: Some special states of mind receive the.
You have said that joy is satisfaction, a happy or agreeable mental sensation.
How would you establish this definition?
If joy is not satisfaction, then what is the dharma that is called joy?
According to this school, there exists a dharma distinct from satisfaction, a mental state called joy.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saumanasyaṃ tu triṣvapi dhyāneṣu sukhamiti / yathecchanti nikāyāntarīyāḥ dharmāntarameva caitasikaṃ prītiḥ saumanasyaṃ tu triṣvapi dhyānesu sukhamiti /
column2: The happiness of the three Dhyānas is satisfaction; hence joy, which is distinguished from happiness, is distinct from satisfaction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na vai sukhaṃ dhyāneṣu saumanasyaṃ yujyate /
column2: It is not admissible that happiness, in the Dhyāṇnas, is satisfaction.
Joy is satisfaction. This is proved by two texts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ hi bhagavatā aviparītakasūtre tṛtīyaṃ dhyānamuktvā “atrāsyotpannaṃ saumanasyendriyamapariśeṣaṃ nirudhyata iti /
column2: The Blessed One says in the Viparñasūtra, “In the Third Dhyāna the faculty of satisfaction which has previously arisen is destroyed without remnant;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: caturthe ca dhyāne sukhendriyaṃ nirudhyata” ityuktam /
column2: in the Fourth Dhyāna, the faculty of happiness is destroyed without remnant.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaścoktaṃ “sukhasya ca prahāṇāt duḥkhasya ca prahāṇātpūrvameva ca saumanasyadaurmanasyayorastaṅgamādi“tyato 'pi na tṛtīye dhyāne saumanasyendriyamasti
column2: ” He says in another Sūtra, “By reason of the abandoning of the. ”These two texts prove that there is no faculty of satisfaction in the Third Dhyāna.
Hence joy is satisfaction, and not happiness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punaḥ kliṣṭeṣvapi dhyāneṣu yathāvihitānyaṅgāni bhavanti /
column2: Does defiled dhyāna possess the parts that we have just studied? What are the parts that are absent in each defilted dhyana?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi kiṃ teṣu na vidyate / kliṣṭeṣvasatprītisukhaṃ prasādaḥ saṃpradhīḥ smṛṭiḥ / upekṣāsmṛtiśuddhiśca
column2: In the defiled Dhyānas there is no joy, happiness, faith, sampradhīḥ, mindfulness, pure equanimity nor pure mindfulness.
When it is defiled, the First Dhyāṇa does not contain joy and happiness ''arisen from separation”, because it is not separated from the defilements of Kāmadhātu.
The Second Dhyāna does not contain internal purity, because it is troubled by the defilements;
the defilements cause it to be unclear.
The Third Dhyāna does not contain mindfulness and awareness, because it is confused by a defiled happiness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ccaturthe upekṣāsmṛtipariśuddhirnāsti / kleśamalinatvāt / evaṃ tāvat kecidāhuḥ /
column2: The Fourth Dhyāna does not contain the purity of equanimity.
According to some, well-being and equanimity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kecitpunaḥ prathamadvitīyayoḥ kliṣṭayoḥ prasrabdhirnāsti / tṛtīyacaturthayorupekṣā nāsti / kuśalalmahābhūmikatvādanayoriti /
column2: According to others, there is no well-being in the first two Dhyānas, and no equanimity in the last two, because well-being and equanimity are dbarmas that are only found in a pure mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trīṇi ca dhyānāni señjitāni uktāni bhagavatā / sāpakṣālatvāt /
column2: The Blessed One teaches that three Dhyānas are disturbed because of faults.
As it is free from the eight faults, the Fourth is undisturbed.
What are the eight faults?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vitarkacārau śvāsau ca sukhādi ca catuṣṭayam //
column2: Viṭarka and vicāra, the two breaths, and the four of which happiness is the first.
The eight faults are vitarka, vicāra, happiness, suffering, satisfaction, dissatisfaction, inbreathing, and outbreathing.
None of these eight is found in the Fourth Dhyāna: this is why it alone is termed “uṇdisturbed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vitarkavicāraprītisukhairakampanīyatvādāneñjyaṃ caturthaṃ dhyānaṃ sūtre nirvāta pradīpanidarśanādityapare / dvayordhyānayoḥ saumanasyamuktaṃ prītivacanāt / tṛtīye sukhaṃ caturthe upekṣā /
column2: ” It is true that the Sūtra says that the Fourth Dhyāna is undisturbed because it is not agitated by vitarka and vicāra, by joy and happiness. According to others, the Fourth Dhyāna is “undisturbed” because it is like a lamp which, in a sealed place, is not agitated by the wind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taskiṃ yā dhyānasamāpattiṣu vedanāstā eva dhyānopapattiṣu /
column2: Do the arisings of dhyāna existences or existences in Rāpadhātu, possess the same sensations as do the absorption of the Dhyāṇas?
No, they do not.
Why is this?
In the dhyāna existences, there is satisfaction, happiness, and equanimity; equanimity and smanaskatā; happiness and equanimity;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukhhopekṣe upekṣā pravido dhyānopapattiṣu // prathamadhyānotpatto tisro vedanāḥ /
column2: and equanimity. In the First Dhyāṇna existence, there are three sensations: 1) the sensation of happiness associated with three consciousnesses;
2) the sensation of satisfaction of the sphere of the mind consciousness;
and 3) the sensation of equanimity associated with four consciousnesses.
In the Second Dhyāna existence, there are two sensations, namely satisfaction and equanimity, both of the sphere of the manas.
There is no happiness here, because the five sense.
In the Third Dhyāna existence, there are two sensations, namely happiness and equanimity, both of the sphere of the manas.
In the Fourth Dhyāna existence, there is a single sensation, the sensation of equanimity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi dvitīyādiṣu dhyāneṣu trayo vijñānakāyā na saṃvidyante vitarkavicārau ca katham te paśyanti yāvatspṛśanti katham cāvijñapti samutthāpayanti
column2: Such is, with respect to the sensations, the differences between the Dhyāna existences and the absorptions of dhyāna. If, from the Second Dhyāna on, three consciousnesses (eye, ear, and body consciousness) are absent, as well as vśtarka and vicāra, how can beings born in the three higher Dhyānas see, hear, and touch? How can they produce the bodily or vocal act of informing?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ve keṣūpapannānāṃ cakṣurvijñānādayona santi / na tu svabhūmikāḥ / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: We do not say that beings who are born in these Dhyānas lack visual consciousness, etc. They possess these consciousnesses, but not in the Second, the Third or the Fourth Dhyānas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāyākṣiśrotravijñānaṃ vijñaptyutthāpakaṃ ca yat / dvitīyādau tadādyāptaṃ
column2: In the Second Dhyāna and above, the body, eye, and ear consciousnesses, and the consciousness that sets the act of informing into motion belong to the sphere of the First Dhyāṇa.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamadhyānabhūmikaṃ cakṣuḥśrotrakāyavijñānaṃ vijñaptisamutthāpakaṃ ca dvitīyādiṣu ca dhyāneṣu saṃmukhīkurvanti /
column2: The eye consciousness, etc. , and the consciousness that sets into.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirmāṇacittavadyena te paśyanti yāvadvijñapti samutthāpayanti / akliṣṭāvyākṛtaṃ ca tat //
column2: But the beings of these Dhyānas manifest these consciousnesses, in the same way as they manifest a fictive mind of creation of a lower sphere, and, by means of these consciousnesses, they see, hear, touch, and produce the action of informing.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anivṛtāvyākṛtaṃ ca tat prathamadhyānabhūmikaṃ vijñānaṃ veditavyaṃ yatte saṃmukhīkurvanti /
column2: These consciousnesses are undefiled-neutral. The four dhyānas which beings in the Second Dhyāna and above manifest, belong to the sphere of the First Dhyāna. Hence they are not defiled, because these beings are detached from the lower spheres;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na kliṣṭaṃ vītarāgatvānna kuśalaṃ hīnatvāditi / avasitaṃ dhyānakāryam /
column2: but they are not good, because the good of a lower sphere is less good.
How does the acquisition of the absorptions of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu take place accordingly as they are pure, undefiled, or defiled?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atadvān labhate śuddhaṃ vairāgyeṇopapattitaḥ / asamanvāgatastena śuddhakaṃ dhayanamārupyaṃ vā pratilabhate /
column2: One who does not possess them acquires them, pure, through detachment or through birth.
One who does not possess these absorptions obtains them by detaching oneself from a lower sphere or by taking up birth in a.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyatra bhavāgrāt / na hi tasyopapattito lābhaḥ /
column2: with the exception of the fourth absorption of Ārūpyadhātu, or Bhavāgra, which one acquires solely by detaching oneself from the third absorption.
What is the meaning of the expression, “He who does not possess them”? This signifies “One who has not acquired them or who has lost them.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śuddhakena prayogato 'pi nirvedhabhāgīyaṃ śuddhakaṃ pratilabhate parihāṇito vā hānabhāgīyam /
column2: In fact a person who possesses these pure absorptions of the falling class, etc. can, through cultivation, obtain pure absorptions of a higher class (i. , of penetration, norvedhabhāgīya); one who possesses pure absorptions of the duration class can, through falling, obtain pure absorptions of the falling class.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evocyate “syācchuddhakaṃ dhyānaṃ vairāgyeṇa pratilabheta vairāgyeṇa vijahyāt /
column2: The Vibhāṣā also says, “Can one acquire a pure dhyāna through detachment? Can one abandon a pure ḍhyāna through detachment? Can one acquire a pure dhyāna through falling? Can one abandon a pure dhyāna through falling? Can one acquire a pure dhyāna through birth? Can one abandon a pure dhyāna through birth?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ parihāṇyā copapattyā ca / syāddhānabhāgīyaṃ prathamaṃ dhayānam /
column2: Yes, in the case of the First Dhyāna of the falling class.”
In fact, one obtains this dhyāna through detachment from.
One acquires them, undefiled, through detachment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāmavairāgyaprahāṇyā tyajyate / upariṣṭādbrahmaloka utpadyamāno labhate / tasmāt punaḥ kāmadhātāvupapapadyamāno vijahātīti /
column2: That is, "one who does not possess them.
The Āryan who detaches himself from a lower sphere acquires the undefiled absorption of a higher sphere. This rule only refers to the ascetic who has completely abandoned the absorption in question.
Oṉe who already possesses an absorption acquires this same absorption of undefiled quality under other conditions.

Through the knowledge of extinction, one acquires the undefiled absorption of an Aśaikṣa; through the perfectioning of his faculties, one acquires an undefiled absorption of a Śaikṣa or an Aṣaikṣa, according to the case.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu ca niyāmā vakrāntito 'pyanāsravaṃ prathamato labhate /
column2: But cannot one say that the ascetic, through entry into the certitude of the acquisition of absolute good, acquires undefiled absorption for the first time? No, for the ascetic who, before pursuing the acquisition of the result of the state of Sakrṛdāgāmin, has obtained the result of the state of Śrotaāpanna can enter into this certitude in the state of Anāgamya;
he does not necessarily acquire the basic absorption.
One acquires them, defiled, through falling and through birth.
One who falls from the detachment of a sphere acquires the defiled absorption of this sphere.
One who, dying in a higher sphere and reborn in a lower sphere, acquires the defiled absorption of this second sphere.
How many types of absorptions arise after how many types of absorptions?
Six absorptions can arise after the first undefiled dhyāna.
Pure and undefiled absorption of the same sphere and pure and undefiled absorption of the Second and Third Dhyānas.
Seven absorptions can arise after undefiled Ākirṁcanyāyatana.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svabhūmike śuddhakānāsrave vijñānākāśānantyāyatanabhūmike ca / bhavāgraṃ śuddhakamevānāsravābhāvāt /
column2: Pure and undefiled absorption of the same sphere, pure and undefiled absorption of Vijñānānantyāyatana and Ākāśānantyāyatana, and pure absorption of Naivasarṁjñānāsaṁjñãyatana.
Eight absorptions can arise after the Second undefiled Dhyāṇa.
Pure and undefiled absorption of the same sphere, and pure and undefiled absorption of the Third, Fourth, and First Dhyāṇna.
Nine absorptions can arise after undefiled Vijñānānantyāyatana.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: svabhūmike dve ākāśānantyāyatanacaturthadhyānabhūmikāni catvāri ākiñcanyāyatanabhavāgrabhūmikāni trīṇīti /
column2: Two of the same sphere, four of Ākāśānantyāyatana and the Fourth Dhyāṇna, and three of Ākiṁhcanyāyatana and Naivasaṁjñānāsathjñāyatana.
According to these same principles, one will see that ten.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa tu saṃkṣepaḥ / tṛtīyādyāvadūrdhvādho 'nāsravānantaraṃ śubham / utpadyate
column2: After the undefiled, up to the third sphere above or below, there arises the good.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śubhagrahaṇena śuddhamanāsravaṃ ca gṛhyate kuśalatvāt anāsravasya samāpatti dravyasyānantaraṃ svabhūmike ca śuddhānāsrave utpadyete /
column2: The word "good" designates the pure absorption and the undefiled absorption, for both are morally good.

After an undefiled absorption, we have either two types of absorption of the same sphere as this undefiled absorption, namely pure and undefiled, or two types of absorption, pure or undefiled, of a higher sphere or of a lower sphere until the third in either direction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vyutkrāntakasamāpattāro hi tṛtīyāt pareṇa laṅghayituṃ notsahante /
column2: In fact, by reason of its too great distance, the ascetic is not capable of jumping over two spheres.
After inferential knowledge, one can enter into the absorptions of Ārūpyadhātu, but not after the knowledge of the dharmas, because this has a lower sphere for its object.
We have seen which absorptions arise after the undefiled absorptions.
The same after the pure, by adding the defiled of its.
A defiled absorption of the same sphere can arise after any pure absorption.
The rest as for the undefiled absorption.
A defiled absorption cannot arise after an undefiled absorption.
After the defiled, the pure and the defiled of its sphere.
A pure or a defiled absorption of the same sphere can arise after a defiled absorption.
And the pure of a lower sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kleśotpīḍito hyadharamapi samāpattiṃ śuddhakaṃ bahu manyate /
column2: Wearied of the defilements of the sphere in which one finds oneself,—defilements belonging to the defiled absorption of a higher sphere,—the ascetic produces an esteem for the pure absorption of a lower sphere. Therefore, after the defiled absorption of a higher sphere, a pure absorption of a lower sphere can arise. "There is a difficulty.
If an ascetic were in a position to distinctly know a defiled absorption and a pure absorption, he would be able to pass from the higher defiled absorption to the lower pure absorption.
But, being defiled, he is not capable of this distinct knowledge;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athāparicchidya kathaṃ saṃcarati / pūrvāvedhāt pūrvaṃ hi sa evaṅkāmo bhavati varamadhastāt śuddhakaṃ nopariṣṭāt kliṣṭamiti / pūrvābhiprāyaṃ ca saṃtatiranuvartate sattvānām /
column2: how then can he, after a defiled absorption, produce a.

He made the resolution, “May I be able to obtain a lower pure absorption! What have I to do with a higher defiled absorption? ” ‘The “series” develops of itself by reason of this resolution, and, as a consequence, the lower absorption arises after the higher defiled absorption, in the same way as a person forms the resolution to sleep until a certain time, falls asleep, and then wakes up at that fixed time.
The undefiled absorptions, of whichever sphere, never arise after a defiled absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samāpattikālaṃ pratyetaduktam / śuddhakāt kliṣṭācca samanantaraṃ svabhūmikameva kliṣṭamutpadyate nānyabhūmikamiti /
column2: We have said that the defiled absorption that succeeds the pure or defiled absorption is always of the sphere of the absorption which it follows. This rule should be understood of life in the course of the absorption; but.
At death, after the pure, the defiled of any type can.
At death, a defiled mind of any sphere can arise following a pure absorption obtained through birth.
Afteṛ the defiled, nothing higher.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kliṣṭāttu dhyānārūpyādanantaraṃ cyutikāle svādharabhūmikaṃ kliṣṭamutpadyate / nordhvabhūmikam /
column2: At death, only a defiled mind of the same sphere or a lower sphere can follow Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu. We have seen that the undefiled absorption can follow the pure absorptions;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca sarvasmācchuddhakādanāśravaṃ samāpattidravyamutpadyate / kiṃ tarhi / caturdhā śuddhakaṃ hānabhāgīyādi
column2: but it cannot follow all types of pure absorptions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: hānabhāgīyaṃ viśeṣabhāgīyaṃ sthitibhāgīyaṃ nirvedhabhāgīyamiti caturvidhaṃ śuddhakam /
column2: The pure absorption is of four types: of falling, of duration, of progress, and of penetration.
Nevertheless, the pure absorption of Naivasarṅjñānāsaṁjñāyatana is only of three types, excluding the category of the pure absorption of progress, because it has no higher sphere.
What are these four types?
In order, they are suitable to the arising of the defilements, to its own sphere, to a higher sphere, to the undefiled.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kleśotpattyanuguṇaṃ hānabhāgīyaṃ svabhūmyanuguṇaṃ sthitibhāgīyamūrdhvabhūmyanuguṇaṃ viśeṣabhāgīyamanāsravānuguṇaṃ nirvedhabhāgīyam /
column2: When the pure absorption is of such a nature that it tends to lead to the arising of the defilements, it is called an absorption "ofWhen the pure absorption tends to lead to its own sphere, it is called an absorption "of duration. When the pure absorption tends to lead to a higher sphere, it is called an absorption "of progress. When the pure absorption tends to lead to the undefiled absorption, it is called an absorption "of penetration.
Therefore it is from this last category of pure absorptions that the undefiled absorption arises.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athaiṣāṃ caturṇā kati kasmādanantaramutpadyante / dve trīṇi trīṇi caikaṃ ca hāna bhāgādyanantaram /
column2: What is the reciprocal generation of these four categories of absorption?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: hānabhāgīyaṃ hānabhāk / tasmādanantaraṃ dve utpadyete / hānisthitibhāgīye /
column2: After the absorption of falling, there can arise absorptions of falling and duration.
After the absorption of duration, three can arise, with the exception of the absorption of penetration.

After the absorption of progress, three can arise, with the exception of the absorption of falling. After the absorption of penetration, only an absorption of penetration can arise. We have seen that immediately after a pure absorption or an undefiled absorption of a certain sphere, there. When this is produced, the ascetic passes over a sphere and changes the characteristics of his absorption: he cultivates what is called the "transitional absorption".
How is this absorption actualized?
Going and coming in two ways over the eight spheres, in immediate succession, by passing over one sphere, going to the third sphere of a different type, is called "transitional absorption".
To go is to take up the absorptions in ascending order;
to come is to take up the absorptions in descending order.
In two ways refers to undefiled absorption and defiled absorption. This refers to the pure absorptions, not to the defiled absorptions.
The eight spheres means the Four Dhyāna absorptions, and the Four Ārūpya absorptions.
In immediate succession signifies by degrees.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ekalaṅghitā ityekāmekāmutkramya / sāsravā aṣṭau bhūmiranulomapratilomasamāpattito nirjitya anāsravāśca sapta /
column2: By passing over one sphere means by skipping a sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paścātsāsravāt prathamāddhyānāt sāsravaṃ tṛtīyaṃ samāpadyate / tasmādākāśānantyāyatanaṃ tasmādākṃicanyāvatanam /
column2: The preparatory exercise includes four successive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ punaḥ pratilomaṃ nirjitya anāsravā apyekalaṅghitā anulomapratilomaṃ ca samāpadyate / ayaṃ prayogo vyutkrāntakasamāpatteḥ / yadā tu prathamātsāsravāt tṛtīyamanāsravaṃ dhyānaṃ samāpadyate tasmātsāsravamākāśānantyāyatanaṃ tasmādanāsravamākiñcanyāyatanam /
column2: When the ascetic is capable of passing from the first defiled dhyāna into the third undefiled Zhyáānṉa, from this into defiled Ākāśānantyāyatana, from this into undefiled Ākiṁcanyāyatana, and to return in the same way, then he has realized the entry into the third absorption of a different quality and has returned from.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ punaḥ pratilomam / tadā visabhāgatṛtīyadravyagamanādabhiniṣpannā bhavati /
column2: This absorption: the transitional absorption has been achieved.
It is impossible to skip over two spheres and enter into a fourth, because a fourth sphere is too distant.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tāṃ ca triṣu dvīpeṣu asamayavimukta evārhannutpādayati / niḥkleśatvātsamādhivaśitvācca /
column2: The transitional absorption is cultivated only by humans of the Three Dvīpas; by Arhats who are non-circumstantially delivered, that is, those who realize absorption of their own accord, those who are delivered independently of circumstances because they possess mastery in absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭiprāptasya yadyapi tīkṣṇendriyatvāt samādhau vaśitvaṃ na tu niṣkleśaḥ /
column2: The Dṛṣṭiprāptas, that is, the ascetics in whom prajñā dominates, are of keen faculties and possess mastery in absorption; but they lack the first condition.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: samayavimukto yadyapi niḥkleśo natvasya samādhau vaśitvamiti /
column2: Arhats whose liberation is occasional and circumstantial have destroyed the defilements, but the second condition is absent. Both are therefore incapable of cultivating the transitional absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kenāśrayeṇa kati dhyānārupyāḥ saṃmukhīkriyante / svādhobhūmyāśrayā eva dhyānāśrayā eva dhyānārūpyāḥ
column2: How many dhyāna and āripya absorptions can be actualized by beings in different spheres? The dḍhyāna and ārāpya absoṟptions have for their support beings of their own spheres or of a lower.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavāgraṃ bhavāgre ca saṃmukhīkriyate adhaśca yāvatkāmadhātau /
column2: A being in Bhavāgra can actualize the absorption of Bhavāgra.

Beings in lower spheres down to Kāmadhātu can actualize it also. In the same way the absorptions of the other spheres can be actualized by beings who are in the sphere of these absorptions or in lower spheres.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ kāraṇamūrdhvopapanno nādharāṃ samāpatti saṃmukhīkaroti / tasmāttasya vṛthā'dharam //
column2: But a being reborn in a higher sphere cannot actualize the absorption of a lower sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi tasyādhareṇa samāpattidravyeṇa kiñcit prayojanaṃ vidhīyate /
column2: A lower absorption has no usefulness.
An absorption of a lower sphere does not have even the smallest amount of usefulness for a being born in a higher sphere, because this absorption is, by comparison, mediocre.
Such is the general rule, which admits of one exception: But, in Bhavāgra, it is by entering the Āryaṉn absorption of Ākiṁcanya that one destroys the defilements.
A being born in Bhavāgra realizes the Āryan, that is, the undefiled absorption of Ākirhcanyāyatana in order to destroy the defilements relating to Bhavāgra.
In fact, the pure Path cannot be cultivated in Bhavāgra;
but on the other hand. What is the object of the Dhyāna and Ārūpya absorptions?
Associated with thirst, absorption has its own existence for its object. “Absorption associated with thirst” signifies the absorption of enjoyment.
Īt has for its object “its own bhava,” that is, the bhava of its sphere.

Bhava signifies “that which is defiled”. This is another manner of presenting the doctrine of viii. 6: the absorption of enjoyment has for its object a pure but defiled absorption, not an undefiled absorption. He does not have a lower sphere for its object, for the ascetic that cultivates the absorption of enjoyment of a certain sphere is detached from the lower sphere.
He does not have a higher sphere for his object, for the spheres are delimited by desire.
He does not have an undefiled absorption for his object, which would imply that it is pure.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānaṃ sadviṣayaṃ śubham // kuśalaṃ dhyānaṃ śubhakamanāsravaṃ ca /
column2: Pure absoṟption has all that exists for its object.
The pure or undefiled absorption takes as its object all of the.
The pure Ārūpya absorptions of the principal spheres do not have lower defiled absorptions for their object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: maulānāṃ kuśalārūpyāṇāmadhobhūmikaṃ sāsravaṃ vastu nālambanaṃ svordhvabhūmyālambanatvāt / anāsravaṃ tvālambanam /
column2: The pure absorptions cultivated in the principal spheres of Ārūpyadhātu in opposition to the Dhyāna absorptions and to the absorptions cultivated in the sāmantakas of Ārūpyadhātu do not have for their object the defiled dharmas of lower spheres, but the dharmas of their own sphere or of a higher sphere.

The undefiled dharmas grasp all inferential knowledge for their object, the sarvānvayajñānapakṣa; they do not concern themselves with the knowledge of the dharmas, the dharmajñāna, whose object, namely Kamadhātu, is too distant; they no longer concern themselves with the extinction of a lower sphere, which would be possible only if they were concerned with this sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sāmantakānantaryamārgāṇāṃ tvadharā bhūmirālambanam / eṣāṃ ca punastrividhānāṃ dhyānānāṃ rūpyārūpyāṇām
column2: The absorptions cultivated in the srārnantakas of Ārūpyadhātu have for their object the lower sphere, for they include an irresistable Path whose sole object is the lower. Among the three types of dhyāna and ārūpya absoṟptions, undefiled and supermundane, pure, and defiled, which one destroys the defilements?
The defilements are abandoned through the undefiled absoṟptions. Any undefiled absorption is capable of cutting off the defilements;

not the pure absorptions, nor even less, the defiled absorptions. The pure absorption does not cut off the defilements of a lower sphere, for the ascetic can only obtain the pure absorption of a certain sphere because he is detached from a lower sphere;
he does not cut off the defilements of his sphere, for he does not oppose these defilements;
he does not cut off the defilements of a higher sphere, because they are more subtle than he himself.
And also by means of the sáġmantakas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānārūpyasāmantakena ca kleśāḥ prahīyante śuddhakenāpi / adhobhūmipratipakṣatvāt /
column2: If the sāmantakas of the dhyānas and the ārāpyas are pure, they cut off the defilements, because they ate opposed to a lower sphere.
How many sāmantakas, prefatory or threshold absorptions, are there?
There are eight rāmantakas in the basic absorptions.

Each basic absorption has a sāmantaka or prefatory absorption, through which one enters into the basic absorption. Are the sāmantakas of three types,—undefiled, pure, or defiled,—like the basic absorptions?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tānyapi trividhāni tathaiva ca teṣu vedanā / netyucyate /
column2: Do they possess the same sensations as they do?
They are pure; they possess the sensation of equanimnity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śuddhakāni ca tānyupekṣendriyasaṃprayuktāni ca yantabāhyatvādadhobhūmyudvegānapagamāt vairāgyapathatvācca nāsvādanāsaṃprayuktāni / āryaṃ cādyaṃ
column2: The sāmantakas are exclusively pure and are associated with the sensation of egquanimity, because one traverses them through effort, because the abhorance of the lower sphere has not yet disappeared, and because they are the Path by which one detaches oneself from the lower sphere. Therefore they only contain the sensation of equanimity and they are not associated with enjoyment.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ādyaṃ sāmantakamanāgamyaṃ tacchuddhakaṃ cānāsravaṃ ca yadyapi sāmantakacittena pratisaṃdhibandhaḥ kliṣṭo bhavati /
column2: The first sāmantaka is called Anāgamya. It is of two types, pure and Āryan, that is, undefiled.
The samantaka mind through which one enters an existence is defiled; but the samantaka mind through which one enters absorption cannot be defiled, for this thesis has been refuted.
Some say that it is threefold.
Other masters say that the Anagamya samantaka is also associated with enjoyment. Does dhyanaantara, the intermediate dhyana, differ or not from samantaka? It differs from it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āsvādanāsaṃprayuktamapyanāgamyaṃ sāmantakaṃ cocyate dhyānāntaraṃ ca / kimidamekārthamāhosvinnānārtham / sāmantakaṃ hi vairāgyamārgaḥ /
column2: In fact, samantaka is the door to detachment from a lower sphere, but this is not the case for dhyanaantara.

Furthermore, dhyanaantara is without vitarka. The first basic dhyana and the first samantaka are associated with vitarka and vicara. In the seven higher absorptions (the basic Dhyanas and their samantakas), there is neither vitarka nor vicara.

Only dhyanaantara is filled with vicara without being filled with vitarka; consequently, it is superior to the First Dhyana but inferior to the Second. This is why it is called dhyanaantara, or intermediate dhyana.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva dvitīyādiṣu dhyāneṣu na vyayasthāpyate viśeṣābhāvāditi / tatpunardhyānāntaraṃ tridhā
column2: Consequently, in the higher spheres, there is no dhyanaantara. To how many categories does dhyānāntara belong?
It can be associated with enjoyment, a pure absorption, and an undefiled absorption.
It has the sensation of equanimity.
Like the prefatory or threshold absorptions, it has the neither-disagreeable-nor-agreeable sensation, for it is associated with the faculty of equanimity.
One progresses through it through effort and therefore it cannot be associated with satisfaction.
Hence it is considered to be a “difficult path”.
What is the result of dhyānāntara?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taddhi mahābrahmaphalaṃ ca tat / tāṃ hi dhyānāntarikāṃ bhāvayitvā mahābrahmā bhavati /
column2: It has Mahābrahmā for its result, Whoever cultivates this absorption to the highest degree is reborn as Mahābrahmā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaḥ sarvasamādhīn saṃkalayya trayaḥ samādhayaḥ uktāḥ sūtre / savitarkaḥ savicāraḥ samādhiḥ / avitarko vicāramātraḥ / avitarko 'vicāra iti /
column2: The Sūtra says that there are three types of samādhi: 1) samādhi with vitarka and vicāra, 2) samādhi without vitarka but with vÉcāra, and 3) samādhi without vitarka and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra dhyānāntaraṃ tāvadavitarko vicāramātraḥ samādhhiriti jñāpitam / vitarkamātrapratiṣedhāt / tataḥ savitarkavicāro'dhaḥsamādhiḥ
column2: Dhyānāntara is samādhi without vitarka but with vicāra.
All samadhi that is below dhyānāntara contains vitarka and vicāra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prathamaṃ dhyānamanāgamyaṃ ca / parato 'dvayaḥ // nātra dvayamastītyadvayaḥ /
column2: This refers to the First Dhyāna and to any other samādhi supported by the First Dhyāna. Beyond, samādhi exists without either.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pareṇa tu dhyānāntarātsamādhiravitarko 'vicāraḥ / dvitīyadhyānasāmantakādyāvat bhavāgram / punastrayaḥ uktāḥ /
column2: Above dhyānāntara, all samādhi is without vṛtarka and vicāra, from the sārmantaka of the Second Dhyāna to the Fourth Ārūpya absorption. The Sūtra teaches that there are three absorptions, the absorption of emptiness, the absorption of the absence of characteristics, and the absorption of the absence of intention.
The absence of characteristics has the aspect of the Tranquil.

The absorption associated with the aspect of the Truth of Extinction, that is, the absorption in which the ascetic considers extinction, is called the absorption of the absence of characteristics. This absorption has four aspects. Why does it receive this name?
Because Nirvāṇa or extinction, being free from ten characteristics is called animit$a.

The absorption that has NirvāṇaThe ten characteristics or marks are: the five āyatanas, exterṉal sources of the sense consciousnesses, physical matter, sound, etc. ; male and female; and the three characteristics of conditioned things, arising, duration-and-change, and death.
Emptiness has the aspects of emptiness and non-self.
The absorption associated with the two aspects of emptiness and of non-self is called the absorption of emptiness. There are thus two aspects, the last two aspects of the Truth of Suffering.
The absence of intention is associated with the other Truths.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paraiḥ śeṣaiḥ satyākāraiḥ saṃprayuktaḥ samādhipraṇihito daśākāraḥ /
column2: The absorption of the absence of intention is the absorption that grasps the other ten aspects.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anityaduḥkhataddhetubhya udvegāt mārgasya ca kolopamatayā 'vaśyatyājyatvāttadākāraḥ samādhirapraṇihitaḥ /
column2: On the one hand, there are aspects of impermanence and suffering (duhkha, the first two aspects of the Truth of Suffering) and the four aspects of the Truth of Origin, which provoke dread, and on the other hand, the four aspects of the Path, for the Path is like a raft and should necessarily be. The absorption that grasps these ten aspects is turned toward the passing beyond of things that are impermanent, suffering, arising, and the Path; it is then called apraṇihita, free from praṇidhāna, the will or desire for something. On the contrary however, Nirvāṇa, under these four aspects and as the object of the absorption of the absence of intention, should not be abandoned;

and the last two aspects of the Truth of Suffering, namely emptiness and non-self, the object of the absorption of emptiness, do not provoke dread, for these two aspects belong to Nirvāṇa as well as to conditioned things.
These three absorptions are of two types.
Pure or immaculate.
They are pure or immaculate, that is undefiled, accordingly as they are worldly or transworldly.
Worldly, they exist in eleven spheres;
transworldly, they exist in the sphere of the Path.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nirmalāstu te vimokṣamukhatrayam / anāsravāstvete trayaḥ samādhayastrīṇi vimokṣamukhānyucyante /
column2: Immaculate, they are the three gates to deliverance. When they are undefiled, they are also called “the gates to”.
We have emptiness as a gate to deliverance, the absence of characteristics as a gate to deliverance, and the absence of intention as a gate to deliverance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: punaścocyante / śūnyatāśūnyatādyākhyāstrayo 'parasamādhayaḥ // śūnyatāśūnyatā apraṇihitāpraṇihitaḥ ānimittānimittaśca / śūnyatādyālambanatvāttannāma /
column2: There are also three other absorptions called "emptiness of emptiness", etc. They are also called the absorption of the emptiness of emptiness, the absorption of the absence of intention in the absence of intention, and the absorption of the absence of characteristics in the absence of characteristics, because they have respectively, and in a manner that we shall explain, the absorptions of emptiness, the absence of intention, and the absence of characteristics for their objects.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣāṃ punaḥ ālambete akṣaikṣaṃ dvau śūnyataścāpyanityataḥ /
column2: The first two refer to the Aśaikṣa under the aspects of emptiness and impermaṇence.
They have for their object the absorption of the Aśaikṣa; that is, they have respectively the absorption of emptiness and the absorption of the absence of intention as realized by an Arhat for.

The absorption of the emptiness of emptiness considers the absorption of emptiness, which considers the dharmas as empty and non-self, as empty but not as non-self, because a view of non-self does not provoke the same dread as does a view of emptiness.

The absorption of the absence of intention in the absence of intention has the absorption of the absence of intention of the Aśaikṣa for its object, an absorption which considers things under ten aspects, impermanence, suffering, etc. , by considering them as impermanent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na duḥkhato na hetvādito 'nāsravasyātallakṣaṇatvānna mārgākāraiḥ dūṣaṇīyatvāt /
column2: It does not consider them as suffering, nor as cause, origin, condition, or appearance, for the absorption of the absence of intention, being undefiled, is not suffering or cause; and although the absorption of the absence of intention is the Path, the absorption of the absence of intention in the absence of intention no longer considers it as a Path, the truth, the route, nor as pertaining to the truth, because the goal pursued by the ascetic is that of becoming disgusted with the absorption of the.
The absence of characteristics in the absence of characteristics has for its object extinction not attained through conscious effort, and considers it as tranquil.

This is to say that the absorption of the absence of characteristics in the absence of characteristics has for its object the extinction that is not attained through conscious effort of the absorption of the absence of characteristics, and considers this extinction under the aspect of tranquility, thinking, “This extinction is tranquil”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anāsravasya pratisaṃkhayānirodhābhāvāt / na nirodhapraṇītaniḥsaraṇākārairanityatānirodhasādhāraṇatvādavyākṛtatvā davisaṃyogācca / ekāntena caite parasamādhayaḥ sāsravāḥ
column2: It does not have for its object the extinction attained through conscious effort of the absorption of the absence of characteristics, for this absorption is undefiled, and there is no extinction attained through conscious effort of anything that is pure. And of the four aspects under which one can consider extinction attained through conscious effort, namely extinction, tranquility, excellent, and leaving, the aspect of tranquility is the only one that. In fact, the characteristic of extinction belongs to the extinction not attained through conscious effort, as well as to the extinction brought about by impermanence;

the extinction not attained through conscious effort is not excellent, for it is morally neutral; it is not leaving, for it is not disconnection from the defilements. The three absorptions are exclusively Defiled. Because they hate the Path, they turn away from it, regarding it as empty, etc. Now such absorptions are not pure, or undefiled dharmas.
Where do they arise?
Among humans.
They are cultivated only by humans of the Three Dvīpas, and not by the gods.
Among whom do they arise?
Among the Unshakeable Ones.
Only among the Arhats of the Unshakeable class, and among no other Aṛhats.
In what sphere do these also exist?
With the exception of the seven sāmantakas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sapta sāmantakāni hitvānyāsvekādaśasu bhūmiṣu / kāmadhātvanāgamyadhyānāntaradhyānārupyeṣu / punaścatasraḥ samādhibhāvanā ucyante /
column2: These absorptions arise eleven spheres, namely Kāmadhātu, Anāgamya, the eight basic absorptions (Dhyāna and Ārūpya absorptions, with the exception of the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti samādhibhāvanā āsevitā bhāvitā vahulīkṛtā dṛṣṭadharmasukhavihārāya saṃvartate” iti vistaraḥ /
column2: The Sutra says that there are four cultivations of absorption: "There is a cultivation of the absorption that cultivates, practices, repeatedly cultivates, which has for its result the possession of happiness in this world," and the rest.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra samādhibhāvanā dhyānaṃ śubhamādyaṃ sukhāya hi //
column2: The First good Dhyana is the cultivation of the absorption that has for its result happiness; (the supernormal knowledge of the eye has sight for its result; the cultivation of good arisen from exercise has comprehension for its result; the absorption likened to a Vajra of the Fourth Dhyana has the extinction of the defilements for its result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalaṃ prathamaṃ śuddhakamanāsravaṃ vā dṛṣṭadharmasukhavihārāya samādhibhāvanā /
column2: ) The "First good Dhyana" is the first pure or undefiled dhyana. Through this dhyana, the ascetic obtains "happiness in this world".
This holds for the other three Dhyanas as for the First Dhyana.

This absorption does not necessarily have for its result happiness beyond this world, for the ascetic who possesses it can fall from it, he can be reborn higher, or he can obtain Nirvana: inThese three cases he does not enjoy happiness in a future life.
The supernormal knowledge of the eye has sight for its result.
The second cultivation of the absorption has for its result the acquisition of the seeing of knowledge. This is the supernormal knowledge of the divine eye.
The cultivation of good arisen from exercise has comprehension for its result. The third cultivation of the absorption has for its result the attainment of the excellent forms of prajñā.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prayogajāḥ sarve guṇāstraidhātukā anāsravāḥ prajñāprabhedāya samādhibhāvanā /
column2: This is the samādhihāvanā of the superior qualities which arise from cultivation, that is, the qualities of the three spheres and pure, undefiled qualities. The samādhi that produces these qualities is called the samādhibhāvanā of these qualities.
The absorption likened to a Vájra of the Fourth Dhyāna has the extinction of the defilements for its result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaścaturthadhyāne vajropamaḥ samādhiḥ sa āsravakṣayāya samādhibhāvanā /
column2: In the Fourth Dhyāṇna there is produced an absorption that is called the cultivation "like a Vajra". This absorption destroys all of the defilements.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmopanāyikī kilaiṣā bhagavato dharmadeśanā / ataścaturbhya evāha /
column2: According to the School, the Blessed One, in setting forth this fourfold cultivation of the absorptions, teaches his own cultivation. How is this? Because he places himself in the Fourth Dhyāna in order to realize the Vajropamasamādhi which, as we have seen, can be realized in other states of absorption.
We have explained the absorptions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idānīṃ samādhisaṃniśritānāṃ guṇānāṃ nirdeśakāla iti vyākhyāyante
column2: Let us explain the qualities that the ascetic realizes by being in the absorptions.
The Immeasurables are four in number.
They are goodwill or friendship, compassion, joy, and equanimity.
They are called the Immeasurables because they apply to an immeasurable number of beings, drawing after them an immeasurable merit, and producing immeasurable results.
Because they oppose ill-will, etc. ,

In order the four Immeasurables oppose ill-will, harm, dissatisfaction, and sensual craving and hostility. Goodwill causes persons who are given over to ill-will to abandon ill-will, and so on. We have seen that the meditation on loathsome things. we learn here that equanimity also opposes it.
What is the difference between the meditation on loathsome things and equanimity in their opposition to sensual craving?

According to the Vibhāṣā, there is reason to distinguish, with respect to sensual craving, craving for the visible things of Kāmadhātu, and sexual craving. Now meditation on loathsome things opposes the first of these two craving, whereas equanimity is opposed to the second.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ tu yujyate / maithūnarāgasyāśubhā mātāpitṛputrajñātirāgasyopekṣeti / tatra
column2: We would say rather that meditation on loathsome things is opposed to sexual craving, whereas equanimity is opposed to craving that has for its object father, mother, children, and parents.
Goodwill is the absence of hatred.
The nature of goodwill is the absence of malice.
This is also the case for compassion.
The nature of joy is satisfaction.
The nature of equanimity is the absence of desire.
how can it oppose ill-will?
Because ill-will is provoked by desire.
We would say rather that equanimity is both the absence of desire and the absence of ill-will.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣāṃ tu maitryādīnāṃ ākāraḥ sukhitā duḥkhitā vata /
column2: Their aspects are happiness, unhappiness, joy, and beings.
Happy beings are the object of goodwill.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sukhitā vata sattvā iti manasikurvan maitrīṃ samāpadyate /
column2: The ascetic produces with regard to them a mind having the following aspect, “Beings are happy! ” and by this, he enters the meditation of goodwill. Suffering beings are the object of meditation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: duḥkhitā vata sattvā iti karuṇāṃ modantāṃ vata sattvā iti muditāṃ sattvā ityeva manasi kurvannupekṣāṃ samāpadyate / mādhyasthyāt / atadvatāṃ sukhādhimokṣatvāt kathaṃ na viparītatvaṃ bhavati /
column2: With regard to them the ascetic thinks, “Beings are unhappy! ” and, by this, he enters the meditation of compassion. Joyful beings are the object of joy. With regard to them, the ascetic thinks, “Beings are joyful! ” and, by this, he enters into the meditation of joy.
Beings considered merely as beings and without making any. With regard to them the ascetic produces a mind having the following aspect, “Beings!

” and, by this, by means of what can be called “impartiality”, he enters into the meditation of equanimity. Yet, to consider the beings who do not possess happiness as happy is an intentional view not conforming to the facts, and is erroneous. it is not erroneous: when the ascetic thinks, “Beings are happy! ” the sense is “May beings be happy!” There is no error in his intention, for the ascetic indeed knows that he conceives an intentional view.
And even though the ascetic himself is mistaken, what harm is there in that?
Would you say that the Immeasurables are bad because they take beings as they are not?
But they are the roots of good since they oppose ill-will, etc. The Immeasurables have living beings for their object.
More precisely, they have the living beings of Kāmadhātu for their sphere.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadālambanānāṃ vyāpādādīnāṃ pratipakṣatvāt / yattūktamekāṃ diśamadhimucyeteti tadbhājanena bhājanagataṃ darśitam /
column2: In fact, they oppose ill-will with respect to these beings. The Sūtra speaks of the physical world but it has in view the beings that are to be found in the physical world.
In what spheres does the ascetic produce the Immeasurables?
Joy in two Dhyānas.
One cultivates joy in only the first two Dhyāṇas, for joy is satisfaction and satisfaction is absent in the other Dhyāṇas.
The others in six spheres.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyāni trīṇi apramāṇāni ṣaṭsu bhūmiṣu / anāgamye dhyānāntaredhyāneṣu ca / saprayogamaulagrahaṇāt /
column2: The other three Immeasurables exist in six spheres: in Anāgamya, in dhyānāntara, and in the Four Dhyāṇas.
Or, according to some, in five.
However, according to other masters, they are in only five spheres, with the exception of the Anāgamya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: daśasvityapare / kāmadhātuṃ sāmantakāni ca prakṣipya samāhitāsamāhitamaulalprayogagrahaṇāt /
column2: According to still other masters, they exist in ten spheres, by adding to the six Kāmadhātu and the three sāman:akas of the higher Dhyānas. The number varies accordingly as one attributes the Immeasurables to a state of non-absorption.
We have said that the Immeasurables oppose ill-will, etc. Does this mean that one could abandon the defilements by means of the Immeasurables?

There is no abandoning through the Immeasurables. For the Immeasurables have the basic Dhyanas for their sphere or places of their arising; because they include an arbitrary or voluntary judgment and not an exact judgment; and because they have for their object living beings and not the general characteristics of things.

However, in their preparatory stage, the Immeasurables disturb ill-will, etc. , and the Immeasurables dispel ill-will already abandoned: this is why we have said above that the Immeasurables oppose ill-will, etc. More specifically: goodwill, compassion, etc. , cultivated in Kamadhatu and in Anagamya, the preliminary stages, only resemble goodwill, compassion, etc. in a state of.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prahāṇa dūrīkaraṇācca / kāmadhātvanāgamyabhūmikāni hi maitryādīni maulāpramāṇasadṛśāni saṃvidyante /
column2: After having disturbed ill-will, etc. , by means of preliminary goodwill, compassion, etc. , the ascetic produces, in the absorption of Anāgamya, a path of abandoning —īndependent of goodwill, compassion, etc,.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: taistānviṣkambhya prahāṇamārgaiḥ prajahāti / tato vītarāgāvasthāyāṃ maulāpramāṇalābhāt /
column2: —by which he abandons the defilements. Once the defilements are abandoned, the ascetic obtains detachment from Kāmadhātu, enters the basic Dhyāna, and then obtains the Four Immeasurables of the sphere of the basic Dhyāna.
The defilements are thus dispelled, and made distant, and the ascetic will henceforth be invincible, even when he encounters powerful causes of defilement.
How does the beginner cultivate goodwill?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā sukhitamātmānaṃ manyate parānvā śṛṇoti buddhabodhisattvāryaśrāvakāṃstathā sattvānāṃ tatsukhamadhimucyate evaṃ sukhitā vata santu sattvā iti /
column2: He calls to mind the happiness that he himself has experienced; he hears one speak of the happiness experienced by others, by the Buddhas, the Bodhisattvas, the Śrāvakas, and the Pratyekabuddhas. He forms the vow that all beings shall obtain this happiness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cecchaknoti kleśasyodbhatavṛttitvāt sa mitrapakṣaṃ tridhā bhittvā 'dhimātre tatsukhamadhimucyate /
column2: When his defilements are too strong, the ascetic is not capableHe should then divide all beings into three categories, friends, persons to whom he is indifferent, and enemies.

The first category is also divided into three: good friends, medium friends, and lesser friends; and in the same way the third. The category of persons to whom he is indifferent is not so subdivided: thus there are altogether seven groups.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: teṣu cetsamāṃ maitrīṃ labhate tata udāsīnapakṣe /
column2: Having made this division, the ascetic first forms the vow of happiness with regard to his good friends;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ śatrūpakṣaṃ tridhā bhittvā mṛdau tat sukhamadhimucyate / tato madhye 'dhimātre ca /
column2: he then follows this with a vow of happiness with regard to the medium friends and lesser friends.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataścedadhimātra iva mitrapakṣe sukhādhimokṣo na vyāvartate /
column2: Finally the ascetic no longer distinguishes the three categories of friends; he then forms the same vow with regard to persons to whom he is indifferent and with regard to his enemies. Through the force of all these, he produces, with regard to his greatest enemies, the same vow of happiness as with regards his dearest friends. When this meditation or cultivation of the vow of happiness, sevenfold and impartial, is achieved, the ascetic then progressively.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tataḥ krameṇa grāmarāṣṭrasukhādhimokṣo yāvadekāṃ diśaṃ yāvatsarva lokaṃ maitryā sphurati /
column2: Enlarges the domain of this vow, embracing his town, his country, one cardinal direction, and then all the universe.

When all beings, without exception, are embraced in his infinite mind of goodwill, the meditation of goodwill is achieved. Those who take pleasure in the qualities of others easily and rapidly cultivate goodwill, but not so those who take pleasure in discovering the faults of others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śakyaṃ hi samucchinna kuśalamūle 'pi guṇagrāhiṇā bhavituṃ pratyekabuddhe ca doṣa grāhiṇā pūrvaṃ puṇyāpuṇyaphalasaṃdarśanāt /
column2: For even persons who have cut off their roots of good are not without their good qualities, and one can even find faults among the Pratyekabuddhas themselves: the consequences of the ancient good deeds of the former, and the bad deeds of the latter, are visible in their bodies, etc. So too one should understand the meditation or cultivation of compassion and joy. One sees beings falling into the ocean of suffering: one forms the vow: “May they be delivered from suffering! May they enter into joy.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ karuṇāyāṃ muditāyāṃ ca prayujyate amī sattvā bahuvidhavyasanīdhanimagnā apyevaṃ duḥkhādvimucyeran apyevātipramoderannityadhimucyamāna upekṣāṃ tūdāsīnapakṣādārabhate / etāni cāpramāṇāni
column2: In this way one exercises himself in compassion and joy. One who cultivates equanimity takes as his point of departure the category of persons. In what sphere of rebirth does one cultivate the Immeasurables?
One produces them among humans.
Only humans can cultivate the Immeasurables and not beings in any of the other spheres of rebirth.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ punarya ekenāpramāṇena samanvāgataḥ so 'vaśyaṃ sarvaiḥ / kintu
column2: When a person possesses one Immeasurable, does he necessarily possess all of the others? He does not necessarily possess them all.
He necessarily possesses three.
The person who has produced the Third Dhyāna or the Fourth Dhyāṇa cannot possess joy, since satisfaction is absent in these Dhyānas.
When one possesses one Immeasurable, one always possesses three.
What are the Deliverances? The Deliverances are eight in number.
According to the Sūtra, "One endowed with physical matter sees physical matter": this is the First Deliverance.
Not having the idea of internal visible things, he sees external visible things: this is the Second Deliverance. Bringing forth agreeable Deliverance, he dwells in this absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śubhaṃ vimokṣaṃ kāyena sākṣātkṛtvopasaṃpadya viharatīti tṛtīyaḥ /
column2: this is the Third Deliverance.
The Fourth to the Seventh Deliverances are the four absorptions of Ārūpyadhātu.
The Eighth Deliverance is the absorption of the extinction of ideas and sensations.
The first two are meditations on loathsome things.

The first two Deliverances are, by their nature, meditations on loathsome things, for they have for their aspect the idea of a corpse turning blue, etc. The ascetic considers internal and external visible things, his body or external bodies, under the aspects of a corpse turning blue, etc. Consequently the rules that concern the first two Deliverances are the same as for the meditations on loathsome things.
They are in two Dhyānas.
They are cultivated only in the first two Dhyānas;

when they are cultivated in the First Dhyāna, they oppose attachment to the visible things of Kāmadhāṭtu; cultivated in the Second Dhyāṅa, they oppose attachment to the visible things of the First Dhyāna.
In the Second Dhyāṇna there is no attachment to.
The Third Deliverance can only be cultivated in the Fourth Dhyāṇa.
It is the absence of desire.
It is by nature the root of good absence of desire, not a meditation on loathsome things;
in fact it takes for its object a thing that it considers as good: it therefore has the aspect of something good.
These three Deliverances, with the dharmas that are associated with them, are the five rēandhas.
As for the Deliverances of Ārūpyadhātu: They are good Ārūpyas and absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kuśalāḥ samāhitā eva cārūpyavimokṣākhyāṃ labhante na kliṣṭā nāpyasamāhitāstadyathāmaraṇabhave /
column2: The Third to the Seventh Deliverances are the good ārūpyas, that is, they are pure or undefiled, and they pertain to absorption, but not the ārūpya that is produced at the end of life.
Āccording to others, the mind and mental states produced by retribution among beings born in Ārūpyadhātu are not concentrated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sāmantakavimukti mārgā api vimokṣākhyāṃ labhante / nānantaryamārgā adharālambanatvāt /
column2: The name of “Deliverance” is also given to the Path of Deliverance of the prefatory stages of the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vaimukhyārtho hi vimokṣārtha iti / nirodhastu samāpattiḥ saṃjñāveditanirodhastu aṣṭamo vimokṣo nirodhasamāpattiḥ /
column2: The absorption of extinction is the Eighth Deliverance.
We have already mentioned it.
It is called "Deliverance" because it turns away from ideas and sensations; or rather because it turns away from all conditioned things.
According to others, the Eight Deliverances are called deliverances because they deliver one from the obstacles to absorption.

The absorption of extinction is realized immediately after a subtle-subtle mind. A mind in Bhavagra, which belongs to the ascetic who is in a position to realize the absorption of extinction, is subtle in comparison with any mind associated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavāgraṃ hi saṃjñā sūkṣmaṃ tat punaḥ sūkṣmataraṃ kṛtvā nirodhaṃ samāpadyante / samāpannānāṃ tu svaśuddhakādharāryeṇa vyutthānaṃ cetasā tataḥ //
