column2: Subtle-subtle signifies a mind more subtle, but yet one which enters the absorption of extinction that is to say, upon which there immediately succeeds. Going out into a pure mind of the sphere of the same absorption, or into a lower Āryan mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhāvāgrikeṇa vā śuddhakena cetasā tato vyutthānaṃ bhavatyākiñcanyāyatana bhūmikena vā sāsraveṇa /
column2: The absorption of extinction comes to an end when there appears either a pure mind of the sphere of Bhavāgṛa, the Fourth Ārūpya—the sphere to which the absorption of extinction belongs—or an Āryan, that is, an undefiled mind of the sphere of the Third Ārūpya.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadevaṃ tasyāḥ sāsravaṃ samāpatticittaṃ bhavati sāsravānāntarya tu vyutthānacittamiti /
column2: Then there is entry into the absorption of extinction by a defiled mind, and going out by a defiled or undefiled mind.
What is the object of the Deliverances?
The first ones have for their object the visible things of Kāmadhātu.
The first three Deliverances have for their object the physical matter of Kāmadhātu, unpleasant physical matter in the first two, pleasant physical matter in the Third.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye tvarūpiṇaḥ / te 'nvayajñānapakṣordhvasvabhūduḥkhādigocarāḥ // ārūpyavimokṣāṇāṃ svabhūmikordhvabhūmikaṃ duḥkhaṃ taddhetunirodhau cālambanaṃ sarvaścānvayajñānapakṣo mārgaḥ / apratisaṃkhyānirodhaśceti vaktavyamākāśaṃ caikasyeti /
column2: As for those that are non-material, all that which. We have seen that the first two Deliverances belong to the first two Dhyānas, that the Third Deliverance belongs to the Fourth Dhyāna.
Why is there no Deliverance in the Third Dhyāna?

Since body consciousness is absent in the Second Dhyāna, there is no craving for the visible things of this Dhyāṇa because the Third Dhyāṇna is “agitated by its excellent pleasures”. But if there is no craving for visible things in the Third Dhyāna, what purpose does the ascetic pursue in producing the ’Third Deliverance? The ascetic should gladden his mind which the meditation on.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aśubhayā līnaṃ saṃtatiṃ pramodayituṃ jijñāsanārthaṃ vā /
column2: loathsome things has depressed; or rather he should take into consideration his achievement or his lack of achievement.
He asks himself if the first two Deliverances have been achieved or not.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ca punastau niṣpannau bhavato yadi śubhato 'pi manasi kurvataḥ kleśo notpadyata iti /
column2: If, in his contemplation on an agreeable object, defilements do not arise, then the first two Deliverances have been achieved.
In fact the ascetic cultivates the Deliverances, the Dominent Āyatanas, etc. , with a twofold purpose: 1) to remove, to render more distant, the defilements;
and 2) to obtain mastery in absorption.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sā punaryayā vastupariṇāmādhiṣṭhānāyurutsargādīni kriyante / kasmāttṛtīyāṣṭamayoreva sākṣātkaraṇamuktaṃ nānyeṣām /
column2: This mastery has for its result the production of the qualities, such as Absence of Contention, etc. , and the production of the supernormal powers of the Āryans: the supernormal power by which a saint transforms objects or causes them to last, by which he gives up his life, etc. Why does the Sūtra use the expression “having experienced in the definition of only the Third and the Eighth Deliverances?
It is because of their excellence and because they are found to.
The Dominant Āyatanas are eight in number.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: adhyātmaṃ rūpasaṃjñī vahirdhā rūpāṇi paśyati parīttāni suvarṇāni durvarṇāni tāni khalu rūpāṇyabhibhūyajānātyabhibhūya paśyatītyevaṃsaṃjñī bhavatīdaṃ prathamamabhibhvāyatanam /
column2: There is the idea of internal physical matter, and there is the seeing of a small amount of external attractive and unattractive physical matter.
This is the First Dominant Āyatana.

There is the idea of internal physical matter, and there is the seeing of an unlimited amount of external physical matter. There is an absence of any idea of internal physical matter, but there is the seeing of a small amount of external physical matter. There is an absence of any idea of internal physical matter, but there is the seeing of a large amount of external physical matter.
These are the first four Dominant Āyatanas.
There is an absence of any idea of physical matter, but there is the seeing of external blue, yellow, red, and white.
These exist in the final sphere of the two Dhātus.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā prathamo vimokṣa evaṃ dve abhibhvāyatane prathamadvitīye / dve dvitīyavat
column2: The first two Dominant Āyatanas are similar to the First Deliverance.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā dvitīyo vimokṣa evaṃ dve abhibhvāyatane tṛtīyacaturthe /
column2: The Third and the Fourth Dominant Āyatanas are like the Second Deliverance.
And the last four are like the Third Deliverance.
And the last four are like the Third Deliverance.

What is the difference between the Deliverances and the Dominant Āyatanas? Through the Deliverances, one is only “delivered”, bat through the Dominant Āyatanas, one attains domination of their object.
This domination includes the view of the object as one desires and the absence of any defilement provoked by the object.
There are ten All-Encompassing Āyatanas.
They are called all-encompassing because they embrace their object in its totality and exclusively. They are ten in number: this is the totality of earth, water, fire, and wind;
blue, yellow, red, and white;
plus the uninterrupted āyataṉas of space and consciousness (the First.
Eight are the absence of desire.
The first eight are, by nature, the root of good which is absence of desire: (with their concomitant dharmas, they are the five skandhas).
They belong to the last Dhyāna.
They are realized by an ascetic in the Fourth Dhyāṇna.
They have Kāmadhātu for their object.
They refer to the visible things of Kāmadhātu.

However some think that the Fourth, the All-Encompassing Āyatana of Wind has for its object the tangible thing that is called the wind element. Some think that the first four have tangible things for their object, while the last four have visible things for their object.
Two are pure ār/pya.
The last two are pure absorptions of Ārūpyadhātu.
They have the four skandhas of their sphere for their object. Their objects are the four skandhas of the sphere to which they belong.
The Eight Dominant Āyatanas have the Eight Deliverances for their "entry" and the Ten All-Encompassing Āyataṉas have the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sarvāṇi caitāni vimokṣādīni pṛthagjanāryasāṃtānikāni sthāpayitvā nirodhavimokṣam /
column2: All these qualities can have the mental series of a Prthagjana or the mental series of an Aryan for their support, with the exception of the Deliverance of Extinction which can only be produced by Aryans. Concerning the acquisition of these qualities and the persons who can produce them.
Extinction has been explained.
All of the types of the Deliverance of Extinction have been previously mentioned.
The others are obtained either through detachment or through cultivation.
The qualities other than the Deliverance of Extinction are obtained either through detachment or through cultivation accordingly as they have been, or have not been, habitually cultivated.
The qualities of Arapyadhatu are obtained by beings of the Three Dhatus;
the others, only by humans.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ārupyavimokṣā ārupyakṛtsne ca traidhātukāśrayāṇi śeṣaṃ manuṣyāśrayameva / upadeśasāmarthyenotpādanāt /
column2: The Deliverances and the All-Encompassing Ayatanas of Arupyadhatu are cultivated by beings born in any of the Three. But only humans can cultivate the other absorptions—the three Deliverances, the Eight Dominant Āyatanas, and eight All-Encompassing Āyatanas—because these absorptions arise through the power of the Teaching.
If this is the case, how can beings born in the spheres of Rūpadhātu and Ārūpyadhātu realize the dhyāna and ārāpya absorptions higher than the spheres in which they are born?
They can do this by reason of the power of cause, of actions, and the nature of things.
In two spheres, it is through the power of cause and of action that one produces the absorptions of Ārūpyadhātu.

In Rūpadhātu and in the lower spheres of Ārūpyadhātu, the higher absorptions of Ārūpyadhātu arise through the power of cause when they have been, in the course of a previous existence, closely and intensively cultivated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: hetubalādāsannābhīkṣṇābhyāsāt karmabalāccordhvabhūmikasyāparaparyāyavedanīyasya karmaṇaḥ pratyupasthitavipākatvāt / nahyadhastādavīta rāgeṇordhva śakyamutpattumiti /
column2: They also arise through the power of action, that is to say, by reason of the imminent retribution of a previous action of the category “to be retributed later,” including a sphere of retribution higher than.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhyānānāṃ rūpadhātau tu tābhyāṃ dharmatayāpi ca //
column2: In Rupadhatu, it is through these two powers, and also by reason of the nature of things, that one produces the dhyanas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpadhātau dhyānotpādanametābhyāṃ hetukarmabalābhyāṃ dharmatayā ca saṃvartanīkāle /
column2: Beings born in a lower stage of Rupadhatu produce dhyanas higher than the stages in which they have been born because of the two powers described above. Also, at the period at the end of the world, they are produced through the force of dharmata.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadānīṃ hi sarvasttvā evādharabhūmikāstaddhyānamutpādayanti / kṛtsnānāṃ dharmāṇāmudbhūtavṛttitvāt /
column2: In this period, all the beings of lower spheres produce higher dhyanas, for the efficacy of good dharmas becomes fully developed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiyacciraṃ punarayaṃ saddharmaḥ sthāsyati / yatreme īdṛśānām dharmāṇāṃ prakārāḥ prajñāyante /
column2: How long will the Good Law of the Blessed One last, during which time these different types of dharmas can be clearly known and seen?
The nature of the Good Law of the Master is twofold, agama and adhigama.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāgamaḥ sūtravinayābhidharmā adhigamo bodhipakṣyā ityeṣa dvividhaḥ saddharmaḥ /
column2: Agama is the teaching, the Sutra, the Vinaya and the Abhidharma. Addhigama are the dharmas aiding Bodhi. Such is the Good Law, twofold in its nature.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dhātārastasya vaktāraḥ pratipattāra eva ca // āgamasya hi dhārayitāro vaktāraḥ / adhigamasya pratipattāraḥ /
column2: Those who preach it and who cultivate it support it. Those who preach the Good Law, the Sūtras, etc. , support the Good Law which is āgma. Those who cultivate or who realize the Good Law, the dharmas aiding Bodhi, etc. , support the Good Law which is adhigama.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato yāvadete sthāsyanti tāvatsaddharma iti veditavyam /
column2: As long as such persons exist in the world, the Good Law will last.
It is said that the Good Law will last one thousand years after the Parinirvāṇa.
This number refers to the adhigamea, but according to others, the āgama will last longer.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo 'yamiha śāstre 'bhidharma uktaḥ kimeṣa eva śāstrābhidharmo deśitaḥ /
column2: This present treatise is based on the treatises of the Abhidharma. According to which interpretation is the Abhidharma explained in this treatise?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kāśmīravaibhāṣikanītisiddhaḥ prāyo mayā 'yaṃ kathito 'bhidharmaḥ / yaddurgṛhītaṃ tadihāsmadāgaḥ saddharmanītau manayaḥ pramāṇam //
column2: The Abhidharma that is established through the interpretation of the Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmiīr is, in its.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prāyeṇa hi kāśmīravaibhāṣikāṇāṃ nītyādisiddha eṣo 'smābhirabidharma ākhyātaḥ /
column2: For the most part, this Abhidharma, which has been spoken by me, is the Abhidharma as established by the Vaibhāṣikas of Kaśmīir.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadatrāsmābhirdurgṛhītaṃ so 'smākamaparādhaḥ / saddharmanītau tu punarbuddhā eva pramāṇaṃ buddhaputrāśca /
column2: That which, herein, has been poorly grasped, is my fault: for the Buddhas and the sons of the Buddhas alone are the authority for the interpretation of the Good Law.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nimīlite śāstari lokacakṣuṣi kṣayaṃ gate sākṣijane ca bhūyasā /
column2: The Master, the eye of the world, is closed; the witnesses, for the most part, have perished;
the Law is put into confusion by persons who have not seen the Truth; and by bad sophists, independent, from whom nothing is gained.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gate 'tha śāntiṃ paramāṃ svayaṃbhuvi svayaṃbhuvaḥ śāsanadhurdhareṣu ca /
column2: For he who knows for himself has departed on the Supreme Path, as well as the supports of the Law of the one who knows for himself: the world no longer has a Protector.
The defilements, which destroy spiritual qualities, now have full liiberty.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: iti kaṇṭhagataprāṇaṃ viditvā śāsanaṃ muneḥ / balakālaṃ malānāṃ ca na pramādyaṃ mumukṣubhiḥ //
column2: Seeing that the Law of the Muni is in its last breath, andThose who desire liberation should be diligent.
Syam, entitled "Instruction in the Absorptions.

Refutation of the pudgala.
namo buddhāya	Homage to the Buddha.
kiṃ khalvato 'nyatra mokṣo nāsti /	Is there any liberation outside of Buddhism?
nāsti /	No, there is not.
kiṃ kāraṇam /	What is the reason for this?
vitathātmadṛṣṭiniviṣṭatvāt /	There is no liberation outside of this teaching, because other doctrines are corrupted by a false conception of a soul.
nahi te skandhasaṃtāna evātmaprajñaptiṃ vyavasyanti / kiṃ tarhi /	The word as other doctrines conceive it is not a metaphoric expression for a series of skandhas.
dravyāntaramevātmānaṃ parikalpayanti ātmagrāhaprabhavāśca sarvakleśā iti /	By the power of their belief in this soul as a substantial entity, there arises clinging to the soul, the defilements are generated, and liberation is impossible.
kathaṃ punaridaṃ gamyate skandhasaṃtāna evedamātmābhidhānaṃ vartate nānyasminnabhidheya iti / pratyakṣānumānābhāvāt /	How do we know that the word soul" is only a designation for a series of skandhas, and that no soul exists in and of itself?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye hi dharmāḥ santi teṣāṃ pratyakṣamupalabdhirbhavatyasatyantarāye / tadyathā ṣaṇṇāṃ viṣayāṇāṃ manasaśca /
column2: We know this because no proof establishes the existence of a soul apart from the skandhas, no proof by direct perception, nor any proof from inference. If the soul were a real entity, separate like other.
In fact, the five organs are known through inference.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sati kāraṇe kāraṇāntarasyābhāve kāryasyābhāvo dṛṣṭo bhāve ca punarbhāvistadyathāṅkurasya /
column2: In the world, despite the presence of general causes, a result is not produced if certain specific causes are absent: for a sprout to be generated, one needs not only water, earth, and human effort, but also a seed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satyeva cābhāsaprāpte viṣaye manaskāre ca kāraṇe viṣayagrahaṇasyābhāvo dṛṣṭaḥ punaśca bhāvo 'ndhavadhirādīnāmanandhāvadhirādīnāṃ ca / atastatrāpi kāraṇāntarasyābhāvo bhāvaśca niścīyate /
column2: In the same way, even though general causes — the presence of an external object, attention, etc. ,-—-are present, the blind and the deaf do not see and hear to the extent that the non-blind and the non-deaf see and hear.

The first are lacking, whereas the second have the specific causes for visual and auditory consciousness: these are the organs, material organs that are made of an invisible and intangible matter, and which is known only through inference.
There is neither direct perception nor inference of a soul independent of the skandhas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattrhi vātsīputriyāḥ pudgalaṃ santimicchanti / vicāryaṃ tāvadetat / kiṃ te dravyata icchantyāhosvit prajñaptitaḥ /
column2: We know then that a real soul doesThe Vātsīputrīyas admit a pxágala which is neither identical to the skandhas nor different from them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ cedaṃ dravyata iti kiṃ vā prajñaptitaḥ /
column2: We should examine whether this prdgala exists as an entity or as designation of a nominal existence.
If it has a separate existence, like physical matter, then the puágala exists as an entity.
If it is only a collection, Iiike milk, then it exists as a designation.
What is wrong with admitting the first or the second hypothesis?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃbhinna svabhāvatvāt skandhebhyo 'nyo vaktavya itaretaraskandhavat / kāraṇaṃ cāsya vaktavyam /
column2: If the pudgala is an entity, it will be different from the skandhas, because its nature is separate, as the sēandhas are different one from another, and you will have to name its causes;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asaṃskṛto vā / atastīrthikadṛṣṭiprasaṅgo niṣprayojanatvaṃ ca / atha prajñaptitaḥ / vayamapyevaṃ trūmaḥ /
column2: or it will be unconditioned: and this is a non-Buddhist opinion; and if it is unconditioned, the pudgala will be useless.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva hi dravyato 'sti nāpi prajñaptitaḥ / kiṃ tarhi / ādhyātmikānupāttānvarttamānān skandhānupādāya pudgalaḥ prajñapyate /
column2: (It is thus false to believe that the pxdgala is an entity. ) But if you admit that the pudgala exists only as a title of designation, you will abandon your doctrine and you will be placed within our doctrines.
A blind response, containing little to enlighten us!
What does the expression "in relation to' mean?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyayamarhtaḥ skandhānāṃ lakṣyate teṣveva pudgalaprajñaptiḥ prāpnoti / yathā rūpādīnālamvya teṣveva kṣīraprajñaptiḥ / athāyamarthaḥ skandhān pratīyeti /
column2: If you explain séandhān upādāya as skandhānāṁ lakṣate, you must then say "The designation pudgala occurs by taking the elements as an object" this is to recognize that puágala is a word designating the rkandhas, the same as the designation "milk" occurs taking as its object the constituents of milk—color, etc. If you explain skandhān upādāya as skandhān pratītya 'conditioned by the skandhas," the same conclusion follows.
You admit, in fact, that it is the rkandhas which are the cause of the designation pudgala.
This is not the way that we conceive of the pndgala and its relationship with the séandhas, but rather as the world conceives of fire and its relationship with fuel.
How does it conceive of fire and its relationship with fuel? The world conceives of fire "in relation to fuel" they do not conceive of fire independent of fuel;
they believe that fire is not identical with fuel nor different from fuel.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi vinendhanenāgniḥ prajñapyate na cānya indhanādagniḥ śakyate prajñapayituṃ nāpyananyaḥ / yadi hānyaḥ syādanuṣṇamindhanaṃ syāt /
column2: If fire were different from fuel, fuel would not be hot;
if fire were the same as fuel the consumed would be the consumer.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ na ca vinā skanvaiḥ pudgalaḥ prajñapyate /
column2: In the same way we do not conceive of the pudgala as independent of the skandhas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na cānyaḥ skandhebhyaḥ śakyate pratijñātuṃ śāśvataprasaṅgāt / nāpyananya ucchedaprasaṅgaditi /
column2: we hold that the pudgala is neither identical to the séandhas nor different from the skandhas: if it were different from the skandhas, it would be eternal and thus unconditioned; but if it were identical to the skaṇndhas, it would then be susceptible of annihilation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: aṅga tāvadbrūhi kigindhanaṃ ko 'nniriti / tato jñāsyāmaḥ kathamindhanamupādāyāgniḥ prajñapyata iti /
column2: Define the terms "fire" and "fuel," so that I can better understand what the expression "fire in relation to fuel" signifies.
What shall we say to you? The consumed is the fuel, the consumer is fire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: etadevātra vaktavyaṃ kiṃ dāhyaṃ kok dāhaka iti /
column2: But that is precisely what I want to know with precision: what is the thing consumed, and what is the thing that is the consumer? In the world, a thing to be burned, not on.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: loke hi tāvadapradīptaṃ kāṣṭḥādikamindhanamucyate dāhyaṃ ca /
column2: the thing that exercises the action of burning, bright, very hot, in flames, is called the consumer or fire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pradīptamagnirdāhakaśca / yacca bhasvaraṃ coṣṇaṃ ca bhṛśaṃ ca tena hi tadidhyate dhyate ca / saṃtativikārāpādānāt /
column2: The series that constitutes the fuel, is ignited by the fire, and it is reduced to ashes;
by means of fire, each moment of existence of the series of fuel is made different from the preceeding moment. The fire and fuel are both made up of eight substances;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā kṣīraṃ pratītya dadhi madhu pratītyaśuktam / tasmādhigdhanamupādāyetyucyate /
column2: consequently, fire is generated by reason of the fuel, as milk ferments and vinegar is created by reason of milk and wine.

This is why the world agrees in saying that fire exists “in relation to fuel”” If this were the case, fire is different from the fuel, as their time-periods are different: there is first fuel, and then fire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi caiyaṃ pudgalaḥ skandhān pratītyotpadyate sa tebhyo 'nyaścānityaśca prāpnoti /
column2: If your pndgala exists in relation to the skandhas, as fire exists in relation to fuel, you then have to admit that, since it is produced by reason of the skandhas, it is different from the skandhas, and that it is, moreover, transitory.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha punastatraiva kāṣṭhādau pradīpte yadīṣṇyaṃ tadagnistatsahajātāni trīṇi bhūtānīndhanamiṣyante /
column2: In the thing set on fire, wood, etc. , one of the substances, namely a tangible object which is heat, is the fire; the other substances are the fuels. Then your remark on the priority in time of the fuel does not hold.
But fire and fuel, generated at the same time, are “separate,” since their characteristics are distinct.
The meaning that you attribute to the expression 'in relation to' has not yet been explained.
Since fire and fuel are generated at the same time, how can one say that fire exists in relation to fuel?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi tattasya kāraṇaṃ nāpi tat prajñapteḥ /
column2: Fire, which is one of the substances of the object on fire, does not have fuel for a cause, which is the other substances of the said object, since all these substances were generated at the same time, each from its own, separate cause.
One can say no more than that the term “fire” had for a cause fuel, since this term is applied to the tangible “heat.”
The expression “fire in relation to fuel” means that the fire has fuel as its basis, or that the fire coexists.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: skandhā apyevaṃ pudgalasyāśrayasahabhūtāḥ prāpnuvantīti vispaṣṭamanyatvaṃ pratijñāyate / tadabhāve ca pudgalābhāvaḥ prāpnoti /
column2: This means that the pwdgala coexists with the skandhas or that it depends on the skandhas: this then admits that it differs from the rkandhas.
And logic demands also that, as fire does not exist when fuel is absent, likewise the pudgala does not exist without skandhas. You do not admit these conclusions; then your explanation is worthless.
Fire is not different from fuel, because, in this hypothesis, fuel would not be hot.
What does "hot" mean?
If "hot" is defined as being the tangible heat", as has been done above, then fuel will not be hot (since fuel is the object on fire, without the tangible element "heat").
If "hot" is that which is associated with heat (i.

, if one admits that fuel is termed hot by reason of its association with heat), then this means that different things are called "hot": the one tangible "heat" is designated by "fire" and all that is associated with this tangible is designated by the name "hot. To think thus is to confess that fuel is termed hot although.
The Vātsīputrīyas are thus justified in saying that “fire is not different from fuel since fuel is hot.” Wood on fire is called fuel;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha punaḥ sarvameva tat pradīptaṃ kāṣṭhādikamindhanaṃ cāgniśceṣyate /
column2: it is also called fire.
Explain then the meaning that you attribute to the expression “fire in relation to fuel”!

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: skandhā eva ca pudgalā ityananyatvamanivāryaṃ prāpnoti / tasmānna sidhyatyetat /
column2: The puágala (the active data of relation, of the pādāya) will be identical to the skandhas (passive data of the said “relation”): no reasoning can establish the non-identity.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathendhanamupādāyāgniḥ prajñapyate evaṃ skadhānupādāya pudgalaḥ iti /
column2: The thesis of the Vātsīputrīyas, that the puágala exists in relation to the séandhas as fire exists in relation to fuel, cannot be rationally established in any hypothesis. The puágala is ineffable in that which concerns its relationship—its identity or non-identity—with the skaendhas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cāyamanyaḥ skandhebhyo na vaktavyaḥ “pañcavidhaṃ jñeyamatītānāgataṃ pratyupannamasaṃskṛtamavaktavyami“ti na vaktavyaṃ prāpnoti /
column2: How can they distinguish '‘five categories of things susceptible of being known”ʼ: 1-3. conditioned things, in other words, past, present, and future things; unconditioned, or non-caused things, and 5.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva hi tadatītādibhyaḥ pañcamaṃ nāpañcamaṃ vaktavyam /
column2: the ineffable ”?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadā ca pudgalaḥ prajñapyate ki tāvatskandhānupalabhya prajñapyate āhosvit pudgalam /
column2: Let us examine what this word "pudgala" depends on.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tāvat skandhāṃsteṣveva pudgalaprajñaptiḥ prāpnoti / pudgalasyānupalambhāt /
column2: If it depends on the skandhas, then the pudgala exists solely as a designation, as the expression "pwágaula" depends on the skandhas and not on a real pudgala.
If it depends on a real pudgala, why did the Vātsīputrīyas say that the designation "pudgala" is 'in relation to the skandhas'?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pudgala eva hi tasyā upādānaṃ prāpnoti /
column2: Then would have had to say "'in relation to the pudgala. But, in fact, they do not maintain that the pudgala is established in relation to a pudgala.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha mataṃ satsu skandheṣu pudgala upalabhyate tataḥ skandhānupādāyāsya prajñaptirucyata iti /
column2: Moreover, the expression pudgala is a simple designation of skandhas. Given the skandhas, the pudgala is perceived: that is why we say that the designation "pudgala" is "with relation to the skandhas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadevaṃ rūpasyāpi cakṣurmanaskārālokeṣu satsūpalambhāt tānupādāya prajñaptirbaktavyā /
column2: But color is perceived when diverse causes are present, the eye, light, etc. ;
may we thereby conclude that the designation "color" is.
Another point.
By which of the six consciousnesses—consciousnesses of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, or mental consciousness—is the pudgala perceived?
It is perceived by all six consciousnesses.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣurvijñeyāni cedrūpāṇi pratītyapudgalaṃ pratibhāvayati cakṣurvijñeyaḥ pudgalo vaktavyaḥ no tu vaktavyo rūpāṇi vāno vā /
column2: When the eye consciousness recognizes physical matter, it indirectly discerns the pudgala, and then we can say that the pudgala is known by the eye consciousness. But the relationship of the pudgala with physical matter, be it identical or different, is inexpressible.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ yāvat manovijñeyān ceddharmān pratītya pudgalaṃ prativibhāvayati manovijñeyaḥ pudgalo vaktavyo no tu vaktavyo dharmā vā no vā /
column2: The same for the other consciousnesses: when the mental consciousness recognizes the dharmas (mind and mental states), it indirectly discerns the pudgala; it is then known by the mental consciousness, but its relationship with these states is inexpressible.
It follows from this explanation too that the pudgala exists solely as a designation exactly like milk.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cakṣurvijñeyāni cedrūpāṇi pratītya kṣīraṃ vibhāvayatyudakaṃ vā cakṣurvijñeyaṃ kṣīramudakaṃ ceti vaktavyaṃ no tu vaktavyaṃ rūpāṇi vā no vā /
column2: When the eye consciousness recognizes the color of milk, it indirectly discerns the milk: the milk is then known by the eye consciousness and one cannot.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ ghrāṇajihvākāyavijñeyaṃ vaktavyaṃ no tu vaktavyaṃ spraṣṭavyāni vā no vā /
column2: The same for ear, nose, tongue, and body consciousness: the body consciousness recognizes tangibles; from whence there is the consciousness of milk; the milk is then known by the body consciousness without which one could only say that the milk is identical to the tangible, or different from the tangible.
In fact milk is not fourfold: then it is not color, smell, taste, tangible; but furthermore, one cannot say that the milk is not made of these four.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato yathā rūpādīnyeva kṣīramudakaṃ vā prajñapyate samastānyevaṃ skandhāḥ pudgala iti siddham /
column2: The conclusion is that one metaphorically designates a complex of elements by “pv dgala,” the same as the designation “milk” is understood as a coming together of color, smell, etc. They are merely names without reality.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaccocyate cakṣurvijñeyāni rūpāṇi pratītya pudgalaṃ prativibhāvayatīti / ko 'sya vākyasyārthaḥ / kiṃ tāvadrūpāṇi pudgalopalabdheḥ kāraṇaṃ bhavatiti āhosvidrūpāṇyupalabhamānaḥ pudgalamupalabhata iti /
column2: What meaning do you therefore attach to the phrase, “When the eye consciousness recognizes physical matter, it indirectly discerns the pudgala?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi rūpāṇi pudgalopalabdheḥ kāraṇaṃ bhavanti sa ca tebhyo 'nyo na vaktavyaḥ / evaṃ tarhi rūpamapyālokacakṣurmanaskārebhyo 'nyanna vaktavyam / teṣāṃ tadupalabdhikāraṇatvāt /
column2: Do you want to say that physical matter is the cause of the perception of the pudgala, or that the perceptionIf the Vātsīputrīyas answer that physical matter is the cause of the perception of the pwudgala but that, nevertheless, one cannot say that the pudgala is different from physical matter, then the condition and the causes of the perception of physical matter—eye, light, an act of attention—would not be different from physical matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha rūpāṇyupalabhamānaḥ pudgalamupalabhate / kiṃ tayaivopalabdhyopalabhate āhosvidanyayā / yadi tayaiva /
column2: If the Vātsīputrīyas answer that one perceives the pudgala at the same time as one perceives physical matter, we would question whether one perceives the pudgala by the same operation which perceives physical matter, or by a different operation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: rūpādabhinnasvabhāvaḥ pudgalaḥ prāpnoti rūpa eva vā tatprajñāptiḥ /
column2: In the first hypothesis, the pudágala is only physical matter and the designation ““pudágala”” applies only to physical matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: idaṃ ca rūpamayaṃ pudgalaḥ kathamidaṃ gamyate / athaivaṃ na paricchidyate /
column2: It is then impossible to distinguish “This is physical matter; that is pudgala.”
Without this distinction, how can one prove that there is physical matter and that there is a pudágala?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: upalabdhivaśena hi tasyāstitvaṃ pratijñāyate / evaṃ yāvaddharmebhyo vaktavyam /
column2: The existence of the pndgala caṇṉot be proven by this distinction.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athānyayā bhinnakālo palambhādanyo rūpātprāpnoti / nīlādiya pītaṃ kṣaṇādiva ca kṣaṇāntaram /
column2: The pudgala will be as different from color and shape as yellow is from blue, as former is from latter.
The same reasoning follows for the other séandhas.

As one cannot say that the puāgala is the saṃe thing as color and shape, nor that it is different from color and shape, likewise the perception of the pudgala is not the same as the perception of the color and shape, nor different from this petception.

TwThis point of view obliges you to say that the perception of the pnudgala, being ineffable, is not made part of the category of “conditioned things”: but now you do not admit this thesis, since, for you, all perception is “conditioned”.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cāyamasti no tu vaktavyo rūpāṇi vā to vā / kiṃ tarhi bhagavatoktaṃ “rūpamanātmā yāvadvijñānamanātme“ti /
column2: If the pudgala is an entity that one cannot define as being matter nor as being non-marter, why did the Blessed Oṇne say that "“matter and the other skandhas are not self”?
The pudgala, you say, is attained by the eye consciousness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ tadrūpāṇi pratītyotpadyate āhosvit pudgalamubhayaṃ vā / yadi rūpāṇi pratītyotpadyate /
column2: IsThis consciousness generated by color and shape, or by the pudgala, or both?

In the first hypothesis, one cannot maintain that this eye consciousness perceives the pudgala, because the pudgala is not the object of this consciousness, as neither is sound. In fact, all consciousnesses that are produced having as their condition a certain thing, has this same thing as an "object as condition"; now the pudgala, not being a condition of the eye consciousness, cannot be its object. Thus the visual consciousness does not perceive the pudgala.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yameva hi viṣayaṃ cakṣurvijñāneṣu pratītyotpadyate vijñānaṃ sa eva tasyālambanapratyayaḥ / atha pudgalaṃ pratītyotpadyate ubhayaṃ vā / idamutsūtram /
column2: The other two hypotheses contradict the Sutra which says that the eye consciousness is generated by reason of two things, namely, by the eye and by physical matter and shape.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sūtre hi nirdhāritaṃ dvayaṃ pratītya vijñānasyotpādo bhavatīti / “tathā cakṣurbhikṣo hetū rūpāṇi pratyayaścakṣurvijñānasyotpādāya / tatkasya hetoḥ /
column2: The Sutra says "Oh Bhikshus, eye consciousness is generated having the eye as its cause and physical matter as its condition (pratyaya = alambanapratyaya).

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatkiñcit bhikṣo cakṣurvijñānaṃ sarvaṃ taccakṣuḥ pratītya rūpāṇi ceti / anityaśca pudgala evaṃ prāpnoti /
column2: All eye consciousness is by reason of the eye and physical matter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “ye hi hetayo ye pratyayā vijñānasyotpādāya te 'pyanityā” iti sūtre vacanāt /
column2:
If the pudgala is the cause of the eye consciousness, it will be.
atha pudgalo na tasyālambanaṃ na tarhi tena vijñeyaḥ /	We admit then that the pudgala is not an object as condition of consciousness. Very well; but then it is not discernible, an object of vijnana; if it is not discernible, it is not cognizable, the object of jnana; if it is not cognizable, how can one prove that it exists? If one cannot prove that it exists, your system collapses.
yadi ca pudgalaḥ ṣaḍvijñānavijñeyaḥ pratijñāyate /	You have said that the pudgala is discerned by the six consciousnesses.
sa śrotravijñānavijñeyatvādrūpādanyaḥ prāpnoti śabdhavat /	But, if it is discerned by the eye consciousness, it will be, like physical matter and shape, different from sound;
caturvijñānavijñeyatvācchabdādanyaḥ prāpnoti rūpavat /	if it is discerned by the ear consciousness, it will be, like sound, different from physical matter and shape.
evamanyebhyo 'pi yojyam /	And thus for those that follow.
idaṃ ca sūtrapadaṃ vādhitaṃ bhavati /	Moreover, your thesis is in contradiction to the Sutra.
“yānīmāni brāhmaṇa pañcendriyāṇi nānāgocarāṇi nānāviṣayāṇi svaṃ svaṃ gocaraviṣyaṃ pratyanubhavanti / nānyadanyasya gocaraviṣyaṃ pratyanubhavati / tadyathā cakṣurindriyaṃ śrotrendriyaṃ ghrāṇendriyaṃ jihvendriyaṃ kāyendriyam /	The Sutra says, “Oh Brahmin, the five organs (of sight, hearing, smell, taste, touch) have distinct spheres and objects. Each one of them perceives its own sphere and its own object.
mana eṣaṃ pañcānāmindriyāṇāṃ gocaraviṣayaṃ pratyanubhavati manaścaiṣāṃ pratisaraṇami“ti /	And the mental organ perceives the spheres and the objects of the first five organs, and they have the mental organ as their refuge.
na vā pudgalo viṣayaḥ /	Or rather would you say, in agreement with the Sūtra, that the pudgala is not the object?
na cedviṣayo na tarhi vijñeyaḥ /	In this case, it would not be discerned, and you put yourself in contradiction to your own system. (You affirm, according to the Sūtra, that each of the five organs has its own object, and you thus conclude that the pudgala is not the object of eye consciousness).
yadyevaṃ manaindriyasyāpyavyabhicāraḥ prāpnoti /	But, according to the Sūtra, the mental organ also has its own object.
ṣaḍimānīndriyāṇi nānāgocarāṇi nānāviṣayāṇi svaṃ svaṃ gocaraviṣayamākāṅkṣantī tyuktaṃ ṣaṭprāṇakopame /	In fact, the Ṣatprāṇakopama-sūtra says, “Each of these six organs has its own object and its own sphere; each seeks after its object and its sphere.”
na ttrendriyamemvendriyaṃ kṛtvoktam / pañcānāṃ darśanādyā kāṅkṣaṇāsaṃbhavāt tadvijñānānāṃ ca / atastadādhipatyādhyākṛtamatra manovijñānendriyaṃ kṛtvoktam /	This Sūtra does not intend to speak of the six organs, because the five material organs and the five consciousnesses which are dependent on them do not possess the desire to see, to hear, etc. This Sūtra understands, by organ of the eye, etc. , the mental.
yacca tatkevalaṃ mana ādhipatyādhyākṛtaṃ manovijñānaṃ naivaṃ tadanyeṣāṃ viṣayamākāṅkṣatyato nāstyeṣa doṣaḥ /	By this fact, the mental consciousness which is isolated—that is to say, which is not induced and dominated by one of the five material organs, but solely by the mental organ—does not have any desire with regard to the spheres and objects of the five organs, but solely with regard to the dharmāyatana. Thus the Ṣatprāṇakopama-sūtra does not contradict the Śūtra previously quoted.
uktaṃ ca bhagavatā “sarvābhijñeyaṃ vo bhikṣavo dharmaparyāyaṃ deśayiṣyāmī“tyuktvā cakṣurabhijñeyaṃ rūpāṇi cakṣurvijñānaṃ cakṣuḥsaṃsparśo yadapi taccakṣuḥsaṃsparśapratyayamadhyātmamutpadyate veditaṃ suḥkhaṃ vā aduḥkhāsukhaṃ vā yāvat manaḥsaṃsparśapratyayam /	The Blessed One has said, “Oh Bhikṣus, I declare to you all the dharmas that should be penetrated and known , namely: the eyes, physical matter, eye consciousness, eye contact, the sensation which is produced having as a cause eye contact, painful, pleasant, and neither painful nor pleasant sensation. And thus following to: `the sensation which is produced having as its cause contact with the mental organ: these are what should be penetrated and known.
ayamucyate sarvābhijñeyaparijñeyo dharmaparyāyaḥ iti /	This text teaches us that the dharmas to be penetrated and comprehended are only those enumerated.
ata etāvadevābhijñeyaṃ pratijñeyaṃ cetyavardhāryate na pudgalaḥ / tasmādvijñeyo 'pyasau na bhavati /	The pudgala does not figure in this list: then it.
prajñāvijñānayoḥ samānaviṣayatvāt /	In fact, the speculative consciousness by which one penetrates or comprehends, has the same sphere as does ordinary consciousness. The masters who maintain that the eye sees the pudgala should learn that the eye sees only that which is real in the pudgala.
cakṣuṣa ca pudgalaṃ paśyām iti paśyanta paudgalikā anātmanā ātmānaṃ paśyāma iti dṛṣṭisthānamāpannā bhavanti /	They fall into the abyss of harmful views in saying that it sees a soul in what is not a soul. Furthermore, the Buddha explained that the word p$#dgala designates the skandhas.
sūtre ca bhagavatā nītametat / “skandheṣveva pudgalādhye“ti mānuṣyakasūtram / “cakṣuḥpratītya rūpāṇi cotpadyate cakṣurvijñānaṃ trayāṇāṃ saṃnipātaḥ sparśaḥ sparśasahajātā	In the Sūtra of Man, he said, Supported by the eye, having physical matter for its object and condition, the visual consciousness arises: by reason of the coming together of these three, contact arises;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vedanā saṃjñā cetanā itīme catvāro rupiṇaḥ skandhāśvakṣurindriyaṃ ca rūpametāvanmanuṣyatvamucyate /
