prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathāpi tu yathā bhūtamātraṃ rūpamevaṃ skandhamātraṃ pudgala ityabhyupetaṃ bhavati /
column2: But, to adopt the opinion that you wrongly attribute to us, we say that in the manner that secondary matter is made up of the four elements, in that way the five skandhas constitute the pudgala.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi skandhamātraṃ pudgalaḥ kasmāt bhagavatā sa jīvastaccharīrakanyo veti navyākṛtam /
column2: If the puágala is only a word serving to designate the five sēandhas, why did the Buddha not declare that the vital principal is the body?
Because the Buddha takes into consideration the intention of whomever asks him questions.
The person who asks this question of the Buddha understood by jṝva, not a being, a simple designation of the skandhas, but a person, a real living entity;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa ca kasmiścinnāstīti kathamasyānyatvamananyatvaṃ vā vyākriyatām /
column2: and he was thinking of this person when he asked if the jṝva is identical to the body or different from the body. Now this jṝva does not absolutely exist; and so the Buddha only maintained that it is neither identical to nor different from the body, and then the Blessed One condemned the two answers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kaurmasyeva romṇo 'ntaḥkharatā mṛdutā vā / eṣa ca granthaḥ pūrvakaireva nirmocitaḥ /
column2: In like manner one cannot say that the hairs of a tortoise are hard or soft.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sthāviro hi nāgasenaḥkaliṅgena rājñopasaṃkramyoktaḥ / “pṛccheyamahaṃ bhadantam bahuvollakāśca śravaṇā bhavanti /
column2: At that time, the King of Kalinga went up to him and said, “I have come with the intention of clearing up my doubts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi yadeva pṛccheyaṃ tadeva vyākuryā iti / pṛcchetyuktaḥ pṛṣṭavān /
column2: But monks are verbose: shall we agree that you answer plainly to the questions that I ask?”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kiṃ nu sa jīvastaccharīramanyio jīvo 'nyaccharīramiti / avyākṛtametadityavocat sthaviraḥ /
column2: Nāgasena accepted his request and the King asked, 'Is the vital principal identical to the body or different from the body?
“To this question,”’ said Nāgasena, `there are no grounds for answer.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nanu bhadantaḥ pūrvameva pratijñāṃ kārito nā 'nyadvacyākartavyamiti /
column2: “Haven't we agreed that you shall answer plainly?
Why speak off the point and not answer?”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ahamapi mahārājaṃ pṛccheyaṃ bahuvollakāśca rājāno bhavanti /
column2: “I wish to ask the King concerning a doubt.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi yadeva pṛccheyaṃ tadeva vyākuryā iti /
column2: But kings are verbose: shall we agree that the King answers plainly to the question that I shall ask?”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: pṛcchetyuktaḥ pṛṣṭavān / yaste 'ntaḥpure ābhravṛkṣastasya kimamlāni phalāni āhosvit madhurāṇīti /
column2: The King consented and Nāgasena asked, “Do the mangos in the King’s palace give sweet fruit or bitter fruit?”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva mamāntaḥpure kaścidābhravṛkṣo 'stītyāha / nanu mayā pūrvameva mahārājaḥ pratijñāṃ kārito nānyadvacyākartavyamiti / kimidamanyadevoktamābhra eva nāstīti /
column2: And the King answered him, “There are no mango trees within my palace.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa āha kathamasato vṛkṣasya phalānāmamlatāṃ madhuratāṃ vā vyākaromīti /
column2: Nāgasena protested as the King“But,” said the King, “as there are no mangos in my palace, how could there be any sweet or bitter fruits?”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evameva mahārāja sa eva jīvo nāsti kuto 'sya śarīrādanyatāmananyatāṃ vā vyākaromīti /
column2: “In the same way, Oh King, the vital principal does not exist: one cannot then answer your question and say that it is identical to the body or different from the body.”
But, if the pudágala does not exist, why didn’t the Blessed One answer that the ñāva absolutely does not exist?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa hi yasyāpi skandhasaṃtānasya jīva ityākhyā tasyāpyabhāvaṃ pratīyāditi mithyādṛṣṭiṃ pātitaḥ syāt /
column2: Because he took into consideration the intention of the questioner, that questioning on the jṝva may be with the idea that the jṝva is a series of skandhas. If the Blessed One answered that the jṝva absolutely does not exist, the questioner would have fallen into false views.

Furthernore, as the questioner was not capable of understanding “dependent origination’”” ,he was not a fit receptacle for the Good Law: the Blessed Oṇe then did not tell him that the ṝāva exists except by way of designation.
The explanation that we have given here is the same that theI did not answer him.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yat bhagavatoktam “astyātmetyānanda vatsasagotrāya parivrājakāya praśnaṃ pṛṣṭo vyākuryāṃ nanvakalpaṃ syādvacanāya sarvadharmā anātmāna iti /
column2: In fact, to answer that there is a soul is to contradict the truth of things, because no dharma is a soul nor has any relationship with a soul;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nāstyātmetyānanda vatsasagotrāya parivrājakāya praśnaṃ pṛṣṭo vyākuryāṃ nanu vatsasagotraḥ parivrājakaḥ pūrvameva saṃmūḍho bhūyasyā mātrayā saṃmohamāpadyeta abhūt me ātmāsa me etarhi nāstīti /
column2: and if I had answered that there is no soul, I would have increased the folly of Vatsagotra, for he would have thought: ‘I had a soul, but this soul does not now exist. For, in comparison to the folly of the belief in the existence of a soul, this second folly is graver.
Whoever believes in the soul falls into the extreme view of eternity;
whoever believes that the soul does not exist falls into the extreme view of annihilation. Thoughtless error, heavy error…”, and so on. It has been said;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: dṛṣṭidaṃṣṭrāvabhadaṃ ca braṃśaṃ cāpekṣya karmaṇām / deśayanti jinā dharma vyāgrīpītāpahāravat //
column2: Taking into consideration the injury that heresy does and, also, the falling off of good deeds, the Buddhas teach the Law in the manner in which a tigress carries its young.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmāstitvaṃ hyupagato bhinnaḥ syāddṛṣṭidaṃṣṭrayā bhraṃśaṃ kukśalapotasya kuryādaprāpya saṃvṛtimi“ti /
column2: Those who believe in the reality of the soul are torn by theThose who do not recognize the conventional self let their good actions fall away, and perish.
And again: Since a real jṝva does not exist, the Buddha does not say that the jva is identical or non-identical;
he does not say any more than that the jñva does not really exist, fearing that one would only negate the conventioṇal jṝva.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yatra hi skandhasaṃtāne śubhāśubhaphalāstitā / jīvākhyā tatra sā na syāt jīvanāstitvadeśanāt //
column2: Series of skandhas, actions, and the results of actions are what are termed jṝva: if the Buddha were to negate the jṝva, he would negate actions and their results.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: prajñaptimātraṃ skandhesu jīva ityapināvadat / abhavyaḥ śūnyatāṃ boddhuṃ tadānīṃ tādṛśo janaḥ //
column2: And if the Buddha does not say that the so-called jñva is in the skandhas it is because he sees that the questioner is not capable of tolerating the teaching of emptiness.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathā hyātmāsti nāstīti pṛṣṭo vāstyeva nāvadat /
column2: It is then because of the state of mind of Vatsa that the Buddha, asked if there was a soul, yes or no, did not answer.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: āśayāpekṣāyā praṣṭuḥ sati tvastīti nāha kim //
column2: But if the soul were to exist, why wouldn’t he have answered that it exists?

The Buddha did not answer four questions relative to the eteṟnity of the world: again this is because he took into account the incapacity of the questioner. Consideration the intention of the questioner.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi hi tāvadātmā loka iṣṭaḥ syāttasyābhāvādayuktaṃ caturdhā vyākaraṇam / atha sarva eva saṃsāro lokastasyāpyayuktam /
column2: If such a person understands Joéka to be a soul, the four alternatives are incorrect, since the soul does not absolutely exist. If he understands oka to be transmigration or saṁsāra, the four alternatives are incorrect;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śāśvate loke na kasyacit parinirvāṇaṃ prāpnuyāt /
column2: if transmigration is eternal, no one could obtain Nirvāṇa;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śāśvate loke na kasyacit parinirvāṇaṃ prāpnuyāt / aśāśvate sarvepāmucchedaḥ prāpnuyāt / ubhayathātve niyamata ekeṣāṃ parinirvāṇaṃ prāpnuyāt ekeṣāṃ na /
column2: if it is not eternal, all would obtain Nirvana by spontaneous annihilation, and not through effort: if it is both eternal and non-eternal, some would never obtain Nirvāṇa, whereas others would obtain it spontaneously;
finally, to say that Joka, in the sense of sarṁsára, is neither eternal nor non-eternal, is to say that beings both would and would not obtain Nirvāṇa: a contradiction in terms.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ato mārgadhīnatvāt parinirvāṇasya caturdhāpi niyamo na vyākriyate nirgrantha4rāvakacaṭakavat /
column2: In fact, Nirvāṇa is possible through the Way; then no categorical response is acceptable. In the same way the Buddha did not answer the Nirgranthaśrāvaka who held a bird in his hand and asked if this bird was dead or alive.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata evāntavān loka iti catuṣkāvyākaraṇam / tulyārtho hyeṣa catuṣkaḥ /
column2: The four questions as to whether the world is infinite, namelyif it has an end or not, has the same sense as the questions relative to the eternity of the world, and present the same defect.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tathāhi muktikaḥ parivrājaka eva catuṣkaṃ pṛṣṭvā punaḥ pṛṣṭavān kiṃ nu sarvo loko 'nena mārgeṇa niryātyāhosvidekadeśo lokasye“ti /
column2: How do we know that "the infinity of the world" should be understood in this sense? The wandering monk Uktika, after having asked the Buddha about infinity, resorted to a ruse in order to repeat his question and asked, "Does the whole world obtain deliverance through the Way, or only a part of the world?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sthavira ānanda āha “yameva tvaṃ muktika tatprathamato bhagavantaṃ praśnaṃ pṛṣṭavāṃstame vaitarhi pṛcchasyanena paryāyeṇe“ti sarvam /
column2: The elder Ānanda then said to him, "You have already posed this question, Uktika. Why do you repeat it by changing the terms?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhavati tathāgataḥ paraṃ maranādityapi catuṣkaḥ praṣṭurāśayāpekṣayā na vyākṛtaḥ /
column2: If the Blessed One did not explain concerning the four questions relative to the existence of the Tathāgata after death, this is again because he took into account the intentions of the questioner.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa hi muktvāmānaṃ tathāgataṃ kṛtvā pṛṣṭavān /
column2: Such a person understood the Tathāgata to be a "soul" liberated from the defilements.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: paudgalikastu paryanuyojyaḥ kiṃ kāraṇaṃ bhagavān jīvantaṃ pudgalamastīti vyākaroti paraṃ maraṇānna vyākarotīti /
column2: We ask in our turn those who hold to a "soul:" The Blessed One, according to you, declared that the pxdgala exists, indescribable: why did he not declare that the Tathāgata exists after death?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: śāśvata doṣaprasaṅgaḥ / idaṃ tarhi kasmādvacyākaroti “bhaviṣyasi tvaṃ maitreyānāgate 'dhvani tathāgato 'rhan saṃyaksaṃbuddha” iti / kasmācca śrāvakamabhyatītaṃ kālagatamupapattau vyākarotyamuko 'mutropapanna iti /
column2: If the Buddha kept silent on this point because he feared that the disciple, by admitting the survival of a pudgala named Tathāgata, would fall into the view of eternity, we would then ask why the Blessed One predicted to Maitreya, In the ages to come, you will be a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Samyaksambuddha; and speaking of one of his deceased disciples, he said, He is at present reborn in such a place.

Are not these discourses defiled by the opinion of permanence? If we answer that the Blessed One does not say anything concerning the deceased Tathāgata because, seeing at first the pudgala, he now no longer sees the pudgala once it has attained Nirvana; it is then through ignorance that the Tathāgata does not make any declaration concerning the deceased Tathāgata, and to speak thus is to deny the omniscience of the Master. Rather one should believe that if the Blessed One abstains from all declarations, it is because the soul that the questioner alluded to in speaking of the Tathāgata does not absolutely exist.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi ca bhagavān pūrvaṃ pudgalaṃ dṛṣṭvā parinirvṛtaṃ punaḥ na paśyatyajñānānna vyakarotīti sarvajñatvaṃ śāsturutpāditaṃ bhavati na vā so 'stītyabhyupagantavyam
column2: If the>Vatsiputriyas say that the Blessed One sees the pudgala, which is in Nirvana, but that he still does not make a statement on this subject;
and that the pudgala exists but is not, at the same time, an object of a statement of the Blessed One, we then conclude that admit that the pudgala is permanent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: arthatadapi na vaktavyaṃ paśyati vā naveti / evaṃ tarhi idamapi śanaiḥ śanairavaktavyaṃ kriyatāṃ sarvajño vā na vā bhagavānna veti /
column2: If say that "whether the Blessed One does or does not see the pudgala" is indescribable, they then proceed to say that all is indescribable, and that one can only say that the Blessed One is omniscient or non-omniscient.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: astyeva pudgalo yasmātsatyataḥ sthitito nāsti me ātmeti dṛṣṭisthānamuktam / astītyapi dṛṣṭisthānamuktam /
column2: The pudgala really exists, as it is said, that "To say that I really, truly do not have an aeman is an incorrect opinion.
This is not a proof, for it is also said that it is an incorrect opinion to affirm the existence of an aemegn.

Scholars of the Abhidharma think that a belief in the existence of an aeman and a belief in its non-existence are two extreme opinions, as they identify them with the two branches of "the opinion that consists in believing in extremes.
This doctrine is certain, as it is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “astyātmetyānanda śāśvatāya paraiti nāstyātmetyānandocchedāya paraitī“ti vātsyasūtre vacanāt /
column2: Ānanda, those who affirm a soul fall into the extreme of the belief in permanence; those who deny a soul fall into the extreme of the belief in annihilation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tarhi pudgalo nāsti ka eṣa saṃsarati /
column2: If the pudgala does not exist, what is it that wanders in ra/sāra?
In fact, one can only allow that sa/ṁsāra itself waṅders.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: uktaṃ ca bhagavatā “avidyānivaraṇānāṃ sattvanāṃ saṃdhāvatāṃ saṃsaratāmi“ti /
column2: Further the Blessed One has said, “Beings misled by ignorance, bound by thirst, wander here and there, either among beings in hell,among animals, among pretas, humans, or the gods; thus for a long time they experience all suffeṛing.
” How does the puvdgala wander in raṅsāra?
Would you say that this wandering consists in abandoning old réandhas and in taking up new skandhas?
But we have shown that this explanation is inadmissable.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathātu kṣaṇiko 'gniḥ saṃtatyā saṃsaratītyucyate tathā sattvākhyaḥ skndhasamudāyastṛṣṇopādānaḥ saṃsaratītyucyate /
column2: A good explanation is simple: one says that when a flame burns a field it travels, although they be only moments of flame, because it constitutes a series; in the same way the harmony of the rkandhas which is constantly repeated receives, metaphorically, the name of being; supported by thirst, the series of skandhas.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi skandhāmātramidaṃ kasmādāha bhagavān “grahameva sa tena kālena tena samayena sunetro nāma śāstā 'bhūvami“ti / kasmānna vaktavyaṃ syāt /
column2: If only the skandhas exist, we do not see how one can explain these words of the Blessed One, “In the past, I was the teacher Sunetra.

” In fact, in the hypothesis of the existence of the individual reandhas metaphorically termed “soul,” past skandhas are not the same as present skandhas, and so the Blessed One cannot express himself in this manner.
But what is the thing that the Blessed One calls “soul"?
The pudgala, you would say: then, since the “soul” is permanent, a past “soul” is identical with a present “soul”.

For us, when the Blessed One said, 'I was the teacher Sunetra,”' he teaches us that the skandhas that constitute his present “'soul’” formed part of the same series as the skandhas that constituted Sunetra.
In the same way one says, “This fire has been burning here. ” You affirm the existence of a real soul: we hold that only the Buddhas, Tathāgatas would see it.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi cātmā bhavettthāgatā eva suvyaktaṃ paśyeyuḥ /
column2: But if the Buddhas see a soul, they would produce a firm belief in a soul; fromThis belief in a soul there would be produced among them a belief in things pertaining to a soul;

from these two beliefs there would be produced among them affection for the soul and for things pertaining to a soul. The Blessed One said in fact that “whosoever believes in a soul, believes in things pertaining to a soul;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: “ātmani ca satyātmīyaṃ bhavatī“ti sūtre vacanādātmagrāho 'pyeṣāṃ skandheṣvadhikaṃ pravarteta /
column2: believing in things pertaining to a soul, they become attached to the skandhas as they form a soul and things pertaining to a soul.”
There would be then sa among the Buddhas;
they would be bound by affection for a soul and for things pertaining to a soul;
and they would be very far from liberation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha mataṃ naivātmani pravartate sneha iti /
column2: Affection is not produced with regard to a soul. We explain: when one recognizes a soul in what is not the soul, as do the non-Buddhists, one feels affection for this pretended soul;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat ka idānīmeṣa yogo yadanātmanyātmadhimokṣāt sneha utpadyate ātmanyeva tu notpadyate /
column2: but, when one sees the soul in that which is truly the soul, namely the ineffable pvdgala, as do the Buddhas, no affection is produced with regard to the soul. This statement has no support.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmāt dṛṣṭacyarvudametasmin śāsane utpannaṃ ya eṣa ekeṣāṃ pudgalagrāha ekeṣāṃ sarvanāstitāgrāhaḥ /
column2: The Vātsīputṛīyas, without anyWhereas there are those who admit an ineffable pudgala, others deny the existence of all the dharmas;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ye 'pi ca dravyāntaramevātmānaṃ manyante tīrthakārāstepāmeva mokṣābhāvadoṣo niṣkampaḥ /
column2: non-Buddhists imagine a soul apart from all other substances. All these doctrines are wrong and present the same flaw in that they do not lead to liberation.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi tarhi sarvathāpi nāstyātmā kathaṃ kṣaṇikeṣu citteṣu cirānubhūtasyārthasya smaraṇaṃ bhavati pratyabhijñānaṃ vā /
column2: If the soul does not absolutely exist, how can a mind—which perishes as soon as it is generated—be capable of remembering an object perceived a long time before? How is it able to recognize an object similar to what it has formerly perceived?

Memory and recognition are generated immediately, in a series, from a certain type of mind, when this type of mind arises from the idea of object already perceived and which one calls “object of the memory.”
What is the type of mind from whence memory immediately shoots up?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tādṛśo 'pi hyatadanvayaścittaviśeṣo na samarthaḥ tāṃ smṛtiṃ bhavayituṃ tadanvayo 'pi cānyādṛśo na samarthastāṃ smṛtiṃ bhavayitum /
column2: We answer: It's a certain mind, bent towards the object of memory, a mind in which one finds ideas related to that thing or resembling that thing, or even “resolutions” of a certain. It is necessary that a bending of the mind be produced, an act of atteation, towards the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: labhayathā tu samartha ityevaṃ smṛtirbhavatyanyasyāṃ sāmarthyādarśanāt /
column2: It is necessary that the mind involves an idea resembling the object, in the case where one remembers by reason of resemblance (for example, I remember fire perceived a long time ago because the idea of fire is placed in my mind by the sight of present fire). Or it is necessary that the mind involves an idea in relation to the object, in the case where one remembers without there being resemblance (for example, I remember fire because the idea of smoke is placed in my mind by the sight of smoke). Or it is necessary that the mind involves a praṃidhāna, or resolution, an abhyāsa, oṟ habit (fot example, the resolution has been placed in the mental series, I shall remember.
How can one mind see and another mind remember?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ hi devadattacetasā dṛṣṭaṃ yajñadattacetaḥ smaret / nāsambandhāt /
column2: It is contrary that Yajñadatta remembers an object that Devadatta has seen. That is right.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi tayoḥ saṃbandho 'sti akārya kāraṇabhāvādyathaikasaṃtānikayoḥ /
column2: There is no connection between Devadatta and Yajñadatta: Their minds are not in the relationship of cause and effect, as is the case for minds which form series.

Indeed, we do not say that one mind sees an object and that another mind remembers this object, because these two minds belong to the same series. WeSay that one past mind, bearing a certain object, brings about the existence of another mind, the present mind, capable of remembering this object.
In other words, a mind of memory is generated from a mind of seeing, as fruit is generated from the seed through the force of the last stage of the transformation of the series.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃtatipariṇatyā yathoktamiti ka evaṃ sati doṣaḥ /
column2: This point has been clarified.
Memory is generated after recognition.
In the absence of a soul, who remembers?
What do you understand by “to remember”?
To grasp an object by the memory.
Does “to grasp” differ from memory?
Memory is the agent of the action “to grasp.”
We have explained what is the agent of this action: it is the cause of memory, namely a certain type of mind.
But, if it is only a certain type of mind that is the cause of memory, how can one say that Caitra remembers? One gives the name Caitra to a series;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tato caitrākhyātsaṃtānāttāṃ bhavantīṃ dṛṣṭvocyate caitraḥ smaratīti /
column2: a mind of memory is generated, in this series, from a mind of seeing, and by reason of this fact one says that Caitra remembers.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asatyātmani kasyevaṃ smṛtiḥ / kiṃarthaiṣā ṣaṣṭhī / svāmyarthā /
column2: In the absence of a soul, whose is the memory?
What is the sense of the genitive "whose"? This genitive designates its master. Explain by an example how you understand that someone is the master of memory.
As Caitra is the master of the cow.
In what is Caitra the master of the cow?
In that he directs and employs the cow as he pleases.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kva ca punaḥ smṛtirviniyoktavyā va evaṃ tasyāḥ svāmī mṛgyate /
column2: To what then is the memory directed and employed by a master, for whom you search with great pains.
It is directed and employed on the object that one wants to remember (that is to say, it is employed on remembering).
To what purpose?
For the purpose of memory.
What idle talk!
I direct and employ a certain thing with a view to the same thing!
Explain to me then how memory is employed: do you want to say that one transmits it to a certain place?
Do you want to say that one causes it to be produced?
Memory does not die out; it is then not transmitted. One causes it to be produced.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: hetureva tarhi svāmī prāpnoti phalameva ca svam /
column2: What you call "master" is then simply the cause, and what you call "subject" is simply the result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yasmāddhetorādhipatyaṃ phale phalena ca tadvān heturiti /
column2: In fact theCause, by its command, operates the result; it is then "master'; and the result, in that it is subordinate to the cause at the moment of its arising, is called "subject. " Since the cause suffices as master, why require a self to which you could attribute memory?
Memory belongs to whatever causes memory.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaścāpi sa caitrābhidhānaḥ saṃskārasamūhasaṃtāna ekato gṛhītvā gavākhyasvāmītyucyate
column2: Complexes of saskāras, or the five skandhas forming a homogeneous series, are called "Caitra" and "cow.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa cāpi tasya deśāntaravikārotpattau kāraṇabhāvaṃ cetasi kṛtvā na tu khalu kaścidekaścaitro
column2:
One says that the Caitra-series possesses the cow-series, because the Caitra-series is the cause of the geographic displacement and the various changes of the cow-series.
nāmāsti na cāpi gauḥ /	There is not there any one, real entity Caitra," nor another entity called "cow;

there is not, for the Caitra-series, any quality of owner or master outside of its quality of cause.
evaṃ ko vijānāti kasya vijñānamityevamādiṣu vaktavyam / tasya heturindriyārthamanaskārā yathāyogamityeṣa viśeṣaḥ / yo 'pyāha bhāvasya bhavitrapekṣatvāt sarvo hi bhāvo bhavitāramapekṣate /	We would answer, mutatis mutandis, to the questions: Who knows? To whom do we attribute consciousness? " and to other similar questions, "What feels, what makes ideas? " as we have responded to the questions, "What remembers? To whom do we attribute consciousness? " and to other similar questions, "What feels, what makes ideas?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā devadatto gacchatītyatra gatirbhāvo gantāraṃ devadattamapekṣate /
column2:
Certain scholars say that the soul exists, as existence depends on an existing being, as the walking of Devadatta depends on Devadatta. Walking is an action, and Devadatta is the active being.
tathā vijñānaṃ bhāvaḥ / tasmādyo vijānāti tena bhavitavyamiti / sa vaktavyaḥ /	In the same way consciousness and all action depends on a base of support," "one who knows," the agent.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ko 'yaṃ devadatta iti / yadyātmā sa eva sādhyaḥ / atha vyavahārapuruṣaḥ / so 'pi na kaścidekaḥ saṃskārā hi ta evaṃnāmānaḥ /
column2: We would ask what it is that they understand by "Devadatta. " If they regard Devadatta as a real individual, we have discussed and refuted this theory. Devadatta is an imaginary individual and not an individual entity; Devadatta is only the name that one gives to the series of samskaras.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra yathā devadatto gacchati yathā vijānāti /
column2: In the sense that one could say that such a Devadatta walks, in the same sense we can say that Devadatta knows.

How does Devadatta walk? "Devadatta" is only a homogeneous series of samskaras, moments of existence replaced without interruption and roughly similar one to another. The foolish see within this series an entity which would be the cause of the action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kṣaṇikā hisaṃskārā abhinnasaṃtānā devadatta iti bālairekasattvapiṇḍagraheṇādhimuktāḥ svasya saṃtānasya deśāntare kāraṇaṃ bhavanta ucyante gacchati devadatta iti /
column2: In fact, the walking of Devadatta is simply the act of the generation of the series which is the body in different locations;
the cause of this action—that is to say, the previous moment of the series—receives the name of “walker.”

It is in this sense that we say that Devadatta walks, in order to designate a walk totally similar to that of fire or sound: the fire walks, the sound walks, that is to say, the fire-series and the sound-series go being generated from one place to another.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ta eva ca punarvijñānasya kāraṇaṃ bhavanta ucyante jānāti devadatta iti /
column2: In the same way the world says that Devadatta knows because the complex which is Devadatta is the cause of consciousness ;
and, in order to conform to received usage, the Āryans also express themselves in this manner, which is inexact.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattarhi “vijñānaṃ vijānātī“ti sūtra uktaṃ kiṃ tatra vijñānaṃ karoti / na kiñcitkaroti /
column2: Nevertheless, a Sūtra says that the consciousness knows the object. What does the véñāna do with regard to the object? It is simply produced resembling the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā tu kāryaṃ kāraṇamanuvidhīyata ityucyate / sādṛśyenātmalābhādakurvadapi kiñcit /
column2: In the same way that fruit, although it does nothing, is said to correspond to the seed, to reproduce the seed, because it is produced resembling the seed;
the vijñāna also, although it accomplishes no action with regard to the object, is said to know the object because it is produced resembling the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sādṛśyenātmalābhādakurvadapi kiñcit / kiṃ punarasya sādṛśyam / tadākāratā /
column2: This resemblance of the vijñāna consists in that it has the appearance of the object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ata eva tadindriyādapyutpannaṃ viṣayaṃ vijānātītyucyate nendriyam /
column2: By reason of this appearance one says that the vijñāna knows the object which is only one of its causes; the organ is also a cause of the vÉyñāna, but one does not say that the vjñāṇa knows the organ because the vijñāna does not take the aspect of the organ. This manner of speaking, “The vÉñāna knows,” is again justified from ánother point of view. Several successive moments of vôjñāna are produced with regard to the object: the previous moment is the cause of the later moment;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: athavā tathā 'trāpi vijñānasaṃtānasya vijñāne kāraṇabhāvādvijñānaṃ vijānātīti vacanānnirdoṣaṃ kāraṇe dartṛśabdanirdeśāt /
column2: the véñāna is then a cause of vijñāna; it is then called the agent since it is the.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ghaṇṭā rautīti yadvat / api khalu yathā pradīpo gacchati tathā vijñānaṃ vijānātīti / kathaṃ ca pradīpo gacchati /
column2: One attributes the action of knowing to it as one attributes the action of ringing to a bell or the action of moving to a lamp.

One says that the lamp moves: here is what the moving of the lamp consists of: “lamp” is the name metaphorically attributed to the uninterrupted series of moments of the flame that one sees, wrongly, as a “unity.”

When one of these successive moments is produced in place other than that of the preceeding moment, one says that the lamp moves. But there does not exist a “mover” apart from and distinct from the moment of the fire.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ vijñānamapi cittānāṃ saṃtāna upacaryate / tadviṣayāntareṣūtpadyamānaṃ taṃ viṣayaṃ vijānātītyucyate /
column2: In the same way, one metaphorically designates a series of minds by vśjñāna, or consciousness: when one moment of mind is produced relative to a new object, one says that the consciousness knows this object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā cābhijāyate tiṣṭhati rūpamityatra bhaviturbhāvādanarthantaratvamevaṃ vijñānasyāpi syāt /
column2: One says that the consciousness knows: the same way that one says that “physical matter” exists, is produced, lasts, without there being an “exister”, a “producer,” “anything that lasts,” distinct from what is called its existence, etc. If the later consciousness is produced from the previous consciousness and not from a soul, why is not the later consciousness always similar to the previous consciousness?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadi vijñānādvijñānamutpadyate nātmānaḥ kasmānna nityaṃ tādṛśamevotpadyate na ca kramaniyamenāṅkurakāṇḍapatradivat /
column2: Why do not consciousnesses succeed themselves in a determined order, as do shoots, stems, leaves, etc? Answer to the first question: Because everything that is produced through causes, i.
, conditioned things, presents the character of “transformation”;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: eṣa hi saṃskṛtasya svabhāvo yadavaśyaṃ prabandhasyānyathātvaṃ bhavati /
column2: this is the nature of conditioned things: in the series which they form, the latter should differ from the former.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anyathā hi nikāmadhyānasamāhitānāṃ sadṛśakāyacittotpattau prathamakṣaṇaniṃrviśeṣatvāt paścādapi na syāt svayaṃ vyutthānam /
column2: If it were otherwise, the ascetics who had entered into meditation—in which the body and the consciousness are always produced in the same way, the successive moments of the series being identical—would not spontaneously get out of meditation. As for the second difficulty: The production of consciousness is subject to a certain order.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kramo 'pi hi cittānāṃ niyata eva / yato nūtpattavyaṃ tata eva tasyotpādāt / tulyākāramapi hi kiñcidutpādane samarthaṃ bhavati / gotraviśeṣāt /
column2: If a certain mind should be produced after a certain mind, it will be produced after this mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yadyathā strīcittānantaraṃ yadi tatkāyavidūṣaṇācittamutpannaṃ bhavati tatpatiputrādicittaṃ
column2: For example, upon the idea of "woman" there immediately arises the idea of detesting the body of a woman, but there immediately arises the idea of a wife or daughter.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vā punaśca paścātsaṃtatipariṇatyā strīcittamutpadyate tat samartha bhavati tatkāyavidūṣaṇācittotpādane tatpatiputrādicittotpādane vā /
column2: Later, following upon the differing development of the succession of ideas, the idea of a woman reproduces itself. This second idea of a woman would have the capacity of producing the idea of detesting the body, or the idea of wife or daughter, accordingly as it has either of these ideas as gotra, that is to say, as a seed;
but not when it does not have a similar gotra.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha punaḥ paryāyeṇa strīcittādvahuvidhaṃ cittamutpannaṃ vahutara māsannataraṃ vā tadevotpadyate / tadbhāvanāyā valīyastvāt /
column2: And again innumerable different ideas can succeed the idea of a woman, and that by reason of multiple causes. Among all these ideas, those are produced first which are the most "numerous"—having formed a series in the past—the most "alive," the "nearest"—as these ideas have most strongly.
Except, of course, at the moment when other ideas are produced by a certain state of the body or by certain external objects.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saiva balīyasī bhāvanā kasmānnityaṃ na phalati /
column2: But why does the consciousness, which has most strongly impregnated the mental series, not continue to so impregnate it without ceasing?
Because, as we have said, transformation is a characteristic of the mental series; this characteristic is eminently propitious for the production of the result of ideas, having medium or small force.
Here we have, in an incomplete and summary manner, explained the causes and conditions of the order of the reciprocal generation of different categories of consciousness.
Complete knowledge of these causes belongs only to the Buddha.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ hyāhuḥ / sarvākārakāraṇamekasya mayūracandrakasyāpi / nāsarvajñairjñeyaṃ sarvajñabalaṃ hi tajjñānami“ti //
column2: Thus the stanza says, 'All the types of causes which go to produce a peacock feather—no one can know them except the Omniscient Ones: this is the power of knowledge of Omniscience (to know a thing completely).
The causes of the variety of material things areDifficult to know;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ya eva tvayamekīyastīrthika ātmaprabhavāṃ cittotpattiṃ manyate tasyaivedaṃ sphuṭaṃ codyamāpadyate kasmānna nityaṃ tādṛśamevotpadyate na ca kramaniyamenāṅkurakāṇḍapatrādivaditi
column2: how much more difficult is it to penetrate the variety of causes and conditions of non-material things, minds and mental states! A certain non-Buddhist believes that the consciousnesses are produced from a soul. One can successfully oppose his objections vainly formulated against us: Why isn't the latter consciousness the same as the former consciousness? Why aren't the consciousnesses produced in a fixed order?

This master explains the variety of consciousnesses and the absence of a fixed rule to their arising by the diversity that he terms “the conjunction of the soul with the anas or mental organ. ” This explanation does not hold. No type of conjunction is proved.
On the other hand, reasoning shows that two things in conjunction should be delimited, that is to say, localized in distinct places.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: saṃyoginostu paricchinnatvādaprāptipūrvikā prāptiḥ samyoga iti lakṣaṇavyākhyānāccātmānaḥ paricchedaprasaṅgaḥ /
column2: Judge if your definition of conjunction, “possession succeeding upon non-possession, admits of the same conclusion as our reasoning, namely that the soul is delimited, localized.

It also results from your definition of conjunction that, when the manas moves—it goes to such and such a part of the body—the soul should also move to make a place for it or that it should perish or eternal.
On the other hand, you cannot admit that the soul is in partial conjunction with the manas, for, according to you, the soul is an entity without parts.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasyaiva tatpradeśatvāyogāt / astu vā saṃyogastathāpi nityamaviśiṣṭe manasi kathaṃ saṃyogaviśeṣaḥ /
column2: Supposing also that there is conjunction between the permanent soul and an always immoveable manas, how does one explain the diversity of the conjunction necessary for the diversity of consciousness?
Would you say that this diversity results from the diversity of the buddhi, intelligence, which is a quality, guna, of the soul?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sa eva paricodyate kathaṃ buddhiviśeṣa iti / saṃskāraviśeṣāpekṣādātmamanaḥ saṃyogāditi cet /
column2: But the buddhi presents the same difficulty as the manas if the soul is not diversified, how would buddhi be diversified?

Would you say that the diversity of the buddhi results. From the diversity of conjunction of the soul and the meanas, a variety which results from the sa/skāras? In this hypothesis, the soul serves no purpose; why not say that the diversity of consciousnesses comes from the consciousness itself which is diversified by the saṁskéāras?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nahi kiñcidātmanaḥ upalabhyate sāmarthmauṣadha kāryasiddhāviva kuhakavaidyaphuḥsvāhānām /
column2: The soul does not intervene in the beginning of consciousness, and to say that consciousness comes from a soul is to be as the charlatan who, although drugs suffice for the healing of the sickness, pronounces some magic syllables: Phuṭ! You would say without doubt that consciousness, like the saṁskāras, exists through conjunction with the soul: but this is merely a statement without proof.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: satyātmani tayoḥ saṃyoga iti cet / vāṅmātram / āśrayaḥ sa iti cet / yathā kaḥ kasyāśrayaḥ /
column2: But you would insist, saying that the soul is its support : please explain by an example the nature of the relationship of the support and the supported. The consciousness and the saṁskāras themselves are not a picture or a fruit that the soul supports as a wall supports a picture or as a plate supports fruit: in fact, on thePhysical contact exists between the soul and thought-rzeṁskāras.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na hi te citravadarādivadādhārye nāpi sa kuḍacyakuṇḍādivadādhāro yuktaḥ / pratighātiyutadoṣāt naiva sa evamāśrayaḥ / kathaṃ tarhi /
column2: The picture and fruit exist independently of the wall and plate.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā gandhādīnāṃ pṛthivīti cet / atiparitoṣitāḥ smaḥ /
column2: The soul supports thought-raṁskāras like earth supports smell, color, taste, and touch.
This comparison establishes the non-existence of the soul. The thought-saṁskāras are what one designates by the word "soul".
The idea of "earth" cannot be obtained apart from smell, etc. Certain smells, etc. , are qualified as properties of earth to distinguish them.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ko hi sa gandhādibhyo 'nyāṃ pṛthivīṃ nirdhārayati / vyapadeśastu pṛthivyā gandhādaya iti viśeṣaṇārtham / te hyeva tadākhyā gandhādayo yathā pratīyerannānya iti /
column2: other words, one wants to indicate that certain smells, tastes, etc. , are what is termed “earth,” not other smells or tastes which are termed “water.
” In the same way, one designates a certain thing as being “the body of a wooden statue” indicating by that that it is of wood, and not of baked clay.
If the soul produces the consciousnesses by reason of the variety of the saṁskāras, why doesn’t it produce all the consciousnesses at the same time?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo hi baliṣṭhastenānyeṣāṃ prativandhaḥ / sa eva valiṣṭhaḥ kasmānnityaṃ na phalati / yo 'sya nyāyaḥ so 'stu bhāvanāyāḥ /
column2: Because the strongest rarṅskāra opposes the weakest seṁskāra in producing its result. And if the strongest saṁskāra does not constantly produce its result, it is for the same reason that you have given in explaining the traces abandoned by the consciousness in the series: we think that the saṁskāras are not permanent and are subject to change.

But then of what use is a soul? Diverse consciousnesses would be generated by the diverse force of the saeṁskāras, since there is no difference in nature between your sarskāras and our vāsanās. Memory, the saṁskāras, etc. , are things that are termed “attributes”;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: avaśyamātmābhyupagantavyaḥ / smṛtyādīnāṃ guṇapadārthatvāt tasya cārthādavaśyaṃ dravyāśritatvāt teṣāṃ cānyāśrayāyogāditi cet /  na /
column2: these attributes must of necessity have for their substratum, or support, a “substance” and, among the nine substances, the soul, since it is inadmissable that memory and the other mental qualities would have for their substratum any substance other than the soul, since the soul alone is intelligent.
But this system of substances and attributes is not proved.
We think that all that exists is “substance.”
A Sūtra says that “the result of the religious life consists of six substances.”
It is false that memory, etc. , has the soul as its substratum: as we have criticized the idea of a substratum.
If the soul does not really exist, what is the result of actions?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ahaṃ sukhī syāmahaṃ duḥkhī na syāmityevamarthaḥ /
column2: The result of actions is that the “soul’ experiences pleasure or pain.
What do you understand by “soul’’?
It is what one speaks of when one says “I,” the object of the idea of self, the skandhas or object.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kathaṃ jñāyate / teṣu snehāt / gaurādibuddhibhiḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyāttu /
column2: How do we know this? It is to the series of skandhas, that is, to the skanṉdhas—to oṉe’s body, to one’s sensations—-that one becomes attached;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: gauro 'hamahaṃ śyāmaḥ sthūlo 'hamahaṃ kṛśaḥ jīrṇo 'hamahaṃ yuveti gaurādibuddhibhiḥ sāmānādhikaraṇo 'yamahaṅkāro dṛśyate / na cātmana ete prakārā dṛśyante /
column2: as the idea of “I” is generated with reference to the idea of white and other similar ideas: in the world does one not say “I am white, black, old, young, thin, fat”? What one regards as white, etc,.

—evidently the skandha of physical mattero—is also what one regards as “L.” The “ṣoul” imagined by the Vaiśeṣika is different from white, etc. ; but, in fact, the idea of “I¹ is relative only to those skandhas and not to any “self” imagined. It is through metaphor that the world designates the body by the word “I” when it says, “I am white.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmana upakārake 'pi śarīra ātmopacāro yathā ya evāyaṃ sa evāhaṃ sa evāyaṃ me bṛtya iti bhavatyupakārake 'pi ātmopacāro natvahaṅkāraḥ /
column2: This metaphor is justified because the body is in the service of the true “L.” So be iti: one metaphorṟically calls what is used by the “I” by the name of “I.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: sati śarīrālambanatve paraśarīrālamvano 'pi kasmānna bhavati / asaṃvandhāt /
column2: But one cannot explain in this manner the consciousness that says “I”Because there is no relationship between the series of skandhas of others and this idea.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yenaiva hi sahāsya saṃvandhaḥ kāyena cittena vā yatraivāyamahaṅkāra utpadyate nānvatra /
column2: When the body or mind is in a relationship with the idea of “I"’—a cause and effect relationship—this idea is generated with regard to this body and this mind; but not with regard to the skandhas of others.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: anādau saṃsārra evamabhyāsāt / kaśca saṃbandhaḥ / kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ /
column2: The habit of considering “my” series as “I” exists in “my” series from the very beginning.
If there is no “soul,” to what do you attribute the idea of “I'?
We have answered this question when we explained what memory belongs to.
The master of memory is simply the cause of memory. It is the same for the idea of “I".
What is the cause of the idea of “I’?
It is a defiled mind, impregnated by this same idea of self, and having for its object the series of minds wherein it is produced.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asatyātmani ka eṣa sukhito duḥkhito vā /
column2: In the absence of a soul, who has suffering or pleasure?
The āśraya within which suffering or pleasure is.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā puṣpito vṛkṣaḥ phalitaṃ vanamiti / kaḥ punaranayorāśrayaḥ /
column2: Produced, in the same way that a tree is said to have flowers, a forest has fruit.
And the āfraya in question may belong to any of the six internal āyatanas, the eye-āyataṉa, etc. This has been explained.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asatyātmani ka eṣāṃ karmaṇāṃ kartā kaśca phalānāṃ bhoktā bhavati /
column2: In the absence of a soul, who is it that does a deed? Who is it that tastes the result?
What do you understand by ‘“he who does,” and `he who tastes¹’?
We understand this to be the agent, the taster. Your explanation is merely words and explains nothing. The Vaiśeṣikas here invoke the doctrine of the Grammarians.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhuṅkta iti bhoktā / paryāya ucyate nārthaḥ / “svatantraḥ karte“ti kartṛ lakṣaṇamācakṣate lākṣaṇikāḥ /
column2: They say that the agent is he who has independent power, that the taster is he who enjoys the result of the deed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: asti punaḥ kvacideva kārye kasyacit svātantryam /
column2: Iṅ the world he who possesses independent power with regard to a certain action is considered as the '“agent”ʼ;
for example, Devadatta, having the power to bathe himself, to seat himself, and to walk, is called “the bather,” “the sitter,” and “the walker.” This definition is not admissable.
What does one understand by “Devadatta”?
If one understands this to be a soul, the example is.
If one understands a certain coming together or complex of séandhas, then Devadatta is indeed an agent, but he is not ‘an independent agent and creator of deeds.”
Action is threefold ~body, speech, and mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra kāyakarmaṇi tāvat kāyasya cittaparatantrā vṛttiḥ /
column2: That which produces bodily action is the wind agitating the body;

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: cittasyāpi kāye svakāraṇaparatantrā vṛttistasyāpyevamiti nāsti kasyacit svātantryam /
column2: the body and the mind depend again on their causes and conditions; these causes and conditions depend in their turn on their causes and conditions: in all this there is not any simple entity, a “producer” dependent on itself or, in other words, independent.
For everything that exists depends on causes and conditions.
The soul as you understand it does not depend on causes and conditions; furthermore, it does nothing;
it is not then an independent agent. Nowhere does anyone maintain the existence of an agent conforming to your definition, “He who possesses independent power is termed an agent.”

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yattu yasya pradhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ tattsya kartetyucyate /
column2: That which one terms the agent of a certain action, is, amongst all its causes, that which is the principal. Memory causes a wish or a desire for action to surge up; from desire there proceeds imagination; from imagination there proceeds effort which gives rise to a vapor which sets in motion bodily action. In this process, what activity do the Vaiśeṣikas attrṛibute to a 'soul"?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca ātmanaḥ kvacidapi kāraṇatvaṃ dṛśyate /
column2: This soul is certainly not an agent of bodily action.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tasmātsa evamapi na kartā yujyate / smṛtijo hi cchandaḥ cchandajo vitarko vitarkātprayatnaḥ prayatnādvāyustataḥ karmeti kimatrātmā kurute /
column2: Vocal and mental action can be explained in the same way.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: phalasyāpica ka upabhogo yamayamātmā kurvannupabhoktā kalpyate / upalabhiriti cet /
column2: You say that the "soul" enjoys the result, because it discerns or knows the result: but soul has no role in discerning the result;
it does not figure among the causes that produce consciousnesses as we have shown above.
If there is no soul, why do good and bad deeds not die out in "non-living things"?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: vedanādyanāśrayatvāt tadāśrayaśca ṣaḍāyatanaṃ nātmā yathā tathoktam /
column2: Because the "non-assumed" elements, not constitutive of living beings, are not susceptible of serving as a support for sensation.
In the absence of a soul, how can past action, which is now destroyed, produce a future result?

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: ātmanyapi sati kathaṃ vinaṣṭāt karmaṇa āyatyāṃ phalotpattiḥ / tadāśritāddharmādharmāt /
column2: To this question we would answer now by asking how, even though a soul were to exist, destroyed action can have the force of producing the result.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā kaḥkimāśrita ityuktottaraiṣā vāco yuktiḥ / tasmādanāśritādeva dharmādharmāt bhavatu /
column2: The Vaiśeṣikas would have it that the result is generated from merit or from demerit, inherent attributes of the soul, supported by the soul: but we have criticized the idea of a substratum or “support” and shown that it is not rational.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: naiva tu vayaṃ vinaṣṭāt karmaṇa āyatyāṃ phalotpattiṃ brūmaḥ / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: According to the Buddhists, future results are not generated from destroyed action;
results are generated from the last moment in the evolution of a series that has its origin in action. How does fruit proceed from the seed?
One says, in the world, that fruit is generated from a seed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: na ca tadvinaṣṭādvījādutpadyate / nāpyanantarameva / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: But in speaking in this way, one does not intend to affirm that the fruit is generated from a destroyed seed, nor that the fruit arises immediately after the seed. In fact, the fruit is generated from the last moment in the evolution of a series that has its origin in the seed.
The seed successively produces a sprout, a stalk, a leaf, and finally the flower that brings the fruit into existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tat punaḥ puṣpānniṣpannaṃ kasmāttasya vījasya phalamityucyate /
column2: If one says that the seed produces the fruit, this is because the seed, through a series of intermediate stages, projects in the flower the efficacy of producing the fruit.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tadāhitaṃ hi tat parayāpuṣpe sāmarthyam / yadi hi tatpūrvikānnabhaviṣyat tattādṛśasya phalasyotopattau na samarthamabhaviṣyat /
column2: If the efficacy of producing the fruit, efficacy which is found in the flower, did not have the seed as its original cause, then the flower would not have produced a fruit resembling its seed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evaṃ karmaṇaḥ phalamutpadyata ityucyate / na ca tadviniṣṭātkarmaṇa utpadyate nāpyanantarameva / kiṃ tarhi /
column2: In the same way, one says that although a result is generated from an action, it is not generated from destroyed action, nor is it generated immediately after the action: it is generated from an ultimate moment in the evolution of a series issuing from the action. Series, or santana, means the material and mental rkandhas succeeding without interruption in a row which has an action for its original cause.
The successive moments of this row are.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: kā punaḥ saṃtatiḥ kaḥ pariṇāmaḥ ko viśeṣaḥ /
column2: There is then evolution, or transformation of the series.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yaḥ karmapūrva uttarottaracittapravasaḥ sā saṃtatistasyā anyathotpattiḥ pariṇāmaḥ / sa punartho 'ntaraṃ phalotpādanasamarthaḥ so 'ntapariṇāmaviśiṣṭatvāt pariṇamaviśeṣaḥ /
column2: The last moment of this evolution possesses a special efficacy, the capacity of immediately producing the result: it is distinguished, in this regard, from other moments; it is then termed vinesa, or the ultimate moment of evolution.
For example, when the mind at death is "associated with attachment," it possesses the capacity of producing a new existence.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: trividhakarmapūrvakatve 'pi yatkarma guru vā bhavatyāsannamabhyastaṃ vā yatkṛtaṃ sāmarthyaṃ dyotyate natvanyasya / āha ca “yat guru yaccāsannaṃ yaccābhyastaṃ kṛtaṃ ca yat /
column2: This mind has for its antecedents many actions of all types: nevertheless, it is the efficacy projected by a weighty action that informs the last thought; in the absence of heavy action, the efficacy is projected by near action; in its absence by habitual action;
and in its absence by the action of a previous life. There is a stanza which says, "Weighty action, near action, habitual action, old action: these four die in this order.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatra vipākahetvāhitaṃ tu vipākaphaladānasāmarthyaṃ vipākaṃ dattvā vinivartate /
column2: There is good reason to establish a distinction between a retributive result and an out-flowing result. When the force that produces a retributive result has given forth its result, this force is. But the force that produces an out-flowing result, a force projected by a ““cause similar to its effect” , does not perish by the production of its result;
when it is defiled, this force perishes by the force of its opposition;
when it is not defiled, it perishes through Nirvāṇa, which involves the abolition of the series, both physical matter and mind.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: atha kasmādvipākādvipākāntaraṃ notpadyate vījaphalādiva phalāntaram / na tāvat dṛṣṭāntena sarvaṃ samānaṃ bhavati /
column2: Why is a new retribution not generated from the retributive result as a new fruit is generated from the fruit of a tree, or as a fruit is also a seed? But a new fruit is not generated from the fruit seed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: tatrāpi tu na phalādeva punaḥ phalāntaramutpadyate / kiṃ tarhi / viklittiviśeṣajādvikāraviśeṣāt /
column2: From what is the new fruit generated, if not from the evolution of a new series? The first fruit seed, encountering the conditions necessary for evolution , finally produces the ultimate moment in the evolution—from whence the new fruit arises.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yo hi tatra bhūtaprakārāṅkuraṃ nirvartayati sa tasya vījaṃ nānyaḥ /
column2: When it produces the shoot, the old fruit takes the name of seed.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: bhāvinyā tu saṃjñāyā sādṛśyādvā pūrvako 'pi saṃtāno bījamityākhyāyate /
column2: If, before any evolution, , it is given the name of seed, it is an anticipative name, a name justified by the similarity of the ungerminated seed and the germinated.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: evamihāpi tasmādvipākādyadi sadasaddharmaśravaṇā dipratyayaviśeṣajaḥ kuśalasāsravo 'kuśalo vā cittavikāra utpadyate tasmātpunarvikārāntaramutpadyate nānyatheti samānametat /
column2: In the same way here when a retributive result encounters the conditions that produce good and bad—good teaching, bad teaching—it gives rise to minds that will be rewarded, namely bad or good-impure minds. From these minds there proceeds an evolution of their series that results in an ultimate state from whence a new retribution will emerge. This is not generated under any other conditions. The example then justifies our thesis.
One can also take into account the nature of the retribution by another example that shows that a new retribution does not necessarily succeed the first.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: yathā lākṣārasarañjitāt mātuluṅgapuṣpātsaṃtatipariṇāmaviśeṣajaḥ phale raktaḥ keśara upajāyate na ca tasmāt punaranyaḥ evaṃ karmajādvipākāt na punarvipākāntaramiti / yathāsthūlamidamasmadbuddhigamyaṃ darśitam /
column2: If one colors the flower of a lemon tree with milk, a certain evolution of the plant series will take place which will cause the seed of the new fruit to be red. But the red seed, once planted, will not generate another red seed. In the same way the retribution of an action does not produce a new retribution.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: nānāvidhaśaktibhinnaistu karmabhiradhivāsitāḥ saṃtataya etāmavasthāṃ gatā īdṛśaṃ phalamabhinivartayantīti buddhānāmeva viṣayaḥ / āha khalvapi “karma tadbhāvanāṃ tasyā vṛttilābhaṃ tataḥ phalam /
column2: I have, to the measure of my intelligence, taught in a summary and outline manner the result of actions.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: niyamena prajānāti buddhādanyio na sarvathā // ityetāṃ suvihitahetumārgaśuddhāṃ buddhānāṃ pravacanadharmatāṃ niśamya /
column2: Only the Buddhas know. There is a stanza, 'Action, the impression caused by the action, the active entry of this impression, the result that results from it—no one if not a Buddha, knows all this in the totality of its processes.

' Seeing then, by a path of demonstrative arguments, that the doctrine of the teaching of the Buddhas is perfect, and rejecting the opinion of those blind through bad views and through bad steps, the non-blind see.
In fact, this doctrine of the non-existence of the soul is the only road to the city of Nirvāṇa;

although illumined by the rays which are the words of this sun which is the Tathāgata, although followed by thousands of saints, and although it is without obstacles, it is not seen by persons of weak insight.
In this book one will find but a summary indication for the use of intelligent persons: but poison, once within a.

prathamaṃ kośasthānam oṃ namo buddhāya: braṇadeśoviṣasyeva svasāmarthyavisarpaṇa iti / pudgalakośamabhidharmakośabhāṣyaṃ samāptamiti / kṛtiriyamācāryavasubandhupādānāmiti // ye dharmahetuprabhavā hetuṃ teṣāṃ tathāgato hyavadat / teṣāṃ ca yo nirodha evaṃvādī mahāśramaṇaḥ // devadharmo 'yaṃ pravaramahāyāna sakalatathāgataśāsanadhūrddharasya uttarāpathikapaṇḍitasthaviraśrīlāmāvākasya yadatra puṇyamityādi /
